title: What Reagan Left Behind: More Than Some Jokes
description: The Reagan Presidency, still able to provoke arguments among politicians and historians, comes under scrutiny in ''The Reagan Legacy'' on ''Discovery Journal.'' Sunday's opening hour focuses on what has come to be known as Reaganomics; Monday brings back the Strategic Defense Initiative, a k a Star Wars. Both have figured in the Presidential campaign now reaching its climax or anticlimax, and both, by this incisive account, sprang full-blown from Mr. Reagan's philosophy and personality.

title: 4 Longhorns Ineligible
description: Texas declared the football players MIKE ADAMS, BRYANT WESTBROOK, TRE THOMAS and CHRIS CARTER ineligible yesterday after learning that an agent had paid for their lunch during a weekend meeting.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: For Children
description: Hoboken Firefighters Museum

title: The Spoken Word
description: POETRY READINGS, Barnes & Noble, 33 East 17th Street, Union Square. Featuring Ed Foster, Eileen Myles, Simon Pettet, Ed Roberson and Leonard Schwartz. Today at 1 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 253-0810.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 10
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Medeva Wins in Court Battle With Biogen
description: Medeva P.L.C. said today that it had won a final court victory in Britain against Biogen Inc. in a patent fight for rights to develop a hepatitis B vaccine.

title: Where Fact and Fiction Intertwine
description: THE year is 1938. Some farmers in work shirts, jackets and hats stand in a dark room looking down despondently at a table where a bureaucrat sits reviewing their papers. The last thought you would expect to have in front of this Depression-era photograph is the one that springs to mind: Is that Henry Fonda in the background?

title: CHRONICLE
description: Gilda's Club, a free meeting place in Manhattan for people with cancer and their families, is expanding its services to include a children's program called Noogieland. The official announcement is scheduled to be made today at the club, which is in SoHo. Since Gilda's Club opened last year, it has offered support services to children of families with cancer. The new program is designed to help children who have cancer.

title: Programs Are Expanded On Domestic Violence
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced an array of new programs to combat domestic violence yesterday, including the addition of shelter beds and the creation of a special telephone line to notify victims when an attacker is released from jail.

title: Toronto, but 50 Years Later
description: They will not have their starting point guard or power forward in uniform. Nonetheless, the Knicks open the 1996-97 season tonight against the Toronto Raptors in the Skydome as part of the National Basketball Association's 50th-anniversary celebration.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17

title: When Politics Has Become TV Clutter
description: TOO bad that a new Federal law does not require all television sets to be equipped with V-chips until 1998. New Yorkers could have used the technology this fall, not to keep pornography away from children, but to block those endless Senate campaign commercials from New Jersey, the ones with the two candidates casting each other as the most dreadful character since Vlad the Impaler.

title: RYDER GETS HELP IN EXAMINING UNIT'S FUTURE
description: Ryder System Inc. said yesterday that it had hired an unnamed adviser to help it explore options for its Ryder Automotive Carrier Services unit. The company, which is based in Miami, said it needed to restore the financial performance of the auto-hauling unit. Ryder agreed in September to sell its consumer truck-rental unit for $575 million, leaving the company to focus on its logistics and commercial truck leasing businesses. Last week, Ryder reported a 26 percent increase in net income for the third quarter. Ryder's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to close at $29.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Agreement on Hebron Should Be Honored
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: New England

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Global Trade, High Tech Lift Railroad 'Basket Case'
description: Derided as ''a basket of basket cases'' when the Government created it from the ruins of six bankrupt railroads two decades ago, today Conrail Inc. is a corporate jewel at the heart of the biggest railroad merger battle ever. Conrail has worked hard to modernize, but a visit to Port Elizabeth underscores that the railroad itself is only part of this Cinderella story.

title: F.B.I. Philosophy in Spotlight in Atlanta Case
description: To the Editor:

title: A Femme Fatale Who's a Little Loony
description: The modern movie femme fatale is a far cry from what she used to be. In today's post-Freudian era of talk-show catharses and 12-step panaceas, she has diminished from a mythic force of nature into a manipulative rageoholic whose destructive impulses come tidily wrapped in psychological jargon. Contemporary therapeutic parlance might describe her as someone traumatized by childhood sexual abuse, with serious ''boundary'' issues.

title: Keep in Mind
description: ANNUAL RADIO FESTIVAL, events for children include a ''recreating radio'' workshop in which participants will use scripts and authentic sound effects to produce old-time radio stories; a live broadcast (with music and a performance) of ''The Radio Thrift Shop'' to feature Laura Cantrell of WFMU-FM in East Orange, N.J., and a chance to meet Florence Barrau and David Rafael Gonzalez, the hosts of the ''New York Kids'' program on WNYC-FM. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52d Street, Manhattan. Suggested admission: $6; ''recreating radio'' workshops (at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. tomorrow, and at 2 P.M. on Sunday) are $5 and require reservations; museum admission is not required. Admission to the live broadcast, tomorrow from noon to 3 P.M., is included in museum admission: $6; $4 for students and the elderly; $3 for children under 13. Reservations: (212) 621-6600.

title: Maybe It's Not a Gene Behind a Person's Thrill-Seeking Ways
description: For those hard-nosed people who were skeptical of a widely heralded finding earlier this year that linked a single gene to a personality trait called novelty-seeking, a group of scientists now says, ''You had reason to be.''

title: No Headline
description: ''War is very hard for our bodies but what is to come will be much harder for our souls.''

title: Marcel Carne, Film Director, Dies at 90
description: Marcel Carne, the French movie director whose 1945 classic, ''Les Enfants du Paradis,'' became one of the most loved and admired films of all time, died today at a hospital in the Paris suburb of Clamart. He was 90.

title: Pay-Per-Round Idea for Tyson-Holyfield Fight Stirs Controversy
description: Mike Tyson dispatches his opponents so quickly that one of the country's major cable operators has offered an unusual discount to pay-per-view fight fans who have cried foul after shelling out $39.95 or more.

title: Isles Fans Have Little to Cheer About
description: The boos for Kirk Muller died down with each successive period tonight. Of course, there were not that many people left to boo -- from the not-too-many people to start with -- at Nassau Coliseum.

title: A Resigned Mellencamp
description: Old songs got a new beat when John Mellencamp performed at Irving Plaza on Wednesday night in one of only two public concerts scheduled since the release of his current album, ''Mr. Happy-Go-Lucky'' (Mercury). On that album, which has reversed Mr. Mellencamp's slide in popularity, he enlisted Junior Vasquez, a disk jockey and dance-music producer, to modernize the music from the bottom up. Although Mr. Mellencamp performed only two new songs, ''Key West Intermezzo'' and ''Just Another Day,'' there were revamped rhythms and percussion breaks throughout the set.

title: $25 and Under
description: I first noticed Tomoe Sushi about a year ago on my way to the restaurant next door. To get into my restaurant, I had to step around the line of people waiting to get into Tomoe (pronounced tuh-MOH-ay). My meal turned out to be completely forgettable. But I couldn't forget the eager people waiting to get into Tomoe and decided to check it out eventually.

title: A Rape Charge Unsettles West Point Pride
description: The hard-eyed, rigid-jawed cadets at the United States Military Academy here walked stiffly today amid a palpable chill that could be attributed only in part to autumn.

title: BOOM IN PROFITS FOR CORPORATIONS NOW APPEARS OVER
description: The great boom in corporate earnings, which helped propel the market and buoyed the economy for more than four years, seems to be over. What analysts are arguing over now is how much more slowly earnings will grow.

title: Net Income Unchanged At Pharmacia & Upjohn
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter net income before charges was unchanged from last year, in line with a profit forecast the company made three weeks ago. The company, a Swedish-American drug maker, said net income before one-time items was $231 million, compared with $232 million a year ago. Operating profit dropped 9 percent, to $285 million from $313 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Japan Premier Did Too Well in Election to Form Solid Coalition
description: Despite a resounding victory for his party in national elections, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is having difficulty forming a new governing coalition, raising the likelihood that Japan's next government will be fragile and indecisive.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Anne Frank Remembered

title: Plays of the Day, All Day, Every Day
description: Keith Olbermann, the ESPN ''SportsCenter'' anchor, was present at the creation of ESPN2 in 1993, which he began by telling viewers, ''Welcome to the end of our careers.''

title: Watson Does Not Sound Like a Man on the Move
description: Bob Watson is still the general manager of the World Series champion Yankees, he is still helping them make critical decisions on players and he has no meetings scheduled with George Steinbrenner to discuss his future. Not only that, but Watson is continuing to sound more like an executive who will honor his contract in 1997.

title: Whitman Suffering From Herniated Disk
description: The severe back pain that has kept Gov. Christine Todd Whitman at home all week is caused by a herniated disk in the lumbar, or lower, part of her spine, her office said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Profit Boom for Companies Appears to Be Over

title: A Rebellion From Below
description: The Finnish Chamber Orchestra, an ensemble of young musicians who also play in Helsinki's larger orchestras, produced a vibrant, cohesive sound on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, but it was another quality -- a peculiar approach to the balancing of lines and the blending of timbres -- that caught the attention most consistently.

title: Bank of France Cuts Intervention Rate
description: The Bank of France said yesterday that it was trimming its official intervention rate in what economists read as another cautious step that leaves room for further monetary easing.

title: Lowest Rate Since April On Long Bond
description: The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell yesterday to its lowest level since April 1 after fresh data suggested that the economy was continuing to slow, with no sign of inflation.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Searching Endless Landscapes for the Real Corot
description: ''MORNING AT VILLE-D'AVRAY,'' in the exhibition of Corot's paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a big silvery pastorale: a figure and two cows standing in a vaporous glade under a brightening, mother-of-pearl sky. If you want to understand what Corot's contemporaries saw in him, this work from 1868, when he was 72, is a place to start, a misty reverie, mostly gray-on-gray, with a few slender tree trunks picked out against the soft receding masses of branch and leaf.

title: HUNTSMAN BUYING AMOCO'S POLYSTYRENE BUSINESS
description: The Huntsman Chemical Corporation, based in Salt Lake City, said yesterday that it would buy the polystyrene business of the Amoco Corporation's chemical unit for an undisclosed price. The acquisition will include manufacturing plants in Joliet and Willow Springs, Ill., with a combined annual capacity of 330 million pounds of polystyrene. Amoco's polystyrene business had 1995 revenue of $120 million. Polystyrene is primarily used in packaging, consumer products and construction. Huntsman said it expected to retain all the Amoco workers. The Amoco purchase will bring Huntsman's annual United States polystyrene production to 1.5 billion pounds.

title: Art in Review
description: Chuck Close

title: Block Island's Top Official Is Accused of Rape
description: Less than 48 hours after the town's leading politician and two other men were charged with raping a waitress here, the protests began. Beneath the word ''stop'' on each of the four stop signs at the town's major intersection, someone had plastered a sticker with the word ''rape.'' Within hours, the stickers themselves were removed.

title: Just a Guy and His Elephant
description: How could a comedy based on the tantalizingly funny notion of Bill Murray transporting a circus elephant across America misfire as badly as ''Larger Than Life''? The very idea conjures up visions of classic sight gags in which man and beast fail to communicate, or worse, fail to get along. Think of elegant circus tricks executed in the wrong place at precisely the wrong time. Think of an elephantine stubbornness that makes the most recalcitrant donkey look like an obedient eager beaver. Think of a rampage in a supermarket or a spontaneous grand entrance at a chi-chi social event, and you can begin to see the possibilities.

title: Magazine Settles Libel Suit by Scientologist
description: Time magazine has agreed to settle a lawsuit brought by a member of the Church of Scientology who contended that the magazine libeled him in a 1991 article about the church.

title: The Third Wave
description: In the decade since World War II, Republican candidates have used scare tactics effectively on two issues, Communism and crime. They persuaded significant numbers of voters that Democrats were ''soft on Communism'' and, later, ''soft on crime.''

title: A Westchester Judge Doubles As an Ambulance Corps Volunteer
description: The call crackled over the voice pager at about 8 P.M. on Sept. 11: ''Two down, GSW!'' George Washington Bridge? The ambulance corps volunteer, accustomed to treating the bee stings and broken legs of suburban Chappaqua, N.Y., was puzzled. Then he raced out of his well-appointed home, suddenly realizing: gunshot wound.

title: A Run for the Money Over Uneven Course
description: In August, the distance runner Joe LeMay of Danbury, Conn., placed 14th at the Falmouth Road Race in Massachusetts, a 7.1-mile event on Cape Cod that draws a world-class field. LeMay, who had placed second in the United States Olympic Trials 10,000 meters earlier this year, was more than a minute off the winning pace. The 13 men ahead of him were all from Africa. Ten of them were Kenyans.

title: Cigar's Career Is Ended By 'Grateful' Paulsons
description: Any lingering doubts about Cigar's racing career were ended yesterday when his owners confirmed that the 6-year-old bay horse who had captivated the public for two years would race no more.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Hint of Martian Life

title: CHRONICLE
description: First it was films, then it was wines and now it is a magazine. In January, FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA will publish a New York-based fiction magazine called Zoetrope: Short Stories, said ADRIENNE BRODEUR, its editor. Mr. Coppola wants to supplement the dwindling market of short fiction, she added.

title: GENERAL MAGIC HAS ANOTHER LOSS AND LAYS OFF 80
description: General Magic Inc. has posted its 11th straight quarterly loss and dismissed 29 percent of its workers. The software maker said late Wednesday that it had discharged about 80 of its 280 employees. It will take a fourth-quarter charge of $2 million to $4 million to cover the dismissals. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said its third-quarter loss widened to $12.4 million, or 48 cents a share, from $5.1 million, or 20 cents, in the 1995 period. General Magic writes programs that look for information or perform tasks automatically for computer users. Founded in 1990 by former top engineers from Apple Computer Inc., the company has never had a quarterly profit. Its shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to close at $3, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Executive Promoted At Food Court
description: The Food Court Entertainment Network said yesterday that it had promoted James N. Perkins to president and chief executive from chief operating officer. Mr. Perkins, 63, succeeds Stephen G. Bowen, 52, who resigned to return to advertising.

title: Clinton Goes One-on-One
description: As President Clinton worked the crowd at a sun-splashed rally at Arizona State University in Tempe this morning, the shrill squeals of a single delighted teen-ager pierced the tumult of one corner of a crowd that stretched to perhaps 20,000 people under the palms.

title: Morrison Foe Charged
description: Instead of preparing to face the heavyweight TOMMY MORRISON, ANTHONY COOKS found himself facing a judge yesterday on a charge of second-degree rape.

title: As Usual, Most Incumbents in Albany Have Little to Fear
description: In a year when battles are raging across the country for control of Congress and nearly a dozen state legislatures, political scientists and strategists in both major parties predict that there will be only marginal changes in the New York Legislature.

title: We Need to Track the Maps of Aggression
description: To the Editor:

title: Lowe Direct files a lawsuit against five executives who defected from the agency two weeks ago.
description: LOWE DIRECT, the direct marketing division of Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, struck back yesterday at five executives who abruptly left in a mass defection two weeks ago and formed their own breakaway shop.

title: Archer Daniels Promotes Two High-Level Executives
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company has created a four-person ''office of the chief executive,'' promoting two insiders who might succeed the longtime chief executive, Dwayne O. Andreas, the company said yesterday.

title: Togetherness Replaces Toughness
description: The phone in Jeff Van Gundy's office at SUNY-Purchase was ringing steadily on Tuesday morning. The day after his final preseason game, the Knicks' coach had maybe 10 people whose basketball knowledge he respects call to tell him his team had a problem.

title: Between a Rock And a Soft Place
description: Two forces are always at work in fashion: innocence and its brazen opposite. But what is amazing about Miuccia Prada and Anna Sui, fashion's most conniving designing women, is how they manage always to work both notions into their shows. All the touchstones of virginity and innocence are there: the crisp white linen and floral prints of Ms. Prada's Miu Miu; the butterflies, chiffons and laces of Anna Sui.

title: Torricelli's New Ad Cites Endorsements and Ignores Opponent
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate in New Jersey, began broadcasting this 30-second commercial yesterday. Mr. Torricelli's Republican opponent is Representative Richard A. Zimmer.

title: Ohio, Which Picks Winners, Likes Clinton
description: As goes Ohio, so goes the nation. Well, not exactly, but close enough, at least in Presidential years.

title: Telling All on John Huang
description: It has been hard for voters and reporters to get a straight answer about what John Huang, the mysterious Democratic fund-raiser who allegedly solicited money from foreign sources, did and when he did it.

title: J. Edward Day, 82, Postmaster Who Brought In the ZIP Code
description: J. Edward Day, the wisecracking Cabinet officer who gave the nation a million laughs and the five-digit ZIP code as Postmaster General for three ebullient years, died on Tuesday in Hunt Valley, Md. He was 82 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md., 20815, as it has been known since Mr. Day inaugurated the ZIP code system on July 1, 1963.

title: Battle of the Princetons
description: For weeks, local residents have been arguing over the question on Tuesday's ballot that asks whether Princeton borough should be merged with the surrounding Princeton township. Now it seems that the issue may be decided by Princeton University students. About 1,000 of the university's students are registered in Princeton, mostly in the borough, where voters have periodically rejected consolidation since 1952. To pass, the measure needs to carry both the borough, which has 6,060 registered voters, and the township, which has 9,188 voters.

title: Perot, on the Stump, Goes on the Attack
description: As the 1996 campaign draws to a close, the nation is seeing another side of Ross Perot.

title: Stakis to Buy Hotels From Lonrho
description: Stakis P.L.C. said yesterday that it was buying five luxury Metropole hotels from the British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. for $:327 million ($530.4 million) and was setting a rights issue to help finance the deal.

title: Irate but Ambivalent in Rural California
description: If you flew over the vast farm land of the San Joaquin Valley, you would see an endless patchwork quilt of emerald green orchards, muddied wheat fields awaiting the next seeding and acres of fluffy cotton tufts not yet picked. And in a corner of the Kahl family's almond orchard, you would see an unusual item sprouting in this fertile valley -- a blue Dole/Kemp billboard.

title: Kevorkian Indicted on Charges of Helping in Three Suicides
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who has been repeatedly tried and acquitted for assisting in suicides, was charged today with helping three women die over the summer.

title: Cinar to Buy Film Library
description: Cinar Films Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Filmfair Ltd.'s library and animation unit from the Caspian Group of Britain for $:10.5 million ($17.14 million) in cash and stock. Cinar, based in Montreal, specializes in television programming for children. The acquisition includes more than 100 hours of animated children's literary properties, including Paddington Bear and the Wombles. Cinar's stock rose $2 a share, to $24.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: William Rosenwald Dies; Benefactor to Many Was 93
description: William Rosenwald, who gave and raised millions of dollars in a life dominated by philanthropy that saved tens of thousands of lives and bettered countless others through education and the arts, died yesterday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 93.

title: The Wrong Indonesian
description: I don't know what made Cicih Sukaesih, an Indonesian factory worker, think the Clinton Administration would want to hear from her. She must have been dreaming. Her fellow Indonesians James and Mochtar Riady could have told her the score. Access costs money. You need really big bucks to guarantee that you'll get a hearing in Washington, and Cicih (pronounced CHEE-chee) had no money at all.

title: Nation's Newspapers Report Mixed Results on Circulation
description: The country's two big national newspapers, The Wall Street Journal and USA Today, have continued to build their circulation leads over metropolitan dailies, whose own figures generally showed growth in suburban and Sun Belt markets and stagnation elsewhere, according to nationwide figures released yesterday.

title: Homage to a Slave Sanctuary
description: The site where runaway slaves are believed to have found a haven will be dedicated as a historical monument at a ceremony today. Now a vacant lot, the site was once occupied by a store owned by Josiah P. Huntoon, an abolitionist who local historians say operated a station of the Underground Railroad.

title: Abductions Rock Mexico, Scaring Not Just the Rich
description: Soon after Francisco Resendiz reported the abduction of his teen-age son to the authorities last year, he felt the same sinking feeling shared by hundreds of other Mexicans whose loved ones have been kidnapped: the police working on the case, he suspected, were collaborating with the abductors.

title: Inside Art
description: With Picasso, More Is More

title: Those 'Objective' Tests Still Benefit the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: When Donors Hesitate, the Republicans Have Ways of Not Taking 'No' for an Answer
description: It is common practice for political parties to solicit contributions from supporters over the telephone by invoking the names of party luminaries.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Moll Flanders

title: Judge Blocks Drug Evidence In Trial of 1986 Rape Case
description: The defense rested in the Alex Kelly rape case today without putting Mr. Kelly on the stand after the judge blocked a defense effort to introduce evidence suggesting that his 16-year-old accuser might have used cocaine and marijuana on the day of the events a decade ago.

title: With Insurers' Payment, Exxon Says Valdez Case Is Ended
description: Seven years after the Exxon Valdez supertanker ran aground off Alaska, spilling oil in one of the worst environmental disasters ever, the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was closing the books on attempts to recover its costs from scores of insurance companies, with a final settlement installment of $480 million.

title: In New Jersey, Meeting the Voters Is a Luxury
description: If the New Jersey Senate race is any guide, mingling with the public is no longer a prerequisite for office.

title: Arthur F. Quern, 54, Head Of Illinois Education Agency
description: Arthur F. Quern, chairman of the Illinois Board of Higher Education and a former aide to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and President Gerald R. Ford, died on Wednesday in the crash of a corporate jet that was taking off from an airfield north of Chicago. Three others, all crew members, also died.

title: Molson and Coors Reach Pact on Licensing
description: Molson Breweries said today that it had reached an interim agreement with the Coors Brewing Company the production and sale of Coors products in Canada.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN AGREES TO BUY BAY MEADOWS
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the California Jockey Club and the Bay Meadows Operating Company for about $195 million in cash or stock. The transaction will give Patriot American control of the Bay Meadows horse track in San Mateo, Calif., as well as an unusual corporate structure that will allow it to shelter earnings from corporate income taxes while operating the horse track and hotel properties. Shares in Patriot American, a real estate investment trust based in Dallas, rose 87.5 cents, to close at $35.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Bay Meadows' stock jumped $8.375, to $33.25, on the American Stock Exchange. Shares in Bay Meadows and California Jockey are traded as a single unit. Patriot American will pay $33 in cash, or 0.9365 of a Patriot share.

title: Old Oceanside Spa to Be Razed for Town Houses
description: For nearly a decade, a five-story building has sat empty on a bluff here overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. But by the end of the year, work is expected to begin on a $10 million luxury town house complex to replace it.

title: Hingis Qualifies
description: Sixteen-year-old MARTINA HINGIS is the eighth player to qualify for the Chase Championships, the WTA Tour finale, to be played in Madison Square Garden Nov. 18-24. (AP)

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Talk-Show Host, Testifying at Murder Trial, Plays Down Her Role in Program
description: Jenny Jones, the talk-show host, testified yesterday in the murder trial of a onetime guest on her show, saying that she had almost no involvement in the planning of the show, considered the topic, ''same-sex crushes,'' to be ''light hearted'' and ''fun,'' and did not believe that the episode deserved to be a called ''ambush television.''

title: Undertow for the G.O.P.
description: Just as California's Proposition 13 in 1978 ushered in the anti-tax wave Republicans have ridden to this day, the state's backlash against immigration and affirmative action was supposed to energize enough ''angry white men'' to bury Democrats for a decade. But these so-called wedge issues are not helping Republican Congressional candidates here. In fact, they're laying the groundwork for erosion of the Republican base in the nation's pivotal electoral state.

title: Change the Drug Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPBELL HEIR SELLS NINE MILLION SHARES
description: John Dorrance 3d, the grandson of the founder of the Campbell Soup Company, sold nine million shares of Campbell stock yesterday for $720 million on the New York Stock Exchange. Officials said that in dollars, it was the seventh-biggest block trade in the history of the exchange. Mr. Dorrance has been selling blocks of Campbell stock in recent months, apparently intending to cash in on the strength of the shares. Campbell, based in Camden, N.J., announced a major reorganization and stock buyback program on Sept. 5. The trade, almost 4 percent of Campbell's 247 million shares outstanding, was not part of the share buyback plan. The stock closed at $80, down $3 a share, and its volume of 10.6 million shares was the largest of the day on the Big Board.

title: Giants Look to the East For a Rise in Standings
description: If the Giants are to have any chance of making the playoffs, it starts on Sunday against visiting Arizona. Lose here, and the team's overall record falls to 3-6. The more important numbers for the Giants, however, have to do with the division. The Giants are looking for their first National Football Conference East victory this year. They are off to an 0-4 start in the N.F.C. East for the first time since 1979.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Lot of Help From a Friend

title: Queens Man Is Held In Counterfeiting
description: A Queens man was arrested in New Jersey on charges that he tried to sell $5 million worth of counterfeit bills, officials said yesterday. Investigators also recovered $2 million in counterfeit money from his home.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Spy Hard

title: What Stalin Knew
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Board and S.E.C. may clash over circuit breakers
description: IT looks as if the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission may be headed for a showdown on whether to update circuit breakers, the rules that would halt trading temporarily if the stock market plunged.

title: BAHRAIN INVESTMENT COMPANY ACQUIRES CARTER
description: Investcorp International, an investment group based in Bahrain, said yesterday that it had bought the closely held William Carter Company, a maker of baby and children's apparel products. The purchase price was not disclosed. Carter, based in Morrow, Ga., had 1995 sales of $295 million. The company employs 6,500 people. Carter sells its products under the names Carter's, Carter's Classic and Baby Dior. The investment bank is known for reviving such upscale retailers as Gucci Group, Saks Holdings Inc. and Tiffany & Company.

title: Refugees Flee Camps as Rebel Forces Drive Zairian Troops Back
description: Tens of thousands of refugees fled into the bush today and aid agencies prepared to evacuate workers as Tutsi rebels closed in on Goma, Zaire, battling Zairian troops for control of the airport, United Nations officials said.

title: Showing Off Players (and Saving Cash)
description: Parnassus, the respected contemporary music ensemble, began its 23d season at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night. And it was the first concert in all those years that Anthony Korf, the artistic director, did not conduct. In a rare departure, the concert was presented by just three of the ensemble's 15 players: the clarinetist Alan R. Kay, the violinist Cyrus Stevens and the pianist James Winn.

title: Art in Review
description: Pieter Laurens Mol

title: Restaurants
description: On Saturday night, when restaurants all over New York City were cursing the Yankees, Maloney & Porcelli was full.

title: RENO MAKES MOVE TOWARD AN INQUIRY INTO FUND RAISING
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that the Justice Department had taken the first step toward deciding whether to seek an independent counsel to investigate possible wrongdoing by Democratic fund-raisers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Ammirati Secures Labatt Business
description: Labatt USA said yesterday that it had consolidated its account, with billings estimated at $7 million to $10 million, at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York.

title: FOOD LION AGREES TO BUY KASH N' KARRY
description: Food Lion Inc., the eighth-largest United States supermarket chain, said yesterday that it would acquire Kash n' Karry Food Stores Inc. for $26 a share, or $121.5 million, in cash. It will also refinance $221 million of long-term debt. Kash n' Karry, with 100 supermarkets and about 35 liquor stores, emerged from bankruptcy proceedings last year. Food Lion, based in Salisbury, N.C., operates 1,100 stores in 14 Southeastern states. A Belgian grocery company, Delhaize-Le Lion S.A., owns about half its voting stock. Trading in Kash n' Karry stock was halted pending the news; it last traded at $24 a share, up 25 cents. Food Lion plans to invest as much as $150 million to remodel Kash n' Karry stores in four years after the purchase is completed.

title: ALLEGHENY POWER BUYS HALF-INTEREST IN GENERATOR
description: Allegheny Power System Inc., based in Hagerstown, Md., said yesterday it bought a 50 percent interest in an electric generator from the Duquesne Light Company for $170 million. Allegheny Power said the 276-megawatt generator was at the Fort Martin Power Station near Morgantown, W. Va. Allegheny's AYP Energy unit will sell the energy to power marketers, municipal electric systems and other utilities. AYP Energy said it had commitments for December power sales, and that contracts were being written for 1997. Duquesne Light is a unit of DQE Inc., an energy company based in Pittsburgh.

title: People
description: * Deborah Fine was named publisher at Bride's magazine, New York, part of the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications, succeeding Roger Antin, who resigned. Ms. Fine had been associate publisher at Glamour magazine, New York, also published by Conde Nast.

title: Plan to Return Parole Officer
description: An administrative law judge has recommended reinstating a veteran parole officer who was dismissed last year after an Atlantic City parolee went on a murderous rampage. Judge Robert W. Scott acknowledged that the parole officer, John Goodman, showed poor judgment in his handling of Darnell Collins, who killed seven people before being slain by police, and should not receive back pay.

title: Art in Review
description: Eric Fischl

title: For Dole, Plenty of Movement but Momentum Remains Elusive
description: As with families, so, it seems, with campaigns.

title: Stocks Climb in Tokyo
description: Stocks rose here today after two days of declines. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 166.20 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,633.06. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 214.81 points, or 1.04 percent, to 20,466.86.

title: Shell Reports Drop in Profits
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that its third-quarter operating profit fell as weak refining margins and a collapse in chemical earnings offset the highest oil prices since the Persian Gulf war.

title: Ameritech Expands Agency Roster
description: The Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that it had further expanded its agency roster by naming Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York to handle the creative portion of its cellular and paging account, which had been handled for three years by DDB Needham Chicago. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $20 million; spending last year was $50 million, according to Competitive Media Reporting.

title: Ward's Bid For Title Ended by Frenchman
description: Most horses and riders are sensible enough to be aghast at the prospect of tackling the Puissance wall, the mushrooming seven-foot monster that demands a talent most famously displayed by Superman: the ability to leap tall buildings in a single bound.

title: Two Vanishing Breeds
description: There is a vanishing breed of women -- designers call them their ladies -- who have wealthy husbands or high-profile jobs and dress in a certain way. Their clothes are expensive and tasteful but change little with the years, much like their hairdos. Fortunately for them, there is a vanishing breed of designer who understands their needs, who can supply them with the kind of clothing they've always worn while occasionally sneaking in a trendy new look by taking the edge off it.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Stealing Beauty

title: Smoltz Ready to Cash In On Free Agent Riches
description: John Smoltz, the Atlanta pitcher who led the major leagues with 24 victories this season and added four in the post-season, embarked yesterday on a course that could make him the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history.

title: Excesses of '96 Race Make Finance Reform a Top Issue
description: For most of the election season, President Clinton and Bob Dole seemed to be honoring a kind of gentlemen's agreement that the less said about changing the campaign finance system, the better.

title: Boy Hit by Stray Gunfire After Egg Fight
description: Halloween turned into a true-life horror story for a 10-year-old boy in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn last night when he was hit by a stray bullet fired during an egg fight that escalated into a gunfight, the police said.

title: Cuba Makes a Strict Move In Order to Deter Defections
description: By suspending for life three of its top baseball players because of their relationship with a Cuban-American sports agent, the Cuban Government has sent a clear signal that it is determined to prevent its star athletes from defecting.

title: Glitter and Flash From the Provinces
description: The Zhongmei Dance Company has a wealth of source material to drawn upon, but doesn't quite know what to do with its treasures. The Chinese group, made up of graduates of the Beijing Dance Academy, offered ''Silk River,'' a survey of dances from the Chinese provinces, on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Calipari Hardly Expects to Be Conquering Hero
description: It's a tough request. John Calipari is asking everyone for something he is not willing to adopt as a character trait for himself: patience.

title: Furor Over 'Ethnic' Ad
description: What does it mean when a campaign advertisement touts a candidate's ethnic heritage and then urges voters to cast their ballot for ''one of us?'' Opponents of Kathleen A. Donovan, the Republican seeking to replace Representative Robert G. Torricelli, are upset about an ad running in the weekly Kearny Observer that exhorts voters to ''Vote Irish-Italian-German Pride'' and proclaims: ''Kathleen Donovan: She's One of Us!''

title: U.S. vs. China in Bridge Play
description: The United States women's bridge team began play against China in the final of the World Team Championship here this afternoon and trailed after the first 16 deals.

title: A Nonstop G.O.P. Tour
description: Looking for a last-minute flourish with which to conclude his bid for the White House, Bob Dole announced today that he would embark on a 96-hour, nonstop campaign marathon of airplanes and buses that would take him from Ohio to California and back to Russell, Kan., to vote at his local schoolhouse.

title: Nightmare Journey Through Manhattan
description: An arrogant man of wealth and stature is humbled in ''Mercy,'' but when this tale of careless pride comes to an end, the suspicion lingers that before long he will return to his old ways and only the audience will feel as if it has taken a senseless battering.

title: Remembering a Sculptor Who Became the Landscape
description: Since her death in 1975, Barbara Hepworth, once a name to conjure with, has not had much currency in the art world. (She is trumpeted in the catalogue for the current show at Wildenstein & Company as ''the first great female sculptor in the history of Western art.'') We hardly remember, it seems, that with Henry Moore she was a prime mover in bringing modernism to English sculpture, and that in Manhattan she was author of the simple bronze monument on United Nations Plaza to Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General from 1953 to 1961.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: On Crime and Conscience Among Brothers
description: There are moments in Abel Ferrara's hot-blooded, broodingly well-acted new gangster film that can be explained in only one way: Abel Ferrara. A fascinating maverick and a fearless one, Mr. Ferrara never fails to put his subversive stamp on even the most familiar-sounding material. A case in point is ''The Funeral,'' which unfolds squarely in well-trodden ''Godfather'' territory. Set in the 1930's, it considers guilt, religion, capitalism and the myth-making power of American movies while describing three brothers and their father's legacy of gangland crime.

title: Palettes Full of Ideas About What Painting Should Be
description: NEW YORK CITY has many things in quantity, and one is surely painting. Moving through its many museums and galleries, you can encounter works by masters long dead and living. You can see brand new works by young unknowns and those of painters who have toiled for years in relative obscurity. They all conspire to make New York one of the world's great centers of painting, and of the debate about painting. For every painting is, among other things, an argument about what painting should be.

title: Rummaging in the Mind Of a Genius Growing Up
description: HENRY JAMES

title: Devils' Frightful Night Is Also Fight Filled
description: The Devils, sporting a 4-5-1 record after the first month of the National Hockey League season, are in a fighting mood. Heading into the three games on last night's N.H.L. schedule, the Devils were atop the league's 26 teams in average penalty minutes with 28.8 a game.

title: Four Are Hospitalized After Drinking Brew for Bodybuilding
description: Using a recipe from an underground pamphlet on steroids for bodybuilders, four young Long Island men cooked up a caustic potion and drank it, hoping for a chemical high and bigger muscles.

title: Blacks' Discontent May Doom Louisiana Democrat Who Leads in Polls
description: Mary Landrieu, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, was making her way gingerly through the stadium stands, offering her hand to potential voters at the historically black university here in northern Louisiana. But most eyes stayed fixed on the football field, and the fans whose votes she desperately needs hardly noticed when she left.

title: Nike's Shrine to Itself Is a Glitzy Showcase
description: When Nike designed its biggest and glitziest retail store ever, it did not overlook a fish tank (unfilled as of yesterday), several infrared foot-sizers, the actual Stanley Cup or a complex system of 26 tubes, some visible to pedestrians on 57th Street, to hoist ''the product'' from the storeroom to five floors packed with 5,000 different products.

title: Compromise In G.M. Strike Still Elusive
description: Negotiators from the United Automobile Workers union and the General Motors Corporation held marathon talks today aimed at settling the third big strike this year against the company, but a compromise remained elusive.

title: More Growth, a Recession, Or a 'Growth Recession'?
description: On Wednesday it was the Government tally showing that the nation's growth rate fell by more than half over the summer. Today, figures showed that consumer spending barely budged in September, rising less than inflation. And the General Motors strike swelled first-time claims for jobless benefits, while the United States Chamber of Commerce said its index of business confidence skidded to the lowest level since February.

title: Forget Pluralism as a Policy in Central Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Riders Finds Trouble As a Trail Blazer
description: ISAIAH (J. R.) RIDER, who has said he looked forward to a fresh start in Portland, has been cited for possession of marijuana less than two days before he is to play in his first Trail Blazers game.

title: When All Else Fails, You Can Always Run for Congress
description: Let's suppose there's a 73-year-old man, a World War II veteran with a physical disability, who is in danger of losing his current line of work. Just where in the world is someone like that likely to find a decent-paying job?

title: Mexican Seeks Compromise On Selloff of Petrochemicals
description: Given Mexico's history of political and economic dominance by the United States, even the slightest hint of capitulation in a sacred area like the state oil industry can create a political outcry.

title: Panel Sees No Proof Of Health Hazards From Power Lines
description: There is no convincing evidence that exposure to electric and magnetic fields from power lines and appliances in the home presents a health hazard, a panel of scientists said today.

title: Kurdish Factions Extend Cease-Fire in Iraq; U.S. Still Cautious
description: Two Kurdish factions whose rivalry led the United States to fire missiles against Iraq last month agreed today to extend their cease-fire and to resume talks in mid-November on a more permanent political settlement.

title: Tolerant Idaho
description: To the Editor:

title: SARA LEE TO BUY BACK UP TO 20 MILLION SHARES
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back up to 20 million shares in addition to the 12 million shares remaining from previous buyback programs. The food and consumer products company also raised its quarterly dividend 11 percent, to 21 cents a share, to be paid Jan. 1 to shareholders of record Dec. 1. Sara Lee, based in Chicago, has about 485 million shares outstanding. The stock closed yesterday at $35.50, down 25 cents, on the Big Board.

title: Gender and Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Jean-Michel Basquiat

title: In War-Ravaged Chechnya, Russia's Presence Is Fading
description: Draped in mists and surrounded by the unassailable snow-covered peaks of the Caucasus, the Chechen elders gathered on a hilltop here to thank Allah for bringing them victory in their war against Russia.

title: Home Video
description: Accord on Scrambling

title: Democrats Assail Ex-Iranian Aide's Donation to D'Amato Fund
description: A former Finance Minister for the Iranian Government contributed $25,000 to a political action committee that is paying for a television advertising campaign touting Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's support for a $1.7 billion environmental bond act.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENESCO INC., Nashville, a footwear maker and retailer, said it would close its Hohenwald, Tenn., boot factory, laying off about 180 employees. The company will take a $1.7 million charge in the third quarter.

title: Business Dispute May Delay Introduction of Abortion Pill
description: In a possible setback for the introduction of the abortion pill RU-486 in the United States, a California company contended yesterday in a lawsuit that the license to manufacture and distribute the drug in this country was held by a convicted criminal.

title: Stocks Climb as Investors See Low Inflation
description: The stock market rose yesterday, paced by consumer-product makers like Procter & Gamble and Clorox, after falling commodity prices and a series of economic reports reinforced investors' perception of a slow-growth, low-inflation economy.

title: Miners Are Told to Take Election Day Off
description: The United Mine Workers of America said today that it would tell its 75,000 active members, most of them Democrats, to take Tuesday off without pay to be sure they get out to vote.

title: F.B.I. Philosophy in Spotlight in Atlanta Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Elie Nadelman

title: Race Lacks Personal Touch
description: If the New Jersey Senate race is any guide, mingling with the public is no longer a prerequisite for office.

title: 2 Big Retailers Sue Visa, Hoping to Avoid Accepting a Debit Card
description: Two of the largest retailers have gone to court to block one of the hottest products of the largest credit card company, Visa U.S.A. Inc.

title: A Top Russian Nuclear Scientist Kills Himself
description: In a suicide that has spotlighted the plight of Russia's scientists, the head of one of the nation's top nuclear research centers has shot himself, the police said today.

title: Where Do Dead Letters Go? Heaven
description: In ''Dear God,'' a cute con man named Tom Turner (Greg Kinnear) is nabbed for fraud and given a cute punishment. He is assigned to work for the United States Postal Service at the Dead Letter Office, which is treated in Garry Marshall's sugary new film as a situation comedy waiting to happen.

title: Indiana Coach Fired
description: BILL MALLORY, who briefly lifted Indiana from the depths of Big Ten football mediocrity, was dismissed yesterday, a victim of his own success.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Suit Challenging Investment Adviser Is Dismissed
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit today by a Tennessee family that contended it had been treated unfairly by its investment adviser.

title: Fund Research Company Sold
description: Boston Institutional Group Inc. said today that it would acquire the Financial Research Corporation, a mutual fund research company, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Peaceably, Scots War With London
description: For hundreds of years the leaders of this wild and blustery land donned their fighting tartans and sought their independence from England with swords and truncheons and longbows and muskets.

title: An African Peace Force
description: The Clinton Administration is giving belated but useful attention to one of Africa's most acute problems -- the terrible human suffering caused by civil conflicts, like the current fighting between Tutsi and Hutu in eastern Zaire. The Administration has proposed creation of an African Crisis Response Force, whose troops would come from African armies and much of the financing and training from the West. The idea marks a welcome departure from the recent international neglect of Africa's problems and could save thousands of lives.

title: Trapped in the Web Of a Monstrous Charade
description: Kurt Vonnegut's fiction has never really found its way to the movies. The author's curmudgeonly popularity as a great campus favorite for baby boomers has had much to do with the simplicity and cosmic jokeyness of his writing, qualities that should translate forthrightly to the screen. On the other hand, such spare and fanciful novels leave much to the imagination. And Mr. Vonnegut's wry moral ambiguity is as elusive as his whimsy. The ''hi ho'' or ''so it goes'' that works as a shrug on the page has no easy counterpart on screen.

title: Ex-Manager of Magellan Fund Is Returning To the Arena
description: Five months after leaving the most prominent post in the mutual fund industry, Jeffrey N. Vinik, former manager of the Fidelity Magellan fund, will return to the Wall Street arena today when he begins investing an $800 million hedge fund at his new firm, Vinik Asset Management.

title: Airbus Sets Timetable for New 500-Seat Jet
description: Officials at Airbus Industrie, the four-country consortium that is challenging the Boeing Company for first place in the global commercial passenger plane market, are saying that their design for a plane with 500 or more seats will be ready by the end of the year. The Airbus plane is intended to compete with Boeing's planned stretch-747 jumbo jet

title: Manuscripts as Windows Into Poets' Minds and Souls
description: One of the things that I most like to do is to stay home and read other people's letters (as a licensed intruder, I must add).

title: For New York State Senate
description: In a year of dissatisfaction with New York's dysfunctional State Legislature, the shortage of seriously contested races speaks volumes about the state's closed political process. Here are our endorsements in a few of the more interesting State Senate races in New York City and the surrounding suburbs.

title: Eldredge Keeps His Mind Trained on Next Olympics
description: Figure skating has become so popular that it gets big television ratings in prime time. Nancy and Kristi and Brian and Scott have become first-name sports heroes to rival Deion and Shaq and Ken Jr.

title: Writer's Message to Those Who Trashed His Work
description: Pramoedya Ananta Toer, Indonesia's greatest writer, is an angry man. He has been imprisoned. His library has been taken from him. His books are banned. He is barred from leaving Jakarta.

title: Zimmer Visits a Halfway House To Showcase His Philosophy
description: Trying to blunt efforts to portray him as a fiscal conservative opposed to social welfare programs, Representative Richard A. Zimmer visited a halfway house for addicted women today, saying it was an example of how the government can help people.

title: New Traces Of Past Life On Mars
description: Another meteorite from Mars has been found to contain evidence for possible life on that planet, British scientists reported yesterday.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Powerful Expressions'

title: These Yanks Were Not Home-Grown
description: NEW YORKERS take considerable pride, of course, in their home team, the World Series champion New York Yankees, a team that, except for the manager, has not a single player or top executive who was actually raised in any of the five boroughs or anywhere in the environs.

title: Correction
description: An article on Saturday about the Clinton Administration's record on immigration misstated the date when President Clinton reversed himself a second time and agreed to grant asylum interviews to potential Haitian refugees. It was May 1994, not May 1993.

title: Torricelli Vows to Fight G.O.P. Cuts In Medicare
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli stopped by a new center for the elderly here today and talked about Medicare, saying he would fight to protect the 31-year-old program if he won election to the United States Senate and using the example of his own grandmother to illustrate its importance.

title: Diner's Journal
description: If you're looking for a way to be extravagantly self-indulgent, I have a suggestion: dinner at Cellar in the Sky in the World Trade Center. Reopened just last week, the room is so quietly soothing and the service so solicitous that it is easy to imagine you have been invited to the home of some extremely wealthy gourmand.

title: Giddy Informality From a New Guard
description: Just as there is a thread that joins the new school designers in Paris, so there has blossomed a common spirit among the younger generation of designers in New York, which sets them apart from America's old guard.

title: L.I.R.R. Is Leasing Freight System For 20 Years
description: A private company agreed yesterday to take over the Long Island Rail Road's small freight operation, a deal that both sides said would increase rail freight traffic on Long Island and return some life to the moribund Brooklyn docks.

title: In L.I. Contest, Incumbent Charges 'Catholic Bashing' by Challenger
description: Serenity on Long Island is often found in autumn and due east, where the island splits like a fishtail into the Atlantic Ocean. Here, farmers sell pumpkins and pies from roadside stands and the beaches are dimpled with the footprints of solitary walks.

title: A Widow Alone, Loving And Full of Longing
description: Every beleaguered working mother should be as lucky as Monica (Marisa Tomei), to live next door to someone like Mildred (Gena Rowlands), the central character of Nick Cassavetes's sticky-sweet film, ''Unhook the Stars.'' A 60-something widow with two grown children, Mildred has nothing better to do than care for Monica's 6-year-old son J. J. (Jake Lloyd) voluntarily, all day, every day. It helps that the child is a poker-faced little angel (quite unlike his crude, profanity-spewing parents) who docilely soaks up the knowledge Mildred pumps into him from a children's encyclopedia, which she reads out loud, proceeding alphabetically from the letter A.

title: Accounts
description: * Maryland Aviation Administration, Linthicum, Md., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore and Washington, to handle advertising and marketing for the Baltimore-Washington International Airport and Martin State Airport, which had been handled by Richardson, Myers & Donofrio, Baltimore. Eisner was awarded a three-year contract with total billings estimated at $8.5 million.

title: Munich in Washington
description: America at election time: two Chamberlains and not a Churchill in sight.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Soft! What Light? It's Flash, Romeo
description: WHILE Shakespeare spins, the madly flamboyant film maker Baz Luhrmann (''Strictly Ballroom'') invents a whole new vocabulary for a story of star-crossed young love. It calls for pink hair, screaming billboards, tabloid television stories, music-video editing and a little hot dog shack called Rosencrantzky's on Verona Beach. Wherefore art thou? A good question, and not just for Romeo. Why bury ''Romeo and Juliet'' amid all this creative ferment? Where is the audience willing to watch a classic play thrown in the path of a subway train?

title: Militias Hold a Congress, and Not a Gun Is Seen
description: Sandwiched between notices for meetings of a pest-control company and an auto repair group was this news: The Third Continental Congress was meeting in a conference room in the basement of a Holiday Inn on the southern fringe of the city.

title: Warm Minimalism Rooted in Poetry
description: Much ink has been spilled over whether the stark Minimalism of the 1960's was an art of the mind or of the heart. But there isn't much doubt in the case of Ronald Bladen (1918-1988). The sculpture that made his name was sleek and geometric, but the sensibility that produced it was romantic to the core.

title: Election Fun for Everyone
description: POLITICS, politics everywhere.

title: Touting Outsiders Who Endorse Longer Term Limits
description: The Coalition for Voters' Choice, formed by City Council members, began broadcasting a 10-second television commercial, ''Endorsed,'' yesterday. The coalition is campaigning for a referendum proposition to change the city's term limit law to allow three terms instead of two.

title: Three Variations
description: Highlights of proposals by President Clinton, Bob Dole and Ross Perot for changing the way political campaigns are financed:

title: In Term-Limits Fight, Simpler Messages for Perplexed Voters
description: Having already spent millions of dollars on advertising, supporters and opponents of the ballot proposal that would change the city's term limits law are planning a last-minute weekend blitz of television ads and leafletting.

title: A Singer Darting Among Her Many Voices
description: Sooner or later every diva wants to sing at Carnegie Hall. Diamanda Galas had her debut there on Thursday night, before an adoring crowd dotted with Halloween outfits. Her recital was billed as ''Malediction and Prayer: Concert for the Damned.''

title: Esoteric, Asymmetrical and Coolly Campy
description: How important is novelty to fashion? Is it less important, or more, than continuity, wearability and seasonlessness? Three of America's most important designers are grappling with this issue and dealing with it in entirely different ways, ending the New York shows yesterday with collections that artfully balanced commercial continuity and creating collectibles.

title: It Takes a Rebel and a Showoff to Love a Begonia
description: In most horticultural trends, I keep pace with the rest of the world. I dutifully filled a bed with heirloom roses after bumping into those prickly bloomers in every book, magazine and lecture series I encountered. Ditto for dianthus. But as far as begonias are concerned, until very recently I seemed to be on my own. Except for a few stubborn members of the American Begonia Society (a group whose numbers seem to dwindle annually, to 1,500 from 1,600 last year) and a handful of other fanatics who are equally out of sync with the age, I am one of the few misguided souls who still go around extolling the virtues of begonias.

title: 9 New Plans Are Submitted For Coliseum
description: Opening a new round in the long and contentious battle over what to do with the New York Coliseum, nine development groups have submitted proposals for projects to be built on the site, ranging from Donald Trump's plan for a condominium-hotel to a proposal by Sony for a ''multimedia retail, restaurant and entertainment complex.''

title: Tips For Voters
description: For a long time voting seemed like the patriotic thing to do. Good upright people said failure to vote would undermine democracy. It never occurred to me to doubt it. I voted.

title: EMMIS BROADCASTING BUYS ST. LOUIS RADIO STATIONS
description: The Emmis Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired three radio stations in St. Louis from the closely held Zimco Inc. for $42.5 million, extending its presence in a market it already serves. Emmis bought stations WKBQ-FM and AM, which use a top-40 format, and country station WKKX-FM. Emmis already owns and operates KSHE-FM in St. Louis. Zimmer Radio Group, the parent company of Zimco, said the sale of the radio stations would allow it to focus on stations in other markets, as well as its telecommunications business.

title: 'Carmen' As a Battle Between Opposites
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Carmen'' suffers symptoms difficult to diagnose. There are moments when it looks the picture of health, but it is precisely then that it behaves so badly: drooping into helplessness, dropsical and aimless. At its gloomiest, on the other hand, this production leaps into life. So it went for three and a half hours on Thursday night: these visions of life force and near death in puzzling alternation.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Congressman Falsely Took Credit for Bill, His Rival Says
description: A Congresswoman from Westchester County visited Long Island yesterday to back up a fellow Democratic candidate's claim that the candidate's opponent took credit for legislation he didn't write.

title: No Political Action Committees, Dole Says
description: With two former Republican Presidents in tow, Bob Dole began the last march of his campaign today with a triple punch that reprised a year of Republican assaults on President Clinton's ethics and character. Mr. Dole, in a new proposal, also called for abolishing political action committees.

title: Where Do We Live Anyway?
description: Is New Jersey suffering from an identity crisis? That's one explanation being offered for the state's poor record on voter registration. Only about 4.3 million of the more than six million voting-age New Jersey residents (a figure that includes noncitizens, who are ineligible to vote) are registered, according to a study released yesterday by a nonpartisan political consulting company. That puts New Jersey in 40th place among the states and the District of Columbia, more than 3 percent below the national average, said the company, Election Data Services.

title: Rebels in Mexico Resume Raids, Killing at Least 6 in 3 States
description: The guerrillas of the Popular Revolutionary Army ended a two-month-old cease-fire this week with small-scale attacks in three Mexican states that left at least six dead.

title: For State Assembly and City Council
description: Here are our endorsements in some of the livelier races in New York City and its suburbs for the New York State Assembly, and in the single special election for New York City Council.

title: Leonardo Used No Mirror for His Mirror Script
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Kept 'Miz' Cast In the Dark On Change
description: The cast members of ''Les Miserables'' reacted with shock, dismay and anger when John Caird, the show's co-director, announced last weekend that most of the company would be out of a job in January. Now they have a new focus for their emotions: their own union.

title: Ethics in Fund Raising: The October Surprise?
description: The Republicans have been talking for months about an October surprise, but what has happened in the last few days is not exactly what they had in mind.

title: No Headline
description: ''Everybody in Las Vegas loved him, but every time he went back to New York he got in trouble. We tried real hard to get him not to go back to New York.''

title: Well on the Way to the Next Whiskey Bar
description: ''SHOW me the way to the next whiskey bar,'' Jim Morrison sang. If he were alive today and still doing his version of the Brecht-Weill song, he would have only to follow Rande Gerber, the owner of the bellwether Whiskey Bar in the Paramount Hotel, a second Whiskey Bar in Los Angeles and two, three or maybe more to come.

title: Clinton Returns to Platform Plank of '92
description: Seeking to quell controversy over the Democratic Party's fund-raising practices, President Clinton today proposed to ban political contributions by noncitizens and reiterated his support for a range of other changes in campaign finance law that he had endorsed in the past but never pressed hard for.

title: Contract Settlement Averts Wider Strike At General Motors
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union announced an agreement early this morning on a new three-year labor contract, averting a national strike against the world's largest auto maker and likely bringing to an end the greatest labor unrest in the American automobile industry since 1970.

title: Giuliani Grouchiness Is in Eye of the Beholder
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: A Democrat Is Struggling in a Democratic Haven, West Virginia
description: Charlotte Pritt, the Democratic nominee for governor here, likes to brag of the close relationship she forged with President Clinton during a brief ride on Air Force One a few months ago.

title: Knicks Finally Show Up for N.B.A.'s Party
description: The curtain seemed to rise on the Knicks' new season about 36 minutes too soon. Jeff Van Gundy's grand production was not ready for prime time. His players were lost on defense. Bringing the ball across halfcourt was an adventure against Toronto's trap.

title: Dallas Eyes Mitchell
description: With the Pro Bowler JAY NOVACEK's prospects for the season dimming and ERIC BJORNSON hobbled by a sprained ankle, the Dallas Cowboys are looking for an ''insurance policy'' at tight end. JOHNNY MITCHELL may be it.

title: In Their Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: ALLEGIANCE TO TAKE $550 MILLION EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The Allegiance Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $550 million charge in the fourth quarter, its first quarter as an independent company, because of an accounting change. Allegiance, a medical products company, which was spun off from Baxter International Inc., changed its method of accounting for good will, or the value of intangible assets, like a respected business name. Good will is written off over time. Allegiance had about $1.1 billion of good will as of Sept. 30. Allegiance said the accounting change and write-down of good will will reduce amortization expenses by $4.7 million in the fourth quarter and by $18.9 million annually.

title: Expand Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Corn and Soybean Prices Fall On Ideal Weather for Harvest
description: Corn and soybean futures fell yesterday as ideal weather was forecast for this weekend, allowing farmers to harvest bumper crops.

title: New Roster Looks Good With Houston
description: The National Basketball Association tipped off its 50th anniversary season last night, and Allan Houston and John Starks combined for 50 points.

title: Auto Makers Seek to Reduce the Danger of Air Bags' Impact
description: Chrysler, Ford and General Motors have asked the Federal safety authorities for emergency permission to switch to air bags that inflate more slowly, seeking to reduce the risk of neck-injury deaths among infants, children and short adults when air bags inflate at up to 200 miles an hour.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Cigar Gets His Own Parade
description: Cigar's racing days may be over, but he is hardly being put out to pasture. The 6-year-old horse will be saluted today at an elaborate farewell ceremony intended to provide a highlight, and draw a crowd, for closing day of the 113th National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Happening Upon Love Amid Books And Flowers
description: In ''Mary and Tim,'' based on a Colleen McCullough novel, Candice Bergen cracks her hard-boiled ''Murphy Brown'' shell to play, quite affectingly, a widow who drifts into a special relationship with a much younger man. Complicating matters, the man has, as the script puts it, some unusual mental limitations. Making this dicey situation work nicely may be the fact that Ms. Bergen, herself widowed in the past year, is one of the executive producers. Even more important, the director is Glenn Jordan (''Sarah, Plain and Tall''), who is adept at skirting sentimentality excesses.

title: Channel Crossing
description: A solution to the Ted Turner-Gerald Levin lockout of the Fox News Channel? If there's such a logjam on the Time Warner cable system, why not free up the airwaves for others by combining some of the many channels that already exist? The programming, which could use some work anyway, might look something like this:

title: C.I.A. Orders Inquiry Into Charges of Chemical Arms Cover-Up
description: The Central Intelligence Agency announced today that it had ordered an internal investigation into charges by two former C.I.A. analysts that the agency ignored evidence showing that thousands of American troops may have been exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons in the Persian Gulf war.

title: New Tests Finally Point to a Cause of Jetliner Crash That Killed 132 Two Years Ago
description: Mystified for more than two years by the crash of a Boeing 737 near Pittsburgh, investigators have finally found what may have been the cause: the flow of unusually hot hydraulic fluid into an unusually chilled metal part, an occurrence that, new tests have found, can jam the 737's rudder.

title: Four in Troubled Precinct Cleared in Brutality Case
description: Four officers arrested as part of a wide-ranging investigation into brutality and corruption in a Bronx police precinct were acquitted yesterday of charges that they beat a drug suspect, pummeled him with a flashlight and forced a gun into his mouth.

title: For $8.6 Million, Christie's Sells a Rare Korean Dragon
description: A rare Korean dragon jar from the 17th century, cracked down one side, was sold on Thursday night for $8.6 million at Christie's in New York. The price was the highest ever paid at auction for an Asian art object. The names of the seller and the buyer, who bid by telephone, were not disclosed.

title: States Can Prevent Wetlands Destruction
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plunge From Hoop Dream to Nightmare
description: Richie Adams sat in the stands at Madison Square Garden two weeks ago with the bill of his baseball cap pulled low over his face, his eyes darting back and forth as the New York Knicks and his buddy Larry Johnson scrambled across the court.

title: A BRITISH COMPANY WEIGHS BUYING MCI IN $22 BILLION DEAL
description: In the most dramatic foray ever by a foreign company into the American communications business, British Telecommunications could announce as early as tomorrow that it has agreed to buy MCI, the nation's second-largest long distance company, in a deal worth more than $22 billion, people close to the situation said last evening.

title: Murdoch-MCI Efforts Under Growing Strain
description: As the MCI Communications Corporation was solidifying an alliance with British Telecommunications, its tempestuous relationship with the News Corporation appeared to be coming unraveled.

title: The Prince Who Believes In Poltergeists
description: THE midday sun's glare made it hard for Prince Michael of Greece to see if the cab he was trying to hail had its ''Off Duty'' sign lighted. He craned his head slightly toward the traffic on Columbus Avenue and peered past the smudged passenger partition.

title: POP
description: Writing Vigorous Songs

title: Beliefs
description: Take 2,000 Americans, a cross-section of the adult population. Sit each of them down for 90 minutes. Ask each around 400 questions, about everything from whether the United States is in decline to what each believes about God and how often he or she listens to talk radio.

title: Disturbing the Spirits
description: It might appear that the battle between evolutionists and creationists has broken out again in the case of a 9,300-year-old skeleton recently discovered near the Columbia River in Washington State. But because these remains were found on the sacred land of an Indian tribe, the Umatilla in nearby Oregon, it is not quite as simple as that. There is also history to consider, and vindication.

title: Hungary 1956
description: The failed Hungarian revolution of 1956, bloodily suppressed by Russian tanks, was a cold-war watershed. It stripped away any pretense of popular consent to the regimes Moscow had imposed on Eastern Europe and showed that the Soviet Union would use force to keep its new empire intact. It also made clear, for the first time, that the West would not send military aid even to a broadly supported, armed anti-Communist uprising.

title: G.M. Car Sales Drop as Other Makers Report Increases
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that its car and truck sales dropped 7.9 percent last month from a year earlier, even as Chrysler, Honda and Toyota all announced their highest October sales ever.

title: Gore Comes to the Shore to Assist Torricelli
description: Vice President Al Gore stood by a smooth stretch of bay here today and called upon a crowd of southern New Jersey residents to elect Representative Robert G. Torricelli to the United States Senate, stressing that Mr. Torricelli would champion environmental protection in a state that sorely needs it.

title: Ball to Museum
description: The EDDIE MURRAY home run ball that sold for $500,000 last month will go to the Babe Ruth Museum, which won a national call-in poll.

title: In San Francisco, Jazz's Friendliest Context Since the 40's
description: This city is blessed with many good things, one of them being an abundance of excellent music halls. That may be a footnote to some, but not for the San Francisco Jazz Festival, the latest edition of which started on Oct. 23 with a concert by Sonny Rollins and will end on Sunday with a tribute to the organist Jack McDuff.

title: In Nobody's Whistlestop, N.J., if Anyone Cares, a Few Votes for Bruce Willis
description: Once again, the politicians looking for votes were close by, just not close enough.

title: Oddly Wonderful, This Look at Yiddish Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Arrested in Music Piracy
description: Police officers seized thousands of audiocassettes Thursday and arrested two men for violating antipiracy laws and three of their employees for conspiracy, the authorities said yesterday. The two principals, James Russo of Toms River and Lawrence Nesser of South River, copied tapes supplied by nightclub disk jockeys but failed to pay for the right to reproduce and sell the music, said Sgt. Joseph Kolakowski of the South River police. Their businesses, Beat Productions and Hip Hop International, did business in five states and grossed about $500,000 during the past year, Sergeant Kolakowski said.

title: Giuliani Grouchiness Is in Eye of the Beholder
description: To the Editor:

title: Bipartisan Voter Rebellion Against Big Money in Maine Is Expected to Succeed
description: With campaign financing suddenly sparking scandal charges on the national scene, Maine voters are a step ahead in their concern and are expected to approve a populist-tinged ballot initiative for a pioneering public program that will favor small-stakes community financing over big-money politics.

title: Endorsing the Unethical
description: To the Editor:

title: Headgear for the Techno-Salesclerk
description: ON duty behind the cash registers, they look like air-traffic controllers or football coaches or telephone operators. In fact, they are retail salesclerks, the same as always. What is new, and what is prompting caustic customers to ask for a large order of fries and a Diet Coke, is their headgear.

title: COMPUTERS HINDER EUROPEAN FIDELITY INVESTMENTS
description: The European brokerage arm of Fidelity Investments agreed with a British regulator yesterday not to accept new clients for three months because of problems with a new computer system. Fidelity Brokerage, the brokerage unit of Fidelity that has 30,000 European clients, said it would comply with a recommendation by the Securities and Futures Authority not to take on new clients until the end of January or until it fixes the problems, which resulted in some dividend checks not being sent or credited to proper accounts.

title: In the Beginning There Was . . . Something?
description: To the Editor:

title: Noisy Fight Over a Tax On Sugar
description: Nowhere are the environmental issues that echo through this year's political debates being argued more noisily and at greater expense than in Florida, where a fight over sugar and the Everglades is raging.

title: Germany's Retailers Beckon Warily to Customers
description: The shopkeepers in this 500-year-old village tried hard to look happy today, as they marked the first day in German history that stores will be allowed to stay open on weekdays past 6:30 P.M.

title: Mickey Kantor, Gutsy Campaigner, Has Smoothed Clinton's Path
description: It is midday at the sprawling Pinney Dock, and halfway through a tour of the piles of coal and iron ore moving off the waterfront on Lake Erie, Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor is already spewing the endless statistics that he repeats nonstop from one Congressional district to the next.

title: NABISCO PAY $204 MILLION FOR OVERSEAS UNITS
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it had paid $204 million to buy five non-United States food businesses this year.
