The company, which makes Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers, had previously not disclosed the purchase prices of the five acquisitions. The company did not break out the purchase price of each business. It disclosed the total purchase price in a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The purchases were: the Argentine biscuit and cracker makers Mayco and Capri; Cia. Produtos Pilas, a Brazilian cookie and biscuit business; the biscuit, confectionery and snack food assets of the Lucky Enterprise Corporation of Taiwan; the Argentine pasta business Luis Vizzolini e Hijos, and Galletas Fontaneda, a Spanish biscuit business.

title: Ex-Officer Gets Prison Term For Fatal Shooting of Woman
description: A former New York City police officer received close to the maximum sentence in State Supreme Court yesterday for shooting a woman to death during an off-duty scuffle in a Washington Heights restaurant last year.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Campaign Tale

title: A Mixed Midseason Report For Giants
description: The Giants are 3-5 and, for the first time since 1979, without a victory in their first four division games. So far this has not been one of the organization's better years. But even in years when there are not a lot of good movies, they still have to hand out the Oscars.

title: Family Dog Sniffs Evil And Rears Into Action
description: A nice German shepherd knows a big bad werewolf when he sees one. If he could only translate his frantic barking into human speech, he would warn you to watch your back while taking nighttime hikes through the woods of the Pacific Northwest.

title: The Day of the Ghouls vs. the Day of the Dead
description: As dusk fell and shadows began to creep, the streets were suddenly filled with unearthly creatures, running in packs.

title: Bonds Drop Despite Reports Of Slower Economic Growth
description: Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday, as economic reports showed the pace of growth in jobs and manufacturing slowing but not enough to ease investors' concern that inflation could rebound later this year.

title: Dow Off a Bit On Concerns About Profits
description: Stocks fell as investors saw signs of weaker earnings among the economic signals that pushed borrowing costs down this week.

title: MCI Deal Would Speed Pace of Current Mergers
description: Every day seems to bring yet another announcement of a multibillion-dollar merger and acquisition deal, and with almost two months left in the year, British Telecommunications' pending $22 billion acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation would propel 1996 well beyond last year's record.

title: Gooden to Return To the Yankees
description: Dwight Gooden insisted in late September that the Yankees would bring him back in 1997. He reiterated his thoughts last week, after they won the World Series, and yesterday the team finally made Gooden's return official by exercising the $2 million option for next season on the right-hander's contract.

title: Arrest in Shooting of Boy
description: The police arrested an 18-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday in the shooting of a 10-year-old boy in Greenpoint on Halloween.

title: A Robust Pace Of Job Growth, With Inflation Under Control
description: In the latest of a string of pre-election reports showing the economy on a slow but steady track, Government figures indicated today that the number of American jobs once again grew at a robust pace in October while wages posed no threat of faster inflation.

title: Two-Term Limits With a Message Repeated Twice
description: In an unconventional 30-second television commercial titled ''The Facts,'' which began appearing on Thursday, New Yorkers for Term Limits repeated a 10-second spot two more times. The commercial urges rejection of a City Council ballot referendum that would allow city officeholders to serve three terms instead of two, the present legal limit.

title: Strife on Zaire Border Erupts Into Open War With Rwanda
description: A simmering conflict erupted into open warfare between Zaire and Rwanda today as the two countries traded heavy artillery barrages. And ethnic Tutsi from Zaire, bolstered by support from Rwanda's Tutsi-led Government, closed in on the key Zairian city of Goma.

title: Democratic Official Replies on Donations
description: A senior official of the Democratic National Committee, which has been under fire for questionable campaign contributions, acknowledged that the party had abandoned a procedure set up years ago to detect contributions from donors with questionable backgrounds.

title: Renovating The Nets' Franchise
description: HOURS before the Nets' home opener against Cleveland last night, John Calipari, the Nets' rookie head coach, invited some members of the news media to follow him. Calipari was eager to show off the Nets' new locker room.

title: F.B.I. Pulls Out of Joint Inquiry On Fatal Blast in Saudi Arabia
description: Federal authorities said today that the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, exasperated by the lack of cooperation from Saudi security officials, had pulled out a team of agents sent to investigate the bombing in June that killed 19 American airmen at their military housing in Dhahran.

title: Geoffrey Beene Shows the Way
description: There is a temptation to lose faith in fashion in a season like this when so many designers made a startling about-face from what they showed last time. Women have barely started wearing their fall pants suits when they're being told to jettison them in favor of fragile dresses.

title: Whitman Takes It Easy
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who is suffering from a herniated disk, made a brief appearance at the Statehouse yesterday to proclaim November as Puerto Rican Heritage Month but spent the rest of the day at home, her office said.

title: Dublin Is Seeing Irish Of a Very Different Sort
description: As Notre Dame and Navy prepared for their 70th football meeting Saturday -- the first one not on United States soil -- the question on many Dubliners' minds was not who would win a game of giants with such incomprehensible rules, but which team had more Irish roots. And, for that matter, why is Notre Dame called the Fighting Irish at all, at all?

title: Isles Fans Cry for Help
description: Like most people at the top of Nassau Coliseum on Thursday night, JOHN SPANO did not know what the remainder of the 7,719 fans during the Islanders' 5-3 defeat to the Toronto Maple Leafs were chanting.

title: Texas Players Eligible
description: The Texas Longhorns began focusing their attention on football again -- namely today's game against Baylor -- after the National Collegiate Athletic Association restored the eligibility of four star players who had lunch with an agent, arranged by the former Longhorn linebacker WINFRED TUBBS, now with the New Orleans Saints.

title: Emerging From the Footlights
description: The stars come out for the Met, Carnegie Hall, Alzheimer's research and the Acting Company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MCI Shares Soar on News Of British Telecom Talks

title: A Thriving Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana Strike to Close Plant
description: Some 2,150 workers at General Motors' Linden assembly plant were told yesterday that the plant would shut down at 2 A.M. and remain closed until the settlement of a strike at a G.M. metal pressing plant in Indianapolis, union officials said. Without the hoods, tailgates and other parts made at the Indiana plant, Linden workers cannot produce the 49 pickups and four-wheel drive trucks that normally roll off the assembly line every hour, said Charlie Marshall, president of Local 595 of the United Auto Workers. The Linden plant shut down for a week in March after workers at two brake plants in Ohio walked out. $(Related story, page 39.$)

title: Democratic Official Admits Less Scrutiny of Donations
description: A senior official of the Democratic National Committee, which has been under fire for accepting questionable campaign contributions, acknowledged today that the party had abandoned a procedure set up years ago to detect contributions from donors with questionable backgrounds.

title: Confidentiality Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Sun Sets On Gurkhas Guarding Hong Kong
description: As a doubloon sun slithered toward the forested hillsides in the distance, a plaintive wail of bagpipes seeped across the parade ground at the Malaya Line. Slowly, the line of bandsmen wheeled around, washing the air with the reels of the Scottish Highlands.

title: After Disappointment in Atlanta, a Chance for Glory in New York
description: He was favored in the Olympic marathon, the defending world champion, but Martin Fiz of Spain made the mistake of looking behind him when he should have been looking ahead.

title: Bridge
description: The American women's contract bridge team won a world title here tonight, defeating China by 70 imps.

title: 'President McKinley's Paper' Evolves, and So Do Its Political Endorsements
description: In 177 years, Canton's newspaper, The Repository, had never endorsed a Democrat for President. ''President McKinley's paper,'' they called it, and it really was, owned by his wife's family. In the 1896 Presidential election, run from the front porch of the McKinley home here, special editions of The Repository featuring the daily speeches of William McKinley were printed each evening and sent round America by train.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: Baseball

title: Company Briefs
description: TELEX COMMUNICATION GROUP, Minneapolis, a maker of audio, wireless and multimedia communications devices for the commercial and industrial markets, hired the investment banking firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, to study options that include the sale of all or part of the company, a possible public stock offering or recapitalization.

title: Paper Reflects Change
description: In 177 years, The Repository, the newspaper in Canton, Ohio, had never endorsed a Democrat for President. When the Republican William McKinley was elected President in 1896, his wife's family owned the paper. But things had changed by 1992, when the newspaper decided to endorse Bill Clinton for the Presidency.

title: Zimmer Drops Ad Featuring Fake Newscast
description: The television campaign advertisement that became a touchstone for critics of the New Jersey Senate race has been pulled off the air, according to officials for the Republican candidate, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, who first began broadcasting the spot three weeks ago.

title: J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka Dies at 90; Modernized Nation He Led for 11 Years
description: J. R. Jayewardene, a former President of Sri Lanka who modernized and reshaped the country politically and was later criticized for his handling of ethnic tensions at its most critical moments, died yesterday in Colombo. He was 90.

title: On Stump, Gore Shows a New Touch in Connecting With Crowds
description: Vice President Al Gore, whose boxy shoulders and predilection for polysyllabic earnestness have often made him seem like a kind of uptight Mr. Rogers, looks relaxed these days. No, really.

title: Michael Burnett, 67, Criminal Who Exposed City Corruption
description: Michael Burnett, a career swindler whose work as a Government informer helped expose major municipal corruption in New York City and Chicago, died on Thursday at a Federal prison in Georgia, where he was serving a life sentence for masterminding a murder.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: His Efforts to Become the Speaker Carry Gephardt to Stumping Far From Home
description: All day long, Richard A. Gephardt earnestly sought support for Democrats running against Republican freshmen, telling how ''Gingrich's robots'' had voted against Medicare, or education, or pension security.

title: Special Education
description: To the Editor:

title: WITCO COMPLETES SALE OF LUBRICANTS SUBSIDIARIES
description: The Witco Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the sale of three business units within its Lubricants Group for $121 million. Witco said the Sun Company had purchased its Kendall-Amalie unit, the Exxon Corporation had bought its Southwest Petro-Chem Inc. unit, and the Stant Corporation had acquired Southwest's Lubrimatic business. Witco, a chemicals company based in Greenwich, Conn., said proceeds from the sales would be used to reduce the company's long-term debt. The company said it was in talks with prospective buyers for the remaining units of the Lubricants Group.

title: Dollar Falls Against the Yen After Ex-Official's Remarks
description: The dollar fell against the yen, after Lloyd M. Bentsen, a former Treasury Secretary, said further gains by the dollar would hurt American trade competitiveness.

title: OPERA
description: Fresh Faces, Pledging Love

title: CAMBRIDGE TECHNOLOGY ADDS RAMOS & ASSOCIATES
description: Cambridge Technology Partners Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Ramos & Associates Inc., an information technology consulting firm, for about $39 million in stock. Ramos & Associates, based in San Ramon, Calif., has about 189 employees. The company had revenue of $11.8 million in 1995 and $17.5 million in the first nine months of 1996.

title: Program Allows Teen-Agers To Limit Consequences of Arrest
description: At 16, Robert F. has already been arrested four times. He can list guns by their caliber and range. And he is quick to say that his role model is a 35-year-old neighborhood drug dealer who has never been caught.

title: 2 Top Jet Defenders Return
description: In what has been the Jets' worst season, today's rare cheery moment contrasted with familiar somber news.

title: Times Union Accepts Pact
description: Local 6 of the New York Mailers Union announced yesterday that its members had ratified a four-year agreement with The New York Times that will give 200 workers lifetime job guarantees and give the newspaper more flexibility to print in the Northeast outside the New York region.

title: In Face of African Crisis, No Plans for World Action
description: As fighting intensifies daily in eastern Zaire, imperiling more than a million refugees and hundreds of relief workers, no sense of urgency has gripped major capitals, including Washington, and there are no concrete international plans to confront the looming catastrophe.

title: Swiss Envoy Vows Action On Old 'Holocaust Funds'
description: The Swiss Ambassador to the United States, concerned that his country's reputation could be harmed by the growing disputes over the unclaimed accounts of Holocaust victims, offered assurances today that Switzerland would give full restitution to ''anyone with a legitimate claim to get their money back.''

title: Correction
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about an offer by Patriot American Hospitality Inc. to acquire the California Jockey Club and the Bay Meadows Operating Company for $195 million in cash or stock reversed two digits in citing the amount of stock offered. It is 0.9635 share of Patriot for every unit of Bay Meadows, not 0.9365.

title: S.E.C. Is Investigating Rebates From Firms
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting more than a dozen investigations of rebates to mutual fund companies from securities firms trying to win their business, S.E.C. officials said today.

title: New Coach, New Look; New Nets Still Lose
description: It was as shiny as tinfoil, with a new car smell. It was the Nets' brand new locker room, complete with all the amenities of a spa. It was the luxury of having John Calipari as the Nets coach.

title: U.S. ROBOTICS TO DISMISS AS MANY AS 600 WORKERS
description: The U.S. Robotics Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss as many as 600 workers to cut costs, after doubling its work force in the last year. The company, a modem maker, which has increased its work force to 6,000 from 3,000, will eliminate less than 10 percent of its jobs, said a U.S. Robotics spokeswoman, Karen Novak. She declined to be more specific. U.S. Robotics shares, which traded below $33 a share in January, fell $2.625 yesterday, to $60.25.

title: From Acrobat to Artist: Kwan Grows Into a Star
description: In 1994, Michelle Kwan of Torrance, Calif., finished fourth in the world figure skating championships, a feat for a 14-year-old girl. She had skated well enough to medal, but the judges seemed to be sending a message that they wanted to see a young woman and not a girl.

title: Pin Stripes Without Yankees
description: Pin stripes, the dour armor of bankers, lawyers and corporate executives, are periodically imitated by the fashion world. Such mimicry could be seen on buyers, editors and guests at last week's New York spring fashion shows in Bryant Park, as it was also last month at the Paris collections. Both men and women are wearing jackets as long as coats, in chalk stripes.

title: A Candidate's Good Week
description: It has been a good week for David Del Vecchio, the Democrat seeking the Congressional seat now held by Representative Richard A. Zimmer. The editorial pages of all of the major newspapers that circulate in central New Jersey except for The Hunterdon County Democrat endorsed Mr. Del Vecchio. Those endorsements should be especially helpful in a relatively low-profile contest, said Mr. Del Vecchio's spokesman, Jeff Whelan.

title: Languorous Dresses, Singular Visions
description: There are those designers whose ambition is not to dress everybody, nor to clothe a woman from sunup till sundown. Instead, designers like Tanya Sarne, Shawn Ray Fons and Wynn Smith set out to create idiosyncratic, thoughtful clothes, which have in common a feminine delicacy and singularity.

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES SELLING PART OF CARMAX STAKE
description: Circuit City Stores Inc. plans to sell 15 percent to 20 percent of its Car Max auto-dealership business to the public in a sale valued by analysts at about $200 million. The initial public offering is aimed at letting investors focus on the vehicle business, whose promise is obscured by the 450-store electronics chain. The sale follows a wave of successful initial public offering by auto dealerships. The offering could value the money-losing Car Max at as much as $1 billion, said an analyst at the Chicago Corporation, Mark Mandel. Circuit City did not say how much it hoped to raise in the offering.

title: Labor Musters Infantry For Long Island Race
description: Julie Dade Howard has already enlisted 300 union members to leaflet at Long Island train stations, knock on doors and drive retirees to the polls, but that is not enough -- she is on the phone badgering yet another labor leader, telling him she needs more.

title: INSIDE
description: Easing Risk From Air Bags

title: Man Fatally Shoots His Wife in Her Manhattan Office
description: A man who was arrested six weeks ago on charges of harassing his estranged wife shot and killed her yesterday in a Manhattan social service agency where she worked as a secretary, the police said. Then he tried to commit suicide by shooting himself, they said.

title: The Hidden Passion
description: You hardly expect a ballroom full of tony New Yorkers to be utterly riveted by a screen performance by Demi Moore. But so they were on Thursday morning at the Plaza Hotel, where the crowd at a National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League ''power breakfast'' found itself watching Ms. Moore emote. Kate Michelman, Naral's president, screened a brief excerpt of the current HBO movie in which the glamorous star, dressing down a notch, powerfully portrays an all-American everywoman who dies as a result of a 1940's back-alley abortion. For a few minutes, even networking New Yorkers were stunned into a hush by this graphic remembrance of pre-Roe-v.-Wade nightmares.

title: Working on Black Turnout
description: Black ministers were stung in 1993 when Governor Whitman's campaign manager, Ed Rollins, said they had been paid to keep their members from voting. Mr. Rollins later withdrew that claim, but the ministers want to make sure that no one can raise that issue this year, said Cathy Ellis, a spokeswoman for the Democratic State Committee. The Black Ministers Council of New Jersey will work through the weekend to get out the black vote, the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, executive director of the council, said yesterday.

title: High Court Agrees to Hear 2 Cases on Asbestos Exposure
description: Agreeing for the first time to confront the litigation crisis caused by huge numbers of lawsuits over exposure to asbestos, the Supreme Court today accepted two cases that will help define how the Federal courts treat the legal claims of people who have been exposed to toxic substances but have not yet become ill.

title: Resist Judicial Gimmickry
description: The Clinton Administration has asked the Supreme Court to reopen an 11-year-old decision barring public school teachers from traveling to parochial schools to offer federally financed remedial classes and counseling. In doing so, it has raised legitimate concerns about the ruling's costly practical impact -- but in a way that offends the Court's deliberative process.

title: DANCE
description: When an Interracial Gay Couple

title: News Summary
description: International 3-6

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES IN $134.1 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: Huntington Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it would pay about $134.1 million in stock and cash to acquire Citi-Bancshares Inc. It said on Thursday that it would buy Citi-Bancshares to expand its presence in Florida, but did not disclose the price. Huntington, based in Columbus, Ohio, said it will pay $30 for each of the Florida-based bank's 4.47 million shares. Citi-Bancshares rose $2 yesterday, to $27.25, in Nasdaq trading. Citi-Bancshares stockholders may elect to receive payment entirely in stock or take a combination of $18 in Huntington stock and $12 in cash. Citi-Bancshares is based in Leesburg, Fla.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Sale of Mace Begins, but Demand for It Is Unclear
description: The sale of Chemical Mace and other self-defense sprays became legal in New York State yesterday, and while at least one store in Manhattan reported heavy sales, there was no sign by day's end of a widespread stampede.

title: Is the Clock Winding Down On Reeves?
description: Like a haze that won't dissipate, it is a question that has hung around the Giants organization all year. Players wonder about it. The coach is constantly asked about it. Management will soon be meeting about it. At the halfway point of the season, it is the paramount issue facing the team.

title: Perot Continues Attack on Clinton's Morality and Ethics
description: Continuing a scathing attack on President Clinton, Ross Perot asserted today that Whitewater and other inquiries into possible White House misdeeds had rendered Mr. Clinton unfit to even be a baby sitter, a house painter or fast-food cashier.

title: The Man Behind The Scowl
description: The high school coach and surrogate father of Anthony Mason figured enough people in Mason's life had told him what he wanted to hear.

title: Treaty Banning Chemical Arms Worldwide Is Set for Spring
description: A treaty banning chemical weapons worldwide is set to go into force next spring after the required number of ratifications was achieved this week with approval by Hungary.

title: A Midtown World Of Worldly Cuisines
description: ARTUSI **

title: The Autumn of the Matriarch
description: THE FAMILY MARKOWITZ

title: Irate Parents Get Promise On Repairs
description: When Public School 15 in University Heights opened last year after a number of construction delays, parents were worried that unfinished floors, exposed ventilation ducts and other incomplete construction work would compromise their children's safety. Across town, at P.S. 20 in Bedford Park, parents had similar concerns when the school opened in September, three years late.

title: Looking for Laughs, 90's Style
description: THIRTY-SIX YEARS AGO, ''The Button-Down Mind of Bob Newhart'' became the first album of stand-up comedy routines to reach No. 1 on Billboard's album chart. Mr. Newhart's sly, low-key monologues stayed at the top of the chart for 14 weeks -- still a record for a comedy album.

title: Quick, Is the Economy Better or Worse?
description: At the campaign's end, it was about the economy. But the question was which economy.

title: Tanya L. Chalfin, David C. Berman
description: Tanya Laurie Chalfin, a daughter of Phyllis and Dr. Lawrence Chalfin of New York, was married last evening to David Charles Berman, a son of Barbara Schapiro Hoffman of Livingston, N.J., and the late Edward Berman. Rabbi Laurence Groffman performed the ceremony at the New York Athletic Club.

title: He Isn't Soaring This Time, But Helms's Foe Gains Ground
description: Six years ago, Harvey Gantt's race against Senator Jesse Helms was not so much a campaign as it was a crusade. The crowds were big and boisterous, the rhetoric broad and sweeping. Even when the Democratic challenger did not say so explicitly, the campaign was clearly out to make history, both by ending the career of a conservative icon and by electing the first black Southerner to the Senate since Reconstruction.

title: A Move and a Makeover for the State Historical Society
description: After a century and a half of collecting and exhibiting New Jersey's historical paintings, costumes and other treasures, the New Jersey Historical Society is moving into social history.

title: Pentagon Health Chief Fights Claims of a Gulf War Cover-Up
description: Stephen C. Joseph, the Pentagon doctor overseeing the investigation of gulf war syndrome, is under attack on a political battlefield.

title: No Time to Visit the Library? This One Makes House Calls
description: Several years ago, the Lubavitcher Rebbe called on all Jews to do something to make the world a better place, ushering in a new era of redemption.

title: Summer Cottages
description: To the Editor: Your article about summer cottage (''A Cabin, a Lake, a Memory,'' Sept. 8,) and a resort ad with the heading ''Summer as it used to be'' reminded me of my family's summer cottage on the Raystown River near Everett, Pa. Built during the Depression, it had no electricity, no heat except a fireplace, no bathroom and no water except a slim trickle out of a pipe in a nearby lot. Anyone who visited was greeted with two buckets and ordered to fill them.

title: RUNNING AGAINST HILLARY
description: I am an unapologetic, dyed-in-the-wool liberal who would sooner vote for Socks than for either Bob or Elizabeth Dole. While I have no sympathy for Dole's third and final lunge for the Presidency, the tragic irony of Mrs. Dole's situation is inescapable. I can't imagine a hotter spot in hell for this woman than her husband's current campaign. She outclasses him in every measure of a candidate and would, I believe, be a more agile, able challenger to Clinton in this election.

title: Hazing Days
description: THIS IS FRATERNITY PLEDGE SEASON ON AMERICAN campuses, when many students come to classes late or not at all. Instead, they try to meet the demands of ritual initiation. They march in silent lockstep to secret meetings. They memorize the Greek alphabet backward. They chug grain alcohol mixed with mayonnaise. They turn up in shopping-mall Dumpsters, blindfolded and au naturel. They yearn to belong.

title: Whose Coattails? Gingrich's Or Clinton's?
description: REPRESENTATIVES Sam Gejdenson and Gary A. Franks are like those moving ducks in carnival games. They look like easy targets, but so far no one has been able to knock them down.

title: Matthew Miles, 69; His Research Led To School Reform
description: Matthew Bailey Miles, a psychologist and theorist on the educational process, died on Oct. 24 at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 69 and lived in Tappan, N.Y.

title: Unlikely Supporter of Gay Rights Recalls Pivotal Night
description: Before April 15, 1972, Michael J. Maye was known to some gay men as a bouncer at a gay bar in Greenwich Village, where he says he roughed up a number of straight men who bothered the customers.

title: Why China Has No Ears For American Demands
description: IN the last four years, America has remained right where it began in its efforts to change China.

title: Fund-Raiser Wed To Billionaire Finds Roles Clash
description: Few people in the annals of New York society have made an entrance like that of Patricia Duff, the influential Democrat who two and a half years ago left behind a Hollywood studio executive, married the Revlon billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, gave birth to their child the following day, then turned her attention to raising enormous sums of money for President Clinton, her old friend.

title: Policing Bridgeport Is a Group Effort
description: WHEN Mayor Joseph P. Ganim was elected in Bridgeport at the end of 1991, he said his priority was to find a way to reduce the city's rising crime rate, the gang wars, drive-by attacks and an all-time-high 61 homicides that year.

title: Going, Going in Zurich: A $1.2 Million Stamp
description: A scrap of yellow paper is being offered for sale on Friday by an auction house in Zurich. The last time collectors were offered this particular scrap -- an 1855 Swedish stamp printed in the wrong color -- it sold for $1.2 million, making it not only the world's most valuable stamp, but also pound for pound (or perhaps milligram for milligram) the most valuable thing in the world.

title: So His Dad Just Gives Him This Elephant
description: Sleepers

title: Prep School Drag: A Boy's Own Dress Code
description: WHEN the all-male Collegiate School on the Upper West Side imposed its dress code -- no jeans, no shorts and a blazer over either a turtleneck or a collared shirt with tie -- its administrators undoubtedly figured they could rest easy. Anyone who glanced inside those hallowed halls would see a vision of prep-school propriety, a distinguished fraternity of precociously clad teens and pre-teens all in neat rows.

title: THE NEXT HUNDRED YEARS
description: The future has never been more wonderfully expressed than in your special issue ''The Next Hundred Years.''

title: Pipe Dreams or Not, Repair Company's Fans Persevere
description: THIS Thursday, the fans of a specialty construction company will see if its promise has finally begun to show up in earnings. But if it hasn't -- and their hopes are low in light of a recent company announcement -- many of them will still hang in there. Investors in ''turnaround'' companies are used to waiting, and many of the shareholders in this one think it is worth waiting for.

title: Mayor on 'Dynamic' List
description: A week after his beloved Yankees won the World Series, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani got another dose of good news yesterday: he made the cover of Newsweek.

title: A Chance for Yankee Stadium
description: The afterglow of the World Series and the Yankees' victory parade could offer New York City a new chance to keep the team in its historic Bronx stadium. The window seems to be open -- at least a crack. The debate over the Yankees' future has been poisoned by political rivalries, the longstanding hostility of New Yorkers toward owner George Steinbrenner, and his refusal to say exactly what the city would have to do in order to keep the Yankees in New York. Now that team, owner and city are a mutual admiration society, they might be able to resolve their differences in a way that benefits everyone.

title: Airline Dining, No Soup to No Nuts
description: DIETING ALOFT was already rampant in late 1995 when American Airlines discovered that it could save $100,000 a year by removing one olive from each salad it served to its passengers. But this was just the tip of the iceberg lettuce, for other airlines have gone far beyond merely deregulating salad: they have been canceling whole meals in the hope that passengers have eaten in the terminal.

title: Man Charged in Stabbings
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested on Friday and charged with killing his half-sister and her 4-year-old daughter in their Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment last April, the police said.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Campaign '96, R.I.P.
description: The 1996 Presidential campaign is staggering to a close with a blizzard of complaints about the candidates and the lack of suspense. But the sour emotion should not divert attention from the potentially important trends underlying the electoral contests. Whoever wins on Tuesday, the center has re-emerged as the pivotal place in American politics, and centrist voters, while more tough-minded, still favor a Federal role in guarding the health and security of Americans and their environment.

title: 100 Years of Books
description: To the Editor:

title: On Ballot, Money to Dredge and Clean
description: Two statewide questions will be on the ballot Tuesday.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Oct. 20 about Wendy Brackman, an artist who makes hats from paper plates, misattributed a joke book on her shelf. It is ''Henny Youngman's Private Joke Book,'' not Benny Goodman's.

title: Yeltsin Gets a New Close Confidante: His Daughter
description: As he prepares for his heart bypass operation, President Boris N. Yeltsin is not taking phone calls, meeting with aides or even glancing at briefing papers. His one liaison to the Kremlin and the political world roiling around it is the person who has in the last six months become his closest confidante and adviser -- his daughter, Tatyana Dyachenko.

title: Kicks and Burn, for Athletes
description: IT was 9:15 on a Monday morning, and Todd Mossa was becoming impatient. Like the rest of his teammates, the 6-foot4, 290-pound senior lineman had spent the summer preparing for the football season, working hard enough to be named a top player by both ESPN and USA Today. But here it was, the first day of practice, and Helen Ingraham was late. A restless murmur filled the Darien High School gym.

title: A Market-Moving Guru Plans to Run Funds
description: FOR three months, Elaine Garzarelli has predicted the United States stock market will fall by 15 to 25 percent. Now, she wants to put your money where her mouth is.

title: Village Voices
description: THE ORCHARD ON FIRE

title: To Pry or Not to Pry?
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON promised ''a campaign of ideas and issues, not insults,'' by which, of course, he hoped to shield himself against another round of stories about pot, women, Indonesian moneybags and draft board correspondence. Senator Dole bragged of his lower cholesterol count and greater experience, by which, of course, he meant to deflect suggestions that he was too old to be President. But both candidates beat the subliminal drums. Clinton slyly claimed ''the future'' to consign his opponent to ''the past.'' Dole piously shouted ''character,'' hoping the media would fill in the blanks.

title: Extra!
description: TABLOID DREAMS

title: Candidate Loses Before Election
description: Julio C. Ramirez will not be on the ballot for State Senate in Tuesday's election, even though dozens of voters may have already voted for him.

title: A Method to Avoid the Madness
description: Selecting the right college is an important step in the life of a teen-ager, but many stumble on this threshold, weaving through the process in a haphazard and disorganized way. Facing mountains of information, they are more to be pitied than criticized for this deficiency.

title: Farewell to a 'Big Man'
description: On a recent autumn evening, as Senator John Breaux stood at a podium hailing Senator Bennett Johnston, a fellow Louisiana Democrat, he surveyed a sea of old friends who had gathered inside a Washington auditorium to observe Johnston's pending retirement. Many of them, he said, might have been ''broke and lost without Bennett Johnston in the Senate.'' Like? Like the next man up: Daryl Owen, Johnston's chief of staff for a time in the 80's and now one of Washington's most powerful lobbyists. ''He has made a fortune in the private sector, let's face it,'' Breaux laughed.

title: Kerry vs. Weld: An 'Elegant Hammering' of a Race Remains a Tossup
description: Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, as ruddy as a Yorkshireman, sat in his State House office beneath a heroic portrait of that jolly rogue, James Michael Curley, one of its earlier occupants, as his campaign against Senator John Kerry approached its final weekend.

title: Shaving Fares On the Shuttle
description: LAST summer, I spent a lot of time trying to find a cheap shuttle trip to Boston, a daunting task because the advertised shuttle fares represent perhaps the highest per-mile rate in the country, a result of the predominance of business travelers in the Northeast corridor. But I knew there were weekend discounts and I had a couple of coupons. There was also the possibility of an airline senior coupon book that could mean a cheaper fare if I needed to take the trip more than once in a year.

title: Just Say God Did It
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture on pages 66 and 67 of The Times Magazine today showing a house in San Francisco is reproduced in mirror image. The living-room table with the books should appear at the right.

title: A Keeper of the Flame of Jewish Culture
description: FOR those American Jews who may or may not be religious but are interested in staying connected to the culture of their ancestors, there is the 96-year-old Workmen's Circle.

title: A Reopening at Longwood
description: After two years of reconstruction, the central conservatory at Longwood Gardens, the 1,050-acre former estate of the chemical magnate Pierre du Pont near Kennett Square, Pa., has reopened to the public. The Beaux Arts-style structure is considered the most significant of Longwood's 22 conservatories, which were designed by J. Walter Cope, a Du Pont Company architect, and originally opened in 1921.

title: Tax Could Lower Pay
description: If the owners somehow ratify the labor agreement at their meeting in Chicago on Wednesday, Major League Baseball will have a new economic scorekeeping system. The revolutionary luxury tax will change how player payrolls are computed.

title: If You Need Help
description: These local programs are run by the New Jersey Coalition of Battered Women. They provide shelter and counseling for abused women and their children, free of charge.

title: 100 Years of Books
description: To the Editor:

title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Miami Heat Sweetens Deal To Make Case For an Arena
description: The Miami Heat basketball team has agreed to cover the entire $165 million cost of building a new arena here under an agreement with Dade County officials, in response to widespread opposition to the use of public money for the construction.

title: Labor Deal in Jeopardy as Selig Stays Silent
description: When they meet in Chicago on Wednesday, baseball's team owners will decide whether they want to have peace with the players for the next four years under terms their chief labor executive has negotiated or renew the war from which their business has still not recovered. Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, is apparently not afraid of a renewed war.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A CIVIL WAR

title: Paul A. Burke, Elizabeth A. Schaefer
description: Elizabeth Allen Schaefer, a daughter of Blaine and Cris Hayden Schaefer of Woodbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul Aloysius Burke, a son of Mary H. Burke of Buffalo and the late Howard V. Burke. The Rev. Wallace Matson performed the ceremony at the North Congregational Church in Woodbury.

title: Suzanne Crerend, L. W. Vandervoorn
description: Suzanne Marie Crerend, the daughter of Dolores and William J. Crerend of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lawrence Wynn Vandervoorn, a son of Cornelius J. M. Vandervoorn of West Simsbury, Conn., and Jacquelin McKenzie of Frederick, Md.

title: Caryn Goodman, Mitchell Caplan
description: Dr. Caryn R. Goodman, a daughter of Rosalyn and Lawrence Goodman of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last evening to Mitchell L. Caplan, a son of Joyce and Donald Caplan of Rockville, Md. Rabbi Henry Glazer performed the ceremony at the Fair Lawn Jewish Center.

title: At a Distance, Zimmer Welcomes Dole
description: By 2:30 yesterday morning, the aisles of the Bendix Diner in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., were so packed with Republican faithful that fire marshals showed up to tell anyone who did not have a seat to move outside.

title: A Desert Spreads A Welcome Mat
description: EARLY this century, an American explorer named Roy Chapman Andrews fought off pistol-toting brigands as he drove a caravan through the Gobi Desert in Mongolia in search of dinosaur remains. Later known as the inspiration for Indiana Jones, the archeologist hero of adventure movies, Mr. Andrews carefully recorded his dangerous exploits and his deep appreciation for the hidden beauties of the desert.

title: Big Bird Teaches Little Ones To Prevent Lead Poisoning
description: It goes without saying that Big Bird and the Cookie Monster do more for children than entertain them. Now, these ''Sesame Street'' characters are teaching youngsters in the Newark area the dangers of dirt and dust in old buildings where peeling paint is contaminated with lead.

title: Orthodox Jews Confront Domestic Violence
description: In a community sometimes characterized as insular, the quiet work of a few Jewish women has taken hold in the last year in a way that could be considered quite radical.

title: Memoirs Without the Revelations
description: Almost by definition, a good memoir is self-revelatory. Almost by definition, a good politician is not. Over the course of the long months leading up to Tuesday's election, these two simple truths appear to have been overlooked by the publishing industry and, perhaps even more surprisingly, by politicians themselves. Practically everyone who had an eye on the White House in 1996 has written -- or at least had ghostwritten for him -- a version of his life story.

title: New Threat to Drug Agency
description: For Promesa, a community group heralded for its drug rehabilitation program, the downward spiral began on a December night in 1992. Lillian DeJesus, an accountant who had discovered discrepancies in Promesa's books, was shot execution style. A caseworker at the agency was later charged with hiring two teen-agers to carry out the killing.

title: Violins for Finale Of Jerusalem 3000
description: Five of the world's leading violinists -- Itzhak Perlman, Pinchas Zukerman, Midori, Shlomo Mintz and Gil Shaham -- will appear with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra under Zubin Mehta on Dec. 28 in the International Convention Center in Jerusalem to mark the conclusion of the 15-month-long Jerusalem 3000 celebration. The violinists will perform music in homage to King David, who designated Jerusalem as the capital of the Kingdom of Israel 3,000 years ago.

title: ELECTION '96
description: THE CHOICE - A look at how Bob Dole and Bill Clinton compare on more than a dozen issues. Page 38.

title: 'The Tailor of Panama'
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Block Broad St.
description: To the Editor:

title: F-16 Fighter on Patrol Over Iraq Fires on a Radar Site, U.S. Says
description: An American jet fighter fired on an Iraqi radar installation in southern Iraq early on Saturday in the first American attack on Iraqi forces in more than a month, Administration officials acknowledged today.

title: For Asian-Americans, Political Power Can Lead to Harsh Scrutiny
description: For years, when Asian-American leaders discussed their frustrating struggle to gain political influence, they often used idealistic terms like ''empowerment,'' but when a small group of Asian-American business executives met over breakfast in Washington last spring to plot a strategy for this election year, the talks turned on a new phrase: ''bundling.''

title: Bad News on Scallops, Thanks to Brown Tide
description: ''I HOPE you don't have any scallops in that boat,'' an East Hampton marine officer, Don Bousson, warned a bayman, Stuart Heath, who was coming in from his first morning of the year scalloping in Lake Montauk.

title: 'Volunteering' Should Mean Just That
description: To the Editor:

title: John Henderson McNeill, 55, Legal Adviser to the Pentagon
description: John Henderson McNeill, a senior legal adviser in the Defense Department on issues ranging from arms control to matters pending before the World Court in The Hague, died on Oct. 26 in the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. He was 55 and lived in Washington.

title: When Builders Take Wing
description: IN THE CATEGORY OF DESIGNED things that architecture critics usually ignore but that have a profound effect on the quality of life, airplanes and airports rank high. Who thinks much about airplanes as works of design? As engineering, yes, but as design, almost never. And how often do airports show up in the architecture books? We talk a great deal about the experience of air travel but not about how the work of architects and industrial designers can make it better or worse.

title: The Kings of Flatbush
description: As the neighborhood around the Loew's Kings undergoes a development renaissance, the city is attempting to sell the theater. The city's Economic Development Corp. is expected to invite developers to make new proposals for the property within the next month or so. SARAH KERSHAW

title: Excuses, Excuses: Why 9 Big Funds Sank
description: FIDELITY MAGELLAN isn't the only mega mutual fund to have let down a lot of investors over the last year, even as markets have rallied and cheered so many.

title: The Master Skeptic Steps Aside
description: ON A RECENT MORNING at his quiet office in the Washington bureau of ABC News, David Brinkley looked and sounded -- as he often does on his Sunday-morning program, ''This Week With David Brinkley'' -- like a man who had been woken too early. With his heavy-lidded eyes and laconic, halting manner of speaking, which distinguished him when he was a co-host of the groundbreaking ''Huntley-Brinkley Report'' in the 1950's and 1960's, Mr. Brinkley has always seemed unusually sedate for a television newsman. Now, at the age of 76, he seems more so: his shoulders slouch a bit, his soft-featured face is smaller and more drawn, and his voice, no doubt affected by lung surgery last year, is sometimes weak.

title: What Drives a Batterer? Issues of Control
description: COMPLAINTS by battered spouses -- women and men -- increased sharply last year, as did deaths caused by domestic partners. In New Jersey, reports of domestic violence increased 22 percent over 1994, to 86,213, in part because the authorities take it more seriously and because more women are seeking help. And 61 adults were killed by domestic violence, compared to 42 in 1994.

title: RUNNING AGAINST HILLARY
description: In Elisabeth Bumiller's article ''Running Against Hillary'' (Oct. 13), Arizona's Republican Senator John McCain is quoted as saying (in describing an exchange between Elizabeth Dole and her husband): ''It was not like a wife. It was like a peer discussion.''

title: 3 New Michelin Guides Rate the Sights
description: Three destinations are getting Michelin Green Guides of their own for the first time. The new books are on Venice, Brussels and Scandinavia, including Finland. The guides rate sights with one (interesting), two (highly recommended) or three stars (very highly recommended).

title: The Bride Wore Fatigues?
description: If you're planning a decidedly off-road wedding -- in a swamp, say, or a remote desert -- the party will not be complete without this Hummer stretch limousine, which rumbled into the Limo Digest Show in Atlantic City last week. Just make sure the bridesmaids wear boots.

title: Cold Cereal and a Hot Scene
description: Late on Sunday mornings, Robert Eby stands inside the front doors of E. J.'s Luncheonette on Third Avenue at 73d Street, clutching his clipboard with The List, the names of 50, sometimes 60 people (mostly in their 20's) who are waiting to get in.

title: G.M.'s Ticket: Family Values
description: Ending a virtual drought of new products, General Motors greets 1997 with a flood of new models, providing nearly every kind of family transportation one can imagine. Each vehicle will be aimed at a specific type of buyer, the central tenet of the company's new Procter & Gamble-style ''brand management'' strategy.

title: The Monster Builder
description: THE ARCHITECT OF DESIRE

title: 100 Years of Books
description: To the Editor:

title: A Guide to Where the Candidates Stand
description: During a combined total of more than 60 years in public office, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole have shown themselves adaptable politicians, more likely to cut deals than to insist on ideology. Still, on a multitude of issues, deep gulfs divide them. Here are some examples. ROBERT PEAR

title: Free TV-Time Experiment Wins Support, if Not Viewers
description: Three of the four major broadcast networks, plus PBS and CNN, gave away high-priced minutes of prime television time to the Presidential candidates this fall, hoping to produce more virtuous and issues-centered dialogue than is found in political advertisements as well as more extensive comment than is found in 10-second network news sound bites.

title: No, It's Not a Bathroom Scale
description: It's a Japanese solar-powered car from the Honda team en route to the World Solar Challenge in Australia.

title: Why Lillian Hellman Remains Fascinating
description: THERE IS STILL SO MUCH OF Lillian Hellman around, it's beginning to appear that she beat death just as she beat so many other career setbacks. In the 12 years since she died, she has been the subject of five books, two of which, mine and another, were full biographies. Her plays continue to be performed, and they are performed more frequently than the works of male playwrights like Maxwell Anderson, Robert Sherwood and Clifford Odets -- all of whom, in their day, were considered her betters. Her work will be back in New York this spring with a new Lincoln Center Theater production of ''The Little Foxes'' starring Stockard Channing as Regina.

title: Gayle Johnson, B. S. Worthington
description: Gayle McCrimmon Johnson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Johnson Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Bradford Scott Worthington, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Worthington of Trumbull, Conn. The Rev. Jonathan B. Coffey Jr. performed the ceremony at St. James the Less Episcopal Church.

title: THE WARS OF ALEKSANDR IVANOVICH LEBED
description: In Michael Specter's article ''The Wars of Aleksandr Ivanovich Lebed'' (Oct. 13), Lebed was compared to Lenin by a rival, as having ''been on every side of every issue.'' A more accurate comparison would be to President Clinton and most of our other recent Presidents, Ronald Reagan excluded.

title: Judge Says Yes To Loehmann's
description: Opponents of the construction of a Loehmann's Plaza on Emmons Avenue have lost another round. Led by the Bay Improvement Group, they went to court in an effort to block development of the 28,000-square-foot shopping center, but were rebuffed last week when a State Supreme Court justice affirmed the city Board of Standards and Appeals' approval of the project. The store is expected to open this month.

title: Study and Involvement In Breast Cancer Battle
description: We are the principal investigator and project coordinator of the Long Island Breast Cancer Study Project, the focus of the article ''I Got Breast Cancer, Why Me?'' (Oct. 13) by Bea Tusiani.

title: The Wretched of Broadway
description: The French proletariats of ''Les Miserables'' are up in arms. But who should they attack first? Last Sunday the cast of ''Les Miz'' was told, in a decree worthy of the Bourbons, that most of the 37 actors would lose their jobs in January. John Caird, the co-director of the musical, announced that he and Cameron Mackintosh, the producer, had seen the show recently and had not been amused. It was suffering, said Mr. Caird, from ''long-run-itis.''

title: Judy Zecchin And John Mayo
description: Judy Zecchin and John Richard Mayo, both lawyers, were married yesterday in Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Constance Wilkerson performed the ceremony at Old First Presbyterian Church.

title: Marathon Today
description: Streets on the New York Marathon route will be closed for much of the day. These are the major ones: In Manhattan, First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge; Fifth Avenue from 138th Street to 102d Street, and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Columbus Circle. In Brooklyn, parts of Fourth Avenue from 83d Street to Flatbush Avenue, and portions of Lafayette Avenue and Bedford Avenue.

title: Winning the Series Can Be Dangerous
description: As euphoric as the final out of the World Series was for John Wetteland, the pile that ensued on the mound at Yankee Stadium was frightening for him. That's because the Yankee closer was on the bottom.

title: Skating's Top Pairs Include Two Rangers
description: ''Skaters seem to inhabit a world apart,'' observe Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean, who write that skaters can ''sweep in close to people watching, make them see the sweat and feel the wind as they swirl past, only to fly away again.''

title: Sophisticated Food but at Half the Price
description: SCARSDALE Avenue Cafe is a very Manhattan kind of eating spot, but at half the price. Each dining area has considerable charm: the entry room is glassed in like a bright porch, and beautifully draped swags frame the windows; more sophisticated is the inner room with its murals, long banquette and handsome bar. Three visits to this honey of a restaurant brought slightly mixed results. We encountered a few mistakes but many more splendid dishes. The cooking here is careful and creative and the presentations eye-catching.

title: Rights for Crime Victims
description: THE family of James B. Irwin Jr. has been outspoken about its treatment in the Litchfield County murder case where John Tyler Fussenich was on trial in the murder of their son.

title: When the Candidate Is a Kidnapper
description: THE political ads bray their surly epithets: Liberal! Medicare-slasher! Clone of Newt!

title: Peekskill Students Hail Renewed Planetarium
description: AT the first class session held in the newly renovated and refurbished planetarium at Peekskill High School, Delwin Guiao, 14, a ninth grader in the Regents Honors Earth Science class gave what may be the most practical reason for studying astronomy. ''Someday there may be trouble on Earth and we may have to leave our planet to go elsewhere,'' he said.

title: Go Directly to Jail
description: BODY COUNTMoral Poverty . . . and How to Win America's War Against Crime and Drugs.By William J. Bennett, John J. DiIulio Jr. and John P. Walters.271 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: KICKING TIRES

title: There Must Be an Easier Way to Win $30,000
description: THE winners of the New York City Marathon will each hobble home today with at least $30,000 and a brand-new Toyota sedan.

title: The Four Rules Of Politics, By Nick Fish
description: For Nicholas Fish, politics is the family trade, but even he is quick to admit he has learned a few things in the bare-knuckle world of Manhattan politics. The scion of a political family that dates to the American Revolution, Mr. Fish, 38, was for three years chairman of Community Board 5, which covers midtown. He resigned last month to join his wife and daughter in Oregon. In an interview in his last week on the job, Mr. Fish distilled his political experiences into these four maxims.

title: Recipe for Corporate Disaster
description: CALIFORNIA'S initiative process is viewed by most Americans with a sense of grateful detachment in the belief that the impact of these referendums is rarely felt outside the state.

title: Students Take a Break to Help Others
description: Dan Moore, was a long way from Puerta Vallarta, a resort town in Mexico, where he enjoyed a fun-in-the-sun spring break as a college freshman three and a half years ago. He was on Chicago's South Side for the spring break of his sophomore year, sleeping on a cold tile floor in a converted storage room in the Dearborn housing projects.

title: F.B.I., in Reversal, Decides to Keep Agents on Saudi Bomb Case
description: One day after Federal authorities said the F.B.I. Director had pulled agents off the investigation of the June bombing in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 American airmen, the agency reversed itself today and issued a statement saying some agents would remain on the case.

title: George M. Grover, 81, Inventor Of Popular Heat Transfer Device
description: George M. Grover, a nuclear physicist who developed a deceptively simple heat-transfer system that helps devices like satellites and lap-top computers operate more efficiently, died on Oct. 24 at a nursing home in Albuquerque, N.M., where he lived. He was 81.

title: A Designer Whose Specialty Was the Sunny Side
description: THE DESIGNER Lester Beall is in the tradition of artists whose work has been informed by a distinctly American childhood. The summers he spent at his grandparents' farm in Missouri endowed his poster art with a powerful directness and simplicity: bare-bone images, vivid colors and lettering as lean as paper clips.

title: Garden Opener Promises Emotion
description: They didn't handle the ball very well. They didn't have any more fouls to give. When the offense broke down, the kick-out jump shot became their weapon of choice.

title: When the Consultant's Cure Is Worse Than the Ailment
description: Guess who has an image problem? Could it be those busybodies known as consultants? So the recent mail would indicate. But not to worry. Surely someone out there knows how to restore their tarnished image. All that consultants need is some advice from a good consultant. As to how some consultants earned their reputations, read on.

title: Q and A
description: Fishing in Spain

title: Eldredge and Kwan Out-Leap Competition
description: Todd Eldredge and Michelle Kwan, the world figure-skating champions, acted the part this afternoon and night in winning the singles titles in the season's first major competition, the Thrifty Car Rental Skate America International.

title: Orangeman Are Showing No Mercy
description: The near-capacity crowd that gathered at Mountaineer Field today had thinned considerably by the end of the second quarter. It was cold, it was windy and West Virginia was trailing Syracuse by 27-0.

title: Search for Scholarships Can Be a Bitter Lesson
description: JESSE SALDANA 3d's dreams of an athletic scholarship to the University of Texas at El Paso crumbled along with his knee during a high school football game in his senior year. Without the money, his parents doubted that they could afford to send him to the school. But then he was reached by a company that guaranteed to find him a scholarship or grant.

title: Portugal's Untraveled Northeast
description: IN the Minho, the cabbages are jade green and monstrous. They grow to wild heights of six feet, and patches of them adorn the blue-tiled train stations through which we shuttled as we made our way, by bus and train, through the small towns scattered about this remote region of northernmost Portugal. When the train slowed down, I could reach out the window and touch the plants. Vines, too, were taller than I had ever seen. Instead of white picket fences or concrete walls I saw thick, crawling Bacchanalian creepers, turned crimson and yellow by the autumn sun. And though I was there in November, roses were everywhere, like pink and yellow weeds, climbing church walls, spilling into cafes. It was when the landscape turned to vines, roses and cabbages that I knew I had reached the Minho.

title: Even Met Fans Join In
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dublin's Adopted Irish Conquer
description: If St. Patrick had made a miraculous appearance in Croke Park today, he could hardly have received more clamorous support than the Notre Dame football team did.

title: The Nanny Track
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A quiz answer today on page 41 of the special Education Life section misidentifies the Presidential candidate who received the highest percentage of electoral votes ever cast. Except for George Washington, who ran unopposed, the highest percentage of electoral votes went to James Monroe, with 99.57 percent in the 1820 campaign against John Quincy Adams. Ronald Reagan did receive the most electoral votes, in the 1984 election against Walter F. Mondale, but the percentage was only 97.58.

title: Ms. Perez-Marques And Mr. Baron
description: Gabriela Maria Sofia Perez-Marques, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Segundo A. Perez of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Howard Baron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett J. Baron of Woodbury, L.I. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Jones Trying to Break 26.2-Mile Jinx
description: The offer was for lunch, but Kim Jones politely declined. After a bout of food poisoning four years ago, she was taking no chances with restaurants in the days before the New York City Marathon. She brought her own food, oatmeal and rice, along with a rice cooker and her own coffee pot from home in Spokane, Wash. And as a precaution against chronic asthma, she had the hotel change the air filter in her room.

title: Newest Recruiting Tool is on Line
description: When Anne Stevens decided to transfer to a different college for her junior year, she turned to friends -- and to her computer -- for information.

title: A Tale of Two 'Tales of Hoffmann'
description: SOME OF THE MOST POPULAR works of art ever were left incomplete by their creators, from Gilbert Stuart's abandoned portrait of George Washington, immortalized on the dollar bill, to Schubert's ''Unfinished'' Symphony. These great torsos deserve their popularity. If anything, their incompleteness lends them special poignancy.

title: War Crimes Tribunal Is a Legal Imperative
description: To the Editor:

title: Fly Bowser, or Whatever Fits the Flagpole
description: IN case you haven't noticed, and that's hardly possible, there's a whole lot of flags fluttering in the breezes lately.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Swimming the ChannelBy Sally Friedman.Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.

title: Laura A. Ward, Barry S. Smulian
description: Laura Alice Ward, an assistant United States attorney, and Barry Scott Smulian, a pharmaceutical sales representative, are to be married today in New York. Rabbi Daniel P. Alder is to perform the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue.

title: When the Best Policy May Be No Policy at All
description: DASHING through the airport, you pass a Mutual of Omaha insurance kiosk. Scenes of T.W.A. Flight 800 flash before your eyes. You already have life insurance, but is it enough? Now you can get $300,000 worth of flight-accident coverage for a mere $6 a trip. You know you're being foolish -- the taxi to the airport was far more dangerous than the flight to Dallas -- but you sign up.

title: For the Electorally Challenged
description: It's almost Election Day. A friend isn't planning to go to the polls, saying one vote won't make a difference. What would you say to change his mind?

title: Bound for Washington? Voters Will Soon Decide
description: FIRST DISTRICT

title: Giuliani Plan On Tuition Fails to Move
description: Almost two months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani pledged to find a way to move 1,000 failing public-school students to religious schools, not one student has been transferred, no contributions have been collected and there is not even a bank account for donations.

title: How To Survive a Campus Visit
description: Choosing a college is difficult, and to help you decide, colleges and universities offer formal admissions tours, alumni information sessions and a variety of video and audio guides to campuses. But the best way to get to know a campus is at ground level, by spending a weekend in a dorm with other students. Here's the lowdown on how to get the most out of the experience:

title: Courses at Your Convenience
description: A student in Tisha Bender's Reading for Writing class at the New School for Social Research in New York City wanted to contribute to an ongoing class discussion.

title: What's Hanging on Your Neighbors' Walls
description: ''PASSIONATE Pursuits,'' the title of a serendipitous but substantial exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum, refers to the enthusiasm and avidity of New Jersey art collectors. But it also characterizes the hunt for collectors that produced this show of 140 works from 60 collections, subtitled ''Hidden Treasures of the Garden State.''

title: Bernard Holmes, 82, Monk and Educator
description: The Rev. Bernard George Holmes, a Benedictine educator who was credited with doubling the size of St. Anselm College in Manchester, N.H., died on Oct. 24 at Catholic Medical Center in Manchester. A monk at St. Anselm Abbey, he was 82.

title: Rye Gets a Proposal for a 'New Urban' Mini-Village
description: BORROWING from the concept of the ''new urbanism,'' which advocates building self-contained communities that resemble samll towns, a development partnership has advanced a $100 million proposal to turn a 140-acre former hospital site here into a sort of mini-village, complete with housing, an office building and a village green.

title: Little Dishes, Big Flavors From Spain
description: PIKA TAPAS CAFE, a newcomer to New Haven, is the latest of three eating places opened by Ignacio Blanco, proprietor of the first and best, Meson Galicia in Norwalk.

title: A Movement Misses Its Nurturing Mother
description: When the hostility from his family became too much to bear, Denny Dromm, a gay rights advocate based in Queens, always turned to Jeanne Manford for consolation.

title: BASEBALL'S GLORY DAYS ARE . . . NOW
description: As enthusiasm for baseball has faded among many of my 20-something peers in recent years, having been replaced by football, basketball and hockey, sports that have more flash, less poetry and require less patience, I remain a diehard baseball freak (''Baseball's Glory Days Are . . . Now,'' Oct. 6). In his article, Allen Barra uses the record-shattering statistics of contemporary stars to make exactly the point that I've been making to anyone who will listen: To watch Tony Gwynn hit or Greg Maddux pitch is to witness a thing of absolute beauty.

title: Preserving Pop-Culture Treasures
description: Syracuse University's Street & Smith Archive -- a trove of pop-culture icons including the earliest comic books, scripts of 1930's radio shows like ''The Shadow'' and mass-market magazines like Love Story Magazine -- has been steadily disintegrating into piles of crumbling wood pulp. Access to scholars has been curtailed and photocopying of materials is no longer allowed.

title: 100 Years of Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution Is Harder
description: To the Editor:

title: Caryn J. Karmatz And Lee D. Rudy
description: Caryn Julie Karmatz, a daughter of Anne and Michael Karmatz of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., was married last evening to Lee David Rudy, the son of Lynne and Michael Rudy of Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Ivan Caine, a cousin of the bride, officiated at the College of Physicians of Philadelphia.

title: Good Sports, With Finesse or Brute Force
description: BABY boomers are having midlife crises, and yes, a fire-engine-red roadster may be the best revenge, but how many of these toys can the market bear? For '97, Mercedes-Benz and Porsche are unveiling their two-passenger convertibles, up-market from the Honda del Sol, Mazda Miata and BMW Z3.

title: Memo to Guilt-Ridden Parents
description: FROM their rueful scheduling of a child's first play date to their serving of yet another takeout dinner in its aluminum tray, one thing seems to unite New York parents: guilt.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Dancing With Death
description: Alvin Ailey

title: WHY NEGATIVE ADS ARE GOOD FOR DEMOCRACY
description: ON SEPT. 4, THE REAL CAMPAIGN FOR BILL BRADLEY'S SENATE SEAT began secretly in a conference room at the Sheraton Hotel in Woodbridge, N.J. About 70 people, recruited by a market-research firm offering $40 for two hours' work, sat there with meters recording their reactions to a dozen television commercials. They weren't told the source of the commercials, but it quickly became obvious. One ad praised the Democratic candidate, Representative Bob Torricelli, as a man with ''our values.'' The rest were chiefly devoted to savaging his Republican opponent, Representative Dick Zimmer.

title: Vying for the Breast Vote
description: FORGET the deficit. Forget taxes. Forget Medicare. Politicians, hoping to appeal to women, are now engaged in the battle of the breast.

title: Experimental Drug May Be Better Than Aspirin for Angina
description: An experimental drug works better than the standard treatment, aspirin, to treat a dangerous heart condition that leads to more than 570,000 hospital admissions in the United States each year, researchers reported on Friday.

title: Jennifer Prehn, Jeremy Lewis
description: Jennifer Anne Prehn, a daughter of Sherry Prehn and Dr. John Prehn of Sherborn, Mass., was married on Oct. 26 to Peter Jeremy Lewis, a son of Barbara and Salim Lewis of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth Powell, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at Castle Hill, a historic house in Ipswich, Mass.

title: THE KINDEST CUT
description: Gee whiz. If I had known that having breast cancer was so much fun and so cosmetically enhancing, I would have endeavored to have had this disease sooner (Lives: ''The Kindest Cut,'' by Melissa Bloch, Oct. 6).

title: Redress For Broken Nest Eggs
description: WHEN a worker loses money in a 401(k) or similar retirement plan, is the company or the worker responsible? Generally, the worker is, because he chose where to put his money.

title: A Circle Long Unbroken
description: CIRCLE REP ENDED rather as it had begun, performing an obscure play in a small, upper-story theater space with few seats and fewer prospects.

title: Preparing Before, Enjoying After
description: THE best dinner parties are those the host or hostess can enjoy. This, of course, means preparing food ahead so that a minimum of time has to be spent in the kitchen after guests have arrived. The following dinner for 10 is manageable even for someone preparing it alone. A marinated leg of lamb is roasted and served with flageolets, baked eggplant and tomatoes. Dessert is a caramelized pear tart served warm with creme fraiche.

title: Garden Roars This Time for a Four-Footed Hero: Cigar
description: The Yankees used up all the ticker tape in New York City, and Cigar was probably grateful for that small favor when it came time for his much-publicized surprise retirement party (well, it came as a surprise to him) yesterday in midtown Manhattan.

title: Sharon Nybro, Michael Moran Jr.
description: Sharon Nybro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans R. Nybro of Prince's Bay, S.I., was married yesterday to Michael Arthur Moran Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moran of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. David Schalekamp officiated at the Huguenot Reformed Church in Huguenot, S.I. Msgr. James Tahaney took part in the ceremony.

title: Body Identified as Clubgoer
description: The New York City Medical Examiner's office, using dental X-rays, has identified a legless corpse that washed ashore in Staten Island last April as the body of Andre J. Melendez, a 26-year-old man who disappeared in March.

title: A Savvy Pick for Japanese Food Lovers
description: YUKI'S PALETTE is a savy pick for diners who love Japanese food and for those who rarely eat it. The new Westbury storefront showcases ''sushi and exquisite American-Japanese cuisine.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Other Entertainment

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 1 6 THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (Viking, $23.95.) The disappearance of a 3-year-old boy brings a family anguish and redemption. 2 2 4 DESPERATION, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) Visitors to a small mining town in Nevada encounter terrifying forces. 3 3 10 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) Vice President Jack Ryan has problems after the deaths of the President and most of the Cabinet, Congress, the Joint Chiefs and the Supreme Court. 4 4 4 THE REGULATORS, by Richard Bachman. (Dutton, $24.95.) Killings and other horrors disrupt a quiet suburban town in Ohio. 5 1 MY GAL SUNDAY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) The autobiography of the host of ''The Tonight Show.'' 12 3 HIS HOLINESS, by Carl Bernstein and Marco Politi. (Doubleday, $27.50.) The role played by Pope John Paul II in the fall of Communism in Europe. 13 6 6 THE RUN OF HIS LIFE, by Jeffrey Toobin. (Random House, $25.) An account of the O. J. Simpson trial by a journalist and former prosecutor. 14 1 AMERICAN TRAGEDY, by Lawrence Schiller and James Willwerth. (Random House, $27.50.) The O. J. Simpson trial seen from the defense team's viewpoint. 15* 14 3 DOWNSIZE THIS! by Michael Moore. (Crown, $21.) Observations on the current social and political scene by the director of ''Roger & Me.''
