(+) 3 3 33 THE ZONE, by Barry Sears with Bill Lawren. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $23.) Diets to prevent disease and enhance mental health. (+) 4 30 SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+)

title: Sunday November 3, 1996: VOTING MECHANICS
description: ''It's like the Foreign Legion -- march or die,'' says Sam Cunningham, a Manhattan elections official who helps get 5,600 New York City voting machines to 1,250 polling places. With scores of mechanisms to set manually, it took a month to ready the ballots on the half-ton machines, another week to put them all on site. Some date back to the 60's, but don't expect to see lighter electronic models anytime soon. A few have been tested in the Bronx, but some question how the microchips will fare in transit over New York's bumpy streets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-21

title: Limestone Remnant of Fifth Avenue's Chateau Days
description: BIG mansion, limited budget. That's what the Ukrainian Institute of America has with its magnificent but slightly dog-eared 1898 chateau at 2 East 79th Street. Now the owners are beginning a modest restoration campaign for this refreshingly unrestored house.

title: Julius Raskin, 90, A Retired Principal
description: Julius Raskin, a retired educator in New York City public schools who worked on programs designed to widen students' horizons, died on Oct. 9 at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in the Bronx. A former resident of Manhattan, he was 90 and lived in the Bronx.

title: Virtual Bob Dole
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Heffernan, Mr. Bradshaw 3d
description: Caroline Luttrell Heffernan and William Daniel Bradshaw 3d were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Samuel Abbott performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A rich variety of gems - two mysteries, an Italian mosaic and a political staire - peep out from the movie treasure chest this week.

title: Correction
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about Congressional elections was published in error. It showed Representative Robert L. Livingston. Representative David R. Obey, who would become the chairman of the Appropriations Committee if the Democrats regain control of the House, appears at the left. (Photo: David R. Obey)

title: LET OUR CHILDREN GO
description: John Tierney's solution of letting the American public bow out of public education in the name of choice is shortsighted (The Big City: ''Let Our Children Go,'' Oct. 6).

title: Claire Corter, Andrew Hunter
description: Claire Bailey Corter and Andrew Michael Hunter were married in Richmond yesterday. The Rev. Thom Williamson Blair Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: 18-Story Building Makeover, With a 9-Floor Garage
description: AFTER a three-year downtown hiatus, construction cranes for office buildings are expected to rise again next spring when a mothballed 40-year-old building is renovated as the new headquarters for Morgan Lewis & Bockius, the nation's third-largest law firm, with 825 lawyers in 14 offices worldwide.

title: ZAIRE REBELS TAKE A TOWN WITH HELP OF RWANDAN ARMY
description: The town of Goma fell to Zairian rebels and Rwandan troops this morning. The United Nations evacuated its foreign staff, leaving hundreds of thousands of refugees in nearby camps with only a few days' supply of food and warfare raging all around them.

title: A Touch of Japan
description: IT was Frances Kelley, and not her husband, James, the extrovert, who stood on the cushions of the built-in sectional in the conversation pit and began ripping the hand-painted panels of Japanese trees off the Shoji screen partitions.

title: THE KINDEST CUT
description: Melissa Bloch's Lives essay is the first positive piece I have read on the subject of mastectomy. I felt a shock of recognition, since her experiences and feelings paralleled mine after my mastectomy at the age of 63.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: A Cool Head At the Eye Of the Calm
description: AS HE DEMONSTRATED WHEN HE moderated the campaign pseudodebates, Jim Lehrer is no showboat. That is a considerable distinction for television, where the interrogators are often bigger stars than their guests or victims. This man of modest mien keeps the spotlight on the person being questioned. His somewhat halting conversational manner invites rather than commands. And his professional principles dispel any fears that he is out to get not just his guests' point of view but also the guests themselves.

title: Shunpiking To the Sunshine
description: THREE times my husband and I have driven in leisurely fashion, rather than flown, between our winter home just south of Palm Beach, in Manalapan, Fla., and our home outside Philadelphia.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday with an article about the role of women in the electorate reversed the party affiliations of the two candidates. Stephanie H. Sanchez is a Democrat, Lisa E. Mason a Republican.

title: Soon, People May Talk of Chris Penn's Big Brother
description: NEVER MIND THE torrential downpour or the twilight darkness on this Saturday afternoon in New York. Disregard, too, the fact that he's nearly drenched in his hooded navy sweatshirt, blue Levis and black cowboy boots, and that he charges in and out of stores and restaurants with a bulk and a low center of gravity befitting his roots as a former high school wrestler. On screen or off, wet or dry, Chris Penn already seems hazily recognizable.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 5/

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about James E. Mazza, the superintendent of Community School District 3 on the Upper West Side, added a word erroneously to Mr. Mazza's comments, reversing their meaning, about the strength of a school when its principal is replaced. He said, ''But if you build a good school, I don't believe that things fall apart when one person leaves.''

title: Tax Cut for Manhattan Drivers Who Lease
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that New York City was cutting its parking tax by 8 percent for Manhattan residents who lease cars.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Man of His Word
description: I have a dream my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin, but by the content of their character.''

title: SoHa Loses Blight, Gains Acronym
description: Three years ago, gunfire punctuated the night air in Manhattan Valley, the area from 96th to 110th Streets, from Central Park to Broadway. Now, it rarely does.

title: Several New Restaurants Are Making Debuts
description: JOSEPH FELICETTA, the chef and part owner of Fusion Grille, is opening a 65-seat restaurant in Port Washington, Octopus Garden, in mid-November at 45A Shore Road (883-4920). Mr. Felicetta will take a leave from Fusion Grille to get his new venture started. It is on the site of the former Cottabella Ristorante, the Italian spot situated directly across from the bay.

title: INDEPENDENTS' DAY
description: 1. Alternative candidacies, as usual, will be plentiful

title: Rodin and Gauguin On View by the Bay
description: A selection of more than 70 works from one of the world's most important private collections of modern sculpture is on display at the California Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco. ''Masterworks of Modern Sculpture: The Nasher Collection'' is drawn from more than 300 pieces acquired since the mid-1960's by Raymond and Patsy Nasher of Dallas.

title: Marsh Reclamation Still Leaves Fish Survival in Doubt
description: Public Service Electric and Gas began a vast wetlands-restoration project last week that is part of an attempt to return more than 20,000 acres of foxtail and former hay farms off the Delaware River to their natural state.

title: Henrys, Georges and Victorias, Writ Small
description: IMAGINE A MODERN COUPLE SITTING around sorting out the family photographs. Now, flash back to 1860 and imagine Queen Victoria and Prince Albert spending the afternoon in a quiet corner of Windsor Castle reorganizing their collection of portrait miniatures dating back to the 16th century. The scenes are not too different; portrait miniatures were, of course, the family photos of the privileged of that era.

title: Album Chronicles Era of Dance Band Music
description: CLIMBING down the stairs to the totally jammed home office of Dominic P. Cerulli is like stepping back in time. ''The debris of a 40-year career,'' he said, surveying with fondness thousands of books, magazines and recordings.

title: Quaker Waking Up to a Snapple Hangover
description: QUAKER OATS may be gearing up to report its biggest loss ever.

title: Interior Archeology
description: THE NIGHT IN QUESTION

title: Corrections
description: On page 21 of the section, the credit for the illustration of Bob Dole and President Clinton misspells the artist's surname. He is Greg Christie.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: So His Dad Just Gives Him This Elephant
description: Romeo and Juliet

title: WHAT WILL GATES GIVE?
description: For years I've daydreamed that if I were Bill Gates, I would use my wealth to put a Windows-based PC on the desk of every child in America (The Capitalist: ''What Will Gates Give?'' by Michael Lewis, Oct. 13). Not only would this ''philanthropy'' create an entire nation of Windows users, but the early exposure to computers would also nurture the next generation of programmers, whom I could then hire to create the software that would make my next $18.5 billion.

title: How Public Relations Tries to Keep the World Spinning
description: I still have the 1918 grade-school certificate that declares my father a ''Liberty Ace.'' He earned it, I know, for selling war bonds in his immigrant Bronx neighborhood. But until now, I didn't know the public relations history that lay behind this effort: the role played by Government public relations agents, who organized an army of local orators to help quash antiwar sentiment in such neighborhoods.

title: Attitudes Shift Among Jobless
description: Thanks to years of corporate downsizing, there is little stigma attached to losing a job, and the experience often brings families closer together, a new survey has discovered.

title: So His Dad Just Gives Him This Elephant
description: Looking for Richard

title: Amherst Remains Unbeaten
description: Amherst College, sparked offensively by quarterback Rich Willard and defensively by free safety Todd Nichols, won the New England Small College Athletic Conference battle of unbeaten teams by defeating Trinity, 24-7, today.

title: THE NEXT HUNDRED YEARS
description: All the articles in your special issue (''The Next Hundred Years,'' Sept. 29) assume that we will remain a race in isolation. Even if you don't believe the thousands of U.F.O sighting, contact and abduction reports of this century, how can you ignore the possibility that contact with intelligent life from beyond our world will occur in the next? Who has considered the impact this will have on human society and on our economy, art, religion, environment, etc.? Who has considered how we, as a race, can prepare for contact that many agree is inevitable?

title: In Praise of Smaller Trees, Seasonal Treats
description: TREES are on everyone's minds these days, if not for their beautiful colors, then for the raking after they have strewn the lawn.

title: Meredith Berkman, Daniel Mintz
description: Meredith Jane Berkman, a daughter of Judith and Charles Berkman of Neponsit, Queens, is to be married today to Daniel Robert Mintz, the son of Anita and Morton Mintz of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Allan Blaine is to perform the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Palm House.

title: Putting a Fresh Face on the Paris Bistro
description: IN Paris these days, economy, tradition and a certain sense of nostalgia have rekindled one of the city's most powerful traditions -- that of the old-fashioned, family-run bistro. Diners no longer have the pocketbooks or the patience for lengthy dinners night after night, and chefs of modest means and healthy ambition are finding ways to fill their restaurants day after day with satisfied diners. The secret is no secret at all: offer them good value and they'll come back for more. Here then, is a quartet of some of the city's best, reasonably priced new bistros:

title: Following a Dream of Rock 'n' Roll
description: I was so much older then,

title: The Outlet Shopping Center as a Growing Retailing Concept
description: AS president and chief executive officer of Tanger Factory Outlet Centers Inc., Steven B. Tanger runs a family business that his grandfather, Moe Tanger, started 78 years ago, and that his father, Stanley Tanger, continued.

title: In New York, 31 Seats for the United States House of Representatives
description: Except where noted, candidates are listed in the order in which they appear on the ballot.

title: Cyclists' Holiday
description: EVERY year, my friend Laura and I plan extravagant events for our birthdays, which are in December. And since we both love to eat, they typically involve food.

title: Americans Don't Like Treasury Bonds
description: Over the last two years, since the last Congressional election, the Treasury bond market has done very well, with the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds falling from 8.16 percent to 6.67 percent.

title: A Voice of the People
description: Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little, the son of a Nebraska preacher. He grew up in rural Michigan in a white foster home and excelled at school. He moved to Boston, fell in with a bad crowd, was arrested for theft and ended up in jail, where he found his life's mission. MALCOLM X (1992), starring Denzel Washington (above), is Spike Lee's film biography of the Nation of Islam convert and militant black spokesman. It begins full of color and exuberance but becomes rather awe struck and breathlessly desperate as it moves toward his 1965 assassination - THURSDAY at 10 A.M. on CINEMAX.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Education Life/Section 4A

title: Development Plans Divide Sands Point
description: APPROXIMATELY nine acres of waterfront property in Sands Point, formerly owned by Averell Harriman, is being considered for subdivision into four lots, which the village plans to sell to finance a proposed nine-hole extension of the existing golf course in the Village Club of Sands Point. The estimated cost of the extension is $3 million.

title: Which Radio Marti?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sculptural Installation of Large Intention
description: FAR northeastern Connecticut is known as ''The Quiet Corner,'' and the impression from a first visit to the region is that the name is deserved. So it is an event of some note when there is an alien invasion. In a field just beyond the parking area of the Vanilla Bean Cafe in Pomfret, clearly a popular and relaxing eating spot, 23 strange beings declaim and gesture histrionically. Though they look human for the most part, they are also the size of dwarfs and are often distorted for the sake of expression. .

title: Study and Involvement In Breast Cancer Battle
description: As a breast cancer survivor, activist and president of 1 in 9: the Long Island Breast Cancer Action Coalition and on behalf of the board of that organization, I must address Bea Tusiani's article. So many of us could and probably have said the same thing. The only difference is that some of us have aggressively gone after the answers.

title: Why the Election Is Like Baseball
description: TAP, tap, tap. Students, the question for today is: How is organized baseball like the Presidential election? Or, more specifically, how is the World Series like the Electoral College? Come, come. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to see the connection.

title: BASEBALL'S GLORY DAYS ARE . . . NOW
description: I agree with Barra that, in terms of talent, today's ballplayers are better than their brethren of bygone days.

title: Modern History
description: BEING MODERN IS MORE COMPLICATED THAN IT USED to be, and a newly renovated house in San Francisco offers a short course in modernism, then and now. When it was built in 1961, the 10,000-square-foot house, designed by the architect William Wurster, did not exactly fit the white-box mold. The ceilings were 12 feet high, for one thing, not the regulation 8 feet, and there was a central courtyard, an obvious nod to California's sunny climate that purists from the International Style school would have disdained. Noted by the local landmarks board, but otherwise uncelebrated, the house was bought in 1991 by Lawrence J. Ellison, a billionaire software mogul, who had his own ideas about finding the Zen in modern design. After considering all the big-name talent that money can attract, Ellison settled on Olle Lundberg, a relatively unknown, 42-year-old architect who likes to work with his hands -- anathema to any modernist reared on mass production -- fabricating much of the hardware for his projects in his office.

title: A Violinist Already a Legend But Still a Dynamo
description: IN 1931, THE 20-YEAR-OLD violinist Felix Galimir, together with his three string-playing sisters, bravely performed Alban Berg's ''Lyric Suite,'' which, though completed five years earlier, was still generally considered incomprehensible and almost unplayable. The 46-year-old Berg rewarded him with an inscription in his score: ''To Felix Galimir, outstanding quartet leader, excellent violinist, splendid musician, in remembrance.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A WORLD LOST

title: Power Lines and Health
description: A report commissioned by Congress released last week has found no convincing evidence that exposure to electric and magnetic fields from power lines and home appliances causes a health hazard. A panel of scientists from the National Research Council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, said in a report that more than 500 studies over the last 17 years have produced no proof that such fields caused leukemia or other cancers, or harmed health in other ways.

title: A Page on Black Culture Is Closed
description: GENEVA HUDSON had spent most of her entire adult life working as a nurse at Montefiore Hospital before she decided at the age of 57 to open her own bookstore here. ''Elimu,'' the bookstore's name, which in Swahili means ''knowledge,'' opened five years ago on the day, Ms. Hudson said, Nelson Mandela was released from prison in South Africa. Last month no longer able to finance the bookstore on her own, Ms. Hudson, much to her regret, had to close Elimu.

title: Tamper Proofing Is Not a Monopoly
description: We are very dissappointed with the article on Sept. 22 regarding Sharon Lobel (Long Island Q&A: ''Riding a Business Crest by Making Products Tamper Proof'').

title: Margaret Cochran, David Williams
description: Margaret Hope Cochran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Morton Cochran of Burlington, Mass., was married on Friday evening to David Dunlevy Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Alison Williams of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald Bucke performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: The Year of the Yawn
description: NOT a vote has been counted, but one return is already in: This will almost certainly be remembered as one of the dullest Presidential campaigns in recent times.

title: Insurer Withdraws From Coverage For Homeowners
description: IN the 20 years that Melvin Rabinowitz had a homeowner's insurance policy with Geico, he filed one claim, for water damage after an ice storm in February 1994.

title: Feet Don't Fail . . .
description: Today some 30,000 runners will take part in the New York City Marathon and it's safe to say that most will have selected their footwear with the utmost care. Here are some popular styles and what they are selling for around the city:

title: One Card, Many Uses on Campus
description: At a growing number of colleges and universities, the identification card that students often had beenusing solely to enter their dormitories has taken on a much more universal use -- from banking to shopping to long distance telephone calls.

title: Night and Day
description: Some clothes are about glamour, whatever the hour.

title: Wartime Tragedy Recalled
description: NEXT Saturday night the Audubon String Quartet, currently ensemble-in-residence at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, is offering a recital of pieces by composers interned during World War II in the Czech concentration camp called Terezin. The recital, which begins at 8 P.M. in the First Congregational Church of Litchfield, includes works by Hans Krasa, Gideon Klein, Pavel Haas and Odeon Partos.

title: Jennifer Signori, Mark P. Johnson
description: Jennifer Lynn Signori, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Signori of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Patrick Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Johnson of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Jonathan L. King performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in White Plains.

title: Yes, Things Can Get Worse in Africa
description: HORRIBLE as the reports of refugees and new fighting are, the news out of Zaire in recent weeks has had a ring of ''here we go again.'' But this time may well prove different.

title: Evolution Has No Need of 'Intelligent Design'
description: To the Editor:

title: Moving Up in Southwest Florida
description: BY way of explaining his latest home purchase in the southwest Florida community of North Naples last year, Nicholas Lusuriello had this to say: ''The condo was too small, and the kids kept visiting us.''

title: 2 Top Ensembles Give Concerts, Then Repeat
description: TWO of the county's top professional ensembles will perform next weekend, the Westchester Philharmonic and the Philharmonia Virtuosi both presenting concerts Saturday at 8 P.M., followed by repeat programs next Sunday at 3 P.M. At Purchase College, the Philharmonic's music director, Paul Lustig Dunkel, leads concertgoers to ''Paris, Rome and Beyond'' with three expansive scores: the Poulenc Organ Concerto (with Robert Fertitta as soloist), Respighi's ''The Pines of Rome'' and -- for the beyond part -- Holst's astrological trip to ''The Planets.''

title: Romanians Vote Today, But Change Isn't Likely
description: After seven years in power, Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic and Ion Iliescu of Romania, have become the longest-serving leaders in Central Europe.

title: A Vet In a Van With a Cause
description: WHY did Vernon A. Tait leave an initial bequest of $500,000 to John A. Caltabiano and his nearly bankrupt nonprofit foundation, All-Animal Adoption?

title: A Master Dealmaker
description: WHAT comes through that door'' -- Marty Wood pointed to the front of his pawnshop -- ''you just wouldn't believe.''

title: Correction
description: An entry on Oct. 6 in the chronology of literary events in the centennial issue of the Book Review, about the prosecution of Maurice Girodias for obscenity in 1946, misstated the year of Flaubert's obscenity trial for ''Madame Bovary.'' It was 1857, not 1844.

title: Ms. Manchester And Dr. Bailey
description: Sarah Gardner Manchester, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Manchester of Cohasset, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Earle Duff Bailey, the son of Mrs. Edward C. Bailey of North Olmsted, Ohio, and the late Mr. Bailey. The Rev. Bruce W. B. Jenneker officiated at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: An Economics Lesson: The Candidates' Plans for Education
description: Correction Appended

title: Preservation Trust Honors Its First New Jersey Site
description: The farmhouse Gustav Stickley built in Parsippany-Troy Hills and the remnants of the utopian community he tried to establish there have been honored by the National Trust for Historic Preservation with its first National Preservation Honor Award to a New Jersey site.

title: The Fudge Factory
description: Let's get right to the point: The Clinton Administration has not been candid with the American people about its intentions in Bosnia. It has been playing the worst sort of word games. And it will be lucky, very lucky, if those shenanigans don't come back to haunt it.

title: TV Campaign Nonsense
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Are Rushing to Widen Investigations of Fund Raising by the Democrats
description: Racing to expand a growing investigation, Congressional Republicans have filed more than 77 requests seeking information from an assortment of Federal agencies, the Democratic National Committee and the White House regarding questionable fund raising by the Democratic Party.

title: Now It's a Son Letting Gena Rowlands Shine
description: THERE IS SOMETHING familiar, almost mythic, about the sight of Gena Rowlands striding up the hallway of her Hollywood Hills residence. Her presence in this narrow, photograph-lined corridor, as well as the living room, staircase and bedrooms, has been captured in almost every film that Ms. Rowlands's husband, John Cassavetes, wrote and directed and she starred in.

title: Cider, Sweet and Sometimes Hard
description: FOR some, fall arrives with the first frost. Others swear by the week the leaves turn from green to pumpkin-orange and schoolhouse-red. Then there are those who set their autumn alarm clocks by the sound of the steam whistle and the sight of smoke billowing from the chimney of B. F. Clyde's Cider Mill in Old Mystic, believed to be the nation's last remaining steam-powered cider press.

title: No Grimy Raincoat for Sex Shops' Lawyer
description: HERALD PRICE FAHRINGER has a keen appreciation of the notion of ''guilt by association.'' When he defended the publisher of Hustler magazine, Larry Flynt, against obscenity charges in Georgia two decades ago, Mr. Fahringer's co-counsel took a bullet that Mr. Fahringer thinks was intended for him.

title: Q. & A.
description: Limiting Disposal Of Garbage

title: Where the Choice (Yes, a Choice) Lies on Tuesday
description: AFTER 10 months of campaigning, after the expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars, after innumerable witless speeches and enough wretched television commercials to last a lifetime or two, the voters of America are underwhelmed, or so they tell the pollsters. Many of them say it doesn't really matter who is elected President this week.

title: Variety Is the Word Facing the Voters
description: WESTCHESTER voters will have nine candidates to choose from when they go to the polls on Tuesday to elect a President, along with dozens of other candidates who are running for Congress, the State Legislature and the judiciary.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Late-Harvest Niagara

title: New Baseball Parks Taking the Field in the State
description: PLANS are advancing in New Jersey for three baseball stadiums and the possibility of a fourth, in Bridgewater, is being explored.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Its Inquiry
description: For the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Olympic bombing case seems to be going from bad to worse. Just days after the Justice Department issued a highly unusual statement exonerating Richard A. Jewell, after months in which he was the agency's prime suspect, the F.B.I. acknowledged it may have trampled his constitutional rights in the process. F.B.I. Director Louis J. Freeh announced that his agency is investigating whether agents gulled Mr. Jewell into a deceptive interview, in which he was asked to waive his right to remain silent -- on the pretense that he would be featured in a training film. And the bottom line? Three months after the July 27 pipe bomb explosion that killed one woman and injured 111 others, law enforcement officials said they far from solving the attack. DAVID JOHNSTON

title: So His Dad Just Gives Him This Elephant
description: Larger Than Life

title: MEN WHO HOPE TOO MUCH
description: While Richard Tafel and the Log Cabin Republicans wait for ''a gesture or two (compassionate words about AIDS might do)'' from Bob Dole, they might give real serious thought to this: One definition of insanity is to keep doing what you are doing and expect different results (Sunday: ''Men Who Hope Too Much,'' Oct. 13).

title: QUIZ ANSWERS
description: 1. (J) William McKinley, Democrat. His pin-backed political buttons in 1896 were the first used by any candidate.

title: Fattening Up the Menu for Children's TV
description: CHILDREN'S television keeps growing like Topsy, as networks see more dollars to be made, parents pay closer attention to what their children are watching and children make their own opinions heard. But while new shows keep appearing and a few good ones manage to take root, the sturdiest and strongest competitor in the field, Nickelodeon, just goes on relentlessly taking over more territory.

title: U.S., Defending Efforts on Zaire, Says It Has Sent Relief Experts
description: Responding to criticism of the American reaction to the growing refugee crisis in Zaire, a senior Clinton Administration official said today that the United States had sent teams of relief experts to the region and would soon send a special envoy to Geneva to coordinate emergency aid.

title: Rosalind Cheung, James B. Crystal
description: Rosalind Pearl Cheung, the daughter of Katherine and Soo Cheung of South Pasadena, Calif., was married last evening to James Barr Crystal, a son of Laura Crystal and Dr. Raymond Crystal of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, performed the ceremony at the Yale Club in New York.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PARK SLOPE

title: Morrison and Foreman Prevail
description: Tommy Morrison, easily won his first fight since it was determined that he has the virus that causes AIDS, but 47-year-old George Foreman went 12 rounds before winning a unanimous decision in a later heavyweight bout today on the same card.

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Delegating Dinner
description: ''TO TEMPT THE PALATE IS TO TEMPT fate, particularly the awful possibility that guests might be, shall we say, overly challenged by anything out of the ordinary,'' said Mrs. J., a grande dame of Park Avenue dinner parties.

title: Drug May Help Prevent Bone Loss
description: OSTEOPOROSIS, a disease characterized by low bone mass and structural deterioration of bone tissue, affects one in two women, according to the National Osteoporosis Foundation. But until now many women believed there was little they could do to stop the effects of this disease unless they took estrogen, which many patients avoid because of their fear that estrogen could be linked to breast cancer.

title: Bonus Pay at the Top
description: ONE sure-fire way to make money in mutual funds is to accept a job as chief executive of a fund company. The pay packages of chief executives -- salary plus cash incentives -- reached an average of $1.02 million in 1996, a 6.2 percent increase from last year, according to a broad new survey by Buck Consultants, a worldwide employee benefits and compensation consulting firm based in New York.

title: Sophia Yee And Howard Lee
description: Sophia Yee, a daughter of Liu Oy and Shui Kou Yee of New York, was married yesterday to Howard Lee, a son of A-Hsueh and Cheng-San Lee of Cedar Grove, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Paul J. Jaw, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Richfield Regency, a catering establishment in Verona, N.J.

title: Chilly in London
description: To the Editor: I laughed when I read Libby Lubin's article ''Chilly Welcome in London'' (Oct. 6). I too, fell into the ''Windbreaker Syndrome'' last March. After a brutally cold and snowy winter, my husband said, ''We won't miss these parkas, it's much warmer now in London, right?'' ''Oh, yes,'' I replied.

title: Astrid A. Perlbinder, Cristian S. Rosa
description: Astrid Ann Perlbinder, the director of graphics for the Downtown Digital division of AT&T in New York, was married last evening to Cristian Sabella Rosa, an architect. Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Dicey Days in Moscow
description: With President Boris Yeltsin nearing heart surgery, Russia is about to put its new democratic institutions to an exacting test. During and after Mr. Yeltsin's bypass operation, which could take place as early as this week, Kremlin power will be up for grabs. Under the Russian Constitution, Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin will serve as acting president until Mr. Yeltsin can resume his duties. But putting that plan into practice in the fractious world of Moscow politics will be no easy trick.

title: A Bulgarian Is Slain And Motives Are Many
description: Who killed Andrei Lukanov, the longtime Bulgarian Communist leader who was close to the Russians, friendly with the Americans and respected by many Bulgarians?

title: This Funny Business About Comedy and Politics
description: THERE ARE NO TWO MORE UBIQUITOUS enterprises in America than show business and politics. And they have always had similarities, like pretense and glamour. Actors, comedians and politicians are often perceived to have the air of the huckster, the transient, someone unworthy of a credit card, someone you wouldn't want your sister to marry. Both callings are meritocracies of a sort, in the sense that if the public turns you down, you must obtain other work. The politician must be content with the humiliation of a Washington-based consulting job at five times his Government salary. The entertainer, busing tables.

title: Shedding The Weight Of Theory
description: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN Ornette Coleman's music scared people. His early-1960's albums for Atlantic had combative titles -- ''Change of the Century,'' ''This Is Our Music,'' ''Free Jazz'' -- and promised to break through song forms and eliminate distinctions between foreground and background. He led pianoless quartets, escaping the piano's unbending pitches and confining chords. Melody and the impulse of the moment would be Coleman's guides, a prescription that placed him in the supposedly forbidding camp of the avant-garde. But his two new albums, ''Sound Museum: Three Women'' and ''Sound Museum: Hidden Man'' (Harmolodic/ Verve), are affable, concise and playfully brilliant.

title: Miss Alfonzo-Larrain, Mr. Salzinger
description: Maria Eugenia Alfonzo-Larrain, the daughter of Maria Eugenia de Alfonzo-Larrain Landaez and Cesar Alfonzo-Larrain of Caracas, Venezuela, was married last evening to Steven Mark Salzinger, a son of Eleanor Salzinger and Dr. Lee Salzinger of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Samuel Vainberg performed the ceremony at La Esmeralda, a reception hall in Caracas.

title: To an Enduring Wit, Election Day Was More Fun Than Halloween
description: ''ALL I know is just what I read in the newspapers.'' Will Rogers's famous setup line could also have been, ''All I know is what I write in the newspapers.'' In 1922 the humorist, who became known as the ''Cowboy Philosopher'' while working in the Ziegfeld Follies, agreed to produce a weekly column for The New York Times and the McNaught Newspaper Syndicate that would echo his stage material. His first Sunday column appeared in The Times on Dec. 24. By the time of his death at 56 in a plane crash in 1935, Rogers's daily syndicated column and his special dispatches to The Times had 40 million readers -- a third of the American population.

title: Julia E. Gallagher, Mark D. Unferth
description: Julia Evans Gallagher and Mark David Unferth were married yesterday at Keswick Hall, a hotel in Charlottesville, Va. George W. Bailey, a marriage commissioner for Albemarle County, Va., officiated.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Trusting the PeopleThe Dole-Kemp Plan to Free the Economy and Create a Better America.By Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.HarperCollins, $15.

title: Against Little Resistance, Army and McAda Keep Their Ledgers Perfect
description: Army warmed up for its showdown against Air Force here by crushing an overmatched Lafayette team, 41-21, today before a near-capacity crowd of 39,269 at Michie Stadium.

title: Fellowships Changing The Face Of Medicine
description: Residents of the Coeur D'Alene Indian Reservation in Idaho are often suspicious of Western medicine. So it helps to have Dr. David R. Baines practicing nearby.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 3, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Dell, $7.50.) A woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler. 2 3 INTENSITY, by Dean Koontz. (Ballantine, $7.99.) On a weekend visit to a Napa Valley farm, a young woman contends with a serial killer. 3 2 ABSOLUTE POWER, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $7.50.) Stories meant to ''open the heart and rekindle the spirit.'' (+)

title: Love Hurts
description: Ethan Hawke the actor is the 25-year-old star of such movies as ''Dead Poets Society,'' ''Reality Bites'' and ''Before Sunrise.'' Ethan Hawke the novelist is part of the cross-pollination trend in the art and entertainment world, but far less embarrassing than Julian Schnabel putting out a rock-and-roll CD. In THE HOTTEST STATE (Little, Brown, $19.95), Mr. Hawke does a fine job of showing what it's like to be young and full of confusion, but if he didn't want us to think his book was autobiographical, why did he make the main character an actor? In ''The Hottest State,'' William Harding falls hard for Sarah Wingfield, a preschool teacher from Seattle who sings at the Bitter End, wears dresses because she thinks her thighs are fat and reads only black women authors. William is from Texas by way of New Jersey, and lives in the East Village. Sarah breaks his heart and William breaks lots of other things -- a chair, a refrigerator, his kitchen cabinets, two telephones and a pair of contact lenses. It's difficult to have much sympathy for William when he's lashing out at the people and objects around him, but in the end we can't help it. (After all, he finds plump girls sexy.) Young love. Doesn't last. ''The Hottest State'' is ultimately that: a sweet love story. It doesn't belabor the Zeitgeist like ''Bright Lights, Big City''; instead, it easily evokes the restlessness of being 21 in the mid-1990's south of 14th Street. Jen Nessel

title: In the Script, the Art Says, 'They're Rich'
description: A YEAR AGO, THE PHONE rang, and I was in the movies. I write about art, much of it covering historical subjects, so if I spend time in the dark, it's to look at microfilm, not dailies, and a close-up means a detail of an oil painting. Interactions with Hollywood are not ordinary occurrences in my life. That all briefly changed when my only real acquaintance in the movie industry, Alan Hergott, a Beverly Hills entertainment lawyer, asked if I could help some clients who needed a little information on art.

title: Tests Find No Proof First Lady or Top Aides Touched F.B.I. Files
description: A fingerprint analysis, requested by Senate Republicans, of personnel files improperly obtained by the White House turned up no evidence that Hillary Rodham Clinton or top Presidential aides had handled the records, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: 100 Years of Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Schedule for Polls In 3-State Region
description: New York voters face decisions in all 31 House districts and a variety of county and local offices. Polls will be open on Tuesday from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: For Isles, Saturday Night Live
description: Twice in their first 11 games, the Islanders have scored more than three goals in a game. Must be something about Saturday nights at Nassau Coliseum. Either that, or Zigmund Palffy.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: Athlete Chooses Field of Nursing
description: He is a wide receiver who wants to be a nurse.

title: Aida Alvarez, 78, a Dancer and Choreographer
description: Aida Alvarez, a dancer, choreographer and teacher of Spanish dance, died on Oct. 26 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Civic Angels Curb Detroit 'Devil's Night' Fires
description: As if fighting the ghosts of the blazes that have razed hundreds of houses here over past Halloweens, a brigade of volunteers has managed to keep arson at bay this year.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: The End for Winsted Hospital
description: AFTER six months of community debate and legal wrangling over the future of financially strapped Winsted Memorial Hospital, the end came quickly. Litchfield Superior Court Judge Richard A. Walsh ordered the hospital closed on Oct. 25, three days after receiving an independent report that showed there was no money to pay employees.

title: Tribe Famous for Horses Sees Future in Them
description: As Rudy Shebala walks through a pasture full of quietly grazing horses on a nickel-gray autumn day, a long-legged colt approaches him and nuzzles his arm, and Mr. Shebala reaches out and scratches the sleek beast's nose.

title: Abused No More
description: THIS is what Debbie Karamanol remembers about her 12-year marriage: Her husband threw hot coffee on her. He broke her hand. He blackened her eyes and blackened her eyes and blackened her eyes. He threw her down the stairs for cooking pork chops too rare. He threw her down the stairs for carrying the baby he wanted aborted.

title: WHAT WILL GATES GIVE?
description: I applaud Lewis for his witty acknowledgment of the example that Bill Gates is or isn't setting and the questionable state of philanthropy this highlights.

title: Deja Vu
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Columbia's Chaplain Looks Outward
description: The last time Columbia had a university chaplain was in the turbulent 1960's. In 1969, in the midst of student protests against the Vietnam War, the position was terminated. Since then, chaplains on campus have represented and been paid by their individual denominations. But no one was coordinating the increasingly diverse spiritual life of the campus as well as its volunteer programs for the surrounding community.

title: Democrats Battle Odds to Regain Senate Control
description: Democrats could regain control of the Senate in Tuesday's elections, but they would have to overcome the odds and win more than two-thirds of the many races that appear to be close.

title: A Risky Movie? Not Really
description: To the Editor:

title: Sophia Stergianis, Timothy E. Hartch
description: Sophia Stergianis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Evans Stergianis of Elmwood Park, Ill., was married yesterday to Timothy Ewing Hartch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Hartch of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Sydney A. Woodd-Cahusac performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: School Isn't a Building, But What Goes On Inside
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Burnout And Landscaping
description: Everything from sessions on the nuts and bolts of a co-op's budget, its financial statement and admissions policies to more esoteric discussions of landscaping in an urban setting and how to keep board-member burnout at bay will be offered when the Council of New York Cooperatives holds its 16th annual Cooperative Housing Conference on Nov. 17.

title: Mid-October Storm Highlights Fire Island Concerns
description: WHILE Fire Island lost no houses during the nor'easter that pounded the New York metropolitan area Oct. 19, its battered beaches lost large chunks of sand in some areas as the churning seas washed over dunes and walkways.

title: Take a Bow
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tricia L. Trask, Joseph N. O'Leary
description: Tricia Lynn Trask and Joseph Nugent O'Leary were married yesterday at the Academy of the Sacred Heart Chapel in New Orleans. C. J. Smith, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: RUNNING AGAINST HILLARY
description: Since you speak of ''Elizabeth Dole's campaign'' and declare in your headline that she is ''Running Against Hillary,'' I say, let's see a televised debate between these two consummate politicians charging toward the White House.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: PACKAGING THE SLOPES Avis and its subsidiary, Preferred Holidays, have introduced a Ski America program until April 15 that includes round-trip midweek air fare, lodging, car rental with unlimited mileage and lift ticket at some resorts. For travel starting in New York, a seven-night package to Whistler starts at $1,322 from Jan. 11 to 18 and $1,395 from Feb. 22 to March 1. Prices are for each of two people in double occupancy and include a six-day lift ticket. The car rental in the package is typically a B group four-door compact (such as a Chevy Cavalier) or a two-door full-size (such as an Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme); in Whistler it has four-wheel drive. Reservations: (800) 998-2019.

title: Monroe to Offer Bachelor's Degrees
description: IF the little train engine that kept saying, ''I think I can, I think I can,'' was a college it might be Monroe.

title: Classical Briefs
description: MARTINEZ: PSALMS

title: Ethics Pushed in Challenger's 4-Day Tour
description: Racing through his 96-hour cross-country campaign marathon, Bob Dole implied that President Clinton would be so busy defending himself on various fronts that he would not be able to lead the country in a second term.

title: Can Pepsi Become The Coke of Snacks?
description: PEPSI'S blue.

title: Walter Ridley, 86, Who Broke Color Barrier to Get Ph.D., Dies
description: Walter N. Ridley, an educator who was ready when the State of Virginia was ordered to integrate its all-white university system in 1950, died on Sept. 26 at his home in West Chester, Pa. He was 86 and had made history in 1953 when he received a Ph.D. from the University of Virginia, becoming the first black person ever to obtain a doctorate from a state-supported university in the South.

title: Tradition Fought an Escape
description: As an Orthodox Jewish woman, she kept her kitchen kosher, lighted Sabbath candles and took her children to the yeshiva. She followed her rabbi's teachings. And she respected her husband, even as he verbally abused her, reduced her self-esteem and scared their children.

title: Children's Characters Join With Their Authors
description: THE Stinky Cheese Man, Curious George and the Cat in the Hat will be among the luminaries from modern fairy tales appearing in costume at the Children's Book and Activity Fair beginning Friday at the World Financial Center. William Wegman, pictured at left, and his Weimaraners will take part in the opening ceremonies on Friday, and Mr. Wegman will read from his new book, ''Mother Goose,'' on Saturday and Sunday at 1:15 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 38 of The Times Magazine today about the boxer Christy Martin includes an outdated reference to her opponent in a fight next Saturday in Las Vegas. Bethany Payne replaced Mary Bouie after the article went to press.

title: Bronx Feud Leads to Rare November Ballot Battle
description: In the Bronx, where roughly 90 percent of the voters are registered Democrats, winning a Democratic primary usually gives a candidate a certain inclination to relax and assume victory long before the general election.

title: Judge Rules Against Limits on Welfare for Newcomers
description: A judge in Rochester has declared that New York State's recent policy of reducing welfare payments for new residents is unconstitutional, and lawyers familiar with the case say the ruling could affect thousands of people and force the state to find new ways to save money.

title: The Campaign on Campus
description: From the leafy campuses of New England to the sun-splashed universities of the South and Far West, college students are being urged to exercise the right first granted to their counterparts of a quarter-century ago.

title: Where Did the Negative Ads Go? Senate Race Turns Cuddly
description: Soft images float across the television screen. Marfy Goodspeed Zimmer, seated in front of a bale of hay, looks directly at the camera and says that living on a farm has taught her and her husband, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, to appreciate the beauty of New Jersey. ''Dick has always voted to protect the environment,'' she says.

title: Tours to Take In Hong Kong's Hand-Off
description: No one is quite sure exactly what is going to happen after the keys to Hong Kong are handed over to China by Britain at midnight on June 30, 1997. But visitors can find out firsthand with any of several tour packages built around that historic change in sovereignty. Travelers will have the distinction of getting a British stamp in their passports when they arrive in Hong Kong and a Chinese stamp when they leave. Hotel rooms are expected to be scarce, and packages are the best way to find accommodations. Also, people making reservations can expect to be asked for most of the price immediately as a nonrefundable deposit.

title: Pesticides in Food, Children at Risk
description: THE potential danger of toxic chemicals in pesticides has been called an ''invisible hazard,'' but for John Wargo of Westbrook, the evidence of continued contamination and its risks to humans is all too clear.

title: A Boxer in a Hurry
description: Christy Martin IS ZIGZAGGING THROUGH A maze of fight fans in the halls of the MGM Grand Garden in Las Vegas. ''Chriss-TAY!'' a voice calls out from the thicket, breaking her pace. ''Hey!'' she responds, smiling obligingly. The crowd loves her for it. Disposable cameras are thrust in her face. Napkins and shopping bags presented to sign. All along, she is smiling, smiling like the new Miss America. But when she reaches the podium for the dreaded final weigh-in of her third televised fight, her nerves are jangling.

title: The Most Vulnerable Iraqis
description: With no end to sanctions against President Saddam Hussein in sight, and no hope of an early agreement that would allow his Government to sell a limited amount of oil to pay for emergency needs, living conditions for the Iraqi people deteriorate monthly, United Nations officials say. Carol Bellamy, Unicef's executive director, said last week that as many as 4,500 children under the age of 5 may be dying monthly. In September, the United Nations asked for $39 million in emergency aid; it received only $1.6 million, most of it from Europe.

title: Off the Screen, Onto the Page
description: Sometimes I worry that home computers, even ones running software designed to teach your children calculus by the age of 2, are secretly scrambling their minds, training them to be nonlinear, nonrational thinkers.

title: War Crimes Tribunal Is a Legal Imperative
description: To the Editor:

title: Seems Like Old Times: Wildcats Crushed
description: The type of punishment Penn State inflicted and Northwestern suffered this afternoon once held about as much surprise as Dog Bites Man. All that was supposed to have changed in a Penn State season that had held nearly as much uncertainty as success, and a Northwestern season that still held high hopes of New Year's Day in Pasadena.

title: Shift to Right Looms at Top for U.S. Catholics
description: The Roman Catholic Church in the United States is on the verge of a major shift in its leadership that would cement years of appointments of conservative bishops by Pope John Paul II.

title: Unity Is Stressed by President in Texas Visit
description: At a rousing rally in the shadow of the Alamo today, President Clinton began what he called ''the last weekend of the last campaign of my entire life'' with the upbeat oratory of unity and progress, promising to practice ''the new politics of common ground'' but getting in last licks at his opponent all the same.

title: A Kick for the Economy
description: FOR NEW YORKers, the Presidential campaign has been a depressing reminder of how happy our fellow Americans are. We keep hearing about an economic boom that has created millions of jobs, but New York still hasn't recovered all those lost during the last recession. Other cities have labor shortages; New York's unemployment rate remains one of the highest in the country. What are we doing wrong?

title: Korean Air 747 Hits Light Pole
description: A Korean Air Lines 747 jet veered as it was taxiing toward a terminal Friday night at Kennedy International Airport, knocking a light pole to the ground and denting its wing. There were no injuries.

title: Don't Ask, Don't Print
description: STRAIGHT NEWSGays, Lesbians, and the News Media.By Edward Alwood.Illustrated. 386 pp. New York:Columbia University Press. $29.95.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Mohawks and Steel

title: Flatbush Ave. Renaissance Brings Hope For Kings
description: It isn't quite a complete turnaround for Flatbush, because even after the neighborhood's Golden Age was over, after the Brooklyn Dodgers left town and the Loew's Kings movie palace closed down, the avenue didn't lose all its allure. Still, by the late 70's, the commercial strip near Flatbush and Church Avenues was clearly in decay: discount shops dominated and scores of shuttered businesses became graffiti-strewn emblems of decline.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BAD NEIGHBORSBy Kathrine Beck.Doubleday, $22.95.

title: New Champions of Bridge
description: A bridge team representing France won the world championship here today, defeating Indonesia in the final by a substantial margin.

title: The Salad Bar Code
description: ''There seem to be more salad bars in New Jersey than in my whole country,'' said my guest, a graduate student from a largish member of the European Union, as we drove along Route 3. ''And I love these salad bars, but I am not experienced with them. I have . . . concerns.'' I pressed him to explain. He did. Later, I checked with my more salad-bar-savvy friends. They had concerns. You probably have concerns. Maybe I can reassure you. Take me to your favorite salad bar and fire away.

title: The Big BAM Theory
description: DEMOCRACY is having its way,'' Harvey Lichtenstein, president and executive producer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, wrote recently in a magazine published in conjunction with the academy's Next Wave Festival. ''It has become increasingly clear that unless our institutions open up and become more accessible to contemporary and popular influences, they are going to fall apart.''

title: Election Day: By the Numbers
description: THE polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. on Tuesday in all 169 towns in the state.

title: Maple Court In East Harlem
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Guide to New Jersey Elections for the Senate and 13 Seats in the House
description: UNITED STATES SENATE

title: The Fever Days
description: THE CATTLE KILLING

title: Emily Stamelman, Stephen Walsh
description: Emily Gibson Stamelman, the daughter of Rebecca White Stamelman of Portland, Conn., and Dr. Richard H. Stamelman of Williamstown, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Rall Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Walsh of Hawthorne, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald P. Cohen performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Wesleyan University Chapel in Middletown, Conn.

title: Why the Bach Cantatas? Because They're There
description: EVEN AFTER SIR EDMUND HILLARY conquered it in 1953, Mount Everest was still there, perhaps the ultimate physical challenge for the hale and hearty. And even though the vast, imposing range of Bach's almost 200 surviving sacred cantatas has been traversed twice on records, in more or less simultaneous expeditions led by Helmuth Rilling on Hanssler Classic and Nikolaus Harnoncourt and Gustav Leonhardt on Teldec, it is still there, to tempt only the bravest and most serious-minded musical adventurers.

title: Bradley Tries to Pass the Torch to Torricelli
description: With Senator Bill Bradley at his side, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, campaigned throughout New Jersey today, urging supporters in union halls and firehouses to help get out the vote for him and other Democrats on Election Day.

title: Inspired by Segovia, Fly Fishing and God
description: CHRISTOPHER PARKENING may come from a ranch out West and play guitar, but he doesn't do ''Git Along, Little Dogies.'' He is among the most accomplished living masters of his instrument, and the repertory is strictly classical. If he joins forces with a singer at all, it's the likes of Kathleen Battle, with whom he has just made a Christmas CD, or Julie Andrews, who made one with him a few years ago.

title: Agreement Reported on Forming Trans-Atlantic Phone Company
description: The boards of British Telecommunications and MCI Communications approved a plan yesterday to merge their companies to create the world's first trans-Atlantic telephone carrier, said several people familiar with the talks. The companies plan to announce the $22 billion deal at news conferences today in New York and London.

title: Diners Know the Difference Between the Two Planets
description: To the Editor:

title: So His Dad Just Gives Him This Elephant
description: High School High

title: Tax Ruling Is a Benefit To Co-ops
description: THE October newsletter of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives contained a brief, cryptic reference to a complicated United States Tax Court case involving a Bronx co-op. ''A co-op loses in tax court and all co-ops win!'' the newsletter proclaimed before advising co-op boards to speed-dial their tax accountants for further details.

title: Columbia's Perfect Run Drifts Wide to the Right
description: Columbia's vision of an undefeated season, and perhaps its hopes for an Ivy League championship, vanished yesterday at Baker Field.

title: In Mexico, Bargains As the Peso Slides On
description: TWO years ago, one peso was worth 30 American cents. Today it is the equivalent of about 13 cents. As a result, Mexico has become a moveable feast of bargains. Hotels, taxis, restaurants, movies, picnic food, handicrafts and many other vacation accouterments now cost far less than in the United States.

title: Rookie Who Spurned Bruins Helps Rangers Reach .500
description: The Rangers are a .500 team and happy about it, at least for now. By beating the Boston Bruins by 5-2 at Fleet Center tonight, they extended their undefeated streak to four games, their best spurt thus far.

title: QUIZ
description: Since 1896, when the first modern campaign button made its debut, Americans have worn pin-backed buttons to express their political preferences.

title: Music in the Air
description: The art deco sets and the Gershwin score are dazzling, and the dancers incomparable in Marck Sandrich's SHALL WE DANCE (1937). Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, nearing their professional parting, don't dance to the number ''They Can't Take That Away From Me.'' This time he only sings it; true, years later in their 'Barkley's of Broadway'' (1949) reunion, they dance - but seven years was a long time to wait. Tune in - ''They All Laughed,'' ''Beginner's Luck,'' ''Let's Call the Whole Thing Off'' and ''Slap That Bass'' are part of the golden batch of Gershwin - SUNDAY at 9 P.M. and SATURDAY at MIDNIGHT on CHANNEL 21.

title: The Creativity of Black and White Photos
description: Contrasts

title: 'Call Me Al'? 'I'm a Dole Man'?
description: As last summer's conventions demonstrated anew, a political party with four days' air time to fill and little to fill it with is a media menace. On Day 3 of the Democratic convention, Peter Jennings tried to wring some suspense out of Clinton's choice of campaign song: would ''Don't Stop'' by Fleetwood Mac be jettisoned in favor of something by 10,000 Maniacs? Save for myself, few Americans could care, and my own interest was frankly a vested one. Not long after I was born, my father, the songwriter Milton Ager, composed ''Happy Days Are Here Again,'' the best-known campaign song of all time, with lyrics by his partner, Jack Yellen.

title: Devils Get Lift From Power Play
description: The Devils' dismal power play came alive with two goals less than two minutes apart this afternoon at Continental Arena. Dave Andreychuk and Scott Niedermayer scored with the man advantage, and that held up for a 2-1 triumph over the Tampa Bay Lightning.

title: Corrections
description: An aerial photograph of the Parkchester community in the Bronx last Sunday was reproduced in mirror image. The road extending up from the oval in the picture should extend to the right, not the left.

title: Manhattan Burial Ban Sent Dead, and Living, to Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A map on Oct. 6 with the What's Doing column, about Rome, located two sites incorrectly. The Piazza del Campidoglio is just south of the Piazza Venezia, not to its west. The Palazzo Senatorio is on the Piazza del Campidoglio, not southwest of the Piazza Venezia.

title: No Headline
description: ''Everything we have there is being distributed to prevent looting. The goal is to give the food out before the rich and the strong take it.''

title: Clinton-Dole Eclipsed By Races On Island
description: TWO close Congressional races involving female Democratic challengers and a final flurry of campaigning that brought Hillary Rodham Clinton to Suffolk County last week have quickened voter interest on Long Island.

title: Navy Divers Finish The Hunt for Debris In Flight 800 Crash
description: Scuba divers completed their three-month search for the shattered wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 yesterday, ending one of the largest deep-sea salvage missions in the history of the United States Navy.

title: The New Old News of Nazi Loot
description: IT is sensational news: tales of looted gold, stolen art treasures and other wartime plunder secretly passing from the Nazis to the well-manicured hands of bankers in Switzerland.

title: Picturesque, Affluent West of Palisades
description: A SHORT distance west of the Palisades and bordering the Boy Scouts' Camp Alpine is the picturesque and affluent Bergen County Borough of Norwood, just 10 miles northwest of the George Washington Bridge.

title: Diners Know the Difference Between the Two Planets
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Don't Give Up the Ship
description: THE YELLOW ADMIRAL

title: Next: How's Medicare Doing?
description: President Clinton may have rejoiced last week over the drop in the Federal budget deficit, but he had little to say about Medicare, whose hospital trust fund lost a record amount of money.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE THIRD LIEBy Agota Kristof.Grove, $20.

title: Everyone's Favorite Material Girl
description: EVEN though there were changes wrought during the seven-month interval between an East Haddam closing (September 1976) that promised a rich afterlife, and a fulfilling opening night on Broadway (April 1977), history of the not-to-be-rewritten kind proclaims the Goodspeed Opera House as the official birthplace of ''Annie.''

title: Dartmouth Is Alone Atop Standing After Edging Harvard
description: Dartmouth 6, Harvard 3

title: Turning College Names Into a Business
description: Several universities have been alarmed to discover that companies are buying Internet addresses that are similar to the universities' official ones.

title: Avoiding Mistakes When Working With Electrical Systems
description: MOST homeowners and do-it-yourselfers have a healthy respect for electricity. They are aware that mistakes can be deadly and cause fires. Unfortunately, a number of homeowners are tempted to take shortcuts that deviate from safe electrical practices. Others make mistakes because they are ignorant of proper wiring and hook-up procedures. In older homes, problems may exist because the electrical system was installed when safety practices were less rigid.

title: A Large Passion for a Miniature Carousel
description: THE view of distant hills beckoned on the brilliant Autumn afternoon, while next door to Sal D'Incecco's yard here, a neighbor's horse munched lazily in the sun.

title: How Will Wall St. Vote on the Vote?
description: LESS than two weeks ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell back below 6,000, there was plenty of talk that the threat of a Democratic takeover of the Republican-controlled Congress -- President Clinton's re-election being taken for granted -- was already sending tremors through the stock market.

title: A Classical Player
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Down Under, the Skinny on Unmentionables
description: FOR more than 30 years, Elaine Benson ''dined out'' on the news that she was writing a book about underwear. ''After a while, it got to be a joke,'' recalled Ms. Benson, the owner of the art gallery in Bridgehampton that bears her name. ''People would laugh and say 'Elaine is writing a book for 30 years but there's no book.' ''

title: No Wrong Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From The Roof of Arabia
description: WE knew Yemen would be exotic. After all, it was the land of the Queen of Sheba and the ancient Incense Route, the ''Arabia Felix'' of the Romans. But years of civil war and ideological struggle had cast a pall on tourism as North and South Yemen battled out their differences.

title: BENEFITS
description: Mr. Abbott and Mr. Richards

title: Man Charged in Killings of 2 Girls Is Found Hanged in Cell
description: In a grisly ending to a small-town tragedy, law enforcement officials said yesterday that John B. Andrews, the man accused of killing two 16-year-old girls in Dryden, five miles east of Ithaca, N.Y., had hanged himself in his jail cell.

title: Fordham and Garden Renew Tower Dispute
description: In a clash that has spanned two years of discussion and legal challenges, two Bronx cultural titans, the New York Botanical Garden and Fordham University, are facing off again over a proposed radio tower on the college campus.

title: On the Road, With Pluck and a Camcorder
description: LAST autumn, Jay Schadler, a correspondent for the ABC news magazine ''Prime Time Live,'' stepped out on a two-lane road near his home in Plum Island, Mass., and stuck out his thumb. A self-described ''adventurer-journalist,'' Mr. Schadler has climbed portions of Mount McKinley, trekked through the South American rain forest on a bicycle and chased tiger poachers through India on the back of an elephant. But as he began to hitchhike his way across America, camcorder in hand, Mr. Schadler was seeking to do more than give his viewers another vicarious experience.

title: For an Ex-Synagogue, A Return to Its Roots
description: A dilapidated three-story brick building originally built as a synagogue at 401 Ninth Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn in 1913 may soon become a synagogue again.

title: Phoebe Bunn, Robert McMillan
description: Phoebe Bunn, a nursery school director, and Robert R. McMillan, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church. The Rev. James W. Adelmann, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Overcoming Ballotitis (And Don't Forget to Vote!)
description: You get up on Election Day, primed and prepared to exercise one of your most precious rights. Months of reading news articles, watching debates and listening to campaign advertisements have enabled you, you're convinced, to go to the polls with your head held high, ready to make a well-informed decision about the candidates.

title: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: This Month Last Month Hard Cover 1 1 THE DILBERT PRINCIPLE by Scott Adams (Harperbusiness, $20). The creator of the Dilbert comic strip satirizes management manuals.

title: Sophie Liebman, Jeffrey Oberstein
description: Sophie Elisabeth Liebman, the daughter of Nina Liebman of Brooklyn Heights and John Simon of Blauvelt, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey David Oberstein, the son of Sandy and Dr. Barry Oberstein of Millbrae, Calif. Rabbi Richard Steinberg officiated at Guyot Hall on the Princeton University campus.

title: INSIDE
description: F.B.I. to Stay on Saudi Case

title: A Block of 13th Street Looks Like Bowery of Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodbye to the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Insuring That The Trend Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE APPRENTICE

title: The Sawtooths
description: To the Editor: Those who wish to be less frugal than Susan Spano (''Learning to Love the Sawtooths,'' Sept. 8) should consider Sun Valley as a base for exploring the region. My wife and I stayed at a B & B called the Idaho County Inn in June and enjoyed wonderful breakfasts and great views from our spacious room. The rate was $125 a night.

title: That Courthouse Religion
description: JOURNEY TO JUSTICE

title: Corrections
description: A picture on page 14 of the Travel section today, showing the Palace of Imam Yahya in the Wadi Dhahr, in Yemen, carries an erroneous credit. The photographer is Pascal Marechaux.

title: Boxing as Metaphor in the Post-Civil War Era
description: AFTER slavery, there was cha os and a fear of renewed slavery. The spoils of the the post-Civil War years, paradoxically known as the Reconstruction era, hurl Keith Glover's eruptive new play, ''Coming of the Hurricane,'' into startling flights of theater at Crossroads here.

title: Whatever Happened To Baby Avery?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mozart, Monet and Mickey Mouse
description: THE most rousing number in the hit show ''Rent'' is the Act I curtain-closer, a boisterously syncopated celebration of ''La Vie Boheme,'' set in the lively, multiculti, artistically thriving, though financially pinched, Lower East Side of Manhattan. The characters -- artists, intellectuals, local folks, squatters -- offer the song in a mock funeral as an ironic rebuke to the real-estate developer who has declared Bohemia dead.

title: On Borrowed Cash
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Places
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's piece, ''Great Art in Small Places'' (Oct. 13) was wonderful to read our first Sunday back after a glorious honeymoon in Italy. I cannot agree more. Two hours in line at the Ufizzi, where a fashion show was going on, did not compare to seeing a fresco by Piero della Francesca, ''The Resurrection,'' with my husband and our very small group. There was no pushing and shoving and we could enjoy it as long as we wished.

title: The Perils of City Cycling
description: When Rosemarie Brodie was struck and killed Monday morning as she pedaled her purple bicycle a few blocks from her house, it didn't make headlines or the evening news. But her death underscores the dangers of riding bikes in city traffic, which kills, on average, about 15 cyclists a year.

title: Too Many Cooks?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Arab Worlds as Seen Through Film Makers' Eyes
description: THE TITLE OF THE remarkable film festival now at Lincoln Center is a bit of a misnomer. ''The Centennial of Arab Cinema,'' which features 36 Arab films, all of them subtitled and many never before shown in this country, celebrates the 100th anniversary not of Arab film per se but of Egyptian cinema.

title: WHAT WILL GATES GIVE?
description: So billionaires would be more inclined to give to charity if there were a list published of who did the giving. Thank God, the vast majority of society doesn't feel the same way and is content to help others altruistically.

title: A Step Toward Restoring Hoboken-Sparta Rail Line
description: It has been 30 years since passengers could ride the rails between Sparta and Hoboken. But the Federal Transit Administration has taken a big step toward restoring passenger service to the New York Susquehanna and Western Railway. It recently approved a preliminary environmental report that releases $21.6 million for engineering and initial construction costs.

title: Where Designers' Ideas Can Take Flight
description: THE second annual event called ''Rooms With a View'' at the Southport Congregational Church will take a forward leap this year. The show of original room vignettes, now expanded to include a craftsman's marketplace and antique and art galleries, will open Thursday and continue through Sunday.

title: East Hampton Limits Spread of Superstores
description: It should be noted the Town Board of East Hampton has performed a ''small miracle of local government'' by passing a law limiting the size of ''superstores'' adjacent to the Montauk Highway that bisects this long, but narrow, pastoral community and, by limiting larger stores to ''central business districts'' encourages sensible future development of a growing community that wants to keep its natural, semi-rural beauty.

title: A 'Conservative' Is (Fill in the Blank)
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON tried to convince us. ''The old labels of liberal and conservative,'' he said more than a year ago, ''are not what matter most anymore.'' But as campaign season winds down, the old labels are tossed around freely as ever. So what do they mean to the audience?

title: Artful Dodger
description: Next year will mark a half-century since Jackie Robinson broke the color line in major league baseball. In anticipation, his widow, Rachel Robinson, and his daughter, Sharon, have each written an ''intimate'' account. And, perhaps surprisingly in an era of tell-all confessionals where dirt flies as copiously as that kicked on umpires by Robinson's former manager Leo Durocher, both take the high road. STEALING HOME: An Intimate Family Portrait by the Daughter of Jackie Robinson (HarperCollins, $24) is a paean to the former baseball great's achievements on the field, in public life and at home. And why not? Sharon Robinson's relationship with her father was apparently idyllic. Born in 1950, she was not present for his debut with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947, and scarcely remembers the abuse from fans and opponents that he silently endured or the hate mail with which he was bombarded. Instead, she focuses on the years after his retirement following the 1956 season. The only friction she reports concerns her difficulty growing up in an all-white Connecticut suburb and the dissension between her father and her oldest brother, Jackie Jr., who was arrested for weapon and drug possession and later died at the age of 24 in an automobile accident. Her own abusive first marriage is recounted, but only a few pages are devoted to her father's political rifts with black leaders like Martin Luther King Jr., Ralph Bunche and Malcolm X, or his controversial support of Richard Nixon in the 1960 Presidential election. Rachel Robinson is even less revealing in JACKIE ROBINSON: An Intimate Portrait (Abrams, $29.95). Her book, written with the journalist Lee Daniels, is basically a celebratory picture album. The photographs, many drawn from the Jackie Robinson Foundation archives, portray Robinson's rise from teen-age stardom in the Pasadena, Calif., school system to his legendary baseball career and subsequent work as a civil rights activist. Many are exceptional. In addition, the foreword by Roger Wilkins puts Jackie Robinson's achievements in balanced perspective. Sharon Robinson hyperbolically claims that breaking the baseball color line was ''one of the most historic moments in the 20th century'' and that ''nothing in the world was ever quite the same again''; Mr. Wilkins's reasoned assessment describes Robinson's enormous contribution to black American life. The highlight of this book is its penultimate photograph. That picture of Robinson with hand pressed to his brow, weary and graying but with eyes still alert, captures better than any words could express the pride, determination, independence and complexity of a man who for a time carried the weight of his race on his shoulders. Mel Watkins

title: California's Proposition 211: Vital Protection for Investors
description: THE trustees of five large California pension plans have endorsed a referendum on Tuesday's state ballot that would remove prohibitive legal barriers to class-action lawsuits in cases involving stock fraud and would hold corporate directors and officers personally liable when juries award damages.

title: Races in Connecticut for Congress and Plan to Widen Crime Victims' Rights
description: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

title: Chilly in London
description: To the Editor: Please suggest to Libby Lubin that her parents visit again in September. We've just returned from two weeks in Britain when our raincoats were not unpacked and our umbrella was unfurled only once, while watching the Changing of the Guard.

title: What's New for '97? Style and Substance
description: ALL in America used to be synonymous with new-car hoopla, as throngs of people showed up at dealerships for the unveiling of Detroit's latest and greatest offerings. That tradition has gone the way of the push-button automatic transmission, with auto makers introducing new models when market conditions are most favorable. Still, some new vehicles continue to make their debuts in the fall, and the auto makers, more out of habit than necessity, still celebrate their new year when the leaves are falling.

title: Eugene Polyakov, Balletmaster, 53
description: Eugene Polyakov, a Russian-trained balletmaster who was Rudolf Nureyev's chief assistant when Nureyev was director of the Paris Opera Ballet in the 1980's, died on Oct. 24 in Paris.

title: Ruth Diebold, Culinary Archivist, 77
description: Ruth Diebold, a librarian who combined her professional interests with a personal dedication to culinary pursuits and so helped to preserve the legacy of James Beard, apostle of American cookery, died on Tuesday at her home in Upper Nyack, N.Y. She was 77.

title: $300 Million for Yonkers, but Is It Enough?
description: THERE was jubilation in Yonkers earlier this fall when the Board of Education learned that the state would be held responsible for up to $300 million in desegregation costs. Reginald F. Marra, Superintendent of Schools, eyed the potential windfall and declared it ''a great day!'' And the city's civil rights leaders and educators -- once foes -- slapped one another on the back and shared credit for their joint victory over a common enemy.

title: A Concert Where the Organ Reigns
description: THE Flentrop organ, a 29-foot-high, 19-foot-long portable mammoth, commands its own room at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College here, where it awaits rare excursions onto the concert stage. There it looms majestically over the audience, its 4,200 pipes encased in mahogany. The player seated at the built-in console of the instrument appears an incidental part of the machinery -- almost an afterthought in the visceral power of the music.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Long Island copies on Oct. 20 about office-building renovation misstated the abbreviation by which a development concern that has been upgrading its buildings is known, and omitted its formal name.
