The concern is the Blumenfeld Development Group; it is referred to as BDG, not BGD.

title: Canadian Witchcraft
Pricey Point Guard Takes Seat on Bench
description: Robert Pack seems more like a curious art exhibit every game, an expensive and abstract one, drawing stares from those who cock their heads and wonder just what he is.

title: In a Bumper Crop Year, Potato Farmers Moan
description: TRACTOR-TRAILERS fat with potatoes are rumbling westward along Long Island roads, heading for market. Across the East End, where most of the Island's crop is grown, farmers are harvesting, grading and bagging a bumper crop, trying to beat the frost that can damage the produce.

title: 'Joe Turner' Displays Its Wizardry
description: THERE'S A QUINTESSENTIALLY August Wilson moment near the end of the first act of his ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' set in a black boardinghouse in Pittsburgh in 1911. It's a Sunday night. The other boarders are in the midst of a juba -- dancing and singing to the rhythms of their own clapping -- when Herald Loomis, a deacon of the Abundant Life Church and a recent arrival from the South, is possessed by an apocalyptic vision.

title: Harold Gulliksen, 93, Pioneer in Testing, Dies
description: Dr. Harold O. Gulliksen, a psychologist who influenced how America tests people, whether to see how well they can be expected to shoot a naval gun or to perform in college, died last Sunday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 93.

title: Winning Isn't Everything
description: It hardly matters that discovery stories are often apocryphal. Their value is in tantalizing us with the notion that there are myriad ways to win life's little lotteries. Who has not heard how 16-year-old Lana Turner was plucked from oblivion while sipping a soda in a Hollywood drugstore? Or how the director John Ford singled out a U.S.C. football player who was pushing props on the Fox lot, figuring thatDuke Morrison -- later known as John Wayne -- would make a pretty fair cowboy?

title: Remembering a Life That Read Like a Movie Script
description: THE LANDSCAPE OF American history is strewn with colorful characters whose exploits are almost too grandiose to be believed. One is Charles Bedaux, the subject of ''The Champagne Safari,'' a documentary by the Canadian film maker George Ungar that opens on Friday.

title: Everywhere I Turn, I Get Offers and Offers
description: AN impressive embossed envelope came with the junk mail. I am a sucker for these things. Instead of consigning it to the recycling box at once, I opened it.

title: Incumbent Dismisses Consultant
description: During a debate televised statewide, a civil-rights official on Friday accused a black consultant to Senator John W. Warner of using a racial slur. With cameras rolling, the Senator summoned the aide, who denied it.

title: Fund-Raiser Raising Eyebrows
description: As the Presidential campaign entered its bell lap last week, the Justice Department began cranking up reviews of Democratic fund-raising practices.

title: 100 Years of Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Do as She Says
description: To the Editor:

title: Gordon Bakoulis and Alan Ruben
description: LIKE many marathon runners, Alan Ruben and Gordon Bakoulis pace themselves, in everything from races to romance.

title: Our System, Right and Wrong
description: Critics have called this year's campaign onerously dull. (No arguments

title: Juliette Salzman, David M. Kreiss
description: Juliette Salzman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Salzman of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married today to David Michael Kreiss, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel Kreiss of Shady, N.Y. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel is to perform the ceremony at the Pearl River (N.Y.) Hilton.

title: Judges Seek to Alter Forced Retirement
description: TURNING 70 is not much of a celebration for most judges in the state. Unless they preside over a Supreme Court or a town or village court, the judges are forced to retire under the state mandatory retirement law.

title: A Loner Makes Peace With the Mainstream
description: THE CHOREOGRAPHER AND DANCER Douglas Dunn is an enigma in the dance world, and not just because he holds a degree in art history from Princeton University. He has been making cerebral, eccentric dances for the last 25 years, yet he has deliberately remained aloof from the dance scene, refusing to network or to promote himself. ''I didn't do the getting-to-know-people thing that one must if one wants to make a career happen by virtue of relationships,'' Mr. Dunn said recently. ''I didn't have the appetite for it. It was also about my stubbornness and a certain arrogance. I wanted my work to prove itself without any personal charm.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ICONBy Frederick Forsyth.Bantam, $24.95.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Men Have Run . . . And Lost
description: It's sad but true: most of the candidates running for office on Tuesday

title: Two Congressmen Who Want a New Job
description: THE RACE ''Disgusting.'' ''Demagogic.'' ''Scorched earth.'' These are words from the editorial pages of several newspapers describing the campaign between Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Torricelli to claim the seat of Bill Bradley, the three-term Democrat who is retiring after three Senate terms. Indeed, the race has been among the nastiest and costliest in the country, with the two hurling invective in an apparent game of can-you-top-this. The stakes are high: the race is seen as a toss-up, and pivotal in a Senate that is up for grabs. Mr. Zimmer has portrayed Mr. Torricelli as a liberal with questionable ethics; Mr. Torricelli has painted his opponent as an extremist supporting most of Speaker Newt Gingrich's agenda. The truth, not surprisingly, lies somewhere in the middle. Mr. Zimmer, a pro-abortion-rights moderate who has recently distanced himself from Bob Dole, is a deficit hawk who was also instrumental in the passage of the Federal version of Megan's Law. Mr. Torricelli, meanwhile, has been a staunch supporter of gun control (while Mr. Zimmer has revised his position) and the environment, and is well-versed in foreign affairs.

title: Just Driving By
description: IT BEGAN WITH A SLIP of the tongue by President Clinton. At a campaign visit to a Rhode Island hospital, he joined the criticism of limiting maternity stays to 24 hours. But instead of reading his derogation of drive-by deliveries, a phrase first directed in print last year at hurry-up hospitals by Carol M. Ostrom of The Seattle Times, Mr. Clinton mistakenly used the term drive-by pregnancies, a quite different, not unknown but hitherto unlabeled problem. A Dole-Kemp news release called attention to this minor gaffe under the headline ''Much More Fun Than a Drive-In Movie.''

title: Pow! Thwack! Bam! No Dubbing Needed.
description: ''BAYWATCH,'' that weekly salute to the dedicated men and women of lifeguarding -- and to swimwear -- remains the most popular American television show in the world. But sex is still not the universal language of television.

title: Sweets for the Mouth, Joy to the Heart
description: This time of year, workers at the Chowpatty Bakeries kitchen in Union are cranking up the Hobart 4322 mixer-grinder, crushing up the cashews and almonds and pistachios and rolling out acres and acres of marzipan-like dough. Good thing, too, because, this time of year, no self-respecting Indian American would think of entering a friend's or relative's house without a box of the dense, nutty confections known as mithai.

title: Joy Rains in New Yankee City
description: New York may be notorious for being wickedly hard on the sports teams that let it down, but, boy, does it get carried away over the ones that give it what it wants.

title: Impossible Becomes Possible
description: THE ELDERLY physician and grandfather of five in the conservative gray suit and brown-rimmed spectacles and clipped British accent hardly appears now as the ultimate sports symbol, the one who achieved the impossible dream.

title: Man Charged in Slaying Eluded Law for Month
description: The man who shot and killed his estranged wife in the Flatiron district of Manhattan on Friday had eluded arrest for the last month after a series of missteps enabled him to walk out of a courthouse free on bail, law enforcement sources charged yesterday.

title: BASEBALL'S GLORY DAYS ARE . . . NOW
description: The players today look bigger, stronger and faster than players of the past. Why do they get hurt so often? We've never had so many injured players before. Even the bats are sick! I've seen more bats shatter this year than in all the previous years of baseball combined. What's different? Are the balls harder, or is the wood weaker? Oh, well, just another example of today's baseball not measuring up to the past. And then there are the umpire incidents.

title: Parish Holiday
description: To the Editor: I have recently returned from the most delightful vacation -- and I have The New York Times to thank for it.

title: Trump Ball for Pirro Scores Home Run
description: YOU might think no one in his right mind would voluntarily leave Yankee Stadium in the middle of the sixth and final game of the World Series. But Donald Trump did just that to attend a giant costume ball fund-raiser for the Westchester County District Attorney, Jeanine Pirro.

title: As America Changes, So Should Television
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mutiny In Golf's Pro Shops
description: TO MOST people, golf means Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer, Tiger Woods, Nancy Lopez. Those marquee names are the body of golf, but club pros are its soul.

title: A Drowsy Portfolio in the City That Never Sleeps
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI is famed for his fiscal rigor, for striving to impose on sprawling, messy New York a semblance of discipline about money matters.

title: Locust Valley Defeats Carle Place
description: Long Island

title: I'll Bring It Back, Promise
description: Admit it, you're guilty. You have probably used company time or property for your personal benefit. Like the official in one city who used a municipal highway crew to pave his driveway. Maybe your crime is not on the same scale, but we'd still like to hear about it. What was your justification and were you caught? Does everybody in your office take something and does your company do anything unique to stop it? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Teaching English Around the Dinner Table
description: WESTCHESTER'S business voice is changing, and one of the reasons is the remarkable growth of minority-owned businesses.

title: Classical Briefs
description: MOZART: ARIAS

title: Farm Workers Stand Tough And Walk Out
description: THERE was a time when the farm workers never dared ask the bosses for a raise. Theresa Dillon figured that time had passed.

title: Can Harvard's Powerhouse Alter the Course of Black Studies?
description: On a gorgeous early fall afternoon, in a conference room overlooking Harvard Square, Henry Louis Gates Jr., has somehow moved from Hegel, to the lives of black slaves to the starship Enterprise.

title: After a Rough Start, Patriots Are on Top
description: The Patriots are walking proof that you cannot pronounce a team dead after just a couple of weeks of play in the National Football League. Since getting off to a dreadful start, New England (5-3) has won five of its last six games and is tied with Indianapolis and Buffalo for the lead in the American Football Conference East division.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Dole Should Look at Affirmative Action Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Revolutionaries Fading Away
description: In its day, the Pathfinder Mural received its fair share of negative attention. Some people called it anti-American. Vandals threw bottles of paint at it. And the city gave out $3,500 in fines for posting handbills promoting one of its artists.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Sportswear Shop's Iron Is for Decor, Not Mike Tyson

title: Adventures of a Republican Revolutionary
description: Mark W. Neumann, A FRESHMAN REPUBLICAN Congressman from Janesville, Wis., is a sometimes-mutinous soldier in the army of Newt Gingrich who believes that extremism in the pursuit of deficit reduction is no vice. He also has a tendency to yell at his constituents, which is inadvisable, considering that he rather desperately needs their votes on Tuesday. This penchant of Neumann's is on display during a recent campaign stop at the Sons of Norway lodge in downtown Janesville, a monochromatic American everywhere of a city an hour and a half west of Milwaukee.

title: The Global Campaign
description: Since the news broke that a couple connected with an Indonesian conglomerate, the Lippo Group, contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to the Democratic Party, journalists have been trying to discover whether the money was given illegally and, if so, whether the Clinton Administration might have given anything in return.

title: For Mickey, Bugs and Nike, It's Breakfast at Tiffany's
description: DIRECTLY across 57th Street from the mahagony and marble hush of Tiffany's, heroic size statues of Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck in formal clothing doff their top hats to visitors.

title: Daddy's Girl
description: In this free blend of short stories by William Faulkner, THE LONG, HOT SUMMER (1958), a cunning patriarch (Orson Welles) savors a virile transient (Paul Newman) for his daughter (Joanne Woodward). It is the character of this proud and independent woman and the subtle interplay between Ms. Woodward and Mr. Newman that give the picture its real distinction in their first film pairing. They set a high standard indeed, not only for acting couples but for themselves. Directed by Martin Ritt and handsomely photographed in Louisiana, it's classily atmospheric and looks Southern as sorghum - SATURDAY at 5 P.M. and SAT.-SUN. at 1:30 on AMC.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ART EXHIBITIONS

title: C. Brett Boocock Jr., Headmaster, 66
description: C. Brett Boocock Jr., a former headmaster of the Buckley School in Manhattan, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Basking Ridge, N.J. He was 66 and also had a home in Mantoloking, N.J.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Henry James

title: An Itinerant Troupe That Embraces the Extremes
description: ONE MORNING RECENTLY, the choreographer Margo Sappington was a wee bit wild. She ricocheted around her apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, suitcases still packed although she had arrived home from France four days earlier.

title: Long Time Coming
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Stoning of Afghan Adulterers: Some Go to Take Part, Others Just to Watch
description: When the Taliban religious movement decided to stone to death a couple caught in adultery, it chose a blazing afternoon in late August.

title: In This Campaign, the Most Telling Signs in Oregon Say 'Help Wanted'
description: On the day that Bob Dole was saying, ''The evidence of a weak economy is everywhere -- everywhere!'' Brian Norris, a longtime Republican, wondered what country Mr. Dole was talking about.

title: Rhonda Dunn, Jesse P. Butler Jr.
description: Rhonda Bertinia Dunn, the daughter of Naomi Dunn of Montclair, N.J., and Flemming Dunn Jr. of Jersey City, was married yesterday to Jesse Philip Butler Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Butler Sr. of Cincinnati. The Rev. Archie L. Hargraves performed the ceremony at Trinity Presbyterian Church in Montclair.

title: Joan E. Eisinger, Douglas Herman
description: Joan Elaine Eisinger, the daughter of Sheila and Frank Eisinger of St. James, L.I., is to be married today to Douglas Charles Herman, a son of Ina and Herbert Herman of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff is to officiate at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield.

title: Capriati Upsets Seles In Semifinal
description: Jennifer Capriati revived her game and an old rivalry today when she upset the top-ranked Monica Seles in the semifinals of the $450,000 Ameritech Cup to reach a tournament final for the first time in more than three years.

title: Richard Stolar, Stacey Bernstein
description: Stacey Karen Bernstein, the daughter of Linda Bernstein Marmureanu of New York and Allen J. Bernstein of Manhasset, L.I., was married last evening to Richard Fredric Stolar, a son of Amy and Leonard Stolar of Bay Harbor Island, Fla. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Bruce Albert and Amy Heineman
description: Amy Lauren Heineman, a daughter of Linda and Melvin Heineman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Bruce Adam Albert, a son of Janet G. Albert and Dr. Joel S. Albert of Weston, Conn. Rabbi Judith Schindler performed the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Chilly in London
description: To the Editor: I read with amusement Libby Lubin's article on London. My friend Nancy and I visited in April 1995, armed with heavy sweaters, warm coats and umbrellas. London greeted us with a whoosh of wind and six gorgeous sunny days. The seventh, spent at Stonehenge and Bath, was more ''typical,'' but we were too caught up in where we were to care about rain and cold. The next time I go, I'll take my umbrella and warm jacket, but inclement weather won't dampen my spirits.

title: Toni Korzan, Miles Arnone
description: Margaret Antonia Korzan, an engineer at Energy Research Group, a consulting firm in Waltham, Mass., was married last evening to Miles Arnone, the president and chief executive of Boston Digital Corporation, a machine-tool manufacturer in Milford, Mass. Mayor Douglas Nelson of Chamberlain, S.D., officiated at the Cedar Shore Resort in Oacoma, S.D.

title: Think a Payout Looks Attractive? Think Again
description: THIS year's rising stock market should mean bigger-than-usual dividends as 1996 winds up.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: In the Starlight Ballroom

title: Tough Talk Aside, Helms Barely Alters Foreign Policy
description: After all the hand wringing about a self-described ''redneck'' running foreign policy, Senator Jesse Helms's chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has produced surprising little of substance beyond the Helms-Burton bill on Cuba, disappointing Republican conservatives and providing a source of some relief to President Clinton.

title: A Sentence for 'Prime Evil'
description: Last week Eugene de Kock -- the former head of a notorious South African police-hit squad -- was sentenced to two life terms and more than 200 years in prison for his crimes. As he heard the sentence, the former colonel nicknamed ''Prime Evil'' by his men didn't flinch. But many South Africans are hoping that the severity of the ruling will send other participants in apartheid-era atrocities to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which can offer amnesty to those who confess all.

title: F.D.A. Head Reimburses Agency for Cab Fares
description: Dr. David A. Kessler, head of the Food and Drug Administration, has written an $850 check to reimburse the Government for possible excess travel charges.

title: Ethical Issues Facing the White House
description: As a candidate and as President-elect in 1992, Bill Clinton assailed the Bush Administration's standards of behavior in office and promised that he would conduct ''the most ethical administration in the history of the Republic.'' And after he took office the next year, Mr. Clinton made some moves in that direction. He tightened the rules that discourage senior Government officials from becoming lobbyists. He opened discussions on a plan to overhaul the rules for financing Federal political campaigns.

title: For Watson, the Fun Is Over and 1997 Is Beginning
description: Ninety minutes after the Yankees completed their dramatic season by defeating the Atlanta Braves to win the World Series eight days ago, General Manager Bob Watson rested his chin on his wife's shoulder inside an elevator at Yankee Stadium and looked peaceful and content. The imposing job was over and the Yankees had finally won. Watson was relaxed.

title: Working By Day, Politicking By Night
description: Each weekday since August, after delivering thousands of cupcakes and chocolate eclairs, Pat Lepore has changed from his blue-and-white Entenmann's Bakery shirt into a neat sport coat and tie and goes campaigning in the streets of West Paterson, his hometown.

title: The Modern Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: New Union Contract Lets G.M. Trim Some Labor Costs
description: After months of sometimes acrimonious negotiations and strikes that idled tens of thousands of workers, the United Automobile Workers union and the General Motors Corporation concluded a new three-year labor contract early this morning.

title: Where 'It's Not Over Till It's Over' May Mean Campaigns Past Election Day
description: As the campaign staggers through a marathon weekend before giving way to Tuesday's vote, weary candidates across the nation are hoping that they are just days away from being elected to Congress. Except in Texas, where many candidates in more than a dozen districts are hoping that once the votes are counted, they will still be running for Congress.

title: In the 3d Grade in Long Beach, Reading Is Often a Team Effort
description: IN a third grade classroom, the students were working in pairs, reading aloud the story of ''The Floating Princess'' with their partners.

title: Man Held in Wife's Death Avoided an Earlier Arrest
description: The man who shot and killed his estranged wife in the Flatiron district on Friday eluded arrest during the last month, law enforcement sources said yesterday, beginning with a missed opportunity on Sept. 30 when, despite efforts to detain him, he left a courthouse free on bail.

title: Tucson
description: For many Tucsonans, fall is the best season, the period when they again start referring to sun-drenched days as luminous rather than blistering or lethal. It's especially welcome this year, after temperatures hovered near 100 degrees well into October. Fall is a season of clarity here, a good time to be outdoors really looking at the city and its surroundings. Oddity strikes the eye. Even the natural icons of the region -- such as the unlikely-looking saguaro cactus or the dumpy, spindly legged javalina -- could have been designed by Dr. Seuss.

title: The Lab of Last Resort
description: VIRUS GROUND ZERO

title: Financing for Environmental Act Shows D'Amato's Influence
description: The increasingly expensive campaign for the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act has been financed largely by lobbyists, corporations and individuals who either stand to benefit financially from the proposition's passage or have ties to the state Republican Party and its paramount leader, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, according to campaign finance forms.

title: Bills Return to the Days Of Hurry Up and Win
description: Fearing that opposing teams had caught up to their K-Gun offense, which features a three-wide-receiver set and a hurry-up attack, Bills Coach Marv Levy had sought to wean quarterback Jim Kelly off the offensive system this season.

title: New York City Needs Sensible Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Busy Week of Treasury Sales
description: In addition to the regular weekly bill auction of new three- and six-month bills, the Government plans to hold its quarterly refunding this week, selling 3-year notes on Tuesday, 10-year notes on Wednesday and a 30-year bond on Thursday, along with a 52-week bill.

title: Science Votes No on California's Marijuana Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Kovalev's Play Has Improved, but the Rangers Are Still Looking for More
description: Aleksei Kovalev no longer wears a shield on the front of his helmet, so there was nothing between his face and Bruins goalie Scott Bailey except undefended space.

title: Affirmative Action Measure Nears a High-Profile Finish
description: Of the 90 statewide ballot initiatives facing the country's voters on Tuesday, the most in 82 years, not one has drawn more national attention and debate than California's Proposition 209, which calls for a ban on the use of race and sex criteria in all government-sponsored affirmative action programs.

title: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, 75, Ruled The Central African Republic
description: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, a former colonel who seized power in the Central African Republic and went on to proclaim himself Emperor of his impoverished nation, died on Sunday night, his son Jean Charles announced today in Bangui, the capital. He was 75.

title: N.F.L. Concussions Are Not Really Funny
description: SOME of the other Giants thought it was funny now that Tyrone Wheatley had walked into the locker room. Still in a trance from his concussion, the 24-year-old running back had slowly plopped onto the stool at his locker. His eyes glazed, he was slicing tape off his ankles and wrists when Howard Cross suddenly stood above him.

title: A Web Guide for Election Enthusiasts
description: For tomorrow's televised election coverage, ABC offers a ''virtual reality studio,'' NBC boasts of its ''election ticker'' and CBS promises ''new technology 10 times more powerful than that which created the special effects in the blockbuster film 'Jurassic Park.' ''

title: The Network Computer As the PC's Evil Twin
description: The so-called network computer is an unproven product chasing a market that does not yet exist. Yet the concept of the network computer, promoted as a low-cost alternative to the personal computer, is already stirring waves of interest in corporate America.

title: No Roar and Hardly Any Crowds
description: For the first time since 1960 -- when John F. Kennedy stood on a flag-covered dais and asked union members on Seventh Avenue for their votes -- there will be no big pre-election labor rally in the garment district. The Democratic Party, which usually rents the main ballrooms in the New York Sheraton to wait out Election Night, has reserved the basement this year. The Republicans are not bothering with a hotel at all.

title: The Humble Beginnings of an Empire
description: FOUNDER

title: Eleanor L. Dulles of State Dept. Dies at 101
description: Eleanor Lansing Dulles, an economic specialist for the State Department who played a major part in planning the reconstruction of West Berlin in the 1950's, died on Wednesday in the Knollwood military retirement home in Washington. She was 101.

title: Taking Cues From Lighting Designers
description: Because dancers and musicians frequently improvise, there was nothing totally surprising about ''Spectral Hoedown,'' the improvisational programs over the weekend at St. Mark's Church. What did make them out of the ordinary was the fact that they were organized by lighting designers.

title: Bridge
description: A group with a New York nucleus won the World Women's Team title here Friday, while France captured the Open Team title a day later.

title: It's Viva Italia! (and Viva Romania! as Well)
description: The favorites were not concerned with Giacomo Leone in yesterday's New York City Marathon. Some had never heard of him. Even the Italians ignored him when choosing their team for the Olympics. But his invisibility gave Leone a great advantage, shielding him from any pressures or expectations. He could be patient, sit and wait, then make his move in Central Park. His strategy was as perfect as his hair.

title: The Coattails Myth
description: A day before the election, the race for control of the House of Representatives is still too close to call, and some even believe that the Democrats have a shot at retaking the Senate as well. A much-discussed theory is that Democratic candidates will ride into office on President Clinton's coattails and that Bob Dole may drag many Republicans candidates down to defeat.

title: Questions of Pasteurization Raised After E. Coli Is Traced to Juice
description: An outbreak of E. coli bacterial poisoning thought to be caused by a health food fruit juice sold in seven Western states has prompted some Federal and state health officials to call for a review of whether pasteurization should be required for all widely distributed juices.

title: The Sober Man in the Gray Suit
description: John Birt cuts an unlikely figure for a revolutionary. He wears sober suits and peers through large glasses, he speaks slowly and monotonously, he smiles nervously for the camera but rarely at those around him. He is definitely not charismatic. Yet since becoming director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation four years ago, he has shaken up the giant organization almost beyond recognition.

title: Opportunities Missed
description: Bob Dole never had much of a chance. Voters like sunny personalities and his is too easily associated with gloom. But any slender chance the former Senate majority leader had of winning the Presidency was squandered. He was dealt a lousy hand by his party, and he played it about as poorly as you can.

title: No Headline
description: ''I would love to get excited about a candidate and donate my time and walk the streets for him, but, gosh, I just can't.'' LARRY EDWARDS, on the Presidential race. $(A1:5$)

title: Casino Jobs in Indiana Attract People Who Want a New Life
description: Irene Moore, who has lost so many times before, stood among the hopefuls looking to come out as winners of jobs at a new casino here.

title: With the Workers
description: On the last weekend before the election, the politically faithful across America busily sought converts for their favorite candidates and causes.

title: Girl Presses State's First Case Alleging Sexual Harassment in Grade School
description: To Eve Bruneau, entering sixth grade was like entering a different world: Schoolboys she had played with at age 5, she said, now tormented her at age 12. Every day, boys in her class called her names, and they frequently shoved her, snapped her bra strap and spat on her, she said.

title: Catuna Runs a Career Best; Loroupe Fades Near the End
description: Tegla Loroupe, the two-time defending champion from Kenya, threw caution and common sense to the winds yesterday, setting such a punishing pace in her quest for a course record and a third successive victory in the New York City Marathon, that she failed in both efforts and opened the way for a new champion.

title: Across U.S., the Politically Faithful Work for Candidate and Cause
description: Fort Myers, Fla.

title: Light In the Murk
description: The dreary, depressing campaign of 1996 is coming to an end in a burst of hypocrisy. Bob Dole, favorite son of the tobacco and gun lobbies, born again as an apostle of campaign finance reform! Bill Clinton, who soft-pedaled the issue at the urging of Congressional Democrats, demanding action!

title: Yes, Evidence Shows Press Bias in Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: In South Africa, Seek Both Truth and Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Outshine Disco Lights in the Home Opener
description: The strobe lights that flickered brilliantly before the game were only a precursor. With several new faces in their lineup, and the anticipation building around Madison Square Garden long before tip-off, the new-look Knicks walked onto the floor in their home opener last night and ran away from the Charlotte Hornets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Competitive Spur Seen; British Telecom Brings Local Phone Experience
description: The British are coming to the American telephone market. And for people who call London or Long Island, that could translate into lower overseas phone rates and more competition to provide local service.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Stepping Cold (and Coolly) Into Domingo's Shoes

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Election Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Across U.S., the Politically Faithful Work for Candidate and Cause
description: Federal Way, Wash.

title: Statistician Dies at a Game
description: Joe Schwartz, the statistician for Madison High School's football team since 1952, died yesterday during the Golden Knights' 21-12 victory over Jefferson.

title: It's a time of uncertainty: just how much merger can the industry get away with?
description: OF you are looking for Wall Street analysts who follow radio, you can find them hanging from window ledges all over New York,'' said Jeff Smulyan, chairman of the Emmis Broadcasting Corporation, one of the nation's largest radio station companies.

title: Penney Seeks to Purchase Drug Chain for $2.5 Billion
description: Continuing the consolidation in the drugstore business, the J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Eckerd Corporation for $2.5 billion in cash and stock.

title: Microsoft has failed to apply its own success formula to interactive media.
description: OF the Microsoft Corporation's grip on the software industry is roughly equivalent to the Kremlin's control over the former Soviet Union -- so great that the world scrambles to decode every ceremonial hiccup -- then the industry's Kremlinologists should take note of the subtext in the revamping that the company announced last week.

title: In Final Days, Fund-Raisers Play the Money Game on Their Knees
description: With the election only a day away, candidates have stopped asking for campaign contributions -- now they are begging.

title: Voters Asked to Buy Parks
description: Voters in Passaic and Monmouth counties will decide tomorrow whether to spend millions of dollars to buy undeveloped land and farms to create and expand parks.

title: Hours for Going to Polls on Election Day
description: Tomorrow is Election Day. Voters throughout the metropolitan area face decisions in the Presidential election, Congressional races and other contests.

title: Is There A Doctor Around?
description: These are the kinds of days when the National Football League earns its status as the toughest of all professional leagues to play in.

title: U.S. Pilot Fires in Iraq in Radar Misreading
description: An American jet fighter opened fire in southern Iraq when the pilot mistakenly believed that he had been targeted by an Iraqi radar installation, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Behind a Giant Merger, A Strategy to Attract Customers in Europe
description: Ever since word leaked out on Friday that British Telecommunications had reached a $22 billion deal to buy the MCI Communications Corporation, the most puzzling question has simply been, why?

title: Corrections
description: A voter's guide yesterday summarizing Congressional races in New York misstated one candidate's position on abortion. Daniel Frisa, the Republican incumbent in the Fourth District, is an opponent of abortion rights.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Equity Offerings Set This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Women and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Wins Its First World Cup Qualifier
description: The United States embarked on the long road to the 1998 World Cup with a victory today, defeating an emotional Guatemalan team by 2-0 before an R.F.K. Stadium crowd that mainly cheered for the visitors.

title: Free TV Time? Zimmer Makes the Most of It
description: With only two days left to campaign in a Senate race that is one of the tightest in the country, Representative Richard A. Zimmer took advantage of 20 minutes of free television time today to lay out his philosophy of ''Christie Whitman Republicanism'' and to take a few swipes at his Democratic opponent.

title: Across U.S., the Politically Faithful Work for Candidate and Cause
description: Deer Park, Tex.

title: Across U.S., the Politically Faithful Work for Candidate and Cause
description: Palos Heights, Ill.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Dole Is Spirited and Hopes It's Catching
description: Bob Dole whizzed from city to city today in a frenetic last-chance dash through the West, hammering away at President Clinton's character and describing him as a big-spending, promise-breaking, sweet-talking politician who has betrayed American values.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Penney in $2.5 Billion Deal For Eckerd Drug Chain

title: Races Ending in Bitterness and Silliness
description: The command post for Representative Daniel Frisa's direct-mail campaign is a cute yellow garage across the lawn from his home here on the Plain Road. From within these walls emanate the red, white and blue letters and leaflets that have showered southwestern Long Island in the final days of his quest for re-election.

title: In Rape Trial, 2 Faces of a Defendant
description: Alex Kelly did not take the stand. So it is now up to his lawyer, in his closing statement on Tuesday, to paint a picture of Mr. Kelly as he tells the defendant's version of the events that led to his being charged with the rape of a 16-year-old girl a decade ago.

title: Our Wiser Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: A water-jet tool seeks to offer surgeons an alternative to scalpels and lasers.
description: STANDING in a driving rain or under a powerful shower head can effectively demonstrate that jets of water are sometimes very sharp. The force of those conventional sprays is a mere fraction of the power possible with a pump. By harnessing and increasing that power, a New Jersey medical technology company has developed a surgical tool that can cut through tissue using a beam of water moving at supersonic speed.

title: USA Network To Fallon McElligott
description: The USA Network cable channel has named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis to handle its account, with billings estimated at $15 million. The account had been handled for 12 years by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, a unit of Havas Advertising, which resigned rather than participate in a review.

title: DeBakey Flies To Moscow To Discuss Yeltsin Surgery
description: Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, the American heart surgery pioneer, arrived here today for a meeting with Boris N. Yeltsin's doctors on Monday to clear the Russian President for a heart bypass operation.

title: Troops Rallied and Issues Rehashed, Senate Race Winds Up
description: On the last weekend in the New Jersey Senate race, both candidates were visiting their parties' strongholds and talking about the same issues they debated when they started campaigning last winter.

title: After a Long Trip, Election Arithmetic Has Gone Nowhere
description: After the costliest Presidential competition in history, after months of stumping and an often scalding shower of commercials, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that the electoral picture in the closing days is virtually unchanged from the start of the race.

title: New Urban Art Form, Old Copyright Problem
description: A haphazard collection of disk jockeys, rap music fans and radio personalities was gathered in the dark cave in lower Manhattan that calls itself Vinyl when Red Alert, a disk jockey from radio station WQHT-FM arrived at the club to begin the first awards ceremony for the disk jockeys who create ''mix tapes,'' a new urban art form.

title: PATH System Might Link To Metrocard
description: Transportation officials from New York and New Jersey said yesterday that they are looking into expanding the electronic fare card system now used on New York City's subways and buses to the PATH commuter rail system as well.

title: Athens Re-enters the Olympic Beauty Contest
description: ATHENS  Never mind the Acropolis. Tell us about the buses, the computers, how many hotel rooms have you got and what is everybody going to do during their spare time?

title: Kodak Consolidates Global Media Buying
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has consolidated the responsibilities for worldwide media buying at a new unit to be formed by its two worldwide consumer agencies in New York, the J. Walter Thompson Company and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide. Though billings were not disclosed, Kodak spends more than $300 million annually to advertise around the world.

title: Texaco Executives, On Tape, Discussed Impeding a Bias Suit
description: Senior executives with Texaco Inc. bantered comfortably among themselves in August 1994, planning the destruction of documents demanded in a Federal discrimination lawsuit and belittling the company's minority employees with racial epithets.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Across U.S., the Politically Faithful Work for Candidate and Cause
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Huang Huang Blues
description: ''We have played by the rules,'' President Clinton said with a straight face about his money-laundering campaign tricks and sale of influence to foreigners.

title: The Changing Face of AIDS
description: AIDS is now the leading cause of death among blacks aged 25 to 44, greater than homicide, heart disease and accidents combined. The disease long associated with white gay males is slowly devastating black communities, claiming more men, women and children every day. Yet among blacks, AIDS has been a silent killer. That is why a group of black religious, political and community leaders met at Harvard last month -- to sound a warning loud enough to shake the black community, and the nation as a whole, out of its lethargy.

title: Two Priests Are Robbed at a Monastery in Queens
description: A man entered a monastery in Queens yesterday evening under the guise of seeking confession, then attacked and robbed two priests of credit cards and a set of rosary beads, the police said.

title: Surreal Talk-Show Host Roams Through an Opera
description: The Kitchen is about the size of the television studios where talk shows are taped, so it was just right for Mikel Rouse's ''Dennis Cleveland'': an opera in the format of a talk show, which had its world premiere last week as a five-night Kitchen production. A recording has been released by New World Records.

title: Parental Rights Measure Not So Simple
description: The ballot language is deceptively simple. It would add to the bill of rights in the Colorado State Constitution a new right, that of parents ''to direct and control the upbringing, education, values and discipline of their children.''

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Central Africa Ruler Dies

title: Foreman and Morrison Earn the Right to Fight Again
description: George Foreman was supposed to be too old and too fat to box. Tommy Morrison, some said, should not fight because he is infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Sending a Name South
description: The name South Toms River is fine as far as it goes, but some of the borough's 3,900 residents think they can do better: they want to change the town's name to Cedar Pointe.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: An Old Friend Called Giuliani, and New York's Cable Clash Was On
description: It began with a phone call to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on Sept. 20, an entreaty that would soon mire City Hall in a feud between two media conglomerates. On the line was an old friend of the Mayor, Roger Ailes, a former Republican political consultant who is now chairman of the 24-hour news channel started by Rupert Murdoch.

title: Senate Race Is Close in Polls
description: With months of bitter campaigning behind them, neither candidate in the race for the United States Senate can claim to have scored a knockout. Two polls released yesterday showed the Democrat, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, and his Republican opponent, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, in a statistical dead heat. About 15 percent of those polled were still undecided. The two men returned to their parties' strongholds to hammer the same issues they debated when the campaign began. $(Page A1.$)

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Brown Gets Leveled, But Kanell Carries Load
description: They met in the unlikeliest of places, the training room, and Giants quarterback Dave Brown and the Arizona Cardinals quarterback Kent Graham could do nothing but shake their heads and laugh about it.

title: At Mile 20, Doctors Aim to Rejuvenate
description: WELCOME to the 20th mile,'' Stuart Bethiel, wearing a red Red Cross cap, said yesterday morning, facing a group of New York City Marathon volunteers. He smiled. ''I'm the disaster chairman.''

title: How Belgium Blinked at Child Killer's Trail
description: A year ago, when young girls were disappearing in Belgium, Jeanine Lauwens contacted the police to point them toward an obvious suspect: her own son.

title: Across U.S., the Politically Faithful Work for Candidate and Cause
description: Charlotte, N.C.

title: They've Got Your Numbers
description: Phone customers who found the 908 area code tough to get used to might have some real problems with New Jersey's two new area codes: 732 and 973. The Associated Press yesterday identified those numbers as the ones that will be phased in beginning next May.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Clinton and 2 Senators Support Torricelli
description: In two black churches, at a labor breakfast and at a big rally in a hotel here in New Jersey's largest city, Representative Robert G. Torricelli spent the next-to-last day of his campaign for the United States Senate visiting traditional Democratic strongholds to appeal passionately for help on Election Day.

title: After Politics, Some Prayer
description: This has been a particularly bitter election season in New Jersey. So the Sisters of Mercy at Mount Saint Mary Chapel decided that the best way to bring it to a close is with prayer. Tonight, the sisters will hold a special election eve service to pray ''that the Holy Spirit will inspire the people of our country as they elect leaders who will guide us into the millennium with justice and compassion for all.''

title: The Many Ailments of the Presidents
description: George Washington had a carbuncle. Andrew Jackson had rotting teeth. Chester A. Arthur suffered from a kidney problem known as Bright's disease, John F. Kennedy from a glandular problem known as Addison's disease.

title: Elaine Anthony, 53, Whose Art Mixed Landscape and Collage
description: Elaine Anthony, a painter who specialized in lush semi-abstract landscapes, died on Oct. 26 at her home in West Redding, Conn. She was 53 years old.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: New York's Looming Welfare Burden
description: The new welfare law threatens to impose huge costs on New York City taxpayers. The city's nonpartisan Independent Budget Office, created earlier this year as part of the city's Charter reform, estimates that Federal cutbacks and requirements to put welfare recipients to work could cost the city as much as $4.3 billion over the next six years.

title: Good-Natured Noodling, And Blues, for Mozart
description: When did you last see a conductor perch on the edge of the piano, peering benignly at the soloist, during the cadenza of a Mozart piano concerto? On Saturday evening, if you attended the New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Excerpts From Tapes In Discrimination Lawsuit
description: Following are excerpts included in court records of a tape recording of a meeting in August 1994, during which a group of senior Texaco executives discussed a request for information they had received in a lawsuit filed by company employees charging the company with racial discrimination. The executives included Robert Ulrich, then the company treasurer; J. David Keough, then Texaco's senior assistant treasurer, and Richard A. Lundwall, then the senior coordinator for personnel services at Texaco's finance department:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Choreographer and Friends Exercise Their Imagination

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Two Men in Six Roles On One Park Bench
description: Certain things automatically trip the alarm systems of confirmed theatergoers: a sign in the lobby saying that smoke machines will be used, a program that lists three intermissions, a set that features a hospital bed surrounded by life-support equipment.

title: TIGHT RACES LEAVE BALANCE IN HOUSE TOO CLOSE TO CALL
description: Republican hopes of winning the House twice in a row for the first time since 1930 remained in doubt today as armies of volunteers canvassed voters and as harsh last-minute radio and television advertisements competed for that final percentage point or two.

title: A Balladeer Of Bluegrass Is Now Gone Yet Lives On
description: The dirt has music in it.

title: In an Era When the Polls Are King, Cookie-Cutter Campaigns
description: When poll after poll tells voters that Bob Dole is running far behind in the Presidential race, do the surveys create a self-fulfilling reality?

title: Judge Forbids PAC Donation
description: Charges that a corporation used a political action committee to get around campaign contribution limits are familiar at the national level. But they have also played a part in the race for the Voorhees Township Committee.

title: An Organized Runner Maps Out Her Support
description: For Jill Gartenberg, running the New York City Marathon is like throwing a party. She even mailed invitations.

title: Party Leaders Spar, Each Side Predicting Victory on Tuesday
description: On the last Sunday before the first Tuesday in November, famous and powerful Republicans and Democrats spent the morning on network television interview programs predicting victory, hurling invective at their opponents and their hosts and, more often than not, interrupting each other.

title: M.T.A. Can Do Better Than Free Transfers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Search for Answers As B.C. Inquiry Starts
description: Officials at Boston College met again yesterday afternoon as the school continued investigating possible gambling-related activity by members of its football team.

title: Netanyahu Ousts a Negotiator Who Met With the Opposition
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has suspended an army general from his post as a negotiator in talks over Hebron because of his meetings with opposition leaders, as the slow pace of the talks raised fears of new violence.

title: Fiber Optic Cable Demand Outstrips Supply
description: The information highway is being paved with glass, but now the road crews are running low.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Ac-Cent-Tchu-Ating the Arlen In Songs From Head and Heart

title: Arrested Progress in China
description: In the 15 years since Deng Xiaoping tossed away Maoist dogma and set China's economy on a reform course, his country has edged within reach of its ambition to once again be a respected world power. But China will not achieve that goal as long as its leaders cling to a rigid and obsolete political system. With several milestones approaching, including the 1997 return of Hong Kong to Chinese control, the world is watching to see if Mr. Deng's heirs have the courage and imagination to discard the habits of dictatorship.

title: Magazines Learning to Take Not-So-Clueless (and Monied) Teen-Agers More Seriously
description: Magazines for teen-agers have not changed much: they continue to expound upon the best bubble-gum lip gloss, to offer tips on how to wear a bikini and get the boy, to trumpet cover lines such as ''Zit-free forever!,'' ''Should you cut your hair?'' and ''What's up with him? Your guy questions answered.''

title: Saudi Official Says U.S. Got Cooperation
description: Despite clear American dissatisfaction, the Saudi Foreign Minister said today that his country had made good on its pledges to cooperate fully with the United States in the investigation of the car bomb attack in June that killed 19 American servicemen.

title: Book Awards Evoke Grumbles
description: As the evening looms for an elite, black-tie gathering on Wednesday to celebrate the National Book Awards, the literary version of the Oscars, prepare for a few choice lapses of grammar and civility from publishing houses distressed by some of this year's more obscure finalists.

title: Fallon McElligott and the Children's Defense Fund celebrate 10 years with no bounced checks.
description: AN agency and an advocacy organization are commemorating an unusually long collaboration on pro bono campaigns.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LARRY FLYNT, the publisher of Hustler magazine, who has been shot and partially paralyzed, and whose freedom of speech has been upheld by the Supreme Court, is now an actor, making his debut as a judge in a film about his life, ''The People vs. Larry Flynt.'' Directed by MILOS FORMAN, the film was screened to rave reviews last month on the closing night of the New York Film Festival. And now Mr. Flynt is receiving some unusually positive press, in some cases being called a folk hero.

title: Scotland the Colonizer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Eagles' Little Edges Bring Big Victory
description: The individual matchups were as testy and as enticing as the big picture when Philadelphia met Dallas here this afternoon.

title: In the Studio, Perot Prepares A Last-Minute TV Assault
description: As Bob Dole worked the West Coast and President Clinton paid calls along the Eastern Seaboard, Ross Perot left the campaign trial to tape his election-eve infomercials today at a Dallas television production studio.

title: Taliban and Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaigns Fail To Stir Passion Among Voters
description: Bill Clinton and Bob Dole have crisscrossed the land for months, even years, to inspire voters. Businesses, unions and parties have spent hundreds of millions of dollars to drill home differences between the candidates. Ominous accusations have been traded. The reputations of political consultants have shot to glittering heights, then burst spectacularly.

title: $23 Billion Deal Is Largest Foreign Takeover of a U.S. Firm : BT and MCI Confirm Merger
description: British Telecommunications PLC is offering its shareholders a pounds 2 billion sweetener to go along with its plan to buy the 80 percent of MCI Communications Corp. it does not already own, the company revealed Sunday as it provided details of the dollars 23 billion transaction

title: The Unknown Marathoner
description: Marathon organizers discovered late in the day that an unidentified man crossed the finish line 137th over all wearing bib No. F9887, issued to Emily White of Blanchester, Ohio. He could not have been she, so that finish was eliminated and everyone who finished after that moved up a spot. JERE LONGMAN

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Bob Dole's day of campaigning with Gerald R. Ford and George Bush referred incorrectly in some editions to the span of Presidential election experience represented by the three men. Among them, they have held at least one spot on every Republican Presidential ticket since 1976, not since 1972.

title: Election Aside, Milosevic Plans to Run Yugoslavia
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who is viewed by the West as most responsible for Yugoslavia's dismemberment and the Balkan conflict, launched a carefully choreographed political dance today that was likely to finish with his anointment as Yugoslavia's leader for years to come.

title: A Reporter's Debut on '60 Minutes'
description: Christiane Amanpour made her ''60 Minutes'' debut last night with a solid 13-minute report from the Afghan capital of Kabul on the fundamentalist Islamic Taliban whose forces now control three-quarters of the country. Ms. Amanpour brings to the venerable news magazine program the reputation and authority she earned during years of covering the world's misery spots for CNN.

title: Mason Must Put Deal Behind Him
description: If Anthony Mason needs a haircut to describe last night's game, his barber should shave the word ''frustrated'' into Mason's head.

title: Across U.S., the Politically Faithful Work for Candidate and Cause
description: Glastonbury, Conn.

title: American Indian Newspapers Seek to Assert Independence
description: Native American newspapers are thriving, with more than 50 new tribal publications having started up in the last decade. But while the business of the press is flourishing in American Indian regions, financed in large part by gambling revenues, the sale of natural resources and the cash settlements from land disputes, freedom of the press is not.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Fed up with fans flocking to the rock star Jim Morrison's grave, the caretakers of Pere Lachaise cemetery in Paris may remove the star's remains when the 30-year lease on his grave expires in 2001, Entertainment Weekly magazine reported.

title: When a Mayor Really Holds School Power
description: IN overwhelmingly Democratic Chicago, where the outcome of the election is considered such a certainty that Presidential politics barely makes the 10 o'clock news, it is the school system that gets the headlines.

title: To Whitman, Signs of Fiscal Gains
description: Local property tax revenues rose by 3.6 percent across New Jersey this year, a relatively modest increase that is surely welcome news to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's administration. It would seem to bolster her contention that her state income tax cut and a freeze in state aid had not -- despite Democrats' dire warnings -- led to sharply higher local taxes.

title: Editing Systems Can Bring a Little Bit of Hollywood Dazzle to Home Movie-Making
description: The disposable-income set shoots miles of videotape a year: no celebration, from vacation to retirement, is without at least one fanatic recording the event's most embarrassing moments.

title: Orpheus Relocated In Time And Place
description: Pascal Rioult, a former dancer with Martha Graham's company, continues to go his own way as a choreographer. ''Kansas City Orfeo,'' a full-evening work he presented as a world premiere at Gould Hall on Thursday night, is still another reworking of the Orpheus myth but has enough distinctive touches to surprise the viewer.

title: British Museum Explores A Little-Known China
description: A new exhibition at the British Museum, ''Mysteries of Ancient China,'' is aptly named because so little else is known about the first civilizations of the Middle Kingdom. Indeed, with each new archeological find, fresh questions about the mores and beliefs of the early Chinese peoples are raised, and invariably left unanswered.

title: Strolling Down The Aisles Of History
description: Unbecoming though feelings of superiority are in a place of worship, viewers of ''Westminster Abbey'' may succumb as they watch tourist groups being herded through Britain's national shrine by tip-taking functionaries. For in tonight's upscale BBC tour, the guide is Alan Bennett, that rare combination for television of intelligent writer and practiced performer; the man actually delivers his own literate lines.

title: Avoid 'Politics of Division,' Says Clinton
description: With a closing campaign appeal to the nation to rise above its racial, ethnic and sharp political divisions, President Clinton made his last bid for Florida today and then raced up the East Coast and into New England to bolster Democratic candidates locked in close races for the Senate.

title: Careful With Russian Rocket-Technology Envy
description: To the Editor:

title: Hungry and Jobless, Elephants Wander the Streets
description: Jobless and hungry, 18-year-old Dao has fled the parched northeastern province of Surin to become a beggar on the crowded streets of Bangkok. Her story of economic migration is a common one in Thailand today, but Dao belongs to a special subgroup of Bangkok's homeless population -- she is an elephant.

title: Army of Volunteers Insures That the Race Goes Off Without a Hitch
description: First comes the deafening blast of the howitzer. For the next 10 minutes, all is pandemonium as nearly 30,000 runners roar with pent-up exuberance and push their way across the starting lines, flinging their warm-ups in every direction.

title: International Contingent
description: Many runners from overseas were members of large groups which make the trip every year. One of the largest groups from France was from Credit Agricole, with 140 men and 5 women entered.

title: War in Eastern Zaire Leaves Relief Agencies Scrambling
description: With a million Hutu refugees engulfed in a growing civil war in eastern Zaire, United Nations officials, relief workers and diplomats were scrambling today to find some way to intervene in the conflict and restore the flow of aid.

title: Tumo: The Road Warrior
description: Turbo Tumo's parents were farmers in the Sidamo region of Ethiopia and he grew up herding cattle and farming (sometimes with an ox, and sometimes pushing the plow himself). But Tumo -- whose first name means ''lion'' and whose second name means ''tiger'' in his native language Sidama -- said he comes from a line of warriors. He has proved himself a fierce opponent on the marathon circuit, winning two this year and placing second yesterday.

title: 2 Agencies Name Chief Executives
description: Two agencies have named chief executives.

title: Top American Man Is 24th (Without His Dog)
description: He ran with an injured left leg, wore No. 147 on a faded Lehigh University jersey and was urged on by friends who wanted him to finish quickly so the post-race party could get under way at a West Side pub. Joseph McVeigh, the party's host, obliged, covering the New York City Marathon course yesterday in 2 hours 21 minutes 12 seconds, to place 24th and earn a somewhat dubious distinction as the top-finishing American in the men's race.

title: Accounts
description: * Ugly Duckling Corp., Phoenix, to Dieste & Partners, Dallas, as the first agency to handle advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers for the chain of used-car dealerships. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million. The Riester Corp., Phoenix, was named to handle general market advertising, which had been at Moses & Anshell, Phoenix. Those billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the absence of an international response to the growing violence in Zaire misidentified one country that has offered troops to the United Nations for a standby peacekeeping force in Central Africa. It is Zambia, not Zaire.

title: John M. Cannella, 88, Judge in Federal Court for 31 Years
description: John M. Cannella, a former Fordham football star who worked his way through law school playing tackle for the New York Giants, then survived the rough and tumble of Tammany Hall politics to spend more than 30 years as a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan, died on Thursday at North Shore Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Kemp Makes A Last Trek In California
description: Jack Kemp, the Republican candidate for Vice President, spent the last full day of the Presidential campaign in California today praising his running mate, Bob Dole, and trying to rally party loyalists, rescue struggling Congressional candidates and win a big state from the Democrats.

title: Help the Hutu Refugees
description: Three-quarters of a million Hutu refugees have been cut off from food and clean water by the rebel army that has seized control of eastern Zaire. The outside world, led by the United States, must act quickly to save them from starvation and a potential cholera epidemic.

title: $2 Billion Airbus Order By Emirates Airline
description: Emirates, the airline owned by the Government of Dubai, announced a $2 billion order yesterday for 16 Airbus A330-200 planes, with an option to buy seven more. The order makes Emirates the largest customer for the new long-range aircraft.

title: Briefly, the Jury Pool Welcomes a Big Fish Named Giuliani
description: When the ''very nice man'' sat down next to Beth Kliegerman Tafuri in the State Supreme Court jury box yesterday, trailed by a retinue of bodyguards and aides, it occurred to Ms. Tafuri that jury service was not what it used to be.

title: Women's Runner-Up Says Catuna Got Help From a Pacer
description: After Anuta Catuna of Romania won the New York City Marathon on Sunday, supporters of the second-place women's finisher, Franca Fiacconi of Italy, complained that a male runner appeared to be pacing Catuna in the final miles of the race.

title: Chess
description: It is hard for Garry Kasparov's opponents to figure out what to play against him. Even after he wins, if he has played something doubtful he will work with great energy to find improvements.

title: HOARSE BUT GRITTY CANDIDATES WIND UP THEIR 'LAST' CAMPAIGNS -- CLINTON BUOANT
description: President Clinton delivered ''the last speech of my last campaign'' early this morning after hopscotching buoyantly across America, remembering moments from campaigns past and calling on supporters to ''seize the day to keep your country moving in the right direction.''

title: A Telecom Marriage Made Somewhat Shy of Heaven
description: It was hard to tell from the lofty price tag, the jet-setting management structure or the elegant corporate moniker, but the deal that created Concert was not the first choice of British Telecommunications P.L.C.

title: Zimmer Seeks Out the Undecided at Malls
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer spent the final day of his fiercely fought campaign for the United States Senate today popping into diners and shopping malls, hoping to sway a few more undecided voters in a race whose outcome is still anyone's guess.

title: Corrections
description: A table by The Associated Press in Business Day on Saturday, showing prices of bonds traded last week on the New York Stock Exchange, carried outdated figures. Readers wishing corrected copies may write to Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1474.

title: Preventing Conflicts
description: To the Editor:

title: Audiences In Love With the Doomed Lovers
description: Studio executives have never been especially fond of William Shakespeare. Sure, the guy was a genius, but the language seemed overripe, the plots stilted and the acting demanded British accents.

title: Reject Plan for African Peacekeeping Force
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neal vs. Ewing, Now for One Night Only
description: Their matchups have seemed more like pillow fights, two egos bumping up against each other until one would occasionally burst. Words would fly like stuffing, but nothing ever seemed to scar either Shaquille O'Neal or Patrick Ewing.

title: Whitman Vows Help in Easing Of Local Taxes
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that annual increases in local property taxes in New Jersey have fallen to a 20-year low and she pledged her administration's help for towns and school boards seeking streamlined operations and cost savings.

title: A Viewers' Guide to Election Night
description: Election night can seem chaotic, but all the returns really boil down to a few key numbers. In the race for the White House, the operative number is 270 electoral votes. In the battle for the Senate, the Democrats need a net gain of three seats to put them at 51, if Mr. Clinton wins the White House and Vice President Al Gore returns to the Senate as its presiding officer and tie-breaking vote. And in the struggle for the House, the Democrats need to pick up 18 Republican seats to regain a voting majority.

title: Bronx Woman Is Found Murdered in Her Bed
description: A 13-year-old Bronx boy getting ready for school yesterday morning walked into his mother's room and found her murdered in her bed, her neck slashed and a bloodied ax lying beside her, the police said.

title: 300 'Motor Voter' Registrations Appear Invalid
description: At least 300 people around New York State who registered to vote under the ''motor voter'' law have found that their registrations were botched -- and that many will not be able to vote today, elections officials said yesterday.

title: Act IV, Years Later: The Cast Battles Time
description: A loaf of bread can stay fresh for days. A bouquet of roses thrives for a week. A car battery holds a spark for two years. But how long can a Broadway musical sit in a theater before it goes stale?

title: Yeltsin Undergoes Heart Bypass In Moscow
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin underwent a long-awaited multiple-bypass heart operation early today at a cardiology institute here, the Kremlin announced.

title: GENESEE AND WYOMING TO BUY RAIL SERVICES UNIT
description: Genesee and Wyoming Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., the owner of 12 railroads in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy Rail Link Inc., a provider of railroad switching and related services, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Rail Link is a former unit of Brenco Inc., which was acquired by the Varlen Corporation of Naperville, Ill., in August. Varlen is selling Rail Link to concentrate on Brenco's core business of manufacturing transportation equipment. Rail Link has 19 industrial switch operations in Texas, Louisiana, Georgia, Florida and South Carolina, as well as three short-line railroads in Virginia, North Carolina and Florida. Varlen said it would use the proceeds of the deal to repay the debt associated with the $165 million Brenco acquisition. According to Varlen, Rail Link contributed about $10 million of Brenco's 1995 revenues of $120 million.

title: Mahoney Picks Up A Microphone
description: BRIAN MAHONEY will be back on the sideline working college basketball games this season, but not as a head coach -- as a color commentator.

title: Pathos and TV Nuance
description: To the Editor:

title: Nation Is Still Locked Onto Rightward Path, Leaving Liberals Beside Road
description: Shards from a broken campaign:

title: Patterns
description: Tent Defections Bring Chaos

title: Hong Kong Growth Rate Is Slowest in 5 Years
description: Hurt by a slump in exports, the Hong Kong economy grew at its slowest pace in five years in the second quarter of 1996, according to preliminary Government estimates released yesterday.

title: Bay Networks Invites 6 Agencies to Review
description: Bay Networks Inc., a provider of network products in Billerica, Mass., has invited six agencies to compete in a review for its account, with billings estimated at $5 million. The incumbent, Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White in Salt Lake City, majority owned by Havas Advertising, declined to participate in the review.

title: Southern National to Buy United Carolina Bancshares
description: The Southern National Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the United Carolina Bancshares Corporation for $985 million in stock. The deal will create the nation's 30th-largest bank, but will result in the dismissal of 10 percent of the combined work force.

title: 3COM RESCINDS STOCK BUYBACK PLAN
description: The 3Com Corporation said yesterday that its board had voted to rescind the company's stock repurchase program because of uncertainties surrounding an accounting rule governing acquisitions. The computer networking company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., cited the Securities and Exchange Commission's interpretation of Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 96. It effectively tightens restrictions on stock buybacks by companies that make acquisitions and account for them using the ''pooling of interest'' basis. 3Com's 30 million share program was authorized by the company's board in March 1990. As of last Wednesday, the company had repurchased 24.5 million shares.

title: Democrats Say Flier Is G.O.P. Scare Tactic
description: State Democratic officials expressed outrage today at what they claimed was an attempt to intimidate black and Hispanic voters with a flier stating that polling booth computers could be used to track anyone with legal problems involving immigration, taxes, child support or probation.

title: U.S. Is Considering Cutting Off Archer
description: The United States Agriculture Department is investigating whether the Archer Daniels Midland Company should be barred from Federal programs, a senior aide said today.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: G.M. Workers Remain Out
description: About 2,150 workers at a General Motors assembly plant in Linden forced to shut down late Friday by a strike at an Indianapolis parts plant will remain out of work until Thursday, union officials said yesterday. The four-day strike was settled on Saturday, but it temporarily cut off the supply of hoods, doors and tailgates that Linden workers affix to G.M. pickups and sport utility trucks, said Charlie Marshall, president of Local 595 of the United Auto Workers union. The shutdown is costing the average assembly line worker $165 a day, Mr. Marshall said.

title: Indonesian Magnate and Clinton Talked Policy, White House Says
description: James T. Riady, an Indonesian billionaire with a financial stake in American policy toward Asia, discussed trade policy with President Clinton and perhaps senior aides in some of the more than a dozen visits he made to the White House, Administration officials acknowledged today.

title: The C.I.A. and Drugs
description: The San Jose Mercury News made some explosive and unsubstantiated charges in articles earlier this year suggesting that the Central Intelligence Agency helped start the crack epidemic in the United States. The agency did so, according to the newspaper, by condoning drug dealing in California in the 1980's by Nicaraguan exiles associated with the American-backed contra rebels.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Artful Spring Shows, but Where Was the 'Moment'?
description: Action movies are out to glamorize typing.

title: Library of Congress Gets Feiffer Papers
description: Jules Feiffer, the cartoonist, playwright and novelist, has agreed to donate his papers and several hundred drawings and book illustrations to the Library of Congress.

title: Loving Progress Report On the Art of Clowning
description: There is a lovely, poignant moment at the conclusion of ''The New Bozena,'' the new post-modern clown show: behind a scrim, a clown in a black fright wig strums a guitar, as his two confederates dance a gentle, otherworldly jig. It's a sweet send-off for the audience, a reflection of the obvious love the three performers have for their material and for their craft.

title: Manley Out on Parole
description: DEXTER MANLEY walked out of prison yesterday, free on parole after serving nearly 15 months of a four-year term for cocaine possession. ''I'm O.K.,'' the former Washington Redskins star said at the Walls Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice in Huntsville as he hugged his girlfriend, LYDIA LANG. Manley won parole for good behavior. (AP)

title: 2 Princetons Consider A Merger, Once Again
description: On a good New Jersey map, the border lines between the two Princetons are clear: tiny Princeton Borough looks like the hole in a lumpy Princeton Township doughnut.

title: Helping the Yankees -- and the Schools
description: For the first time in a decade, baseball has been very good to New York. But now that the ticker tape has been swept up, New York City and New York State face hard choices on what, if anything, to do about building 21st century ball parks for both the Yankees and Mets.

title: Election Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Democrat Calls Her Opponent's Mailing a Lie
description: Representative Daniel Frisa, a Republican in a bitter Congressional race on Long Island, has sent a mailing to voters that resembles an official Board of Election mailing, criticizing his opponent's voting record as a citizen. His Democratic challenger, Carolyn McCarthy, called the allegations lies.

title: Controversial Play, and Loss, Leaves Rangers Kicking Themselves
description: The Rangers' four-game undefeated streak ended in embarrassing fashion last night at Madison Square Garden when the Tampa Bay Lightning defeated New York, 5-3.

title: INSIDE
description: Yeltsin Undergoes Surgery

title: If Voters Had Chosen The Choices
description: TWO proposals are on the New York City ballot today, one to borrow money for environmental projects, the other to change the rules on term limits. Important issues, both. But how many New Yorkers lost sleep over either one?

title: On Latin Web Site, How to Say 'Whoa!'?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS TO BUY STAKE IN BRITISH COMPANY
description: The U.S. Office Products Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 49 percent stake in Dudley Stationery Ltd., a closely held British concern, for $79 million. It said that Dudley, an office products supplier in Britain, had sales of $110 million last year, and that it would invest the $79 million in Dudley during the next two years. Since its founding in 1994, U.S. Office Products, which is based in Washington, has completed 113 acquisitions. It reported annual sales of $2.5 billion, and said the British market is the first of several European markets it planned to expand into.

title: Short Memories on Nigeria
description: Five months ago, my mother, Kudirat Abiola, was murdered in the streets of Lagos, Nigeria. She had been critical of the Government of Gen. Sani Abacha and had campaigned tirelessly for my father and her husband, Mashood Abiola. He has been held in solitary confinement since 1993, charged with treason. My father's real crime? Winning the June 1993 presidential election, which international monitors deemed to be free and fair.

title: Philip J. Fialkow, 62, Leader in Medical Genetics
description: Dr. Philip J. Fialkow, a leading figure in medical genetics and auto-immune diseases and dean of the School of Medicine at the University of Washington, died along with his wife and three others when their hiking camp in western Nepal was buried by a sudden snowstorm.

title: Adding a Little Something
description: Little by little, accessories are showing up on the runway. During last week's Seventh on Sixth spring shows, designers used jewelry, belts, scarfs and handbags to accentuate their fashion themes. Just as there were romantic clothes and boldly ethnic styles, so were there accessories to complement each.

title: Final New Jersey Push
description: Worried that President Clinton's commanding lead in statewide polls in New Jersey may keep voters home on Election Day, and with many races in the state considered to be extremely close, both parties are fielding paid workers and volunteers to get loyalists to the polls.

title: Long Line Fishing Seen as Damaging To Some Fish and to the Albatross
description: HIGH-SEAS drift nets that stretched for miles and swept the ocean clean a decade ago are now banned because of their destructiveness to marine life. But scientists say the nets are being supplanted by another damaging method: fishing lines up to 80 miles long, sometimes machine-baited, that deploy thousands of hooks apiece.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Air Force Parachutes In To Play Untested Army
