description: Army's unbeaten record (8-0) lacks national substance because none of its opponents so far are ranked in the polls, two are Division I-AA teams (Yale and Lafayette) and only one has a winning record. That's Ohio University (6-3) of the Mid-American Conference.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: First With Africans
description: To the Editor:

title: Wildcat May Transfer
description: The freshman quarterback TIM COUCH, a former high school player of the year, said he is considering transferring from the University of Kentucky at the end of the season. The Wildcats (2-6) fired Coach BILL CURRY on Oct. 21.

title: A Shanghai Museum With Western Flair
description: This city is undergoing a renaissance, of sorts, with a manic building boom that is throwing up countless skyscrapers and highways, a feverish devotion to money-making and a rekindling of the pride that Shanghai knew in its heyday earlier this century.

title: In Saudis' Heartland, Unrest Is Aimed at Rulers and U.S.
description: Far from the palaces of the capital and the Red Sea coast, this is Saudi Arabia's religious heartland, where beards are worn untrimmed and resentment toward those in power is not easily disguised.

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Nets Trade Askew for Pacers' Williams
description: Vincent Askew came to the Nets in July as a disgruntled defender from Seattle, upset over his playing time with the Sonics. He left New Jersey last night, after growing just as discontented, traded to Indiana for the scoring forward Reggie Williams.

title: Pakistan's Premier Bhutto Is Put Under House Arrest
description: Pakistan's President dismissed Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto as Pakistan's head of government early today, justifying the action with a proclamation that depicted her administration as incompetent, corrupt and defiant of constitutional restraints on executive power.

title: Kanell Is at Ease As Hero, Or Backup
description: Danny Kanell walked into the Giants' locker room today and it was as if he had fresh meat tied around his neck. His teammates could not wait to pounce.

title: Torricelli's Theme: Mainstream vs. Extreme
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, used the final hours of his campaign today trying to fix one lasting image of himself and his Republican opponent, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, in the minds of voters.

title: Mason Pleads Guilty
description: ANTHONY MASON, a former Knick, pleaded guilty yesterday to disorderly conduct for an early-morning scuffle with police officers in midtown Manhattan last summer.

title: Yankees' Voice Remembered In a Tribute at St. Patrick's
description: Nearly five months after his funeral inside a modern synagogue in Stamford, Conn., Mel Allen, the longtime voice of the Yankees, was honored at a memorial tribute yesterday inside the Gothic-style St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Inquiring Into Texaco's Actions in Suit
description: An unfolding scandal at Texaco Inc. widened yesterday, as Federal prosecutors in White Plains opened a criminal investigation to determine whether senior company executives illegally destroyed documents sought in a discrimination lawsuit, people with knowledge of the situation said.

title: Physicists Predict Progress in Solving Problem of Gravity
description: Some 200 prominent physicists who gathered here last week found themselves in general agreement that despite gnawing problems in financing research, the next 50 years would see a flowering of physics the like of which has never been known. A leading prospect is for progress in fathoming the subtle nature of gravity.

title: In Flight 800 Crash, 3 Revised Theories, Lacking a 'Eureka'
description: After recovering nearly all of the mangled remains of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 from the ocean floor, investigators said yesterday that they still have found no evidence that shows what caused the plane to explode and plummet into the sea. But this absence of evidence holds sharply different implications for the three theories guiding the crash investigation.

title: New Spin on 'Cinderella': Prince Finds a Dream Guy
description: Arthur Aviles has grown impressively as a choreographer and a director in the two years since he left the Bill T. Jones company, to judge by a performance by the Arthur Aviles Typical Theater troupe on Saturday night at the Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture. And Mr. Aviles would also seem to have something important to contribute to the New York dance scene.

title: N. W. Ayer & Partners lands U S West account after losing AT&T in a recent merger agreement.
description: IT HAS been a while since the words 'N. W. Ayer & Partners'' and ''landed a large account'' have appeared in the same sentence. But that ended yesterday when Ayer was awarded assignments from U S West Inc. -- with an estimated $60 million in billings -- that return the agency to telecommunications.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: St. John's Signs Jessie
description: REGGIE JESSIE, a 6-foot-7-inch shooting guard who has averaged 19.6 points a game at Bishop Loughlin High School in Brooklyn, signed a letter of intent with St. John's University yesterday. His decision came down to the Red Storm or West Virginia. ''He knows most, if not all, the players on the team, especially the New York City kids,'' said Loughlin Coach BOB LECKIE.

title: Investor Guilty In Fraud Case
description: A former financial adviser and principal owner of a financial services company in Ronkonkoma, L.I., pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he plotted to defraud a group of teachers of more than $500,000 in retirement savings.

title: It's No Contest as Jeter Captures Rookie of the Year
description: Derek Jeter was supposed to be the question mark on the Yankees this season, even according to Manager Joe Torre. Could the rookie handle playing shortstop? Could he succeed in New York? What would happen to the Yankees if the youngster floundered?

title: No Hot Rod, but a Nice Family Car
description: IN olden days, when Apple Computer Inc.'s graying senior executives were young and when cool technology was epitomized by hot-rod automobiles instead of computers, it was fashionable in some quarters to paint flames on the side of the car to indicate great speed.

title: Environmentalists Fear a Low Turnout
description: Supporters of the Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act said today that they were concerned that low turnout on Election Day would hurt the proposition's chance of passage, and they stepped up their efforts to insure that sympathetic voters, particularly big-city Democrats, go to the polls.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday listing New York State candidates for the United States House misidentified the Republican candidate in the 15th Congressional District. He is Edward R. Adams (not Jose L. Adames).

title: Two Goals For Palffy Yet Again
description: The Islanders are usually hard-pressed to score more than two goals on any given night. Funny, then, that they have a player who is averaging two goals a game over his last three games.

title: Bernard Lafferty, the Butler For Doris Duke, Dies at 51
description: Bernard Lafferty, the butler who became a millionaire after the death of Doris Duke, the lonely tobacco heiress he had befriended, died in Los Angeles yesterday. He was 51.

title: German Factory Output Fell 1.8% in September
description: Industrial output in Germany fell 1.8 percent in September from the previous month, the first decline since February, the Economics Ministry said yesterday. But it said the September data would probably be revised upward. ''Experience shows the preliminary September data will be corrected upward significantly,'' the ministry said in a statement.

title: Canadian Arrest Is Tied To U.S. Child-Porn Ring
description: The Canadian authorities investigating an international child pornography ring on the Internet have confiscated 30,000 pornographic computer files and arrested a northern Ontario man believed to be connected with a group of pornographers in the United States known as the Orchid Club.

title: No. 1 Is All Graf's
description: STEFFI GRAF has taken over the top spot on W.T.A. Tour rankings after MONICA SELES lost to JENNIFER CAPRIATI in the semifinals of last weekend's Ameritech Cup in Chicago. Seles, who shared the No. 1 ranking with Graf since returning to the tour on Aug. 14, is now co-ranked No. 2 with ARANTXA SANCHEZ VICARIO. (AP)

title: Concern on Fungus Infection Pushes Wheat Prices Higher
description: Wheat prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid concern that fungus infections were reducing the amount of good quality wheat in the United States.

title: A Move for Fewer Mayors
description: Beneath Bedminster's tranquil surface, confusion reigns. In the last six years, the community of 7,800 has had five mayors. ''As soon as a mayor is chosen, people start fighting over who's going to be mayor next year,'' said Edward R. Russo, vice president of the Planning Board. Mr. Russo supports a referendum on today's ballot that would change the township's form of government so the mayor is popularly elected for a four-year term instead of being chosen annually by the five-member Township Committee.

title: Wilson's Health
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says a Woman, 31, Posed As a Lawyer in Brooklyn Court
description: A 31-year-old Manhattan woman was arrested yesterday and charged with falsely posing as a lawyer and representing up to a dozen criminal defendants in Federal cases in New York City over the last two years.

title: CUNY Campus Assails Hate but Allows Black-Pride Speakers It Had Barred
description: After three years of clashes over Black Solidarity Day at York College, City University's campus in Jamaica, Queens, the event was celebrated there yesterday with music, dancing, speakers -- and calm.

title: Perot Keeps Up Attacks on Clinton's Integrity
description: On election eve, Ross Perot today kept up his attack on President Clinton's character and declared that the occupant of the Oval Office ''should live in the center of the field of ethical behavior and hold himself to a much higher standard than is it legal or illegal.''

title: Final Push in Battle Over Term Limits
description: As the battle wound up yesterday over a ballot proposal that would change the city's term limits law, the supporters were marshaling an army of volunteers to flood polling locations today, while the opponents were relying on a $2 million media campaign to drive home their message.

title: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, Self-Crowned Emperor Of the Central African Republic, Dies at 75
description: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, a former colonel who seized power in the Central African Republic and went on to proclaim himself Emperor of his impoverished nation, died on Sunday night, his son Jean Charles announced today in Bangui, the capital. He was 75.

title: Let's Spend Less Time and Money on Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Slaying Tells of Russia's Deadly Capitalism
description: It started out as a shining symbol of United States investment in Russia: a posh American-managed hotel nestled along the Moscow River.

title: Incumbent in Romania, a Leftist, Faces a Runoff
description: A third term for President Ion Iliescu, who has led Romania on a leftist course since the collapse of Communism, seemed uncertain today after partial results from the presidential election on Sunday were announced.

title: Some Owners Consider Altering the Labor Deal
description: As baseball's club owners approach a critical meeting tomorrow, a move was afoot yesterday to maneuver the responsibility of killing the pending labor agreement from the owners to the players.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MITCHELL ENERGY AND DEVELOPMENT CORP., The Woodlands, Tex., an energy concern, announced the sale of a portfolio of retail properties in The Woodlands and other real estate assets for around $38 million, including a $9 million note receivable.

title: U.S. ROBOTICS STOCK JUMPS AFTER PROFIT REPORT
description: Shares of the U.S. Robotics Corporation rose sharply in after-hours trading yesterday after the company said its fourth-quarter profit from operations almost doubled, meeting Wall Street estimates. Shares of the company closed at $59.50 and traded as high as $61.50. U.S. Robotics, the computer modem maker based in Skokie, Ill., said net income for the quarter was $13.5 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with $34.2 million, or 37 cents, in the similar period last year. Excluding a pretax charge, U.S. Robotics posted profit from operations of $67.5 million, or 71 cents a share. Revenue more than doubled, to $611.4 million, from $293.4 million a year ago.

title: The Lesson of Detente
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidents: The Bottom Line
description: President Clinton's term has been the third best of the past century, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average. But such great terms of office are sometimes followed by poor ones, and Wall Street has never enjoyed a Democrat's second term. Market Place, page D12.

title: When Ignorance Is Bliss, Love Is (of Course) Blind
description: When it comes to women making their presence felt on prime time, in front of the cameras and behind, it's obvious that career credits in soap operas don't hurt. Two instances at hand involve Michele Lee, who for 14 years played Karen MacKenzie on the nighttime soap ''Knot's Landing,'' and Judith Light, who, before her long run opposite Tony Danza in the sitcom ''Who's the Boss?,'' won two Emmys for her portrayal of Karen Wolek on daytime's ''One Life to Live.''

title: Don't Name Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: TV to Hold To Practice In Calling Election
description: Aside from being gussied up with state-of-the-art computer graphics that will make dull numbers virtually stand up and dance, television news coverage of the Presidential election results will unfold tonight much as it has in the last 20 years.

title: 2 Companies to Make TV-Top Internet Links Using Oracle Systems
description: The Oracle Corporation said today that two major manufacturers would produce set-top devices that link televisions to the Internet, using technology licensed from its Network Computer Inc. subsidiary.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Mad at Everybody, Including Themselves
description: For some listeners, probably a majority, popular music is a realm of order and ease, an escape from everyday strife. But for an active minority -- people who rush to stores to get an album the day it's released -- music is cathartic; in songs, pent-up ideas and emotions can be unleashed, examined, confronted and perhaps exorcised. On the albums reviewed here, unruly ideas arrive with sonic jolts to match.

title: New Admission Puts Kevorkian Suicide List at 46
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian's lawyer said today that his client had assisted in a previously unacknowledged suicide on Aug. 30, and he played two videotapes showing the woman begging for help in ending her life.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: In Argentine Bribery Scandal, an Ex-Executive of I.B.M. Says He Is a Scapegoat
description: A year ago, Gustavo Soriani was one of the most respected executives in Argentina as vice president for operations at I.B.M.'s Argentine operations. But these days he has few admirers.

title: A Life Defined by a Mother's Death
description: MY DARK PLACES

title: HOARSE BUT GRITTY CANDIDATES WIND UP THEIR 'LAST' CAMPAIGNS -- DOLE IS TENACIOUS
description: With time running out and his wife and daughter at his side, an increasingly hoarse Bob Dole gamely barreled through the last leg of his 96-hour marathon today, sweeping across the Southwest and preparing for the end of his fourth, and probably final, national campaign.

title: Justices Refuse Case on Whether Health Care Networks Must Be Open to All Doctors
description: Bypassing a growing legal dispute over the organization of managed care health plans, the Supreme Court today refused to hear a case on whether states can insist that health care networks open their doors to any doctor who wants to practice with the group.

title: Pentagon Defends 2 Jet Missile Firings in Iraq
description: The Defense Department said today that the pilots of two American jet fighters were justified in firing missiles to the ground in southern Iraq, even though it was still unclear that either plane had actually been in danger.

title: Orgies in the Kitchen
description: Al and I went out to dinner. The chef was from the Pile-It-On School of Cooking. ''I'll have some shrimp,'' I said.

title: 4 Players at B.C. Told Of Lack of Evidence
description: Four Boston College football players reported linked to a university gambling investigation were told today that there was no evidence to suggest their involvement, according to a lawyer representing them.

title: Zaire Rebel Calls a Truce, but Refugees Remain in Danger
description: A Zairian rebel leader declared a unilateral three-week cease-fire today between Tutsi guerrillas and Zaire's army, raising hopes that international aid could be provided to the estimated one million refugees who have had supplies of food and clean water cut off by the fighting.

title: PNC BUYS CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS FROM MELLON
description: The PNC Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired credit card accounts held by members of the American Automobile Association from the Mellon Bank Corporation. To take over the accounts, PNC, which is based in Pittsburgh, paid a premium of $116 million plus the $771 million in outstanding charges owed on 1.3 million A.A.A. credit cards. PNC will also have the right to market other financial services to the association's 35 million members for 10 years. The company said the contract would generate $15 billion to $25 billion in new assets as it marketed savings accounts, auto loans, credit cards and other services to association members.

title: Separating the Faint From League's Beasts
description: IN a surreal setting in a surreal game we were offered a surreal sight here on Sunday afternoon.

title: THERMO OPTEC ADDS TWO UNITS FROM PARENT COMPANY
description: The Thermo Optec Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired two business units from its parent company, Thermo Instrument Systems Inc., in a transaction valued at $68.7 million. Thermo Optec and Thermo Instrument are both owned by the Thermo Electron Corporation, which is based in Waltham, Mass. The purchase price includes $55.2 million in cash and $13.5 million in assumption of debt for the two units, Applied Research Technologies and VG Elemental. Thermo Optec, which makes analytical instruments for chemical analysis, said the acquisition of Applied Research Technologies would give it access to X-ray fluorescence technology, while the VG Elemental acquisition would allow it to expand its elemental liquids analysis business.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Oct. 4 about Tunica County, Miss., reported its transformation by casino gambling, from the poorest county in America to the home of a billion-dollar-a-year industry. The 2,500-word article was fully based on The Times's reporting and interviewing at the scene, but some avenues for the reporting were suggested by an article by John Brans ton in the July-August issue of Memphis, a Tennessee magazine.

title: A Day of Hard Knocks Leaves Teams Hurting
description: It was one of the most brutal days of this National Football League season. Four starting quarterbacks, including two in one game (the Giants' Dave Brown and the Cardinals' Kent Graham), were knocked out of games with injuries.

title: Robertson Sentenced
description: The former National Basketball Association All-Star, ALVIN ROBERTSON, was ordered yesterday to serve six months in jail for a burglary conviction. Robertson was convicted last month of burglarizing the apartment of his former girlfriend, SHARON RAEFORD. (AP)

title: Icahn Renews Battle With RJR Nabisco
description: Carl C. Icahn renewed his battle yesterday to force the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to immediately spin off its food business from its tobacco operations, submitting the names of 10 people he hopes will replace the company's current board.

title: Trading in MCI Options Soared Recently
description: Bankers involved in the merger talks between British Telecommunications and the MCI Communications Corporation have said that when they started receiving telephone calls a few weeks ago from British reporters, they began to fear that word of their impending $22 billion deal might leak prematurely.

title: AQUILA GAS INCREASES ITS STAKE IN OASIS
description: The Aquila Gas Pipeline Corporation said yesterday that it had bought an additional 25 percent stake in the Oasis Pipe Line Company for $84 million. Aquila Gas bought the stake from Dow Hydrocarbons and Resources Inc., bringing its share in Oasis Pipe Line to 40 percent. Aquila Gas, based in San Antonio and 82 percent owned by Utilicorp United Inc., had bought 15 percent of Oasis in July. Aquila Gas said its acquisition of Oasis stock would give it greater access to supplies of natural gas in West Texas and greater market potential in the Katy, Tex., hub. Other owners of Oasis, based in Houston, include Dow Hydrocarbons and a unit of Tenneco Inc.

title: Burnishing Ives's Reputation Yet Again
description: We are rediscovering Charles Ives again. This seems to happen every 20 years or so, and then life goes on: according to a recent report by the American Symphony Orchestra League, Ives ranked only fifth among the most frequently performed American composers last season, after Hindemith. But those of us who would want him placed higher were well served over the weekend, when the Bard Music Festival brought to Alice Tully Hall three generous concerts of chamber pieces, chorales, symphonic works, band music and songs.

title: Corrections
description: A list of hours for polling places yesterday misstated the closing time for polls in Connecticut. Polls there are open today from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M., not 9 P.M.

title: Bond Prices Up Modestly In Wary Day
description: The prices of Treasury securities made modest gains in thin trading yesterday, as dealers and investors braced for a heavy new supply this week and for the outcome of today's national elections.

title: Police Blame Drag-Racing For a Crash That Killed 2
description: Two people died and six were injured in Brookville, Queens, on Sunday night when a sports car that the police said was drag-racing went out of control, hurtled across a low concrete divider and collided with a van carrying four people, including a toddler. Both cars burst into flames.

title: BANTA IN STOCK DEAL FOR DITTLER BROTHERS
description: The Banta Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Dittler Brothers Inc., a printer of direct mail literature, for about $64 million in stock. The transaction calls for Banta, a commercial and book printer based in Menasha, Wis., to acquire all of Dittler's outstanding stock for 3.07 million shares of Banta common stock. Based on Banta's closing price on Friday, the transaction is valued at $64 million. Shares of Banta, which reported sales of more than $1 billion last year, closed yesterday at $21.5, up 50 cents. Closely held Dittler has two printing plants in Atlanta and reported sales of $104 million last year. The company specializes in direct mail, promotional games, airline timetables, lottery tickets and hotel directories.

title: Invesco to Acquire AIM for $1.6 Billion
description: Invesco P.L.C., a British investment manager whose United States mutual fund business has suffered in recent years from bad publicity and mediocre returns, agreed yesterday to buy AIM Management Group Inc. for $1.6 billion in cash and stock.

title: Close Races Mean Army Of Volunteers
description: Worried that President Clinton's commanding lead in statewide polls may keep voters from casting ballots on Election Day, Democrats and Republicans are fielding thousands of paid workers and volunteers to get voters to the polls.

title: Using Rats to Trace Anatomy of Fear, Biology of Emotion
description: THE realm of emotion and feeling is a treacherous one for science. Rage, lust, envy and shame churn in the human psyche. Yearning, disappointment and fear mingle with conscious thought, sway decisions and then recede like phantoms.

title: Scaling Mystic Heights On a Driving Sufi Beat
description: On paper, there was a logic to the Next Wave Festival's double bill of the Sabri Brothers, Pakistanis who sing the Sufi devotional music called qawwali, and Cornershop, an English rock group with Punjabi roots. But onstage on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Sabri Brothers made the rockers sound like beginners.

title: Conrail Stock Shaken by Suitors' Conflicting Accounts of Talks
description: Conflicting accounts of discussions between the Norfolk Southern Corporation and CSX Corporation over the fate of Conrail yesterday sent the stock of the railroad prized by both companies into a steep dive before it pulled out later in the day.

title: Marathon Coverage By Ch. 11 Wasn't Safe
description: To broadcast the New York City Marathon, one must not miss key moments in the race. Don't miss the start. Don't miss the finish. Don't miss when one runner passes the other toward the end. Although it is not very difficult to succeed with such simple guidance, Channel 11 flopped on Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day yesterday about appointments at two advertising agencies misstated the new title of Woody Kay, executive vice president of Pagano Schenck & Kay in Boston. While remaining creative director, he was promoted to co-chairman, not co-president.

title: No Headline
description: ''I thought it was great that everybody has to serve. If I had to be there he has to be there, too.''

title: One Partnership And Two Purchases
description: A partnership and two acquisitions have been announced.

title: Republicans Seek a Second
description: In the contests for the Essex County Board of Freeholders, Republicans do not think they are asking for too much. ''We'd like to be able to introduce and second a motion so we could get our voices heard,'' Matt Kirnan, executive director of the county Republican Party, said yesterday. To do that, though, the Republicans, outnumbered eight to one on the board, would have to win a second seat.

title: Campaign Trail: Vignettes of the Longest 24 Hours
description: At midnight, Eastern standard time, there are 24 hours to go. It has gone on so very, very long, the campaign of 1996, and in a mere 1,440 minutes, give or take a few, it will finally be over.

title: One Assembly Seat Is at Stake
description: Residents of Essex and Union counties will decide today who will serve the remaining year in the unfinished term of Assemblyman Monroe Jay Lustbader, a Republican who died in March. The state's only Legislature race pits Joel Weingarten, 37, a former Milburn Councilman who was appointed to the Assembly seat by the local Republican organization, against Robert R. Peacock, 67, a Democrat of Roseland and the former chairman of Ramapo Savings Bank.

title: BMW Sales Rise 8.5%, Aided by New Models
description: A strong performance by new models that went on the market this year helped the sales of Bayerische Motoren Werke to rise 8.5 percent in the first nine months of 1996, the company said yesterday. BMW said demand was strong for its new Z3 roadster sports car and the 5-Series sedan, as well as several Rover Group models.

title: First Ninny
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban on Medical Experiments Without Consent Is Relaxed
description: For the first time in a half century, new Federal regulations allow investigators to enroll patients in some medical research studies without their consent.

title: Ruling Issued On Milken Pact
description: A Federal court denied a challenge yesterday by TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc. to the 1992 global settlement that ended litigation against the former junk bond financier Michael R. Milken.

title: Am I Better Off?
description: Am I better off than I was four years ago?

title: In the Front Lines of Politics, Anything but Apathy Awaits the Election
description: Voter turnout is predicted to be low on Tuesday. Many complain that whether Bill Clinton or Bob Dole is elected makes little difference.

title: Accounts
description: Skyy Spirits Inc., San Francisco, to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, to handle advertising for brands like Skyy Vodka, which had been handled by Monte Sandy & Needham Advertising, Walnut Creek, Calif. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Downtown Retailing Trend Again Favors a Car Culture
description: Sandwiched between Chicago and Detroit, this city of 80,000 people always had one little retail thrill to distinguish itself from its bigger neighbors. It was home to the country's first pedestrian mall, a charming European-style enclave of trees and water fountains built in 1959, lined with shops and restaurants that awaited the strollers who popped in from around the state.

title: Transplanted Serbs in a Garden of Pain and Death
description: The war in the Balkans ended two weeks ago for Milan Vuksic when he gently kissed his wife and 10-year-old son as they sat eating lunch, limped to the small common bathroom in a refugee center outside Belgrade and shot himself with a pistol.

title: CHRONICLE
description: From New York to The New Yorker.

title: Jets' Objective Is to Win, Whatever Their Motivation
description: After their bye week, which for many players meant a couch-potato Sunday watching pro football on television, the Jets returned to practice today with new goals for the rest of the season. Which goals remain for a team with a 1-8 record is unclear.

title: Broncos Only Bend; Raiders Break
description: This is not your grandfather's Denver Broncos. Denver's defense bent tonight, but did not snap in two. And Denver's offense had a running back who could run out the clock.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the recovery of the bodies of two American trekkers and three local guides killed in a snowstorm in Nepal referred incorrectly in some copies to the age of one victim. Helen Fialkow was 62, not 61.

title: Can O'Neal Charm Way To a Title?
description: WHEN Shaquille O'Neal comes to Manhattan, cameras, celebrities and excitement follow. So tonight's Knicks-Los Angeles Lakers game at Madison Square Garden will be a major event, even though the National Basketball Association season is less than a week old. There is no doubt that Shaq has enormous star power. But when his career ends, will O'Neal be remembered more for his charisma or for his championships?

title: Safir, Taking Drug War On the Road, Seeks Help
description: New York City's Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, brought his campaign against drug dealing in Washington Heights here today, asking officials for help in bringing Dominican fugitives to justice.

title: Q&A
description: Nail Ridges

title: Sierra Health Stock Falls on Acquisition Announcement
description: In a transaction that drew a resoundingly negative reaction from investors, Sierra Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it has agreed to buy the Physician Corporation of America in an all-stock deal initially valued at $509.4 million.

title: They'll Do the Writing-In
description: The Mayor and a councilman in Lower Township, both Democrats, are conducting an aggressive write-in campaign to try to retain their posts, after losing to two challengers in a June primary.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Admiral Robert E. Peary accomplished the feat by walking three feet at the North Pole. Others have trudged some 25,000 miles around the equator. And still more have done it by bicycle, submarine and -- in the cases of Neil Armstrong, Sally Ride and John Glenn -- aboard spaceships.

title: Holik Becomes A U.S. Citizen
description: Bobby Holik of the Devils had a good excuse for missing yesterday's practice. The native of Jihlava of the Czech Republic became an American citizen in Newark. Holik, 25, came to the United States as Hartford's first choice in the 1989 draft and came to the Devils in 1992 in a trade. His wife, Renee, is American, and Holik filed for citizenship as soon as he became eligible.

title: Long Island Debates Future of Psychiatric Hospitals
description: More than a century ago, Manhattan's insane asylum, as it was called then, opened an experimental farm colony on 1,000 acres of wild countryside here. The property cost $25 an acre.

title: A Stronger China Is No Threat to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget the Tropics, Pharmaceuticals May Lie in Nearby Woods
description: WHILE collecting fungi as a class assignment, a group of students at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., added to their heap of mushrooms and molds a fungus sprouting from behind the head of a beetle grub. What they had stumbled across, scientists report, was a long-sought piece of a fungal puzzle, a sexual form crucial to identifying the mold that produces the billion-dollar drug cyclosporin, which is widely used to prevent the rejection of transplanted organs.

title: Election Day Choices
description: What until a week or so ago had been an unusually bland Presidential campaign ended with both candidates battling harder than they had all year. The endgame was especially frantic for Bob Dole, who went virtually without sleep during a valiant five-day drive for votes in New Jersey and California and a dozen states in between. Even so, experts predict a lower turnout than four years ago, when a little over 104 million Americans, or 55.2 percent of the voting-age population, went to the polls -- the highest percentage since 1972.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Conrail Stock Swings Wildly On Takeover Reports

title: History Lesson: With Dow Up, Incumbent Wins
description: As goes Wall Street, so goes the election.

title: CBS Pulls 3 Wednesday Shows
description: CBS pulled the plug on its failing Wednesday night schedule yesterday, hurriedly scrapping the three series that had been broadcast from 9 to 11 P.M. and replacing them with movies for the next month.

title: A Computer in the Guise Of Futuristic Furniture
description: IT looks like something George Jetson might keep on the coffee table, electronic furniture of the future as seen from the 50's. The Compaq Presario 3020 offers perhaps the most novel desktop look in a year where design is becoming a way to sell computers. But looks are not everything.

title: Voting Hours
description: NEW YORK: Polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. All 31 House seats, state Senate and Assembly seats and county and local offices are at stake.

title: SOCCER
description: U.S. National Team

title: Man Charged in 1985 Killing
description: Police have made an arrest in the 1985 slaying of a teen-age girl under the Goethals Bridge in Elizabeth, officials said yesterday. The suspect, Roosevelt Daniels, 42, was arrested on Friday after his name came up in an unrelated police matter, which prompted investigators to revisit the 1985 case using forensic techniques that were not available when the girl, Lillian Dorothy Christopher, was killed, Edward M. Neafsey, Acting Prosecutor for Union County, said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Sunday about the Clinton Administration's efforts to end fighting in Zaire and Rwanda referred incorrectly to the former colonial power there. It was Belgium, not France.

title: Warning in Saudi Arabia
description: The United States Embassy here urged all Americans in Saudi Arabia ''to exercise increased caution and vigilance'' during the next 10 days and warned that the elections in the United States on Tuesday and other events ''could provide an excuse'' for a terrorist attack.

title: N.A.S.D. tries to split the difference on arbitration rules.
description: WHEN two sides are bitterly fighting over two issues, it sounds like a good idea to let each win one issue, effectively splitting the fight down the middle.

title: Stocks Rise, With Dow Climbing 39.50 Points
description: Wall Street breathed an Election Day sigh of relief yesterday, as expectations of a Democratic White House and a Republican Congress spurred stock prices higher. Technology stocks, moribund for weeks after many companies posted lackluster third-quarter profits, rebounded strongly, further aiding the rally.

title: Diplomas and Plentiful Jobs For 'Supply Chain Managers'
description: Arizona State University already had the country's largest undergraduate purchasing program three years ago when it revised its graduate program in purchasing and logistics to take a broader look at ''supply chain management'' -- that is, the whole process from establishing a need to getting it filled.

title: A Posthumous Victory
description: Clifford Svenningsen was seeking a fourth three-year term on the Mount Arlington Borough Council when he died of a heart attack last Friday, too late for the Republican Party to replace him on the ballot. Mr. Svenningsen won anyway yesterday with 750 votes, the second-highest total among four candidates for two seats. Mayor Dolores Rivinius, a Republican, had urged residents to vote for Mr. Svenningsen, 56, as a tribute to his public service.

title: PENRIL IS SPINNING OFF ITS REMOTE ACCESS BUSINESS
description: Penril Datacomm Networks Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its remote computer access business to shareholders on Nov. 19, creating a new company called Access Beyond Inc. The move is part of the company's effort to focus solely on the remote access business, which links users to corporate networks from outside the office. As part of the strategy, Penril also plans to sell its modem business to Bay Networks Inc. for $120 million. Shareholders of Penril, based in Gaithersburg, Md., are to receive one Access Beyond share for each Penril share held. Penril shareholders will also receive $10 in Bay Networks stock for every Penril share in exchange for the modem business. Penril's stock gained 68.75 cents, to $14.75 a share, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Corn Prices Slump on Forecast Of a Bigger Autumn Harvest
description: Corn prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after a private company forecast a larger autumn harvest than traders expected, raising concern that the crop would overwhelm demand.

title: Dining-Room Bias
description: To The Living Section:

title: Racism at Texaco
description: Critics of affirmative action routinely argue that the effort is no longer necessary because discrimination is now dead. Nothing disproves that theory as emphatically as the emerging scandal at Texaco, where senior executives have been caught on tape deriding minority employees in racist terms -- and plotting to destroy documents subpoenaed in a Federal discrimination case.

title: Just Trying to Get Even While They Get Rich
description: On the long list of Hollywood heist movies that make you root for its criminals to steal a million dollars and live happily ever after, F. Gary Gray's film ''Set It Off'' is one of the most poignantly impassioned. If this messy roller coaster of a film often seems to be going in several directions at once, it never for a second loses empathy for its quartet of black female bank robbers who grew up together in a Los Angeles housing project and earn meager wages working for a janitorial service.

title: Holyfield Is Carrying Banner for Underdogs
description: Evander Holyfield is not afraid. Not afraid that he is a 12 1/2-1 underdog to Mike Tyson. Not afraid that his most recent fights have been struggles while Tyson's have been routs.

title: Yeltsin Has 7-Hour Heart Surgery And Doctors Say It Was a Success
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin came out of a seven-hour, multiple-bypass heart operation in a hospital here on Tuesday with his doctors declaring the operation a success. They said they were optimistic about the 65-year-old Russian leader's chances of resuming a full workload.

title: Decency Standards Rejected For Federal Grants to Artists
description: A Federal appeals court today ruled that the Government cannot require the National Endowment for the Arts to consider prevailing standards of decency in making grants to artists.

title: U S WEST ACQUISITION OF CONTINENTAL APPROVED
description: U S West Media Group Inc. received Federal antitrust approval yesterday for its $11.8 billion acquisition of Continental Cablevision Inc. after promising to sell Continental's interest in Teleport Communications Group Inc. Without that sale, the Justice Department said, the Continental acquisition would have damaged competition for some telephone services in cities where Teleport competes with U S West Inc. Boston-based Continental, the cable television operator, owns 10 percent of Teleport. Teleport's shares rose $1.50 yesterday, to $28.625. The Justice Department also said yesterday that it would allow SBC Communications Inc. to buy Pacific Telesis Group.

title: A Chili Dish Lightened by Yogurt
description: Chili is often topped with sour cream. But accompanying this version is a cucumber-yogurt salad, which has its roots in Turkey, Greece and the Republic of Georgia, that is a perfect mate to the chili. It slips nicely into the place of the sour cream.

title: Problems Keep Some From The Polls
description: There were no major foul-ups like those that greeted many Brooklyn voters in the September primary, when voting machines failed to show up, but a few scattered problems were reported at New York City polling places yesterday.

title: British Air Has 24% Rise In Earnings
description: British Airways said today that earnings rose 24 percent in its fiscal second quarter as lower interest payments and the resurgence of the carrier's partner airlines, USAir Group and Qantas Airways, offset higher fuel costs.

title: Economy Helps Again
description: Four years ago, a faltering economy persuaded American voters to give Bill Clinton a chance as President. Yesterday, surveys of voters leaving the polls showed, a robust economy persuaded them that he deserved a second term.

title: Brewery's Exit Leaves a Bitter Taste
description: The breweries that made Milwaukee fa mous Schlitz, Pabst and Miller -- were a source of good jobs and civic pride for generations and became as much a part of this city's image and soul as the winds howling off Lake Michigan.

title: Belgium Holds Suspects in Immigrant Smuggling
description: The Belgian police say they have uncovered and partly dismantled a criminal network that promised at least 4,000 people from the Philippines bright futures in Western Europe -- for a price -- and then took them to Italy where they were pressed into prostitution or manual labor.

title: The Question, Days Later: Is It Soup Yet?
description: THE documentary ''Awara Soup,'' about life in Mana, a town in French Guiana whose residents are obsessed with soccer and with a complicated creole stew that is made with meat, seafood and vegetables and that takes days to make, will be shown next Wednesday at 9 P.M. The 1995 movie, released by California Newsreel, is part of the Margaret Mead Film and Video Festival at the American Museum of Natural History. Tickets, $8, or $7 for members and students, can be bought at the door or ordered by credit card at (212) 769-5200.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: In Early Results, Voters Give Meager Hints on the Outcome of the Battle for the House
description: Republicans kept control of the House early today, as the overwhelming majority of their embattled freshmen fought off challenges from Democrats and organized labor, and they won several open seats vacated by retiring Democrats.

title: The Downsizing Trend Shifts From Jobs to the Things That Companies Buy
description: When Leonard Garrambone became Nynex's head of purchasing two years ago, his assignment was clear: ride herd on the nonpayroll expenses, everything from furniture to health benefits to consulting.

title: MCKESSON UNIT SIGNS A DEAL TO SUPPLY SHOPKO STORES
description: The McKesson Corporation said yesterday that its health care unit in the United States had signed a five-year contract to supply pharmaceutical products to Shopko Stores Inc. that could be worth as much as $2.15 billion. McKesson said the agreement to supply Shopko's 130 pharmacies, which will be worth $1.1 billion over five years, will almost double in value if Phar-Mor Inc.'s planned acquisition of Shopko is completed. San Francisco-based McKesson will provide branded and generic pharmaceuticals and over-the-counter products to Shopko pharmacies and to Shopko's Provantage mail service pharmacy.

title: Among the Funeral Rites, a Lively Dating Game
description: With the tropical heat beating down from a leaden sky, family members and other mourners began crowding a funeral home here just before noon the other day.

title: AMERICAN PRECISION TO BUY A SWISS COMPANY
description: American Precision Industries agreed in principle yesterday to acquire Portescap S.A., a Swiss maker of electromechanical drive systems, for about $60 million in convertible preferred stock, an exchangeable note and cash. American Precision is acquiring Portescap, which is based in La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland, from Inter Scan Holding A.G. American Precision, which is based in Buffalo, makes heat-transfer equipment.

title: Eating Well
description: HERE are holiday gift ideas that are low in fat or calories, environmentally sound or all three.

title: Democrats Appear to Win Majority in Connecticut State Senate
description: Democrats today appeared to have won back the majority in the State Senate that they lost in 1994, picking up at least two seats in elections that Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, had cast as a referendum on the first two years of his administration.

title: Investigator Loses in Freehold
description: Joy DeSanctis, who has agreed to plead guilty to charges filed in Idaho accusing her of kidnapping a member of a religious cult, lost her bid yesterday for the Freehold Township Committee. Ms. DeSanctis, a private investigator, and her husband, Carmine, were accused of holding the cult member, LaVerne Collins, in a motel for a week while three other people tried to persuade her to leave the Church Universal and Triumphant. Republican incumbents Dave Salkin and Gene Golub were re-elected to the committee.

title: Rules of the Game
description: To The Living Section:

title: Dark Side of Einstein Emerges in His Letters
description: The stipulations were as cold and precise as any of his mathematical equations. In July 1914, Albert Einstein wrote to his first wife, Mileva Maric, the mother of his two sons, laying down a series of conditions under which he would agree to continue their marriage:

title: Nielsen Is Asked To Scrap 'Sweeps'
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies has asked Nielsen Media Research to consider gathering demographic data on television viewers year-round rather than continuing the present ''sweeps'' system of measuring viewership four times a year.

title: Savoring First Trips To Ballot Box
description: THE past few days have been a blur for Altagracia Giraldo, who kept a whirlwind schedule as hectic as any candidate's. She had stayed up late on Monday night attending meetings, visiting apartments and talking on the phone, reminding the voters she had personally registered that they had to turn out in strength.

title: Elected to '50 Greatest,' O'Neal Aims to Serve
description: When Shaquille O'Neal made the National Basketball Association's list of the 50 greatest players in history last week, some people argued that he did not belong.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in The Living Section last Wednesday with an article about organic milk that evaluated some organic and conventional milks misspelled the name of one brand. It is Krisco Farms, not Frisco Farms.

title: Torricelli's Old Seat Taken by Rothman
description: The Congressional seat left open by Robert G. Torricelli's successful run for the United States Senate was filled by a fellow Democrat. Steven A. Rothman, the former Mayor of Mr. Torricelli's hometown of Englewood, defeated Kathleen A. Donovan, the Bergen County Clerk and former chairwoman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in the Ninth District race.

title: SOUTH
description: ALABAMA -- DOLE

title: Yeltsin's Recovery: Medical and Political What-Ifs
description: Even if all goes well for Boris N. Yeltsin and today his doctors gave every reason to believe that it would -- it may be months before the Russian President can run this troubled country again.

title: Owners Ready To Turn Down Labor Deal
description: A deeply divided group of owners meets in Chicago today to act on the pending baseball labor agreement. But by yesterday, the deal's fate had been pretty well determined.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Serbian refugees misidentified one woman shown. She was Zeljka Vuksic; Milan Vuksic was her husband.

title: 'Love Therapist' And Sales Therapist
description: A recorded-music giant is hoping a make-believe ''love therapist'' can sell consumers on the concept of buying compilation albums of love songs by various artists.

title: New York's Welfare Load Is New York's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Doctor Will See You Now.' Uh-Oh.
description: David Letterman has certainly had his detractors over the years. But it's unlikely that even he could have predicted that one of them would be a woman from 18th-century China, who shows up in ''The Waiting Room,'' Lisa Loomer's calmly delirious play at the Vineyard Theater, to denounce the talk show host.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN ENDS TALKS WITH CSX
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said last night that it had terminated discussions with the CSX Corporation over their competitive bids to buy Conrail Inc. At the same time, Norfolk reaffirmed its all-cash $100-a-share offer for Conrail. On Oct. 23, Norfolk Southern announced a hostile offer intended at upending a friendly merger between CSX and Conrail. On Monday, CSX said it was discussing a post-merger sale of some of Conrail's assets to Norfolk. While confirming the talks, Norfolk insisted it was still pursuing its bid. CSX could not be reached for comment. The statement was released after the stock market closed. Shares of Norfolk Southern fell $1.75 yesterday, to $89, CSX slipped 87.5 cents, to $44, and Conrail fell $1.375, to $92.25.

title: Theater in Review
description: Serious Blocks

title: Nazis Delivered Victims' Gold to Swiss
description: To the Editor:

title: Keyboard Landscapes, Both Sweet and Spiky
description: Jean-Efflam Bavouzet, a French pianist in his mid-30's, has proven himself an unflappable advocate of contemporary works, able to find the musicality in Serialist and avant-garde pieces without sacrificing their steely edges. He offered a broader view of his interpretive personality on Sunday at Columbia University's Miller Theater, when he played music that requires a lyrical touch, flexibility of tone color and a sense of high Romantic drama.

title: Write-In Is No Shoo-In
description: Mayor Robert Conroy Jr. and Councilman Sarge O'Shea, both Democrats, lost their aggressive write-in bid to retain their jobs. Together, the four Democratic candidates -- the write-in candidates and the two men who beat them in a June primary, Edward Erne and Joseph Lonergan, respectively -- won more votes yesterday than their two Republican opponents. But the mayor's race went to Larry Starner and the Township Council seat to Arthur Blomkvest.

title: Term Limits Stay 8 Years As Extension Is Rejected
description: New York City voters rejected a ballot proposal yesterday that would have extended the amount of time the city's elected officials can stay in office, voting instead to keep the existing limit of two terms, or eight years.

title: Excerpts From President Clinton's Victory Address at Arkansas Statehouse
description: Following are excerpts of a transcript of the speech President Clinton delivered last night outside the Statehouse in Little Rock, Ark., after his re-election:

title: Astros Hire Cubbage
description: The new Houston Astros manager, LARRY DIERKER, completed his coaching staff yesterday by hiring MIKE CUBBAGE as third-base coach.

title: New Faces in Congress
description: NEW YORK

title: Defense Lawyer Says Accuser Fabricated Rape Charge Out of Shame
description: Ten years after a 16-year-old girl accused Alex Kelly of rape, his lawyer said it was a lie invented by a girl from ''a strict Catholic family with its prohibitions and its rules.'' She was ashamed, he said, of choosing to lose her virginity in the back of a car with ''an attractive older boy'' she had just met.

title: Flatley Wonders If He'll Face Isles
description: As the Rangers prepared today to head to Long Island Wednesday night for their first meeting of the season with the Islanders, there were a number of subplots surrounding one of hockey's most heated rivalries.

title: New Republican in Assembly
description: In New Jersey's only State Legislature race, voters in Essex and Union counties elected Joel Weingarten, 37, a former Milburn Councilman, to serve the remaining year in the unfinished term of Assemblyman Monroe Jay Lustbader, a Republican who died in March. Unofficial tallies yesterday showed Mr. Weingarten, a Republican, with 40,154 votes to 30,340 for Robert Peacock, a Democrat of Roseland and a former chairman of the Ramapo Savings Bank.

title: The Challenge of Victory
description: President Clinton started out ahead in the polls, and nine months of campaigning and an estimated $800 million in spending seem not to have made a dent. The last two weeks of the campaign will be remembered more for their surly tone and alarming hints of White House scandal than for memorable debate.

title: Seeking Harmony, Finding Cabernet
description: THERE are pessimists who say the heart has gone out of the wine business, that the pioneers and risk takers have abandoned the stage to number crunchers and marketing types and that one day, not too far off, all wines will taste pretty much the same.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Civil Rights Groups Asking U.S. to Join Texaco Bias Suit
description: An umbrella organization of 180 civil rights groups has asked the Government to join a discrimination lawsuit brought against Texaco Inc. by some of its employees, an official at the organization said yesterday.

title: Of TV in Montreal
description: To the Editor:

title: Balance of Power Unchanged Between Democrats and Republicans in Albany
description: The majority parties in the New York State Legislature coasted through the election yesterday, emerging as entrenched as ever.

title: Incumbent Loses In Albany County
description: In the other defeat of an incumbent in the State Senate, Neil Breslin, a Democrat and political neophyte, ousted Michael J. Hoblock Jr., a first-term Republican, in Albany County.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Good Wins, the Bad Loses

title: Now That's Interesting
description: If you read between the lines of the recent stories in The Washington Post, New York Times and Arab media about who was behind the June 25 bombing of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, two intriguing facts stand out: Fact #1 is that Saudi Arabia is accusing Iran and pro-Iranian Saudi Shiites of masterminding the bombings, which killed 19 Americans and injured hundreds more. Fact #2 is that Saudi Arabia is letting it be known that Syria may have been involved in this bombing, because a key witness ''committed suicide'' while in Syrian custody before he could testify. Now for Saudi Arabia, a notoriously cautious nation, to let these incendiary facts out on the eve of the U.S. elections is very interesting. What's going on? Here are a few possible explanations:

title: Personal Health
description: LAWSUITS over two eventually fatal cases of cervical cancer that were missed in repeated misreadings of Pap smears and news reports of substandard methods in some laboratories have had at least two happy results. The attention of women and the medical profession is now focused on the true benefits and limitations of this most popular screening tool. And new rules have been established and techniques designed to improve the test's accuracy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Traders Bet on Continuity And Markets Rise Strongly

title: Stolen Stradivarius Divides a Family
description: Marcelle Hall thought she had exhausted her 15 minutes of fame in 1987 when she returned a stolen Stradivarius to Lloyd's of London -- a violin that she said her husband told her on his deathbed he had stolen from a Carnegie Hall dressing room in 1936.

title: Relief for Winter: Heating Oil Prices Fall
description: Refiners have begun producing heating oil in near-record amounts in recent weeks, easing fears that prices will soar this winter. The high production, which surprised the industry, has sent wholesale and retail prices tumbling.

title: Doctor Dad Dissects Kanell's Day in Sun
description: Dr. Dan Kanell Sr. saw his son's winning touchdown pass for the Giants on the big-screen television Sunday at Foxboro Stadium, where he was serving as the Miami Dolphins' team physician. Yet because of a late flight home, father and son didn't speak until the morning after.

title: Traffic Congestion
description: To the Editor:

title: Runners Deny Pacing
description: Two Brazilian runners who ran near ANUTA CATUNA of Romania late in last Sunday's New York City Marathon told a Brazilian newspaper that they did not know Catuna and were simply offering her vocal support as she surged toward victory. FRANCA FIACCONI of Italy, the second-place finisher, complained that Catuna had received help on the course.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in SportsTuesday on Oct. 29 listing recipients of the Key to New York City, with an article about the Yankees' planned victory celebration, misstated the title of Miguel de la Madrid, who recieved the honor in 1986. He was President of Mexico, not Mayor of Mexico City.

title: Abrams of Eagles Is Punched in Game
description: Danya Abrams, a Boston College forward and first-team all-Big East player last season, was punched in the face tonight during an exhibition game against the Converse All-Stars.

title: Remarks By Dole in Conceding Defeat by Clinton
description: Following are excerpts from the concession speech tonight by Bob Dole, the Republican nominee for President, at a hotel in Washington, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private company:

title: Japanese Stocks Rise
description: Stocks soared in trading here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 399.19 points, or 1.94 percent, at 20,991.52. On Tuesday, the Nikkei lost 40.73.

title: Following Harsh Race, Kind Words for the Winner
description: The official election night celebration at the headquarters for Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, seemed over even before it started.

title: T. Vincent Learson, 84, I.B.M. Chief, Dies
description: T. Vincent Learson, a former chairman of I.B.M. who led the company's gamble on a new generation of computers in the early 1960's, a project whose success insured I.B.M.'s prosperity for two decades, died on Monday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 84 and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: Borough Development Units Are Turned Down by Pataki
description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill yesterday that would have shifted some of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's authority over economic development in New York City to the five borough presidents.

title: TV Soccer Rights To Bertelsmann
description: Bertelsmann A.G. has bought exclusive rights to live broadcasts of some major league German soccer games for two seasons, gaining an important stronghold in the battle for control of the German pay television market, the company's chief executive said today.

title: Spanish Court Clears Leader In 'Dirty War'
description: Spain's Supreme Court voted by a narrow margin today to clear former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of involvement with death squads blamed for killing Basque separatists in the 1980's.

title: Wetteland and Girardi File For Their Free-Agent Status
description: The Yankees' No. 1 relief pitcher and No. 1 catcher filed for free agency yesterday, but not necessarily to get away from the Yankees.

title: Theater in Review
description: Poet With an Eye for Women,

title: Hormone Therapy Can Increase Bone Mass, New Study Says
description: Hormone replacement therapy can do more than slow the loss of bone after menopause; it can actually increase bone mass even in women who start using it in their 60's, a new study has shown.

title: Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr., 89, Leading Investment Banker
description: Carl Howard Pforzheimer Jr., a leading New York investment banker, book collector and benefactor of medicine, education and the arts, died on Monday at his home in Stuart, Fla. He was 89 and a former resident of Purchase, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: N.C.A.A. Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolling With the 'River'
description: Some people in South Toms River think the town would have a spiffier image if it changed its name. But most residents who voted yesterday were satisfied with the current name. By a vote of 802 to 362, voters in the Ocean County community rejected a measure that would have changed the borough's name to Cedar Pointe. Supporters had argued that a new name would enhance property values in the largely blue-collar town. Opponents said the name change would cost taxpayers thousands of dollars.

title: Father and Son Lose Their Races
description: In an acrimonious race, two Democratic candidates brought a bruising halt to the political careers of the incumbents, State Senator Pedro G. Espada of the 32d District, and his son, Assemblyman Pedro Gautier Espada of the 75th District. Defeating the Espadas were City Councilman David Rosado, who was elected to a State Senate seat with 78 percent of the vote, and Ruben Diaz Jr., a Democratic leader, who was elected to the Assembly with 73 percent.

title: Focused and Passionate Campaigner
description: Robert Guy Torricelli is a lifelong politician. He began running for office in the fifth grade. He ran for office in high school. And by the time he got to college, he knew just how to get the voters' attention.

title: Fanciful Flights of Food, by Mail Order
description: IT'S a tough job but someone has to do it: taste about 150 samples of cookies and cakes, smoked meats and fish, cheeses and jams to decide which are worthy of being included in the New York Times annual holiday mail-order list.

title: No Headline
description: ''I considered not voting for President. I kept going back and forth, I talked about it more than I ever have in my life -- I even was discussing it with my dentist. But in the end there were issues that were too important.'' SALLY EFREMOFF, 57, of Canton, Ohio. $(A17:1.$)

title: Law Secretary Defeats Incumbent
description: Ann Margaret Carrozza, a 29-year-old Democratic lawyer and law secretary to a Supreme Court justice in Queens, defeated one of the senior members of the Assembly, Republican incumbent Douglas Prescott. Except for a two-year period, Mr. Prescott has represented northeastern Queens since 1980.

title: President Clinton Makes a Celebratory Return to His Starting Point in Arkansas
description: President Clinton came back tonight to where it all began, down a red carpet to the illuminated steps of the Old State House where he delivered his first acceptance speech four years ago.

title: For Ohio Republicans, Shifting Allegiance Was Hard; for Some, Too Hard
description: When it was all said and done, Sally Efremoff, 57, a family court magistrate and longtime suburban school board member, walked into her polling place, Trinity United Church of Christ in Plain Township, and cast her first vote ever for the Democrat for President.

title: NORTHEAST
description: CONNECTICUT -- CLINTON

title: The Souls of Prewar Berlin, but Not the Faces
description: A frieze of rabbits and dogs runs round the top of a wall papered with elephants, pandas, monkeys and palms. A pig and a squirrel share a tiny settee, and a teddy bear drives a small car across the floor. This is the nursery of the Goldschmidt-Rothschild children in Berlin, two years before the coming of the Third Reich. Their toys were captured in this state of implausible tidiness by a photographer named Marta Huth in the winter of 1931, along with their father's priceless collection of Dutch paintings and French furniture downstairs. All were shortly to go under the hammer.

title: Company Briefs
description: INVESTCORP, Bahrain, an investment company, has sold 26 percent, or 7.25 million shares, of Prime Service Inc. , a rental equipment company, Houston, at $23.50 a share in an initial public offering.

title: WEST
description: ALASKA

title: Saluting a Teacher and the Vienna of Old
description: There were both heartening and slightly amusing undercurrents in the Mannes College of Music's tribute to Felix Galimir on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall. The ostensible occasion was Mr. Galimir's 20th anniversary as a member of the Mannes faculty. But unlike laborers in other fields, musicians tend not to cash in 20 years of service for a pension and a gold watch, nor do they usually retire at 65.

title: Bond Prices Post Sharp Increases
description: Weak economic data and a strong dollar, combined with expectations in the stock and bond markets that the post-election political landscape will not change, sent bond prices sharply higher yesterday.

title: Rail Victim's Widow Captures House Seat
description: Carolyn McCarthy, whose husband was shot on a Long Island commuter train and who ran on a gun control platform, won a House seat by soundly defeating a freshman Republican. In Connecticut, Representative Gary A. Franks, a black conservative considered a rising G.O.P. star, lost his seat, while voters in New York City rejected a plan to lengthen term limits for elected city officials.

title: Experts Disagree on Adding Fatty Acid to Infant Formula
description: IN the last year and a half, the issue of adding a certain fatty acid to infant formula has become an international cause celebre.

title: Kelly Fends Off Democratic Rival
description: Representative Sue W. Kelly yesterday fended off a well-financed Democratic challenger, Richard S. Klein, to preserve the long Republican hold on the 19th District.

title: Upheaval in Pakistan
description: A grim sense of deja vu surrounds the sudden ouster of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan. With Ms. Bhutto under house arrest, and the capital of Islamabad ringed with army troops, democracy and democratic institutions are clearly once again in peril. To prevent the country's latest political crisis from leading to greater turmoil, the new caretaker Government installed by Pakistan's President must fulfill the promise to call new elections, with Ms. Bhutto and her political organization allowed to participate. Any charges of corruption against her or her entourage must be made, and proved, in court.

title: Near Boston, Developer Takes the Plunge: An Office Building on Speculation
description: Boston Properties Inc., the owner of 12 million square feet of real estate -- mostly office buildings -- in New York, Boston and Washington, is doing its first speculative office project in seven years.

title: Gehe Rejoins Battle To Buy Lloyds Chemists
description: Gehe A.G. rejoined a bidding battle yesterday against Unichem P.L.C. for Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., offering to buy the British drugstore chain for the same $:650.6 million ($1.06 billion) it bid in February. Under the Gehe offer, shareholders will get cash, while Unichem's bid of $:651.5 million is a mixture of cash and shares. Analysts and investors said shareholders were likely to favor Gehe.

title: Westinghouse Special Meeting
description: The board of Westinghouse Electric Corporation held a special meeting in New York yesterday, and analysts speculated that directors and management were discussing a long-anticipated plan to split the company's media and industrial businesses.

title: U.S. May Send Troops to Zaire To Aid Those Fleeing Fighting
description: Prompted by France, American officials are considering whether to send some American troops to Central Africa for logistical support in an international force to protect and feed up to 1.4 million refugees caught in the fighting between Zaire and Rwanda, senior American and European officials said today.

title: Big Gains for Small Colleges In Fund-Raising Campaigns
description: Some small liberal arts colleges, which have long looked enviously at the fund-raising prowess of the major private universities, are beginning to gain admission to the big leagues.

title: Goodbye To All That
description: Don't you feel better already?

title: Democrats Pick Up Seat as Pascrell Defeats Martini in Expensive Eighth District Race
description: Democrats picked up one Congressional seat as Mayor William J. Pascrell of Paterson outlasted Representative William J. Martini, a freshman Republican, to win the high-priced, gritty race in New Jersey's Eighth District.

title: Theater in Review
description: An Avuncular Vonnegut

title: WEAK SALES ANNOUNCEMENT SENDS UNIFY SHARES TUMBLING
description: The shares of the Unify Corporation fell 38 percent yesterday after the company forecast a second-quarter loss because of weak sales of certain graphics products. The developer of data base software based in San Jose, Calif., said revenues from its core products are meeting expectations. But sales of its graphics products have been hurt by longer delays in orders and a tendency by customers to make orders larger and less frequent. Unify expects second-quarter revenues to come in at $7.2 million. It expects $1.8 million in losses for the period. Unify shares closed down $3.625 yesterday at $5.75.

title: Joy for the Victor and Praise for His Predecessor
description: Despite the three giant television screens in the ballroom of the Sheraton Woodbridge Plaza Hotel, tonight's celebration by Robert G. Torricelli and his supporters had an old-fashioned touch.

title: Nicaragua Now Plans to Look Into Where the Bodies Are Buried
description: In a wooded area just off a rutted road here, a simple white cross has recently been planted in the ground. It was at this site, Maria Reyes Ruiz asserts, that two of her brothers and 11 other people were buried in a common, clandestine grave after the newly installed Sandinista revolutionary Government arrested and executed them in 1979.

title: Armstrong Back Home
description: The former world champion cyclist LANCE ARMSTRONG is out of the hospital after undergoing brain surgery and chemotherapy.

title: Gingrich Says Attack Was 'Tribute'
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich presented himself as a leader more honored than humbled today after having been personally targeted in an estimated 75,000 Democratic attack ads across the land in one of the most singularly vituperative campaigns in modern politicking.

title: MCI's Risky Deal
description: British Telecommunications' $22 billion deal for MCI is not just another big media merger, because MCI isn't just another media company. It is the company that single-handedly invented competition in telecommunications, the David that took on the world's largest company, AT&T.

title: 2d Dissident Slate of Candidates Is Filed for RJR Nabisco Board
description: Taking Wall Street by surprise, Bennett S. LeBow, the investor who failed to win control of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation last April, filed a dissident slate of nine board nominees yesterday. It was another attempt to force the company to spin off its food business immediately from its tobacco operations.

title: Union Effort Helps Democrats Win Franks's Seat
description: Democrats gained one Congressional seat in Connecticut yesterday as a rising national star for the Republicans, Representative Gary A. Franks, a black conservative from Waterbury, was swept out of office after three terms representing the Fifth District, a stronghold for his party since the Reagan years.

title: A Big Man, Big Attraction
description: It wasn't as if center Shawn Bradley wasn't prepared for the wild reception he received when the Nets landed in Japan on Monday for two games with the Magic this week.

title: Lakers Are Early Choice for Best Makeover
description: Forget the endless hype and their unbeaten records. The Knicks and the Los Angeles Lakers -- two of the mightiest preseason-magazine teams of all time -- came to Madison Square Garden last night looking for people who could distinguish between a glossy cover and the truth.

title: CHECK POINT SOFTWARE STOCK DECLINES ON NEWS
description: The stock of Check Point Software Technologies Ltd. fell yesterday after the company disclosed that revenue from Sun Microsystems Inc., a big distributor of its software, had fallen in the latest quarter. Shares of Check Point, an Israeli company, fell $4.75, to $25.625. An analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, Rakesh Sood, said revenue from Sun, which ships Check Point software with its computers, fell to $2.7 million in the third quarter from $3.8 million in the second quarter. Separately, the company also said it was named in a lawsuit filed by Checkpoint Systems Inc. of Thorofare, N.J., which contends trademark infringement and unfair competition because of the Check Point name. Check Point said it believes the charges are without merit.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on Sunday about the education proposals made by President Clinton and Bob Dole misstated the position held by Robert B. Reich. He is the current Secretary of Labor, not the former one.

title: Missteps Cited Before Woman's Killing
description: For six weeks, the police and Manhattan prosecutors had reason to believe that Pasquale Coppola was so morbidly obsessed with his estranged wife that he might kill her. Yet in a series of missteps and miscommunications, they repeatedly allowed him to elude their grasp, culminating with Mr. Coppola's fatally shooting Helen Coppola the day after a judge had mistakenly been assured that Mr. Coppola was in jail.

title: Pungent and Prized, However You Slice It (Preferably, Thin)
description: THE ancient Romans appreciated them. Uncanny pigs and dogs ferret them out at the bases of oak trees in Piedmont, Perigord and Provence. They are truffles. And now New Yorkers have caught the scent.

title: Devils Drop Reese in Favor of Dunham
description: The Devils discarded another veteran player yesterday in favor of youth. Goaltender Jeff Reese was dropped, following in the footsteps of forward Neal Broten, who was told three weeks ago that his services were no longer needed.

title: BASF to Sell Tape Unit To Kohap of Korea
description: BASF A.G. said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its 1.2 billion mark ($795 million) magnetic tape business to the South Korean textile maker Kohap Ltd. instead of Raks Electronics of Turkey. The company did not disclose the price of the new deal.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: MY locker at the West Side Y is near the pay phone; consequently I hear many conversations, some worth repeating.

title: Two Coaches With a Single Destination
description: THE National Basketball Association season is young, but Coach Jeff Van Gundy had no doubt that the Knicks' showdown last night with the Los Angeles Lakers was significant.

title: CLINTON ELECTED TO A 2D TERM WITH SOLID MARGINS ACROSS U.S.; G.O.P. KEEPS HOLD ON CONGRESS
description: William Jefferson Clinton was re-elected President of the United States yesterday, capping a yearlong political resurgence that made him the first Democrat since Franklin Delano Roosevelt to win a second term as President.

title: New Faces In the Senate
description: SOUTH DAKOTA

title: 23,000 Newspapers Stolen After Referendum Editorial
description: The entire print run of the University of California at Berkeley's free newspaper -- some 23,000 copies -- was stolen from its racks this morning after the paper ran an editorial supporting a state referendum that would end affirmative action programs, campus police and the newspaper's editors said.

title: A Democrat Wins In Brooklyn District
description: In a heated State Senate contest that deepened the fissures in the Republican Party in Brooklyn, Vincent Gentile, a 37-year-old assistant district attorney in Queens, became the first Democrat since 1984 to be elected from the district to the State Senate. The district's core is in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bensonhurst and Bay Ridge and in a small section of Staten Island.

title: Memories of Franey
description: To The Living Section:

title: Opting for Appointed Mayor
description: Residents of Bedminster Township voted 1,819 to 1,594 yesterday to reject a referendum proposal that would have changed their form of government so the mayor would be elected to a four-year term. Under current laws, the mayor is chosen each year by the five-member Township Committee.

title: No, Don't Relax Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising in the Bathroom
description: The University of Toronto has decided to lease advertising space in its bathrooms, causing a backlash among students and faculty that includes a guerrilla campaign to replace the ads with modern art.

title: Henning Concedes Possibility Of Betting
description: Dan Henning, the Boston College football coach, acknowledged today for the first time that some of his players may have jeopardized their eligibility by gambling on sporting events.

title: CISCO REPORTS STRONG EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS
description: Cisco Systems Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income was $180.9 million, or 26 cents a share, compared with net income of $181.4 million, or 28 cents, in the first quarter of last year. Profit from operations, however, was $320.8 million, or 47 cents, in the quarter ended Oct. 29. During the quarter, Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., took a charge of $175 million, or 26 cents a share, and reported a pretax gain of $55 million, or 5 cents. Wall Street expected the company to earn 46 cents a share, according to 33 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. In after-hours trading, shares of Cisco Systems fell 25 cents, to $61.50. The maker of computer networking equipment said revenue rose 79 percent to $1.43 billion.

title: Pappas Overcomes Del Vecchio Charges
description: In New Jersey's tightly contested 12th District, Mike Pappas, a Republican, defeated his Democratic opponent, David M. Del Vecchio, overcoming Mr. Del Vecchio's attempt to paint Mr. Pappas's opposition to abortion rights and gun control as too extreme.

title: If you're looking for a New Year's Eve cruise  in 1999, now is the time to get in line.
