description: AS Times Square and other traditional New Year's Eve sites plan for the arrival of the year 2000, the travel industry is also busy preparing to ring out the old and ring in the new.

title: Carril and Thompson Nominated to Hall
description: PETE CARRIL, whose Princeton teams were everybody's favorite National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament underdogs, and JOHN THOMPSON, who transformed Georgetown into one of college basketball's top teams, were nominated yesterday for the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass.

title: Democrats Fail to Reverse Right's Capitol Hill Gains
description: With close races all across the country, Republicans retained control of the Senate and the House in yesterday's elections.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Since he's an author, JAY McINERNEY is one of those men who needn't ever wear a suit. But he likes to.

title: Yes, Allow Some Medical Study Without Consent
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Sean Connery For Bond and Beyond
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is to honor Sean Connery at its annual gala tribute on May 5.

title: Ruin the Raceway
description: To the Editor:

title: Day of Losses Doesn't Keep D'Amato From Gazing at '98
description: Someone in the great Republican political machine in Nassau County, Long Island, was probably out of a job last night because when Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, kingmaker in races from town supervisor to President, went to vote yesterday, his name was inexplicably missing from the voting rolls.

title: Dispute May Delay Abortion Drug in the U.S.
description: A dispute between the groups working to bring the French abortion pill to American women is threatening to create further delays in making the drug, mifepristone, available.

title: San Francisco Nears Domestic-Partner Benefits Rule for Companies
description: Pressing a new case for the equal treatment of same-sex couples, San Francisco is moving to become the first major city in the country to require the companies with which it does business to offer health and other benefits to the unmarried partners of their employees.

title: Men in 'Servitude'
description: To The Living Section:

title: A Mile-High Party Out of Bounds
description: Their coach has had everyone over to the house, and their quarterback has had everyone over to the end zone. Their season began with a game of craps, continued Monday night with a game of catch and now there is only one bored Denver Bronco: the team doctor.

title: Table Etiquette 101
description: Like many of his college friends, Paul Pastor knows that landing his first job at a consulting firm next year won't simply be about good grades. He's got to know how to handle a soup spoon.

title: An F.D.A. Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Fordham's Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDWEST
description: ILLINOIS -- CLINTON

title: De Benedetti Selling French Company Stake
description: The former chairman of Olivetti S.p.A., Carlo de Benedetti, is selling his stake of nearly 27 percent in the French auto parts maker Valeo S.A. for 6.5 billion francs ($1.27 billion). Mr. de Benedetti's French holding company, Cerus S.A., said yesterday that it would sell more than 20 percent of Valeo to a French investment concern, Compagnie Generale d'Industrie et de Participations. Valeo is France's second-largest supplier of auto parts, behind Michelin.

title: Lachemann Returns
description: MARCEL LACHEMANN, who resigned as the California Angels' manager three months ago, rejoined the club yesterday as pitching coach on the staff of TERRY COLLINS, who was hired as the team's manager on Monday. Lachemann, 55, spent nine years as the team's pitching coach. He has been with the Angels' organization for 14 years. ''There is no finer teacher than Marcel Lachemann,'' Collins said. (AP)

title: Slick Magazine Offers Immigrant Readers Practical Advice
description: Magazines on the newsstands were not speaking to Karen Hylton, who moved to Brooklyn three years ago from the island of Jamaica.

title: Zairian Rebel Leader Invites U.N. to Return
description: The commander of the ragtag rebel army that now controls this looted town in eastern Zaire invited the United Nations and international aid agencies today to return and resume caring for nearly 700,000 Rwandan refugees who are fleeing the fighting. But Goma remained in chaos and security in the region remained tenuous at best.

title: Democrats Make Inroads In Elections for Governor
description: As President Clinton won a second term tonight with surprising victories in former Republican strongholds like Florida and New Hampshire, Democratic candidates for governor also headed to victory in states well known for their Republican leanings.

title: With Goats and Gunfire, Pakistanis Cheer Bhutto's Fall
description: Goats were slain in the street, automatic rifles were fired jubilantly in the air, and cakes and sweetmeats were distributed free in bazaars today as much of Pakistan celebrated the dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and the dissolution of her Government.

title: For Jets' Douglas, The Wait Is Over
description: Pro football life was going so well for Hugh Douglas. Last season, when his 10 sacks broke Joe Klecko's 18-year-old club rookie record, he was voted the National Football League's defensive rookie of the year. This season, in the first two and a fraction games, he had 14 tackles, 2 sacks and 1 forced fumble.

title: Food Notes
description: Ciao, Mr. Chips

title: Strategy of Torricelli Painted Foe as Extreme
description: Convince New Jersey's independent, middle-class voters that Congressional Republicans endanger Federal programs they care about. Campaign relentlessly against Speaker Newt Gingrich. Portray your Republican opponent as a Gingrich ally and an extremist out of step with the state's moderate tradition.

title: 75% Interest in Cigar Is Sold to Stud Group
description: Even as he was being led from his stall at Belmont Park for the last time for the flight to Kentucky and a new career, Cigar was being sold yesterday by Allen Paulson to Coolmore Stud, where he will embark next year on his new role as a stallion.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan referred incorrectly in some editions to the date of the execution of her father, former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. He was hanged in 1979, not 1977.

title: TORRICELLI WINS SENATE CONTEST
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat who has served in Congress for seven terms, won election to New Jersey's open United States Senate seat yesterday.

title: Forbes Holds Seat On Long Island
description: Representative Michael P. Forbes, an early supporter of House Speaker Newt Gingrich, easily withstood a challenge from Nora L. Bredes yesterday to hold onto his seat in the First Congressional District on Long Island.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: High-Tech Fraternity
description: It's not a glass house, but it might as well be considering how many people have come to peer into the new high-tech home of the Phi Kappa Theta fraternity at Washington State University.

title: Costly Race Keeps Kerry In the Senate
description: After eight debates and a total of $10 million spent on television advertising, in what was one of the most closely watched and hard-fought races in the country, John F. Kerry survived a tough challenge by the popular Republican Governor, William F. Weld, to win re-election as Senator of Massachusetts.

title: Voter Interviews Suggest Clinton Was Persuasive On Path of U.S.
description: On both sides, voters cast their ballots with fingers crossed yesterday. About half of President Clinton's backers said they had emerged from the voting booth with second thoughts, as did close to 6 in 10 of Bob Dole's.

title: Unit Being Formed Against Tobacco
description: David Milenthal, chairman and chief executive at HMS Partners in Columbus, Ohio, is continuing his efforts to persuade the advertising and marketing industries to help stop the sale of tobacco products to minors by forming a task force called the Initiative on Tobacco Marketing and Children.

title: Governor Claims Victory For Environment Bond Act
description: Gov. George E. Pataki claimed victory last night for passage of the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act, which will authorize the state to spend $1.75 billion during the next three decades on environmental projects, from buying clean electric vehicles to closing leaky landfills to building sewage treatment plants.

title: The Second Term: Promise and Peril
description: Four years ago Bill Clinton won the Presidency with an outsized agenda and an underwhelming mandate, and the gulf between the two left him struggling in the first half of his term simply to establish his legitimacy. By the midpoint, the President had been reduced to proclaiming his own relevance.

title: People
description: * Gary M. Mulloy was named president and chief operating officer at Advo Inc., Windsor, Conn., succeeding Joe Durrett, who left to become chief executive at Broderbund Software Inc., San Francisco. Mr. Mulloy had been president and chief executive at Pilkington Barnes-Hind, Sunnyvale, Calif., a division of Pilkington Vision Care.

title: British Petroleum Posts Profit Rise
description: British Petroleum announced yesterday that it had a strong rise in third-quarter profits despite downward pressure on its margins in refining, marketing and chemicals.

title: An Election Day For 2d Thoughts
description: More than half the voters yesterday spoke openly about having second thoughts. Those voting for President Clinton said they had confidence enough in the nation's economy to overcome doubts about their candidate's honesty. Bob Dole meanwhile pulled nearly half the wavering voters his way as the campaign ended.

title: His Journey Over, Dole Ends Campaign With Sigh
description: Bob Dole formally conceded, at 11:25 tonight, that he had lost his fourth and last try for national office, but he had been informally conceding that fact for several hours, even before the end of his 96-hour marathon campaign swing.

title: APPLE COMPUTER REDUCES THE PRICE ON SOME SERVERS
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it had lowered by 12 percent to 23 percent the price it charges resellers in the United States for its servers based on its Macintosh operating system. The company, based in Cupertino, Calif., said the new prices cover products bundled with software for World Wide Web and Internet publishing, Mac OS-based applications and Appleshare file and print services. Servers affected by the price cuts will range in estimated retail price from $1,900 to $6,100. The Compaq Computer Corporation, a seller of personal computers that use the Windows operating system, also cut server prices, reducing the price on selected Compaq Prosignia 300 servers by up to 12 percent.

title: In California, Voters Bar Preferences Based on Race
description: Californians yesterday approved a ballot measure banning most state-sponsored affirmative action.

title: Student Group Attacks U.S. News College Guide
description: The U.S. News & World Report college guide, in which editors rank hundreds of institutions by value and academic standing, is under attack from a group of students who say the magazine's methods are decidedly unacademic.

title: Dreyfus is planning to put new life in the old lion by urging investors to 'Rule your kingdom.'
description: THE Dreyfus lion comes roaring back in an assertive campaign that begins today. But the beast had better be a mountain lion because the campaign, by Citron Haligman Bedecarre in San Francisco, faces a dauntingly steep uphill climb in convincing consumers that Dreyfus's mutual funds offer improved investment opportunities.

title: Hinchey Defeats Conservative Foe
description: Maurice D. Hinchey, a two-term Congressman who proudly campaigned as a liberal despite Republican efforts to stigmatize his outlook, was re-elected yesterday in a closely watched race against Sue Wittig, who ardently opposed abortion and gun control, in a largely rural New York State district.

title: Theater in Review
description: Visiting an Old New World

title: Accounts
description: * Sapient Corp., Cambridge, Mass., to Frierson & Mee, New York, to handle advertising and marketing for the networking solutions company, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $1.2 million. Also, Schieffelin & Somerset Co., New York, a unit of Guinness P.L.C., to Frierson & Mee to handle promotions for its new-brand development group, which had been handled by CMG Communications, New York. Billings have not been determined.

title: One Commando Still At Large In Korea Submarine Manhunt
description: Nearly seven weeks after 26 North Korean commandos slipped ashore on a rocky South Korean coast after their submarine ran aground, just one of them remains at large after outwitting the 40,000 South Korean troops searching for him.

title: So Reserved, and Yet, King of Beasts
description: Henri Matisse may have said that he wanted his art to be as soothing as a comfortable armchair, but that doesn't mean that a film about the great French painter should put you to sleep. Perry Wolf's uninspired documentary tonight on PBS comes close, being saved by the greatness of the art itself, although even that isn't as well represented as it might be.

title: TV Networks Keep Word, Holding Back on Returns
description: The three major broadcast networks kept their promise tonight not to call the Presidential winner until the polls had closed in enough states to guarantee the 270 votes needed for victory.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE ELECTIONS

title: High-Flying Falcon Piles Up Yardage
description: You could make a case for Beau Morgan, the quarterback at Air Force, as the most exciting player in college football. Maybe even as the best player in college football.

title: Princeton Will Stay Split
description: Since 1952, Princeton Borough has voted six times against a proposal to merge with Princeton Township. Yesterday, despite speculation that a heavy voter turnout among Princeton University students might reverse that trend, the borough rejected the measure by a vote of 1,878 to 1,418.

title: Perot Supporters Concentrate on Their Goals for the Future
description: Ross Perot acknowledged defeat tonight, congratulated President Clinton and victorious Congressional candidates and then immediately put the White House and Capitol Hill on notice.

title: Dole Campaign Ends With a Misstep, Conceding by Mistake
description: In the final hours of Bob Dole's campaign, the candidate took to appearing with a reproduction of a famous newspaper headline, which gave Mr. Dole hope in the face of discouraging polls. ''Dewey Defeats Truman,'' The Chicago Daily Tribune declared in 1948, the evening before Harry S. Truman won re-election to the Presidency.

title: INSIDE
description: Wall St. Bets on Status Quo

title: Somber News for Women on Corporate Ladder
description: If only corporate America would make it easier for women to take care of their duties at home, they could at last compete on an equal footing with men in the workplace -- and rise to the top.

title: Staying With God For Better or Worse
description: FOR a man who has come to talk about the perils of trying to be perfect, Rabbi Harold S. Kushner shows commendable patience when told that his restaurant table is not yet ready, despite a reservation.

title: A Scholar's Prophecy: Global Cultural Conflict
description: THE CLASH OF CIVILIZATIONS AND THE REMAKING OF WORLD ORDER

title: Lakers' Mission: To Grow Together
description: They were moving and he was shaking. There was Elden Campbell, left as the uncertain spectator to the Lakers' summer salary-cap maneuvers.

title: The Big Scam of 1996
description: Bill Clinton's critics on both the left and the right have derided him as a copycat politician. In his campaign, Bob Dole joked that 1996 felt like the first year of a Dole Presidency.

title: Ravitz Survives A Challenge
description: Assemblyman John Ravitz survived a strong challenge from Jess A. Velona, a 35-year-old Democrat and lawyer with the firm of Paul Weiss Rifkin Wharton & Garrison. Mr. Ravitz, a Republican supported by Mayor Giuliani, represents the Upper East Side of Manhattan. A former social worker, he is also a protege of Roy M. Goodman, the popular Republican State Senator from that area.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Well, my dear,'' said KITTY CARLISLE HART by way of an update, ''I've gone back to my night job.''

title: Auto Makers Fell Shy of Expectations
description: Vehicle sales were below expectations last month, rising only slightly from the lackluster period a year before. Sales of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans were strong but the results were dragged down by car sales.

title: Those Special Election Bells, Whistles and, Yes, Some Numbers, Too
description: Who is spreading the canard that when it comes to election-night coverage you can't tell one network from another? For one thing they had different names. CBS was covering ''Campaign '96''; NBC, ''Decision '96''; ABC, ''Politics '96''; CNN, ''Election '96,'' and PBS, ''Vote '96.''

title: Tender Solution for a Tough Cut of Meat
description: IN the beginning, centuries ago, braising represented a technological breakthrough involving what was then the latest high-tech equipment: a container that was waterproof, fire resistant and blessed with a tight-fitting lid.

title: This Band Battle Is a Real Classic
description: Three Tenors, move over. Here come . . . two orchestras!

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a former editor in chief of New York magazine who is to become a columnist for The New Yorker misspelled his surname at one point. He is Kurt Andersen, not Anderson.

title: Widow of Rail Shooting Victim Defeats Incumbent in Emotional Contest on L.I.
description: Carolyn McCarthy, transformed into an anti-weapons crusader by a gunman's shooting spree on a Long Island commuter train, yesterday defeated Representative Daniel Frisa, a freshman Republican, in an emotionally charged race that brought national attention to the Republican bastion of Nassau County.

title: Stocks Decline in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks fell today after their biggest one-day gain in six weeks. On Wednesday, the shares of exporters like the Honda Motor Company and the Sony Corporation soared amid expectations the dollar will remain strong after the United States election, and the Nikkei saw its biggest daily gain since Sept. 17. Today, the Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 220.41 points, or 1 percent, at 20,771.11.

title: Issue Is Resolved at St. John's
description: St. John's Athletic Director Ed Manetta confirmed yesterday that Zendon Hamilton and Felipe Lopez, two juniors on the Red Storm basketball team, will not be suspended for any games for accepting airplane tickets to attend a basketball workout this past summer in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Television section on Oct. 13 for the CBS program ''48 Hours'' misidentified the publisher of Penthouse magazine, who figured in one segment. He is Bob Guccione, not Larry Flynt.

title: The Texaco Tapes Speak for Corporate Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Steps Up Effort To Deny U.N. Chief a 2d Term
description: Losing no time after the Presidential election to step up a campaign to deny Boutros Boutros-Ghali a second term as Secretary General of the United Nations, the Clinton Administration today accused him of interfering in American politics by pressing his case in Congress.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Monday about ''Founder: A Portrait of the First Rothschild and His Time,'' by Amos Elon, misstated the given name of the first of the Rothschild financiers. In later life, Meyer Amschel Rothschild changed the spelling of his name to Mayer.

title: The First Casualties In Scandal at Texaco
description: The growing scandal at Texaco Inc. claimed its first management casualties.

title: Few Freeholder Shifts
description: In county freeholder elections Tuesday, New Jersey voters chose the status quo.

title: In California, Foes of Affirmative Action See a New Day
description: Supporters of a measure to dismantle state-sponsored affirmative action programs in California predicted yesterday that its approval would begin a new era of equal opportunity by wiping out preferences based on race or sex in public hiring, contracting and college admissions.

title: Merry Mayor (No Dour Red He) to Come Calling
description: The Mayor of Shanghai, Xu Kuangdi, shares a few things with his counterpart in New York City: an array of problems that demand immediate attention in his country's largest city, a love of classical music and a determination to comb his hair over a gradually balding pate.

title: INTEL PREDICTS STRONG QUARTERLY SALES INCREASE
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it expected its fourth-quarter sales to significantly exceed sales of $5.14 billion in the third quarter and that its gross margin would be wider, because of an increase in new orders and strong holiday sales of personal computers. In the fourth quarter last year, Intel reported net income of $867 million, or 98 cents a share, on sales of $4.58 billion. The chip maker is expected to report per-share earnings of $1.61, according to the average estimate of 29 analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc. Intel also cited the defeat of California's Proposition 211 -- an initiative that Intel opposed -- which would have made it easier for shareholders to sue companies and would have held companies and their directors personally liable for damages. Shares of Intel rose $4.875 today, to $118.875, an all-time high on a split-adjusted basis.

title: Currency Plan In Europe Gets Good Report
description: The European Commission said today that a ''significant'' number of the 15 members of the European Union were on course to qualify for a common currency in 1999, with accelerating economic growth helping to drive budget deficits lower.

title: Bond Market Off Slightly After Election
description: The prices of Treasury securities dropped slightly yesterday, as the bond market put the elections behind it and continued to work through the Government's quarterly refunding of debt, which concludes today with the sale of a new 30-year bond.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Hockey

title: Texas Instruments Takes Bids for Sale of Defense Unit
description: Plans by Texas Instruments to sell its defense electronics business and concentrate on making chips would bring higher but more volatile profits, analysts said today. Texas Instruments, as expected, has begun taking bids for its defense unit, those familiar with its strategy said.

title: Torricelli Returns to His Roots Victorious And Reflects on Wounds of the Campaign
description: One day after his commanding victory in the United States Senate race, Robert G. Torricelli came home to the suburban Bergen County town where he cut his political teeth as a child, and suggested that his opponent's negative campaigning -- engineered by outsiders -- had been a decisive factor in the race.

title: Events: Architecture, Then and Now
description: Lectures on Architecture

title: WEST
description: ALASKA -- DOLE

title: CHRONICLE
description: How do you get to Avery Fisher Hall?

title: Initiative About Mall Fails
description: By a margin of 55 percent to 45 percent, residents of Kalamazoo, Mich., voted down a ballot initiative to replace a downtown pedestrian mall with streets, thus reintroducing automotive traffic to the area. The 37-year-old mall was the first in the nation to close off streets to cars, a retailing and urban-planning concept in favor in the late 1960's and early 1970's only to ebb in popularity in recent years. Downtown Kalamazoo Inc., a nonprofit business association in favor of the change, said that it would try for a second public vote on a 1997 ballot.

title: With Term Limits Affirmed, Politicians Ponder the Future
description: One day after New York City residents voted to keep limiting elected officials to only eight years in office, many City Council members spent the day yesterday pondering their options once they are forced to step down in 2001.

title: Results of Contests For the U.S. House, District by District
description: ALABAMA

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Nicklaus Gets Open Exemption
description: JACK NICKLAUS accepted a special exemption to the 1997 United States Open yesterday, allowing him to extend two of the most remarkable streaks in sports with his 41st consecutive Open and 142d straight major championship.

title: Harassment's New Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Artur Axmann, 83, a Top Nazi Who Headed the Hitler Youth
description: Artur Axmann, a former leader of the Hitler Youth who sent thousands of young Germans to fight the Red Army and who later claimed to have been the last person to see Hitler alive, died in Berlin on Oct. 24. He was 83.

title: Giants Work Out 3 Punters
description: Is Mike Horan in danger of losing his job?

title: Here Comes Arena Football
description: Madison Square Garden, home of the Knicks and Rangers, will have a new sports team in its lineup this spring, the first franchise for New York City in the 11-year-old Arena Football League.

title: Concerned About Forests, Suburbanites Block Prairie Project
description: For nearly 20 years volunteers have been quietly working to save and restore vanishing patches of oak-shaded grassland that had escaped being plowed under for farms on the edge of Chicago.

title: APRIA HEALTHCARE'S BID FOR VITAS IN JEOPARDY
description: Apria Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that its acquisition of the Vitas Healthcare Corporation might be called off because of a decline in Apria's share price. When the purchase was announced on June 6, Apria's stock closed at $31.875. Yesterday, the shares rose 87.5 cents, to $20.25. Under the agreement, the acquisition can be terminated if Apria's shares fall below $22.125. The stock's decline has reduced the acquisition's value, which includes the assumption of unspecified debt, to about $180 million from the previous $212 million in June, an Apria spokeswoman said. She said the two companies were discussing alternatives.

title: District by District Results in Races for the Connecticut General Assembly
description: STATE SENATE

title: Yin Hails Yang
description: Two years ago Newt Gingrich stayed up nearly all Election Night, splashing around in history, giddily telling everyone that he was going to reshape the character of Americans, restore a black-and-white sense of morality to the nation, run ''the left-wing elitists'' out of the White House, wipe out the ''Great Society, counterculture, McGovernik'' legacy of the ''failed'' Clintons, and have children from Head Start through college ''encounter'' the Declaration of Independence every year and cogitate on why Thomas Jefferson used the word ''Creator'' in the document.

title: Christian Coalition Vows to Exert More Influence
description: The religious broadcaster Pat Robertson, whose Christian Coalition has emerged as a highly influential force in Republican Party politics, said yesterday that religious conservatives would begin working as early as 1997 to shape the message of the next Republican Presidential campaign.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: A Mandate to Get Along
description: The priestly readers of entrails have picked through this election's viscera and pronounced oracularly: ''A victory for the status quo.'' If any of the victors believe that, they are in deep trouble.

title: Pakistan Officials Free a Defiant Bhutto From Custody
description: Benazir Bhutto emerged today from what the new caretaker Government called ''protective custody'' and condemned President Farooq Leghari, who dismissed her as Prime Minister, as another of the ''self-styled messiahs'' she said have repeatedly trampled on democracy in Pakistan.

title: The Sound Of Cultures
description: As Latin music's horizons and listeners expand, it seemed inevitable that it would arrive at the Knitting Factory, the downtown venue whose ambitions grow ever outward. On Tuesday night, the charanga band Orquesta Broadway played the first concert of a series at the club sponsored by Absolut called Smokin' Latin Jazz.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: No Headline
description: ''If I had known I was going to lose, I wouldn't run.'' RICHARD PETTY, the stock car driver, defeated for a state office in North Carolina. $(B8:5.$)

title: Scenes From a Haul
description: ON an industrial street in Brooklyn stands a shop that is shuttered most days of the month. No hours are posted, but every few weeks the man who runs it rolls up a corrugated metal door -- revealing, for just two hours, merchandise that is worn, unwieldy and at times hard to identify.

title: Defiantly, Bosnian Serbs Blow Up Muslims' Homes
description: In defiance of the pledge to allow refugees to return to their homes, Bosnian Serb officials blew up the homes of 96 Muslim families who had applied for permission to visit their native villages in a Serb-controlled area, United Nations officials said today.

title: Volkswagen's History: The Darker Side Is Revisited
description: Fondly, they baptized it the Beetle. Over the years, more than 21 million were sold around the world -- funky, lumpy, never too fast, as much an emblem of a nation on new wheels as an early Ford or a Citroen 2CV.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Proclaim Victory Over Labor
description: Republicans declared unequivocal victory yesterday in their yearlong war with organized labor, asserting that A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders had gambled $35 million of their rank-and-file's money on a Democratic majority and lost.

title: A Divided Government Remains, and With It the Prospect of Further Combat
description: The paradox of the 1996 elections is this: Dissatisfied with their political leadership, American voters opted for the status quo; weary of bickering, they set the stage for more by prolonging divided government.

title: Bobby Witt Stays With Texas
description: BOBBY WITT has exercised a $2 million option to return to the Texas Rangers next season, instead of testing the free-agent market.

title: Top Republicans Say They Seek 'Common Ground' With Clinton
description: With control of Congress secure after slight House losses and slimmer Senate gains, Republican leaders promptly sought to define their role yesterday as seeking ''common ground'' with a re-elected President Clinton -- while keeping their guard up.

title: Tyson Covers His Long Career From Dark Days to Paydays
description: A computerized black baby grand Yamaha piano in the next room played Mozart. Mike Tyson, as if lulled by music of another time, was wistful in a 75-minute stream-of-consciousness in which he freely discussed his dark side, but became truly animated in explaining why he fights now.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES ENDS NORA BEVERAGES BID
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it was unable to complete the purchase of the Canadian bottled-water producer Nora Beverages. Coca-Cola Enterprises, the world's largest bottler of nonalcoholic drinks, said the $117 million offer, announced in July, had not gained the support of all of Nora's shareholders. The Atlanta-based company said it would continue to distribute Nora's Naya products and would look for another bottled water company. Coca-Cola Enterprises' stock rose $1.375, to $43.75. The Montreal-based Nora has about 1 percent of the United States market for bottled water, which had wholesale sales of $3.4 billion in 1995.

title: Bridge
description: When France captured its fourth World Team Olympiad open title five days ago on the island of Rhodes, it set a record for consecutive victories, surpassing Italy, which had three from 1964 to 1972.

title: Marriages That Dare Not
description: As if challenging Leo Tolstoy's famous observation that ''all happy families are alike,'' tonight's ''Turning Point'' presents happy families that are conspicuously different from the usual variety.

title: A Longer NATO Stay in Bosnia Uncertain
description: Faced with last-minute objections from the United States, NATO military planners decided today to put on hold a proposal for keeping troops in Bosnia after their one-year mandate expires, senior NATO officials said.

title: Old Enemy Assumes A New Look
description: THE cherished ideal of sports and honor has been tarnished yet again.

title: A Conciliatory Gingrich
description: After ending a campaign of pointed denunciations of President Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich sounded more conciliatory than he did in 1994, when he began honing his reputation as a revolutionary. Page B3.

title: 95 Years Later, Real Mackintosh
description: THE year was 1901, and in the world of design it was a moment full of possibilities. Glasgow was the booming second city of the British Empire, its progressive architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh was experimenting with daring new concepts, and a German art magazine staged an international competition for a ''grand house in a thoroughly modern style.''

title: Metro Digest
description: THE ELECTIONS

title: No Munich Parallel
description: To the Editor:

title: INTUIT SHARES SOAR ON RUMORS OF BUYOUT OFFER
description: Shares of Intuit Inc., which makes personal finance software, soared 24 percent yesterday amid speculation that the American Express Company is planning a bid. Other potential buyers could include Fidelity Investments, the First Data Corporation and the Charles Schwab Corporation. Intuit shares rose $7 to $36.50, in trading of 4.5 million shares yesterday; the stock was valued at $1.7 billion. Intuit and American Express would not comment.

title: NORTHEAST
description: CONNECTICUT -- CLINTON

title: Prints for All Tastes On View at the Armory
description: The Sixth Annual Print Fair opens tonight at the Seventh Regiment Armory with 89 dealers showing more than 20,000 prints and drawings.

title: The Texaco Tapes Speak for Corporate Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Voters Approve Bond Act for Dredging Harbor
description: A bond act that will provide $185 million to help pay for dredging New York Harbor and other waterways passed with 68 percent of the vote on Tuesday.

title: How the Baby Boomers Can Save Social Security
description: WILL AMERICA GROW UP BEFORE IT GROWS OLD?

title: Louise Ames, 88, a Child Psychologist, Dies
description: Louise Bates Ames, a psychologist whose pioneering work on children held that development unfolded in discrete, predictable stages, died last Thursday at her granddaughter's home in Cincinnati. She was 88 and lived in New Haven until shortly before her death.

title: Zimmer Praises Opponent And His Own Effort, Too
description: Stung by defeat but apparently ready to stop casting aspersions, Representative Richard A. Zimmer said yesterday that he had no regrets about his campaign for a seat in the United States Senate. He praised Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democrat who beat him, for running ''a very tough, effective, focused race.''

title: Results of Voting in New York Races for the State Legislature and the Courts
description: STATE SENATE

title: World Wide Web Gets Mixed Reviews on First Presidential Ballot
description: In the first Presidential election since the Internet became a popular communications medium, there was the occasional network landslide on Tuesday night as popular political sites on the World Wide Web were overwhelmed by requests from computer users seeking voting results. But the overall turnout on the Internet was surprisingly light, technical analysts said, with total usage rising only a few percent above normal weeknight traffic levels.

title: Lou Singer, 71, Guide to the Sights of Brooklyn
description: Lou Singer, who guided thousands and thousands of visitors through the other-borough charms of Brooklyn and sang its praises in accents compatible with that environment, died on Tuesday in Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 71 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Gingrich Tie Almost Costs Incumbent Her District
description: As head of the House Ethics Committee investigating Newt Gingrich, Representative Nancy L. Johnson became mired in the kind of controversy she had never had to deal with before, and it almost cost her an election.

title: Parcells & Co. Have Hot Hand, but Stay Cool About Jets
description: Duane Parcells grew up in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., down the road from what is now Giants Stadium. He took the nickname of a childhood friend named Bill and went on to become an outstanding athlete and coach.

title: 2 Health Care Companies Report Profit Rise as Humana Slips
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation and Oxford Health Plans Inc. both reported stronger third-quarter earnings yesterday, but Humana Inc. said profits fell for the quarter.

title: Women Make Only Moderate Gains Despite the Many Contenders
description: When the number of women winning seats in the House of Representatives nearly doubled, to a record 47, four years ago, the incoming group pronounced themselves evidence of a major new trend in American politics.

title: Mississippi Governor Is Injured When His Car Flips and Burns
description: The Governor of Mississippi, Kirk Fordice, was seriously injured in a fiery accident late Tuesday afternoon in which the car he was driving flipped on a rural stretch of highway in the northern part of the state.

title: Dole's First Day Without 'Anything to Do'
description: After about 114 hours of near nonstop campaigning, Bob Dole finally got a full night's sleep last night in his own bed.

title: Disability Laws Spawn Dispute Over a Dream Denied
description: Two years ago, at the age of 17, Nick Knapp was a 6-foot-5-inch senior basketball star at Woodruff High School in Peoria, Ill., who was about to break the state record for career 3-pointers. Then, during a casual pickup basketball game at a local gym, Knapp threw a pass down the court, took a few steps, knelt down and keeled over. His heart had suddenly stopped beating.

title: U.C.L.A. Decides to Dismiss Harrick, Who Doesn't Bid a Cheery Goodbye
description: A dinner, an expense report, a lie and then a cover-up led to the firing of the U.C.L.A. basketball coach Jim Harrick today. Just 19 months ago, he was winning a national championship, but this afternoon he was accusing his employers of a witch hunt.

title: Help for the Home Office
description: THE work-at-home universe is expanding rapidly: last year, it reached 39 million households, up from 36 million in 1994, according to IDC/LINK, a market research firm that publishes a Home Office Market Update.

title: Drugs' Captives Connect With a Program to Deter AIDS
description: Jerry Lopez hobbled up on crutches on a recent Tuesday, his thin mouth creased by an attempt at a smile, his bloodshot eyes smeared with tears. He is 49, and has been addicted to drugs since he was 13. The thing is, he thought he had finally quit.

title: Hoechst to Revamp, Seek Big Board Listing
description: Hoechst A.G. reported higher third-quarter pretax profits yesterday, and said it would reorganize as a holding company with operating units and seek a listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares in the chemical company jumped 2.58 marks, to 60.92 marks ($40.07).

title: New Faces In the House
description: FLORIDA

title: Accounts
description: Austin, Nichols & Co., New York, a unit of Pernod-Ricard, to Charron, Schwartz & Partners, New York, to handle advertising for Jameson Irish whisky, previously handled by the Image Group, New York. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: Takeover Decision Declined by Investors
description: In a closely watched investor-rights case, the shareholders of Wallace Computer Services Inc. voted yesterday against a proposal aimed at giving them ultimate say over whether the company was for sale, dismissing a challenge to the company's ''just say no'' takeover defense.

title: Eastern Europe Fund to Sell Its Troubled Czech Portfolio
description: The Czech and Slovak American Enterprise Fund, which is part of a billion-dollar Federal program to promote capitalism in Eastern Europe, has agreed to sell its Czech investments to Renaissance Partners, a private venture capital firm, at a substantial loss.

title: Fusing Charm and Jazzy Fun
description: The name is quaint and the concept debatable. But the Daring Project, which made its formal New York debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, is a lot of good, easy fun.

title: On Science Fraud, Mentors Must Share Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Able Was She
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 31 with an article about a Vienna auction of art stolen from Jews by the Nazis referred incorrectly in some copies to an artist whose painting ''Figures in a Roman Arcade'' was displayed to prospective bidders. He was Pierre-Etienne le Sueur, not le Seuer.

title: Stung by Defeats in '94, Clinton Regrouped and Co-opted G.O.P. Strategies
description: As he struggled to come to terms with the 1994 Republican sweep of Congress, President Clinton made one point to anyone who would listen: he had lost the fight to overhaul health care, the centerpiece of his agenda, because his opponents went on television and defined his program.

title: ADT PLANS TO SELL U.S. AUTO-AUCTION BUSINESS
description: ADT Ltd. said yesterday that it planned to sell its United States auto-auction unit, known as ADT Automotive, in a move that would complete its departure from the business. The company, based in Boca Raton, Fla., did not disclose how much it expected to make from the sale. ADT, which sold its European auto-auction business last year, said the move was part of its plan to focus on its fast-growing burglar alarm business. ADT Automotive, the nation's No. 2 auto-auction business, has annual revenues of about $287 million, while the parent company's sales in 1995 totaled $1.53 billion. A proposed $4.3 billion bid for ADT by Republic Industries was abandoned in September.

title: Elf in British Linkup With 2 U.S. Companies
description: The French oil giant Elf Aquitane said yesterday that it was merging its British refining and retail operations with units of two United States oil companies in a $5 billion deal. Elf's deal is with Gulf Oil Ltd., a subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, and Murco Petroleum Ltd., a unit of the Murphy Oil Corporation.

title: School Board to Overhaul Classroom-Leasing Effort
description: Acknowledging problems and some embarrassment in its effort to acquire suitable schoolroom space at a fair price, the New York City Board of Education said yesterday that it would overhaul its school-leasing program.

title: Democrats Persuade Their Voters To Return
description: With President Clinton's landslide victory in Connecticut Tuesday, the Democrats once again gained the upper hand in state politics: they picked up one seat in the state's Congressional delegation and appeared to have taken back the majority in the State Senate.

title: Failure to Support Children Earns Man 6 Months in Jail
description: Jeffrey A. Nichols, the nation's most infamous deadbeat dad, was sentenced yesterday to the maximum term of six months in jail for violating a four-year-old Federal law that makes it a crime to cross state lines to avoid making the payments.

title: Virginia Tech Players Charged
description: Eight Virginia Tech football players, including the all-America defensive end CORNELL BROWN and the starting fullback BRIAN EDMONDS, were charged yesterday with beating a member of the school's track team.

title: Whitman Stays Confident Despite Party's Setbacks
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman brushed aside questions today about whether New Jersey voters were sending her a message by giving both President Clinton and Representative Robert G. Torricelli decisive victories over their Republican opponents.

title: In a Season Of Grays, One Show That's Noir
description: Television noir, the favorite trendy label of the moment, is popping up all over the schedule, but not always with enough survival fizz. Fox's ''Millennium,'' brought to you by ''The X-Files'' folks, seems to be breathing nicely, but CBS, definitely in one of its jittery phases, has already canceled the promising ''EZ Streets,'' a crime drama drenched in Celtic gloom, after only one showing. Dimly lighted alleys, no matter how creatively evoked, don't necessarily spell prime-time survival.

title: Callers React to Brinkley's Blunt and Blue Criticism
description: Callers flooded ABC's phone lines yesterday to complain about or praise David Brinkley for his criticism of President Clinton in election coverage the night before.

title: The Dangers From Air Bags And Ways to Avoid Them
description: Natalie Smith of Pittsburgh says she likes her new 1996 Mazda Protege, but she worries about its air bag. The bag was designed to protect the average man, about 165 pounds and 5 foot 9 -- about 55 pounds heavier and 7 inches taller than Ms. Smith, and according to Government statistics, 19 ''short statured'' people, most of whom were not wearing seat belts, have been killed by air bags in crashes that they otherwise could have survived.

title: Fraschilla Is Attempting to Fire Up Image of a Sagging Red Storm Team
description: Fran Fraschilla, with his double-breasted suit tailor-fit and his thick dark hair combed neatly into place, worked the crowd at the Big East Conference's media day yesterday with the demeanor and confidence of someone who belongs among the nation's top college basketball coaches.

title: Riding the Bond Act Victory, Pataki Tries to Widen His Appeal
description: With the passage of the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act, voters have given Gov. George E. Pataki the opportunity to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on three politically crucial areas -- urban renewal, job creation and the environment -- with just a year to go before the 1998 gubernatorial campaign begins.

title: Music as a Sleeping Aid?
description: To The Home Section:

title: A Contrast in Housing
description: To The Home Section:

title: Wall Street Votes: Dow Soars 96.53
description: Investors and voters seem to agree: They want more of the same.

title: What's 4-H Without Competition for Blue Ribbons? Extremely Stormy
description: Kari A. Beitelspacher has been bringing home blue ribbons for years from 4-H club competitions at the state fair in Des Moines. But this year, even her well-received homemade salsa did not win first place.

title: Report of a Fall in Production Pushes Heating Oil Prices Up
description: Heating oil prices rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, rebounding from a six-day slump after a surprising drop in refinery production left United States inventories lower last week.

title: Gingrich, Role as House Leader Intact, Offers Clinton an Olive Branch
description: Having survived the Democrats' nationwide assault on his leadership, Speaker Newt Gingrich gratefully responded today with a noticeably noncombative call to find ''common ground'' with President Clinton in the Administration's second term.

title: The Vital Center
description: Like a cop bursting in on a culprit's hideout, the nation's voters kicked down the incumbents' door and yelled ''Freeze!'' The result: a political standoff, with power nicely balanced.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Kantor and 3 Others To Leave the Cabinet

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 20 about Clarence I. Blau, a former New Deal official and member of the United States Mission to the United Nations, misstated the surname of one of his surviving daughters. She is Ruth Blau, of Arlington, Va., not Ruth North.

title: Rhode Island Players Charged
description: Five Rhode Island football players have been charged with attacking fraternity members, Attorney General JEFF PINE said yesterday. The players were accused of taking part in an attack on three fraternity members inside the Theta Delta Chi fraternity house on Oct. 7.

title: Acquisition Set By Schlumberger
description: Schlumberger Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy Solaic S.A., a maker of magnetic and smart cards, from Sligos S.A. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Mystery Gift To a Museum Loses Its Mask
description: WHO contributed $20 million to the American Museum of Natural History for its new plan to rebuild the old Planetarium? The Case of the Anonymous Gift has gone unsolved for a year. But now the benefactors have come forward, and truth be known, it would not have taken great detective work to unmask them.

title: A Big Band With an Air Of Repose
description: The always perilous economic state of jazz makes the existence of any big band a small miracle. The band that Joe Henderson is leading at the Blue Note through Sunday represents at least a mid-size miracle.

title: Mayor Can't Force Cable Firm to Add Channel, Judge Rules
description: A Federal Judge issued a broad ruling yesterday barring Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani from trying to force Time Warner to carry Rupert Murdoch's Fox News Channel in New York City, rebuking the Mayor for what she said was a thinly disguised effort to help a political supporter.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Helping Clivias Bloom

title: Disney 'King' For 42d Street: No Lion Suits
description: A theatrical version of ''The Lion King'' will open at the renovated New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street near Times Square next fall, the Walt Disney Company announced yesterday. The choice of ''The Lion King'' for a stage adaptation is hardly surprising since the film was enormously successful, taking in more than $765 million worldwide, and it had been widely regarded as a front-runner for the New Amsterdam.

title: Brodeur Weathers A Fusillade
description: The high-octane Detroit Red Wings aren't shut out very often.

title: Zaire Sets Stringent Terms for Effort to Help Refugees
description: Still reeling from the loss of several important cities to Rwandan-backed rebels, the Zairian Government today set stringent conditions for any Western-led intervention on its soil, and vowed to recapture the lands it had lost, whatever the cost.

title: New Faces in Congress
description: NEW YORK

title: Against the Nuclear Threat
description: To The Home Section:

title: Departures at State and Defense
description: Warren Christopher and William Perry sometimes seemed like the milquetoast twins of the Clinton Administration. Soft-spoken and retiring, they were not central-casting candidates for Secretary of State and Secretary of Defense. But in their own quiet way, both men served their President and country well.

title: The Elusive Edges of Middle Age
description: A YEAR ago, when I had just turned 36, I posed a question at a dinner party that was intended as a casual query, a trifle that slipped off my tongue with the buttery smoothness of the evening's chardonnay.

title: L.I. Widow's Story: Next Stop, Washington
description: The trains pulled into the Mineola station this evening with clockwork regularity, pausing for a few moments before moving on with the sigh of released brakes. It was fitting, in more ways than one, that Carolyn McCarthy was there on the platform, waiting.

title: CLINTON PREPARING FOR 2D TERM WITH SHUFFLE OF TOP OFFICIALS
description: President Clinton followed his 31-state electoral sweep yesterday by beginning to build a new Government, accepting the resignations of some of his top Cabinet officials, including Secretary of State Warren Christopher.

title: When Parents Take Charge
description: IT'S time for bed, O.K.? But little Max and Caitlin just won't go.

title: Booming Brooklyn
description: One of the truly heartening urban success stories of the past decade has been the quiet transformation of downtown Brooklyn, fueled by a series of well-conceived joint public and private investments. The resurgence of New York City's most populous borough will gain fresh momentum today with a ceremonial ribbon-cutting opening Atlantic Center, a new 400,000-square-foot shopping complex at the junction of Flatbush and Atlantic avenues. The site, a city-owned urban renewal property, was proposed 40 years ago for a new stadium to persuade the Brooklyn Dodgers not to flee to Los Angeles. It has stood vacant ever since.

title: Fear of G.O.P. Cuts Emerges In Clinton's Northeast Sweep
description: New York State barely saw Bill Clinton during the campaign, and its economy remains sluggish. Yet the President's overall victory in the popular vote on Tuesday stemmed in large part from substantial margins from New York and surrounding states, support that both Democrats and Republicans said demonstrated clear regional support for the government programs Mr. Clinton vowed to preserve.

title: Crossovers for McCarthy
description: Many voters crossed party lines to give Carolyn McCarthy her upset victory for Congress, including Mrs. McCarthy herself. Though a lifelong Republican, she ran on the Democratic line.

title: SOUTH
description: ALABAMA -- DOLE

title: Genetic Soybeans Alarm Europeans
description: As genetically engineered soybeans from the United States begin to arrive in Europe, concerns about possible health risks raised by consumer groups and critics of biotechnology are prompting a boycott by some food producers and supermarket chains.

title: Potential for 400 Jets And $18 Billion Sale : Airbus Gets Huge Order From USAir
description: PARIS  USAir Group Inc. said Wednesday it planned to buy up to 400 narrow-bodied aircraft from Airbus Industrie in what could be the European consortium's biggest sale.

title: A High-Voltage Dynamo Named Domingo
description: It's a normal operatic season for Placido Domingo. Normal for Placido Domingo.

title: Now What? Baseball's Labor Deal Is Rejected
description: Under the guise of establishing a smoother mechanism for reaching a new labor agreement with the union, baseball's club owners today resoundingly rejected the deal that their chief labor executive had made with the players and created unrealistic conditions for the players to accept.

title: People
description: Jack Klues, senior vice president and United States media services director at the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, was promoted to executive vice president and worldwide media director, effective at year-end. He succeeds Richard H. Hobbs Jr., who will retire. Robert C. Brennan, senior vice president and international media services director, was promoted to succeed Mr. Klues. And Jeannie Euch, vice president and worldwide media director on Burnett's Procter & Gamble Co. account, was promoted to succeed Mr. Brennan.

title: Johnson Shakes Head
description: Larry Johnson sat for a long while by his locker room cubicle on Tuesday night, perhaps 30 minutes longer than most of the Knicks. Unless you count the emotional anguish that goes with two missed free throws in the clutch, he was not nursing an injury. He kept shaking his head in disgust, the final minutes gnawing.

title: Hold China to Its Word On Hong Kong Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: In Clinton's New Term, Old Ethics Questions
description: As they celebrated the prospect of a second Clinton term today, Democrats were warned by Congress's Republican leaders that the investigations that dogged the White House in the last two years were all but certain to spill into 1997.

title: Half the Electorate, Perhaps Satisfied or Bored, Sat Out Voting
description: About 49 percent of the nation's voting-age population went to the polls on Tuesday, the lowest level for a Presidential election since 1924, according to the Voter News Service, a consortium of six major news organizations that provides exit-poll information.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Cartographers of the haut monde will want to revise their maps this morning to relocate one of their watering holes.

title: MIDWEST
description: ILLINOIS -- CLINTON

title: A retrospective of Britain's best television ads from the last 20 years traces their evolution.
description: THE observation by George Bernard Shaw that England and America are two countries separated by the same language is no longer true, at least when it comes to advertising.

title: More Election News
description: THE STRATEGY -- The contours of the 1996 campaign were largely set in 1995, when Mr. Clinton rediscovered his voice and forged a campaign from a budget battle. Page B1.

title: Paradox in Ovarian and Breast Cancer Risk Intrigues Scientists
description: Researchers who have been studying a gene that causes breast and ovarian cancer have stumbled on a surprise. They have found that increased risk of cancer may be accompanied by slower progress of the disease when a person actually gets cancer.

title: Joy Rider on Bucket Loader Uproots Trees on Great Lawn
description: Early yesterday morning, someone broke through the fence surrounding the Great Lawn of Central Park, hot-wired a piece of heavy construction equipment and lurched recklessly about, destroying two mature trees and a lamppost.

title: Accord Reached in Dispute at Tire Company
description: For nearly two years, rubber workers around the nation have boycotted, picketed and condemned the tire giant Bridgestone/Firestone because it has forced workers to accept 12-hour shifts and had replaced hundreds of strikers with permanent substitutes.

title: Serbs Said to Ship Arms to Libya In Effort to Evade U.N. Sanctions
description: For three hours last August a lumbering Russian transport plane, its lights and instrument panels shut down in a power failure, desperately circled low over Belgrade until it crashed as it made an emergency landing at Surcin International Airport.

title: Aliens From Outer Space and Other Election Tales
description: Lynne Plaskett waged a hard-nosed campaign for a second term on the Volusia County Council, running on a contentious proposal to ban cars from the public beaches of New Smyrna Beach, Fla. On Tuesday, she lost.

title: IOMEGA PLANS TO OFFER MINIATURE DATA STORAGE DEVICE
description: The Iomega Corporation, which makes the Zip drive, a removable data storage device, said yesterday that it had developed a smaller version, which could be built into personal digital assistants, cellular telephones, digital cameras and other portable electronic devices. The miniature drive, called the n-hand, will be sold to equipment manufacturers for less than $100, with each 20 megabyte removable disk selling for about $10, Iomega said. Shipments are expected to begin in the second half of 1997. Iomega officials said they expected the new device to outsell flash memory cards -- which contain a type of re-usable memory chip -- by offering greater storage capacity at a lower cost.

title: Courting Lillian Hellman, Most Carefully
description: Look, up there, on the stage! Isn't that a famous person, one of those glamorous culture vultures drag queens are always impersonating?

title: Nolan Gives Purpose To a No-Name Defense
description: Mike Nolan, the Giants' defensive coordinator, may have been born again. Not in a spiritual way, merely football-wise.

title: Action, Not Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: China Paroles Key Dissident

title: Boston College Bans 13 Football Players Over Bets
description: Two Boston College football players bet against their team when the Eagles met Syracuse on Oct. 26, a local law enforcement official said today. They were among 13 players suspended from the team for placing bets on college and professional sporting events in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: Pakistan Coup Threatens Regional Stability
description: To the Editor:

title: Refugee Trek in Zaire: Illness, Thirst and Death
description: After two years in exile, the 36-year-old teacher finally decided to return to Rwanda in the middle of a rain forest. He had been tramping along for four days with hundreds of other refugees on the run from guerrilla soldiers. Then he saw young and old people begin to die from thirst.

title: Mario Savio, 53, Campus Protester, Dies
description: Mario Savio, an incendiary and highly vocal student protest leader at the University of California at Berkeley in the 1960's, died yesterday in Columbia-Palm Drive Hospital in Sebastopol, Calif. He was 53 and lived in Sonoma County, Calif.

title: Champagne Brand Sold
description: The Seagram Company has sold its Champagne brand Heidsieck Monopole to the French Champagne maker Vranken. No financial details were released. Seagram said the sales agreement included the vineyard, the Champagne stocks, the brand and the commercial base. Heidsieck Monopole sold 1.2 million bottles in 1995, and its stock is estimated to be around 3 million bottles.

title: HENKEL BIDS FOR REMAINING LOCTITE STAKE
description: Henkel K.G.a.A., based in Dusseldorf, Germany, began a $1.2 billion tender offer yesterday for the 65 percent of the Loctite Corporation that it does not already own, putting pressure on Loctite's board. Loctite, a maker of adhesives and sealants, urged shareholders to resist the offer of $57.75 a share until it could be reviewed. HC Investments Inc., a unit of Henkel, the maker of detergents and specialty chemicals, had said on Oct. 28 that it was considering making a $56-a-share bid. Analysts said Loctite appeared to be stalling, perhaps hoping for another bidder. Shares of Loctite rose $1, to $58.875.

title: Yeltsin Is Recovering, but Is Warned Not to Rush Back to Work
description: An American surgeon consulting in the treatment of President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that the Russian leader's doctors are delighted with the speed of his initial recovery from multiple bypass heart surgery on Tuesday.

title: That Scottish Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: Violinists Acidic, Sizzling and Frivolous
description: Leila Josefowicz's 'Solo'

title: Business Was a Big Winner, Too
description: The race for the White House and the battle to control Congress may have dominated the election news, but what stood out for corporate America was the defeat of a host of state ballot initiatives that were intended to circumscribe the ability of business to operate freely.

title: Kidnapping Is Snagging Guatemalan Peace Talks
description: The peace talks aimed at ending Guatemala's 35-year civil war, expected to culminate in the signing of a final agreement next month, have hit an unexpected snag as a result of an admission by leftist guerrillas that one of their top commanders carried out the recent kidnapping of an elderly woman.

title: Heavy Spending Helps Republicans Win in Albany
description: An unusual Republican spending drive helped elect two or possibly three Republicans on Tuesday to a state court in Albany that has issued several significant rulings against Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican.

title: Siemens Shares Plunge On 1997 Forecast
description: The stock of Siemens A.G. fell yesterday after the company said its profit for the 1997 fiscal year would not exceed 1996 earnings. The company reported preliminary figures yesterday for 1996, saying it had earned a profit of 2.49 billion marks ($1.64 billion), a rise of 20 percent from a year earlier. The gains came from the energy and communications divisions.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Oct. 30 about ''The Unknown Lenin: From the Secret Archive,'' by Richard Pipes, referred incorrectly to the Russian city where Lenin arrived at Finland Station in 1917. It was then called Petrograd, not St. Petersburg.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: California Department of Water Resources is selling $241.8 million of tax-exempt water system revenue bonds for the Central Valley project through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 5.73 percent for an issue in 2029. For short-maturity serial bonds, the yields range from 4.15 percent in 1999 to 5.50 percent in 2015. The bonds are rated AA by Moody's and S.& P.

title: Chinese Roots of Winner Delight the Pacific Rim
description: Surrounded by news crews from all over the Pacific Rim, Gary Locke was asked today what it felt like to make history. A Democrat who won the Washington State gubernatorial race by a landslide, Mr. Locke will become the nation's first Chinese-American governor.

title: Buntin in Alliance With Campaign Inc.
description: The Buntin Group in Nashville and in Louisville, Ky., has formed a strategic creative alliance with Campaign Inc. in Atlanta in preparation for a merger of the two agencies planned for next year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES, Chicago, a real estate developer, is negotiating to buy six shopping malls for $250 million. The sellers were not identified.

title: Excerpts From Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from the ruling yesterday by Judge Denise Cote of Federal District Court in Manhattan barring the Giuliani administration from forcing Time Warner to add the Fox News Channel to its cable system.

title: Dollar Slips After Elections And Pessimistic Euro Report
description: The dollar slipped yesterday as currency traders shifted their focus from elections in the United States to a report that suggested no more than a handful of countries would qualify to join a single European currency.

title: Dance of Love Lives Up to Its Name
description: There are a thousand stories to the tango and all of them are about love. Take the stars of ''Tango X 2,'' which opens tonight for 11 performances at City Center.

title: TEXTRON TO INVEST IN PAUL REVERE UNIT BEFORE SALE
description: Textron Inc. agreed yesterday to inject almost $155 million in capital into the Paul Revere Corporation, its insurance unit, before selling its 83 percent stake to the Provident Companies. The capital investment will resolve a dispute between Provident. based in Chattanooga, Tenn., and Textron, of Providence, R.I., over the cost of future disability claims and will allow the acquisition, valued at roughly $1.3 billion, to close by the end of March, a Textron spokeswoman said. Provident's acquisition of Paul Revere was delayed in September so the companies could make new estimates of the cost of future disability claims by customers of Paul Revere. Shares of Paul Revere rose $3.25 yesterday, to $29.75.

title: G.O.P.'s Recent Momentum At the State Level Is Halted
description: As state legislatures prepare to grapple next year with new powers over welfare and health care for the poor, Democratic voters on Tuesday halted the enormous electoral advances made by Republicans in those legislatures in the first half of the 1990's.

title: Is LeBow Picking Fight With Icahn Over RJR?
description: Has Bennett S. LeBow, the investor and sometime corporate raider, picked a feud with his erstwhile ally, the financier Carl C. Icahn? This is a question of intense interest to investors in the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, who this week saw the start of not one but two potential proxy challenges to the company's board.

title: 'Ship Fever' Wins Award for Fiction
description: ''Ship Fever and Other Stories,'' a collection weaving tales of fictional and historical 19th-century figures, triumphed over four other finalists last night to win the publishing industry's equivalent of the Oscars, the National Book Award for fiction.

title: In New Jersey, Democrats See Renewed Hope
description: The 1990's have been a good decade for Republicans in New Jersey. They have seized control of the governorship and both houses of the Legislature. But many Democrats ran unexpectedly well in the state on Tuesday, raising the party's hopes for a year from now, when Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is up for re-election.

title: Elegance Well Within Reach
description: FOR those who bid on Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' silver-plated julep cup at Sotheby's last April (lot No. 37) and lost out to the fan who paid $19,550, take heart. You don't need Jackie O's treasures or family heirlooms to add glimmer and elegance to the Thanksgiving table. There is an abundance of new silver-plated serving pieces that are well priced, just in time for the holiday season. Many are reproductions of fine English silver.

title: Liberal Use of 'Extremist' Is the Winning Strategy
description: In the epithet wars that were the 1996 Congressional and Presidential campaigns, ''extremist'' proved to be a more dangerous label than ''liberal.''

title: Same Star, but Supporting Cast to Change
description: President Clinton came home to a sentimental rally on the South Lawn of the White House this afternoon -- and to a Cabinet and senior staff shuffle already swirling around him.

title: CSX Raises Its Offer To Purchase Conrail
description: In an attempt to knock out rival Norfolk Southern Corporation and establish the largest railroad in the East, the CSX Corporation sweetened the cash portion of its bid for Conrail Inc. yesterday, and tightened the agreement that binds the two companies together.

title: In Toulouse, High Culture Embraces High Tech
description: ''The paradox of Toulouse,'' Mayor Dominique Baudis says of this southern French city of 600,000 people, ''is its combination of one of the most complete heritages from the past and the most advanced technology in all of France, all in the same place.''

title: The Road Ahead
description: Pessimists looking at this week's election results will conclude that the voters have no idea what they really want -- Gingrich conservatism, Clintonesque post-liberalism, or just plain gridlock between the Republican Congress and Democratic White House. But the American people actually seem to have sent a pretty clear message. They think the country is going in the right direction, toward a leaner but still active Federal Government. The challenge now is whether the President and Congress can build on that rough consensus and move the country forward.

title: China Paroles Key Dissident Prior to Visit By U.S. Aide
description: The Chinese authorities released a leading dissident from jail in Beijing today, a man whose fate has been almost a weather vane of American-Chinese relations over the last two years.

title: Dredgers Recover a Lode Of T.W.A. Crash Debris
description: After painstaking sweeps with sophisticated sonar and metal detectors and more than 3,200 forays by scuba divers, investigators of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 thought they had found all that they were going to find of the shattered jumbo jet.

title: Evidence Puts Date for Life's Origin Back Millions of Years
description: A team of American, British and Australian scientists has uncovered evidence that life may have originated on earth at least 350 million years earlier than previously believed, at a time immediately after a devastating bombardment by meteors.

title: Islanders Keep Waiting For Their Future Shock
description: John Spano, owner-in-waiting of the Islanders, sat high above center ice last night in Nassau Coliseum. From his location, he had a pretty good view. He could see all the way to the future. And the future looked pretty good.

title: Obesity Can Be a Social and Emotional Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Says ABC Must Surrender Tape of a Whitewater Interview
description: A Federal judge ruled today that ABC News must surrender to the independent Whitewater counsel unbroadcast film from an interview with a major figure in the Whitewater case.

title: Color the New Senate a More Conservative Tint
description: The Senate will be more conservative as a result of Tuesday's elections. The changes may mean an atmosphere less conducive to compromise, and they may enhance prospects for Congressional approval of a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget.

title: Rangers' Point Made, but It Takes Late Goal
description: The Rangers were desperate. Their leader was hobbling. Despite a furious final period, they were 2 minutes 23 seconds from an embarrassing defeat to the upstart Islanders, definitely the weak sisters in this relationship.

title: Prosecutor Will Not Seek Death Penalty in S.I. Killing
description: The Staten Island District Attorney said yesterday that he would not seek the death penalty in the case of a man charged with murdering a 14-year-old girl during a burglary at her mother's home.

title: Anarchists and Spies, Inept and Very Soggy
description: It rains, and it rains and it rains in Christopher Hampton's drably tasteful adaptation of Joseph Conrad's 1907 novel, ''The Secret Agent.'' In almost every other shot, late-19th-century London resembles a giant soot-dusted mud puddle through which horse-drawn carriages slosh carrying dour-faced residents of the waterlogged city. When the screenplay reaches for high drama, the rain is augmented by thunder and lightning; sometimes a fatuously busy orchestral soundtrack by Philip Glass chimes in.

title: Hugh Bullock, Pioneer in Managing Mutual Funds, Dies at 98
description: Hugh Bullock, a financial pioneer who sought to bring dignity and respectability to the sometimes controversial world of mutual funds, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Day in the Part of a Fool

title: Pastel Days Just Before The Terror
description: ''The Garden of the Finzi-Continis'' is a Holocaust film that casts a saddening chill, even though it includes no scenes of concentration-camp horrors or storm troopers on the rampage. Adapted from a novel by Giorgio Bassani, its story about an aristocratic Jewish family in Ferrara, Italy, in the years 1938 to 1943 is set mostly on the luxurious estate where the Finzi-Continis live an exquisitely cultivated existence, all but oblivious to the dogs of Fascism howling around them.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Halfmoon

title: Bill on Gun Sales Advances
description: A bill designed to crack down on people who sell guns to minors cleared its first legislative hurdle yesterday. The measure would hold someone who sells a gun accountable for any crime committed with that weapon. Selling a gun to a minor already carries a three-year prison term, and any further sentence would be added to that, said the bill's co-sponsor, state Senator C. Louis Bassano, Republican of Union. The measure was approved by the Senate Law and Public Safety Committee and now goes to the full Senate.

title: Yankee Coattails
description: To the Editor:

title: Dog Days Didn't Faze Apartment Purchasers
description: In New York City's real estate world, those hot, hot summer months are traditionally cool -- very cool -- in terms of sales. Whether it is because the rich are off to the Hamptons, and the rest of the apartment hunters are just too hot to move around much, no one knows. But this summer was different, according to the keepers of statistics.

title: Let's Untie Our Tongues Before the Year 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoking Report Sees Signs Of Grim Fates, and of Hope
description: More than five million Americans now under the age of 18 will die prematurely from smoking, according to new Government projections that reflect increasing tobacco use by teen-agers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In academe, the figurative heralds are singing up Albany way, where Dr. KAREN R. HITCHCOCK is to be formally installed today as the 16th president -- and the first female president -- of the State University at Albany.

title: Lessons for the Schools
description: When researchers looked into how 10 schools had worked their way off a list of the state's most chronically low-performing, they came up with a common thread: an all-out focus on what is taught in classrooms. The schools tried everything from math laboratories to standardized tests.

title: Holyfield Packs the Power, But How Long Can He Go?
description: Against all odds, Evander Holyfield will uncork a combination that will hurt Mike Tyson on Saturday night. But inevitably, Tyson will stop him within three rounds to retain his World Boxing Association title.

title: Giuliani Finds Money to Replace Aging Textbooks
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was allocating an extra $70 million for new books in the city's public schools, seeking to shore up his record on education as he begins his expected campaign for re-election. .

title: Rates Left Unchanged By German Central Bank
description: The German central bank left all three of its key interest rates unchanged yesterday, as had been expected. The Bundesbank's announcement came after news of a rise in German unemployment in October. The discount rate remains at 2.50 percent, and the Lombard emergency financing rate at 4.50 percent. The central bank's main money market rate, known as the repo rate, was also held steady, at 3 percent.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Robert G. Torricelli's victory in the United States Senate race in New Jersey misstated the context in some editions for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's assertion that proposals to cut taxes were important in the outcome of the election. She referred to the effect of such proposals on the Presidential race, not the Senate one.

title: Child Care, Unisex Prayers and More Attract Parishioners to Failing Church
description: Walk through the celestial front doors of Middle Collegiate Church in the East Village and the first thing you notice are the dancers.

title: Greed and Dick Morris
description: To the Editor:

title: Linebacker Emerging As Starter For Jets
description: At Wisconsin, Chad Cascadden enjoyed more acclaim in the classroom than on the football field.

title: Manufactured Home Makes New Bid for Chateau Properties
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc., the mobile home operator controlled by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, yesterday withdrew its hostile tender offer for the rival Chateau Properties Inc. and proposed a revised bid aimed specifically at winning over Chateau's largest shareholders.

title: Top Recruit From Peekskill Chooses Duke
description: ELTON BRAND, a 6-foot-8 1/2-inch, 238-pound center at Peekskill High School in Westchester County, announced yesterday that he planned to attend Duke University next year. Brand, the top prospect for New York high school player of the year, chose Duke over Kentucky, Virginia and Villanova, he said, because of Duke's superior academics. Brand, who averaged 30 points a game last season and has led Peekskill to state championships the last two seasons, has a grade-point average of 90.

title: True North Fund Gets New Leader
description: Fidelity Investments said today that it had removed the embattled manager of its True North Fund, Veronika Hirsch, and turned over management of the fund to Alan Radlo.

title: New York Official Seeks to Overhaul Special Education
description: The New York State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, proposed an overhaul of special education today that would eliminate the financial incentives that encourage schools to transfer children with mild learning or behavioral problems into segregated classrooms.

title: A Second-Half Rally by Knicks Is Enough to Silence Warriors
