description: John Starks tonight embarked on one of his voyages that can be physically breathtaking and emotionally dangerous. It happens whenever an opponent taunts him on the court.

title: 30 People Indicted For Stock Promotion
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted 30 people, including former officers of Teletek Inc. and United Payphone Services Inc., on charges of money laundering and other improprieties in a scheme to run up the stocks of three companies by bribing brokers and stock promoters.

title: Just Press D or R and #
description: To the Editor:

title: West Point 'Welcomes' Air Force. Notice the Patriot Launcher?
description: If network television exposure is not sufficient proof of the urgency of Saturday's football game at Army, consider the battle dress uniforms that cadets are wearing all week and the Patriot missile launcher pointed down the Hudson to track daily Air Force flyovers. And it is not every week that Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf makes himself available for a pep talk.

title: Tokyo Suspect In Subway Raid Erupts in Court
description: The man accused of being the mastermind of the nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system last year erupted in court today, taunting the judge to execute him.

title: Views on Shared Services
description: The Bergen County clerk's office released official figures yesterday on a nonbinding referendum that asked voters whether municipalities should share five different types of service.

title: AMERICAN FILTRONA DISCUSSING SALE
description: The American Filtrona Corporation said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its shares to WBT Holdings L.L.C. for $43 each, or $160.8 million. The offer by WBT is a 28 percent premium over the price of American Filtrona's lightly traded shares, which closed yesterday at $33.50. The company has 3.74 million shares outstanding. WBT is a limited liability company owned by several trusts for family members of the late Walter Bunzl, who served as Austria's honorary consul general in Atlanta from 1967 until his death in 1988. American Filtrona, based in Richmond, makes bonded fiber and a variety of plastic products.

title: Birthday-Greeting Suite For Clarinet and Smile
description: New music is in full flow at the Miller Theater, where the fifth Sonic Boom festival is going on this month: dedicated Sonic Boomers will be able to hear a wide diversity of composers, from almost silent to loud and furious, from Cambodian to Finnish, from nonagenarian to student, all played by some of New York City's foremost ensembles. To judge from the first full program, given on Wednesday by the New York New Music Ensemble, the only constant feature is likely to be excellence of performance.

title: Savoring the Grace Of an Inward Culture
description: BEFORE the 20th century, China was a universe of its own. It gave much to the rest of the world -- silk and tea, printing and gunpowder -- but was largely indifferent to anything offered in return. Two of its three major religions were home-grown. Its energies were expended less in territorial conquest than in securing its borders and preserving the ideals of its golden yesterdays.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Giuliani administration's effort to force Time Warner's cable systems to carry the Fox News Channel misstated the type of ruling issued on Wednesday by a Federal judge. The judge, Denise Cote, issued a preliminary injunction against the administration; the injunction replaced a temporary restraining order, an emergency measure that the judge had issued on Oct. 11.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: TEXTRON TO BUY GERMAN PLASTIC TANK MAKER
description: Textron Inc., based in Providence, R.I., said yesterday that it would buy Kautex-Werke A.G., Europe's leading maker of plastic fuel tanks, from Klockner-Werke A.G. for about $310 million. Textron, betting that plastic tanks will become more common than steel in cars, estimates the company's annual revenue growth at 20 percent for the next five years. For Klockner-Werke, a German maker of auto parts and packaging equipment that was close to bankruptcy two years ago, the sale is part of a plan to cut debt and improve profits. About 70 percent of the cars sold in the European car market have plastic fuel tanks, compared with 25 percent to 30 percent in the United States and fewer than 5 percent in Asia, John Janitz, president of the Textron automotive division, said.

title: D'Amato Declares His Pursuit Of Whitewater Inquiry Is Over
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato reiterated today that he would not seek to reopen Senate hearings into the Whitewater real-estate venture of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SHORELINE FINANCIAL CORP., Benton Harbor, Mich., a bank holding company, agreed to buy SJS Bancorp Inc., of St. Joseph, Mich., a savings and loan company, for $27 a share, or a total of about $25.4 million.

title: Managing Just Fine: Torre Ties With Oates
description: Joe Torre earned a share of the American League manager of the year award yesterday and might have earned an extension as manager of the Yankees beyond next year, if George Steinbrenner gets his wish. Steinbrenner usually does.

title: Sam Shepard of Today, And of Many Days Ago
description: THE old man in the prison cell and the young man in the bathtub definitely belong to different times. The elder fellow inhabits an austere landscape of grays. The other sits in a bull's-eye of concentric circles of bright, roughly applied color that Jasper Johns might have whipped up in the 1960's.

title: Reluctant Elf Adrift in Macy's Yule
description: When David Sedaris first read excerpts from ''The Santaland Diaries,'' his delightfully thorny account of working as a Yuletide elf at Macy's, on National Public Radio four years ago, he immediately struck chords in an audience that knew that Christmas is the season to be desperate.

title: Man Is Arrested in Slaying Of Ex-Companion in Bronx
description: A 23-year-old woman who had been urged by the police to seek an order of protection against her former companion was found with her throat slashed Wednesday afternoon in her basement apartment in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Democrats Question, and Return, Donation
description: For the second time in recent weeks, the Democratic National Committee has decided to return a large contribution that was solicited by John Huang, the senior party finance official who was suspended last month after reports that he had been involved in questionable fund raising.

title: Board Defeats Incinerator
description: A controversial proposal to build a $260 million incinerator on Duck Island in the Delaware River was defeated yesterday by the Mercer County Board of Freeholders. The incinerator would have handled waste from 9 of the 13 Mercer County municipalities and from Atlantic County.

title: Home Video
description: A New 'Giant'

title: Waterfront Offices Planned
description: A plan to breathe new life into Hoboken's waterfront moved closer to reality yesterday when city officials and the Port Authority announced that a 14-story office building would be constructed on First Street.

title: Successful in Seattle: Turning Grunge to Gold
description: The figure wears a stocking cap and baggy flannels, and he sticks a hand clumsily through a hole in a chain-link fence. He would look dopey enough if he were human, let alone a department store mannequin peddling grunge fashion, Seattle style.

title: One-Stop Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Borrowing Pace Declined During September
description: Consumers remained cautious as the summer turned to fall.

title: Around the World, Life and Artifice
description: The Museum of Modern Art was instrumental in establishing photography as an autonomous art form, which may be why it has often seemed slow to acknowledge photography's mixings with other media, especially since the advent of Conceptual Art. ''New Photography 12,'' one of the best shows yet in this annual series devoted to young and emerging photographers, seems intent on making up for lost time without denying the museum's traditional stance. The six artists represented -- all from outside the United States -- make images that push toward Conceptual Art, performance art, sculpture and fashion photography, but that often hew closely to conventions of photojournalism and portraiture.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Amherst

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Magician and Miscreant of Modernism, Continued
description: A LIFE OF PICASSO

title: Returning After 8 Years, Kodak Runs Into White Anger
description: When most blacks here want a picture of a birthday party, a child's first day at school, or even a new dress, they rarely take it themselves. In the townships, a camera is an expensive and sometimes daunting piece of equipment, something to be handled by a professional like Innocent Mahoa.

title: Art in Review
description: The Print Fair

title: New Cabinet In Japan: Quite a Lot Like the Old
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was formally re-elected in Parliament today, inaugurating a loose coalition Government that says it is serious about streamlining the national bureaucracy.

title: Acura Dealers Switch Agencies
description: The Tristate Acura Dealers Advertising Association said yesterday that it had named DeVito/Verdi in New York to handle its account, which had been at Landey & Partners, Grounds Morris in New York for only eight months. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $7 million.

title: Masks That Heighten, or Hide
description: Masks turned dancers both into farcical fools and imposing symbols of eternal powers in ''The Mask Dance of Korea,'' the program that the Korean Traditional Performing Arts Center of Seoul offered on Wednesday night at the Asia Society.

title: BANYAN SYSTEMS TO SCALE BACK AND SEEK NEW EXECUTIVE
description: Banyan Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would cut about 100 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, close some units and seek a chief executive to replace its chairman and chief executive, David C. Mohoney, who is now vice chairman. The company, a computer-networking software developer, expected to take a pretax restructuring charge in the fourth quarter of $3 million to $5 million for severance costs and other expenses. The company, based in Westboro, Mass., named Jeffrey D. Glidden, its chief financial officer and senior vice president since 1991, to be acting president and chief operating officer in place of Mr. Mohoney.

title: Kevorkian Is Arrested And Charged In a Suicide
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian was arrested today as he emerged from a pawnshop in this Detroit suburb and was driven 100 miles to the western Michigan town of Ionia, where he was charged with several offenses, including helping a woman commit suicide.

title: How Bob Dole's Dream Was Dashed
description: On a gusty evening three and a half weeks before Election Day, Bob Dole was standing on a makeshift stage in an airport hangar in Wichita, Kan., smiling out at the audience. The scene before him was not inspiring. The hangar was just over half full, even though Mr. Dole was in his home state on a Friday night in the heat of the election season. A sizable portion of those who had shown up were Clinton supporters, there to disrupt the event.

title: Is Nothing Sacred? Very Little on This TV Show
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced today that his Government had adopted a new verse to the national anthem to reflect the results of the American elections.

title: Apathy as Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Set Record Again As the Dow Passes 6,200
description: Stocks set records for a second day yesterday, helped by an optimistic forecast for fourth-quarter sales from the Intel Corporation and a better-than-expected sale of 30-year bonds that sent yields back to eight-month lows.

title: The Operating Room
description: So, to sum it all up with clarity and charity: The American people chose as President a man most of them do not trust and who has not revealed his goals for his new administration, except to build some kind of cockamamie bridge. And, God bless America, they were right -- given the circumstances.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Cold Comfort Farm

title: Big On-Line Company Has Quarter Loss
description: America Online Inc., in the midst of a broad revamping brought on by increasing pressure from other Internet companies, said yesterday that its revenue growth was strong in its most recent financial quarter. But the company said that a one-time charge related to a change in its accounting practices resulted in a loss of $353.7 million, or $3.80 a share.

title: Hans W. Kosterlitz, 93; Found Clues in Brain on Pain Control
description: Hans W. Kosterlitz, the neuropharmacologist who won an international race to find the first opiate-like substances in the brain, died on Oct. 26 at a nursing home in Aberdeen, Scotland, where he lived. He was 93.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Mission:Impossible

title: Voting Effort By Blacks Benefited Democrats
description: For six months before Election Day, volunteers from black churches and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People spread out around New Jersey, encouraging black residents to vote. But while that effort may have helped insure a victory for President Clinton and Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the Senate -- turnout in some urban areas was higher than the statewide average of 50 percent -- leaders of the effort said today that they had not encouraged people to vote for Democrats.

title: Puns and Allusions In Just Plain Clay
description: IN the materials-snobbery of the East Coast art world, clay is still seen as a ''craft'' medium. Ambitious sculptors work with metal, stone, wood, plastic, even found objects, although more offbeat materials like felt are sometimes permissible in the case of serious Conceptualists. Clay? That's just for modeling.

title: Brown Says Hit Will Not Affect Him
description: He has never been even close to timid, but quarterback Dave Brown was asked the question anyway, and in the same way he plays on the field, he did not duck the blitz. Would he be timid on Sunday against the Carolina Panthers after taking such a big hit in last Sunday's game against Arizona, a blow that caused part of his back to swell?

title: Perspectives and Musings on Clinton's Round 2
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tenor's Return, With Handstands
description: Hardly any pre-performance publicity surrounded Roberto Alagna's return to the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday night, which must have been a great relief to this gifted French tenor. Last season, Mr. Alagna's Met debut in ''La Boheme'' was extravagantly hyped. His record company, EMI Classics, had the hot young singer's picture posted on subway billboards. No one could have met such expectations, and Mr. Alagna, fighting a bad cold and a worse case of nerves, suffered an embarrassment.

title: For Environmentalists, Mixed Results in Election Efforts
description: A concerted campaign by leading environmental groups to influence the election met with mixed results, as some of their favored candidates won but some of their targets survived, and some of their ballot initiatives fell to the countervailing arguments of industry groups.

title: Liquor Industry Ends Its Ad Ban In Broadcasting
description: The American liquor industry decided yesterday to end a decades-long voluntary ban on the advertising of liquor products like vodka, Scotch whisky, gin and tequila on television and radio.

title: For Children
description: Although you might have assumed that children's theater in Manhattan would be outstanding, some productions can fall short of expectations. Here are three of the better ones.

title: A Recovering Yeltsin Issues a Proclamation
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin made a show today of bouncing back from his quintuple bypass heart operation. Issuing a proclamation and engaging in a tug-of-war with his doctors over his postoperative care, he took his first steps since the surgery, which occurred on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about women elected to Congress misstated the net change in the Senate. The election of Mary L. Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat, as well as Susan E. Collins, a Maine Republican, does not change the number of women in the Senate, which will remain at nine.

title: The Republican Quandary
description: His own plummeting polls no doubt prompted Senator Alfonse D'Amato's doubts about extending the Congressional inquiry on Whitewater. Mr. D'Amato is worried about his re-election campaign in 1998, when he will need Democratic votes. But his personal concern points toward a larger worry for the Republican Congressional leadership about the proper mix of cooperation and investigation in dealing with President Clinton over the next four years.

title: State Branches Seek to Reduce Perot Influence
description: On Election Day, an ad hoc committee representing nine state Reform Parties petitioned the Federal Election Commission for permission to create a national committee, a step that would vest power in the state officials and reduce the clout of Ross Perot, the national movement's founder, financier and 1996 Presidential candidate.

title: League Settles With Retired Players
description: GORDIE HOWE is one of about 1,400 retired National Hockey League players who will receive a share of more than $30 million in a pension settlement that ends a five-year battle with the league.

title: Man Behind '86 Bomb Threats Is Held in New Spate of Calls
description: A decade ago, he used a catchpenny brogue and plagued midtown Manhattan with 700 false bomb threats in the name of the Irish Republican Army. This year, the police say, he made a comeback with a nasal twang -- sometimes on behalf of the ''Iraqi Liberation Front'' -- making scores of 911 calls falsely reporting bombs, fires, heart attacks and other emergencies in midtown.

title: Labor Talks May Be Taking a Long Pause
description: In the words of Bud Selig: ''I don't want to deal here in what happened in the past. That's not useful.'' In the words of George Santayana, ''Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.''

title: Daimler Says Nine-Month Sales Rose 11%
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., Germany's largest industrial company, said today that its revenue rose 11 percent in the first nine months, and the company expects higher profit in the second half.

title: Art in Review
description: Iwao Yamawaki

title: Stocks Rally in Japan
description: Stocks were having a banner day here today. At the close, the benchmark Nikkei average of 225 stocks was up 429.93 points, or just over 2 percent, at 21,201.04. On Thursday, the Nikkei index fell 220.41 points, or 1.05 percent.

title: Art in Review
description: Beverly Semmes

title: CRAFT IS LAUNCHED TO EXPLORE MARS
description: Intrigued by fresh evidence of possible life on Mars, scientists launched an unmanned spacecraft today as the first step in a planned 10-year campaign to explore the arid plains, valleys and polar ice caps of the red planet.

title: Book Award for 'Ship Fever'
description: Andrea Barrett's ''Ship Fever and Other Stories,'' a collection weaving tales of fictional and historical 19th-century figures, won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night.

title: Smart, Free And Female In Paris
description: Anyone smitten with the written word, and in particular with 20th-century literature, has no doubt harbored a romantic fascination with Paris between the world wars. While biographies and memoirs abound with references to the expatriate writers and artists whose synergistic response to the French capital resonates in their achievements, only the screen can yield up their living images and spoken words.

title: My Family Leave Act
description: For several years now, I've been trying to find a better balance between work and family, and failing miserably. I've only just understood why. It's the word ''balance'' that threw me. I've always assumed that a better balance meant more of what you really want to do and less of what you don't. For me, and perhaps many others, that's just not possible.

title: $25 and Under
description: New York pizza can be divided into two major categories: the serious pie and everything else.

title: Officer's Diligence Leads to a Gang's Undoing
description: For nine years, according to the authorities, Officer Michael Kelley buzzed around a Harlem crack gang like a persistent mosquito on a hot summer night.

title: Mafia and a Lost Caravaggio Stun Andreotti Trial
description: It has been 27 years since thieves broke into a Palermo church, ripped a famous painting by Caravaggio out of its frame and disappeared into a stormy Sicilian night. The painting, a haunting and human Nativity scene, has never been seen publicly since.

title: Plea on Whitman's Trip
description: Leaders of Arab-American organizations urged Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday to abandon plans to visit the tunnel near some of Jerusalem's holiest sites. Morad Abou-Sabe, president of the Arab-American League of Voters of New Jersey, said that Arab-Americans would be offended if she toured the tunnel, whose opening in September triggered several days of intense violence.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Nutty Professor

title: Just One More Reason To Stay Off Airplanes
description: If movies like ''The High and the Mighty'' and ''Outbreak'' were somehow able to couple, perhaps with a therapeutic assist from ''Ship of Fools,'' the offspring would undoubtedly resemble ''Pandora's Clock,'' a two-part movie on NBC on Sunday and Monday. Heavily promoted for the November-sweeps ratings race, this is an old-fashioned by-the-numbers thriller aimed at keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. It succeeds often enough to make you uneasy about being suckered into the standard formula yet again.

title: BOSNIA REPORTED TO BE SMUGGLING HEAVY ARTILLERY
description: European intelligence agencies have uncovered evidence that the Bosnian Government has begun a covert operation to smuggle heavy artillery weapons through the Adriatic port of Ploce, Croatia, according to a senior NATO official.

title: The Center of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Retailers Beat Expectations For October
description: Retailers beat analysts' expectations for October same-store sales yesterday with numbers that appeared to be a harbinger for a decent holiday shopping season.

title: Reopening Debate on Bosnia
description: With the one-year mandate for stationing American troops in Bosnia soon to expire, the Clinton Administration is belatedly inviting public debate over what should come next in the Balkans.

title: Dollar Slumps Against Yen After Tokyo Aide's Remark
description: The dollar, which has appreciated by roughly 40 percent against the yen in the last 18 months, fell sharply yesterday after a key architect of its rise strongly suggested the yen had fallen far enough.

title: B.C. Still Ponders Players' Eligibility
description: Boston College officials have not yet determined the number of suspended football players they will seek to return to the team's roster, Chet Gladchuk, the school's athletic director, said today.

title: Art in Review
description: Harriet Korman

title: Teacher Union Approves 3-Year Pact With Archdiocese
description: The union representing teachers at 11 Roman Catholic high schools accepted a contract with the Archdiocese of New York last night that the union said removes threats to teachers' personal freedom.

title: No Headline
description: ''Although I love my job -- it is the best one I ever had or ever will have -- I love my family more.''

title: Rising Star Falls Fast In Connecticut Vote
description: Gary A. Franks, a Connecticut Congressman who was the first black Republican elected to the House in almost 50 years, was a rising star in his party.

title: Rethink Gingrich
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Gerhard Richter

title: Ruling Could Bring Lilco A Billion-Dollar Refund
description: A state judge ruled today that Suffolk County and two local governments owe the Long Island Lighting Company as much as $1.16 billion in refunds and interest for overtaxing the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which never went into service.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Polls: Democracy's Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Unabom Suspect Reconsidering Appearance in Newark Court
description: Lawyers for Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in an 18-year string of lethal mail bombs sent to strangers known as the Unabom case, are reconsidering whether he should appear in New Jersey for arraignment in the killing of a local executive.

title: Approval Seen for Giuliani Plan to Privatize a City Hospital
description: In a milestone for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to turn over some of New York City's public hospitals to private hands, the city's hospitals agency is expected today to approve the leasing of Coney Island Hospital to a profit-making company.

title: Fast Fall Bewilders a G.O.P. Star
description: Gary A. Franks, the first black Republican elected to the House of Representatives in almost 50 years, was a rising star in the Republican Party, credited with being a major force behind the overhauling of welfare.

title: As Mobutu Fights Death, War Offers Him Political Rebirth
description: There is a story making the rounds these days among this city's political class that President Mobutu Sese Seko, watching recently from his sickbed in Switzerland as tensions between his country and neighboring Rwanda grew, blocked a shipment of heavy weapons to the border region. This, the story goes, ultimately allowed the Rwanda-backed rebels to capture major Zairian cities in the area.

title: Bond Prices Rally After Solid Auction
description: The prices of Treasury bonds rebounded sharply yesterday on a better-than-expected auction of a new 30-year bond, after concerns about the dollar's weakness and results of auctions held earlier this week had kept buyers on the sidelines.

title: Softbank Profit Lifted By Software Sales
description: The Softbank Corporation in Japan said yesterday that its profit rose 77.8 percent in the six months that ended on Sept. 30 on a boom in sales of software in Japan. The company said current profit rose to 8.436 billion yen ($75.32 million). Sales rose 46.1 percent, to 86.867 billion yen.

title: All the Ways Not to Say 'I Love You'
description: David can say ''I love you'' in 15 languages. The problem is that he can't -- won't, actually -- say it in English to his girlfriend, Kathy.

title: Pakistan's Bhutto Quandary
description: As Pakistan's new caretaker government settles down to its self-proclaimed task of providing ''good governance and clean administration,'' many Pakistanis are waiting to see what new steps, if any, will be taken to prevent a political comeback by Benazir Bhutto, the deposed Prime Minister.

title: Default Rate Up For Consumers
description: Defaults on credit cards and consumer loans continued to rise in September, although the pace eased slightly because of tighter controls by lenders and improving wages.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Veterans Day

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 11
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Abrams Suffered Two Fractures
description: DANYA ABRAMS of Boston College suffered two orbit fractures beneath his left eye when he was punched in an exhibition basketball game on Tuesday night. The fractures were revealed yesterday during a follow-up examination at Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Exit the Exit Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Mario Savio, Protest Leader Who Set a Style, Dies at 53
description: Mario Savio, an incendiary student leader of the Free Speech Movement at the University of California at Berkeley in the 1960's, a movement credited with giving birth to the campus ''sit-in'' and with being a model for the protests against the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday in Palm Drive Hospital in Sebastopol, Calif. He was 53 and lived in Sonoma County, Calif.

title: Clinton Seeks 'Vital Center' in New Cabinet
description: Formally accepting the resignation of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, President Clinton said today that his Cabinet selections for a second term would reflect his view that the election results were a call for him to ''create a vital center'' as he assembles his Government.

title: INSIDE
description: Army Accuses 2 of Rape

title: Michigan Coach's Contract Extended
description: The University of Michigan extended the contract of its football coach, LLOYD CARR, through the 2000 season, the school said yesterday. Carr, 51, signed a four-year contract in February reportedly worth $250,000 annually. Financial terms of the one-year extension were not disclosed. (Bloomberg)

title: Women Get a Place in the Big Picture
description: As recently as 1990, images taken by women amounted to something like 14 percent of the Museum of Modern Art's photographic collection. Since then, the museum has bought work by five or six dozen women, and many more men. On the other hand, it reportedly paid about $1 million for a complete set of Cindy Sherman's ''Film Stills,'' even though men generally command higher prices than women. Women have made great strides in all branches of photography in the last quarter-century, but the museums and history books have only intermittently caught up with them. Which may just mean that women are really ahead of the game but not all the players know it.

title: An Unfinished Person
description: Bill Clinton is too intelligent to believe those syrupy post-election statements by Newt Gingrich and other Congressional Republican leaders. They will subdue their combative instincts, they say, and seek ''common ground'' with the President. Sure.

title: Songs and Hugs, as in Any Reunion
description: The movies have never done particularly well at capturing the complicated camaraderie of old friends. Who has time to gauge the fluctuating temperature of all that water under the bridge? But Sharon Pollack's small independent film ''Everything Relative'' succeeds better than most in getting the tricky emotional chemistry right. As it follows the weekend reunion of seven college chums, six of them lesbians, who were rowdy radical feminists together in the late 1970's, the atmosphere grows heavy with a mixture of nostalgia and the kind of regressive hysteria in which people suddenly burst out with their favorite summer-camp songs.

title: Howe Gets Probation on Gun Charge
description: The former Yankee relief pitcher STEVE HOWE was sentenced to three years' probation and 150 hours of community service yesterday in New York after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor weapons-possession charge.

title: The Farce Before the Storm
description: Fasten your seat belts and shoulder harnesses, you are going on a wild, wild ride. Forget the nice-nice talk coming out of Washington. The daggers are only temporarily sheathed. To get from here to Election Day 2000, voters will have to travel a chaotic and confusing route through a succession of political combat zones.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Liquor Industry Ends Ban On TV and Radio Ads

title: U.S. Again Denies Assertion That Navy Downed Flight 800
description: Federal officials investigating the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 were forced last night, once again, to deny persistent rumors that the jumbo jet was accidentally shot down by a Navy missile.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's back to school for RICHARD EYRE.

title: Art in Review
description: Alexander Mihaylovich

title: Only 4 More Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Millionaire and a Mountain, Forgotten
description: A picture may be worth a thousand words, but sometimes no amount of pictures can capture the precise image of a man's soul.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Wants U.S. Inquiry Into Texaco
description: Adding to a growing furor over the Texaco Inc. scandal stemming from secret tape recordings, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday called for a Justice Department investigation to determine if the company had violated Federal civil rights laws.

title: PHARMACIA TO SELL BIACORE TO INVESTORS
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the American-Swedish drug company, said yesterday that it planned to sell Biacore A.B. to investors by listing the company on the Stockholm Stock Exchange and on the Nasdaq market in the United States. Pharmacia & Upjohn will start by selling 51 percent of the company in a price range of $15 to $17 a share. That values the whole company at $155 million, Pharmacia said. Pharmacia will offer to sell five million shares, of which 1.5 million will be newly issued stock. The unit, formerly called Biosensor, is based in Uppsala, Sweden; it develops, makes and markets analysts' instruments.

title: Embezzlement Is Charged At Synagogue on East Side
description: For years, the Sutton Place Synagogue has welcomed world leaders and other prominent figures to speak to its well-connected congregation. But yesterday, the arrest of the synagogue's bookkeeper, accused of embezzling more than half a million dollars, was the topic of the day at the synagogue in the posh enclave near the United Nations.

title: PANEL CONDEMNS PENTAGON REVIEW OF GULF AILMENTS
description: A special White House panel has condemned the Pentagon for its investigation into whether American troops were exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons in the 1991 Persian Gulf war and has called for an independent inquiry into more than 15 incidents in which nerve gas and other chemical agents were detected by American troops.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report about Alaska yesterday in the state-by-state election summary misstated the result of a ballot measure to limit hunting there. It was approved.

title: Art in Review
description: Fernando Botero

title: Frank Torre Out of Hospital
description: Frank Torre, the older brother of Yankee Manager Joe Torre, was released from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday, two weeks after undergoing the heart transplant he had been admitted for in midsummer.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Squeeze U.N. And the City Feels the Pain
description: DURING the Presidential campaign -- in fact, because of it -- a prominent foreign resident was mugged on the East Side of Manhattan. At least, that is how some observers of this scene describe what happened, people who usually know what they are talking about.

title: Answers From City's Turnaround Schools
description: A leading educational advocacy organization in New York City set out to answer a single question last year: What does it take to fix a failing school?

title: In Alamo Deal, Republic Puts More Money On Used Cars
description: H. Wayne Huizenga's Republic Industries stepped up its expansion into the growing used car industry yesterday, when it announced it had signed an agreement to acquire Alamo Rent-a-Car Inc. for $625 million in stock, thereby insuring a steady supply of vehicles for the company's nascent used auto supermarkets.

title: Vigilante Dad Vs. Kidnappers
description: IT'S an escapist pleasure to watch Ron Howard put his expert new thriller through its paces. Mr. Howard has made ''Ransom'' in the same clean, swift, logical style that sent his ''Apollo 13'' into orbit, resulting in a spellbinding crime tale that delivers surprises right down to the wire.

title: Another Middleman Suffers in the Process
description: Negotiators in the major league baseball labor wars all suffer the same type of delusions that get Boston Red Sox fans, Chicago Cubs players and Yankees managers most every year. They labor under the impression they can make a difference.

title: Running, Running, Running After a Gilded Record
description: The world's richest race horse and the second-richest filly will be making appearances at Churchill Downs tomorrow. Cigar, with a record bankroll of just under $10 million, will take the stage for a ceremonial farewell promenade just before the feature race. And Serena's Song, with earnings of $3.2 million, will make a business appearance against nine rivals a few moments later in a race that could thrust her past Dance Smartly as the richest filly in history.

title: Victory Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Orders Environmentalists to Pay $1 Million for Idaho Protest
description: A state court jury has ordered 12 members of the environmental group Earth First to pay $1.15 million in damages to a contractor for damaged equipment and work delays as the result of protests in the virgin forests of northern Idaho.

title: Copper Continues to Gain; Coffee Prices Also Increase
description: Copper jumped yesterday for a second day, reaching the highest price in almost two weeks, following a forecast for a smaller surplus than traders previously expected.

title: S.E.C. Acts on Stock Promotion on the Net
description: Cynics who suspect that the real Internet ''revolution'' has been in the area of stock fraud got some ammunition yesterday, when Federal regulators brought what appears to be their first lawsuit to stop securities manipulation over the Net.

title: The Troubles of RU-486
description: After winning provisional approval from the Food and Drug Administration just two months ago, RU-486, the French abortion pill, has become ensnared in a legal and management dispute that could slow its progress toward the American market. Two nonprofit groups that are backing the drug have filed suit against the man chosen to raise money to manufacture and distribute it in this country. The courts will have the final say on the fraud charges against the would-be distributor, but meanwhile he needs to step aside or be removed from the process as quickly as possible lest his legal problems derail the effort to bring a safe, effective abortion pill to American women.

title: Illnesses Reported by Gulf War Veterans Remain a Mystery to Panels of Medical Experts
description: After years of study by five separate expert committees, the illnesses reported by thousands of veterans of the Persian Gulf war continue to baffle medical experts.

title: Rangers' Superb Talent Doesn't Awe Islanders
description: Colin Campbell calls it the ''David and Goliath story.'' Neil Smith says other teams approach each of their matchups with his Rangers as if they were games against their most hated rivals.

title: Nick, Mick and Vic, the Loony Don
description: A few more mobster films as confounding as ''Mad Dog Time'' could put a serious dent in Hollywood's long, happy relationship with Gangland U.S.A. The first feature film directed and written by Larry Bishop (whose father is the comedian Joey Bishop), this unfunny spoof has the feel of an in-joke so private it would take the Las Vegas equivalent of an old-time Kremlinologist to uncover its hidden agenda.

title: Profit Growth Slows At Swiss Bank
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation, Switzerland's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its profit growth slowed in the third quarter as world financial markets calmed. The company said that it still expected a substantially higher profit for 1996 than it recorded last year but not as high as it predicted earlier in the year. The company estimated in September that its net income would show an increase of 33 percent this year, totaling around 1.4 billion Swiss francs ($1.1 billion).

title: Isaac M. Taylor, 75, Prominent Physician
description: Dr. Isaac M. Taylor, a physician, scholar and former dean of the University of North Carolina School of Medicine at Chapel Hill, died on Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 75 and lived in Boston and on Martha's Vineyard.

title: A Star Turn for a Retired Vermont Farmer
description: With 601 of 807 registered voters turning out on Election Day in the civic-minded town of Tunbridge, Vt., Bill Clinton scored 276 votes, Bob Dole 202, Ross Perot 88, and Fred Tuttle 2.

title: Treasures of the Best Families on the Block
description: Pedigree will be every bit as intriguing as quality at this fall's sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art, which begin next week in Manhattan. Collections assembled by prominent American families like the Havemeyers and Engelhards, who began buying art as early as the turn of the century, have found their way to auction this season. Of the estimated $350 million worth of art that goes on view this weekend, including works by masters like Degas, Monet, Manet and Willem de Kooning, these families' treasures will get international attention.

title: The Heart That Helps And Hurts
description: HEART. It's the hip word now in sports to identify the winners.

title: 2 Are Charged With Rapes At an Army Training Center
description: The Army has charged an officer and a drill instructor with raping female trainees at a center in Maryland and is investigating accusations that an unspecified number of other men at the center engaged in sexual harassment.

title: Victory Leaves Posts Vacant
description: Voters in Paterson who helped give William J. Pascrell his victory over William J. Martini on Tuesday gained a new Congressman, but they lost a Mayor and Assemblyman. Mr. Pascrell, a fifth-term legislator and Paterson's Mayor since 1990, must resign those seats before he is sworn in next January. The Passaic County Democratic organization will then have 30 days to appoint a replacement to serve the one year remaining in his Assembly term, said John Currie, the group's chairman. Similarly, the Democratic-controlled City Council will have 30 days to appoint an interim mayor before an election is held next November for the six years remaining in Mr. Pascrell's term, said Alfred E. Steele, president of the City Council.

title: Art in Review
description: Edwin Dickinson

title: Diner's Journal
description: In old New York, patroons were people given large estates with manorial rights in return for founding colonies under the Dutch Government.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the dispute between Fordham University and the New York Botanical Garden over the university's planned radio tower misstated the audience size for the campus radio station, WFUV-FM. It is 176,000 listeners weekly, according to the university, not 15,000.

title: Before 38,600 Fans in Tokyo, Nets Run Out of Luck
description: On a sightseeing tour of Tokyo this week, the New Jersey Nets visited a Buddhist temple where each player received an omamori, a little bag containing an inscription that bestows good luck providing the bag is not opened.

title: Senate Panel Finds Nothing Illegal in Clinton Policy on Iranian Arms Sent to Bosnian Muslims
description: Senior Clinton Administration officials may have misled one another, Congress, American allies and the American people, but they broke no laws by standing mute as Iran shipped arms to Bosnia's Muslims in 1994, the Senate Intelligence Committee concluded today.

title: Corporate F.O.B.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Take the Good With the Bad (Again)
description: Even when the Mets have good news to report, they still cannot shake the dark clouds.

title: U.S. Classifies a Device to Surf the Web as a Weapon
description: Amer ican couch potatoes have become empowered too empowered, in the eyes of the Government.

title: Restaurants
description: ''Is this a special occasion?'' our waiter asks. ''Can we sing to you? Happy birthday? Happy anniversary? Anything?''

title: Corrections
description: The attribution of the Quotation of the Day yesterday, from Richard Petty, the stock car driver, referred incorrectly in some copies to the state in which he campaigned unsuccessfully for secretary of state. It was North Carolina, not South Carolina.

title: Clinton Seeks 'Vital Center' in His Cabinet
description: As he accepted the resignation of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, President Clinton said his Cabinet selections for a second term would reflect his view that the election results were a call for him to ''create a vital center.''

title: Dark Days Grow Darker For a Fallen Congressman
description: Once upon a time, not so long ago, Mel Reynolds was a rising Democratic star here, with a big house in the suburbs where he lived with his devoted wife and three beautiful children.

title: A Unified Battlefront
description: To the Editor:

title: KELLOGG EXPECTS CEREAL PRICE WAR TO HURT EARNINGS
description: The Kellogg Company told securities analysts yesterday that its price war with other breakfast cereal companies would probably hurt earnings through the first quarter of 1997. The company, which makes Special K and Frosted Flakes, also said it expected to report earnings-per-share growth of at least 10 percent for its 1997 fiscal year. Shares of Kellogg, based in Battle Creek, Mich., fell $1, to $66.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading of almost 1.9 million shares. Kellogg cut prices on several of its cereals in June, following in the steps of the Post and Nabisco cereal brands. In the process, however, Kellogg, the industry leader, lost market share.

title: Czechs Plan Inquiry Into Handling and Chemical Protection of Their Gulf War Troops
description: The Czech Defense Ministry has ordered a wide-ranging investigation of whether the Government failed to provide Czech troops with adequate chemical protection equipment in the 1991 Persian Gulf war and whether the ministry ignored the health problems of the soldiers after they returned home.

title: In Plea Deal, Ex-Officer Is Sentenced For Perjury
description: A former police officer, who was described by prosecutors as one of the most corrupt members of the scandal-ridden 30th Precinct in Harlem, was sentenced yesterday to up to three years in prison.

title: Carolyn Agger, 87, Lawyer and Widow Of Justice Fortas
description: Carolyn Eugenia Agger, a prominent tax lawyer and the widow of former Justice Abe Fortas of the Supreme Court, died on Thursday at her home in the Georgetown section of Washington. She was 87.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Football

title: INTEGRATED SYSTEMS STOCK PLUNGES WITH LOW EARNINGS
description: The shares of Integrated Systems Inc. fell 28 percent yesterday after the company told some analysts that its third-quarter earnings would not meet their expectations. The shares fell $7.25, to $19, in Nasdaq trading of 3.1 million shares. The plunge came after executives at the company, a software maker based in Sunnyvale, Calif., told three analysts late Thursday that higher-than-expected costs from the recent acquisition of Diab Data would reduce earnings, the chief executive, David P. St. Charles, said. The three analysts who were notified cut their estimates for the quarter to a range of 13 to 15 cents, Mr. St. Charles said. Previously, the company was expected to earn 18 cents, according to IBES International Inc.

title: Democrats Say Urban Votes Clinched Victory
description: Three years ago this month, when New Jersey voters elected a new Republican governor, the turnout in urban areas was unexpectedly low. This city of 73,000 was no exception: only 14,011 registered voters -- 48 percent of the total -- cast ballots. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman won by only 26,000 votes statewide, and the Democrats attributed their loss to the low urban turnout.

title: Nixon's G.O.P. Will Always Be a Loser
description: At Richard Nixon's funeral in April 1994, Bob Dole declared that the latter half of the 20th century would be known as the ''age of Nixon.'' At the time, it seemed like an inflated claim, given the comparison between Nixon's political legacy and the shape of things at the end of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

title: Agency Approves Private Control of Coney Island Hospital
description: New York City's public hospitals agency voted yesterday to allow a profit-making company from Pennsylvania to run Coney Island Hospital, the first time in the city's history that a public hospital would be turned over to private hands.

title: Unilever Profit Gains And Its Stock Soars
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products company, reported yesterday that it had a better-than-expected 4 percent gain in third- quarter earnings on increases in Latin America and Asia while North American profits were flat. The stock of Unilever, whose best-known brands include Dove soap, Breyers ice cream, Promise margarine and Lipton tea, climbed strongly. The securities linked to Unilever's Dutch shares rose $9.625, to $162.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, and the American depository receipts of the British shares gained $4.625, to $89.25, also on the Big Board.

title: Dresdner Bank to Unite Foreign Funds Business
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's second-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that it planned to merge its foreign institutional funds business under one roof, led by its newly acquired United States unit, RCM Capital Management. The bank said the new unit, whose name and start-up date have not been decided, will have 900 employees worldwide and assets under management of more than $50 billion.

title: California Challenges Deal on Nonprofit Hospital
description: In the latest strong objection by a state to a deal between nonprofit and for-profit health care companies, the California Attorney General yesterday accused the directors of a big San Diego hospital chain of undervaluing their business by $100 million to $200 million in a joint venture with the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation.

title: Canal Plus Revenue Rose 10.8% in 9 Months
description: Canal Plus S.A., Europe's biggest pay television company, said yesterday that its sales rose 10.8 percent in the first nine months of the year as subscriptions maintained their strong growth, especially in France. The Paris-based company, which is facing a legal challenge to its acquisition of a Dutch rival, Nethold N.V., had sales of 8.2 billion French francs ($1.6 billion) from its wholly owned units, up from 7.4 billion francs in the period a year earlier.

title: North's Army Falls Again
description: My uncle and aunt, Sydney and Frances Lewis, are notorious die-hard Democrats in Richmond -- a city where their like are ''few and far between,'' as my aunt puts it. But this year they voted to send John Warner, a fairly conservative Republican, back to the Senate. Not because they disliked his Democratic rival, but because Senator Warner's vocal opposition torpedoed Oliver North's bid two years ago to become a Virginia senator.

title: APPLE COMPUTER PLANS TO SIMPLIFY DOMESTIC SALES
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it would simplify its domestic sales structure as it tried to improve its sagging sales. The plans include simplifying the company's product offerings, improving the relationship with resellers and giving those resellers wider access to Apple products and marketing support. Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., is changing a sales system that ''does not reward those in the channel who are strong advocates of Apple products,'' the company said in a statement. Apple said only that it would encourage retailers who gave Apple products high visibility in their stores. In the last few weeks, Apple has cut prices as much as 30 percent on some product groups.

title: Special Care for Special Education
description: Reforming New York State's special-education system will require dedication from both state and local officials -- as well as an effort to reassure parents who fear a return to the days when disabled children were shunted into corners and ignored.

title: Women at The Citadel Get Shorter Hair, and in Trouble
description: Trying to fit in where they were once not welcome, three female cadets at The Citadel shaved one another's heads to try to make their hair as short as the men's. But they ended up being punished for breaking the South Carolina military college's rules.

title: Tyson and Holyfield Will Meet On Boxing's Richest Night Ever
description: If, in Evander Holyfield's view, Saturday night's heavyweight championship fight against Mike Tyson is about good versus evil, then evil still sells well.

title: Canada Tries to Shake Off Economic Doldrums
description: Gordie Howe ruled hockey and Howdy Doody was a big man on TV the last time interest rates in Canada were as low as they are today.

title: Man Charged in Scheme
description: Prosecutors say Patrick Gawrysiak of Hackensack posed as a global wheeler-dealer in a moneymaking scheme that defrauded investors out of millions. Mr. Gawrysiak, using the name Patrick Gray, tried to buy an insurance company with phony bonds issued by a fictitious entity called the Penske Group, which he claimed was a racing concern affiliated with Roger Penske, the auto racing magnate, Mark Costello, an assistant United States attorney, said.

title: Remedial Classes
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Leaves a Prayer
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman visited the Western Wall yesterday on her first day in Jerusalem and placed a handwritten prayer in a crevice. But she did not visit the controversial tunnel near the Temple Mount. If she does, the Governor said, the tour will not be part of any political agenda. ''I don't have a place in the national foreign-policy scene,'' she said. Some Arab-Americans and Palestinians had criticized her for saying she wanted to see the tunnel and the Golan Heights.

title: B.C. Begins Its Clean-Up By Emptying Five Lockers
description: As Boston College football coaches attempt to fill a depth chart depleted by 13 gambling suspensions for Saturday's game against Notre Dame, five of the Eagles' players had their lockers cleaned out today, raising speculation that they would not be supported by any appeal the school might make to the National Collegiate Athletic Association for reinstatement.

title: Voters of Various Faiths Return to Democratic Fold
description: Looking at a map of the Electoral College after Tuesday's election, one could begin to discern a certain broad religious division between the states won by President Clinton and those that went to Bob Dole.

title: Cars vs. Bikes
description: To the Editor:

title: N.H.L. Decides Not to Discipline Messier
description: The National Hockey League announced yesterday that it would take no disciplinary action against the Rangers' Mark Messier for cutting Darius Kasparaitis of the Islanders during Wednesday's game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Savior of Harvey Nichols Has His Eye on Barneys
description: The scene would be absolutely familiar to viewers of the British television show ''Absolutely Fabulous.'' Edina and Patsy, the two vodka-swigging fashion-victim protagonists, are heading for Edina's office in her limousine, when Patsy tunes in to her inner voice, the one crying out: ''I must go shopping!'' She turns to Edina. Why not stop just for a minute, she wheedles, at Harvey Nicks?

title: Torre Would Like to Finish His Career With the Yanks
description: Joe Torre acknowledged yesterday that George Steinbrenner had spoken with him recently about the possibility of a contract extension beyond next season. But Torre, the Yankee manager, said he has been so immersed in the spoils of the World Series victory that he has barely pondered the future.

title: Selig and Fehr to Meet With Failure in the Air
description: Bud Selig and a corps of his colleagues will meet with Donald Fehr and his aides on Monday in a bargaining session at which the owners are expected to ask for two major concessions from the union. The union is expected to reject the owners' request.

title: U.N. SAYS MILITARY MUST ACT TO SAVE REFUGEES IN ZAIRE
description: As a colossal refugee crisis in Central Africa intensified, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali called today for the urgent dispatch of an international military force to aid about a million refugees, many in danger of dying of hunger or thirst.

title: Graf Is Tickled by Honor
description: Since neither her 21 Grand Slam titles nor her 101 career singles titles have given top-ranked STEFFI GRAF cause to consider herself a tennis legend -- she sees herself as a work in progress -- it figured that she was more amused than awed yesterday when she was inducted into Madison Square Garden's Walk of Fame.

title: Bhutto Foe, a Cricket Idol, Lashes Out, Assailing the 'Thievery in Her Heart'
description: When Imran Khan brought his campaign to become the country's next Prime Minister to this city's ancient bazaar this week, aides wedged a truck hauling two rusty shipping containers into the narrow street. With the athleticism born of years as Pakistan's cricket captain, Mr. Khan bounded up a rickety bamboo ladder onto the makeshift platform, leaving aides to hoist the ladder, drawbridge-style, behind him.

title: The Many Faces (and Legs) of the Tango
description: The tango's rise from rags to riches is celebrated in ''Tango x 2,'' the irresistibly seductive show that opened on Thursday night at the City Center: two hours of tangos without a single dull moment.

title: Bochy Wins in Tight Vote For N.L. Manager Award
description: The breakthrough year for the San Diego Padres continued into the off season yesterday when Bruce Bochy, manager of the National League West champions, was voted manager of the year by the baseball writers.

title: While Zaire Bleeds, Mobutu Rests on Cote d'Azur
description: In the fine light and scented air of a Mediterranean fall, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has ensconced himself at the Villa del Mare, a mansion he acquired a decade ago from a Saudi billionaire and has used only once before -- on a visit to his dentist in Monaco.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about mail-order food for the holidays misstated the quantity of Benne Bits offered for $17.50, including shipping, by the Byrd Cookie Company. It is two seven-ounce tins, not three pounds.

title: Teen-Ager Killed in Stakeout
description: An apparently unarmed 19-year-old was shot and killed Thursday night by a Camden police officer in an abandoned city building, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Dow Keeps On Ascending at Record Pace
description: Stocks rose to records in a late day rebound amid prospects for growing profits and low inflation, giving the Dow Jones industrial average its best weekly gain in more than three months.

title: Four Cubans Defect at Event
description: Four more Cuban baseball players have defected, driven in part by the Cuban Government's recent lifetime ban of three of its top players for what it termed ''treason to the fatherland.''

title: Taiwan's Overtures to U.S. Backfire
description: The Taiwan ruling party's efforts to influence American policy by hiring a high-priced Washington lobbying firm and fostering donations to the Democratic Party seems to have backfired, and critics here fear they have done serious harm to Taiwan's image.

title: U.S. Military in Saudi Arabia Digs Into the Sand
description: To reach what its commander calls ''the newest base in the United States Air Force,'' drive 70 miles from the nearest city, brave three checkpoints, submit to a pat-down search, let dogs sniff out your vehicle, and only then, far across the desert, will you glimpse what the American military presence in Saudi Arabia has become.

title: Principal Relents on Tests
description: Under pressure from a Washington public-interest law firm, the superintendent of Jersey City's public schools agreed yesterday to excuse the absence of eighth-graders taking placement tests for Roman Catholic high schools.

title: Can Russia's Mafia Be Broken?
description: A few years ago, a detective in the city of Yekaterinburg gave me an apologetic explanation for the link between organized crime and commerce in Russia.

title: Spacecraft Is on a Smooth Course for Mars
description: Even though a segment of one of its solar-power panels remained tilted at an odd angle, the Mars Global Surveyor cruised smoothly through space today, bound for Mars, with engineers expressing optimism that the craft would have no trouble conducting its full mapping mission.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the acquisition of the SMC Holdings Corporation omitted part of the name of the investment firm that is buying SMC. It is Haas Wheat & Partners Inc., not Wheat & Partners.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rise to Records At End of Strong Week

title: Escapism Is Letting Us Down
description: If politics defines who we are, the election seemed to be a perfect reflection of our time. It was neither here nor there.

title: Old Tales in a New Telling
description: The City Opera's new realization of ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann,'' which opened on Thursday night, is the first production this company has put together from scratch under the leadership of Paul Kellogg, and it bodes well. People on stage look, sound and move with confidence; the chorus is in much better shape than of late, and the orchestra, under Robert Duerr, gives a thoroughly solid performance. These are all encouraging signs of the organization's general health. The essential requirements for any staging of Offenbach's opera -- a protagonist and a place -- are also admirably fulfilled.

title: Dole Gets a Few Laughs, and $200, on a Talk Show
description: Bob Dole is out of work, but he picked up an easy $200 tonight by going on the David Letterman show.

title: AIDS Crisis Calls Out for a Vaccine and Unity
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Have No Trouble Expressing Opinions
description: What the Jets are saying on the eve of Sunday's home game against the New England Patriots:

title: Sport Marches On
description: For those who have been avoiding eye contact with reality these past months, we now bring you up to date on the sports news:

title: Radio Programs Gave Hungary 'Gift of Truth'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Ideas for the Election Next Time
description: Since it is never too early to start worrying about the next Presidential election, here are a few suggestions inspired by months of keeping television track of the one just past.

title: Justice Dept. Rejects Independent Prosecutor on Financing
description: The Justice Department tonight rejected a request for an independent prosecutor to investigate possible criminal violations of campaign finance laws by the Democratic and Republican Presidential campaigns.

title: HICKS, MUSE TO GET 80 PERCENT OF WINDOW MAKER
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas-based investment firm that has made several acquisitions in recent months, said yesterday that it would buy 80 percent of the Atrium Corporation, a closely held maker of windows, for $135 million. Owners of Atrium, including some members of its management, will retain the other 20 percent. Atrium, which is also based in Dallas, is one of the two largest makers of home windows in the Southern United States. John Muse, a partner at Hicks, Muse, said that the firm intended to make other purchases in the window and door industries. The acquisition is expected to be completed by Dec. 31, a Hicks, Muse official said.

title: Electric Shock: Lilco's $1 Billion Tax Award May Speed Accord
description: There's nothing quite like a bill for $1 billion to get somebody's attention.

title: Charges Expected Against VW President
description: Prosecutors in Germany are expected to file criminal charges of industrial spying against Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the president of Volkswagen A.G., in connection with his departure from General Motors in 1993.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a NATO proposal for keeping troops in Bosnia referred incorrectly to a dispute between the United States and other NATO members over the size and mission of the proposed force. Gen. George Joulwan, the NATO commander, has been involved in the dispute and has argued that NATO needs to keep a sizable force in Bosnia next year. But contrary to the accounts of two senior NATO officials, General Joulwan did not attend a meeting at NATO headquarters in Brussels on Tuesday at which the issue was debated.

title: Keep Public Space Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Love and Anguish of Women Who Have Only One Another
description: The rickety set looks as if it might fall apart at any moment. The grating music, a discordant military march, is repeated far too often. The rudimentary lighting occasionally spotlights the furniture and leaves the actors in shadow.

title: Smith Is the Lineman In the Gray Flannel Suit
description: When Giants guard Lance Smith walks through the locker room, it is seldom that his briefcase is not near his side. Sometimes he looks as if he is a substitute teacher. Or as if he is going to a meeting at I.B.M.

title: Japanese Premier to Name a High-Level Commission to Guide Promised Reforms
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledged today to appoint a blue-ribbon commission this month as the first step toward a major streamlining of the Government and deregulation of the economy.

title: Russian Traders Go Abroad For Some Serious Shopping
description: Galina Glazova walked purposefully down a narrow, crowded street in black ankle boots, a white leather jacket and matching skirt, trailed by her friend Tatyana Savkina and the beckoning glances of several hundred Turkish merchants. She regally ignored the warm cries of ''Natasha! Natasha!'' (the generic Turkish word for Russian woman) and entered a narrow basement shop.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 19 about Magda Trocme, a Frenchwoman who helped shield Jewish refugees from the Nazis in World War II, misspelled the name of her daughter and misstated the daughter's hometown. She is Nelly Hewett, not Hewitt, of St. Paul, not Minneapolis.

title: Alomar Says Umpire Should Share in Blame
description: ROBERTO ALOMAR says Umpire JOHN HIRSCHBECK cursed at him, provoking the spitting incident during the final weekend of the regular season.

title: Bosnian Serb President Ousts Military Chief
description: In a move that could pit the Bosnian Serb military against the newly elected civilian leadership, the Bosnian Serb President announced today that she had dismissed Gen. Ratko Mladic, the military commander indicted by an international tribunal for directing some of the worst atrocities of the Bosnian war.

title: In the Trenches: Pain, Poison, Poetry
description: PBS anticipates what was once known as Armistice Day with tomorrow's opening salvo of a history of the war that failed to end all wars. Without neglecting the political and strategic view, ''The Great War and the Shaping of the 20th Century'' gets into the trenches and into the feelings of soldiers and their families, nurses, black recruits from the British colonies, Christian Armenians enduring an early form of ''ethnic cleansing'' and others. Historians' assessments give way to poignant passages from letters and diaries.

title: On Gay Activism
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Mexico Reach Accord Over Satellite TV Transmission
description: Mexico and the United States jointly agreed yesterday that at least when it comes to satellite television transmission, the 2,000-mile border between the two countries should not be a barrier. Yesterday afternoon in Washington, Reed E. Hundt, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and Javier Lozano Alarcon, subsecretary of the Mexican communications ministry, signed an agreement that gives both countries broad access to each other's rapidly growing direct-to-home television markets.

title: Corruption and Money Woes Divide and Anger Miamians
description: Just last summer this city turned 100 years old, a cause for celebration, self-congratulation and civic pride. But by this Election Day the mood had turned so somber that at some polling places voters signed petitions to abolish their city.

title: INSIDE
description: Serb Army Chief Ousted

title: A Senate Victory in Oregon Gives Republicans 55 Seats
description: Absentee ballots counted today in Oregon assured the Republicans of a 55-to-45 majority in the Senate next year, a net gain of 2 seats.

title: One Way To Control The Chaos In Ives
description: Depicting confusion requires the precisest of hands. Chaos, moreover, appears as chaos only if laid out in an orderly way. Such are the paradoxes that make Charles Ives's music so intriguing to perform and so stimulating to the imaginations of people like Michael Tilson Thomas and the San Francisco Symphony.

title: Norfolk Raises Bid for Conrail To $10 Billion
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation raised the ante yesterday for Conrail in the battle to control rail freight in the East by increasing its bid by 10 percent, to $10 billion cash, or about $1.5 billion more than the offer from its rival bidder, the CSX Corporation.

title: Metro DIgest
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A listing of election results on Thursday for the Connecticut General Assembly misstated the vote total for a House candidate in District 28 and percentages for both candidates in that race. According to the Secretary of the State, the incumbent, Paul R. Doyle, a Democrat, won re-election with 7,842 votes, or 70 percent (not 4,362 votes or 57 percent). The total of 3,320 votes for the Republican challenger, Nita Barrabee, represented 30 percent, not 43.

title: ADVANCED TISSUE SHARES FALL ON CONCERNS OVER PRODUCT
description: The stock of Advanced Tissue Sciences Inc. plummeted almost 26 percent yesterday after it was reported that the company's treatment for ulcers in diabetics might not be as effective as previously thought. Eric Hecht, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, issued a report saying he had concerns over the product, called Dermagraft-Ulcer. ''We now believe the Dermagraft-Ulcer trial data is less robust than we had previously believed,'' Mr. Hecht wrote. Advanced Tissue, based in La Jolla, Calif., has said its testing for the product has reached a point where the company is satisfied it can seek Food and Drug Administration approval. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Advanced Tissue fell $3.75, to $10.875.

title: NOVELL STOCK SURGES AMID TAKEOVER SPECULATION
description: Shares of Novell Inc., a provider of networking software products, soared 26 percent amid speculation that the company could be a takeover candidate. Novell shares rose $2.375, to $11.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 13.4 million shares. Some traders said Sun Microsystems Inc. could be a possible buyer. ''Their product is seen as going well with the Java software,'' Paul Foster, senior options strategist at Mercury Trading in Chicago, said. ''The options are clearly up because people think something is in the works.'' Java is Sun's computer language designed to help run software on computer networks. Sun was not immediately available for comment.

title: Eileen C. Dugan, 51, State Assemblywoman
description: Eileen C. Dugan, a Brooklyn Democrat who was elected to her ninth term in the New York State Assembly only on Tuesday, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. Ms. Dugan, who lived in Carroll Gardens, was 51.

title: Black Weekly's Survival Is in Question
description: The City Sun, the weekly newspaper that has been a voice of black nationalism in New York City and an aggressive competitor to the more staid Amsterdam News, has not published in three weeks, raising questions about the paper's future.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Veterans Day

title: Albania's Democracy Has Full Support of U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worst Gulf War Ailment
description: By now there is little doubt that the Pentagon has botched beyond repair its investigation into whether inadvertent exposure to Iraqi chemical weapons might have caused illness among veterans of the Persian Gulf war. That does not mean that chemical weapons will necessarily prove to be a significant cause of the illnesses reported by tens of thousands of gulf war veterans. But it does mean that the Pentagon has lost credibility as an impartial judge of the evidence. There is little choice now but to put a more neutral agency in charge of the inquiry, as a Presidential panel is about to recommend. If the Pentagon is left in control, nobody will believe the verdict.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FOSTER WHEELER CORP., Clinton, N.J., the engineering concern, received a $174.4 million contract from Hebei Electric Power Corp. to supply equipment for a Chinese power plant.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : 'Guilty of Kindness'
description: Sylvia Stayton, a 62-year-old mother of four and grandmother of 10, thought she was doing a good deed. Spotting a policeman about to ticket a car parked at an expired meter in downtown Cincinnati, she slipped a nickel into the slot.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Clinton at His Post-Election News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from a Washington news conference yesterday by President Clinton, who announced the appointment of Erskine B. Bowles to replace Leon E. Panetta as the White House chief of staff, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Hospital Supervisor Is on Trial as Mobster
description: The bespectacled 36-year-old man seated at the defense table had the bearing of a mild-mannered professional. He was a college graduate who had completed much of the work for a master's degree and who was highly regarded in the New York City hospital world as a hard-working, highly competent administrator and supervisor.

title: News at York College
description: To the Editor:

title: Will the MCI Merger Help Consumers?
description: The proposed $20 billion takeover of MCI by British Telecommunications, the largest foreign takeover of an American company, has the potential to create a powerful rival to AT&T, Nynex and other American phone companies -- a big plus for consumers. Yet if improperly handled by regulatory authorities, the merged company could do the opposite, squelching competition. The best outcome would have the merger go through, but only if British authorities impose regulatory protections.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Brooklyn Man Pleads Guilty In a Phony Investment Scheme
description: An investment adviser who prosecutors said financed a lavish life style by swindling relatives, friends and others out of more than $4 million pleaded guilty yesterday to fraud charges in the case.

title: Rape Jury Says It Is Hung; Judge Tells It to Continue
description: After three full days of deliberations, the jurors in the Alex Kelly rape case told a courtroom of anguished relatives this afternoon that they were deadlocked, but the judge asked them to continue trying to reach a verdict. Deliberations are to resume on Tuesday.

title: No Headline
description: ''Hair cutting is like brain surgery: it is not a job for amateurs.''

title: Clinton Calls on G.O.P. for Cooperation
description: Moving swiftly to start his second term, President Clinton said today that he had asked Republican leaders of Congress to meet with him next week to begin negotiations on a plan to balance the budget and on campaign finance restrictions. He also named Erskine B. Bowles, a soft-spoken and politically moderate North Carolina businessman, to fill the critical position of White House chief of staff.

title: Eddie Harris, 62, Saxophonist And Adventurous Experimenter
description: Eddie Harris, a tenor saxophonist whose compositions brought him early popular success, died on Tuesday at the University of Southern California Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 62 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: A Southern Point Man: Erskine Boyce Bowles
description: When President Clinton summoned his Vice President, his chief of staff and his chief of staff-to-be to join him on a small platform in the East Room of the White House today, he gestured to the gold carpet behind him and said, ''No particular order.''

title: A First for 'Three Strikes'
description: The state's ''three strikes'' law was enforced yesterday for the first time when a 43-year-old felon was sentenced to at least 35 years in prison for hitting a man in the back of the head with a lead pipe and robbing him of crack cocaine and $100. Judge Joseph Riva of the Superior Court sentenced the felon, Gregory Oliver, to life without possibility of parole until he has served at least 35 years, said Steven Brizek, a senior assistant Passaic County prosecutor.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Knicks Sputter, Backfire, Hang in There and Win
description: Allan Houston went to the basket as strong as a new-born doe. John Starks lost his adrenaline from the night before and was shooting poorly. And Patrick Ewing was getting pushed around by Stanley Roberts in the middle.

title: A Grin, but Nary a Gloat
description: Fresh from one of the great triumphs of his life, Bill Clinton avoided any suggestion of triumphalism at his post-election news conference today. At times, he sounded almost mellow.

title: Taking Leave of CBS
description: David Kenin is leaving the presidency of CBS Sports humbly, and as a mensch. He is not crying foul over being fired on Monday by Peter Lund, the CBS president who lauded him last summer as someone who is ''realistic'' and ''thoughtful,'' who ''thinks of the future'' and ''has no lack of vision.''

title: The John O'Hara Cult, at Least, Is Faithful
description: Few writers have fallen further or faster in critical esteem than John O'Hara. Once mentioned in the same breath with big guns like Hemingway and Fitzgerald, he took his reputation with him when he died in 1970. But it may be too soon to write him off.

title: Bridge
description: Put two disconsolate women at a bar, and four disconsolate men further along the same bar, and there may be developments. What developed in Rhodes, Greece, 10 days ago was a mixed team.

title: Frank Kurtz, 85, World War II Hero, Dies
description: Frank Kurtz, who ran away from home at 12, set aviation speed records as a teen-ager, became an Olympic high diver in the 1930's and then won fame as a pilot in World War II, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 85.

title: Yeltsin Back in Kremlin
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin left the intensive care unit of a hospital where he underwent a heart bypass operation on Tuesday and returned to the Kremlin hospital today, making it easier for him to resume work.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: The Composer as Portrait Painter
description: Pablo Picasso was very dubious when, on a spring day in Paris in 1940, his friend Virgil Thomson asked if the painter would agree to be the subject of one of Thomson's musical portraits. ''What nonsense,'' Picasso said. ''How do you do a portrait in music?''

title: Despite Many Denials, T.W.A. Missile Rumor Is Back
