description: The persistent rumor that Trans World Airlines Flight 800 was shot down by a United States Navy missile had long ago cooled to a simmer, fed by Internet chatter but vigorously denied by officials. But yesterday, it erupted with a fury after Pierre Salinger, once the press secretary to President John F. Kennedy and a former ABC News correspondent, said in a speech that he had new information on a secret document confirming the rumor.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Monday about Mikel Rouse's opera ''Dennis Cleveland'' misidentified the MacArthur Fellow associated with the production. He is the set designer, John Jesurun, not Mr. Rouse.

title: U. S. INDUSTRIES PLANS TO SELL QPF TO HOOD COMPANIES
description: U. S. Industries said yesterday that it planned to sell its QPF Inc. subsidiary to the Hood Companies for $43.2 million in cash. U. S. Industries, based in Iselin, N.J., said the subsidiary makes polypropylene films and has offices and a factory in Streamwood, Ill. Hood is a privately held group of companies based in Hattiesburg, Miss. U. S. Industries is an industrial management corporation that was spun off by Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate, in early 1995.

title: Deals Looming To Establish U.S. Ventures In Cash Cards
description: Three groups of banks and credit card companies are racing to complete deals in the next few weeks involving so-called smart cards -- cards embedded with microchips that can store electronic cash and other data.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing

title: Veteran Seeks Corps Spirit In Drug Battle
description: VETERANS DAY gives him a taste of the honor he once felt in wearing a military uniform, of being part of something unique and elite. On a day that some New Yorkers remember only for not having to move their cars, he'll pause to remember troops who moved overseas to places like Bosnia and Saudi Arabia.

title: Guard Slain at Restaurant
description: A security guard at a McDonald's restaurant in Queens was shot and killed last night, the police said.

title: For Japan's Auto Makers, Windfall From Yen
description: A sharp fall in the value of the yen in the last year has been providing an earnings windfall to Japan's major automobile companies.

title: An Adirondack Mountain Mood and a Few Dubious Activities
description: It is 6 A.M., still dark. Here and there are the shadows of looming boulders and big trees. A piece of glass crunches under a shoe. The eastern sky is lightening; birds are suddenly, gloriously, tweeting.

title: Broken Rail And a Fire Halt Trains In Queens
description: The fates frowned on Queens commuters yesterday morning, when an unlikely series of coincidences brought service on one of the city's busiest subway routes to a complete halt at rush hour.

title: President Makes It Official: He May Send More Troops to Bosnia Next Year
description: President Clinton said today that he was considering sending more American troops to Bosnia next year as part of a follow-on force to keep the peace, acknowledging something his aides have said for weeks.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Lower in Shortened Session
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved lower in a shortened session yesterday, as investors took profits following Thursday's rally.

title: Pedestrian Malls Can, and Do, Survive
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Backs Managed Care
description: New Jersey's Medicaid recipients prefer mandatory managed care to the fee-for-service program under which the state used to reimburse doctors and hospitals, the Department of Human Services said yesterday.

title: A Modern Morality Play, In 12 Rounds
description: SHORTLY before Mike Tyson was released from prison, Evander Holyfield sat at a dinner table and speculated about a hypothetical fight with the former heavyweight champion. He was eager, and he scoffed at the notion that Tyson would be as tough coming out of prison as he was going in. ''When people talk about how ferocious he is, they're talking about the pulverizing puncher who knocked everybody out,'' Holyfield said, reminding his guests that Tyson was beginning to lose some of his skills even before he went into prison.

title: HONG KONG
description: Lan Kwai Fong is definitely one of the areas to go in Hong Kong if you're young, trendy and primed for an expensive night on the town. But it's equally appealing to those mortals who are merely seeking a good meal in pleasant surroundings.

title: Highly Illogical
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art of Turning That Old Monet Into New Money
description: Q. I recently inherited an early 20th century painting that I am told may be valuable enough to sell through a gallery or at auction. What should I do?

title: Faith Skolnik, Marc Ackerman
description: Faith Ellen Skolnik, the daughter of Sonia and Joseph Skolnik of North Merrick, L.I., was married last evening to Marc Edward Ackerman, a son of Doris and Allan Ackerman of Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Medicaid Ride Program For Disabled Is Criticized
description: New York State consumes more than a quarter of the $1 billion spent annually across the nation to provide disabled Medicaid recipients with transportation to doctors' offices, hospitals and clinics, a figure that many politicians and health care experts believe reflects mismanagement in the state's program.

title: Chinese Muslims Recount Their Days of Terror
description: Guardedly at first, the young Muslim farmer recounted a story many tell here, of how a local Communist Party official skinned his victims alive as part of a campaign of terror to overthrow the leader of a long and rebellious line of Sufi Muslims who inhabit these hills in northwestern China.

title: The Army Investigates Rape
description: The United States Army clearly has a serious problem at the Aberdeen Proving Ground's Ordnance Center in Maryland. In September a female student at the center, which trains soldiers in equipment maintenance, complained to a superior about sexual harassment. Since then at least 17 more female soldiers have told investigators they were raped or sexually harassed. So far, investigators have charged five soldiers, including a company commander with rape and a drill instructor with multiple rapes.

title: Brown Is All Alone in Second Place
description: Brown 31, Harvard 7

title: Right-to-Play Turf War: Kids vs. Dogs
description: It's not much to look at: an empty, blacktopped space next to Public School 234 in TriBeCa. But the 9,000-square-foot lot on Chambers Street is at the center of an intense conflict between school and community board officials, who have permission to use it as a playground, and local dog owners, who have been using it to exercise their pets.

title: Among the Losers of '96 Were Campaign 'Truths'
description: The Campaign of 1996 may not be remembered for its suspense, or for reshaping the Government. It may hardly be remembered at all.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 20 about New Mexico spas mistranslated the Spanish phrase ''Ojo Caliente.'' In context, it meant hot spring, not hot eye.

title: LIABILITY HOUSE
description: In your Sunday item ''Liability House'' (Oct. 20) you identify Alpha Delta as ''the frat whose early-60's incarnation inspired the movie 'Animal House.' '' Perhaps you are unaware that another Dartmouth fraternity, Bones Gate, also claims this distinction. Truly, we are the most feared and trouble-plagued house on campus.

title: Doffing Restraint for a Chance to Smolder
description: KRISTIN SCOTT THOMAS sexy? You're joking!'' The aristocratic-looking English actress with the screen image of a frustrated spinster remembers her shock at realizing what was expected of her in her next movie. ''The thought of playing someone who was meant to be attractive and desirable totally terrified me,'' she recalled. ''It dawned on me late in the day, and I got a complete attack of the panics.''

title: Should Health Care Come With a Warranty?
description: THERE's a new twist in the baby-making business, and it comes with a money-back guarantee. In a move that has some doctors up in arms, fertility clinics in Minnesota and California are offering to guarantee that their patients will have babies -- or they'll get their money back.

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: DeParle argues that Congress's failure to add new rent subsidies this year marks the end of the Federal commitment to making housing affordable for poor Americans.

title: At Volkswagen, the Past Isn't Pretty
description: Volkswagen wanted to be open about its Nazi past -- here, Hitler speaks at the opening ceremony of a factory in Lower Saxony in 1938 -- so it commissioned an official history. The book is out, and the company may regret it, since some chapters describe the auto maker's use of slave labor. (Associated Press)

title: The Accountant Is a Terrorist
description: East Jerusalem was beginning to stir. Arab women in embroidered, ankle-length dresses balanced baskets of figs and grapes atop their heads on their way to market stalls inside the walls of the Old City. Lumbering delivery trucks on Salah-a-Din Street belched diesel fumes and forced boys with pushcarts to the curb in front of the nondescript Lawrence Hotel. Graffiti in Arabic script, blood red on the mud-brown brick of the hotel's entrance, declared, ''Yes to an independent Palestinian State.''

title: Tangy Sauces With Marinara as Base
description: A SIMPLE tomato sauce, often marinara bolstered with garlic and basil, is likely to be the partner selected most frequently for pasta. But there are some other favorites coming on the scene, in restaurants, cookbooks and on supermarket shelves. These other sauces, notably puttanesca, amatriciana, arrabbiata and fra diavolo, offer extra flavor from garlic, hot peppers and the salty tang of olives and capers. But using marinara as the point of departure, they are all easily made.

title: Baywatch
description: LAST week the state's voters resoundingly approved a bond issue that will raise $300 million for clean water projects, including $185 million to dredge the polluted mud that clogs the shipping channels in New York Harbor.

title: Making Much of Positive Eye Appeal
description: GREENWICH'S short-lived Speakeazy has given way to a marvelous looking new restaurant, Cafe Patina on Greenwich Avenue, a street that seems able to accommodate an ever-expanding number of restaurants, many of them good, even very good.

title: Karen Kalista And Brian J. Vinci
description: Karen Ann Kalista, a daughter of Arlene and Howard C. Kalista of Farmingville, L.I., was married yesterday to Brian John Vinci, a son of Dorothy and Joseph Vinci of Rochester, N.Y. The Rev. Ronald E. Gaesser, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Sage Chapel on the campus of Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Drug War Forces Rio To Dodge Its Bullets
description: The victims were standing at bus stops, attending university classes, chatting with friends on a balmy night or watching a circus. They have included a baby in his father's arms, children playing in front of their houses and a visitor to the Government tourist agency. Some of them have the most fashionable addresses in the city.

title: Wisdom of the Ancestor
description: GRANDMOTHER'S PIGEONBy Louise Erdrich. Illustrated by Jim LaMarche.Unpaged. New York:Hyperion Books for Children.$15.95. (All ages)

title: A Truly Superior City
description: Melbourne,'' a third-generation Melburnian said recently, ''was descended upon and settled by a group of scamps and rascals.'' (Among them was English literature's most enchanting ne'er-do-well, Charles Dickens's Wilkins Micawber, who became -- unlikely as it may seem -- a magistrate.)

title: Duuuuudes! The Audit.
description: he Princeton Review's guide to colleges recently crowned Florida State University the No. 1 party school in the country -- but, achingly, neglected to explain what that means. To find out, we sent a correspondent down to Tallahassee on a big game day (against Clemson), teaming him up with two of the hardest-partying brothers from Alpha Tau Omega, an uber-hard-partying fraternity. Here's a report from Inside the Belly of the Bluto.

title: Didn't Like the '96 Campaign? Don't Look for Change in '97
description: New Jersey gets a bad rap for enough nasty things. Governor Whitman does not want to add political campaigns to the list.

title: Guam, a Spoil of War, Seeks More Autonomy
description: The beaches on this jewel of a Pacific island are like powdered milk, but it is American milk, and the people here are American citizens who every four years are the first ones to go to the polls to cast ballots in the Presidential election.

title: Laurie A. Collins, Kevin Thomas
description: Laurie Ann Collins, the daughter of Jacqueline and LeRoy Collins of Cedarhurst, L.I., is to be married today to Kevin Thomas, the son of the late Gloria B. Thomas. The Rev. Dr. Earle Pratt will perform the ceremony at Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I.

title: Tickets on Sale! But Is the Show a Dud?
description: THE Ticketmaster Group is about to make an offer that the company hopes will become one of the hottest tickets in town -- shares of its own stock. But unlike a World Series game or a Hootie and the Blowfish concert, this show may not be worth waiting in line for.

title: Making a Mark
description: Jerry G. Watts is the author of ''Heroism and the Black Intellectual: Ralph Ellison, Politics, and Afro-American Intellectual Life.''

title: Railroaded
description: BAD LAND

title: A Graceful Hop From State to Stage
description: TWO years ago, Pauline Kezer pirouetted out of public office and into the arts. But as the former Secretary of State marks the completion of her first year as chief executive officer of the Hartford Ballet, she has proved she is not that far removed from the political mindset.

title: A Dowling Doctoral Program Stirs Other L.I. Universities
description: DOWLING College is circulating a pamphlet about a doctoral program in educational administration even though the state has not approved the program.

title: In White Plains, Comfort Food of Cuba
description: WE love returning to this old favorite for another taste of the mellow native dishes of Cuba. As cold weather approaches, it is a comfort to remember that few comestibles can warm body and soul quicker than a bowl of flavor-packed black bean soup (with lots of bread for sopping the thick rich liquid). But in this trim little storefront with its peach walls, natural woods and seductive travel posters, diners can and should linger for more nourishment than soup.

title: A Smoker's Life
description: IT happened on a cold Wednesday in February. I remember it clearly. I walked in the door, threw my jacket and book bag on the couch, and went to get a glass of milk. Hey, it does a body good. When I walked into the living room, my mom stopped me and gave me one of those knowing mom looks -- the ones that make your heart sink because you thought she found out something you didn't want her to know. But this time it was different. Her words were so far from what I expected to hear that I could barely listen.

title: Dr. King's Nice Guy
description: Robert Weisbrot, a professor of history at Colby College in Maine, is the author of ''Freedom Bound: A History of America's Civil Rights Movement.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CHILDHOOD PLAY

title: A 'Phantom' Is Driven By Story and Songs
description: Such is the doleful state of theater in Westchester that a revival of ''Phantom'' -- yes, the other ''Phantom,'' not the Andrew Lloyd Webber version, which is nearing its ninth anniversary on Broadway -- is the only professional show in town.

title: The Maid
description: THE RIVER BEYOND THE WORLD

title: Hollywood Puts Out a Welcome Mat in Cyberspace
description: YOU READ THE BOOK. YOU saw the animated film. You bought the cute little backpacks and the spotted shelf paper. And now you've witnessed the live-action remake with its dozens of digital doglets. What's left to experience? How about ''101 Dalmatians'' the Web site?

title: Stained-Glass Windows Restored in Brooklyn
description: Correction Appended

title: Mortal Coils
description: PRIVILEGED HANDSA Scientific Life.By Geerat Vermeij.Illustrated. 297 pp. New York:W. H. Freeman & Company. $23.95.

title: ROME
description: The historic and moral heart of gastronomic Rome is the Testaccio quarter, bounded by the Tiber, the elegant Aventine Hill and a line formed by the Pyramid of Cestius, the Protestant Cemetery, Monte Testaccio (a hill of ancient pot shards) and the old slaughterhouse, or mattatoio. Many popular Roman recipes were invented here, and Testaccio today attracts not only devotees of unreconstructed cucina romana, but also more eclectic food lovers.

title: Using Some Hidden Storage Space
description: AFTER living in the same home for years, homeowners amass a collection of clothes, books, papers, etc., and they find that there doesn't seem to be enough room to store everything. Fortunately, the average home has many unused voids that can be converted for storage. Usually the potential space must be fitted with shelves, cabinets or hangers to convert it to a usable and efficient storage area.

title: Hunting for Ducks, and Preservation, in the Wetlands
description: Walking through a field of thick grass taller than you are is a novel experience at any time, but ploughing through one in the lavender hour before dawn while seated in a tiny boat called a punt is downright surreal. Welcome to the habitat of the duck, and the domain of the duck hunter. Welcome to the rich, alluvial world in which a punt is not a kick but a boat, wigeon is not a bizarre British card game but a species of duck, and a yellow lab is not an overweight tawny dog forced to wear a red bandana but a lean, working retriever.

title: Giving Credit To John Lindsay
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa J. Oertel And Duke Reich
description: Lisa Jean Oertel, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. R. David Oertel of Baldwinsville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Kurt Reich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel O. Reich of Brooklyn. The bride's father, the pastor of the Baldwinsville United Methodist Church, performed the ceremony at the University United Methodist Church in Syracuse.

title: Whalers and Capitals Trade
description: Center ANDREI NIKOLISHIN was traded by the Hartford Whalers to the Washington Capitals yesterday for defenseman CURTIS LESCHYSHYN.

title: Julie Werner And Paul Lane
description: Julie Lynn Werner and Paul Gerard Lane were married last evening. Cantor Harold L. Levy officiated with Msgr. John J. Enzler at the Metropolitan Club in Washington.

title: A Playground Not All Fun and Games
description: A GREEN van pulled up to Rowland Park at Jennings Beach in Fairfield recently and out stepped the entire basketball team from nearby Sacred Heart University. Dave Bike, the coach, led 6-foot-6 Rod Tuppin, a senior from Danville, Md., and 6-foot-4 Jermaine Johnson, a junior from Long Island, and a line of teammates onto the grassy knoll as if they were heading for center court.

title: Massage Therapy Gains Sign of Acceptance
description: WHEN Loretta Filippelli of Holtsville received her diploma in massage therapy from the New Center for Wholistic Health Education and Research and passed the state examination to become a licensed massage therapist, she never expected a college degree, too.

title: Q. & A.
description: Co-op Loan And Owner Occupancy

title: O'Rourke Proposes No New Taxes
description: WESTCHESTER County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke says his proposed 1997 budget, which will be released this week, calls for no increase in property taxes, cuts a few hundred jobs, mainly at the County Medical Center, and will not lead to a major curtailment of county programs, although it will require some privatization.

title: Collision Course: Cars and Shoppers
description: In a typical year, 100 million pedestrians, the equivalent of the population of Dallas 100 times over, try to squeeze through the eight blocks surrounding Herald Square, according to the 34th Street Partnership, the local business improvement district.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Electoral College misstated the month in which electors cast their votes. It is December, not January. The article also misstated the formula for apportioning electoral votes. In most states, they go to the candidate who wins a plurality of the popular vote; a majority is not needed.

title: Serena's Song Loses Distaff, But Is Top on Earnings' List
description: Serena's Song, racing for the 15th time this year and the 38th time in three years, lost the Churchill Downs Distaff to the 30-1 long shot Fast Catch yesterday by three-quarters of a length. But she still won $45,240 for her fourth straight second-place finish and passed Dance Smartly as the richest filly in history.

title: Richard Duffin, 87, Researcher In Many Areas of Mathematics
description: Richard J. Duffin, a mathematician who made important contributions in several areas of his field, died on Oct. 29 at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 87.

title: Wise Guys
description: The View from Saturday

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: DeParle describes the $66 billion in mortgage-interest and real-estate tax deductions taken each year as ''Government spending.'' In so doing, he makes it clear that he supports the philosophy that everything earned by a nation's citizens belongs to the Government and that if a worker is allowed to keep any of his earnings to pay mortgage interest or whatever, that amount is viewed as a Government grant.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Oct. 27 about a new Koo Koo Roo restaurant in Bayside, Queens, referred incorrectly to the company's 27 stores. They are owned by Koo Koo Roo; they are not franchises.

title: Chechen Separatists in Istanbul Set Up Shadow State
description: In a three-story villa in the wooded heights above the Bosporus, a small group of men in suits and ties were busy working the telephones to a dozen world capitals, trying to set up peace conferences and commercial deals.

title: Vatican Rebuffs Unicef, Widening a Family Planning Dispute
description: The Vatican decided this week to withhold a symbolic annual contribution to Unicef, reopening a debate among American Catholics about the role of international organizations in population and family planning projects. The Vatican says the United Nations children's agency has become an advocate of birth control.

title: Grown-Up Stories
description: THE ABRACADABRA KID

title: Hurricane Strength
description: There is no doubt about what force has become dominant in the American stock market.

title: Clarke Brinckerhoff, 76, Leader Of Drive to Care for the Retarded
description: Clarke Brinckerhoff, a Connecticut lawyer who, exasperated by the lack of adequate public services for his daughter, founded the state's first parent advocacy group for the retarded, died on Nov. 2 at the University of Connecticut Medical Center. He was 76 and lived in West Hartford.

title: BIBLE DISCUSSION GROUP
description: Bill Moyers and Burton L. Visotzky are to be commended for taking the Bible off its pedestal and making it accessible (''In the Beginning There Was a Bible Discussion Group. And Then PBS Came Calling,'' by Rodger Kamenetz, Oct. 20). But if biblical heroes are cut down to gutter size -- as Rabbi Visotzky does when he uses the word ''pimping'' to describe an episode in Abraham's life and calls Genesis ''an ugly little soap opera'' -- why go to the Bible for religious inspiration? ''The Brothers Karamazov'' and ''Moby Dick'' are just as morally edifying and may be of even greater literary value.

title: The Job Switch of Your Dreams
description: Election Day produced some involuntary career changes. If you were voluntarily changing careers, what would your dream job be, and why?

title: Heather Lewisohn And Philip Barton
description: Heather Haley Lewisohn, the daughter of Sandra Saine Bishop of Huntersville, N.C., and Richard Lewisohn 3d of New York, was married yesterday to Philip Newell Barton, a son of Margaret Anna Rose of Greensboro, N.C., and Jon H. Barton Sr., of Marietta, Ga. The Rev. William P. Wood performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Charlotte, N.C.

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: I was surprised that DeParle attacked mortgage-interest and property-tax deductions. These are two of the few tax shelters that the hard-working middle class enjoys. Eliminating these deductions for an already overtaxed and overburdened middle class will only cause more to fall below the poverty line.

title: Pout or Shout, They're Coming to Town, in Force
description: LISTEN TO THE SOUND OF HOLIDAY CHEER IN Hollywood.

title: I Wanna Be Like Ben
description: Is the secret to happiness found inside a leather-bound organizer book invented by two former Mormon missionaries?

title: College Chief Spurns Foes Of Professor
description: Three months after a gentile professor resigned as chairman of the Queens College Jewish Studies Program after complaints from Jewish critics, the college president has named the professor and two of his backers to lead the department temporarily.

title: Cell Development Shows Evolutionary Pattern
description: To the Editor:

title: Nina Carr, Scott A. Ackerman
description: Christina Elizabeth Carr, the daughter of Katherine and Thomas Carr of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Alan Ackerman, the son of Susan Rains of West Orange, N.J., and Joel Ackerman of New York. The Rev. John A. Boehn ing performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. Rabbi Charles D. Lippmann took part in the service.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Edge of the Unknown101 Things You Don't Know About Science and No One Else Does Either.By James Trefil.Houghton Mifflin, $23.

title: A Ride in the Woods, a Way of Life
description: MY horse and I seem to be standing on a porcelain dinner plate under an inverted sponge-wear bowl. It is late winter morning, with Venus and a fingernail moon still with us. I feed my horse a warm mash on these cold days; a mix of apples, bran and molasses, cooked on a stovetop. He always whinnies when he recognizes his special bucket, and kicks it when the mash is too hot.

title: Corinne Myller, Joseph Caramanico
description: Corinne Myller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Myller of New York, was married yesterday to Joseph Salvatore Caramanico, a son of Frederick A. Caramanico of Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Frances K. Caramanico. The Rev. Emmanuel Faraone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: U.S. Leaves Its Mark On Politics In Britain
description: The leading candidate is talkative and telegenic, he likes rock music, and his wife is a lawyer with a lucrative private practice. He promises a ''covenant'' with the public in a tub-thumping style that has been likened to revival-meeting preaching, and he has made a concerted election-season move to the middle, co-opting positions of the more conservative rival party.

title: The West Must Avert Disaster in Zaire
description: As the last humanitarian aid vehicle drove out of Goma, Zaire, and into Rwanda on Nov. 2, the only authority at the border was a lone security officer from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Every other relief worker, as well as Zairian authorities, had left town after Zairian rebels supported by the Rwandan Patriotic Army took over the last big city in eastern Zaire.

title: Take the DARE
description: NERDS AND DORKS and doofuses may come and go, but jerks lurch resolutely on.

title: Forget the Gender Gap. What About the Smoker Gap?
description: The voters have spoken. And so have the experts; they delved into exit polls to explain why more women voted for Bill Clinton and why the High Plains went for Bob Dole.

title: The Point Behind Those Pineapples
description: IN cast iron and concrete, floral forms (as in flora and fauna) have been extending messages of welcome and renewal to New Yorkers for centuries.

title: Quietly, Top Democrats Press Hevesi to Challenge the Mayor
description: For months, Democrats from divergent corners of New York City have called or paid visits to the man they hope to persuade to run for Mayor next year. Although their efforts have been quiet, with few of these politicians even wishing to discuss their overtures publicly, the courting of Alan G. Hevesi is very much under way.

title: Terry L. Steiner, Roger R. Smith
description: Terry Lynne Steiner, a distributor of films and television programs, and Roger R. Smith, an independent film and television producer, were married yesterday in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at Sunningdale Country Club.

title: Still Overwhelming
description: It is 41 years since Sir John Pope-Hennessy, in the first of what would become a three-volume study, set out to persuade scholars to pay as much attention to Italian sculpture as they did to painting. That volume covered the Gothic period. Three years later, in 1958, came the second, on the 15th-century Renaissance, and in 1963 the third, on sculptors from Michelangelo to Bernini. He certainly succeeded: by now a second generation of scholars has followed his call and our understanding of this art changes almost daily. So this great book has had to change as well. As early as 1970 Pope-Hennessy began extensive revisions that continued through three editions. And when he died in October 1994, he had just completed work on the fourth edition of what he still modestly called AN INTRODUCTION TO ITALIAN SCULPTURE (Phaidon, three volumes, slip-cased, $345). The publisher has redesigned it, supplying hundreds of new spectacular black-and-white photographs and integrating them more closely with the text than they ever have been. Not that any illustration could be as eloquent as Pope-Hennessy. He is so restrained and so precise that the power of his emotions catches a reader by surprise. No book on art is more intelligent, more learned and unpretentious, or more infused with passion; it is a tremendously exciting education in art, history, society, the advancement of thought and craft -- in a word, in civilization. And few art books are as engagingly personal. Reading it is like listening to a good friend, who happens to be the most sensitive student of Italian art in this century, share his deepest responses to these glorious works and their creators. At times this can be overwhelming. It is hard to imagine an attentive reader who could get through the section on Donatello, for instance, without having to walk away from it now and then to regain composure. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: Nibble, Nibble, Nibble
description: PIES, pies, pies. That's all I thought about last Thanksgiving, and I'm thinking about them now, too. This year, I'm going to buy mine at Hacklebarney Farm in Chester. First on my list are the traditional lattice- topped and apple crumb; next, the velvety and perfectly spiced pumpkin, and finally, the walnut chocolate pie, which is really a great chocolate chip cookie set in a ton of butter that passes for crust. Since your guests will probably be too full to finish even a sliver, I would recommend freezing the leftovers in bite-size hunks and nibbling on the single morsels -- like candy -- whenever the urge strikes. And it will, often. This is really a one-of-a-kind pie.

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: Your article illustrates the awful conditions in which many must live and points out the Federal Government's abdication in housing the poor. The main reason for the Federal retreat in housing is the prohibitively high cost of constructing and maintaining affordable units. While a poor family may receive as much as $3,000 in food stamps and $6,000 in Medicaid each year, the cost of Federal housing is closer to $100,000 per unit, not including maintenance.

title: Clinton Tide On L.I. Misses Incumbents
description: FOR the first time since 1964, Long Island voters backed a Democrat for President last week and elected Carolyn McCarthy, who was running as a Democrat, in the heavily Republican 4th Congressional District.

title: Rutgers Self-Destructs Early and Often
description: A comedy of early errors today by Rutgers led to a 55-14 West Virginia rout, the Scarlet Knights' worst home loss in 23 years.

title: N.C.A.A. Shouldn't Play High School Principal
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Rules Squeezing Independent Contractors
description: LINDA LUTHER posts her credentials as a software engineer on an electronic bulletin board. In the past, the notices often led to temporary assignments at California software companies.

title: McHenry Tichenor, 98, Tejano Music's Herald
description: McHenry Tichenor, who built a radio empire that spread Tejano music from its Texas cradle to the rest of the country, died on Oct. 24 at his home in La Feria, near Harlingen, by the Mexican border. He was 98.

title: The Patriots' Bledsoe's Air Mail Is Quickly Reaching Its Destination
description: For most of his coaching career in pro football, Bill Parcells has believed that a quarterback has two main functions:

title: Moynihan on Moynihan
description: MILES TO GOA Personal History of Social Policy.By Daniel Patrick Moynihan.245 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:Harvard University Press. $22.95.

title: Granet's Roman Works At American Academy
description: The American Academy in Rome is mounting an important exhibit of views of Rome by the Provencal painter Francois-Marius Granet through Jan. 12. It is the first exhibition in Italy of Granet's Roman oil sketches and paintings, which were created during his long, unbroken stay in Rome from 1802 to 1824, before Rome became the capital of Italy, when classical monuments were covered in vines and wildflowers and the city was still abundantly dotted with fields and gardens.

title: Weathers Runs All Over Nazareth in the Playoffs
description: C.H.S.F.L.

title: TOKYO
description: Twice a day the no-name streets and narrow alleys near Nihonbashi, one of Tokyo's oldest business districts, fill with hungry folk seeking good food at affordable prices. At noon, office workers, managers and well-heeled matrons chitchat, but don't dawdle, over luncheon specials. At night, groups of business buddies linger over drinks. Catering to the weekday hordes, more than a hundred restaurants and pubs nestled among, wedged between and stacked above and below the area's low-rise office buildings and stores serve simple, filling fare.

title: Sarah Burks, Jeffrey Schmalz
description: Sarah Davis Burks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Burks of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey William Schmalz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leigh W. Schmalz of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Wesley Wubbenhorst performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J.

title: Warming Trend
description: It does not take long for the mid-autumn nip in the air to nip the fingers, and gloves, and many stores are featuring pre-Christmas sales on glovs. ''Given that we had such a harsh winter and the April snow is not that distant a memory,'' said Susan Silverstein, retail analyst at Gruntal & Company in Manhattan, ''I would suspect consumers at the first dip in the mercury to rush out to protect themselves, whether it's gloves, hats, scarves or even electric blankets.'' Here are prices of different grades of gloves at stores around the city: KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: The 'Mayor' Who Presides Over Four Corners in Jersey City
description: At the intersection of Washington and Grand Streets in Jersey City lies the Paulus Hook Park. The one-acre park, which was established in the late 1700's, has a community bulletin board, historical markers and a concrete monument commemorating the Revolutionary War Battle of Paulus Hook. Red, white and blue benches, garbage cans and signposts complete the patriotic theme. Although the park officially occupies all four corners, the southwest corner is fenced off and used as a playground by Public School 16.

title: When Older and Younger Find Common Ground
description: MUCH as he would like to, Bill Stack can't throw a football around with Rayon Samuels. Rayon, at the age of 11 is more than six decades younger than Mr. Stack, who captained the Yale football team in 1939 and played on the same Eli teams as Heisman Trophy winners Larry Kelley and Clint Frank. Arthritis now makes it impossible for Mr. Stack to play football, so he and Rayon settled in for a game of checkers on an early autumn morning at the Ponus Middle School in Norwalk.

title: In Precious Days, Chicago Embraces a Cardinal Who Reached Out
description: No man has shaped the National Conference of Catholic Bishops more than its onetime General Secretary and later President, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago. But when the conference opens its fall meeting in Washington next Monday, he will not be there.

title: MINIVAN CRISIS
description: Perhaps driving a minivan is the ultimate suburban cliche in Rhode Island, where Ann Hood lives (Lives: ''Minivan Crisis,'' Oct. 20). But drop the kids off at any school in the New Jersey suburbs and your brain will freeze at the sight of the endless parade of four-wheel-drive vehicles. It's an interesting phenomenon that these gas guzzlers are so popular with the same population that spent its youth fretting over fossil-fuel depletion and planetary well-being.

title: DIRTY LOOKS
description: I'm not offended when a woman at the next table in a restaurant touches up her makeup. I simply take the opportunity to freshen up with my pocket electric razor and after-shave lotion.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: An Owner of a Queens Bar Is Slain and Mutilated
description: The mutilated body of a man found Friday in a wooded area of Queens along the Belt Parkway has been identified as that of an owner of a Forest Hills bar that, law enforcement officials say, is frequented by young men seeking to join the ranks of organized crime.

title: Karen J. Klein, David S. Schafran
description: Karen Joy Klein, a daughter of Marilyn and Richard Klein of La Jolla, Calif., was married last evening to David Spencer Schafran, the son of Lynn and Larry Schafran of New York. Rabbi Isidoro Aizenberg performed the ceremony at the Renaissance Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: Joanne Ferenczi, John Mastrangelo
description: Joanne Ferenczi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Joseph Ferenczi of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to John J. Mastrangelo, a son Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mastrangelo of South Orange, N.J. The Rev. John McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Portuguese Restaurant With Special Breads
description: THE daily newspaper at Portugalia, the month-old bakery and cafe in Mineola, is Publico, from Lisbon. The modest Portugalia itself could well be from there. Its traditional azulejo blue tile walls with pastoral and sea scenes, Louca pottery and Portuguese coffees evoke images of the capital's coffee houses.

title: The Future Of Roseland
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Is Rejected On Campaign Funds
description: The Justice Department has rejected a request for an independent prosecutor to investigate possible criminal violations of campaign finance laws by the Democratic and Republican Presidential campaigns.

title: No Headline
description: ''If I have any moral authority -- and I say 'if' -- moral authority doesn't solve world problems.''

title: The Clams Have a Problem; Is There a Solution?
description: Though Barnegat Bay is getting cleaner every year, its clam population continues to decline.

title: A Feast for All the Senses and Inspirations for Dinner Too
description: Entering this carvernous market on a gray fall day is like stepping into ''The Wizard of Oz'' the moment the film shifts from black and white to color: suddenly everything around you is bright, enticing and green.

title: California Town Hopes Eye-Catching Murals Will Put It on Map
description: This tumbleweed town that took its name from an act of nature has come up with a plan to revitalize itself with man-made creations. City leaders want to make Twentynine Palms the ''Mural Capital of America.''

title: 'Puffbacks' in Heating Systems Spread Smoke and Soot Damage
description: WHEN Irene Towbin's housewatcher called her one day last January to say there was black smoke in her East Hampton house, he said the oil burner people thought they found the source of the problem in one of her two furnaces and corrected it.

title: Arthur the Aardvark Accepts a Mission
description: ''I'M in very heady company here: 'Sesame Street,' 'Mr. Rogers,' 'Zoom,' '' said Marc Brown, the children's book author and illustrator. ''It's quite a responsibility, joining this group.''

title: LONESOME BUFF
description: 'There've been a few calls, but no chiefs or anything,'' says Daniel Shirek, a farmer in Michigan, N.D., and the proud owner of a four-month-old female albino buffalo calf. Shriek is wondering why his snowy critter doesn't seem to rate. According to ancient prophecy attributed to the Lakota Sioux, North American Indians will rise again after the birth of a white buffalo. Such an animal (named Miracle) appeared two years ago in Janesville, Wis., and inspired international coverage and pilgrimages by tens of thousands of seekers. But as Shirek pointedly notes, Miracle later turned brown.

title: Susan Vissers, Anthony C. Lisa 2d
description: Susan Elisabeth Vissers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Frank Vissers of Ellicott City, Md., was married yesterday to Anthony Carl Lisa 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lisa of North Providence, R.I. The Rev. John Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Joseph's Monastery Church in Baltimore.

title: Fat Joe: Hip-Hop Celebrity Faithful to Old Neighborhood
description: There's no mistaking Fat Joe, the hip-hop artist, as he makes his way through the crowded streets of Melrose. At 6 feet 2 inches and 300 pounds, he is far from demure. Bus drivers honk and teen-agers in baggy jeans and hiking boots call his name.

title: A Half-Dozen Ways to Be a Hero at Once by Just Getting the Job Done Without Bluster
description: Correction Appended

title: A Chilling Change in the Contraband Being Seized at Borders
description: Since this summer, a new contraband has been running second only to marijuana in the Customs seizures made here on the Mexican border. It is more profitable than cocaine by some estimates, believed to be bigger business these days than gun-running, and illegal to import for a futuristic reason: it harms the planet.

title: Vuko Tashkovich, Architect And a Builder, Is Dead at 58
description: Vuko Tashkovich, a Westchester architect and builder whose residential designs embraced the sights and styles of his native region of Macedonia, died on Nov. 2 at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 58.

title: Tangy Pasta Sauces With a Marinara Base
description: A SIMPLE tomato sauce, often marinara bolstered with garlic and basil, is likely to be the partner most frequently selected for pasta. But some other favorites are coming on the scene in restaurants, cookbooks and supermarkets.

title: Battle of the Hollywood Hideaways Pits a Legend Against Luxury
description: THE hotel you wanted to open in SoHo has been delayed for years, and faster-stepping competitors have moved into the neighborhood. And next month, your shabby-yet-chic Hollywood hotel will get a new and not necessarily friendly neighbor run by Ian Schrager, who made his reputation at Studio 54 in Manhattan and is now a proprietor of the Royalton and Paramount hotels.

title: Supper Club With Staying Power
description: IT is late Friday night on East Third Street between Avenues A and B. A few steps from where drug dealers are hawking their merchandise, women in short black skirts stand in line with men who are wearing the official preppy uniform: blue blazers and khakis.

title: Robin Weintraub, Alex LaBorwit
description: Robin Lee Weintraub, a daughter of Sue Weintraub of Washington and the late Dr. Robert E. Weintraub, is to be married today to Alex Marc LaBorwit, the son of Phyllis and Dr. Louis LaBorwit of Bowie, Md. Rabbi Michael Kramer is to officiate at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: A Hero to His Biographer
description: WALLACE STEGNER

title: By Their Walk Shall You Know Them
description: From the hustler's strut to the Wall Streeter's swagger, the particular stride indigenous to each species of New Yorker is a portal of discovery into their world.

title: 'Stars Were Always on His Mind'
description: STARRY MESSENGER

title: New Rule on Research Violates Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Scholars Ask Court to Backtrack, Shutting Floodgates on Political Spending
description: A group of prominent constitutional scholars has begun a campaign to get the Supreme Court to overturn a 20-year-old landmark decision that has allowed unlimited amounts of money to flow into political races.

title: A Brawl Between a Couple of Patsy's
description: If this were not a city known for its pizza and if big money were not involved, the haggling over the name of a pizzeria would have been a mere family squabble.

title: Where the Memories Outnumber the Men
description: One thing could be said for this day. At least Fred Hansen didn't know the guy now resting in a box.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Postings column of the Real Estate section today, about the restoration of stained-glass windows at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights, misspells the surname of the artist who designed them. He was William Jay Bolton, not Boulton.

title: The Impossible Dream Team
description: American Tragedy

title: Tanzania Weighs Price of Popularity
description: CAN a country have too many tourists? Tanzania is beginning to think so.

title: For Government Workers, Safer Roads to Retirement
description: FOR years, many government workers have put their money into tax-deferred retirement plans that were less secure and more limited than the plans of many private-sector workers.

title: Chileans Are Prosecuted For Criticizing Officials
description: Two decades ago, Gladys Marin was living in exile when Gen. Augusto Pinochet's secret police abducted her husband, Jorge Munoz, a Communist leader who was never seen again and is presumed to be dead.

title: Aid to Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Chance at Site of Notorious Father Panik Village
description: IT has been a year since Michael and Juan Cintron took over the ownership of their father's 11-year-old grocery on Pembroke Street in East Bridgeport. ''Business is not good now,'' said Michael Cintron. ''There are not enough jobs, and I can't compete with the big supermarkets four or five blocks away.''

title: The Lost Man of Rock-and-Roll
description: IT IS JUST AFTER NOON HERE on an October Saturday. Carl Perkins, composer of the song ''Blue Suede Shoes'' and the original rockabilly singer and guitarist, stands outside a small guitar store in an ordinarily quiet uptown neighborhood, waiting for filming to resume on a promotional video for his new CD. He flew down this morning from his home in Jackson, Tenn., where he has lived for the last 50 years. He takes all the flurry of activity in stride, joking with crew members and photographers, harmonizing on country songs with onlookers and telling stories.

title: STARS AND STRIPES
description: Although we in the United States think that our flag is the Stars and Stripes, the flags of many other nations have stars or stripes or both. Herewith, 11 national flags, and one ringer. Identify as many as you can, just for the Old Glory of it; extra credit for the ringer.

title: Young Men, Too, Affected by Eating Disorders Like Anorexia
description: ATTRACTIVE, articulate and artistically gifted, the Rocky Point High School junior looked in the mirror and saw only one quality: fat. After numerous diets and a weight loss of 57 pounds, the teen-ager, who insisted on anonymity, was hospitalized and helped with innovative therapy.

title: Deborah Glassman and Adam Berger
description: Dr. Deborah Tova Glassman and Dr. Adam Craig Berger, residents at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore, were married last evening. Rabbi Robert E. Fine performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Foreign Danger Zones
description: As President Clinton assembles a new Cabinet and looks ahead to his second term, he has a rare opportunity to review America's interests abroad. The relative tranquillity of recent years has obscured the real risk that one or more countries vital to American security could quickly slip into turmoil. It does not take a seasoned diplomat to see the high danger zones. The potential for long-term instability is considerable in Russia and China. Collapse of the Middle East peace effort would have wrenching consequences, including the prospect of renewed armed conflict. Iraq remains unpredictable. Turkey, pivotal to American interests in the Persian Gulf region, faces powerful internal divisions.

title: Big fun in north florida
description: We're driving an empty, shimmering two-lane road, the sun pooling up in mirages on the asphalt, Tom Petty blasting on the stereo and a cooler full of beer and shrimp in the back seat. Off on our right is solid green swamp and, on the other side, the Gulf of Mexico. It flashes between a screen of cabbage palms and pines, layers of green and turquoise, slate and brown water and, off on the horizon, the thin dark line of a barrier island. I'm driving fast, one eye on the landscape, the other watching the road for turtle and snake crossings, maybe alligators on the swamp side (though they don't like the salt). The air is damp and full of smells: palm rot, oyster shells, low tide, shrimp boats. My nose is as alert and interested as a dog's nose, alive to the wide and various world of stink.

title: Leslie J. Simon and Curt C. Myers
description: Leslie Jean Simon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Simon of Omaha, was married last evening to Curt Coleman Myers, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Myers of New London, Conn. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated at the Equitable Center in New York.

title: Gay Characters Need A Sex Life, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: The Black Hole of Journalism
description: CITIZEN K

title: At the Old Village Gate, a New . . . Whatever
description: It's been more than two years since The Village Gate bopped its basement-level last at 160 Bleecker Street, and less than a year since a CVS drugstore replaced the legendary jazz club's ground-floor corollary, the Top of the Gate.

title: Crime
description: Kinsey Millhone isn't always cute and bubbly, bless her heart. In Sue Grafton's crafty new alphabet mystery, ''M'' IS FOR MALICE (Marian Wood/Holt, $25), the California private eye is in a funk, depressed about her love life and the state of the world in general. (''I know it's not up to me to solve the world's problems, but I'd like to believe there's a hidden order somewhere.'') In this lowdown frame of mind, Kinsey lets herself in for another painful installment of her old affair with Robert Dietz and allows herself to become personally involved in her current case, one of those prickly domestic situations that the author loves to poke and probe and eventually push over the edge into violence.

title: Mary M. Becker, J.E. Kleinstein
description: Mary Margot Becker, the daughter of Barbara and Frederic K. Becker of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jonathan Edward Kleinstein, a son of Jacqueline and Jonah A. Kleinstein of Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Barry H. Green performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Jeshurun.

title: Where A Room Is A Calling Card
description: MY respect for Japanese etiquette is not everything it should be. On my first trip to Tokyo, in August, I forgot to pack business cards. On the other hand, I did take the precaution of booking myself into the legendary Okura Hotel, so I did not entirely lose face. The Okura gives the face of those who stay there an instant lift. The hotel is in the Toranomon district, just across the street from the United States Embassy, and a privileged ambassadorial aura rubs off on the Okura and its guests. A room here is itself a calling card, a credential that identifies the lodger as a Somebody, or at least as somebody willing to go along with the way the Japanese expect visiting Somebodies to behave. There may be better hotels in Tokyo. Fancier, more expensive, and more modern hotels are numerous throughout the city. Let them all try harder. There is only one Okura.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on page 17 of the New Jersey section today, with an ''On the Towns'' entry about the Artist Showcase series at J.C.C. on the Palisades, in Tenafly, was printed in error. It shows Freddy Kempf, who performs on Nov. 24, not Fazil Say, who plays today.

title: Montreal
description: The shorter days and encroaching cold of early November are a tonic to many Montrealers. A fresh cover of snow brings cheer, as do the lights of Christmas. Out come the fur and wool coats -- an opportunity to make a fashion statement. While spring fills the streets for one festival after another, in November Montrealers go back indoors, or to the Underground City, for shopping, restaurants and concerts.

title: The Countercharge
description: To the Editor:

title: The High Cost of Muni Bond Peace of Mind
description: SMALL investors and their big fear of losses are fueling the insured muni bond fund business.

title: Bishop on L.I. Admits Struggle With Alcohol
description: The Episcopal Bishop who presides over Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island, Orris G. Walker Jr., publicly acknowledged on Friday that he was battling a drinking problem and was considering taking a sabbatical next year to rest and recover.

title: 'Amahl' Heralds Holidays
description: THANKSGIVING is still more than two weeks away, but the first concerts of the Christmas season will be given next weekend. On Friday evening at 8, the Asylum Hill Music Series celebrates its 30th anniversary with a production of Gian Carlo Menotti's opera ''Amahl and the Night Visitors'' at the Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: An Eye for the Id
description: It was a bad day for Scott Elliott. Frances McDormand had suddenly backed out of his production -- her apology, written on the mustard-colored stationery of a California hotel, was sitting on his desk -- and now he was short one Masha. On this sultry September afternoon, the angular face of the 34-year-old stage director, who in the past 18 months rose from the fringe-theater world of folding chairs and do-it-yourself sets to the promised land of Broadway, was dark and careworn. McDormand, who in January was to be the marquee Masha in Elliott's all-star staging of the Chekhov masterpiece ''The Three Sisters,'' along with Amy Irving, Eric Stoltz and Lili Taylor, informed him that she could not desert her young son in Los Angeles while he was potty training.

title: INSIDE
description: Search for Survivors in India

title: Another Note Added to Copland's Legacy
description: AARON COPLAND, who died at the age of 90 in 1990, remains among the most popular American composers. Works like ''Appalachian Spring'' and ''Rodeo'' are woven into the culture, while ''Fanfare for the Common Man'' has become aural shorthand for the dramatic events of our time.

title: Graf Withdraws From Advanta
description: STEFFI GRAF, still complaining about the left knee injury that has bothered her since Wimbledon, withdrew yesterday from this week's Advanta Championships outside Philadelphia, the event she had planned as her only tuneup for the year-ending Chase Championships Nov. 18-24 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Packing Light: The Right Stuff, Stuffed Right
description: I KNOW a man who never takes luggage when traveling to Europe; after checking into a hotel, he just goes out and buys whatever he needs. Conversely, my mother leaves for long trips heavy and returns light, by packing old clothes that she abandons en route in a sort of diaspora of the wardrobe.

title: A Debut Of Sorts At Museum
description: THE photographers had gathered behind the police barricades like storm clouds.

title: Cyber-Mice That Roar, Implausibly
description: AT first it sounded like big news: a veteran journalist and ex-spokesman for President John F. Kennedy said he had a document showing that TWA Flight 800 had been shot down by the Navy.

title: At College, Many Learn How to Plunge Into Debt
description: Melissa Allen, a psychology major at the University of Maryland, cannot count on her parents for help with tuition. But rather than go deeply in debt with student loans, she is giving up much of the fun of college life by racing through in three years while working 40 hours a week at three jobs.

title: In District 5, Sparring Gets Physical
description: For weeks, tensions among leaders of Community School District 5 have plagued West Harlem's struggling schools, increasing the likelihood that Chancellor Rudy Crew will step in to run the district.

title: Sunny, Chance of Vote Results
description: SOMETHING momentous happened on Tuesday, and it wasn't an election: On Nov. 5, 1996, television news became weatherized.

title: Hold the Euphoria
description: EWING TOWNSHIP

title: 'La Boheme at Purchase College
description: IT is about time Westchester Hudson Opera got a break. The company's fund-raising gala last June had to be postponed because the theaters at Purchase College were being renovated; rescheduled to September, the event was canceled once again, this time because of the simultaneous illness of the artistic director Franco Gratale and the hospitalization of Birgit Nilsson, who was to have received a Lifetime Achievement Award at the concert.

title: Corrections
description: The Your Home column last Sunday, about a recent court decision on taxing interest from co-op investments, omitted the names of the organizations for which a lawyer filed a supporting brief. Joel E. Miller, a Queens tax lawyer who submitted it, acted on behalf of the Council of New York Cooperatives, the Federation of New York Cooperatives and the National Association of Housing Cooperatives.

title: Krista Trousdale, Michael Sullivan
description: Krista Ellen Trousdale, an assistant Connecticut attorney general in Hartford, and Michael Jay Sullivan, the legal counsel to Connecticut's Comptroller, were married yesterday in Old Wethersfield, Conn. The Rev. John A. Rogers Jr. performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: The Last Mowing, Cleanup and Packing It In
description: THE outdoor gardening season is winding down. The leaves are almost completely down. The compost pile is getting higher. There is a chill in the air.

title: Lunch in the Piazza
description: AUTUMN IS TRICKY IN FLORENCE. ON the sunny days, which are usually quite warm, the light is so clear and unwavering that it creates geometric shapes against the city's sloping tiled roofs, gabled towers, fanciful facades and outdoor sculpture, all of which is as much a part of the city as its watermarked paper and red wine.

title: Defector Declined Help Before
description: The sports agent JOE CUBAS tried to get first baseman ROBERTO COLINA to defect when the power hitter played for the Cuban team at the World University Games in 1993 in Buffalo. Colina politely declined.

title: The Bigger They Are . . . Holyfield Stops Tyson
description: Mike Tyson, who seemed so invincible in his ferocious return to the ring, was battered into an 11th-round technical knockout tonight by Evander Holyfield, the man who needed a certificate of health from the Mayo Clinic to fight.

title: Coming Home From the Revolution
description: WHAT happened to the anger, the boiling discontent, the hunger for change? How did the country end up with a split-the-difference Government after four years of a Great Upheaval that destroyed a Republican President in 1992, shattered a Democratic House in 1994 and upended 60 years of social welfare policy in 1995?

title: New Official In Quandary On Trying Kevorkian
description: Dave Gorcyca thought he had lost his bid to become prosecutor of Oakland County here, a sprawling collection of mostly white-collar Detroit suburbs whose million-plus residents include Jack Kevorkian, the doctor trying to legalize assisted suicides.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on Oct. 27, about rowhouses along St. Luke's Place, misstated the title of an official of Trinity Church, which sold the land on which they were built. John Panter is the parish historian, not archivist.

title: If the Plot Is Girl Meets Girl, Is That Enough?
description: IT'S AN OLD STORY. HE'S a rough guy who has had a few too many brushes with the law. She's a femme fatale who brings him nothing but trouble. It's the story of Larry and Andy Wachow ski's darkly stylized film, ''Bound,'' a sort of ''Double Indemnity'' that merges Old World Hollywood glamour with a quirky contemporary sensibility. But there's an extra twist: the guy that catches the femme fatale is a woman. A lesbian.

title: A Loss of 70 Pounds, and a Gain in Confidence and Health
description: DIANE WILLIAMS weighs 465 pounds. That doesn't sound like good news. But in fact it is: in early June she weighed 535, and in the intervening five months, she has lost 70 pounds.

title: High-Tech Companies Race for Bay Area Space
description: COMPETITION for office and research space by rapidly expanding computer software and information technology companies has pushed rents and land prices on the San Francisco Peninsula to historic highs.

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: The housing crisis described by DeParle is in fact a poverty crisis. No complex Government programs are required. The poor simply need enough money to pay fair market rents.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE PRICE OF LAND IN SHELBY

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Lesbian's Ordination Celebrated by Small Toledo Congregation
description: About 55 people gathered on Sunday to watch the Rev. Elder Wilhelmina Hein lay her hands on Elaine Thomas's head and ordain her to ministry ''in the name of the Parent, the Christ and the Holy Spirit.''

title: Objects Reclaimed From Roadside and Seaside
description: WITHIN the six-acre compound of the Connecticut Audubon Birdcraft Museum in Fairfield visitors can walk nature trails that lead to a lake, a bridge and a gazebo. Out of doors they can listen for birdcalls -- the compound is described as the oldest private songbird sanctuary in America -- then they can go into a natural history museum where ''Creating With Nature,'' a display of natural or recycled craft works, remains on view through Friday.

title: Follow-Up: A Mayoral Nail-Biter Is Settled, at Least for Now
description: On Tuesday night, about 200 West Paterson Republicans gathered at the American Legion clubhouse to wait for the results of the mayoral election. There were big trays of meatballs, rigatoni, and sausages and peppers.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 10, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (Viking, $23.95.) The disappearance of a 3-year-old boy brings a family anguish and redemption. 2 6 2 THE LAWS OF OUR FATHERS, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.95.) The trial of a probation officer for his mother's murder recalls the turbulent 60's. 3 2 5 DESPERATION, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) Visitors to a small mining town in Nevada encounter terrifying forces. 4 5 2 MY GAL SUNDAY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) An ex-President and his Congresswoman wife investigate four crimes in the capital. 5 3 11 eXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) Vice President Jack Ryan has problems after the deaths of the President and most of the Cabinet, Congress, the Joint Chiefs and the Supreme Court. 6 4 5 THE REGULATORS, by Richard Bachman. (Dutton, $24.95.) Killings and other horrors disrupt a quiet suburban town in Ohio. 7 12 2 THE TAILOR OF PANAMA, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $25.) A London tailor, now living in Panama City, is blackmailed into becoming a spy for British intelligence. 8 7 5 TO THE HILT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $24.95.) Trials and tribulations await a reclusive painter summoned to the bedside of his dying stepfather. 9 8 3 THE NOTEBOOK, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $16.95.) A World War II veteran meets an old flame who is about to be married. 10 9 8 JACK AND JILL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Alex Cross on the trail of serial killers at large in Washington. 11 10 141 THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life. (+) 12 14 23 FALLING UP, by Shel Silverstein. (HarperCollins, $16.95.) Poems and drawings, for children and grown-ups, celebrating strange characters and experiences. 13* 1 THE YELLOW ADMIRAL, by Patrick O'Brian. (Norton, $24.) Jack Aubrey's naval ambitions and domestic happiness are endangered when peace threatens to break out during the Napoleonic Wars. 14 11 2 ICON, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $24.95.) In 1999, a former C.I.A. agent returns to Moscow to help prevent Russia from becoming another Nazi Germany. 15* 1 THE THIRD TWIN, by Ken Follett. (Crown, $25.95.) A research scientist's study of genetic components brings her frightening experiences and romance. Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Nonfiction 1 14 2 AMERICAN TRAGEDY, by Lawrence Schiller and James Willwerth. (Random House, $27.50.) The O. J. Simpson trial seen from the defense team's viewpoint. 2 1 28 THE DILBERT PRINCIPLE, by Scott Adams. (Harper Business, $20.) A satirical look, in words and cartoons, at the current foibles of business and management. (+) 3 3 6 SLOUCHING TOWARDS GOMORRAH, by Robert H. Bork. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $25.) An indictment of modern liberalism, by the former judge, for recent declines in American culture and social life. (+) 4 2 3 DOGBERT'S TOP SECRET MANAGEMENT HANDBOOK, by Scott Adams. (Harper Business, $16.) More observations on the foibles of the business world, reported in words and cartoons. (+) 5 4 3 DON'T BLOCK THE BLESSINGS, by Patti LaBelle with Laura B. Randolph. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The memoirs of the Grammy Award-winning singer. 6* 7 7 HOW GOOD DO WE HAVE TO BE? by Harold S. Kushner. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) How a new understanding of guilt and forgiveness can change our lives. 7* 8 5 THE SEA HUNTERS, by Clive Cussler and Craig Dirgo. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) The searches made for shipwrecks that occurred during the past 150 years. 8 6 5 LOVE, LUCY, by Lucille Ball with Betty Hannah Hoffman. (Putnam, $24.95.) The posthumous autobiography of the television star. 9 10 8 ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $24.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood amid the miseries of Limerick. 10 9 17 UNLIMITED ACCESS, by Gary Aldrich. (Regnery, $24.95.) Events in the Clinton White House as reported by an F.B.I. agent formerly on duty there. (+) 11 5 6 JAMES HERRIOT'S FAVORITE DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) Ten tales recounted by the Yorkshire veterinarian, who died last year. 12 131 MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga. (+) 13 3 JOURNEY TO JUSTICE, by Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. with Tim Rutten. (One World/Ballantine, $26.) The autobiography of O. J. Simpson's chief defense lawyer. 14* 3 5 UNDAUNTED COURAGE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The story of how Thomas Jefferson sponsored Lewis and Clark's exploration. (+) 15 15 4 DOWNSIZE THIS! by Michael Moore. (Crown, $21.) Observations on the current social and political scene by the director of ''Roger & Me.'' (+) Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 7 MAKE THE CONNECTION, by Bob Greene and Oprah Winfrey. (Hyperion, $18.95.) Ways to improve one's life physically and mentally. 2 2 181 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $25.) Improving communication and relationships. (+) 3 3 34 THE ZONE, by Barry Sears with Bill Lawren. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $23.) Diets to prevent disease and enhance mental health. (+) 4 4 31 SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+)

title: Postcards From Paris
description: I am sending you this postcard. It is not of Paris, although it is from Paris. It is of me, or of us, for as I write, I imagine you reading these words, just as I suppose you, while reading them, might well be imagining me, writing them.

title: When It's Over Over There
description: Historians still debate why the assassination of the Austrian Archduke Francis Ferdinand by a Serbian nationalist in Sarajevo on June 28, 1914, plunged Europe into the infero of World War I. THE GREAT WAR, a comprehensive, eight-part series on PBS beginning Sunday, takes a fresh look at the causes, from the tortured psychohistory of Kaiser Wilhelm II, to the tangled alliances of the royal houses of Europe.

title: While Digital Video Dithers, Laser Disk Just Gets Better
description: THE FEW, PROUD OWNERS of laser-disk players, a doughty lot said to number two million, are still seeing the best video currently available in the living room. The cinematic experience comes home on laser disks with an immediacy, a precision and subtlety, that simply cannot be rivaled on VHS tape. Meanwhile, of course, a yawning world awaits the digital video disk. Or maybe it doesn't.

title: With Help From the Top, Democrats Gain
description: WHEN James H. Maloney, a Danbury Democrat, was campaigning for the Fifth District Congressional seat, he attended 32 candidate forums. In all but one, he was the only major party candidate there because the Republican incumbent, Gary A. Franks, of Waterbury, declined the invitations. Mr. Maloney attributed his victory in last Tuesday's election partly to just this difference: his presence at such events and his opponent's absence.

title: Even the Art Museums Can't Escape Her Barbs
description: EVERYONE LOVES TO CRITICIZE THE Whitney Biennial, the exhibition highlighting new trends in American art that the museum mounts every other year. But few have done so with such subversive glee as the artist Nicole Eisenman. Her mural ''Self-Portrait With Exploded Whitney,'' included in the 1995 Biennial, depicts the artist with her back to the viewer, calmly painting the one surface that remains standing while the rest of the museum lies in rubble. The Whitney purchased this painting -- situated in the basement next to the restaurant but now hidden by a fake wall -- for its permanent collection.

title: Hillary Clinton's Past
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A' Is for Avalanche
description: The Graphic Alphabet

title: Voting, America's Not Keen On. Coffee Is Another Matter.
description: HERE'S a little test about where America is heading: which of these drew more people?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BRONTE

title: A Touch of Rural, and a Lively Downtown
description: LAST month, this northern Westchester village stood in for for a small town in Indiana during the filming of a movie starring Kevin Kline, Debbie Reynolds and Joan Cusack.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Television section today about the mini-series ''Pandora's Clock'' misidentifies the network that is broadcasting the show tonight and tomorrow night. It is NBC, not ABC.

title: Plan for an Access Road Upsets Stony Brook
description: RESIDENTS of the towns of Brookhaven and Smithtown say they are on edge over development, road work and diminishing open spaces. Even a land-use study is raising concerns.

title: Whittling Away at the Vacancy Rate Downtown
description: IT'S only a 10-minute subway ride from Lower Manhattan to downtown Brooklyn, Manuel A. Romero noted. So he has moved his office from Brooklyn to Manhattan and now he commutes back to Brooklyn to appear in court.

title: As Dole Served in Brooklyn, New Yorkers Saw the South
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: TESTAMENTS BETRAYED: An Essay in Nine Parts

title: All the Young Muses
description: ROBERT GRAVES AND THE WHITE GODDESS1940-85.By Richard Perceval Graves.Illustrated. 618 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.:Weidenfeld & Nicolson/Trafalgar Square. $45.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VICTORIAN WOMEN

title: BIBLE DISCUSSION GROUP
description: The theological philosophy of Rabbi Visotzky, Bill Moyers and others evoked memories of late-into-the-night conversations with my father, a lifelong scholar of the Bible and sometime agnostic. The philosophy that he imbued in me was that God is a thought, put into the human mind to give life a sense of purpose -- leading to the question, Who put it there?

title: BOLOGNA THROUGH MEDIEVAL EYES
description: In the winter of 1995 I spent three months in Bologna, Italy, doing research for a novel, but I had another, equally important agenda: I wanted to participate in the life of the city, to discover (or create) its meaning in a way that was personal without being idiosyncratic.

title: Cry, Argentina: 'Evita' Fashions
description: ON her deathbed in 1952, Eva Peron whispered to her husband, ''What I don't want is for people to forget me, Juan.''

title: Hollywood Does Christmas
description: CORRECT ME IF I'M wrong here, but the way I remember it, the original Christmas Story was a quiet, low-budget affair. Luke's rendition is almost matter-of-fact. ''And it came to pass, in those days, that there went out a decree from Caesar Augustus, that all the world should be taxed.''

title: Corrections
description: The Coping column last Sunday, about a cross-dressing student at the Collegiate School on the Upper West Side, misstated part of the school's dress code. Students are permitted to wear jeans.

title: Doctor's Speakers Aid in Workers' Health
description: OH, my aching back! Eight out of 10 people suffer from lower back pain, which ranks second on the list of ailments that contribute to absenteeism in the workplace, said Dr. Martin Kotlar, a chiropractor in White Plains.

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: Jason DeParle's ''Slamming the Door'' (Oct. 20) sets back America's search for affordable shelter by endorsing failed bureaucratic attempts to address the problem. Community-controlled, Federally financed programs targeted to special local conditions might have been effective. However, national rent subsidies and similar well-meaning schemes have become narcotics for those who seek and those who supply housing. What incentive is there to solve problems if Washington will pay so long as they remain unsolved?

title: Loans That Tap Home's Value
description: IN the 10 months since Selma and Jack Tepper received an $80,000 loan from Saxon National Mortgage Bankers in Hauppauge, they have installed a new bathroom, had their house painted, put in a new walkway -- and paid off a pressing $10,000 debt.

title: Heroes With Mixed Motives
description: PLOTTING HITLER'S DEATH

title: Bullets Open Up Their Gifts and Run
description: So many people have high expectations for the Washington Bullets this season -- their fans, their players, even their relatives.

title: A Spa for All Seasons
description: I can see my grandfather walking in Baden-Baden, Germany, in 1896, on a late winter day, near noon. (I have such a photograph somewhere.) There are not many people on the pathway, besides the customary German dowagers with their dogs. It is not the high season (that comes in the summer), which is probably why this careful bourgeois gentleman from Budapest is there, having chosen to take the waters when the hotel prices and even the Kurtax (the spa tax levied on guests) are low. On his way to the Trinkhalle, the Pump Room, to ingest his glass of mineral water for the day, he looks at the other gentlemen and their ladies, got up smartly enough, on their way to the Cure. He is well dressed, but somewhat uncomfortable in high black boots with elastic sides, and wonders whether he, too, should have brought a walking cane. Along both sides of the Lichtentaler Allee, the tall trees are stiff from the winter, but the famous carpet of Baden-Baden crocuses is starting to appear. Beyond the greensward the houses of the city assemble under a pale watery-blue sky.

title: Dream Weavers
description: NO phrase transports the imagination more powerfully than ''once upon a time.'' Storytelling is the oldest form of theater, the original virtual reality. In an age when the average attention span seems to be a second or less, it survives, with tenacious vigor.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: VOTE IN CALIFORNIA IS MOTIVATING FOES OF ANTI-BIAS PLANS
description: Last year legislation was introduced in 26 states and in Congress to repeal or significantly roll back affirmative-action programs. Not a single bill passed.

title: Sudden Death in the Classroom, and Its Meaning
description: SOME people call them bad-news buffs -- use calamity as a conversation piece. Then there's Anthony Clarvoe, who writes very morbid plays.

title: DIRTY LOOKS
description: Urban commuters may think that women who apply makeup in public are ruining the glory that is public transit. But if we take another look at this public act, we might see its revolutionary nature. Female rituals are coming out of hiding, into the bright light of public space. It is only a matter of time before the quick touch-up will take its place alongside the power handshake.

title: THE GOAT SPEAKS
description: With basketball season under way, we asked Earl (The Goat) Manigault about the game that made him a Harlem playground legend. In the 60's, he became famous for electrifying moves like the double dunk before heroin addiction and prison ended his career. Now clean and running a New York City after-school program, Manigault is the subject of the HBO movie ''Rebound,'' to be shown Nov. 23. ''That stuff they're doing now is just a repeat of the 60's and 70's,'' says the Goat, a tall, shaven-headed 52-year-old who, like many playground greats, likes to convey a healthy blaseness about the N.B.A. ''I know at least 10 guys out of every block that are at least as good as any guy in the N.B.A.'' Um, 10? ''Well, maybe not 10.'' As for today's top players, the Goat agrees with anyone paying attention that Michael Jordan remains the best. Who's next? ''I never thought about that before,'' he says after a pause. ''I guess everybody else.''

title: Stand By for Casualties
description: The welfare reform bill that President Clinton signed into law in August poses serious dangers to poor children.
