Though the President and many Democrats who went along with the measure pledged to fix its flaws after the election, reducing the risks to children requires more than any incremental changes that might be politically feasible in the new Congress.

title: Debra Wiseman, Stephen Tobias
description: Debra Wiseman, the daughter of Cmdr. and Mrs. Charles H. Wiseman of Los Altos Hills, Calif., was married last evening to Stephen Lyle Tobias, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Tobias of Seaford, L.I. Rabbi Sholom Stern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Supermarket Fire Injures 6
description: Six firefighters suffered minor injuries yesterday when a two-alarm fire gutted a supermarket in the College Point section of Queens.

title: Bedroom Hair
description: WHEN THE CLOTHES WE ARE SEEING in the stores now -- classic, clean, controlled -- appeared on the runway in the spring, they were often accompanied by hair that looked as if the models had forgotten to stop at the styling station. Tresses were casually pinned up, with loose locks dangling -- a coif long favored by students pulling all-nighters before exams. It was what you did with long hair when it got dirty or messy or in your way and you had no time to deal with it. Suddenly it was fashion.

title: Free Jazz As Energetic As Chicago
description: IN HER 1977 BOOK ''AS SERIOUS AS YOUR LIFE: The Story of the New Jazz,'' the critic Valerie Wilmer theorized that the difference between the avant-garde jazz in Chicago and that in New York was a reflection of architecture -- in New York, tall buildings, tight corners, hemmed-in areas; in Chicago, space, light, openness.

title: The Decline and Fall of the Classical Empire?
description: THE MUSIC BUSINESS LOOKS uncomfortable in its skin. The faces and places vary, but the animosities, confusions and frustrations do not.

title: Uneasy Marriage of Interests For Television and Publishers
description: When the nation's most unlikely librarian recommends fiction, her gentle readers listen carefully. And then they make mega-best sellers out of obscure first novels and two-decade-old books.

title: Cover Boy
description: Chip Kidd, who has been a leader in changing the look of book jackets, may never have had a hotter moment than right now. The last few weeks have seen the publication of his own book, the opening of a museum show that includes many of his acclaimed covers and the buzz over one particularly provocative jacket design.

title: How Green Is My Market: A Guide to Fresh Produce in the Streets
description: The city's greenmarkets are bountiful sources of fresh produce. A few have closed for the year. Several others will close between now and the end of December, and the remainder stay open year-round on designated days, usually from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. Here is a list of markets and when they are open:

title: Photographs in History's Shifting Gaze
description: PHOTOGRAPHS STOP TIME IN ITS tracks, yet time itself will not stop fiddling with the images. Though neither the subject nor the appearance of a photograph changes, its content shifts in our minds; the data on display may be permanent but the import is hostage to history. In the early years of this century, Edward S. Curtis's pictures of American Indians sang the romance and fascinating traditions of a vanishing race. Now that we know that Curtis sometimes dressed his subjects up in the clothes of other tribes, the pictures speak of rotten anthropology and imperialism. Nineteenth-century photographs of Africans appealed to the European taste for the exotic and erotic; today they often read like chronicles of colonialism and social Darwinism.

title: Q and A
description: A Day in Lisbon

title: Boris Bounces Back
description: When Boris N. Yeltsin suddenly disappeared from public life over the summer, few Russians were surprised. The 65-year-old President, whose health problems were well known, campaigned for re-election like a man on fire.

title: The Brief Blue Period Of Mondrian
description: When visitors to the Museum of Modern Art's Mondrian collection saw a blue liquid splattered down the front of one of the artist's clean geometric paintings last Saturday afternoon, some wondered if they were witnessing the aftermath of an act of vandalism. Was the painting, ''Composition in Red, White and Blue,'' the target of an iconoclast who physically attacks a work of art?

title: Argentina and Chile Offer Bargain Prices
description: CONSUMERS with a flair for adventure and an eye toward a bargain should consider locally available reds and whites from Argentina and Chile. Moreover, while many of these wines may not appeal to those who favor the more traditional taste of wines from Bordeaux, Burgundy and California, one need not be iconoclastic to enjoy some of the exceptional values from South America, since they marry perfectly with a wide range of meats.

title: From Here and There to the East 30's and 40's
description: CHEZ LAURENCE ++

title: Hakone, Once Stern, Now Soothes
description: FOR centuries, Japanese feudal lords struggled across the mountains around Mount Fuji, stopping to rest near the gentle hot springs and glistening lakes around Hakone, about 65 miles southwest of Tokyo.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HOTEL

title: Hawaii Island in Shadow of Volcano Takes Its Jolts With a Shrug
description: Just about anywhere else in the world, people flee from an erupting volcano. But here on the Big Island of Hawaii, Kilauea has been pushing out lava for so long -- 13 years now -- that most people who live in its shadow are blase about it.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ALL WE KNOW OF HEAVENBy Sue Ellen Bridgers.Banks Channel Books, P.O. Box 4446, Wilmington, N.C. 28406, $22.

title: Without a Trace
description: THE MISSING

title: Wynalda Is Making His Point By Scoring
description: Eric Wynalda is the United States national soccer team's leading career scorer. But Wynalda has added arrogance, controversy and outspokenness to his 26 goals for the Americans, to the point of aggravating the people with whom he plays.

title: Ever Punched a Cow?
description: Let's Rodeo!

title: U.N. Fails to Authorize Peace Force for Zaire
description: Despite warnings by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of ''a new genocide'' by starvation in Central Africa, the United Nations Security Council failed early today to adopt a resolution creating an international military force to aid hundreds of thousands of refugees in danger of dying of hunger or thirst in eastern Zaire.

title: Dancers Turn Museum Into Moving Theater
description: TRADITIONALLY settings for hushed contemplation, museums do not normally condone climbing on the exhibitions. Climbing, slithering, jumping and dancing will all be in order here, however, when the Hudson River Museum of Westchester presents ''Off the Walls'' on Thursday, Friday and Saturdays at 8 P.M.

title: Hunting Where Turkeys Run Wild
description: CRISP fall weather signals the coming of winter and draws the sportsman outdoors for pursuits ranging from football to running and golf. Zeke Hunter who lives here prefers to dress in camouflage, trek into the woods and cluck like a hen.

title: Meltdown
description: SAM AND THE TIGERS

title: The Two Faces Of Texaco
description: MICHAEL MOCCIO knew exactly what to do when a complaint of racial discrimination landed on his desk at Texaco Inc.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Chardonnay

title: Last Chores As Season Fades Out
description: THE outdoor gardening season is winding down, but don't put the tools away just yet. As eager as most gardeners are to settle down to that long winter's nap, a few chores remain. Those who can check them off as done deserve at least a passing grade. The rest of us will have to get busy.

title: Mother Goose Preserved
description: MY VERY FIRST MOTHER GOOSE

title: For Bewildered House Newcomers, Help Is Just a Mouse-Click Away
description: When the more than 70 newly elected House members arrive in Washington this week, a cyber Welcome Wagon will be waiting to help them become familiar with their new jobs.

title: Murals From 30's Glow Again
description: Since February, Alan Farancz and his assistant, John Lipper, have spent their nights, wearing face masks and rubber gloves, locked in the Central Post Office at East 149th Street and Grand Concourse. Their mission: To save 12 historic Depression-era murals of hard-working proletarians. The murals, which dominated the walls, were so striking that graduate students wrote dissertations about them and the city granted the building landmark status.

title: Little Gavay, Lawrence Fisher
description: Susan Stefanie Gavay, a daughter of Geraldine and Frank Gavay of Danbury, Conn., was married last evening to Lawrence Martin Fisher, the son of Linda and Robert Fisher of New York. Rabbi Steven Klein officiated at the Essex House.

title: Portrait of the Electorate
description: As in 1992, Bill Clinton won re-election without a majority of the popular vote. He was able to hold on to the support of many of the demographic groups who elected him President in the first place and, in some cases, increase his share of their votes. Women, blacks, young voters, Democrats and liberals all gave Mr. Clinton a majority of their votes. He did well with swing groups, like independents and suburbanites. Bob Dole's best showing was with conservatives, Republicans and white Protestants. Ross Perot received only 8 percent, down from 19 percent in 1992.

title: Virginia Prisoner Receives Rare Mercy on Death Row
description: Commuting death sentences has become political poison for governors, sure fodder for some future opponent's attack ads. But Gov. George F. Allen of Virginia, a conservative Republican, granted that rare gift this week after a highly publicized campaign by a condemned man's lawyer, who tracked down jurors in the case and persuaded several to renounce the verdict.

title: Cruising To The Rescued Treasures Of Nubia
description: In the early 1870's, Miss Amelia B. Edwards and a group of her friends hired one of the graceful sailing vessels called dahabeeyahs and set out on a trip up the Nile. I have always felt an affinity with this lady, who turned from writing thrillers to Egyptology, whereas I turned from Egyptology to writing thrillers. Her novels are long out of print, but the book she wrote about her trip, ''A Thousand Miles Up the Nile,'' has become a minor classic and a more entrancing guidebook than Baedeker for those of us who are diehard Egypt buffs. I had followed in her footsteps from Cairo to Aswan, by boat, by road and by air, but I had never been able to visit the sites she saw south of Aswan -- for an excellent reason. In the 1960's, the building of the High Dam drowned most of what had been Lower Nubia under the waters of a great inland sea.

title: Following His Fixations, Early Music to Whatever
description: Correction Appended

title: Backyard Magic
description: THE LEAF MENAnd the Brave Good Bugs.Written and illustrated by William Joyce.Unpaged. New York:A Laura Geringer Book/HarperCollins Publishers. $15.95.(Ages 4 to 8)

title: Two Decades Later, Just Right for the Role
description: IT WAS A BONE-CHILLING SPRING evening in 1977 when Ann Reinking stepped on the stage of what is now the Richard Rodgers Theater to replace Gwen Verdon in ''Chicago.'' But for musical-theater insiders, the moment burned with significance. It wasn't simply that the 26-year-old ingenue dominated the stage with her sophisticated charm and deceptively casual technique; it was the real-life romantic subplot that brought the audience to its feet.

title: Is It Raining in Maui Or Snowing in Moscow?
description: It's the dead of winter, and you're desperate for the feeling of warm sun on your back. Quick, are your chances for rainless days best in Puerto Rico, Belize or Maui?

title: Devils Light Up The Rink In Shutout
description: Who says these guys can't score?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about Civil War sites near Washington misstated the date of Gen. Robert E. Lee's retreat after the Battle of Antietam. A reader's letter dated Oct. 20 points out that it began on the evening of Sept. 18, 1862, not the night before.

title: Even His Furniture Is Like Arhitecture
description: TO LOOK AT THE LIFE AND work of the 79-year-old architect and industrial designer Ettore Sottsass is to see the history of 20th-century Italian design. Indeed, from his colorful typewriters for the electronics manufacturer Olivetti to the patterned plastic laminates of Memphis furniture, he has created much of it.

title: Sephardic Tradition On Curacao
description: WANDERING the narrow streets of the old Dutch port of Willemstad, on cactus-studded Curacao, I spotted touches of this Caribbean island's tangled history. Under the sinuous gables of the 18th-century Casa Amarilla was the Hebrew date 5466 (1705 or 1706). On the coral bricks of another residence were Hebrew letters that said ''Bet Levi,'' or House of Levi. These tropical Dutch colonial buildings -- in pastel shades of tangerine, strawberry, lime and lemon -- were once the homes of the Jews of Curacao. As I strolled past their graceful balconies, I noticed streets named Sha Caprileskade and Madurostraat, in memory of this island's Sephardic pioneers.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: I Was That Masked Man

title: Lee Brock And Seth Barrish
description: Lee Brock and Seth Barrish, artistic directors of the Barrow Group, a theater ensemble in New York, were married yesterday at the New York Carriage House, a loft space in New York. Maria C. McKenna, an elder of the New York City Pathwork Center, a nondenominational spiritual organization, performed the ceremony.

title: Cadet Defense Shuts Morgan Down
description: Before the game, Army Coach Bob Sutton said, ''We'll find out who's better -- the Army defense or Beau.''

title: Assembling A New Team On Economy
description: Surprised by the speed of a rash of post-election resignations that have claimed all but two central players on its economic team, the Clinton Administration is scrambling to rebuild that side of the Cabinet before it has to confront three major challenges next year: a potential slowdown of the nation's economy, change in entitlement programs and growing tensions with China over trade policy.

title: Enthralled by Asia's Ruling Women? Look Again.
description: MORE women have led modern governments in South Asia than in any other region of the world. But as the ignominious dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's autocratic, corruption-riddled Government in Pakistan last week demonstrates, anyone who would write feminist history needs to look hard at how these powerful women have ruled, and what their exercise of authority has meant to the people they governed.

title: A New Effort to Speed Rape Exam Procedures
description: A GRASS-ROOTS effort to improve the treatment of rape victims in the county has led to a proposed new approach, which advocates say would both assure that victims are treated more compassionately and help obtain more convictions in sexual-assault cases.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: New Queensboro Bridge Rebel Site: 57th St.
description: If Mayor Giuliani thought his recent, and rare, public apology over an unpopular solution to the monumental traffic around the Queensboro Bridge would win him friends among Upper East Side residents, he has not talked to Dr. Carol Poole or to many of her neighbors on 57th Street.

title: A Cardinal's Cancer Saddens All Chicago
description: No man has shaped the National Conference of Catholic Bishops more than its onetime general secretary and later president, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago. But when the conference opens its fall meeting in Washington next Monday, he will not be there.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Mother's Kitchen Opens A Long Way From Home

title: French-American Ties Mostly Untied, for Now
description: The French mood these days is a sour one, and French-American relations, never better only six months ago, have soured with it.

title: Susan A. Britman, Douglas Present
description: Susan Alice Britman, the daughter of Madeline and Norman Britman of Clark, N.J., was married last evening to Douglas Andrew Present, the son of Jane and Dr. Daniel Present of New York. E. Noach Shapiro, a rabbinical student and childhood friend of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: The People Nobody Wants
description: JIPHis Story.By Katherine Paterson.181 pp. New York:Lodestar Books. $15.99.(Ages 8 to 12)

title: Voters Lose in Electoral College 'World Series'
description: To the Editor:

title: When Plagues End
description: I.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football

title: Giants and Marlins Seem Willing to Harvest During Winter
description: Owners have adopted it as a mantra: the teams in the World Series, the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves, had the highest payrolls in their respective leagues; the four teams in the league championship series possessed four of the five highest payrolls in the major leagues.

title: Brooklyn, They Hope, Is for the Birds
description: AS summer resident birds go south, late fall migrant birds and winter residents are arriving to occupy Prospect Park. And next Sunday morning, the Brooklyn Bird Club president, John Muir, will point them out.

title: BENEFITS
description: Comedy at the Pierre

title: THE DISSENT OF MAN
description: 1. Pope John Paul II's recent decree that evolution is ''more than just a theory'' inspired international coverage, but it's drawing a wide variety of razzing from creationists. 2. Reactions include (itals)disappointment: ''It's (itals)sad that the leader of a large denomination would say that,'' says Ken Ham, director of Answers in Genesis, an evangelical ministry. 3. (itals)Determination: ''Doesn't matter,'' sniffs Bill Hoesch of the Institute for Creation Research. ''Scientists will still admit -- when you get them alone -- that evolution is wrong.'' 4. And of course, good old-fashioned (itals)diatribe: ''Why blame it on God?'' says Hendrik Hanegraaf, host of the radio talk show ''Bible Answer Man.'' ''Evolution is a series of painfully cruel, inefficient mutations.''

title: Boston College, Aiming to Regroup, Gets Off to a Rocky Start
description: Depleted by 13 suspensions for gambling, and with their teammates and their team facing an uncertain future, the Boston College Eagles attempted to turn a football field into a sanctuary today. Their 48-21 loss to Notre Dame, in a game that was tied in the third quarter, marked the beginning of the school's effort to replace innuendo with respect at the end of an emotionally exhausting week.

title: Political Animal
description: THE POPE'S RHINOCEROS

title: His Head in the Ether, He Was Among a 'Sorry Herd of Humans'
description: ALBERT EINSTEIN'S most famous letter was arguably the most influential and fateful of modern times: the Nobel laureate's 1939 warning to President Franklin D. Roosevelt of the Nazis' nuclear potential, which led to the Manhattan Project and the development of the atom bomb. On Nov. 25, Christie's in New York will auction Einstein letters of a very different character: correspondence providing a remarkable glimpse into the physicist's emotional life. The collection of more than 400 letters, found in Berkeley, Calif., in 1986, is being sold as a result of a dispute among Einstein's heirs. The letters, mostly in German, contain few revelations for Einstein experts, but most -- including those illuminating the bitter end of Einstein's first marriage, to Mileva Maric -- have never been published. They fill in the portrait of Einstein not only as an intellectual giant but as a man. Here are excerpts. TOM KUNTZ

title: The Game? What Game? The Ritual of Football
description: IF it is a Saturday afternoon in the fall, there is no question where Thatcher Longstreth will be, what team he will be cheering for or even what he will be wearing.

title: Decency Doesn't Count
description: Karen Finley, the performance artist who once smeared simulated excrement on herself to symbolize the degradation of women, may not get a new infusion of Government funding any time soon. But a cause she championed, the fight against Congressional efforts to impose standards of decency on publicly funded art, won a big victory last week in the courts.

title: Vintage TV on Video Taps a Market for Memories
description: EVERY SO OFTEN, home video enshrines television legends as if they were DiMaggio at Cooperstown. Lucy has long had a plaque in the video pantheon, of course, along with ''The Honeymooners'' and Jackie Gleason, ''Star Trek'' and William Shatner, ''Gunsmoke'' and James Arness, and, more recently, Johnny Carson. Video distributors form a veritable old-timers' committee.

title: Meghan Barber and John J. Duval Jr.
description: Meghan Barber, the daughter of Floss Barber Hoover of Philadelphia and Zorie Joseph Barber of Chino Hills, Calif., was married yesterday to John Joseph Duval Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Duval of Flat Rock, N.C. The Rev. Alex Viola, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Heaths and Heathers: Soft Fire of the Wastelands
description: A moor, by the dictionary's definition, is a wasteland. Too acidic and peaty to support anybody's idea of valuable vegetation, it is covered instead with heather. Where moors exist, mainly in Scotland and other areas of the British Isles, they are cloaked each summer in a haze of rose-purple when the heather is in bloom.

title: The Dow Is Up: Greed Revisited
description: IT has been said that you can learn a lot by examining a culture's folk tales.

title: Amy Kauffman, Kenneth Weinstein
description: Amy Beth Kauffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kauffman of Penn Valley, Pa., is to be married today to Kenneth Roy Weinstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Weinstein of Rego Park, Queens. Rabbi Gerald Wolpe is to perform the ceremony at Har Zion Synagogue in Penn Valley.

title: Rabin's Death Still Divides Israel
description: AT first, the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin a year ago seemed to many Israelis a cataclysmic event that would forever change the face of the country. One hope was that it would galvanize Israelis to unite behind his legacy.

title: DIARY
description: THE STOCK MARKET

title: The Night an Outsider Dispelled All Illusions
description: For a theater work so personally taken, thoroughly known and deeply felt by millions, and so often produced, it is astonishing to consider how rarely ''The Glass Menagerie'' is fulfilled or, for that matter, performed within breathing distance of Williams's magical words.

title: As Season Ends, Work Doesn't
description: LIKE all the trees on the East End of Long Island, the apple trees on the Halsey apple and pumpkin farm in Bridgehampton had turned autumn colors. The breeze brought smells of a departing season from the fields up to the farmhouse.

title: The Road Taken, Resolutely, Made All the Difference
description: ROUTINELY, NOWADAYS, talented opera singers are pushed into roles prematurely by impatient conductors and record executives. It's the bane of the opera business. Great voices must be cultivated carefully.

title: Where the High and Low Roads Meet
description: What's the best way to sell a book about New York City's sex industry? It appears there's no right answer, just different choices, as the marketing strategies for two just-published books show.

title: Correction
description: The Art column last Sunday about two exhibitions misstated the location of the Artspace gallery. It is in New Haven, not Hartford.

title: What You Don't Know Can Save You
description: HEADED FOR THE BLUES

title: Blanket Statements
description: The Seasons Sewn

title: Choosing a Career: Attitudes and Aptitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: Correction Appended

title: Artists Muster in Defense of Their 'Happy Nonsense'
description: The entrance is not just a door, but a tunnel of neon lights. The clock is a three-story-high billboard. The hanging sculpture is a Brobdingnagian fishing lure. And the plaza is a bevy of sheet-metal seats in primary colors.

title: The H.M.O. Says the Doctor Is In. Is He Really?
description: SO you're thinking of joining an H.M.O., and your selection of doctors is all-important. You look at the health maintenance organization's list and there, plain as day, is the pediatrician who has been treating Junior since he was a baby. And among the specialists is the orthopedist who fixed your bad knee. Your wife's gynecologist is listed, too.

title: Dr. Earl O. Butcher, Anatomy Expert, 93
description: Dr. Earl O. Butcher, a former chairman of the department of anatomy at New York University's College of Dentistry, died on Nov. 2 at his home in the Meadow Lakes retirement community in Hightstown, N.J. He was 93.

title: Vienna Modern, Back in the Spotlight
description: THE GLITTERING VIENNA MODERN style has for much of the century captivated collectors and the public alike with its sensuous appeal. The furniture, silver and ceramics produced by innovators like Josef Hoffmann and Koloman Moser during the early 20th century had lean silhouettes, geometric patterning and angular shaping, all in keeping with the new Modernism. But soon the Viennese love of decoration reasserted itself, and richly ornamented objects with swirled handles, scalloped edges and ethnic motifs dominated the style until its decline in the 1930's.

title: White House Won't Discuss Any Powell Offers
description: The White House declined to say today whether President Clinton would offer Colin L. Powell a Cabinet position after reports that he had said he would be willing to serve in the Administration.

title: Sometimes It's the Little Things
description: Maybe you took home a few pens from the office or wrote some letters on company stationery. Or maybe you were a little more daring, sending the company jet to pick up your spouse. Many workers have used company time or property for personal benefit. Have you? Or do you have any unusual stories about someone who has? Send your best story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Lisa Beth Lowell, Sam Senturia
description: Dr. Lisa Beth Lowell, a daughter of Roberta and Jon R. Lowell of White Plains, was married yesterday to Dr. Sam Senturia, the son of Juliette D. Senturia of Houston and Harvey Senturia of Lake Jackson, Tex. Rabbi Shira Milgrom officiated at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Miriam Senturia, a sister of the bridegroom, assisted in the service.

title: Olga Valle, Neil Tetkowski
description: Olga Valle, an art administrator, and Neil Tetkowski, a sculptor, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Susan Page, a Lutheran minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Dorothy Kehm, Christopher Holt
description: Dorothy Fulton Kehm, a daughter of Mrs. Walter C. Kehm of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Kehm, was married last evening to Christopher Daniel Holt, a son of Elizabeth and William W. Holt of Orlando, Fla. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Rye.

title: LOS ANGELES
description: It is the fountainhead of hipdom, the front guard of the fashion-forward brigades, the signature street of Los Angeles and also, by the by, possibly the most pedestrian-friendly conglomeration of pocket-friendly restaurants in the city.

title: A Delicacy Of the Past Is a Winner At Drive-In
description: Ponce de Leon Avenue is a fat boy's dream.

title: Boy, 4, and Mother at Bus Stop Hurt When Car Veers Off Road
description: A 4-year-old boy and his mother were critically injured in Brooklyn yesterday morning when a driver who had been eating in his car began choking, swerved off the road and struck them at a bus stop.

description: SLEEPLESS BEAUTY

title: Swifter, Higher, Stronger . . . Gender
description: The Israeli was chatting with the Palestinian in a neutral nation. But the conversation in Lausanne, Switzerland, had very little to do with tenuous peace agreements or tunnels under the Temple Mount.

title: Friends in Deed
description: To the Editor: On Sept. 15, at the conclusion of a visit to Motherwell, Scotland, my wife and I caught the train at the Motherwell station. This train originates in Glasgow and after Motherwell proceeds to Edinburgh and then down the east coast, destination Kings Cross.

title: Feat of Clay
description: THE GOLEM

title: Taking Stock, but No Guff, Mandela Talks of Democracy
description: It is the midpoint of Nelson Mandela's five-year term as South Africa's first democratically elected President, and he settled into a chair in his living room ready to face reporters. It was 7 A.M. He is still an early riser.

title: F.B.I. Questions Salinger on Crash Claim
description: Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, while saying they were certain that Pierre Salinger had no evidence to support his allegation last week that a United States Navy missile brought down Trans World Airlines Flight 800, nevertheless wanted to talk to the former journalist and Kennedy Administration spokesman. Yesterday, F.B.I. agents got that chance.

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: No matter how modest the house or apartment, the two generations of children who grew up in postwar economic prosperity in the United States and in my case, Canada, assumed they would return from school each day to the predictable familiarity of home: a place to eat, do homework, reconnect with siblings and parents and generally get on with growing up, secure and fairly well satisfied with life. But as DeParle wrote, how do you do all that for a child when you live on $4.75 an hour?

title: W.R. Goodwin, 72, Former Johns Manville Chief
description: W. Richard Goodwin, a former president and chief executive of the Johns Manville Corporation, died on Oct. 24 in Denver, where he had lived for many years. He was 72.

title: Forget 'Soccer Moms'; These Boys Just Play Soccer. And How They Play!
description: These pictures by Melchior DiGiacomo, whose usual subjects are professional athletes, document an afternoon in the life of the youth league that plays at Highland Field in Harrington Park. These boys take their soccer seriously, digging in with an intensity that may be available only to 6-year-olds who have not learned other distractions. They practice long hours, in unconventional places: that backboard in the upper right is a garbage container. And when they play, their focus is single-minded.

title: Incumbency Aided Winners, Not Presidential Coattails
description: IN the end, it was the power of incumbency, not the strength of Presidential coattails, that prevailed on Election Night in Westchester, although some results might have been different if certain election districts had been solely within Westchester.

title: Elizabeth Driscoll, Kevin R. Conklin
description: Elizabeth Goulding Driscoll, the director of patient education at the Boston unit of the Shriners Burns Institute, was married yesterday to Kevin Roger Conklin, the middle-school director at Beaver Country Day School in Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. George S. Salzmann officiated at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: Hillary Clinton's Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Bittersweet Journeys Into the Past
description: THE POWER OF THE PAST TO CONTROL the present is sometimes dramatically demonstrated in families. Ancestors peer over the shoulders of their descendants, and not always approvingly. When cultural and racial differences exist, the situation becomes even more complicated.

title: The Mouse That Boogied
description: LILLY'S PURPLE PLASTIC PURSEWritten and illustrated by Kevin Henkes.Unpaged. New York:Greenwillow Books. $15. (Ages 4 and up)

title: No Urban Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: Just What Do the Lawyers Think?
description: AS the newly elected president of the Connecticut Bar Association (founded 1875), Edward Maum Sheehy oversees 11,200 member lawyers.

title: Old Jockeys, New Horses
description: Give them an inch and they will, of course, want a mile.

title: Her Band Plays On, Marching to Victory Time and Again
description: WHO Julie Haran, 30, of New Egypt.

title: Michele Warman, Larry Hirschfield
description: Michele Susan Warman, a lawyer, is to be married today to Larry Edward Hirschfield, a real estate developer. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Knicks Are Winning Despite Their Turnovers
description: When Larry Johnson spun and connected on an arching turnaround jump shot from the left baseline Friday night in Los Angeles, the natural order of the league was still intact.

description: GOLF DREAMS

description: International

description: FLUSHING

description: THE CROW WHO STOOD ON HIS BEAK

title: SHANNON! JAYCIE! DOMINIQUE! AND AGAIN!
description: Jonathan Van Meter's article about the United States Women's Olympic gymnastics team (''Shannon! Jaycie! Dominique! And Again!'' Oct. 20) makes the same odd presumption that many journalists make when discussing teen-age gymnasts -- that all high-school students have active and happy social lives and spend their time at the malt shop, dating, going to proms. My own unscientific survey leads me to the conclusion that perhaps 2 out of 10 people enjoyed their high-school years and that most spent the time feeling out of place and miserable. This was certainly my case; I was short, flat-chested, smart and raised by parents who felt it was more important that I be interesting rather than popular. I thus had no social life at all. It was my involvement in competitive gymnastics that gave me what I was missing. Without it, I would have been home alone every afternoon and evening.

title: Financial Advice Can Come With Many Different Price Tags
description: Financial planners and investment advisers come in many styles: they may have been trained in accounting, investing or law; they may work on their own, in small shops or for large firms.

title: Park Slope Boom Spreads South
description: Eugenio Duval is poised to rise with, or be crushed by, the good times descending on his lower Park Slope street corner. The problem for the 39-year-old bodega owner is deciding what to stock his shelves with.

title: To Machu Picchu, The Hard Way
description: Machu Picchu, the mountain-ringed Inca sanctuary the Spanish conquistadors never found and consequently never destroyed, that was ''discovered'' for the outside world in 1911 by Hiram Bingham, archeologist and later United States Senator from Connecticut, is once again a popular tourist destination. For years fear of Peru's Maoist guerrillas kept many visitors away. From the Andean city of Cuzco, 50 miles to the southeast, you can get there by train in four hours or by helicopter in 25 minutes. But anyone who has trekked in on the Inca Trail, an arduous and spectacular route, will certainly tell you that that is -- if your body is up to it -- the only way to go.

title: Why Silence Isn't Golden During Your Evaluation
description: FOR many employees, the annual performance appraisal is a ritual to be endured. You show up and take your licks or receive glowing reviews. In the end, you hope to get a raise.

title: More Electrified Track on Way
description: A CONTROVERSIAL $1.7 billion railroad electrification project has been approved by the State Department of Environmental Protection, with construction work expected to begin in the next few weeks.

title: Bonnie Cohen And Jeffry Gallet
description: Bonnie Robin Cohen and Judge Jeffry Herschel Gallet are to be married today. Judge Michael Gage, the administrative judge of the Family Court of New York City, is to perform the ceremony at Le Boeuf a la Mode, a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Amy Meadow and Adam Hochfelder
description: Amy Ruth Meadow, a daughter of Dr. Barbara Meyer of Haydenville, Mass., and Dr. Herbert Meadow of New York, was married last evening to Adam Craig Hochfelder, the son of Ellen and James Hochfelder of Glen Head, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: In Cable TV, More Is Less
description: WITH its mix of politicians and plutocrats, high finance and low blows, the feud between Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is a quintessentially New York brawl.

title: Unposed! Rare Campaign Photo Ops.
description: The first campaign photo op probably dates to not long after the first photograph. But, with campaigns becoming more orchestrated and professional handlers routinely shielding their clients from the press and even the public, increasingly the staged photo op -- produced with the most flattering supporting cast and the perfect backdrop -- can be less an opportunity for photographers than for candidates. Which is why unposed images captured during some rare spontaneous moments often are the most revealing and the most enduring. Here are a few from the the 1996 Presidential campaign.

title: Countdown to Danger
description: From the novel by Kenneth Fearing and directed by john Farrow, THE BIG CLOCK (1948) is a bristling melodrama with an offbeat plot and setting. Charles Laughton, as a magazine tycoon, kills his mistress and tries to pin it on one of his executives (Ray Milland, above with Maureen O'Sullivan). As Milland tries to elude a dragnet of colleagues, the suspense is nimbly aided by some good supporting and bit players, including Rita Johnson as the mistress and Elsa Lanchester as a wacky, modern painter. Milland is quite personable but its Laughton's trademark petulance that tightens the noose and adds vicious tingle - THURSDAY at 6:30 P.M. and THURS.-FRI. at 4:45 A.M. on AMC.

title: The Expanding Hispanic Vote Shakes Republican Strongholds
description: The results of Tuesday's balloting around the country made clear that the Democratic-leaning Hispanic vote is becoming an ever larger factor in American politics, nowhere more so than here in Orange County, the sprawling suburb south of Los Angeles that has traditionally been an icon of conservative Republicanism.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Ms. Perlbinder and Mr. Sabella Rosa
description: FRIENDS call Astrid Perlbinder and Cristian Sabella Rosa ''the minimalist couple.''

title: Finding the Path to More Effective Drugs
description: IT has been almost a century since the development by what is now the Bayer Corporation of what is still one of the greatest drugs ever brought to market: aspirin. These days, Bayer's parent company, Bayer AG, employs about 143,000 people in 150 countries producing and marketing more than 8,000 products. And 12,900 people are engaged in research and development.

title: A Silent Rejection
description: To the Editor:

title: Everybody Slept Here
description: UNLIKE most streets in Brooklyn, Middagh Street begins in a neighborhood and stops in midair. Named after a Dutch settler, Aert Middagh, the street runs past a fire station, a rectory, a school, brick and clapboard houses in various states of disrepair, and ends suddenly at No. 12, cut off by the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. One side of the street is now the Harry Chapin playground -- the late singer was a local -- from which you can see the Brooklyn Bridge between two squat modern buildings and, in another direction, lower Manhattan. Past No. 12 the street becomes empty space suspended over the expressway that destroyed it. But Robert Moses' B.Q.E., cutting a great asphalt swath through Brooklyn, demolished more than the neighborhood -- it also made extinct a famous bohemian enclave.

title: Once Again, Downtown's Attraction
description: IN East Hartford the town green is only six months old. A vacant office building was torn down to make space for it. In downtown Stamford, efforts to create an entertainment district have attracted a dozen new restaurants and a half-dozen nightclubs in the last year and a half. In Milford this summer, a city marina opened -- bedecked with a rose garden, walkway and patio -- beckoning customers to downtown businesses.

title: No Turtledoves, but a Flock of Films
description: LIKE THE SEASON ITSELF, HOLIDAY movies seem to start earlier and earlier. Maybe that's simply because there are so many of them. Yes, it's time for 10 times as many movies as anyone actually has time to see, and they're opening practically all at once. Here is a preview of this year's offerings. ANITA GATES

title: In Jammed District, a School Is Half Empty
description: With its growing population of young immigrant families, Community School District 30 has long had classrooms jammed beyond capacity. At the beginning of the school year, it was the eighth most crowded district of the 32 in the city, and one of its junior high schools was under orders from the Chancellor's office to alleviate overcrowding.

title: Maybe It's the Oyster Stew
description: THROUGH storms, floods and the many other catastrophes and reversals that Atlantic City has suffered in the last century, Dock's Oyster House has survived. But don't ask Joe Dougherty Jr. why.

title: Working in Wood Turns Into a Social Occasion at This Club
description: HOW many times have you watched Norm Abram on the ''New Yankee Workshop'' on public television and thought, ''I could do that if I only had that tool,'' or hesitated to buy an expensive tool with only one specialized use? Take heart.

title: A Former Convent Becomes a Co-op
description: IT is an imposing building, on Havemeyer Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a former convent made of mellowed brick piled four stories high, complete with turrets and enormous windows.

title: The Road to La Mancha
description: ''I'm just a storyteller,'' apologizes Miguel de Cervantes, the narrator of Stephen Marlowe's novel THE DEATH AND LIFE OF MIGUEL DE CERVANTES (Arcade, $25.95). But that seems to be more than enough. From the facts of the author's life, judiciously mixed with variants on the adventures of his knight from La Mancha, Mr. Marlowe has fashioned an exuberant, fantastical portrait of Europe and North Africa in the late 16th and early 17th centuries, when the cultures and philosophies of Islam, Judaism and Christianity both mingled and clashed. Mr. Marlowe lets Cervantes speak in a voice of high irony that deftly connects the novel's numerous strands. Here illusion and reality meld: for example, the people Cervantes loves never grow old, even though others can see their wrinkled faces; granted knowledge of the future, he comments with wild comic effect on latter-day critics' assessments of his work. Although there are times when the sheer extravagance of the narration becomes wearing, when events begin to feel redundant, Mr. Marlowe's facility of language and image remains impressive. His novel is a remarkable examination of a tumultuous era in history, of the redemptive force of fiction and of one man's quest for achievement, for a homeland, for love -- and for a way to give of himself to others. Lauren Belfer

title: New Shoes and a Nose Job
description: THE WIZARD OF OZBy L. Frank Baum.Illustrated by Lisbeth Zwerger.103 pp. New York:A Michael Neugebauer Book/North-South Books. $19.95.(Ages 7 to 11)

title: Hotels of a Certain Age
description: Travelers can expect a sense of historical time and place when staying at one of the eight hotels that were recently added to the National Trust's list of Historic Hotels of America. The new members, named last month, include a 19th-century New Orleans mansion with original (though luxuriously refurbished) slave quarters, the Santa Fe retreat of a frontier cleric and, in Omaha, a 1920's rendition of a Florentine palace.

title: Fund Ratings Are Revised
description: THE mutual fund ratings that appear on Sundays in the fund tables of Money & Business have been revised by Morningstar Inc., the fund information company that provides the data. As a result, many funds will show changes in their ratings, starting today.

title: Vanishing Act
description: SEVEN MOVES

title: What Nuremberg Code?
description: At the end of World War II, American judges heard testimony about Nazi doctors performing horrendous medical experiments on whomever they pleased. To insure this would never happen again, the Nuremberg code was written. The first principle of this international code was that no one could be subject to a medical experiment without giving consent. Now, for the first time in the United States, there is an exception to that code.

title: Army Rolls On: Over Air Force And Toward a Perfect Season
description: Those who questioned the strength of Army's schedule can no longer question the determination or skill or preparedness of the Cadets in this marvelous season.

title: Hollywood Adopts the Canon
description: YOU know Shakespeare? William Shakespeare? We're peddling him on the street,'' Al Pacino growls in the distinctive tones of the Bronx in ''Looking for Richard,'' his new documentary about Richard III. And to some extent he has succeeded. ''Richard'' is now playing in 54 theaters nationally, not bad for a documentary, let alone one about Shakespeare. In fact, an MTV-like ''William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet,'' with sex, cross-dressing and rock music -- but still with Shakespearean language -- was No. 1 at the box office last weekend.

title: Health Care Shift In Jackson Heights
description: A lone guard watched over the lobby at Jackson Heights Hospital in Queens, detachedly pointing the infrequent visitor to two slow elevators. Behind him, the hospital's one telephone operator sat in a small office. They were the only people on the first floor, where in room after room, green beds were empty, eerily appropriate symbols for a hospital that is closing.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: JAMES THURBER

title: On Coexisting With Nonhumans
description: You don't have to be four-legged or marsupial to rejoice in the fact that Laura Simon is involved in wildlife rehabilitation in Connecticut (Q&A: ''Raccoons in the Attic? Try Rock 'n' Roll,'' Oct. 3).

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: No Cheap Chirps Here

title: The 97's Have Arrived, and So Have the Rebates
description: Some 1997-model cars and trucks only recently began to arrive at dealerships, and already shoppers are being offered rebates on them. Why offer sales incentives so soon? Auto makers hope the sweeteners will keep sales up as the calendar year draws to an end, and they also soften the blow of 1997 price increases. In lieu of cash rebates, which go directly to consumers, some manufacturers offer financing at special rates, usually from 1.9 percent to 7.9 percent. Dealer incentives, more common among the Japanese auto makers, are paid to dealers to promote a car in any way they wish. In addition to the incentives on 1997 models, many of them listed below, even more generous inducements are offered on most '96 vehicles -- and even unsold 95's -- as dealers try to get rid of aging cars.

title: Certainty of Senses
description: To the Editor:

title: A Partnership of Collages and Sculptures
description: THERE are three violinists playing the Nardin Galleries here, two of them bronze figurines expressionistically modeled, the third a painted wood carving seven feet tall.

title: H.O.V. Lane To Queens Is Snarled
description: HERBERT L. WALD of Douglaston glanced out his front window and shook his head.

title: Finding a Lost Page From a Family History
description: BLINKING back tears, Delores Van Rensalier pushed a shovel into the damp earth in a vacant lot wedged between a Wendy's restaurant and the police and courts complex in downtown Paterson. Beside her, workers were putting up a sign to mark the lot as the location of ''the Huntoon-Van Rensalier Station of the Underground Railroad, 1855-1864.''

title: Hits and Misses at a Sophisticated Gem
description: THE Inn at Great Neck's restaurant is hard to find but worth finding. This sophisticated gem is tucked behind the lobby of a small, discreet, easy-to-pass-by hotel.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Standup Hairdo

title: Thomas Eakins: Oarsmen On the Schuylkill River
description: IN the mid-1980's, Helen Cooper, the curator of American paintings and sculpture at the Yale University Art Gallery, brought together a group of paintings by Winslow Homer on the subject of women playing croquet. The exhibition examined many aspects of the seemingly light theme, which was unfamiliar to most viewers, and made it compelling.

title: MINIVAN CRISIS
description: I too struggled to adapt my personality to the look and feel of a car that most definitely did not suit my image: a silver Buick Park Avenue, a hand-me-down from my parents. When we decided to buy a minivan, it was actually a step closer to my vehicle soul mate. In the past two years I've discovered that my minivan (a Pontiac Transport) does indeed allow my soul to soar, provided it's not full of children on the way to a soccer game and I'm driving alone.

title: Retailers Have Harlem on Their Mind
description: LONG past its legendary prime, the great crosstown thoroughfare wheezed with decay. Mammoth projects intended to stimulate redevelopment were announced by Mayor after Mayor, Governor after Governor, while news reports conveyed assurances that a rebirth of the fabled strip was right around the corner. But the corner was never turned.

title: Holyfield Upsets Tyson in 11-Round Bout
description: Evander Holyfield stunned the boxing world last night, stopping Mike Tyson at 37 seconds of the 11th round at the MGM Grand and ending Tyson's seemingly inexorable march back to the top of the heavyweight division.

title: Looking Out From Behind the Game Face
description: SOMEONE cracked open a window.

title: Chilling Out on the Outer Banks
description: Every December, when luminously wrapped boxes begin to fill the upper shelf of my wife's closet and I'm reminded that it's time to get ready for the upcoming Olympiad of tree trimming, stocking stuffing, cookie and cake confecting, visiting and eating, eating and visiting, I begin to long for clear, clean spaces, pure light, few people or none, and an open sky, with clouds flowing through like freed thoughts. I want to go to the beach.

title: B. Carnow, 74, A Specialist In Health Issues
description: Dr. Bertram Warren Carnow, a thoracic specialist in environmental and occupational health who helped write pollution-control standards and was a consultant to scores of governmental, institutional and industrial clients, died on Monday at Evanston (Ill.) Hospital. He was 74 and lived in Barrington Hills, in suburban Chicago.

title: Illegal Chinatown Peddling Resists Enforcement Efforts
description: To the Editor:

title: But He Smiled for My Birthday
description: THERE was a little ritual on the Dole campaign plane. Reporters, on their birthdays, were given a chance to sit privately with the man who might be the next President of the United States. You could chat for a minute or two and leave with a snapshot.

title: Casting a Wide Web To Catch a Plane
description: Calling an airline to ask whether a plane is on time is often a trip itself, into a long period on hold, or voice mail hell. But for any plane in flight in the 48 contiguous states, a site on the World Wide Web offers a map that shows the plane's route of flight, its location on that route, accurate to two or three minutes, and its expected time of arrival.

title: MINIVAN CRISIS
description: What goes around, comes around. In 1982 I bought a wood-paneled Dodge Aspen station wagon -- the minivan of its era. The same week, my office mate (young and single) bought a Corvette. I remember telling him that my wagon ''may be where I'm at, but it's not where I'm going.'' Today he has school-age children. I can only imagine what he is using to transport them.

title: BROOKLYN
description: I have several times counted the restaurants in the four commercial blocks of Montague Street, Brooklyn. My most recent tally is 29, with culinary style distribution as follows: Italian, 4; Chinese, 3; Japanese, 2; coffee house, 2; Mexican, 2; hamburger joint, 2; ice cream parlor, 2; one each Polish, pizza, Greek, Irish pub, diner, Indian, Blimpie, saloon (self-styled) and neighborhood coffee shop (definitely not house); three that fit no category but yuppie grazing ground.

title: 'I Knew I Needed The Spirit'
description: FROM the opening bell last night, Evander Holyfield wasn't what so many others have been. Evander Holyfield wasn't afraid of Mike Tyson.

title: Rezoning Commercial Land to Meet Housing Needs
description: FOR half a century a 65-acre site in the middle of the Essex County suburb of Nutley was home to ITT. But over the last few years the sprawling building that once housed the company's avionics and military and electronics division was torn down, including its 325-foot research tower.

title: Local Dinosaurs Meet Their Russian Cousins
description: SOME highly unpleasant relatives are visiting Trenton after a very long stay in Russia. Like many distant relatives, they are worth seeing. They will thrill the children, and they can tell us a lot about ourselves.

title: Dengue Fever Alert In Parts of Texas
description: Dengue fever has been increasing worldwide since 1994, and it is now being transmitted in areas of Texas bordering on Mexico. Travelers to that area, as well as to the tropics generally, should take precautions.

title: It's Suffolk, But It Sure Is Different
description: RECENTLY my husband and I moved to the northeast corner of Suffolk County from Amityville, 65 miles away at the county's southwest corner. We still have the county's astronomical property taxes and Lilco rates, but otherwise the contrasts between the two ends of Suffolk could hardly be greater.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: On our recent trip to Tuscany, we were fortunate enough to be able to stay at Relais la Suvera in Pievescola and eat in Arnolfo in Colle di Val d'Elsa -- two pleasures that eluded William Weaver, the author of ''On a Back Road From Siena'' (Oct. 13), when he visited. We were also able to get into San Gimiganano and found the perched fortress well worth the visit.

title: It's Official: Barnes & Noble Plans a Brooklyn Superstore
description: The word had been out in Park Slope for some time: Barnes & Noble is coming. But no one was quite sure when, or quite sure where.

title: As Home Health Care Grows, So Does a New Business
description: THE premise is simple. America is a nation of breaking-down parts. As we age, so do our joints, our backs and our bladders.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 13 about Elizabeth Dole referred incompletely to a hospital she visited during the Presidential campaign. It is St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, not St. Jude's Hospital.

title: An Installation That's Worthy Of the Pharaohs
description: IT IS LUCKY FOR CIVILIZATION that Sir Isaac Newton was sitting under an apple tree when the idea of gravity came to him and not in the vicinity of the Gagosian Gallery in SoHo. Or at least not when Richard Serra was installing his new show, which, weighing in at roughly 222 tons, was his heaviest ever.

title: The Best Illustrated Books of the Year
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1996. The Book Review has annually asked a panel of three judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published each year. The judges this year were Julie Cummins, the coordinator of children's services at the New York Public Library; Sharon Waskow, the librarian at the Scarsdale Middle School; and David Wiesner, whose book ''Tuesday'' won the Caldecott Medal in 1992. As a matter of note, Arthur Geisert, Barbara McClintock, Rosemary Wells and David Wisniewski were winners once before, while Lisbeth Zwerger has been a winner three times previously.

title: The Party Is Over
description: Spectacular evening clothes in which to call it a day.

title: Company History Is No Guide for Investors
description: SELDOM has a company gone public with a longer operating history, or a more dominant position in its market, than Deutsche Telekom. Never has such a history been less relevant.

title: With New Purpose And Look, S.R.O.'s Make a Comeback
description: Single-room-occupancy hotels are making a comeback in New York City, propelled largely by city and state loan programs aimed at creating new housing for the homeless.

title: Breaking Glass
description: he morning of my wedding, my father gave me a piece of unexpected advice. ''When you step on the glass,'' he said, ''why don't you imagine that all the doubts and fears of childhood are inside and that you're smashing them too?''

title: A Sacred Site Reclaimed
description: ELSIE MALPANGKA walked barefoot across the hot, dusty central Australian earth, gathered a small bunch of dried yellow spinifex grass into her hand-carved wira bowl, and began beating it with a stick.

title: Mayor Would Link Opponents to Dinkins
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave a glimpse of his re-election strategy yesterday, vowing to link some of his likely Democratic opponents to what he said were problems of the Dinkins administration.

title: William J. Diamond, Regine Traulsen
description: Regine Traulsen and Commissioner William J. Diamond are to be married today by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at Gracie Mansion.

title: Choosing a Career: Attitudes and Aptitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: Reconstructing a Galloping Crocodile After a Mere 200 Million Years
description: About 212 million years ago, a small galloping crocodile roamed the flood plain that is now the Connecticut River Valley. The bones of nearly all of the creature's vertebrate contemporaries in the region have disappeared, but a three-inch skull of the little crocodile has turned up in exposed rock in a road cut.

title: Quick Trips To Europe
description: IN winter, a long weekend away no longer implies merely a drive to an upstate bed-and-breakfast. It could mean a hotel in a European capital, with a burst of sightseeing and eating fitted in between a night flight from the United States and the flight home. Prices are again appealing; competition among European airlines and travel packagers has meant some trips are cheaper than last year -- but may be going fast.

title: Donna Karan's Lawyers Should See the DSNY Belt
description: To the Editor:

title: DIRTY LOOKS
description: Mary Tannen's ''Dirty Looks'' (Oct. 20) reminded me of an article by the novelist Alison Lurie that I read some years ago. In it, Lurie argued convincingly that the purpose of makeup was to make the wearer look sexually aroused, by mimicking the physical hallmarks of arousal. (The eyes seem larger and wider apart, the lips seem fuller and redder, as do the cheeks.) The point of makeup, then, is to signal to the opposite sex that you are interested.

title: $20 SKIDOO
description: After a bank employee at the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire campus mistakenly filled an A.T.M.'s $5 slot with 20's, word quickly spread, and students dropped their Sunday studies -- some literally running -- to grab the extra money during a five-hour binge. Uplifting note: one youth reported the error, and two infractors surrendered to a campus cop dispatched to guard the cash cow. Bank officials won't reveal how much was initially lost, but say they adjusted students' accounts to deduct ill-gotten gains.

title: Marie Handrich, Robert Kramer
description: Marie Handrich, the daughter of Fred and Nancy S. Handrich of Haledon, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Francis Kramer, the son of Virginia and Robert W. Kramer of Mount Carmel, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Robert H. Pursel performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Selinsgrove, Pa.

title: In Vermont, Milkmen Are Leaving The Scene
description: In his day, Harold Bigelow kept the keys to the town. Six days a week for 25 years, he delivered Monument Farms milk to as many as 400 homes in Weybridge, Middlebury and Cornwall, a sizable portion of the population at the time. And always he carried a large ring loaded with house keys.

title: For Rent: 3-Floor House, 9 1/2 Ft. Wide, $6,000 a Month
description: HAVE you got what it takes to live at 75 1/2 Bedford Street? Start with $6,000 a month, for a freshly renovated rowhouse in the picturesque West Village. Then hire a very small moving van, for the three-story building is the narrowest house in New York City -- only 9 1/2 feet wide on the outside. And it is being named Millay House, after the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay, who lived there in the 1920's.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DEAR FUTURE

title: The Want Ads
description: HELP WANTED: Secretary of State. Salary $148,400, plus yearly C.O.L. raises. Perks: Three weeks annual vacation, unless Iraq invades Kuwait again in August. Own Boeing 707 jet (1960 vintage). Pilots and crew included. Black limousine, with driver. Oak-paneled office with view of the Potomac. Must enjoy international travel, particularly to Syria. Must enjoy spending time with Senator Jesse Helms. Must be able to brief reporters ''on background,'' ''on deep background,'' ''on deepest background,'' ''off the record'' and ''on the record'' all in the same conversation, if not sentence.

title: Behind the Bug
description: Germans sometimes feel that they can never escape their past -- not even in their cars. Last week, after 10 years of research, one of the country's preeminent historians, Hans Mommsen, produced a 1,000-page history of the Volkswagen company, tracing the roots of its most renowned vehicle to Adolf Hitler's hankering for a volkswagen (''people's car'') to motorize the nation.

title: Behind the Good News, a Patchwork of Reasons Why Taxes Rise and Fall
description: When Governor Whitman sliced state income taxes by 30 percent, her critics predicted that a resulting freeze in state aid to schools and municipalities would send local property taxes soaring. Last week, the Governor shared some happy news with the taxpayers (and with fellow Republicans preparing for next year's elections): it hasn't happened.

title: Toughness Isn't Enough For Rangers This Time
description: The Rangers have just one victory in 10 games against the other teams in the Atlantic Division, and people close to the team say there is a reason: other teams in the division are simply stronger and more physical.

title: Design School Gets Building Behind It
description: A redecoration is being planned for the four-story building at 161 East 69th Street, and the work will be in the hands of experts. The New York School of Interior Design has purchased the building behind its headquarters at 170 East 70th Street for $2.7 million, and plans to join the two together to ease crowding caused by growth of the school.

title: Toni Stone, 75, First Woman To Play Big-League Baseball
description: Toni Stone, a scrappy second baseman who became a footnote to baseball history in 1953 as a member of the Negro League's Indianapolis Clowns when she became the first woman to play as a regular on a big-league professional team, died on Nov. 2 at a nursing home in Alameda, Calif. She was 75 and had lived in Oakland, Calif., for many years.

title: Corrections
description: A table with the Behind the Wheel column in the Automobiles section on Oct. 27 misstated the interior volume of the 1997 Ford Taurus G sedan. It is 101 cubic feet, not 117.

title: A Raven as Designed by Committee
description: N.F.L. Properties, based in New York, designs the logos and uniforms for all the league's teams -- an important chore, since the teams' distinctive looks help drive a $3 billion worldwide market for licensed souvenirs. In addition to doing redesigns next season for Tampa Bay, Denver, Cincinnati and Miami, N.F.L. Properties' in-house design agency recently got the opportunity to invent an identity for the N.F.L.'s newest squad, the Baltimore Ravens. Bruce Burke, the agency's creative director, opened up the sketchbooks to demonstrate how it's done.

title: Hold That Reporting
description: To the Editor:

title: St. John's Wins Exhibition
description: The rust, and the unfamiliarity with a new up-tempo style, were evident. But so were flashes of the hustling defense and aggressive offense that Fran Fraschilla hopes St. John's will master.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: An article titled ''Market Day in a Tuscan Town,'' by Frances Mayes appeared on July 19, 1992. It led my husband and me and two Texas friends to make a foray to Camucia from our starting point in Assisi this last July.

title: Better Off Now
description: NOT LONG BEFORE Election Day, I was on the phone to T.W.A. trying to find a way to catch up with Air Force One, which was somewhere in the air over the Middle West on its way to every place at once. The T.W.A. reservations agent, upon hearing my peculiar request, violated the first rule of business -- never talk politics to the customer -- and announced that even though he was a lifelong Republican, he wasn't going to vote for Bob Dole. ''What, you don't want a 15 percent tax cut?'' I asked. ''Oh, PUH-LEASE,'' he said. He went on to talk the kind of talk I'd been hearing all across the country during the campaign, the voice of Average Voter turned Armchair Economist: ''Like, right, cut taxes and balance the budget. I made the mistake of believing Ronald Reagan when he came out with that, and he created a $5 trillion debt.''

title: Inside the Chinese Gulag
description: TROUBLEMAKEROne Man's Crusade Against China's Cruelty.By Harry Wu with George Vecsey.Illustrated. 328 pp. New York:Times Books/Random House. $25.

title: Frankencats
description: The Bengal (a domestic cat breed containing genetic material from the wild Asian leopard), La Perm and the Sphynx (half Vienna sausage?) -- pictured left, from the top -- are among the popular genetic feline mutations that will not be allowed at the Olympics of pedigreed cat shows, the Cat Fanciers' Association International Show, which opens in Anaheim, Calif., on Friday. ''We're very cautious,'' says Michael Brim, a spokesman for C.F.A., his tone implying that others are not.

title: An Author Fishing for Souls of Irish Emigres
description: IN an Irish town, the idea of women fishing is absurd. It's mostly the men who fish, said Colum McCann, a 31-year-old Dublin-born novelist who divides his time between Lloyd Harbor and Manhattan.

title: Drusilla van Hengel, Joshua Patlak
description: Drusilla Ruth van Hengel, a daughter of Drusilla and Maarten van Hengel of Scarborough, N.Y., is to be married today to Joshua Conrad Patlak, a son of Helena and Dr. Erwin Patlak of Jacksonville, N.C. Sheila Lodge, the former Mayor of Santa Barbara, Calif., is to perform the ceremony there at Alice Keck Park.

title: Liquid Launch
description: Distillers agreed to a voluntary ban on radio advertising in 1936 and on television advertising in 1948.

title: Caution: Economic Statistics Are Wrong
description: Imagine you had spent much of your professional life trying to explain something, only to learn that it was all a mistake. What you thought had happened was simply an illusion created by faulty statistics.

title: The Fuzzy Center
description: Here, at the center, it doesn't feel vital.

title: Close to Panama, Dreaming of Rival 'Canals'
description: From the moment it opened in 1914, the Panama Canal has been the envy of nearby countries. For centuries, their governments dreamed of waterways of their own across the Central American isthmus and of the prosperity and power that so busy and vital a trade route would surely bestow on them.

title: A Painter's Images of Mao as Reflected in a Changing China
description: Reflections Abroad

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: As I am fortunate to have a business that takes me to Tuscany several times a year, I was interested in comparing notes with William Weaverespecially upon seeing the photo of La Suvera, where I had stayed a week before.

title: Tangy Sauces With Marinara as the Base
description: A SIMPLE tomato sauce, often marinara bolstered with garlic and basil, is likely to be the partner most frequently selected for pasta. But some other favorites are coming on the scene in restaurants, cookbooks and supermarkets. These other sauces, notably puttanesca, amatriciana, arrabbiata and fra diavolo, offer extra flavor from garlic, hot peppers, and the salty tang of olives and capers. But using marinara as the point of departure, they are all easy to make.

title: Don't Tie Texaco Case to Affirmative Action Foes
description: To the Editor:

title: Straining The Quality Of Water
description: NEW YORK CITY'S drinking water has long been considered one of the city's most precious assets. And while the waters that flow south from the city's upstate reservoirs are arguably as clean and clear as ever, the water that ultimately spurts from spigots to sinks in some areas of the city, it seems, occasionally fails to live up to residents' expectations.

title: Booty's Beneficiaries
description: Back in 1987, Marcelle Hall, the widow of violinist Julian Altman and the executor of his estate, was considered a hero when she surrendered to Lloyd's of London a Stradivarius violin her husband had stolen a half century earlier.

title: Diplomats Cautiously Welcome Ouster of Bosnian Serb General
description: The dismissal of Gen. Ratko Mladic, who has been indicted for war crimes, as leader of the Bosnian Serb Army won support from Western officials today. But foreign diplomats and Bosnian Serb officials warned that it was still unclear whether the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, who announced the general's dismissal Friday night, would succeed in asserting control over the army.

title: Imagine Finding Your Picture On a Virtual Post Office Wall
description: CALL it the wild, wild Web.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Veterans Day

title: On L.I., Never The Twain Shall Agree
description: AS Fred Thiele tells it, the relationship went kaput long ago. Outsiders just couldn't know it.

title: The Player Should Be Allowed To Play
description: IT seems hardly necessary for a court of law to declare that ''life has risks,'' but this was indeed the situation when a Federal judge in Chicago ruled that Nick Knapp, a 6-foot-5-inch, 19-year-old sophomore at Northwestern University, should be allowed to play basketball for the school, which, ironically, had given him an athletic scholarship in the first place and has continued to pay his way.

title: Death at an Early Age
description: TURNING STONES

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today;

title: Making Tracks
description: The labor movement didn't return Congress to Democratic control, but it still had one big thing to boast about last week: It won a contract from Bridgestone/Firestone, the tire maker that unions have been battling for 28 months.

title: It's Only a Movie
description: To the Editor: Aaron Latham's article, ''At Universal, It's Only a Movie'' (Sept. 29) reminded me of an experience my wife and I had at Universal Studios many years ago.

title: Just Speculating
description: THE HIGH-RISK SOCIETY

title: When 50,000 People Need Thanksgiving Dinner
description: The goal is to persuade people to donate frozen turkeys, 3,000 to be exact, in a week-long hustle to place Thanksgiving dinners on the tables of 50,000 people in New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 11 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the conductor Nikolaus Harnoncourt refers incorrectly to the occupations of his three sons. One, who was a violin maker, died in a car accident. The two others sons are alive; one is a surgeon and the other a writer.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: WAR is hell, but in a week that includes Veterans Day, strong films of war and its toll stand out. Yet an old warrior and his autumnal love merit attention, too.

title: Critics Win, Ousting Agency for Mentally Ill
description: The business that moved into a former car service dispatch center on 18th Avenue last year was a mystery, its neighbors said. When they learned that it was an agency for people with mental illnesses, the pressure was on.

title: MINIVAN CRISIS
description: Middle-Aged Minivan Avoidance Syndrome (Mamas), described by Ann Hood, is spreading unchecked, and members of the baby-boom generation seem to be at the greatest risk. Ironically, most victims of Mamas once loved nothing more than to galavant around the country in Volkswagen minibuses. This suggests a cure: just slap a Grateful Dead sticker on the rear window of your Grand Voyager and enjoy the trip.

title: Not Well
description: In the 16th century, the Italians came up with the word influenza because they believed that epidemics were spread by the influence of the stars and planets. Today we know that the flu is spread by influential people coughing and sneezing.

title: Born to Survive
description: REFLECTED GLORY

title: When Your Basic Sport Utilities Start Putting On Airs
description: AS a teen-ager in the muscle-car-mad 1960's, I never fantasized about the pedal-to-the-metal street rods that were burning rubber all around me. My dream machine was a school bus -- a big box high above the road, the better to see anything and everything.

title: The Rails in Wales
description: AT the time my wife, Janet, and I first considered a train tour of Wales, we consulted several guidebooks. One advised that there were two ways to see the country: ''by auto or with great difficulty.'' Another suggested that getting around Wales by public transport would not be easy. A third warned, ''Train stations are few and far between.''

title: Williams to Perform on Guitar
description: BERNIE WILLIAMS, the Yankees' center fielder and a classical guitarist, will make his nightclub debut tomorrow evening at the Bottom Line in Manhattan. As part of the WNEW-FM New Music Concert Show, Williams will perform instrumental tunes and will accompany the rock musician PETE DROGE on songs from Droge's new album.

title: The Last Few Chores of a Fading Season
description: THE outdoor gardening season is winding down, But don't put the tools away just yet. A few chores remain.

title: LONDON
description: There is a small strip of the Fulham Road in Chelsea that hums with so much activity that Tatler magazine recently named it the Beach, after the young, beautiful and barely dressed crowd it attracts during London's long and semihot summer days. The winter chill is setting in now, but the neighborhood is no less busy. And while the restaurants favored by the trendy Beach crowd -- like Kartouche, at No. 329, which has a popular nightclub in its basement -- suggest a kind of of-the-moment snobbery (or, at the very least, require advance reservations), Fulham Road itself is a treasure trove of reasonably priced cafes, snack shops, bistros and bars.

title: Evidence of McSorley's Age Stands Up to Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Someone New in the Driver's Seat on the Airport Run?
description: For 10 years, Denise Daisy has counted on New Jersey Transit's 4:45 or 5:15 A.M. No. 300 Express bus to ride from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan to Newark International Airport, where she works as a customer service representative for Continental Airlines. The bus, she says, has been dependable (a smooth 30-minute trip) and reasonable ($92 for a monthly pass, which slashes the regular $12 round-trip fare to about $4.50).

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 10, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Dell, $7.50.) A woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler. 2 2 SONG OF SOLOMON, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/Penguin, $11.95.) A black man's search for his family's history. 3 3 SILENT NIGHT, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.99.) A family finds adversity and renewed courage during a Christmas visit to New York. 4 4 INTENSITY, by Dean Koontz. (Ballantine, $7.99.) On a weekend visit to a Napa Valley farm, a young woman contends with a serial killer. 5 8 THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Scientists visit a Costa Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs. 6 4 THE WEB, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $6.99.) Alex Delaware encounters a series of macabre events on a tiny Pacific island. 7 3 ABSOLUTE POWER, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $7.50.) Intrigue and murder in Washington. 8 3 PRIMARY COLORS, by Anonymous. (Warner, $6.99.) The progress of a certain Southern governor and his wife on their way to the White House. 9 1 CONTAGION, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $6.99.) A physician seeks to learn why a deadly epidemic has struck a group of hospitals and clinics. 10 57 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) A murder trial recalls the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. (+) 11 4 FROM THE HEART, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $6.50.) Strong women meet strong men in three short novels. 12 3 PANDORA'S CLOCK, by John J. Nance. (St. Martin's, $6.99.) A trans-Atlantic plane bears a passenger carrying a deadly virus. 13 17 THE FIRST WIVES CLUB, by Olivia Goldsmith. (Pocket, $6.99.) Three women conspire to get even with the men who divorced them. 14 6 THE JUDGE, by Steve Martini. (Jove, $6.99.) An attorney defends a judge he doesn't like. 15 1 A DANGEROUS MAN, by Rosemary Rogers. (Avon, $6.99.) In 1846, an ex-Texas Ranger helps a woman escape the shackles of California society. 16* 9 THE GREEN MILE: COFFEY ON THE MILE, by Stephen King. (Signet, $3.99.) The sixth and concluding installment of a thriller set on death row. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 24 SLEEPERS, by Lorenzo Carcaterra. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The true story, the narrator claims, of four boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take. 2 85 REVIVING OPHELIA, by Mary Pipher. (Ballantine, $12.50.) The everyday dangers that beset teen-age girls. (+) 3 9 A CIVIL ACTION, by Jonathan Harr. (Vintage, $13.) A lawsuit brought by Massachusetts householders against industrial polluters. (+) 4 5 HIGH TIDE IN TUCSON, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) Essays about motherhood, nature and other topics by the novelist. 5 2 RUSH LIMBAUGH IS A BIG FAT IDIOT, by Al Franken. (Island/Dell, $6.99.) A television comedian's comments on the political scene. 6* 31 THE LIARS' CLUB, by Mary Karr. (Penguin, $11.95.) A poet recalls her childhood as a member of a troubled family in East Texas. (+) 7 2 MISS AMERICA, by Howard Stern. (Regan Books/Harper Paperbacks, $7.99.) Anecdotes and fulminations from the radio talk show host. 8 5 LONGITUDE, by Dava Sobel. (Penguin, $10.95.) The story of John Harrison, the 18th-century Englishman who invented the chronometer. 9 34 HOW THE IRISH SAVED CIVILIZATION, by Thomas Cahill. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) As the Roman Empire disintegrated, Irish monks copied Western literature. (+) 10* 1 THE REAL WORLD DIARIES. (MTV/Melcher Media/Pocket, $18.)
