A new collection of behind-the-scenes stories and photographs related to the television show ''The Real World.'' 11 5 IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.) The First Lady on ways to create a better society for children. (+) 12 8 MY POINT . . . AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $6.50.) Observations on life by the television star and stand-up comedian. 13* 7 A FEVER IN THE HEART, by Ann Rule. (Pocket, $6.99.) Accounts of six crime cases that occurred in Washington and Oregon. 14 677 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) Inspiration. (+) 15* 111 EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Bantam, $5.99.) A woman's near-death experience. (+) Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 4 THE RULES, by Ellen Fein and Sherrie Schneider. (Warner, $5.99.) The authors offer 35 ''time-tested secrets for capturing the heart of Mr. Right.'' 2 7 IT'S A MAGICAL WORLD, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $14.95.) A new collection of ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 3 111 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE SOUL, compiled by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Stories meant to ''open the heart and rekindle the spirit.'' (+) 4 27 DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (M. Evans, $12.95.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)

title: Germany's Phone Giant Is Bracing for Invaders
description: IT is a telephone company that managed to overcharge 11 million customers last New Year's Day, thanks to a computer glitch. Its prices are among the highest in the world, with long-distance charges more than double those in the United States. It has 207,000 employees, about 37,000 more than it wants, and a hobbling burden of debt. Now, its Government-sanctioned monopoly is about to end, and potential rivals ranging from the German national railway to the electric companies are circling hungrily for a piece of its market.

title: Finding New Life Amid the Vampires
description: THE BLACK, LESBIAN vampires at the center of ''The Gilda Stories,'' a novel by Jewelle Gomez that became an instant classic among feminists when it was published in 1991, gave Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, the artistic director of Urban Bush Women, a new sense of purpose.

title: Parties To Enliven November Nights
description: From celebrations of authors to awards for disabled students.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: One additional hotel to consider when traveling to Colle di Val d'Elsa is the Hotel Villa Belvedere (telephone 0577-920966) just outside the city proper. An 18th-century villa once home to a local aristocrat, it now provides 15 spacious room with modern bath for visitors. A visit to Hotel Villa Belvedere's restaurant alone would merit the trip. A climb to the top of the villa's clocktower makes it possible to see the towers of San Gimignano a few miles to the west; they provide the backdrop to a vision of local vineyards spreading across the rolling Tuscan hills.

title: What, No Sauerkraut? Question Dogs Original Nathan's
description: At the Coney Island Nathan's, diners drop in for the quick, filling bite that is the classic frankfurter. It arrives fast, piping hot, slender, moist and always cherry red. These hot dogs are indisputably the standard. The mustard is there, of course, and so is the relish. Ketchup and onions, too.

title: Sheri Padernacht, Michael Zarkower
description: Sheri Sue Padernacht and Michael Aaron Zarkower, both lawyers, are to be married today in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi A. Allen Block is to officiate at the Surf Club.

title: Swashbuckler
description: THE FLAME AND THE ARROW (1950) turns the simplest of yarns - a genial 12th-century Italian outlaw opposing a ruthless tyrant trying to enslave the land - into fine, dashing fun. In a colorful exercise reminiscent of Douglas Fairbanks and the young Errol Flynn, Burt Lancaster is front and center, teeth gleaming and dominantly athletic. Virginia Mayo (above with Lancaster) makes a prized beauty, and Robert Douglas is amusingly wicked. The script is virgorous and the color production is rich and alive in incident, under Jacques Tourneur's alert direction. Good, clean, lightening fun - THURSDAY at 8:05 P.M. and 11:30 on AMC.

title: Meltdown
description: SAM AND THE TIGERS

title: Allen Is About to Rush Into the Record Books
description: When Marcus Allen takes the field at Arrowhead Stadium this afternoon against Green Bay, he will be only a few steps from landing in the National Football League record books as one of the greatest running backs to ever play the game.

title: Librarian Shares Her Experiences Of Trip to Zimbabwe
description: AFTER a six-month educational sojourn in Zimbabwe, a librarian, Malikah Dada Lumumba, has returned here, ready to share the wealth of her experience.

title: With Wheatley Injured, the Giants Are Looking Toward Elias
description: The letter was from the National Football League, and Tyrone Wheatley opened it patiently and slowly. He wasn't in a hurry. He never is. He goes to a different beat than most and it is one of the things that makes him unusual, makes him a good running back and sometimes makes coaches crazy.

title: Kirsten Turchik, William Russell 3d
description: Kirsten Elizabeth Turchik, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James B. Turchik of Syracuse, was married yesterday to William Odell Russell 3d, the son of Linda W. Russell of Washington and Mr. Russell Jr. of Dallas. The Rev. Stephen B. Swann performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Syracuse.

title: In The Lap of Japanese Luxury
description: ONE of the great joys of traveling in Japan is the opportunity to stay at elegant ryokan, where guests can experience a way of life that has become foreign even to many Japanese. The gracefully proportioned rooms of these traditional inns are detailed with rich natural woods and sliding papered shoji screens. The delicate scent of fresh tatami mats usually fills the air. Meals, works of art themselves, are taken in your room with service provided by one or more kimono-clad maids. In better ryokan, rooms also afford garden views. Hot baths, or ofuro, are always available, and you sleep on luxurious, fluffy futons laid out on the floor at night.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE LAST TIME I SAW MOTHER

title: !Beatles, Si!
description: ''Most of their early music is 'I love you, you love me' -- 7- and 8-year-olds can understand that,'' says Ernesto Juan Castellanos, a 33-year-old former teacher from Havana. ''With older kids we move into ''Magical Mystery Tour'' or ''Sgt. Pepper's'' -- which are filled with metaphors and poetry. . . . Psych-e-del-ic, too,'' he adds.

title: Bad Cop
description: TOWARD the end of 1993, just before Michael Walsh's world came crashing in, he took a graveyard shift job as a security guard at McDonald's. Sure, it was degrading, but the lunacy at the 30th Precinct was wearing him down, he says. As rumors of stings and informers swirled around the Harlem station house, he found it increasingly difficult to eat or sleep, and his wife started to worry. Moonlighting at McDonald's, he figured, might keep him out of trouble.

title: Cats and Dogs, Yes. But a Girl? Never!
description: To the Editor:

title: Texaco's Tale of the Tape
description: Texaco Inc. was rocked last week by the disclosure of a tape recorded conversation among senior executives who were caught not only plotting to destroy evidence sought in a discrimination suit brought by minority employees against the company, but also belittling those employees. The actions of the executives -- including Robert Ulrich, the former treasurer; J. David Keough, then Texaco's senior assistant treasurer, and Richard A. Lundwall, then the senior coordinator for personnel services at Texaco's finance department -- are now under criminal investigation. Here s are excerpts of the conversation, as reported in court records.

title: New Twists From Philharmonic Conductor
description: WITH several thousand miles and just a few days before his first subscription concert with the Long Island Philharmonic, David Lockington, the new music director-conductor, sounded chipper, cheerful and at full throttle at an hour when many people are just waking up.

title: Queens Prosecutor Won't Seek Death Penalty in Stabbings
description: The Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, has decided not to seek the death penalty against a homeless man who has been charged with stabbing a man and a woman to death in their Jackson Heights home in June.

title: Confidentiality And Managed Care
description: In the article about Dr. Herbert S. Sacks and managed care (Q&A: ''A Psychiatrist Talks About Social Policy,'' Oct. 27), Dr. Sacks misses the mark regarding the importance of confidentiality and the role of the Medical Information Bureau as it pertains to the process of applying for life or disability insurance.

title: How to Leap Before You Look: Lessons for a Digital World
description: IN an R. R. Donnelley & Sons printing plant in Crawfordsville, Ind., there is a world-class press that once ran day and night, producing sets of encyclopedias that would anchor the bookshelves in family rooms throughout North America. Today, it is quiet most of the time. I don't think it will ever run again on a regular basis.

title: Just When Guys Thought It Was Safe, Kablooey!
description: FELLOW Gentlemen,

title: Picking Up a Fashionable Pace
description: In shape, on time and looking great: these runners were among the 7,406 women who completed the New York City Marathon last Sunday. And a mile from the finish line, all were doing it with style.

title: A Recluse, A Lost Era
description: THE GOLDEN AGE'' is A. R. Gurney's homage to other voices, other times. It is the tale of a recluse, once the belle of the literati, the very model of gentility and the best party giver, now fussing to get a beau for her granddaughter, a society drop-out. Theatergoers are bound to overhear echoes of Tennessee Williams throughout.

title: SLAMMING THE DOOR
description: The minimum wage of $4.75 an hour yields an annual salary of $9,880 for a 40-hour week. But add a Saturday job, or perhaps an evening position, and it yields $11,856. Throw in a spouse working the same hours and you're up to $23,712. What most poverty writers fail to mention is that wealthier people, by and large, work longer than 40-hour weeks, and many have working spouses.

title: Man Accused in Muggings
description: A homeless man arrested during an attempted robbery in midtown Manhattan on Friday has been charged with six subway muggings, the police said yesterday.

title: Dartmouth Silences Lions to Lead Ivy
description: Earlier in the week, Dartmouth Coach John Lyons said, ''Our approach this week is that we are playing for the Ivy League championship on Saturday.''

title: Pondering the Math Of Nature's Design
description: IT'S that kind of museum where art, science and nature meet, where worlds within worlds are exposed as new ways of seeing are probed. ''Order and Chaos: Patterns of the Natural World,'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through April 27, typifies one kind of interactive family exhibition the Bruce is becoming known for.

title: Post-Fashion Show Bargains
description: November and December are hot months for sample sales, with more than 70 this week. The fashion shows just ended so designers, manufacturers and middle men have time to open their doors to sell off their excess inventory to the public. Merchandise is generally at least half off the retail price, sometimes more. Biggest savings are on damaged merchandise, items from last season and those made in sample sizes (for men, small; for women, size 6 and 8).

title: History Lesson
description: Heat WaveBy Penelope Lively.215 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $22.

title: Bonespotting
description: DINOSAURS OF THE FLAMING CLIFFSBy Michael Novacek.Illustrated by Ed Heck.367 pp. New York:Anchor Books/Doubleday. $24.95.

title: Sun Devils Get Their Rose Bowl Ticket
description: They are unbeaten, untied and untidy.

title: Postwar Italy
description: Much of the irony of John Hersey's novel A BELL FOR ADANO, which was evident also in the Broadway play, is missing from the 1945 Henry King Movie. This appealing story, however, has solid merit in the central, earnest performance of young John Hodiak as an American offering supervising a small Italian two that is purged of its Nazi occupiers. The grateful villagers now want a bell restored to their city hall. Not all the scenes work - like tepid suggestion of romance with a local blonde. But best of all, in pantomime, is the homecoming scene of the village men. The picture nevertheless leaves a good taste of a postwar town in Italy - SATURDAY at 10 A.M. on CINEMAX.

title: Those Gender-Gap Blues
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato's political antennae are as sensitive as a lobster's. True, only a third of the voters say they approve of his performance in office. But there is probably no other politician in America with a 34 percent approval rating who has such a keen sense of what his constituents are thinking.

title: A World Of Spirits Who Defy Science
description: AGHOST WALKS THE CORRIDORS OF A hospital and comforts a patient during surgery; a nurse kneels by a dying man's bed and prays for a miracle; a young woman's behavior is either saintly or insane, who's to say? Lars von Trier's films exist in a peculiar territory where science and the spirit world collide, yet he makes that place seem the most natural on earth.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Race Rules

title: Capturing the Man Who Caught Eichmann
description: PETER Z. MALKIN, the Israeli agent who captured Adolf Eichmann in 1960, was really two people. The first was the man of action, the Mossad spy who surprised Eichmann when the former Nazi stepped off a bus in a Buenos Aires suburb and spirited him away to a safe house and eventually to Israel to stand trial for war crimes. The second Mr. Malkin was the intellectually curious man who sat with Eichmann for 10 days in a small room, trying to enter the mind of a man who sent millions of Jews, including Mr. Malkin's sister and her child, to their deaths.

title: Secret Bosnian Arms Deals
description: The Bosnian Muslims have never hidden the fact that if the Dayton peace agreement failed to unify all of Bosnia, their army would try. They appear to be headed in that direction already. European intelligence agencies have uncovered clandestine arms shipments going from Malaysia and Turkey to the Muslim army in Bosnia.

title: Danielle K. Sanjenis, John L. Bown
description: Danielle Kathryn Sanjenis, the daughter of Julie and Michael Sanjenis of New York, was married yesterday to John Louis Bown, a son of Louise and Robert Bown of Cheshire, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Earth-Friendly Bullets Are Goal of Army Project
description: Bullets may be designed to kill people, but they shouldn't hurt the environment. At least that's the goal of a project at Picatinny Arsenal in Rockaway Township.

title: Lynn Ginsberg, Joshua M. Margo
description: Lynn Ellen Ginsberg, the daughter of Carol and Jerome Ginsberg of New York, is to be married today to Joshua M. Margo, a son of Abbie and Philip Margo of Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Chaim Seidler-Feller is to perform the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: ISTANBUL
description: On the shores of the Bosporus, a few miles north of the ancient neighborhoods where Istanbul's great monuments are clustered, lies the cobblestone Ortakoy quarter. Packed into a 10-square-block area between the shore road and the water are scores of cafes, restaurants, bars and a permanent flea market offering carpets, antiques and all manner of handicrafts. A synagogue, an Orthodox church and a magnificent 19th-century mosque give this neighborhood some of the cosmopolitan verve for which old Constantinople was renowned.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Polly Klaas's Hometown Relives Its Nightmare
description: When Ginny Ranta, a Polly Klaas Foundation volunteer, was visiting friends in Oregon last week, she saw an item in a local newspaper about an attack on a 12-year-old girl in Petaluma. She was certain, she said, it was an old paper.

title: Rare Day for Labontes: Race, Title, Emotions
description: If the Labonte brothers, two of the lowest of low-key personalities, were ever going to register some excitement, today was the day for it.

title: Thanks for the Honesty
description: To the Editor:

title: True believers in the Internet are defining life these days in rather expanded terms.
description: WE are living in organic times.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Pakistan's Ouster of Bhutto Was Constitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentucky Faces Tradition Of Offensive Road Names
description: Even though the seasons change, time sometimes seems to move no more than the hills in eastern Kentucky.

title: Green Light Caper
description: Returning from Richard Nixon's funeral on Air Force One, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott told National Security Adviser Tony Lake that Croatia had asked our ambassador for approval to smuggle Iranian arms into Bosnia -- thereby breaking the embargo foolishly agreed to by the U.S. and its allies.

title: Fire From Hip Isn't Friendly. It Just Hurts.
description: RICHARD PENZER, whose sister, Judith, was killed in the Trans World Airlines Flight 800 explosion, is nothing short of furious at Pierre Salinger, the former White House press secretary who is promoting a debunked conspiracy theory to explain the crash, which took 230 lives. It was ''friendly fire'' from a Navy ship on maneuvers, Mr. Salinger said.

title: Playing Like a Knick, Brooks Starts to Fit In
description: The Knicks were putting Vancouver in its place midway through the third quarter tonight when their well-mannered reserve point guard, Scott Brooks, acted completely out of character.

title: Workaday Racism
description: What a surprise. All the black jelly beans at Texaco seemed to be glued to the bottom of the bag.

title: A Dismal First Half Didn't Shake Parcells
description: It seemed like a good time for Bill Parcells to tighten up like a snapped chin strap, to discard the new whistle-while-you-work demeanor he has worn as a part of his loose-fit wardrobe this year.

title: China Announces Trade Penalty as Reply to Similar U.S. Move
description: China announced a ban on imports of selected goods from the United States today, stepping up a trade dispute with the Clinton Administration and sending a blunt signal that it will not easily succumb to pressure.

title: It has long been known there is oil in tar sands. Now, perhaps, there's a better way to get it out.
description: THE Athabasca tar sands of Alberta, Canada, first captured William J. Rosenbloom's imagination some six decades ago. The tar sands hold enormous amounts of oil, but extracting that oil is an arduous and expensive process.

title: Lotto's Losers Still Dream, Waiting for Winners
description: They are out there somewhere, perhaps stuffed into a glove box in Queens or a pocketbook in Lackawanna, N.Y.: slips of red-and-white paper with tiny printed numbers, no more important-looking than a grocery receipt.

title: David Lachenbruch, Television Expert, 75
description: David Lachenbruch, a writer and editor who was a respected voice in the world of consumer electronics for four decades, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 30 about a 1971 underground test of a nuclear warhead in Alaska for an antiballistic missile defense system referred incorrectly to the system's deployment. The system was operated by the Pentagon for six months in 1975; it was not canceled without being deployed.

title: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: New Ball Parks Won't Educate Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Some trivial circumstances combined to change the result of a semifinal match in the World Team Championships in Rhodes, Greece, early this month. After 95 of 96 deals in the open semifinal between Indonesia and Denmark, it appeared that Denmark had a decisive lead of 11 imps. The last deal was a part-score, which apparently could not change the outcome, so the Danish supporters watching in the Vugraph theater let out a whoop of triumph. This was audible to the players, who could hear more whooping as Danes gathered in the corridor outside.

title: A Washington Vendetta
description: As a State Department official, Richard Nuccio served his country honorably last year when he informed a member of Congress about Central Intelligence Agency misconduct in Guatemala. He has been paying for it ever since.

title: New York Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Diane Morales, 52, Community Adviser
description: Diane Margo Morales, special assistant for families and children to the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, died on Nov. 1 at New York Hospital. She was 52 and lived in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Shostakovich on Death, Bleak but Still Compelling
description: There was a small but steady exodus from the Carnegie Hall audience on Saturday night during the performance of Shostakovich's Symphony No. 14 by the chamber orchestra Orpheus. It was not that the performance was lacking. This was an involving, superbly played account of this unorthodox symphony for soprano, baritone and an orchestra of only strings and percussion. And it could not have been a case of mainstream listeners fleeing some ''crazy modern piece,'' for the musical language of this 1969 work, though murky, drenched in chromaticism and angst ridden, is accessible and clear textured.

title: 2 Executives Quit Chiat/Day Office
description: The two top executives at the St. Louis office of TBWA Chiat/Day -- Lloyd Wolfe, chairman and creative director, and Bill Freeman, president and chief operating officer -- have resigned over what they described as philosophical differences.

title: As Zaire Splits, History Repeats Itself
description: Nearly 20 years ago, a modest rebel force swept across the border into Zaire from neighboring Angola and in the space of a few days captured much of this country's copper-rich Shaba province.

title: Beyond Barbie: Games by Women
description: AS Gillian Bonner was demonstrating her video game at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, a woman dressed in an American flag string bikini and high heals stood in a cage waiting to have her picture taken. One after another, socially challenged young men wrapped their arms around her, smiled as the flash erupted and ducked out. Safely outside the bars, less bold men inspected her through the long zoom lense of a handheld video camera.

title: Marathon Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Rolfe, Actress, 79
description: Mary Rolfe, a radio and stage actress, died on Oct. 28 at Maui Memorial Hospital in Hawaii. She was 79 and lived in Paia, Maui.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close of the session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 135.96 points -- or more than six-tenths of 1 percent -- at 21,065.08. On Friday, the Nikkei index soared, gaining 429.93 points.

title: Sterling Forest Bill Is Ready
description: President Clinton will sign a long-awaited parks bill tomorrow that includes $17.5 million to buy and protect Sterling Forest, a White House spokeswoman said Friday. The bill passed Congress in the last days of the 104th Congress, which ended in early October.

title: Reader's Digest To Ogilvy & Mather
description: The Reader's Digest Association has selected Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York as the first agency to handle worldwide advertising and direct marketing. Billings have not been determined.

title: Brinkley, Goodbye
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet search engines seek help from Madison Avenue to find more users and advertisers.
description: THE Internet directory and navigation services known as search engines, once seemingly as exotic as butterflies in Antarctica, are now almost as commonplace as detergents in Safeway. So like the marketers of detergents and other packaged goods, companies that operate search engines are turning to Madison Avenue to distinguish themselves through advertising.

title: Corrections
description: The When Money Counts column in The Home Section on Thursday omitted a byline. The writer was Marianne Rohrlich.

title: Taxing Rentals for Tourists
description: Tourism drives Ocean City's economy. Each summer, the beach resort's population swells from 15,000 to 125,000. But tourists, some city leaders have noticed, use a lot of city services and do not pay property tax -- not directly, anyway -- in a city where taxes have been increasing an average of 9 percent per year for several years.

title: Congress Won't Act. Will You?
description: The 1996 election will go down in history as one in which campaign money completely overwhelmed the American political process. But this could also be remembered as the year when Americans finally became fed up enough to start taking their democracy back from the power of money.

title: A Growing Isolation As Campuses Plug In
description: Life on college campuses once focused on mingling at the student union. But as computers have proliferated in classrooms and dormitory rooms, E-mail has become a favored means of communication, and the melting-pot aspect of campus life has given way to a sort of electronic isolation. On some of the nation's campuses, the number of E-mail messages processed each day is in the hundreds of thousands.

title: No Headline
description: ''E-mail is like the god of every college student. People probably spend easily three hours a day sending and receiving messages. It's the No. 1 way that romances go on at colleges. It's like the dating game on line.'' ABIGAIL BUTLER, a recent graduate of Vassar College. $(A12:3$)

title: BIPARTISAN MOOD STARTING TO FADE ON POTENT ISSUES
description: The harmony that has prevailed between Republicans and Democrats since last week's elections began to break down today as the Senate's top Republican disagreed with President Clinton and the House Democratic leader on campaign financing and Medicare.

title: $15,000 Theft at Token Booth Is a Quiet Affair
description: A woman posing as a token clerk quietly stole $15,000, mostly in tokens and Metrocards, from a booth at the subway station by the Plaza Hotel yesterday morning, the police said.

title: A Sitcom Family Confronts Marijuana
description: Marijuana! Reefer madness! Did you-know-who inhale or not inhale 25 years ago? The hypocrisy surrounding the subject of pot is astounding. Even the electorate seems to be fed up with it. A gesture toward perspective is attempted tonight in, of all places, a sitcom. CBS's ''Ink,'' starring Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen, delicately tackles a subject that tends to leave so-called drug czars looking like fools.

title: Franco's Foes Return, With Wheelchairs and Memories
description: Irving Gold came in a wheelchair. Others used canes or just walked slowly into the Madrid Sports Palace. Old soliders all, they proudly wore their berets and insignias.

title: Mistakes Bury the Giants' Hopes
description: Maybe it was because the game was on national television. Being so close to Broadway and all, the Giants do like drama.

title: Infoseek Updates Service
description: The Infoseek Corporation, a leading Internet software maker, plans to announce this week a new version of its popular navigation service and a shift in its corporate strategy intended to distinguish it from other Internet search services.

title: Welfare Rules Intensify Need For Day Care
description: The new Federal welfare law is creating a huge demand for subsidized child care, setting up an intense competition between working poor families and welfare recipients who are required to work for their benefits.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Roy Harris's Idea of America: Bold, Rough and Optimistic

title: Queensboro To Restore Old Routes As of Today
description: Four weeks after traffic planners' dreams of easing congestion around the Queensboro Bridge turned into a nightmare, city officials were to restore the normal traffic pattern today, with fingers crossed that the addition of a temporary Queens-bound lane would reduce rush-hour gridlock -- and complaints.

title: A Pair Of Singers Who Don't Just Sing
description: How large a space is there in today's pop climate for smart, introspective singer-songwriters who work in the gray area where folk-rock meets art song? As the careers of Paula Cole and Holly Palmer unfold, their fortunes should give a pretty clear indication of the commercial future of a tradition pioneered by Laura Nyro and Joni Mitchell, and carried on by the likes of Suzanne Vega, Rickie Lee Jones and Tori Amos.

title: Shakur's Reflective Finale
description: Musicians may have clause after clause in their contracts guaranteeing them artistic control over their recordings. But once they are dead, there's no telling what a record company can do to their legacies. After Marvin Gaye was shot dead by his father in 1984, his record label, Columbia, put out two substandard albums of unreleased material that Mr. Gaye might never have allowed to reach his fans' ears. After Kurt Cobain of Nirvana committed suicide in 1994, his record label, Geffen, waited eight months and then released ''MTV Unplugged in New York,'' a moving acoustic performance that served as a beautiful epitaph for the singer and guitarist.

title: Accounts
description: * Maxwell Shoe Co., Readville, Mass., to Greenberg Seronick O'Leary & Partners, Boston, to handle advertising for the Sam & Libby brand of women's shoes, which had been inactive. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Learning How to Cope

title: Taxes for a Baseball Stadium
description: If you build it, they may come, but to build it you have to tax them first, officials in North Wildwood say. Senator James S. Cafiero, Republican of North Wildwood, introduced a bill last Thursday that would send half of the sales tax the state collects in the Wildwoods back to the Greater Wildwoods Tourism Improvment and Development Authority to help pay for a new baseball stadium and convention center. Mr. Cafiero said the measure would send $3.75 million a year to the towns.

title: The Torsilieris Deliver the Rockefeller Tree, Once Again
description: Phone lines have been rerouted, electrical wires relocated. A crane that can handle 175 tons is to be used, along with a custom-made tractor-trailer.

title: The Rest Is Silence
description: Francisco Lucas Rodriguez-Roman grew up in Cuba detesting Fidel Castro's Communist system. A college graduate and teacher, he went into the merchant marine with the hope that some day it would give him a way out. After a few years he had his chance, jumped ship and sought asylum in the United States.

title: 4 Marketers Change Agencies
description: Four marketers have changed agencies after reviews.

title: Hammering a Nail as an Art, Not an Act of Terror
description: TOOLS OF THE TRADE

title: Routing Makes Cisco Systems A Powerhouse Of Computing
description: When Citicorp decided to upgrade its computer systems for the age of the Internet last year, the bank's technology executives decided for sanity's sake to hire a single contractor capable of providing the hardware, software and expertise to link their worldwide enterprise. With those criteria set, the choice for Citicorp became obvious: Cisco Systems Inc.

title: Slow Transition for Investing: Stock Market Meets Internet
description: Despite the millions of dollars that Wall Street spends each year on computers and high-tech gadgetry, in many ways its business has not changed much since the 18th century, when brokers gathered under a buttonwood tree to buy and sell shares.

title: Leveling Spending on Schools
description: The Senate Education Committee will get down to the nitty-gritty of evening out spending differences between rich and poor school districts when it meets on Thursday. New Jersey has until year's end to satisfy a 1994 State Supreme Court order to equalize spending. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and both houses of the Legislature have proposed solutions, but people close to the negotiations said Friday that the final plan would probably be different from anything proposed so far.

title: Lord Sherfield Is Dead at 92; Was British Envoy to the U.S.
description: Lord Sherfield, a British career diplomat who, as Sir Roger Makins, was Ambassador to the United States from 1953 to 1956, died on Saturday in Basingstoke, England. He was 92 and lived in a farmhouse near Basingstoke in Hampshire.

title: J. Kevin McNiff, 64, Prison Reformer and Ex-Priest
description: J. Kevin McNiff, who left the priesthood to pursue a personal path of service to the downtrodden and followed it all the way into politics and a vocation in the New York State prison system, died on Nov. 2 at his home in Delmar, near Albany. He was 64.

title: Offerings of Equities Expected for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday showing leading retailers' sales in October misstated the last year's percentage change for Talbots in stores open at least a year. Such sales rose -- they did not fall -- by 2.3 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a vote by shareholders of Wallace Computer Services Inc. against a proposal on takeover bids misstated the number of votes required for passage. It was a majority of shares represented at the shareholders meeting, not a majority of shares outstanding.

title: Bosnian State Is Neither Possible Nor Desirable
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Hill's Big Day Delays Allen's Record Day
description: This was supposed to be a coronation. The Chiefs' Marcus Allen entered today's game needing just one rushing touchdown to take the career lead from Walter Payton.

title: Negotiating The Twists In Skiing And Life
description: What can you say about Spalding Gray that he hasn't already said?

title: David S. Lifson, Author and Teacher, 87
description: David S. Lifson, a businessman, teacher, author and playwright, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Andre Singer, Composer and Teacher, 89
description: Andre Singer, a composer, pianist and professor emeritus of music at Sarah Lawrence College, died on Nov. 1 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Fordham's Tower, Part II
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutors Seek Clues in Newborn's Death
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that it would not prosecute a 15-year-old girl, Keisha Simmons, who has been accused of dumping her newborn daughter in the garbage, unless it found more evidence that she had killed the child.

title: As Latin Leaders Meet, Castro's Attendance Is Questioned
description: As Latin American heads of state gathered for their annual summit conference here today, a bitter debate erupted over Fidel Castro's presence at the meeting, which is focusing on the expansion of democracy.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A Prosperous Securities Industry Is Urged to Accrue Trust
description: Stockbrokers, strategists and other financial professionals are happy because the stock market seems set for one of its best years ever, but many also express increasing concern, even anxiety, about the future. Many ask: How can things stay this good for this long?

title: Fuss Outside Court Sends Drive-By Spectator Inside
description: At the Alex Kelly rape trial here, Mr. Kelly is often the object of contempt. ''Rapist,'' a woman muttered in the courtroom one day.

title: Tell-All Books About the Duchess of York Compete With Her Own Version of Her Life
description: Her autobiography will not be in stores until Wednesday. But the Duchess of York -- the woman whose name will probably always be inextricably linked with the phrase ''toe sucking'' -- has been all over the news here for weeks, as a former friend and a former ''spiritual adviser'' have rushed their own not-so-flattering books into print.

title: As Unpopular Gowanus Overhaul Looms, a Tunnel Plan Gains Notice
description: For years, residents of western Brooklyn have dreaded the upcoming reconstruction of the Gowanus Expressway, a project that would swamp neighborhoods with traffic for at least five years. But an alternative may be emerging: replacing the crumbling elevated expressway with an underground highway.

title: Whitman's Trade Trip Shows Its Political Edge
description: With Israeli soldiers facing angry Palestinians just three miles away, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey planted a tree that she said symbolized life in the rocky soil of a new forest.

title: Investigation Finds No Evidence of Slur On Texaco Tapes
description: Outside investigators hired by Texaco Inc. have concluded from an analysis of a tape recording that a senior company executive did not use a highly charged racial epithet at a 1994 meeting, though a transcript of the recording, filed in court papers, said he did.

title: Desperately Seeking Surfers
description: Robert Thrasher is out to trick the search engines.

title: Lane for Trucks on Bridge
description: Traffic flow on the George Washington Bridge is expected to speed up a bit starting Wednesday when an exact-change lane for trucks only goes into effect for a three-month trial. The eastbound Lane 14 on the upper level will be restricted to trucks during the morning and evening rush hours, and car drivers who try to use it will face summonses, said Terry Benczik, a spokeswoman for the Port Authority.

title: Graf to Play In Advanta
description: The Advanta Championships got some good news and some bad news yesterday. Top-ranked Steffi Graf, reconsidered an earlier decision and decided she would play this week in Philadelphia despite having a chronically sore left knee.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Homage to Klee Reflects

title: American Dreams Of the 50's, Seen Darkly
description: Though ''The High Life'' is supposedly set in Pittsburgh in the 1950's, this offbeat comedy series truly lives in a more intriguing place: a parallel universe where a sitcom is a dark version of ''The Honeymooners'' and the American Dream of the 50's is depicted as greedy, intolerant and high in cholesterol. Earl (Mark Wilson) is the loud, beefy Ralph Kramden character, who always has a get-rich-quick scheme and a foolproof instinct for putting his foot in his mouth. He owns a storage company (more like a storage room) with Emmett (Robert Joy), the wary, sad-sack Ed Norton-style sidekick. Earl's wife, Irene (Betsy Aidem), is a whiny version of the eternally patient Alice Kramden.

title: C. E. Woodruff, 80; Was Bank Executive
description: Charles E. Woodruff, a former vice chairman of Manufacturers Hanover Trust, died on Nov. 2 in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Key Largo, Fla., and Linville, N.C.

title: New Rivals and Pending Merger Force a Company to Focus on Service
description: For Robert Dieterich, life as a Nynex customer finally became intolerable last spring, when he started getting calls for Randi Baker, his next-door neighbor in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Clinton May Be Pressured to Act on Global Stage
description: Faced with a Republican Congress, President Clinton, like many second-term Presidents before him, is likely to focus on foreign policy.

title: The President's Next Welfare Test
description: President Clinton will have to work with the Republican Congress to keep his promise to fix the welfare law that he signed over the protests of many Democrats. But his Administration has sole control of the implementation of a potentially punitive provision of the new law. That provision would knock children off disability rolls. How well Mr. Clinton protects those children will provide the first post-election test of his resolve to block Congress's worst impulses.

title: Equestrian Troupe Adds Performance
description: An additional, and final, performance of ''Chimere'' by the French equestrian theater group Zingaro has been scheduled for tomorrow night at 8 at Battery Park City by the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Despite Narrow Victory, Republican Is Unbowed
description: J. D. Hayworth has just survived the most expensive Congressional race in Arizona's history, squeaking by with less than half the vote and one of the narrowest victory margins of the 70 Republican Congressional freshmen who ran for re-election last week.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: A Master's Improvisations,

title: Gains Seen in Fish Market Crackdown
description: The Giuliani administration says its campaign to remove corruption and the Mafia from the Fulton Fish Market is paying off in slightly lower fish prices and in a greater supply of fish, but some wholesale dealers, retail merchants and union leaders dispute the findings.

title: For Brown and His Distrustful Public, It's Not a Love Affair Quite Yet
description: THE Giants were playing for their season last night. But the season, like the game, slipped away.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 1 about J. Edward Day, the Postmaster General who introduced the ZIP code system in 1963, misstated the history of his home ZIP code in Chevy Chase, Md. It was originally 20015; later it was changed to 20815.

title: Legislator Presses to Revive Effort for Peace in Ulster
description: John Hume, the mainstream Roman Catholic political leader in Northern Ireland, said today that he had made new proposals to the British Government intended to revive the flagging peace effort in the British-ruled province. The peace talks, which began in Belfast on June 10, have been in deadlock and a bombing attack by the Irish Republican Army last month intensified fears for their prospects.

title: Here Is Why Holyfield Was Not Afraid of Tyson
description: IT was as if Evander Holyfield were an evangelist missionary beating up a tribal executioner, a teacher's pet battering the schoolyard bully, a friendly sheriff gunning down the notorious gunslinger.

title: The Bully Gets Bullied, And the Underdog Reigns
description: As midnight approached on Saturday, the most feared fighter in the world buried his face in a white towel, pressing it against the red welts above his eyes. Mike Tyson, the master of menace, was a loser.

title: In Mamaroneck, Anger and Anxiety Over the Return of Anti-Semitic Graffiti
description: Four houses and a shed on a golf course in the town of Mamaroneck in Westchester County were defaced with swastikas and other anti-Semitic graffiti late last week, recalling incidents in the adjacent village of Mamaroneck earlier this year and sparking fresh outrage among local residents.

title: Feathers and Fireworks In the Jungles of Brazil
description: Placido Domingo's debut tonight as artistic director of the Washington Opera lacked neither color nor fireworks, although both were of the literal sort, not the metaphorical and purely musical kind that operagoers prefer.

title: No Way to Choose Judges
description: The idea of holding elections to choose judges sounds a lot better in theory than it works in practice. The unseemly politicking leading up to last week's judicial elections in New York State provides all the evidence Gov. George Pataki needs to press the State Legislature to change to a nonpartisan system of merit selection.

title: Cowboys Turn Tables on 49ers With Comeback
description: Dallas and San Francisco. The 49ers bury the Cowboys deep in a hole. Dallas bounces back, but falls short. That was the story line the last three times these teams met, and it looked like the story line today.

title: Eric Reissner, 83, Well-Known Math Scholar, Dies
description: Eric Reissner, a mathematician whose work in applied mechanics helped broaden the theoretical understanding of how solid objects react under stress and led to advances in both civil and aerospace engineering, died on Nov. 1 at the Pacific Regent Health Care Center in San Diego. He was 83 and lived in Solana Beach, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: A table yesterday and on Saturday summarizing the observance of Veteran's Day misstated the starting time of today's parade in New York. It is at 9:30 A.M., not 11 A.M.

title: American-Indians Choose Spirit Over Science
description: To the Editor:

title: The Harder Struggle to Make and Market Black Films
description: On Wednesday, ''Set It Off,'' a bank-heist caper starring Queen Latifah, opened across the country. The story of four black women who clean office buildings by day and rob banks by night, it did $9 million at the box office in its first four days.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall Street in Cyberspace: Power and Peril on the Net

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN had not performed in his hometown of Freehold, N.J., since 1967, when he graduated from high school. So on Friday night he returned, holding a benefit solo show at his old parochial school.

title: Filling the 'Politically Incorrect' Gap
description: For executives at Comedy Central, last Tuesday was a bittersweet occasion. It was the end of the election season, a time when the cable network was awash in grade A material from the campaign trail. Its audience had grown by 25 percent in the first nine months of 1996, and overall advertising revenue increased 40 percent in that period.

title: A Woman on the Run or Just Moving On
description: Michelle Shocked was all over the map on Saturday night during her sold-out show at Irving Plaza. She sang about Alaska, Los Angeles, New Orleans and Texas; she sang about cars, trains and just running. She played funk, bluegrass, gospel, blues, disco, folk, soul, jazz and rhythm-and-blues slow jams. She dispensed self-help wisdom, religious views, party enticements and square-dance calls. She even led a conga line to the back of the room and coaxed the entire audience to dance with its back to the stage.

title: New Approach to Overhauling Health Insurance: Step by Step
description: Mindful of lessons learned in the last four years, President Clinton and his aides are developing incremental proposals to fill gaps in health insurance coverage, Administration officials said.

title: Brinkley Offers Apology. Clinton Accepts.
description: After 15 years as the host of ABC's flagship Sunday news program, David Brinkley began his valedictory show today by apologizing to the President for calling him a bore in a broadcast on election night.

title: The United States Is Looking Like a World Cup Force
description: The United States gave more strong evidence this afternoon to justify the feeling that it has joined Mexico in becoming a superior soccer force in the North and Central America and Caribbean region. The Americans have discarded two World Cup qualifying rivals in the span of a week and they have done it convincingly.

title: Variety of Fixed-Income Issues Are Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's financings this week comprise the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, scheduled for tomorrow because of the Veterans Day holiday today, and a 34-day cash management bill to be auctioned Wednesday.

title: Hoboken Gives Sinatra a Get-Well Star
description: Since he left Hoboken in his mid-20's, Frank Sinatra has rarely come back to visit. But few residents in the mile-square New Jersey city on the Hudson River seem to care.

title: Low Voter Turnout
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph M. Baird, 82, White House Adviser
description: Joseph M. Baird, a retired New York businessman and White House adviser on trade issues during the Kennedy Administration, died on Nov. 1 at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82. A former resident of Merrick, L.I., he retired to Fort Lauderdale in 1973.

title: Jets Go Up by 21, Then Go Downhill
description: It would have been the parlay of a lifetime: Mike Tyson losing and the Jets winning on the same weekend. It almost happened until the New England Patriots, a more talented team than the Jets, played better and smarter in the second half today and recovered for a 31-27 victory.

title: Cemetery Bomb In Moscow Kills 13 at Ceremony
description: In a grisly new demonstration of the growing audacity of Moscow's criminal gangs, at least 13 people were killed this morning and dozens more wounded when a remote-controlled bomb ripped through a crowd of mourners at a memorial service at a cemetery here.

title: In Women's Election Victories, the Significance Is in the Details
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Stresses Trade, Planting a Tree in Israel
description: As Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey planted a tree here this afternoon that she said symbolized life in the rocky soil of a new forest here, Israeli soldiers faced angry Palestinians just three miles away in the West Bank after a deadly clash over disputed land.

title: It's Health Reference Data (Do Not Take as Medicine)
description: Tired of bothering doctors at parties with medical questions? Then make an appointment with your computer.

title: INSIDE
description: Africa's Crippled Giant

title: A Gulag Survivor Who Put Her Pain Into Words
description: Even today the ruins of the Gulag, the chain of camps Stalin used to murder a generation of Russians, still heave with suffering. The prisons, built by semiclad and bewildered slaves in the harshest of Siberian conditions, destroyed many of the great minds and spirits of the century. But even Stalin could not kill everyone.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: When Youth and Experience

title: Louis M. Simon, Theater Executive, 90
description: Louis M. Simon, a longtime theatrical executive, died on Oct. 28 at Catholic Medical Center in Manchester, N.H. He was 90 and lived in Manchester.

title: Strongman Takes on 2 Planes
description: Stanley Pleskun is looking for a challenge. The 275-pound professional strongman from South Brunswick says he has already bent a penny between two fingers, lifted 600 pounds with one finger and driven a nail through a two-inch board with his hand. Today at Princeton Airport Mr. Pleskun, who performs under the name Stanless Steel, will attempt to hold his ground as two 160-horsepower airplanes pull in opposite directions at full power while attached to his arms. Naomi Nierenberg, a co-owner of the airport, said she was not worried about the outcome . ''We're not going to have any arms pulling off,'' she said. ''I have great faith in him.'' ANDY NEWMAN

title: Israeli Troops Kill West Bank Arab and Wound 11
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian and wounded 11 others today when a protest against the expansion of this Jewish settlement turned into a violent clash.

title: Atlanta Agencies In a Merger
description: Tausche Martin Lonsdorf in Atlanta has acquired Cleveland-Clark, also in Atlanta. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Budget, Welfare and Rent Rules Point to a Lively 1997 in Albany
description: With the election over, the stage has been set for a 1997 legislative session likely to be every bit as confrontational and protracted as the 1996 version, which dragged into mid-July and produced the latest state budget in the country's history, legislators and political analysts say.

title: Computers Help Unite Campuses but Also Drive Some Students Apart
description: Through a plug in his dorm room, Arthur Desrosiers, a Dartmouth College sophomore, pursues all the preoccupations of undergraduate life without leaving his chair: he questions professors, fishes for dates, browses the library catalogue, orders in pizza and engages in 2 A.M. bull sessions on the meaning of it all.

title: As the cost of newsprint declines, analysts argue over who will benefit.
description: THE page these words are printed on cost about a quarter of a cent, but 10 months ago, it cost closer to a third of a penny. Not much of a drop in price, until one considers that the American newspaper industry prints more than 20 billion newspapers a year. At about 100 pages for each issue, that fraction of a cent drop in price has amounted to a torrent of savings for the industry, which has not had a lot of good news about itself in recent years.

title: Bond Market Closed
description: The Treasury securities market is closed today in observance of Veterans Day. Government offices and most banks are also closed. The stock and commodities markets are open.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1994, JOANNE DAVIS, then the executive editor and a vice president at Warner Books, published JAMES REDFIELD'S ''The Celestine Prophecy,'' which has sold more than five million copies worldwide. The next year, she published the same author's ''Tenth Insight,'' which has sold more than one million copies in the United States. She also published ''The Eagle and the Rose,'' by ROSEMARY ALTEA, an English psychic, which sold 211,000 copies.

title: Counties Begin Flood Recovery
description: Upstate New York communities battered by torrential rains struggled yesterday to return to normal life in the face of closed roads, downed utility lines and flooded basements. For many areas, the rains of Friday and Saturday only undid the progress made after last winter's disastrous flooding.

title: Temptation and Guilt At Boston College
description: The price of Boston College's gambling episode has already extended beyond the job status of a football coach, the impact on recruiting or the reputation of an institution. Long after the outcome is determined, the long-term memories will have as much to do with the loss of trust and the pain of betrayal -- real, imagined and perceived.

title: Aviation Agency Head Steps Down After Tough Period
description: It has not been an easy ride for David R. Hinson, who resigned as head of the Federal Aviation Administration on Saturday.

title: A 10,000-Year-Old Site Yields Trove of Data in Florida
description: Finding what they are calling a 10,000-year-old underwater time capsule, scientists at the University of Florida think they have caught a rare glimpse of how people in North America responded to the last catastrophic climate change, at the end of the most recent Ice Age.

title: FPA MEDICAL AGREES TO BUY AHI HEALTHCARE
description: FPA Medical Management Inc. reached a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire AHI Healthcare Systems Inc. for about $130 million in stock. The companies said FPA would issue about 6.1 million common shares for all of AHI's common shares outstanding. The companies also said that they expected to decrease general and administrative expenses by about $14 million, and that the merger would result in combined revenues for 1997 of about $1 billion. FPA Medical Management, based in San Diego, is a national health care management service organization. AHI Healthcare Systems, based in Downey, Calif., integrates individual and small groups of primary care physicians and specialists into local managed health care delivery networks.

title: Police Watch Suspects in Graffiti Bigotry
description: Officials say they are focusing on several suspects in the hunt for vandals who painted anti-Semitic graffiti on four homes here just before the anniversary of a Nazi pogrom.

title: A Painful Road From Vietnam to Forgiveness
description: It is one of the most enduring and painful images of the Vietnam War: 9-year-old Phan Thi Kim Phuc running naked toward the lens of a camera, holding her arms outstretched and screaming in agony and terror as napalm seared her small body.

title: Battered by Cyclone, Indians Begin to Rebuild
description: As the sun settled over the wetlands surrounding this devastated town on the Bay of Bengal, an Indian Government official paused today to offer a requiem for the victims of a cyclone that roared ashore here last week, killing hundreds of people.

title: A Police Inspector Is Under Inquiry Over Trial Questions
description: A top-ranking police official's decision to take the Fifth Amendment when questioned at trial about whether he accepted trips from a gun dealer has led to an inquiry by prosecutors in Manhattan, according to investigators.

title: Corrections
description: Entries in the Business Digest and the Company Index yesterday referred erroneously in some editions to a front-page article about an investigation that concluded that a senior Texaco executive did not use a racial epithet at a 1994 meeting. The article became ready for later editions. Readers wishing copies of the article may write to Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1474.

title: FIGHTING IN BOSNIA AS EXILES GO HOME
description: Several hundred Muslims stormed a village today to reclaim homes formerly occupied by Muslims in an area now held by Bosnian Serbs, setting off a firefight.

title: Index of Demand for Chips Soars to High for This Year
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded sharply in October, reaching its highest level since last year, a trade group reported today. Analysts had expected a gain, but the actual number exceeded even the most optimistic estimates.

title: What About Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Architect Named to Head School Construction
description: Martin D. Raab, an architect who had headed the largest architectural and engineering firm in the city, was appointed yesterday as president of the School Construction Authority by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: The Dark Underbelly of Ron Howard
description: Movie directors get typed just as much as actors do. No matter how successful, a film maker who specializes in action dramas or comedies or serious films finds it difficult, sometimes impossible, to break the mold.

title: Some luxury watchmakers are switching, and aggressively marketing the appeal of tradition.
description: SEVERAL upscale watchmakers are rolling out new ad and marketing campaigns pushing panache as much as product.

title: Ruling Party In Mexico Has Setbacks
description: Opposition groups, riding a swell of discontent over the economy, have made major gains against Mexico's long-dominant political party in two state elections, in voting regarded as a harbinger of key 1997 elections.

title: Giuliani, 1997 in Mind, Focuses On Education and Attacks Rivals
description: With the Presidential election out of the way, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun to marshal several core elements of his as-yet unannounced re-election campaign, trumpeting the precipitous drop in crime while moving quickly to establish credentials in education. And with growing asperity, he now belittles most of his likely opponents as machine politicians of the past.

title: AID TEAMS RETURN TO ZAIRE BUT FIND ARMIES IN THE WAY
description: Ten days after pulling out of the Zairian town of Goma because of a siege by rebels, United Nations officials and aid workers made a tentative attempt to return today, crossing the nearby border from Rwanda with a shipment of medicine and food in the hope of reaching hundreds of thousands of needy refugees.

title: INSIDE
description: White House Departure

title: Accounts
description: Saville & Holdsworth, Boston, to Rapier Stead & Bowden, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising and public relations in the United States for the human resources consulting company. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Deutsche Telekom Expands Stock Offering
description: Europe's largest public offering of shares got even bigger yesterday as Deutsche Telekom expanded its stock offering. The initial public offering, which will begin next week with shares trading in Germany, New York and Tokyo, may raise as much as 18 billion marks ($12 billion), up from 15 billion marks previously. Priced at 25 to 30 marks a share, Telekom's offering will put about 23 percent of the total equity in investors' hands. The German Government will retain 77 percent.

title: History's Hold on Pakistan
description: Four years before his fall from power in 1977, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan warned his nation, ''What is built on hypocrisy and deceit must finally crumble.'' But he never took that message to heart. Nor, her opponents say, did his daughter, Benazir. Just like her father before her, Benazir Bhutto cleverly used populist oratory, inspirational promises and idealistic national platforms to rise to power. If words had the fructifying powers of water, they would have brought bountiful harvests to impoverished Pakistan. Instead, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's quest for power led to charges of corruption and removal from office. He was executed in 1979.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with the continuation of an article about the Ramble in Central Park misidentified the bird shown. It was a cormorant, not a goose.

title: Italy to Postpone Phone Privatization
description: Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, the Treasury Minister of Italy, said yesterday that the privatization of the state telephone company, known as Stet, would not occur by March 1997, the previously planned deadline. A more feasible deadline would be autumn of next year, Mr. Ciampi indicated after a meeting with Karl Van Miert, the head of the European Union's competition commission.

title: Big East Bowl Bids: Four Book Passage
description: The Big East's four bowl commitments nicely fit its standing, with four teams having achieved the qualification level of six victories -- Miami (6-2), Syracuse (6-2), Virginia Tech (7-1) and West Virginia (7-1).

title: Wal-Mart's CD Standards Are Changing Pop Music
description: The CD rack at the Wal-Mart in this small town in southwestern North Carolina, like the racks in 2,300 other Wal-Mart branches around the country, is a world of shrink-wrapped packages marked ''edited,'' ''clean'' and ''sanitized for your protection.'' Other compact disks are not marked this way, but they have been altered from the original version available at most record stores. Some of the teen-agers shopping here say they are not happy about this. But they have no other choice: the closest record stores are 50 to 150 miles away in Gainesville, Ga., and Atlanta.

title: Insurer Plans 1,800 New Jobs in Manhattan
description: One of the nation's largest insurance companies, American International Group, is planning to keep its headquarters in downtown Manhattan for the next 15 years and to add more than 1,800 new jobs in return for tax breaks, city officials said.

title: Light Traffic On First Day Of Reversal At a Bridge
description: On the first day of yet another change in the Queensboro Bridge traffic pattern yesterday, an unusual thing happened. Traffic actually moved.

title: In Lawsuit Against Swiss Banks, A Hope to Do Justice to a Father's Memory
description: For half a century, Gizella Weisshaus followed a trail of whispers.

title: Getting Faked Out May Be Sea Lions' Last Chance
description: In the 10-year war against California sea lions, biologists in Seattle have tried shooting them with rubber bullets, scaring them with firecrackers and repulsing them with really bad music.

title: Heeding Perceptions of the Past While Listening for the Future
description: Luciano Berio's ''Re in Ascolto'' (''A King Listening'') is one of the great operas, and its American premiere here on Saturday night was a breathtaking occasion. Lyric Opera of Chicago, whose performances continue into early December, wisely imported the production that Graham Vick created for Covent Garden in 1989, complete with trapeze artists, dancers, choristers who gently ascend on wires while singing, a magician, baleful birds and, most important, a moving presentation of the personalities and antagonisms at the heart of the drama. Mr. Berio asks us, with his king, to listen. Mr. Vick makes us listen well.

title: Slips of Things That Slink
description: Remember those movies where the leading lady, usually cast as a secretary, doffed her glasses, undid her chignon and poured herself into a sexy strapless dress to attract the leading man's eye? Well, something akin to that is going on today, with working women shedding the androgynous pants suits they wear by day and slipping into slender columns of metallic lace or bias-cut matte jersey for evening.

title: Inside a Wartime Brothel: The Avenger's Story
description: Years later, asleep in the arms of her husband, Maria Rosa Henson would sometimes cry out the name of the Japanese Army officer who had imprisoned her in a brothel in the Philippines for nine months in World War II.

title: Leaving a War Out of Politics And in Hearts
description: SILENTLY, the torch was passed yesterday to a new generation of American veterans.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Maine Oil Spill Is Less Damaging Than Feared
description: Preliminary studies of a recent oil spill here have surprised scientists, who had feared the worst, the state's Department of Environmental Protection said today.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: This Bernie Is Not Some Banjo Hitter
description: THE tall, scholarly looking young man with wire-rim glasses and goatee -- but with an obvious bundle of muscle under his blue sweater -- strummed a few chords on his electric guitar. He waited on stage at the Bottom Line club in Greenwich Village yesterday afternoon to rehearse with the singer Pete Droge, whom he was to accompany that night on such songs as ''Brakeman'' and ''The House of the Rising Sun.''

title: Ickes, Longtime Clinton Ally, to Quit as No. 2 Chief of Staff
description: Harold M. Ickes, a deputy White House chief of staff, 25-year friend of President Clinton and one of the architects of the President's re-election, will leave his job after being passed over for chief of staff, but may seek a post elsewhere in the Administration.

title: Vindicated
description: To the Editor:

title: Trent Lott's Test
description: Will this post-election period and the next Congress be a time of renewed gridlock or bipartisan progress? The answer depends in large measure on the newest member of the leadership circle, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi. Both President Clinton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich have been battered -- and perhaps chastened -- by two years of political combat. Both seem ready to do business. But the signs from Mr. Lott have not been encouraging as he moves out of the shadow of Bob Dole, his predecessor as Senate majority leader. This is a moment for him to take a broader view of his responsibilities than he has in the past and bring flexibility to such issues as campaign finance reform, Medicare and the push for a balanced budget.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALCO STANDARD CORP. Valley Forge, Pa., appointed Robert M. Kearns 2d senior vice president and chief financial officer, and David M. Gadra senior vice president and chief information officer.

title: Where's Barkley? Suns Are 0-6, Rockets 6-0
description: The Phoenix Suns knew they would miss Charles Barkley, but maybe they didn't know how much.

title: Mexican Aide's Millions: U.S. Charges Drug Link
description: It was 1994, and Deputy Attorney General Mario Ruiz Massieu had only months left in office as Mexico's top narcotics enforcement official. He wanted to get money -- lots of money -- out of Mexico, so he turned his top aide into a cash courier.

title: The Marijuana Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a summit meeting of Latin American leaders in Santiago, Chile, referred incorrectly to Isabel Allende, the woman shown with President Fidel Castro of Cuba at the tomb of her father, former President Salvador Allende Gossens. She is an official of the Chilean Socialist Party; another Isabel Allende, a cousin of the former President, is the acclaimed novelist.

title: Morris S. Novik, 93, Early Director of WNYC
description: Morris S. Novik, who directed WNYC, the municipal radio station, during the administration of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. Mr. Novik, who lived in Chelsea, would have turned 93 on Friday.

title: STRIKES CAUSE G.M. TO CUT 4TH-QUARTER PRODUCTION
description: The General Motors Corporation has cut its planned fourth-quarter production of cars and trucks 11 percent because of strikes in Canada and the United States, costing the auto maker an estimated $666 million. The company slashed 151,000 cars and trucks from its production schedule for the period and said it would now build 1.169 million vehicles in the United States, Canada and Mexico. Last month's 20-day walkout by the Canadian Automobile Workers eventually shut down all of G.M.'s Canadian assembly plants. Two strikes by United Automobile Workers union locals shut down five United States truck plants earlier this month. G.M., the world's largest auto maker, said the strikes canceled the production of 113,000 cars and 38,000 trucks.

title: Chess
description: Strategies that fail often fall out of sight, and after a while their deficiencies are forgotten. Chess generations come and go before someone with no knowledge of the strategy's history stumbles upon it and tries it. At first the player has reasonable success because the opponents are also unaware of its intricacies. But later someone turns up who knows why it was given up, and administers harsh punishment.

title: Superfast Computer Introduced by Cray
description: The Cray Research unit of Silicon Graphics Inc. introduced a new supercomputer today capable of performing a trillion calculations a second, the fastest commercially available system in the world.

title: Oregon's Health Plan Means Good Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the credits with a television review yesterday about ''The High Life,'' on HBO, misstated the scheduled air time. It was last night at 10:30, not 10.

title: The $100 Million Fight: Get Set for a Rematch
description: If a pay-per-view boxing card can be worth $49.95, Saturday night's was, and it would have been even if Evander Holyfield's upset of Mike Tyson had been the only bout. Its value was not diminished by the odd ''Other Side of Mike'' merchandise commercials (reversible caps!) that looked like ''Saturday Night Live'' spoof ads, or by the reporter Bill Boggs's schmoozefest with David Cassidy.

title: British Air Delaying $1 Billion Jet Order
description: British Airways P.L.C. will postpone a $1 billion aircraft order until the effectiveness of a cost-cutting program can be assessed, the company's chairman said yesterday. The chairman, Sir Colin Marshall, said he would wait for results from the program, which began on Sept. 18, before talking again with five aircraft makers that were asked in February to bid to supply a fleet of 60 short-haul jetliners.

title: Top Recruit Picks St. John's
description: JAMES FELTON, a 6-foot-9-inch forward from Marist High School in Bayonne, N.J., announced last night on Madison Square Garden's ''Sportsdesk'' that he will play for St. John's University next season.

title: The Wild Blue Yonder, From a Russian Vantage
description: Along with zippy photographs of the latest in Russian jet fighters doing their stuff, ''Top Gun Over Moscow'' gives a quick course in military fashions. While the United States goes in for sleek, highly computerized, relatively comfortable planes made for missile exchanges far beyond the sight of the pilot, Russia stays with rugged, powerful, fast, rough-riding craft that love an old-fashioned dogfight. An American observer says: ''They build airplanes like tanks. The U.S. Air Force and the West build airplanes like fine watches.''

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on Thursday about quarterly earnings at Humana Inc. and two other health care companies misstated the title of a Humana executive, Gregory H. Wolf. He is president and chief operating officer, not chairman and chief executive.

title: Halting Welfare At 5 Years
description: Bills that would end welfare benefits after five years and require mothers under 18 to live with their parents or a guardian in order to receive assistance will get their first legislative hearing Thursday.

title: Valvoline in Sears Accord
description: Ashland Inc. said today that its Valvoline Instant Oil Change division had agreed to provide oil changes in 20 Sears Auto Centers in three markets next year. Financial terms were not disclosed. Ashland, based in Ashland, Ky., said the companies would initially will test the concept in the three markets -- Dallas, Minneapolis-St. Paul and Kansas City, Mo. -- and expect to open oil change operations in more than 150 Sears Auto Centers nationwide.

title: UST TO BUY BACK 10 PERCENT OF SHARES OUTSTANDING
description: The smokeless tobacco maker UST Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back up to 20 million common shares, or just over 10 percent of its stock outstanding. The repurchases will begin after the company, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., completes a buyback plan in effect since June 1994. UST has repurchased about 18.8 million of the 20 million shares it is authorized to buy back under that plan. On Sept. 30, UST had about 191 million shares outstanding. The company, which makes Skoal, Copenhagen and other smokeless tobacco products, said it intended to borrow $100 million for use in its repurchase program through next year. Shares of UST gained 75 cents yesterday, to $30.625.

title: NEOSTAR RETAIL GROUP TO AUCTION OFF ITS ASSETS
description: After failing to secure other financing, Neostar Retail Group of Dallas, which operates the Babbage's Inc. and Software Etc. Inc. software stores, said yesterday that it would auction off its assets. Neostar, which has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, also said it was notifying its vendors to stop shipping new inventory. The company had been negotiating with Leonard Riggio, a company director, about possible financial support, but the two sides were unable to agree on terms. Neostar made a voluntary filing under Chapter 11 in September and secured $70 million in financing in October.

title: Mets' Wilson Set for Surgery
description: Bill Pulsipher, Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson had hoped to do something special as Mets this past season. In a way, they did. All three pitchers will have undergone some type of surgical procedure to cap a season of unfulfilled expectations.

title: Stocks Rise in Light Day; Dow Up 35.78
description: Stocks continued to rally yesterday, sending the the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500 index and Nasdaq composite index to record highs.

title: Birds Rescued in Spills Do Poorly, Study Finds
description: THE image of birds mired in a sticky black froth is familiar after an oil spill. So is the scene of rescue workers rinsing birds' stained feathers with soapy water, nursing the sick to health and then releasing the shaken survivors into the wild.

title: I.B.M. Sales Unit For New Offering
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had formed a new unit to sell its stripped-down personal computers.

title: Transit Agency Urges Platform Etiquette to Speed Subways
description: Every subway commuter knows this scene.

title: Irish Miniatures, Brought to Life in a Few Strokes
description: AFTER RAIN

title: Islanders Are No Match For Roy and Avalanche
description: This one was fairly predictable. The best offense in the National Hockey League against the worst. The league's top two scorers against a young defense. The Islanders against the incomparable Patrick Roy.

title: Mall Company Picks North Castle
description: The Wells Park Group, a shopping-mall management company in Newton, Mass., has named North Castle Partners in Stamford, Conn., to handle its account, which had been at Houston Herstek Favat in Boston for five years. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $7 million.

title: Clinton Promises Continued Study of Gulf Ailments
description: President Clinton pledged today that the Government would keep searching for an explanation for the ailments that have afflicted thousands of veterans of the 1991 Persian Gulf war.

title: Irma Ullmann, 91, Science Benefactor In U.S. and Israel
description: Irma Ullmann, the matriarch of a New York philanthropic family, died on Nov. 4 at White Plains Hospital while staying with family in Rye Brook, N.Y. She was 91 and lived in Palm Beach, Fla., since moving from Manhattan more than 30 years ago.

title: Governmental Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Studies of Triglycerides See Greater Risk to the Heart
description: Two new studies have intensified health concerns about triglycerides, a fatty substance in the blood that can increase the risk of heart disease. The studies, reported yesterday, indicate that triglyceride blood levels now considered safe are actually far too high.

title: UNIVERSAL HOSPITAL STOCK IS UP ON POSSIBLE TAKEOVER
description: Shares of Universal Hospital Services Inc. rose 16 percent yesterday after the company, a provider of medical equipment, said another company, whose identity it did not disclose, had offered to buy it. Universal, based in Bloomington, Minn., said it had hired Piper Jaffray Inc. as a financial adviser to study options for enhancing shareholder value, including the sale of the company. Shares of Universal rose $1.25 yesterday, to $9, giving the company a market capitalization of more than $49 million.

title: Warped Floor Cancels Game
description: A damaged floor at the Delta Center in Salt Lake City was deemed unsafe and forced the postponement of last night's National Basketball Association game between the San Antonio Spurs and the Utah Jazz.

title: Tensions Rise at European Currency Talks
description: The tensions over Europe's planned single currency rose sharply today as Germany threatened to block agreement on crucial preparations for monetary union unless its European partners accepted tough new limits on deficit spending by governments.

title: British Airport Operator Says Profits Rose 3.4%
description: BAA P.L.C. said yesterday that its first-half pretax profit rose 3.4 percent, less than expected. The company, which operates Heathrow, the world's biggest international airport, reported pretax profit of $:304 million ($502 million) in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, compared with $:294 million a year earlier. Passenger traffic rose 3.3 percent, to 53.7 million, as total revenue grew 6.3 percent, to $:742 million ($1.2 billion). (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Hit Film Helps News Corp. Post 7% Increase in Operating Profit
description: The News Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings from operations rose 7 percent as lower earnings from its American television business were offset by the box office success of its movie ''Independence Day.''
