title: Mad Dogs Wins Apparel Chain Job
description: Designs Inc. in Boston said yesterday that it had named Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York as the first agency to handle advertising for its Boston Trading Company chain store division, which handles apparel. Billings have not been determined.

title: Out of the Bottle
description: As if parents didn't have enough on their hands trying to keep Johnny away from porn on the Internet, misogynistic rap lyrics and blood-filled action flicks, now the liquor industry has decided to lift its decades-old ban on television and radio advertising of hard liquor.

title: Opponents' Gadget Plays Sliced and Diced the Jets
description: In the dictionary, some of the definitions of gadget are contraption, contrivance, device, doodad, doohickey, gimmick and gizmo. In football, gadget plays are all of those, designed to take advantage of players too anxious to make plays.

title: The Aura of Leather, for Less
description: There is no need to spend $1,000 to be in style with the leather and suede clothing that just about every designer showed for fall. There are great-looking shirts, jackets and pants in pseudo-leather and fake suede.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: In Atlanta's Annual Ritual, Smoltz Gets the Cy Young
description: While the Los Angeles Dodgers continue to dominate the National League's rookie of the year award, the Atlanta Braves also have a lock on a coveted trophy -- the National League Cy Young award.

title: Debating Use of Iron As Curb Of Climate
description: THE idea is to fertilize the sea with iron, creating such a bloom of sea plants that they gulp down tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and curb the buildup of this climate-warming gas.

title: Excerpts From Remarks On Themes for Campaign
description: In recent weeks, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun to outline themes for a re-election campaign and begun criticizing his potential opponents. Following are excerpts from his comments:

title: Murder Suspect to Testify
description: A man on trial in the killing of a Franklin Township police officer is expected to testify today that he was taken by surprise by the actions of a fellow member of the Warlocks motorcycle gang when the two were pulled over for a routine traffic stop in May 1995, his lawyer said.

title: Back Surgery for Puppa
description: DAREN PUPPA, the Tampa Bay Lightning's starting goaltender, was scheduled for surgery yesterday to repair a herniated disk in his back, the team said. He is expected to return to action this season, though a timetable has not been set.

title: Giants Still Have Not Put the Pieces Together
description: The Giants are tough.

title: Airtouch Italian Deal
description: Airtouch Communications Inc. said today that it had increased its stake in Omnitel-Pronto Italia, an Italian cellular phone company, to 15.5 percent after buying an additional 3.8 percent for $118 million. Airtouch, a wireless communications company based in Walnut Creek, Calif., also said it had acquired an option to increase its interest in Omnitel-Pronto by up to an additional 6.2 percentage points. The option is valid through October 1999.

title: John G. Crommelin, 94, Dies; Vocal Critic of Navy Policies
description: Rear Adm. John G. Crommelin, a career Navy man who was air officer aboard the carrier Enterprise during six engagements in the Pacific in World War II and later became an outspoken critic of policies seeking to unify the armed forces, died on Nov. 2 at his home in Montgomery, Ala. He was 94.

title: Illinois Fires Coach Tepper
description: LOU TEPPER, his team on a four-game losing streak and coming off a 48-0 defeat to Ohio State, was fired yesterday as coach at Illinois.

title: Super Bowl Sprint Too Close to Call
description: A Sunday full of surprises has tightened things up for those teams racing toward the Super Bowl, particularly in the National Football Conference East. The Washington Redskins lost a wild one in overtime to the Arizona Cardinals, and the Philadelphia Eagles lost a heartbreaker to the Buffalo Bills, enabling the Dallas Cowboys to keep pace in the division.

title: The Machines That Almost Work
description: THIS column was supposed to have covered a clever new product, but the clever new product wasted most of my day in a futile attempt to get just one of its features to work. Substitute topic: If you wonder why productivity gains from computers have been so hard to measure, try counting up the hours of fussing, fuming and frittering their users have squandered through no fault of their own.

title: Slow Repairs After Tornado
description: The tornado that swept through parts of East Brunswick on Sept. 8 lasted just a few seconds, but eight families who lived in a development called The Courts are still feeling the twister's effects: they have not been able to move back home. The tornado and the rains that came with it caused about $200,000 in damage to eight garden apartments, said Mark Rosen, a principal of the company that manages the complex, the Solomon Organization.

title: 6,000 Could Be Sent by Weekend; Pressure Off, U.S. Weighs Its Role : Canada Agrees to Lead Military Force in Zaire
description: PARIS  Canada has agreed to head a multinational military force to protect humanitarian relief operations for refugees in eastern Zaire that could be on the ground as early as this weekend, Western diplomats said Monday.

title: A Playful Ewing Shows He Isn't Over the Hill
description: Patrick Ewing was in a playful mood Sunday night and no one was spared his comedic barbs. Before the game against the Grizzlies, he tossed green grapes across the locker room, finally nailing Herb Williams in the corner.

title: Dam Raises Flood Questions
description: The mayors of Manville and Millstone say the risk of flooding has increased since a shallow dam was built in 1994 near the point where the Raritan and Millstone Rivers meet. Manville suffered $6 million in damage in the Oct. 19 flood -- its worst ever, said Mayor Angelo Corradino. The city was hit almost as hard last January. Mayor Corradino urged Gov. Christine Todd Whitman last week to form a commission to see if the dam should be removed. Mayor Mary Patrick of Millstone said yesterday that she would make a similar request.

title: Bosnia Serb Officers Back Ex-Chief
description: Several high-ranking Bosnian Serb military officers issued a statement today saying that they will continue to support their commander and are refusing to step down despite their dismissals.

title: Automatic Insurance For Your Data Files
description: AN obsessive personality is not a pretty thing, but sometimes a touch of it comes in handy. It is not wise to be devil-may-care about computer files.

title: Missed Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Accountants Are Expected To Adopt New Fraud Rule
description: In an attempt to bolster the public's confidence in financial audits, its version of the Good Housekeeping seal of approval, the accounting industry is expected to adopt today a new standard aimed at clarifying the auditor's role in detecting fraud. The new rule was developed in response to concern that accountants were not doing enough to uncover whether a company was cooking the books or if its employees were stealing from it.

title: No Headline
description: ''I worry less for the dead than for the living. It's the survivors who have to find their ticket to eternity in all this mess, and the Lord alone knows how they will do it.''

title: Reading the History of Life in the Text of Modern Genes
description: IS it possible to recreate the origin of genes, the first stirrings of life in the mists of time more than three billion years ago? One of the country's leading biologists is certain that with the power of thought and statistical technique those mists can be burned away. He is Dr. Walter Gilbert and he has been working on the problem for nearly 15 years.

title: She Opened World to Others; Her World Has Opened, Too
description: The washerwoman's gift of $150,000 to finance scholarships at the local college had taken much of her long and lonely life to save. Oseola McCarty made the gift as she felt her own time creeping to a close, as worsening arthritis made it hard for her to work or sometimes even stand.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: A Lieder Event Becomes A Feast of Storytelling

title: Bond Market Closed
description: The Treasury market was closed yesterday in observance of Veterans Day. There was also no trading of related bond contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange. Government offices and most banks were also closed. The stock and commodities markets were open.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three months after suffering a stroke, MEL TORME, 71, was released from a Los Angeles hospital over the weekend and went home to his wife, Ali, his family and dog, The Associated Press reported.

title: Another Answer to Juvenile Crime
description: With violent-crime rates rising among juveniles, states have been tripping over each other to get tough on young offenders. In New York, for instance, Gov. George Pataki has proposed transferring offenders who are at least 16 years old out of juvenile detention facilities and into adult prisons. Getting tough may be part of the answer, but it is not the only answer. New York City offers another model -- a program that tries to divert young offenders from detention to probation. This program deserves closer attention.

title: Parolee Held in a Killing After 2 Days of Freedom
description: A man who was released from prison against the recommendation of a parole board was charged last night with killing a security guard at a McDonald's restaurant in Queens just two days after his release, the police said.

title: Pataki Welfare Plan Would Cut Payments to Families Over Time
description: Proposing the biggest changes in the 60-year history of the state's welfare system, Gov. George E. Pataki will offer legislation this week to cut the monthly grants of hundreds of thousands of poor families and end cash benefits for many immigrants and able-bodied childless adults, his aides said today.

title: Debate on Homes in a Woods
description: Steven Hyman upset many residents of Denville when he told them last April that he planned to divide the township's largest undeveloped tract into 66 building lots for luxury homes, Mayor Carol Spencer said. Tonight, Mr. Hyman plans to present another plan to the Township Council. Township officials and representatives of an environmental group called Protect Our Wetlands, Water and Woods said yesterday that they hoped that the new plan would confine development to one portion of the 434 acres of steep, heavily wooded watershed property and would preserve the rest.

title: Wacker Out at Minnesota
description: Minnesota Coach JIM WACKER is expected to tell his team today that he will resign, Midwest Sports Channel reported last night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HUGHES NETWORK SYSTEMS INC., a unit of General Motors Corp., has received a six-year contract to supply up to $1 billion of wireless equipment to Nextwave Telecom Inc.'s personal communication network.

title: Yugoslavia's Breakup
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Ask Hungary To Oblige on Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: Holyfield Inspired by Music and Marriage
description: The only remnant of Mike Tyson is a scrape on Evander Holyfield's lower lip, but the doctor has already kissed it all better. She is Janice Itson Holyfield, M.D., and when her husband was in a dead calm on Saturday night, before what was supposed to have been the butchering of his life, it was because of their dance.

title: With Pack in Disfavor, Focus Turns to Kittles
description: All anyone had to see was the player starting at point guard during today's practice to know in what direction Coach John Calipari wants the Nets to go, and whom he wants to lead them.

title: Refs Don't Get in Way Of Ranger Defeat
description: According to the prevailing party line around the Rangers' recent slump, the team would win more hockey games if only these confounded referees would resume calling more penalties for hooking, holding and other forms of obstruction. Wouldn't this allow the natural talent of the star-studded $35 million Rangers to prevail?

title: Ford Joins Move to Used Car Warranties as New Rivals Grow
description: The Ford Motor Company today became the latest auto maker to offer a warranty program for used cars from its dealers, with the first ''quality certified'' used Fords to be sold next week from some dealerships in the Southeast.

title: More Pride Than Crowd For Veterans Day Parade
description: They lined up, as they always do, with great ceremony, in olive and navy and khaki uniforms spanning the various decades of the 20th century, and the various wars. They marched, as they always have, with their heads high and their posture perfect.

title: In Yeltsin, Doctors Have a Patient Who Is Used to Calling the Shots
description: When Boris N. Yeltsin was told in September that he needed a heart bypass operation, he promised the consulting American heart surgeon, Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, that he would be a good patient.

title: Making the Winter of Her Discontent Tolerable
description: Thank goodness for tennis and dogs, not necessarily in that order.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO. (MAY,N)
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings fell nearly 13 percent after the spinoff of its Payless Shoe Source division.

title: Japan Announces New Plan to Deregulate Financial Markets
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan announced a plan today for sweeping financial change that he said would create a financial center to rival New York and London by 2001.

title: Honeycutt to Pitch at 43
description: RICK HONEYCUTT's $500,000 option for 1997 was exercised by the St. Louis Cardinals. Honeycutt, at 42 the oldest active player in the major leagues last season, was 2-1 with a 2.85 earned run average in 61 games. He made $350,000 last season and earned $250,000 more in performance bonuses. The Cardinals could have bought out his contract for $100,000. (AP)

title: Players Give Selig Expected Rejection
description: With owners and players facing a real deadline at midnight Thursday, the chances of their completing a new collective bargaining agreement are not dead, but they are hanging by a thread thinner than the twine wrapped around the core of a baseball.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in SportsMonday this week with a cross reference to Books of The Times was published in error. It showed the writer Jonathan Raban, not Jeff Taylor, whose book, ''Tools of the Trade: The Art and Craft of Carpentry,'' was reviewed yesterday.

title: Miscellany
description: Mezzina/Brown Inc., New York, has formed a strategic partnership with RBI Creative Consultants, Westport, Conn ., a producer of radio, television, video and collateral marketing materials.

title: LEON BLACK TEAM ACQUIRES PARKING LOT COMPANY
description: A team made up of the financier Leon Black and the real estate company Aldrich Eastman Waltch said yesterday that it had bought the Allright Parking Corporation, the nation's largest owner of parking lots. Terms were not disclosed, but a person familiar with the transaction said Mr. Black and Aldrich Eastman had paid about $250 million in cash and debt for the company. Allright Parking, based in Houston and owned by Hang Lung Group of Hong Kong, has 1,700 sites in North America and annual revenue of $170 million. Mr. Black is the head of Apollo Advisors L.P. In recent years, his Apollo Real Estate Investment funds have invested more than $1 billion in real estate and real estate companies. Aldrich Eastman, based in Boston, advises institutional investors on real estate investments.

title: Decline in Casino Revenue
description: Official casino revenue figures for the month of October have yet to be released, but The Press of Atlantic City reported last week that the gambling industry took in 4.1 percent less last month than it did last October. The decline was blamed on competition from a new casino in Connecticut, a heavy weekend storm, and a calendar that gave this October eight weekend days instead of nine.

title: Report Calls for Recasting Corporate Boards
description: Corporate America's board rooms will have a completely new tone and a decidedly different cast of characters if the recommendations contained in a sweeping report, scheduled for release today, are heeded.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's difficult indeed to imagine that LENA HORNE could be unnerved by a public appearance. But tomorrow she is facing one with some apprehension.

title: Envirodyne Shares Soar on Lawsuit Victory
description: The shares of Envirodyne Industries rose 34 percent today after the company said it had won $102 million in damages in a patent lawsuit over plastic films used for meat packaging.

title: New Sumitomo Move Against Ex-Trader
description: The Sumitomo Corporation said today that it had submitted a criminal complaint of fraud to the Tokyo District Prosecutor's Office against its former chief copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka, who is in the center of a $2.6 billion scandal.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the company that delivers the Christmas tree to be erected at Rockefeller Center misstated the date for the tree-lighting ceremony this year. It is Dec. 3, not Dec. 5.

title: Parallel Plots In Classic Of Evolution
description: IT is probably the most famous story of evolution observed: the classic tale of England's peppered moth. In the late 1800's, as nearly every biology textbook recounts, England's industrial centers filled the air with smoke, killing the lichens on trees, and the common form of the moth, with white-and-black flecked wings perfect for camouflage on the lichens, began to be replaced by a black-winged form.

title: Welfare Bonus Vanishes
description: A little-noticed provision of the new Federal welfare law has deprived thousands of welfare mothers of a monthly bonus. Page A12.

title: Worse Than Booze
description: Just as you knew they would after that shameful political campaign, the politicians bring us happy news. They're going to reform the rotten campaign financing situation. Sure they are.

title: Amid Affluence, Reality of Violent Crime
description: One week after an elderly couple were killed three doors from her home, Sally Shapiro has started sleeping again. There are new locks on her doors. The alarm system has been tuned up. And her 12-year-old son, Matthew, is no longer left home alone in the late afternoon.

title: In Rare Merger, Drug Maker Will Be Bought By Wholesaler
description: Announcing an unusual pharmaceutical merger that many investors found confusing, the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, one of the nation's biggest drug wholesalers, said yesterday that it would buy the Ivax Corporation, a financially troubled maker of low-cost generic drugs, for $1.66 billion in Bergen Brunswig's stock.

title: SYLVAN LEARNING ACQUIRES MINORITY STAKE IN JOSTENS
description: Sylvan Learning Systems Inc., based in Columbia, Md., said yesterday that it had acquired a 19 percent interest in the Jostens Learning Corporation from Bain Capital Inc. of Boston, giving Sylvan access to the schools that are Jostens's customers. Sylvan bought the preferred stock in Jostens, which is based in La Jolla, Calif., for an undisclosed price. Jostens was valued at about $50 million as of June 1995, according to Barrington Research Associates Inc. Jostens, which is owned by Bain, agreed to let Sylvan use Jostens's software products in Sylvan's educational programs and contract educational services. It also agreed to let Sylvan gain access to students in Jostens's markets, Barrington said.

title: Continental's Chief Moves Beyond Cutting Costs
description: When Gordon M. Bethune took over as president of Continental Airlines, he discovered the company had a remarkable knack for angering both customers and employees.

title: Schering Reports 66% Rise in Earnings
description: The German drug and chemical producer Schering A.G. said yesterday that its profits jumped 66 percent in the first nine months of the year, to 286 million marks ($190.3 million), as sales rose 12 percent. Sales were 3.85 billion marks ($2.56 billion), up from 3.45 billion a year earlier, when the company earned 172 million marks.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: An Architectural Battle Between Metaphor and Reality

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Plan for Cuts Is Expected From New Sunbeam Chief

title: Sunbeam's New Chief Is Expected to Disclose Cuts Today
description: In an announcement that has been anticipated by Wall Street for months, Albert J. Dunlap, the celebrity downsizer who has been chief executive of the Sunbeam Corporation since July, is expected to disclose today the details of the biggest corporate revamping in the company's history.

title: Patterns
description: Tyler for Byblos

title: TEREX TO SELL CLARK MATERIAL UNIT FOR $139.5 MILLION
description: The Terex Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Clark Material Handling Company unit for $139.5 million to a company formed by the unit's management. Terex, based in Westport, Conn., said proceeds from the sale would be used to pay down debt. Clark, its largest subsidiary, makes lift trucks. The buyer, the CMHC Acquisition Corporation, was formed by Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd. and members of Clark Material's management. Terex, with annual sales of more than $1 billion, makes heavy equipment for the construction, mining and logging industries. Its stock rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $7.625.

title: Booming Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Goldman, Sachs Promotes Official
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that E. Gerald Corrigan, a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, would become a partner and managing director on Nov. 30.

title: Q&A
description: Beer and Liquor

title: The Sinking Palestinian Economy
description: The prospects for peace in the Middle East rest to a considerable degree on the economic condition of the Palestinians. These days it is bad and getting worse, a sure prescription for unrest and anger. Regional economic ministers and business executives meeting in Cairo this week can do something about that. There are concrete, feasible proposals on the agenda of the annual Middle East-North Africa economic conference that can give the Palestinian economy a lift.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: British Steel Posts 52% Drop in Profit
description: British Steel P.L.C. said yesterday that its profit slumped 52 percent in the six months that ended on Sept. 28, citing poor demand in Continental Europe and weak prices as steelmakers sold off stockpiles. The company's pretax profit for the six months fell to $:262 million ($432.3 million), compared with $:550 million a year earlier.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: A Perpetual-Motion Whirl, Even Into the Encore

title: Memorex Marketer Is Reviewing Account
description: Memtek Products Inc., the marketer of the Memorex brand of audio and video products, said yesterday that it placed in review its account, which had been inactive since 1994. Though the billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $5 million to $10 million.

title: 2 More Scallop Boats to Rake Sea Floor in Search for Clues
description: Encouraged by the success of dredging operations at the crash site of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Federal investigators doubled the number of scallop boats raking the sea bottom south of Long Island yesterday for any last clues.

title: Lehman, Seeking Higher Profit, Returns to Merchant Banking
description: Lehman Brothers, in a move to help lift long-term earnings, is returning to merchant banking and seeking to raise as much as $1.5 billion for private equity investments.

title: Richard Nelson, 57; Designed Lighting For Plays and Dance
description: Richard Nelson, a Tony Award-winning lighting designer for theater and dance, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 57 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Spies Can't Even Trust the Other Side Anymore
description: In the cold war, spying was a game with unwritten rules. American and Soviet spies did not kill one another. An American arrested for espionage in Moscow was shipped home, not to the gulag.

title: 28 Held as Arsenal Is Found in Brooklyn
description: Twenty-eight men and women were arrested inside a four-story brownstone in Brooklyn last night after officers found a cache of automatic weapons and pipe bombs in a second-floor apartment, the police said.

title: Texaco Seeks to Settle; Stock Up
description: Shares of Texaco Inc. rose 1.4 percent yesterday after the company sought to settle a racial discrimination lawsuit filed by six employees.

title: The No-Win Gamble
description: For a country as for a business, to take a major gamble with no sign of gain and plain warning of loss is gross mismanagement. For a country or business to plunge ahead with the gamble when it has a chance to get out is worse -- squandering assets for no reason other than to save management ego.

title: Whitewater Counsel Says He Has Found Lack of Cooperation
description: In a rare news conference and speech, the Whitewater independent counsel complained here today about a general lack of cooperation with his investigations but said he was making substantial progress anyway.

title: Welcoming Shakespeare Into the Caliban Family
description: You have a gaudy, seedy Florida beach town, where fake Renaissance meets billboard and neon. You have two rich, bullying families that feud and divvy up the city behind the closed doors of their companies and mansions, while their indulged, neglected sons pick street fights with each other and a pampered, neglected daughter daydreams in her prettily appointed bedroom. Of course, the son of the Anglo Montagues and the daughter of the Latino Capulets will fall in love and die for that love, while cars and helicopters roar, while guns twirl, then blast out bullets, while police chiefs deliver stern and futile lectures and television anchors offer banally solicitous commentary.

title: An Individualist's Operatic Nonopera
description: What a curious, magnificent beast is ''La Damnation de Faust.'' It looks first like a rare species of oratorio, then insists on behaving like an opera. Berlioz's orchestra plays onstage and not as a subsidiary presence in some theater pit. The chorus acts as flesh-and-blood participant, not as disembodied oratorical commentator. The soloists become characters, performing dramatic episodes and fragments based on Goethe's original. ''La Damnation de Faust'' is opera scenes without scenery, punctuated by ballets without dancers.

title: STROBER ORGANIZATION TO BE SOLD FOR $32 MILLION
description: The Strober Organization, a supplier of building materials, agreed yesterday to be sold to an investment group for $32 million. Strober, based in Brooklyn, said Fidelity Ventures L.P. had agreed to pay $6 a share for each of its approximately 5.2 million shares. Strober said its major shareholders and certain senior managers had agreed to throw their 62 percent stake in the company behind the acquisition. Shares of Strober gained 37.5 cents yesterday, to $5.625.

title: New Malta Chief Focuses on Neutrality
description: At a time when countries are lining up to join the European club, along comes tiny Malta -- an island nation in the middle of the Mediterranean with a population the size of Cincinnati's -- and says, ''No, thank you.''

title: 'Balance' in Life: Agony, Yes, and Ecstasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Booming Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillies Name McRae Coach
description: The Philadelphia Phillies named HAL McRAE their new hitting coach yesterday, less than two weeks after passing him over for the team's vacant managerial position. TERRY FRANCONA was given the manager's job on Oct. 30.

title: Bertie Wooster, You Sing? You Dear Dizzy Boy, You
description: There's not a hydraulic lift in evidence at the pocket-size Norma Terris Theater of the Goodspeed Opera House, the unlikely setting for the latest import from Andrew Lloyd Webber, the king of the monster musical. There's not even a painted backdrop to conceal the bare brick walls.

title: Loral Venture in China Satellite Phone Deal
description: Globalstar Telecommunications Ltd. said today that it had an agreement with the Chinese Government to provide satellite-telephone service starting in 1998. The company will connect its system to the existing phone network built by China's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications. No financial details were given.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The normally reticent MIA FARROW was eloquent yesterday about a man to whom she will pay tribute tomorrow: SHIMON PERES. Ms. Farrow will present the former Prime Minister of Israel with a special award at the opening of the 13th Israel Film Festival at the Angelika 57 Theater on West 57th Street.

title: A Heave At the Half Energizes Chargers
description: The Detroit Lions had not seen the San Diego Chargers up close and personal and on the same field in 12 years. After tonight, the Lions would rather wait another 12. A Chargers' lightning bolt out of nowhere struck, dazzled and confused them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Pressing Reform, Child Welfare Commissioner Looks to Los Angeles
description: By her own reckoning, Gloria Jones could hardly have been a worse mother. She was unwed, unemployed and a chronic drug abuser. Discipline often meant a scream and a slap. And she had lost her children to foster care twice because of neglect, and was on the verge of losing them permanently.

title: Make Fathers Pay for the Children of Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: HFS in Accord That Extends Buying Spree
description: HFS Inc. took another step toward becoming a consumer services conglomerate yesterday when it announced that it would acquire the PHH Corporation, the largest corporate relocation business in the country, in a stock deal worth about $1.7 billion.

title: People
description: Mike Lotito, chief media officer at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was named executive director for account services, succeeding Mary Herrmann, who will continue on a part-time basis as a worldwide consultant on account service and will also assist with projects in New York. Sean Cunningham and Lee Doyle, group directors for media, were promoted to co-media directors and assume Mr. Lotito's responsibilities.

title: Welfare Mothers Losing Bonus to Track Fathers
description: Since October, tens of thousands of welfare mothers across the country have lost a monthly bonus, typically about $50 each, that they previously received for helping welfare officials collect child support from absent fathers. Hundreds of thousands more are likely to lose those bonuses as an increasing number of states begin putting the new Federal welfare law to work.

title: Charles House, 88, Chief Justice And Legislator in Connecticut
description: Judge Charles S. House, a Republican who was minority leader in the Connecticut State Senate and Chief Justice of Connecticut's highest court, died on Friday at his home in Manchester, Conn. A native and lifelong resident of Manchester, he was 88.

title: Group's Leader Is Said to Have Used Cult Tactics
description: The people arrested in Monday night's raid on a Brooklyn building were followers, the police say, of a labor organizer turned cult leader who died last year, a man whose past is clouded by aliases, murky organizations and questionable claims.

title: Rules for Safe Disposal Of Dangerous Materials
description: There are many dangerous materials commonly found at home that should never be put at the curb with other household trash, according to sanitation officials.

title: Power Line Paranoia
description: Some scientific controversies never seem to die. After 17 years, the scientific debate over possible adverse health effects of electromagnetic fields from power lines has finally been put to rest by experts at the National Academy of Sciences. After a three-year evaluation of hundreds of scientific papers, the panel concluded that ''the evidence does not show that exposure to these fields presents a human health hazard.'' But critics of power lines are not going to accept the verdict without a struggle. Louis Slesin, the editor of Microwave News, a newsletter about the controversy, said, ''If anyone thinks this report is going to help them sell a home near power lines, they are sadly mistaken.''

title: Salinger Theory Lacks Proof, Officials Say After Meeting
description: Five Federal law enforcement officials met for an hour in Manhattan last night with Pierre Salinger, but afterward several officials said that Mr. Salinger, who was press secretary to President John F. Kennedy, had presented no hard evidence that an errant Navy missile brought down Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: CLINTON SUGGESTS HE MAY NOT RESIST FISCAL AMENDMENT
description: Bowing to political reality, President Clinton today softened his opposition to a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, even as he received a polite but noncommittal response from Congressional Republicans to a range of issues on his agenda for the coming year.

title: Lum Harris, 81, Major League Manager
description: Lum Harris, a former major league pitcher who managed the Atlanta Braves to their first division title in 1969, died Monday in Pell City, Ala. He was 81 and had been ill with diabetes for a long period.

title: At End of 26.2 Miles, Million-Dollar Incentive
description: In an effort to raise the level of marathon running in the United States, the Boston-based New Balance Athletic Shoe Inc., announced yesterday that it would award $1 million to the American man or woman who can break the existing national records in the 26.2-mile event during the 1997 calendar year.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: High-Flying Promotion
description: If NBC needed more proof that its promotions department was as dominant in network television as its program department, the success of its mini-series ''Pandora's Clock'' has provided it.

title: Possible Help on Water Bills
description: The state official who represents the public in rate disputes with utility companies said she would decide today whether recent increases in water rates have made it difficult for some people to pay their water bills and, if so, whether the state can help.

title: Ailing Marvel Receives Offer By Perelman
description: In an attempt to keep the Marvel Entertainment Group from filing for bankruptcy, the controlling shareholder, Ronald O. Perelman, is offering to invest $350 million in the troubled company in a deal that would dilute Marvel's stock by 80 percent.

title: Theater in Review
description: Game of Chance (Like Life!)

title: Calls Issued For Boycott Of Texaco
description: An array of civil rights leaders stepped up pressure on Texaco Inc. yesterday, with calls for a national boycott to protest alleged racial problems there and with demands that the company make changes in its policies toward nonwhites.

title: Rome Talks To Examine Aid to Hungry
description: At a moment when relief agencies are scrambling to get food to an estimated 1 million people trapped in refugee camps in eastern Zaire, the World Food Summit -- which opens here on Wednesday -- does not have to search far for an example of how hunger still plagues a planet that is producing more food than ever.

title: U.S. to Spur Beijing on Trade Group Entry
description: The Clinton Administration plans to tell Chinese leaders, in high-level meetings starting in 10 days, that it is ready to speed up talks on China's entry into the World Trade Organization, although it will not drop demands for a series of market openings that China has so far resisted, Administration officials said today.

title: Anita Hill Plans to Leave Teaching Post in Oklahoma
description: Anita F. Hill, the law school professor who touched a raw nerve in the American psyche during the 1991 confirmation hearings for Judge Clarence Thomas when she accused him of sexual harassment, will leave the University of Oklahoma at the end of this semester ''to pursue other opportunities.''

title: Barbra Streisand, Still Not Pretty Enough
description: By conventional standards, Barbra Streisand is not considered beautiful. ''On the one hand I'll be compared to an Egyptian sculpture and on the other hand people think I'm awful-looking,'' she said. ''My opinion of myself is probably a little bit of both.''

title: The Hero at the Next Table
description: Last year, during my first few months at this newspaper, I eagerly scheduled several breakfast meetings each week to get to know portfolio managers and investment professionals. I soon discovered these meetings were largely forgettable. The participants were typically half-asleep and tended to concentrate more on eating their bagels or berries than on explaining the stock market.

title: G.O.P. Should Pitch 'Values' to Real Families
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sheltered Innocent's Plunge Into Passion
description: ''Breaking the Waves'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4. The film opens today.

title: Ireland's Range War: Urban Cowboys vs. the Law
description: For decades, the young people in Dublin's grimy public-housing ghettos have had one exciting advantage over children in more affluent neighborhoods: horses, about 3,000 of them, living outdoors, where the otherwise underprivileged urban cowboys gallop them bareback, shouting with glee, over sparse grass patches and scrubby fields.

title: Interval Research Is Planning To Spin Off 3 Software Units
description: The Interval Research Corporation, the secretive computer organization created four years ago by the Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, plans to announce three spinoffs on Wednesday.

title: Talk-Show Guest Is Guilty Of Second-Degree Murder
description: A jury today convicted a television talk show guest of second-degree murder in the death of another guest who had declared a homosexual attraction to him.

title: Curry and Crawford Are Hall Nominees
description: The former U.C.L.A. and European star DENISE CURRY and the Amateur Athletics Union standout JOAN CRAWFORD were nominated yesterday for election to the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass.

title: Public Help for Parochial Students, at a Distance
description: If it seems that Bernadine DeCarlo, a public-school social worker who counsels children at a Roman Catholic school in the Bronx, has to act like a spy in a cold war thriller, so be it. She is following Board of Education orders to maintain the separation of church and state.

title: You Think It's a Snap?
description: Business breakfasts have gained popularity because they are ostensibly an improvement over business lunches. Why, then, do so many go wrong? It may be because the participants wrongly assume that a business breakfast is not as important as a business lunch. It may be because they are still not quite awake.

title: Genetic Defect in Women Who Smoke Is Linked To High Risk of Breast Cancer After Menopause
description: SMOKING may cause a fourfold increase in some women's risk of developing breast cancer after menopause, researchers are reporting today. The findings apply to women who carry genes that interfere with their ability to break down certain chemicals in cigarette smoke that are known to cause cancer. The chemicals may then build up in their bodies, and set off the growth of tumors.

title: Scent of Locker Room in Eau de Jordan
description: You don't only take a quick whiff. You savor this fragrance. You let it invade your sinuses. Groove on the scent . . . So light. So refreshing. It will not precede you into a room like a noxious cloud. The name behind it? Brad Pitt? No. Isabella Rossellini? No. Think of a tall man in a tank top, baggy shorts and sneakers who sweats for a living, a man who can more easily walk on a movie set with Bugs Bunny than on city streets with his public.

title: No Headline
description: ''If a Congressman dies in office, it's vulture city, with everyone looking over the office. It gets a little morbid when people come by to look.''

title: Standoff Disrupts Commuters
description: New Jersey Transit suspended rush-hour train service yesterday between Philadelphia and Cherry Hill while the authorities negotiated with a man barricaded in his home near the rail line's tracks in Merchantville, The Associated Press reported.

title: Risotto With Touches of Lobster Fra Diavolo
description: The fancy name given to this risotto, fra diavolo, is a bow to its seasonings of garlic, tomatoes, oregano and hot red-pepper flakes. These ingredients are common to lobster fra diavolo, a wonderful old-fashioned Italian-American recipe whose origins are murky. Today, shrimp is often used in place of lobster because it is less expensive. But the seasonings are good with any seafood.

title: Cornell Running Back Is Hard to Bring Down
description: Last Saturday, a beleaguered Carm Cozza of Yale became the latest in a string of Ivy League football coaches trying to explain the phenomenon he had just witnessed. The Bulldogs had fallen to Cornell, 28-20, and Cozza was trying to explain what had done his team in.

title: Excavating A Monument To Foresight
description: TAP water fascinates George Fox. No, he's not easily amused. He just appreciates what most people ignore when they put a glass under the kitchen faucet. ''You got 13 million people and, boom, spigots around you everywhere -- in basements, jails and in bars,'' he said. ''We take all that for granted.''

title: Drawn by Child's Cries, Police Uncover Arsenal
description: A routine complaint about a crying child Monday night led the police to stumble onto the headquarters of what they called a heavily armed leftist cult that had been living quietly in Brooklyn for 20 years, talking into the night of impending revolution and filling out mounds of bureaucratic paperwork.

title: U.S. Aid to Russia Can't Rein In Mobsters
description: To the Editor:

title: Allied Domecq Says Earnings Fell 10.8%
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C. of Britain reported yesterday that its pretax profit dropped 10.8 percent in the year that ended on Aug. 31. Before a one-time charge, it fell to $:575 million ($949.7 million), from a restated $:645 million a year ago. The results were worse than predicted.

title: Just Say No to Liquor Ads
description: In an effort to recapture some of the alcoholic beverage market from beer and wine, the liquor industry is ending a voluntary ban on radio and television advertising that has been in place for half a century. The industry insists that its new television advertisements will be aimed at adults, not children, but it offers no specific restrictions that would help confine viewer appeal. The major networks have refused to carry the commercials, and President Clinton has rightly denounced the turnaround as ''irresponsible.'' Local affiliates and the cable industry need to follow the networks' lead.

title: Dying Cardinal Asks Court To Rule Against Suicide Aid
description: Writing as a man nearing death, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, has sent a personal letter to the United States Supreme Court asking the Justices not to find that terminally ill people have a constitutional right to doctor-assisted suicide.

title: Athlete's Rape Case Ends in a Mistrial
description: The rape trial of a former high school wrestling star from affluent Darien, Conn., who drew wide attention when he fled to Europe for eight years to avoid prosecution, ended yesterday with a deadlocked jury.

title: Administration Asks Justices to Rule Against Assisted Suicide
description: Weighing in on two of the most closely watched cases of the Supreme Court term, the Clinton Administration today urged the Justices to find that the Constitution does not guarantee to terminally ill people the right to a doctor's assistance in hastening death.

title: A Watchdog Bites
description: George Clooney has yet to prove how successful he might be as the caped crusader, but as a tape crusader, he is already a hit in Hollywood.

title: Utility Settlement Is Attacked
description: Public Service Electric & Gas Company's offer to refund $77.5 million for charges related to its out-of-commission Salem nuclear plants is not large enough, a consumer watchdog group said.

title: How to Help Welfare Mothers
description: The new welfare law allows the states to terminate something called the ''$50 child- support disregard,'' and some states are doing so to save money. This provision allows welfare mothers to keep the first $50 a month paid to them by absent fathers, and is meant to encourage mothers to help government collect child support.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about parents who choose to discipline their children referred incorrectly to the publication Family Relations. It is the research journal of the National Council on Family Relations, not a magazine.

title: Yield Lowest In 8 Months On Long Bond
description: The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell yesterday to its lowest level in eight months as sentiment grew that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting and perhaps not in the coming months.

title: CANADA PROPOSES ZAIRE AID FORCE
description: Canada has volunteered to lead an international force into eastern Zaire to bring food and protection to more than a million refugees displaced by fighting, United Nations officials said today.

title: The Rest of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Coliseum Proposals Attempt To Reflect City's Direction
description: And now for Round 2 of the Battle of the New York Coliseum.

title: Wheat Prices Rise as Forecast Of Big Stockpiles Is Reduced
description: Wheat prices jumped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department said higher domestic and international demand would leave United States stockpiles leaner than expected.

title: Leaving No Seeds Unturned
description: At 7 A.M., I'm usually nursing a cup of black coffee and trying to comprehend the headlines in the newspaper. It is not a time I would pick for breakfast.

title: A Pessimistic Seles Calls '96 Season Dismal
description: The settings have been less than biblical, but suddenly the others are doing to her what she used to do to them. And although she hasn't fallen far, the once-mighty Monica Seles has already taken enough of a fall to write off 1996 as a personal loss whether or not she wins next week's year-ending Chase Championships at the Garden.

title: U.S. Has System to Avert Air Collisions
description: Reliable technology to avoid midair collisions has been in place in big passenger planes in this country since 1993, in the form of a cockpit computer that gives pilots a last-minute warning when human error is leading to what aviators euphemistically call ''conflict.''

title: Deciding When to Seek Execution
description: Because of a unique and so far untested element in New York's new death penalty law, prosecutors who do not feel they have ironclad cases for execution may find it far safer not to seek capital punishment at all. For if a jury cannot decide unanimously whether to impose death or life imprisonment in a first-degree murder case, a judge must then give a defendant the lesser sentence of 20 years to life.

title: Theater in Review
description: On, Dancers! On, Prancers!

title: Personal Health
description: WHEN advised by a respected orthopedist that surgery was unlikely to bring significant relief from the pain in my knees, I decided to take matters into my own hands. Rather than give up tennis, skating and other knee-damaging activities that I love, I consulted an Alexander teacher -- a movement and posture specialist -- who helped somewhat by teaching me how to minimize the stress on my knees from activities like walking, standing and climbing stairs.

title: Simon DeBartolo Picks Evans Group
description: The Simon DeBartolo Group Inc. in Indianapolis, the developer and operator of shopping centers, said yesterday that it had retained the Evans Group in Indianapolis to handle its account, which has been at that agency for five years. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO., St. Louis, said it would buy back about 9 percent of its stock and split its stock 2 for 1 effective March 10 for shareholders of record on Feb. 21, 1997.

title: U.S. Examines Ex-Trade Official's Conduct
description: The inspector general at the Commerce Department has begun a review into a series of contacts between John Huang, a former trade official, and the large Indonesian financial group for whom he had once worked, Administration officials said today.

title: Grants for 6 Museums
description: The Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund has awarded $5 million to help six fine arts museums create programs to attract larger and more diverse audiences. The grants, which range from $800,000 to $900,000 and are to be paid out over three to five years, will go to El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, the Museum of Contemporary Art in San Diego, the San Antonio Museum of Art, the St. Louis Art Museum and the Toledo Museum of Art. The grants are the last under the fund's Museum Collections Accessibility Initiative, which has distributed $32 million to 29 museums since 1991.

title: Stolen Jeep Traced Via Pager
description: A quick-thinking Jersey City woman used modern telecommunications technology to lead police officers to her stolen Jeep, the Jersey City police said yesterday.

title: Coping With an African Emergency
description: The United States has raised legitimate objections to an international plan to protect and assist hundreds of thousands of refugees in Zaire, but Washington must be careful not to obstruct the provision of urgently needed food and medicine to these people.

title: Governors' Group Says States Are in Good Fiscal Condition
description: States are in robust financial condition as they prepare to take greater responsibility for welfare and other domestic programs, the National Governors' Association reported today.

title: Rangers Seek a Reversal of Fortunes
description: Idle since the World Cup with a pulled right groin, Eric Lindros will skate with the Philadelphia Flyers today at Madison Square Garden. But Ranger fans won't get to see the superstar center and the most valuable player of the National Hockey League in 1994-95 when the teams play in the evening.

title: A Huge Insurance Merger: AXA and UAP in France
description: A French insurance giant, AXA, said yesterday that it was buying a rival, UAP, in a stock swap worth $9.02 billion that would create the largest insurer in the world in terms of assets under management.

title: San Diego State Player Is Honored
description: TRAVIS LEE, who played first base and batted .355 for San Diego State and .382 for the United States Olympic team this year, won the 1996 Golden Spikes Award, given annually to the nation's top amateur player. Selected as the No. 2 pick in the June draft by the Minnesota Twins, Lee later agreed to a record $10 million signing bonus by the expansion Arizona Diamondbacks. (AP)

title: National Easter Seal Announces Awards
description: The National Easter Seal Society has named the recipients of its seventh annual Equality, Dignity and Independence, or EDI, Awards, which honor communications judged to enhance the independence of people with disabilities.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Truth Spoken as a Curse

title: Parliament Calls Truce In Fight With Hollywood : One EU Storm Calms, a 2d Brews
description: BRUSSELS  The long saga over European quotas on Hollywood film and television programming imports came to an end Tuesday as the European Parliament failed to muster enough support to tighten quotas and make them legally binding.

title: Setting a Good Example
description: At business breakfasts, there seems to be an unspoken competition to see who can eat the least. People typically tend toward a bowl of fruit or yogurt, even as they are eyeing the flapjacks and home fries further down the menu. But as the only woman at a recent breakfast with three magazine executives at the Millennium Broadway on West 44th Street, I decided to abandon all pretense of daintiness.

title: To the Editor:    In ''Congress Won't Act. Will You?'' (Op-Ed, Nov. 11), Senator Bill Bradley argues that we need radical campaign finance reform for people to ''start taking their democracy back from the power of money.'' However, trying to more tightly control spending by those who contribute too much money to their causes and candidates will not fix what ails our government.    America's central governance problem is that longstanding constitutional constraints limiting government power have been eroded, so that it has turned from protecting the property rights of its citizens to being a violator of those rights on behalf of political supporters.
description: For example, the Constitution grants Congress the power to levy ''uniform taxes'' to provide for the ''general welfare.'' In contrast, today's tax code is riddled with discriminatory taxes that burden particular subgroups of the population, and a large share of government expenditures benefit subgroups of the population at taxpayers' expense.

title: Heir to the Throne at Lazard Freres May Not Be Anymore
description: Is Edouard M. Stern still the heir to the throne at Lazard Freres? Not according to several current and former Lazard partners and employees at the international investment bank, some of whom contend that he may not even continue to work for the firm.

title: Sake Is the Focus For a Hotel Bar
description: The 16-seat Sake Bar in the Hotel Nikko Chicago ''is the only establishment in the country where sake is the primary focus and food is secondary,'' said Elmer Komagata, the director of the Prestige Sake Association, a Los Angeles-based distributor of premium Japanese sakes.

title: The Ineffectual Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Supplier Is Accused of Selling Cheap Coffee as Top Grade
description: To that subspecies of coffee snob for whom the extravagantly priced Hawaiian Kona bean is the liquid equivalent of bliss, Federal agents issued a warning today: The brew you have been sipping may not be quite what you think it is. It might even be (gasp!) from Central America.

title: Good Tailoring Saves the Day
description: With its soaring spaces and coolly minimalist design, Fifty-Seven Fifty-Seven, the restaurant in the Four Seasons Hotel, looks like the kind of place where broadcasting and entertainment potentates would hang out.

title: Can Success Catch Up To the Lions' Sanders?
description: This is the eighth season with the Detroit Lions for Barry Sanders, and after watching him against the San Diego Chargers here on Monday night it is obvious that this special running back can still juke, jive, dive, dance, prance and spin unlike any other pro back.

title: Tharp's Henpecked David, Energetic Guest at a Gala
description: Working on assignment is always a risky proposition, even for those who do not believe in inspiration, divine or otherwise. Twyla Tharp was invited to choreograph a piece d'occasion for ''An Evening With King David,'' a gala benefit for the Jerusalem Foundation on Monday night, and she did so dutifully, fitfully and energetically.

title: Big Shifts in Holdings Disclosed For Fidelity's Magellan Fund
description: In his first five months at the helm of the country's largest mutual fund, Robert E. Stansky has significantly overhauled the Fidelity Magellan fund's portfolio, adding to technology stocks and spreading the assets over a broader array of companies.

title: Dell Computer Reports 93% Net Gain for Quarter
description: The Dell Computer Corporation reported yesterday that earnings had nearly doubled in its third quarter, exceeding analysts' estimates by a wide margin. The company attributed the strong results to market share gains and the continued success of its direct-sales approach.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Nov. 8 about the American League's Manager of the Year award referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of years Johnny Oates has managed the Texas Rangers. This was his second year, not his first.

title: 2 LESLIE'S POOLMART EXECUTIVES BID FOR COMPANY
description: Leslie's Poolmart, a swimming pool products supplier in Chatsworth, Calif., said yesterday that a group led by its chairman and its president had offered to buy the company for $14.50 a share in cash, or about $109 million. Leslie's shares rose $2.25 yesterday, to $13.75, in Nasdaq trading. The shares reached a 52-week high of $19.50 in June, then fell to $10.50, their lowest level in more than two years. The partnership led by Leslie's chairman, Michael J. Fourticq, and president, Brian P. McDermott, is Hancock Park Associates II L.P. Two other companies wanted to buy Leslie's, but their offers were the same as or less than Hancock Park's, the company said.

title: Judge Declares A Mistrial In Rape Case
description: Ten years after a 16-year-old girl from Darien accused Alex Kelly of rape, his trial ended today with a deadlocked jury and an extraordinary exchange of bitter accusations.

title: Probation for a Former Officer
description: In the most lenient sentence yet handed down in Harlem's 30th Precinct corruption scandal, a former police officer who admitted stealing drugs and then selling them was sentenced yesterday to four years of probation.

title: Boardwalk Will Get a Rink
description: In Atlantic City, amenities that other cities take for granted are sometimes scarce or nonexistent. There is no movie theater, for example, and the opening of a supermarket earlier this year was greeted as a milestone. But on Dec. 13, a portable ice-skating rink will open on the Boardwalk in front of Convention Hall, The Associated Press reported.

title: CBS Wants the N.F.L. Back
description: Sean McManus, who will take over as president of CBS Sports on Dec. 18, said yesterday that reacquiring television rights to the National Football League is ''a huge priority, but it's not the only priority.''

title: Jets Perplexed by Their Losing Ways
description: The Jets, as the King of Siam might have said had he followed pro football, are a puzzlement.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly in some editions to the high school whose R.O.T.C. members were shown. It was Francis Lewis, a city high school in Flushing, Queens, not St. Francis High School.

title: Rules to Stop Gas Explosions
description: The State Board of Public Utilities announced new rules yesterday that are intended to prevent accidents like the 1994 natural-gas-line explosion that injured more than 100 residents of an apartment complex in Edison Township.

title: Talks on Getting Along Get the Silent Treatment
description: While the negotiated labor agreement between the players and the owners remained on life support yesterday, the so-called summit meeting stemming from the Roberto Alomar spitting incident was put on hold.

title: To the Guy in the Highchair: Good Luck?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks fell today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 226.99 points, or 1.07 percent, to 20,979.44. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 141.35.

title: When a Legacy of Massacre Rises Up to Haunt a Family
description: Under most circumstances, Non, the stoical but loving matriarch in Leslie Ayvazian's ''Nine Armenians,'' is the sort of character to send you bolting from the theater and into the arms of a very dry martini.

title: INSIDE
description: Suspect Won't Face Death

title: 2d Day of Bosnia Fighting Is Worst Since '95 Pact
description: In the worst fighting since the Dayton peace agreement was reached last year, a pitched morning battle and then an afternoon firefight broke out between Muslims trying to return to their former homes and Serbs who hope to keep them out.

title: G.O.P. Should Pitch 'Values' to Real Families
description: To the Editor:

title: At Business Breakfasts, Minimalist Menus and Maximum Gains
description: FOR the city's power brokers -- the people who make the deals or the policies that are the raw material for the next morning's headlines -- breakfast has long been a favorite time to meet. But after the expense-account-mad 1980's, power lunches seemed more convenient. And a power drink after work was more chic (and less expensive).

title: Good Staff, Vision and a Covetous Eye
description: Armed with detailed floor plans and the square footage of every House office on Capitol Hill, Lisa Weigle pored over her scouting report and assessed her chances.

title: USAir to Get New Name, But Old Costs Will Remain
description: After toiling behind closed doors since January, USAir's latest management team yesterday presented a new strategy for the company that includes a new name, a new logo and paint jobs for its planes.

title: Surgery Goes Well for Wilson
description: The Mets are expecting Paul Wilson to pitch pain-free after undergoing arthroscopic surgery last night to repair a small tear in the labrum of his right shoulder. The hourlong procedure was performed by Dr. James Andrews in Birmingham, Ala. Wilson should be fit for the opening of spring training in February.

title: More Mogul Madness
description: When we last visited our indefatigable media moguls, Ted Turner was likening Rupert Murdoch to Hitler, Mr. Murdoch was running cartoons in The New York Post portraying Mr. Turner as a straitjacketed nutcase, and Mr. Turner's wife, Jane Fonda, was dissing Rudolph Giuliani's wife, Donna Hanover.

title: A Small Hideaway Attracting the Stars
description: It's the kind of place that if you can't find it, you're not supposed to. Yet, when Cindy, Kate, Naomi, Claudia, Julian, Bruce, Slash and Julio are in town and want to kick back with their superstar friends, they know how to get to the Whiskey Bar, discreetly off the lobby of the Sunset Marquis, the exclusive all-suite hotel that has been an entertainment industry refuge since the 1930's.

title: Pentagon Expands Inquiry Into Chemical Exposure in the Gulf War
description: The Pentagon today announced a sweeping expansion of its investigation into whether American soldiers were exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons in the 1991 Persian Gulf war and suggested that it would resist calls to turn over the inquiry to outside investigators.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Friends of Prof. HENRY PINKHAM who have seen the new movie ''The Mirror Has Two Faces'' have noticed certain similarities between the Columbia University math professor and the character played by Jeff Bridges.

title: Trash Haulers Accused of Fixing Federal Bids
description: In a new phase of a campaign against suspected Mafia control of the commercial garbage industry, state prosecutors said yesterday that they had found another victim: the Federal Government.

title: Theater in Review
description: Fighting Fire With Fire

title: George Klebnikov, 73, a Language Wizard
description: George Klebnikov, a pioneer of simultaneous language interpretation at the Nuremberg trials who helped introduce the art to the United Nations and later became chief of interpretation services there, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: WITH winter on its way, my husband and I were making preparations for our annual stay in Florida. Checking the freezer, I discovered that it still contained three pounds of probably the finest Bolognese meat sauce I had ever created. Reluctant to discard it, I decided that my husband, traveling down a week ahead of me, should take the sauce with him in a small, thickly insulated freezer bag.

title: Limit Television Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Bishops Affirm Economic Principles That Raised a Storm in the 80's
description: Ten years after the nation's Roman Catholic bishops issued a lengthy pastoral letter challenging Reagan-era enthusiasm for an unrestrained market economy, they have reasserted their moral convictions about economic life, but now boiled down to a few hundred words.

title: Dad Is a Chef, and Can He Ever Cook
description: PATRICK CLARK, the executive chef of Tavern on the Green, knows that the tastes of his five children, ages 5 to 15, may not be typical. ''My 5-year-old likes lobster and my 8-year-old wanted shrimp curry for her birthday,'' he said.

title: A Rock Icon Still Hits The Sweet High Notes
description: A WAITER placed a plate of thinly sliced raw scallops in front of the tall, angular man who had asked for a vegetarian tasting dinner. Surprised, but not flustered by it, he poked his chopsticks at the gossamer little disks and dipped one in a lemony marinade.

title: CSX Puts Off Making a Higher Offer to Acquire Conrail
description: Despite intense pressure to match a $10 billion all-cash bid from the rival Norfolk Southern Corporation, the CSX Corporation has decided for now not to raise its offer for Conrail.

title: Roses and Outrage at Funeral for 2 Young Girls
description: Police officers brought pink roses. Classmates brought teddy bears. And the 400 mourners who filled the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church here today brought the outrage of a community stunned by society's failure to protect its children.

title: Nets May Start Kittles at Point
description: It wasn't a peace pipe, just a cigar. And since it didn't have playing time rolled up inside, the offering wasn't going to make Robert Pack feel any closer to Nets Coach John Calipari.

title: Accounts
description: Loyola University Medical Center, Maywood, Ill., to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, to handle its account, which had been at Bozell Worldwide, Chicago, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Hugo Buchthal Is Dead at 87; Studied Medieval Illumination
description: Hugo Buchthal, who fled Nazi Germany and became a renowned New York University art historian and an authority on the interplay of cultures in another turbulent age, died on Sunday at a retirement home in London. He was 87.

title: New Fraud Rule For Auditors
description: The accounting industry agreed yesterday to adopt a new standard aimed at clarifying the auditor's role in detecting fraud in financial statements.

title: Neighbors Give Thanks For Arrest of 'Supers'
description: The faces changed every few months in the buildings on Carroll Street, so often that it became almost routine. Still, the tenants would ask the new people who they were.

title: Suspect in Crime Spree Won't Face Execution
description: Prosecutors will not seek the death penalty against John J. Royster, who is accused of murdering the owner of a Park Avenue dry cleaner, beating a piano teacher in Central Park and attacking two other women. Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said he would instead pursue life without parole in the case.

title: Retail Shares Decline Despite Earnings
description: Posting the best quarter of earnings in more than a year is not enough these days -- a company must also beat analyst expectations.

title: Sunbeam to Halve Work Force Of 12,000 and Sell Some Units
description: Albert J. Dunlap, the chairman and chief executive of the Sunbeam Corporation for nearly four months, announced yesterday that half of the company's 12,000 employees will be let go, through layoffs or sales of divisions, in the biggest restructuring in the company's history.

title: Two Airliners Collide in Midair, Killing All 351 Aboard in India
description: All 351 passengers and crew appeared to have been killed on Tuesday night when a Saudi Arabian jumbo jet collided shortly after takeoff with a Kazak Airlines plane approaching the New Delhi airport, Indian aviation officials said. The death toll made it the third-deadliest air crash and the worst mid-air collision in aviation history.

title: Four Seasons to Enter India
description: Four Seasons Hotels agreed today to manage three luxury hotels in India, entering the country for the first time. The hotels are a beach resort to be renovated in the coastal enclave of Goa and business hotels under construction in Bombay and Bangalore. The Leela Group, a hotel developer in India, will spend $315 million to build and renovate the hotels, a Four Seasons spokesman, John Richards, said. Four Seasons, based here, manages 37 hotels and resorts worldwide under the Four Seasons and Regent names.

title: Another Tally In '96 Race: Two Months Of TV Ads
description: To watch every repetition of every Democratic Presidential commercial broadcast from the beginning of April through last week's election, you would have to sit glued to the set, all day and all night, and for an entire month.

title: Strict check-in and checkout times at hotels are becoming a casualty of globe-trotting executives.
description: THERE are early warning signs that the sacred noon check-in and checkout times at hotels -- or variations -- may become a casualty of global business travel.

title: AES CORPORATION TO BUY AFFILIATED AES CHINA GENERATING
description: The AES Corporation, a global power company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire its affiliated company, the AES China Generating Company, in a stock swap valued at $107 million to $120 million. The AES Corporation, which is based in Arlington, Va., said AES China shareholders would receive AES Corporation stock valued at $45 to $50 for each of their shares. The president of the AES Corporation, Dennis W. Bakke, said the deal would ''enhance our collective ability to help meet China's expanding needs for electric power.'' AES China has invested in eight power generation projects in China. Shares of the AES Corporation were up 25 cents to close at $46.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of AES China fell 75 cents to close at $13 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Big Auto Insurers Go on the Offensive As Big Time Fraud Gains Sophistication
description: On a flawless, sunny day in Chicago, Mike Borders and his wife, Nancy, were just picking up speed on Lake Shore Drive in their beige Mercedes when a 14-year-old Buick lurched to a halt in front of them.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM WOLFE, the novelist and journalist, has a nose for news and, as it turns out, a nose for noses, or so it would seem.

title: Trash Collector Dies After Inhaling Discarded Acid
description: A New York City sanitation worker died yesterday after he inhaled the fumes of a corrosive acid from a discarded container that burst under the compacting blades of a garbage truck making routine collections in Brooklyn.

title: 2 Are Named to Plan Clinton Inauguration
description: The last time Bill Clinton held an inauguration it was an elaborate affair with a bus caravan from Monticello, a national bell-ringing ceremony, a White House open house, a soup kitchen and 10 balls.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Nov. 5 about physicists who attended a meeting at Princeton University on the future of their field referred incorrectly to the attendance at a similar meeting there in 1946. Dr. Philip Anderson was at this year's meeting but not the 1946 meeting; Dr. Abraham Pais was at both.

title: The N.B.A. And Iverson, One on One
description: ALLEN IVERSON was just getting to the part about adjusting to the National Basketball Association's invisible rules when he got to the place where the 76ers' team bus was supposed to be. No bus.

title: Pettitte Finds Race Doesn't Go to the Winningest
description: The Yankees' Andy Pettitte was the winner of the race for victories in the American League this season. But he found out yesterday that winning is not enough sometimes. Pettitte was edged in the voting for the Cy Young Award by Pat Hentgen of Toronto, the major league leader in complete games and innings pitched.

title: A Montage on Russia, With Love and Sorrow
description: What are the ties that bind a nation? It is a question that haunts Nikita Mikhalkov's fascinating documentary film ''Anna,'' in which he parallels the growth of his own daughter with the dissolution of the Soviet Union. By the end of the movie, the only answers that the distinguished Russian film maker (''Burnt by the Sun'') can come up with are vague metaphysical notions of religion and homeland.

title: Pancakes Blend A Pair of Cultures
description: Imagine the world's most decadent breakfast, triple it, fry it, sprinkle it with sugar, and you are at the Dutch Pancake Cafe eating pancakes bigger than pancakes have any right to be, with toppings and fillings not even Elvis would have concocted.

title: Parents in the Emergency Room? Researchers Have Some Answers
description: WHEN 2-year-old Laura Vaughn entered White Plains Hospital in suburban New York to have her tonsils out, her mother wanted to be with her when she awakened from the anesthesia. But the doctor said no visitors, not even parents, were allowed in the recovery room, so Jean Vaughn had to sit in the waiting room down the hall.

title: Pataki Is Urged to Seek Waiving of Work Rule to Obtain Food Stamps
description: As state officials put the finishing touches on a sweeping overhaul of New York's welfare system today, advocates for the poor called on Gov. George E. Pataki to seek an exemption from new Federal rules requiring thousands of adults to work in exchange for food stamps.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Museum's Fortunes Rise at Auction
description: What would the Havemeyers have thought?

title: No, the Music Isn't the Whole Idea
description: With the word ''naked'' in the title, a television series eager to grab an audience would seem to be halfway home. At least that's what Bravo is counting on with ''Naked Classics,'' a three-part documentary series that, beginning on Sunday as part of its new ''Expose'' showcase, tries to get behind the somewhat snooty facade of the classical music business. Produced with Channel Four of Britain, the programs come from the same team that created ''Naked Hollywood'' in 1991.

title: ANCHOR GAMING SHARES FALL ON POSSIBLE CHANGE IN PLANS
description: The shares of Anchor Gaming fell 22 percent yesterday as investors were concerned that the company's reconsideration of an addition to a Colorado casino would hurt its earnings. The stock fell $8.875 a share, to $30.125, in Nasdaq trading of 3.2 million shares. Anchor, based in Las Vegas, Nev., makes the popular Wheel of Gold casino game. The company said it was re-evaluating plans to expand its casino in Black Hawk, Colo. It did not elaborate, and company officials could not be reached immediately for comment.

title: Brodeur Secures Devils' Winning Streak
description: Martin Brodeur demonstrated one more time his invincibility against the Washington Capitals. Although he allowed two goals on consecutive shots in the second period tonight after setting a franchise record for shutout minutes, Brodeur settled down and the Devils squeezed out a 3-2 overtime triumph at Continental Arena.

title: Wrong Way on Welfare
description: The overhaul of welfare enacted in Washington this year poses a staggering challenge in New York State, where 1.4 million poor people count on the program to survive. It is thus dismaying that Gov. George Pataki has opted to implement the federally mandated welfare changes in a needlessly harsh spirit. The new law's work requirements and aid cutoffs will be difficult enough to manage under the best circumstances. According to reports leaking in Albany, Mr. Pataki will propose sharp cuts in welfare grants beyond what the Federal law requires in an apparent effort to balance the state budget on the backs of the poor and their children.

title: Olivetti Shares Soar On Sale of Assets
description: The shares of Olivetti S.p.A. soared yesterday for a second day amid enthusiasm that the office products maker's plan to sell some assets would exceed expectations. Olivetti stock rose 31 lire, or 6.5 percent, to 510, its highest price in a month, after gaining 6 percent on Monday.

title: Mayor Gets a Second Rival
description: In May 1993, Bret Schundler won 69 percent of the vote, becoming the first Republican Mayor of Jersey City since 1917. Over the next two years he endeared himself to voters by cutting taxes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business day yesterday about a report calling for new standards for corporate boards misidentified the organization that gives a Director of the Year award. It is the National Association of Corporate Directors, not the commission it assembled to write board standards.

title: Chronic Illness Has Vast Cost, A Study Finds
description: Nearly 100 million Americans have chronic diseases or disabilities, and caring for them accounts for three-fourths of the nation's health spending, researchers reported today.

title: Compassion and Peril in Africa
description: Momentum is building for military intervention in Eastern Zaire, where hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees have been cut off from aid by fighting between rebels, the Zairian Army and Rwandan Hutu guerrillas. But any force that would wade into the conflict here would face a quandary not unlike the one American soldiers faced in Somalia two years ago when they tried to help the United Nations stop a famine there -- how to avoid fueling a war.

title: The New Zagat Favorite in New York
description: THE Union Square Cafe was rated the favorite restaurant in the 1997 Zagat survey of New York City restaurants, replacing Bouley, which had been the reigning favorite since 1992, but closed in June.

title: David A. Wood, 91; Led a Cancer Institute
description: David Alvra Wood, who headed the Cancer Research Institute at the University of California at San Francisco from 1951 to 1972, died on Nov. 6 at the California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 91 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 19 about a visit to New York by Mikhail B. Piotrovksy, director of the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, misidentified the producers of a television program, ''The Hermitage: A Russian Odyssey.'' It was produced by Daniel Wilson Productions for the Christian Science Publishing Society, not by PBS.

title: No Death Penalty in Park Ave. Killing
description: John J. Royster, accused of murdering the owner of a Park Avenue dry cleaner, beating a piano teacher in Central Park and attacking two other women, will not face the death penalty, the Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday.

title: Columbia Women In Soccer Tourney
