description: The Columbia women's soccer team has received its first invitation to the East Coast Athletic Conference tournament. The fourth-seeded Lions will play visiting and fifth-seeded Army today at 7 P.M. at Baker Field. The winner will advance to the semifinals Saturday afternoon in New Haven against Yale or Colgate.

title: Affordable Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Try to Ignore the Headhunters
description: THE SPEARS OF TWILIGHT

title: Woman, 73, Found Dead Of Stabbing
description: A man returning home from work yesterday afternoon found his mother stabbed to death and his 3-year-old son critically wounded -- with stab wounds throughout his body -- at his Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: Celtic Eyes Smiling as Feet Are Dancing
description: At 2 on Sunday morning, dance floors were busy at the Friar Tuck Inn here. In one room, couples stamped and spun to a 50-year-old Irish group, the Tulla Ceili Band. In another, couples two-stepped to a Louisiana Cajun band, File. Elsewhere, musicians from Brittany were playing flute-driven dances. Wherever people could pull a few chairs together, musicians were sharing tunes and watching fingers fly.

title: Wine Talk
description: ARE you ready to become a serious wine buyer? Not deadly serious, just moderately serious? There is a defining moment, you know. It's the first time you say to a salesclerk, ''I'll take a case.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Set to Speed Entry By China Into Trade Group

title: Buyers Are Sought For 28% Stake in Cofir
description: Carlo de Benedetti has hired an investment bank to solicit buyers for the 48 percent stake in Cofir S.A. that is held by a French company of his, Cerus. Cofir, of Madrid, said Mr. de Benedetti had retained J. Henry Schroder & Company to seek prospects. The announcement sent shares of Cofir up as much as 29 pesetas to 375 pesetas. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Food Notes
description: Help Numbers for Cooks

title: The Summer Olympics failed to vault any gold medal winners into major endorsement deals.
description: THE Olympic Games in Atlanta were supposed to be the launching pad for the next Bruce Jenner or Mary Lou Retton. Gold in Atlanta was supposed to beget gold on Madison Avenue.

title: G.O.P. Should Pitch 'Values' to Real Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Setback for Hispanic Congressional District
description: The Supreme Court today threw into doubt the future of the first Hispanic-majority Congressional district in the Midwest, setting aside a lower court's decision that found the oddly shaped Illinois district to be constitutional.

title: Pyramid Power
description: The most revealing thing about the Middle East Economic Conference that opened in Cairo yesterday was that it was held at all. There was a big fight here over whether to host this annual gathering of 1,500 global investors and Arab and Israeli business leaders. Many in the Egyptian Foreign Ministry argued against it, contending that these economic summits were part of the Oslo peace process, designed to promote commerce between and within the Arab world and Israel. To hold the summit at a time when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has stalled the peace process, argued the Egyptian Foreign Ministry, would be to reward Israel for intransigence. The Islamic opposition newspaper Al-Shaab denounced this gathering as ''the conference of shame.''

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: People
description: Jim Helberg was named senior vice president and media director at G2, a division of Grey Advertising, Huntington Beach, Calif., succeeding Gail Bindi, who left.

title: One Sergeant Pleads Guilty As Army Widens Sex Inquiry
description: On the same day the Army announced that it had expanded its investigation into allegations of sexual harassment in its ranks to all 17 of its training bases, a male drill sergeant at one of its largest training installations pleaded guilty today to having sex with three female recruits.

title: U.S.G.A. Decides That Nicklaus Belongs
description: The recent announcement by the United States Golf Association that it has granted a special exemption to Jack Nicklaus for next year's United States Open at Congressional Country Club is perplexing. It's not that Nicklaus, 56, doesn't belong in the Open for the 41st time. It's just that he had given the impression he didn't feel as though he belonged.

title: Fruitless Exercise
description: To the Editor:

title: 17 Years in Fatal Arson
description: A man who lighted a fire to keep warm inside an abandoned building last year, igniting a blaze that killed a Queens firefighter, was sentenced yesterday to 17 years to life in prison for the killing.

title: Free Range? Natural? Sorting Out Labels
description: SO why did the chicken cross the road?

title: A Fish Out of Water
description: In the summer of 1993, while I was working in Japan as a foreign correspondent for another newspaper, a colleague at a Japanese daily asked me to go fishing with several businessmen in the mountains above Nagoya, about 175 miles southwest of Tokyo. I left my apartment shortly after 4 in the morning, arriving at the river resort shortly after 7. No one had eaten. So, our host decided that we should start the day with a meal together.

title: New Mexico State Coach Is Dismissed
description: Coach JIM HESS of New Mexico State was dismissed yesterday, just four years after leading the Aggies to their first winning season in 14 years.

title: 4 Indicted in Stock Bribe Case Involving Firm Set Up by F.B.I.
description: The first indictments were returned yesterday against stock promoters who were arrested last month in an F.B.I. sting intended to catch people who were willing to bribe stockbrokers.

title: Tone Is Edgy as Mideast Economic Conference Opens in Cairo
description: As political and business leaders gathered to celebrate commerce as a bridge across political divides, the subdued mood here spoke to what has changed in the Middle East since their last conclave a year ago.

title: Burning at Both Ends, Boomers Turn 50
description: MAYBE it's sheer numbers. Maybe they're late bloomers. Or maybe it's because, at the moment, they've got all the money.

title: Iverson Is the Philadelphia Story as 76ers Beat the Knicks
description: A young, exciting backcourt star rose to the forefront last night at Madison Square Garden. And when Allen Iverson's season-high 35-point performance had finished off the Knicks, New York's three-game winning streak was finished as well.

title: Still a Mystery
description: The Discovery Channel could get some promotional mileage out of the furor over Pierre Salinger's allegations that the Federal Government concealed evidence that an errant Navy missile might have caused the crash of the T.W.A. jetliner. Discovery's documentary ''The Crash of T.W.A. Flight 800: A Scientific Investigation'' is scheduled for Sunday night at 9.

title: Prized Syracuse Recruit Won't Play
description: WINFRED WALTON, the star recruit who was expected to start at power forward for Syracuse, must sit out the season because of poor scores on his college entrance tests.

title: Wacker Quits at Minnesota
description: JIM WACKER took over at Minnesota five years ago, determined to lead the Gophers to the Big Ten title, the Rose Bowl and whatever other glory was out there.

title: A Legal Star
description: Not a bad start for Erik Sorenson, who became the executive producer of Court TV about 10 weeks ago. Yesterday, he and the cable channel's founder, Steve Brill, announced that they had signed Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., the high-profile lawyer who successfully defended O. J. Simpson, to be a co-host of a live, five-night-a-week talk show.

title: Budget for Nassau Is Signed With Homeowner Tax Cuts
description: The Nassau County Executive signed a budget today that will provide tax cuts of between $15 and $20 for homeowners.

title: Choosing the World's Top Diplomat
description: Before the end of the year, the United Nations is likely for the first time to deny a sitting Secretary General a second five-year term. In May, the Clinton Administration announced it would veto Boutros Boutros-Ghali's re-election. He has proposed a compromise two-year extension, but Washington seems unlikely to agree. A General Assembly vote to overrule the United States is possible, but improbable. The U.N., therefore, has some decisions to make.

title: Merrill in Paris in Spring
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the largest United States securities firm, said today that it would open a brokerage in Paris in the spring to play a more aggressive role in trading French equities. ''Merrill Lynch occupies the No. 1 spot in equities trading in London,'' Michel Fleuriet, the head of Merrill Lynch's French operations, said. ''We feel we can play an important role in Paris, too.'' At present, Merrill does its French stock trading through other Paris-based brokerage firms.

title: Interest Rates Not Changed By Fed Panel
description: The Federal Reserve voted to keep interest rates unchanged today, as the Government's report on producer prices provided the latest evidence that inflation remained quiescent despite a surge last month in food and energy costs.

title: Orgy Of Disloyalty
description: It has been said that yuppies don't have loyalty. They have useful relationships and meaningful encounters. They don't have friends, they have contacts.

title: Dorothy Bird, Dancer, Dies at 84; Performed With Martha Graham
description: Dorothy Bird, an early Martha Graham dancer who also appeared on Broadway and became a noted Graham teacher, died on Tuesday at the home of her son, Casey Villard, in Etna, N.H. She was 84.

title: PACTEL CANCELS DEAL FOR 2 WIRELESS VIDEO SYSTEMS
description: The Pacific Telesis Group canceled its planned $175 million acquisition yesterday of Wireless Holdings Inc. and Videotron Bay Area Inc., which are wireless video joint ventures of Transworld Telecommunications Inc. and Le Groupe Videotron. Pacific Telesis said it would not make concessions demanded by Videotron and Transworld. Groupe Videotron said it would fight the decision. A Pacific Telesis spokesman, Craig Watts, acknowledged the company is now without a way to deliver TV signals in San Francisco or San Diego. Pacific Telesis had said last year that it would pay as much as $175 million for the systems.

title: Servers at an Exhibition
description: Though it will only be only an exhibition, men's tennis will return to Madison Square Garden next month for the first time since 1989. PETE SAMPRAS, ranked No. 1 in the world, and three former No. 1 players -- ANDRE AGASSI, JIM COURIER and JOHN McENROE -- will play in the Nike Cup on Dec. 20 to raise money for the Tim and Tom Gullikson Foundation to help patients who have brain cancer and their families.

title: Panel Proposes Large Raises For Top Officials in Suffolk
description: A panel appointed by the Suffolk County Executive proposed raises up to 62 percent for the county's top elected and management officials today.

title: Cathay Pacific Shuffles Its Top Management
description: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd., Hong Kong's flag carrier, made changes in its top management yesterday, naming an executive of Dragonair, Philip Chen, as its new deputy managing director. Cathay Pacific, 48 percent owned by the British-controlled Swire Pacific Ltd., announced the changes two months after naming a new chief executive, David Turnbull. Mr. Chen replaces Simon Heale, who becomes finance director at Swire Pacific.

title: Man Held in Slaying Of His Grandmother
description: The grandson of a woman found stabbed to death in a Brooklyn apartment on Monday was charged yesterday with killing her during a robbery and critically wounding another grandson, the police said.

title: UConn's Sales Emerges As Coaches' Top Choice
description: The Big East women's basketball coaches chose their preseason player of the year today. Some clues:

title: Guzman Re-signs With Jays
description: JUAN GUZMAN and the Toronto Blue Jays agreed yesterday to a $9.5 million, two-year contract. Guzman, who made $2.24 million last season, will get $4 million in 1997 and $5 million in 1998. The Blue Jays have an option for 1999 at $5.25 million with a $500,000 buyout, and are giving him an interest-free loan of $1 million, payable over the three years.

title: Hampton Turns a Step Too Slow ...
description: Talking about it, players wince. None of them wants to admit it, but they all know it's true. Even the head coach, who is such a big fan of his that he has constantly defended his skills, finally admitted the obvious today. Rodney Hampton is probably the most popular, most respected player in the Giants' locker room, yet right now, fairly or unfairly, he's the one being scrutinized for the woes of the running game.

title: RATIONAL SOFTWARE TO ACQUIRE SQA IN STOCK SWAP
description: The Rational Software Corporation agreed late Tuesday to acquire SQA Inc. for stock valued at $313 million. Rational Software, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would pay 0.86 share of its stock, or $35.26 a share, for each SQA share. SQA has 8.9 million shares outstanding. Shares of SQA rose $7 a share, or 27.5 percent, to $32.50. Rational Software, which makes software used by telecommunications and aerospace companies, dropped $1, to $40. SQA, based in Burlington, Mass., makes software to test applications on networks. Rational Software said it would take a charge for the SQA purchase in its fourth quarter ending in March.

title: Accusations That Are Readily Believed
description: In the 1980's, nearly 200 parents and child-care workers in 40 communities were accused of molesting young children, their own or those who had been entrusted to their care. Scary stories on television and in the press fueled fears that bred new charges.

title: Saatchi Officials To Switch Roles
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide said yesterday that Alan Bishop and Jennifer Laing, senior executives in its North American and London operations, respectively, would switch roles at the end of the year.

title: Ford Will Move Its Corporate Work
description: The Ford Motor Company unexpectedly said yesterday that it would move its worldwide corporate advertising account to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, from the Detroit and New York offices of Wells Rich Greene BDDP, effective in February. Billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Pataki Releases Details of Plan To Cut Welfare
description: Releasing a sweeping welfare plan that includes new restrictions on benefits, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he was not trying to balance the state budget on the backs of the poor and vowed to reinvest all savings from his proposal into day care, job training and other programs intended to end welfare dependency.

title: Honors College Is Cited in the Defense of Adelphi's President
description: The dean of Adelphi University's honors college praised its establishment yesterday as a major accomplishment of the school's president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos.

title: Interstate to Acquire Hotel
description: The Interstate Hotels Company has agreed to buy the 400-room Washington Vista hotel in Washington for about $50.7 million. The Pittsburgh-based hotel management concern said it would convert the hotel to the Westin brand. After the deal, Interstate Hotels will own or have a controlling interest in 25 hotels and manage another 161 hotels in 28 states, as well as Canada, Mexico, Israel, the Caribbean, Thailand, Panama and Russia. The seller was not disclosed.

title: Pope Tells U.N. Group Population Control Is No Cure for Hunger
description: In an opening address at the World Food Summit here, Pope John Paul II injected a hint of old controversies today as he chided those who link hunger with overpopulation.

title: The Art of Offending
description: On Election Day, a time when the news media wouldn't have been paying much attention, a Federal appeals court ruled in the case in which I became notorious as ''the chocolate-smeared woman.''

title: Harnessing Horses Instead of Writers
description: JANE AMSTERDAM, the former New York news media star, stood in her immaculate horse barn painstakingly adjusting a harness encircling Beverley, her high-stepping hackney. One of its leather bands had to be tightened by three holes, but Ms. Amsterdam could tell that the horse needed time to get used to the annoying straps.

title: In Clash of Decades, A House Surrenders
description: THE iron address sign on the oak tree on Sheridan Road still says, ''1371.'' But all that's left of the house I grew up in is the chimney.

title: Safety Board Cites Crew Error in Air Accident
description: An American Airlines jet with 78 people on board came within a few feet of a catastrophic crash near Hartford last November because the pilots were looking out the windows for the runway when they should have been watching their instruments, the National Transportation Safety Board said today. Because of that error the plane descended more than 300 feet below the minimum safe altitude.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Columbia U. to Offer Cheaper, Simpler Loans
description: Persuading bankers to treat its students as preferred customers, Columbia University announced a new student loan program yesterday with lower rates, more flexibility in repayments and one-stop shopping for loans. Financial aid experts said the program was likely to be used as a model by other expensive private colleges.

title: Love and Manners and Meaning, All on E-Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Ex-Officials of Transit Police Union Indicted in Scheme to Buy Cars
description: Two former officials of the union that once represented transit police officers were indicted yesterday on charges that they used the association's money to buy late-model cars for themselves, family and friends.

title: Keeping Us Social
description: To the Editor:

title: Highway Project Is Opposed
description: Borough and township officials agreed Tuesday to oppose a $45 million project designed to alleviate traffic congestion along Route 1. The proposed Millstone Bypass would close Washington Road, an elm-lined thoroughfare that is nearly 200 years old, and funnel all traffic to Princeton from Route 1 onto a single overpass. Traffic along Route 1 would speed up because four traffic lights would be eliminated. Princeton officials believe that the plan would dump more traffic into an already congested downtown, said Sandra Starr, a Borough Council member.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How do you compress 1,100 years of history into three minutes? That's a tall order even in the age of sound bites, but GYORGY BANLAKI, Hungary's Ambassador to the United States, managed to do it at a black-tie dinner on Tuesday celebrating his country's millennium-plus-one-century anniversary at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Poor Earnings Send Retail Stocks Lower
description: Retail stocks endured a second day of pounding yesterday, with some companies paying for the earnings misdeeds of their peers as many skittish investors headed for the exit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Westinghouse to Spin Off Industrial Businesses

title: For Texaco, an Unsought Role on a Big Stage
description: On Monday, Texaco Inc. announced that contrary to the claims made in court records, no company executives had been caught on tape uttering racial epithets. Still, it apologized for the tone and content of that recorded meeting. In addition, the company reaffirmed the promise it made last week to review and reform its equal opportunity policies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In New York on the same evening, at two parties honoring authors of children's books, the social tone was somewhat less sophisticated.

title: Caminiti Gets M.V.P.; Matt Williams Gets Traded
description: The National League's two best third basemen received momentous news yesterday. Ken Caminiti of San Diego learned he was the National League most valuable player, and Matt Williams of San Francisco learned he was traded to the Cleveland Indians.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the resignation of Harold M. Ickes as deputy White House chief of staff misstated the requirements for appointment as director of the National Park Service, a job that some in the White House said Mr. Ickes might seek. The omnibus parks appropriation bill signed by President Clinton on Tuesday would, for the first time, require Senate confirmation to the post.

title: Immigration Law
description: To the Editor:

title: B.C.'s Speight Leaving Team
description: Boston College cornerback KIERNAN SPEIGHT, accused but exonerated in the gambling scandal that led to the suspension of 13 teammates, said yesterday that he would not return to the team.

title: Army: First in War, First in Rushing, Fourth in Defense
description: As a perfect Army season began to take shape the curiosity was focused on the offense, a unit that extended drive after drive with its complex option approach. But it has become clear now that a defensive unit with eight senior starters has been an essential part of Army's remarkable achievement -- the self-defined 1-0 record that has been repeated nine times.

title: Michael Moynihan, 68, Free-Trade Champion
description: Michael W. Moynihan, an advocate of free trade who served in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died on Tuesday at his home in Kitty Hawk, N.C. He was 68.

title: BASF 3d-Quarter Profit Down Amid Revamping
description: BASF A.G. said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 2.3 percent in the third quarter from the similar period a year earlier because of costs of its reorganization efforts. Third-quarter pretax profit fell to 1.046 billion marks ($697 million) from 1.071 billion marks a year earlier.

title: Drug Suspect Lives Good Life, Beyond Reach of U.S.
description: In this poor country, Santiago Luis Polanco-Rodriguez has all the riches a man would desire: a casino, a clothing factory, hotels, beachfront condominiums, banana fields, discotheques and a stately home shaded by mango and lemon trees.

title: Practicing What Is Preached
description: To The Home Section:

title: Nasdaq Offers Stricter Rules For Listing of Companies
description: The Nasdaq stock market, after being embarrassed by scandals that involved penny stocks, said yesterday that it was proposing stricter listing standards that could cause hundreds of companies to be dropped from its listings.

title: Mubarak Warns Israel to Soften Stance
description: Warning that patience is running short on Arab streets, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that he and other moderate Arab leaders could be thrust into ''a very difficult position'' unless Israel proves more willing to accommodate Palestinian demands.

title: U.S. Held Likely to Keep Troops in Bosnia
description: NATO's Secretary General, Javier Solana, met here today with Vice President Al Gore, a senior NATO official said, and came away with the conviction that the United States would agree to take part in a follow-on force in Bosnia after the current mandate ends on Dec. 20.

title: Corrections
description: A brief dance review on Monday about a premiere by the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company misidentified the studio in which it was presented. It was the Jeannette Stoner Studio, not the Phyllis Lamhut Studio.

title: Houses-in-a-House for Young Patients
description: A RENOVATION has changed the plain, ungarnished interior of a Ronald McDonald House in New Hyde Park, L.I., into an oasis of charm and fun.

title: People
description: Robert R. Beltran was named senior vice president and account director at Citigate Albert Frank, New York, a unit of Citigate Group Ltd., succeeding David Simpson, who left to join CMG Communications, New York, as a senior vice president and strategic planning director. Mr. Beltran had been a vice president and account director at Young & Rubicam in New York.

title: Germany Says Exports Fueled Economic Growth
description: Growth in Germany stayed on track in the third quarter, but the country's recovery was still driven by foreign orders as domestic investment lagged, the Economics Ministry said yesterday. German gross domestic product probably rose 2 percent in real terms in the third quarter from the comparable period last year after an expansion of 1.2 percent in the second quarter, the ministry said in its monthly report.

title: The Pop Life
description: Making 'Hype'

title: Officers Who Fight Toxic Waste
description: They are a little-known force among the city's many law enforcement agencies: a group of armed officers whose focus is not drug dealers or murderers but the 30,000 tons of garbage that New Yorkers produce each day.

title: And in Berlin, More Lawns to Cut
description: NOWHERE, it seems, has the wheel of fortune spun faster than in Berlin, which reeled from world capital to blitzed and divided ruin, and is now heading for world capital status again.

title: Westinghouse will spin off its remaining industrial businesses.
description: FOR the last three years, as Michael H. Jordan, chairman and chief executive of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has tried to render order out of chaos at the conglomerate, the stock market's response has been akin to the sound of one hand clapping.

title: 2 Officers Shot After White Officer Is Cleared in Black Man's Death
description: A white police officer was cleared on Wednesday in a shooting that sparked a racial disturbance last month, and just hours later demonstrators returned to the same streets, gunshots rang out and two other officers were injured.

title: Testimony of Betrayal and Kisses At Army Drill Sergeant's Hearing
description: Lonely and far from home, Joy Paulsen was a scared 21-year-old Army recruit last spring when a drill sergeant asked her up to his room for a smoke and some talk.

title: Veba Earnings Soar On Strong Oil Sales
description: Veba A.G. said yesterday that its profit jumped 25 percent in the first nine months of the year, exceeding analysts' and the utility's expectations, as oil and telecommunications sales increased. Profit rose to 1.23 billion marks ($814 million), from 980 million marks a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Benefits column in the Styles pages on Sunday about a dinner to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 26 to aid the Committee to Protect Journalists referred incorrectly to the evening's program. Although Peter Duchin and His Orchestra will play, there will be no dancing.

title: Office That's Really the Devil's Playground
description: Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? Kelly Stuart, for one.

title: Efforts to Help Refugees in Zaire Are Blocked by Shelling
description: Shells fired by Hutu militias slammed near a major hospital here this afternoon, sending patients running down the street on foot, many in bandages. The attack was evidence that the conflict that has kept aid workers from reaching 400,000 refugees trapped here has not eased.

title: MEN'S WEARHOUSE TO BUY SOME C & R CLOTHIERS ASSETS
description: Men's Wearhouse Inc., based in Houston, agreed yesterday to acquire certain assets and leases from C & R Clothiers Inc. in a deal worth as much as $13.5 million. C & R, in Culver City, Calif., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. The deal must receive the bankruptcy court's approval. Shares of Men's Wearhouse rose $1.875, to $18.875. Men's Wearhouse agreed to assume leases for as many as 19 of the C & R stores in California, sign a lease for C & R's warehouse in Culver City, Calif., and acquire its existing inventory.

title: At Princeton, the Smoke Clears for Carmody
description: ''How's life without Pete?'' one of her Ivy League colleagues asked Liz Feeley, the Princeton women's basketball coach.

title: So Many New Shows, but Not One Hit
description: Don't believe those network promos that bray about the ''new hit comedy'' you can't afford to miss. For a second straight year, television has completed its fall fusillade of new prime-time series without a single, verifiable breakout hit, and this despite freshly minted shows with some of the highest-priced stars in television: Bill Cosby, Ted Danson, Michael J. Fox.

title: Decline Seen In Death Rates From Cancer As a Whole
description: For the first time since 1900 , overall cancer death rates have shown a sustained decline, a new analysis has shown.

title: No Rise Found In Death Rates After Gulf War
description: Two large Federal studies of Persian Gulf war veterans have found that their death rates from disease and their hospitalization rates are no different from those of veterans of the same era who did not serve in the war.

title: Legal Stances Make Retrial Likely in Rape Case
description: Before the jurors in the Alex Kelly rape case were out of the parking lot after their deadlock was declared on Tuesday, attention shifted to the next trial.

title: The Talk of the Army
description: Soldiers say the Army's zero-tolerance policy on sexual harassment is clear, but some acknowledge that problems exist. Page B13.

title: Indian Officials Gather Evidence on Midair Collision
description: As scores of bereaved relatives and friends wandered through twin crash sites on the dusty Indian plain, struggling to absorb the tragedy, Indian officials today began reconstructing what caused the worst midair collision in aviation history.

title: ... as Murrell Is Approaching a Milestone
description: After more than 60 years, the 1,000-yard mark remains a yardstick for a running back in the National Football League. And after 37 seasons, the Jets are on the brink of having only their third 1,000-yard man: Adrian Murrell.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO. (CPB,N)
description: The Campbell Soup Company yesterday reported lower first-quarter earnings, reflecting a $160 million charge to cover the costs of a revamping that includes plant closings.

title: Silver Tureen Sets Record
description: A rare French 18th-century silver tureen with a royal pedigree was auctioned yesterday for $10.3 million at Sotheby's in New York. The price was the highest paid at auction for a work of the French decorative arts and three times the previous record for a silver object. The buyer's name was not disclosed.

title: More Space for Clammers
description: An additional 4,800 acres of ocean bottom along the coastline of Ocean and Cape May counties will be opened to clamming, state officials said yesterday. Some of these acres are in areas where clamming has been banned for 30 years, the state Department of Environmental Protection said. In August, 623 acres at the mouth of the Navesink River were made available for clamming. Areas are being added as new sewage treatment plants reduce ocean pollution, said Loretta O'Donnell, a spokeswoman for the department.

title: Up the Grassy Knoll and Down: The Plot Is Thick
description: At whatever age she may be, Elizabeth Ashley can still prowl a stage as sultrily as anyone. She wears a scanty black slip with unimpeachable authority in the new production of Tennessee Williams's ''Red Devil Battery Sign'' at the WPA Theater, and she knows just how to extend a shapely leg to its most cosmetic advantage.

title: Hartford Plan Aims to Help Pay for College
description: The State Treasurer proposed two programs today to encourage parents to save for their children's college education, including a tuition prepayment plan similar to those in 11 other states, including Massachusetts.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Amoco in Deal to Build Gas Plant in Egypt
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to build a liquefied natural gas plant in Egypt worth up to $4 billion that will supply gas to Turkey, one of the region's fastest-growing energy consumers. The Chicago-based Amoco will build the plant with the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation, using reserves it found in the gas-rich Nile delta. Gas will be transported by tanker across the Mediterranean Sea to Turkey. ENI S.p.A., Italy's largest energy company, may also participate in the plant, instead of building a gas pipeline it was considering. ENI's AGIP unit and Amoco are the two biggest foreign gas producers in Egypt. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about charges filed against John J. Royster in a string of violent attacks misstated the nature of one assault attributed to him. In the case of a piano teacher in Central Park, Mr. Royster was charged with attempted rape and sexual abuse, not with rape.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Alex Kelly rape trial in Stamford, Conn., included an erroneous reference in some editions to a juror, Helena Furson. Her hometown is Weston, not Wilton.

title: Grand Jury Seeks Reason Behind a Group's Arsenal
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani displayed what he called ''an enormous cache of weapons that can be used for mass destruction,'' officials said yesterday that a grand jury would investigate the secretive group that amassed the stockpile of guns and ammunition in a cluster of Brooklyn apartment buildings.

title: Isles Come Back Strong, and Then Some
description: Usually, it's the Islanders who blow third-period leads. They have done it five times this season, turning a possible 10 points in the standing into 5 points from five ties. The Islanders also were 0-7-0 when trailing after two periods.

title: Government Bond Prices Hold Steady
description: Government bond prices were little changed yesterday, despite relief that the Federal Open Market Committee left interest rates unchanged.

title: G.O.P. Quest To Narrow Gender Gap
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI recasts himself as the Education Mayor. Gov. George E. Pataki embraces the environment. And Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, former Whitewater buff, pledges to focus henceforth on ''the things people want'' (presumably after he cures breast cancer with a bond act).

title: CHRONICLE
description: Across town at Sony Style, the store in the Sony Building on Madison Avenue, partygoers got a first look at holiday windows designed by MAURICE SENDAK. They featured giant fanged woolly creatures from his classic 1963 book, ''Where the Wild Things Are.'' The event, which drew 650 people, was a benefit for the Robin Hood Foundation, a New York anti-poverty group.

title: Shopping the 'Modernism' Show: Their Favorite Things
description: TO any critic who rejects modern design with a dismissive ''it's so cold and bland,'' the right retort is: ''Which modernism? Raffishly tawdry Miami Deco? French 50's swank? The jubilant irreverence of Italian ceramics?''

title: Giuliani Aides See Windfall In Revenues
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top aides said last night that because of rising profits on Wall Street, the city would take in $450 million more in taxes this fiscal year than had been projected, allowing the Mayor to increase spending and scale back budget cuts as he begins his re-election campaign.

title: Tiny Village In Germany Subdues A Goliath
description: In the annals of German reunification, there have been few occasions when eastern Germans have triumphed over western Germans, who are seen in places like this village north of Berlin as capitalist vultures picking over the remnants of the collapsed Communist state.

title: The Dictator Speaks
description: The Nixon Center for Peace and Pragmatism (formerly Freedom) demeaned itself this week by using Lee Kuan Yew, the dictator of Singapore, as the draw to raise $400,000 for its staff's salaries.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Pruning Hydrangeas

title: Oversight Suggested for Study of Gulf War Ills
description: A special White House panel found today that while the Defense Department ''did not act in good faith'' in its investigation of whether American troops were exposed to Iraqi chemical agents, the Pentagon inquiry might become credible if subjected to oversight by a powerful outside body.

title: '97 Budget By O'Rourke Holds Line On Taxes
description: The Westchester County Executive has proposed a budget for 1997 that freezes hiring in many sectors of government, provides no raises for county workers and calls for no increase in the property tax levy.

title: Rangers Go Quiet Into a Bad Night
description: What sort of Ranger team will return to Madison Square Garden in December after the coming six-game road trip? Will it have the same players? Will it have the same coach? Will it still be in a downward spiral that continued last night at the Garden with a 2-1 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers?

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Dartmouth Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: No Charges in a Shooting
description: A New Brunswick police officer who fatally shot a woman he was trying to arrest will not face criminal charges, prosecutors said yesterday. A grand jury decided last week that Patrolman James Consalvo was justified in shooting Carolyn Adams, 39, as they struggled on a street on Sept. 10, said Robert W. Gluck, the Middlesex County Prosecutor.

title: I.B.M. In $110 Million Deal For Ailing Software Seller
description: Taking its first big step toward becoming a major seller of educational software to schools and homes, I.B.M. announced yesterday that it would buy the troubled Edmark Corporation for $15.50 a share, or about $110 million.

title: Clinton Offers U.S. Troops to Help Refugees in Zaire
description: President Clinton gave initial approval today to the deployment of several thousand United States troops as part of a Canadian-led mission to avoid a human catastrophe and bring food and water to hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees in Zaire, where aid supplies have been cut by recent fighting.

title: Whitman Cancels a Tunnel Tour Arabs Opposed
description: Acknowledging that she had stepped into a political minefield, Governor Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey canceled a planned tour today of an Israeli archeological tunnel near Muslim shrines in Jerusalem's Old City.

title: An apparel offspring of Gerber draws its parent, at least indirectly, into its fight for market share.
description: IN a new ad campaign, Gerber Childrenswear Inc. is trying to promote its parent's long association with baby care to help it fend off new rivals in the market for baby clothing.

title: Hiring a Consultant to Do Battle When a Medical Bill Seems Unfair
description: ASHER JASON had a stack of medical documents to prove that his hospital had overcharged him. His health plan and the hospital had agreed that his colonoscopy 18 months ago should have cost $339. So he wondered why he kept receiving a bill for $1,476.

title: The Muddled and Befuddled Nets Are Still Without a Victory
description: Coach John Calipari was going to sleep on it, take an afternoon nap, wake up refreshed and make a decision: Kerry Kittles or Robert Pack?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Games Children Play
description: To The Home Section:

title: Lloyd A. Free, 88, Is Dead; Revealed Political Paradox
description: Lloyd A. Free, who upstaged his career as a pioneering specialist in international public opinion with a single American study that revealed a central paradox of national political sentiment, died on Monday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 88 and is remembered chiefly as the man who first established that Americans love big government every bit as much as they profess to loathe it.

title: Brute Sound That Denies Subjectivity And Meaning
description: In ''Testaments Betrayed,'' Milan Kundera has told how, soon after the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia, he found in the music of Iannis Xenakis ''a bizarre kind of solace.'' On Tuesday, there was a rare chance to sample this electric balm in New York, when the ''Today's Composers'' series at the 92d Street Y moved downtown to the Cooper Union to present the United States premiere of Mr. Xenakis's longest concert work, the 75-minute ''Kraanerg'' for a small but mighty orchestra of 20 or so players and tape.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about new research on smoking misstated the decline in smoking rates for adults in a study comparing California and Massachusetts statistics with those from other states. The decline was 2.2 percentage points in Massachusetts (from 23.5 percent to 21.3 percent), 2.7 percentage points in California and eight-tenths of a percentage point in 41 other states, not 2.2 percent, 2.7 percent and 0.8 percent respectively.

title: What U.N. Solution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Soupy's Slow-Motion Slump
description: IN a quiet family moment at their Rye, N.Y., home the other day, Colin Campbell remembered that his young son Gregory would have a soccer game that afternoon.

title: U.S. Sues New York on a Voter Registration Law
description: The United States Justice Department charged in a suit yesterday that New York State and New York City were failing to comply with a Federal law requiring that voter registration be offered to all those applying for social services and other aid.

title: China Economy's Class Act: High Growth, Low Inflation
description: To those who wonder when China's locomotive-paced economy will slow down, the chief of its central bank replies: Not anytime soon.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: A Mariner of the Tub
description: IT'S an ancient art, but Melissa Glen of the Sag Harbor Tile Company makes mosaics look fresh again. One of her fresh design ingredients is fish, which she draws on for inspiration in her installations for kitchens and baths. She arranges exuberant schools of them in showers and baths, across walls and around kitchen cabinets.

title: The First Turnaround
description: It may be remembered as President Clinton's first post-election flip-flop, but he was right to let Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin correct his tactical error on the balanced-budget amendment. It was probably just a hangover from triangulation that caused Mr. Clinton to say Tuesday that he could live with the balanced-budget amendment if the Republicans in Congress pushed it through. The Wednesday morning headlines about Mr. Clinton's rush to surrender cleared everyone's thinking, and with White House blessings, Mr. Rubin said yesterday that the Administration will fight the Republicans' foolish passion for this paralyzing amendment. It is a fight worth making, because common sense has a chance to prevail.

title: TENNECO BUYS TRUCK PARTS BUSINESS OF COLTEC UNIT
description: Tenneco Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the truck exhaust system products business of Stemco Inc. from Coltec Industries. Terms were not disclosed. The operations, which include the production of heavy-duty mufflers, pipes and tubing, had 1995 revenues of $21 million, the Houston-based Tenneco said. Coltec Industries is a diversified manufacturing concern. Tenneco, which has annual sales of nearly $3 billion, makes auto parts and packaging products. It is selling its energy division to the El Paso Energy Corporation.

title: East of SoHo, A Street of Jewel Boxes
description: THERE is at least one street in Manhattan where boutiques really are boutiques. Elizabeth Street, especially the block between Prince and Houston Streets, is a trove of parlor-size wonderlands, overseen by owners with taste and vision. Not to mention a healthy disregard for what they consider the soulless, nerve-racking shopping experiences uptown.

title: Fehr Says Selig Torpedoed the Deal
description: The telephone lines between New York and Milwaukee did not overheat yesterday, but heat permeated a memo the players received this week from their labor leader.

title: INSIDE
description: India Investigates Air Crash

title: Expected Return of Childs Is Just in Time for Knicks
description: After watching Chris Childs practice today, the Knicks expect to activate the point guard soon, perhaps as early as Thursday night for the team's game against Toronto at Madison Square Garden.

title: Hispanic Vote Shows Many Twists and Turns
description: To the Editor:

title: CHATEAU PROPERTIES REJECTS RIVAL'S SWEETENED OFFER
description: Chateau Properties Inc. said yesterday that its board had rejected as inadequate a sweetened bid of $387 million, or $26 a share, from Manufactured Home Communities Inc. Last week, the Chicago-based Manufactured Home, headed by the investor Sam Zell, ended its hostile tender offer for its rival Chateau, a real estate investment trust that owns manufactured home communities, and said it would instead try to court Chateau. Mr. Zell is trying to break up the agreement by Chateau, based in Clinton Township, Mich., to acquire ROC Communities in a stock swap. The Chateau-ROC combination would create the biggest company that rents land to owners of manufactured homes. Shares of Chateau slipped 25 cents, to $24.375.

title: Looking Outward
description: To the Editor:

title: Investments in Stock Mutual Funds Declined 25% in October
description: Cash flows to equity mutual funds fell 25 percent in October, to $13 billion, a trade group said, as uncertainty over the strength of the economy and over the outcome of the fall elections tempered investors' long-running love affair with stocks.

title: Residency Rule Is Debated
description: City employees who live outside Newark might not have to move back into town after all. Then again, they might. The City Council voted yesterday to amend the city's long-standing but rarely enforced residency requirement so that it applies only to employees who already live in Newark and to new workers hired from now on. The vote preserves the jobs of 57 employees who live out of town.

title: Official Wins Ethics Appeal
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that a Board of Public Utilities commissioner who was found to have violated ethics rules should keep his job. The court reversed a July 25 decision by the Executive Commission on Ethical Standards that the commissioner, Edward Salmon, should be dismissed and barred from public service for five years, The Associated Press reported. The ethics commission found that Mr. Salmon had accepted free meals and other favors from utility company representatives. The appeals court agreed that Mr. Salmon had exercised poor judgment but ruled that his punishment should consist of a 50-day suspension and a $2,500 fine.

title: Special Diet Is as Effective as Drugs for Blood Pressure, Study Finds
description: A diet low in fat and rich in fruits and vegetables has been found for the first time to lower blood pressure quickly and as effectively as drugs, a new multicenter study has shown.

title: Bridge
description: In the field of bridge parody, a father-and-son combination from England, Robert and Philip King, have no peer. In a new book, their third, ''Farewell, My Dummy,'' authors who are victimized are Jeffrey Archer, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Jane Austen and Raymond Chandler.

title: Netanyahu Cancels Visit to U.S. to Take Charge of Hebron Talks
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu canceled a trip to the United States today to take personal charge of the elusive search for an agreement on the withdrawal of Israeli troops from the West Bank city of Hebron.

title: High-Tech Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Simplifies Student Loan Program
description: Persuading bankers to treat its students as preferred customers, Columbia University is offering a new kind of student loan program with lower rates, more flexibility in repayments and one-stop shopping for loans.

title: Election Night On Line
description: To the Editor:

title: FISCAL AMENDMENT WON'T BE BACKED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: A day after President Clinton appeared to open the door to a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, his Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, slammed it shut again today, declaring that the Administration would ''actively oppose'' the adoption of any such amendment.

title: Calendar: Antiques Sale, Art Talks
description: Antiques on the Piers

title: Function That Follows the Fantastical
description: IN the 1980's, Borek Sipek, an architect and designer from Prague, became famous for his zany gem-colored glass works -- vases and chandeliers in particular. Once seen, they are not easily forgotten: their sinuously organic shapes make them look as if they had floated up from 20,000 leagues under the sea.

title: At Maryland Post, Talk Is of Shame
description: In the mess halls, in the barracks, in the classrooms of this vast Army training base, the talk is of shame and dishonor, of a stain upon the Army.

title: Kendall Square Case Is Settled
description: The former top sales executive at the Kendall Square Research Corporation has settled Federal regulatory charges by surrendering $321,526 and agreeing to a 10-year suspension from holding senior positions in a public company, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 2 Monets Lead the Bidding at Christie's Auction
description: The wheel of fortune spun round and round last night, often stopping at high numbers as collectors from all over the world relentlessly bid for the Impressionist and modern artworks being auctioned at Christie's in Manhattan. From the moment Christopher Burge, Christie's chairman in America and the evening's auctioneer, started the sale, collectors brazenly went after what they wanted.

title: A Bosnian Town Held Hostage by Fear
description: The sullen men, some of them armed with assault rifles, lined the streets and filled this town's main square today, all of them intent on a single goal.

title: Stocks Set Another Record on Very Strong Earnings Reports
description: Stocks rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve left benchmark lending rates unchanged and investors looked to corporate earnings for their cues.

title: Science Editor Appointed
description: The appointment of Cornelia Dean as science editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, the paper's executive editor. Ms. Dean, now a deputy Washington editor, will assume the new post in January, succeeding Nicholas Wade, who will move to the writing staff.

title: Dimensions of an Ordered Universe
description: In ''Yuragi: In a Space of Perpetual Motion,'' Ushio Amagatsu, the founder and director of the Japanese Butoh dance group Sankai Juku, presents an ordered universe.

title: Shoe Policy May Change In Airlines
description: Spiked heels are out. So wearing shoes while escaping from an airplane in an emergency may now be in.

title: Miscellany
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said that the number of magazine advertising pages in October fell three-tenths of 1 percent from October 1995, to 20,702. For the first 10 months of 1996, total ad pages fell 1 percent, to 170,958, from the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Inquiry in Brooklyn Seeks Origin of Deadly Garbage
description: Investigators canvassed businesses yesterday in the Brooklyn neighborhood where a sanitation worker died after inhaling fumes from a corrosive acid that had been improperly discarded, seeking to find a business that might have used the dangerous acid.

title: Guessing Game in the Capital: Future of Attorney General
description: Three years after Attorney General Janet Reno emerged as a surprise star of the Clinton Cabinet, she has skidded to a stop at an unexpected career crossroads. She has said she wants to stay on at the Justice Department, but President Clinton has pointedly passed up opportunities to say he would keep her.

title: France Nears the End Of Elf Aquitaine Sale
description: The French Government sold a 9.1 percent stake in Elf Aquitaine yesterday for about 10 billion francs ($2 billion), nearly ending its interest in the oil company. The Government is left with about three-quarters of a percent in the company, which was privatized in 1994.

title: For G.O.P., Northeast Is Becoming Foreign Turf
description: Much as the South has been for nearly a generation, the Northeast has emerged this year as a politically distinct, and somewhat ideologically isolated, region when it comes to deciding how the country should be governed and who should govern it.

title: Jurors Acquit White Officer In the Death Of Black Driver
description: An all-white jury today acquitted a white police officer of involuntary manslaughter in the death of a black motorist, a case that has led to racial tensions here.

title: Cold Sends Heating Oil Up; Europe Lures Some Supplies
description: Heating oil prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as cold weather in the United States and the lure of high prices in Europe threatened to erode lean refinery inventories.

title: New Weapons, New Rivals in Wireless Phone Competition
description: The wireless telephone war has begun. And if the industry scouting reports are right, it promises to be as clamorous as the wired war among long-distance carriers like AT&T, MCI and Sprint.

title: No to Telephone Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Picks Top Inauguration Planners
description: With the election over, the White House got down to organizing the celebration today by naming the leaders of the team that will plan President Clinton's second inauguration and promising to limit individual and corporate contributions for the event to $100 and require broad disclosure of loans and gifts.

title: A big tax cut to lift the economy. Not here, in Ukraine.
description: BOB DOLE'S plan to speed growth by slashing taxes never played well with the American economics establishment -- or, for that matter, with the deficit-wary electorate. But supply-siders are alive and well in the least likely of places: Ukraine.

title: Still Exorcising Demons From a Long-Ago War
description: There is something fitting about seeing James Carroll in Rome. Neither he nor this city has ever had a great facility for putting the past to rest.

title: Grambling Players Suspended
description: Four Grambling football players were suspended from the team yesterday, pending an investigation into an accusation that they and a fifth student raped a 14-year-old girl.

title: Becker and Seles to Play
description: The defending champions, BORIS BECKER and MONICA SELES, have confirmed that they will play in the Australian Open, the tournament's director, PAUL McNAMEE said today.

title: Justices Weigh Suits Over Going Too Far to Protect Environment
description: An unusual environmental case that was argued before the Supreme Court today found the Clinton Administration struggling to defend its view that people can sue the Government for doing too little to protect endangered species, but not for doing too much.

title: From Drought to Dissent in the Western Plains
description: BAD LAND

title: Jail Packed, Hudson Asks Local Police To Cut Arrests
description: Packed with 750 more prisoners than it was built to hold, the Hudson County jail has all but shut its doors to new inmates, forcing local police departments to cut back on arrests.

title: After Days of Counting, Dornan Race Is Too Close to Call
description: After a drawn-out, eight-day ballot count, there was still no resolution today of the tight Congressional race between Representative Robert K. Dornan, a nine-term Republican from Orange County and perhaps the most bombastic conservative on Capitol Hill, and his liberal Democratic challenger, Loretta Sanchez.

title: In Philippine Ballroom Dance Boom, Women Lead
description: What was former Senator Rene Saguisag doing on the dance floor at the Inter-Continental Hotel, twirling a woman who is not his wife through the rapid paces of a tango?

title: Isles Interested In Smolinski
description: Pittsburgh is reportedly preparing to trade center Bryan Smolinski, and the Islanders are among those interested in acquiring him. In fact, they could be front-runners for the restricted free agent.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about Gizella Weisshaus, a Holocaust survivor who is suing Swiss banks to recover her family's money deposited during the war, misstated the location of Mrs. Weiss haus in an old family photograph. She was the eldest daughter, shown between her parents in the back row of the photo, not the younger girl who was second from the left in the front row.

title: Glassware Bargains Ready for Holiday Duty
description: IT'S time to refill the glassware cabinet for the impending feasts. (Everyone's stash diminishes from one year to the next, making glassware a welcome gift as well.)

title: John R. Cortelyou, 82, Former President of DePaul
description: The Rev. John R. Cortelyou, who wrapped up a 60-year academic association with DePaul University as its eighth president, serving in a period of growth and turbulence, died on Saturday at St. Joseph Hospital in Chicago. He was 82 and a resident of the Chicago campus.

title: 2 Sentenced For Dumping Toxic Sludge
description: A former New York City port official and her sister, whose family ran a network of troubled marine-transport companies, were sentenced to jail terms yesterday for dumping hundreds of barge-loads of hazardous sewage sludge into New York Harbor.

title: Guilty Plea in Threats
description: A 54-year-old Voorhees woman pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to felony charges that she mailed two Federal judges a handwritten threat in which she pointed out how easy it is to buy a gun, prosecutors said.

title: Britain Takes On European Union Over Hours in a Workweek
description: Prime Minister John Major has plunged Britain into another clash with its 14 European Union partners by rejecting a court ruling that mandates a maximum 48-hour workweek unless employers and unions agree otherwise.

title: No Headline
description: ''My wife loves me a million more times when I take her out dancing. But we rarely dance with each other; we both have excellent dance instructors. My wife is born to dance. Wow!'' RENE SAGUISAG, a Filipino, on the ballroom dancing fad that is sweeping Asia. $(A1:3$)

title: Baseball's Discontents
description: The baseball owners have now rejected a labor settlement agreed to by their own negotiator and the players' union. The union has said it has no desire to amend the agreement. The deadline for completing the deal is midnight tonight. Does it matter if no deal is struck?

title: Intervention Has a Price
description: From the civil wars in Somalia and Bosnia to the current crisis in Zaire, it has been the international aid agencies who have most strongly and consistently called for military intervention in humanitarian disasters. Only through a combination of military muscle and logistical support, they insist, can we hope to rescue starving people like the more than one million Rwandan Hutu refugees now cut off from aid in eastern Zaire.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP., Lafayette, Ind., sold its EM Corp. division to Morgan Crucible Co., of Britain for $26.8 million.

title: Mexico Is Evolving Into a Plural Political System
description: To the Editor:

title: Bishops Approve Standards For Catholic Universities
description: For years, the nation's 235 Roman Catholic colleges and universities, including institutions like Notre Dame, Georgetown, Fordham and Holy Cross, have been striving for academic distinction while resisting the forces that led universities like Harvard, Yale and Princeton from their denominational roots to total secularization.

title: A Stimulant, Not a Sedative
description: To The Home Section:

title: Executive Changes
description: SALOMON BROTHERS, New York, named David Jarvis chief of its global investment banking business for financial services companies and banks. Mr. Jarvis, who is currently co-head of European investment banking in Salomon's London office, will move to the United States at the start of 1997. Eric C. Fast, the co-head of Salomon's investment banking division, will become the operating chief of the firm's European banking business until a replacement for Mr. Jarvis can be found.

title: Mexico's Telephone Revolution
description: Telephone deregulation has come to Mexico, bringing with it fierce competition unlike anything Mexicans have seen.

title: Pirates Trade 3 Vets
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates continue to trade away veterans for prospects. They sent second baseman CARLOS GARCIA, outfielder ORLANDO MERCED and pitcher DAN PLESAC to Toronto yesterday for six players.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Show So Nice . . .

title: Caretaker Premier Leads Pakistan Into 90 Days of No Frills
description: When Pakistan's caretaker Prime Minister made his first trip outside the capital last week after Benazir Bhutto was dismissed, he turned his journey into a lesson in civics.

title: Dishonor And Betrayal
description: Guys in the military are having a tough time realizing that women in the military are not the spoils of the gender war.

title: Dredging At Crash Site Yields Debris And a Victim
description: Medical investigators have identified another victim of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, lowering the number of missing victims to 15 of the 230 people who perished.

title: U.S. Sets Conditions for Using Troops to Aid Refugees in Zaire
description: Plans for an international military mission to support relief efforts for a million refugees in eastern Zaire bogged down today as Canadian and American officials haggled over details.

title: 2 Valujet Founders Sell 1 Million Shares Each
description: Two of the four founders of Valujet Inc. sold one million shares in the airline apiece yesterday, the first time either had cashed in his original investment in the carrier, which saw spectacular success before a crash in the Florida Everglades on May 11 killed 110 people, crippling its business.

title: Gill Carries A Burden For 0-4 Nets
description: Kendall Gill is the kickstand to this team, a steel support holding up the Nets' offense, a player they can lean on.

title: As Settlements Grow, Palestinians Talk of Coming Explosion
description: Rumbling across a rocky hillside near this Palestinian village today, Israeli bulldozers gnawed at the hard, scrub-covered earth as they broke ground for expansion of the Orthodox Jewish settlement of Qiryat Sefer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL JACKSON is a bridegroom again, The Associated Press reported. His publicity agent in Los Angeles, Christine Holevas, confirmed yesterday that the singer had married DEBBIE ROWE yesterday in Australia following a concert there. Mr. Jackson has said that Ms. Rowe is six months pregnant with their child.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 12
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Power Outage Hits Devils, And Streak Ends Quietly
description: In a game that leaned more toward pacifism than pugilism, the Vancouver Canucks handed the Devils their first shutout of the season tonight in a 3-0 victory at Continental Arena that ended New Jersey's winning streak at five games.

title: Streisand on Topic A, With 2 Pet Men in Orbit
description: In ''The Mirror Has Two Faces,'' Barbra Streisand plays a shy, unglamorous college professor whose finer qualities go unappreciated by the people in her life. As an actress she's on familiar and solid ground with such a role, but Ms. Streisand has produced and directed this romantic comedy, too. Elaborately lighted, carefully coiffed and always, always the center of attention, she can play plain Jane with the broadest of winks, like Grandma being impersonated by the Big Bad Wolf.

title: Scientists Identify Site of Gene Tied to Some Cases of Parkinson's
description: Scientists have found a general site for a gene believed responsible for some cases of Parkinson's disease, which they say is the first time anyone has found a genetic cause for a form of the debilitating nerve condition.

title: A Radical Change
description: Anyone who thought the 1996 election was a victory for centrist policies should think again. It is quickly threatening to bring on the most radical change in the structure of the United States Government since 1789: the so-called balanced budget amendment to the Constitution.

title: October Retail Sales Weak; Price Index Up 0.3%
description: Consumers spent a bit more money last month but only because of inflation.

title: Mayor Details Plan for Fiscal Windfall
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani formally presented a plan yesterday for using an unexpected $450 million windfall in tax revenues, drawing praise from some independent budget analysts and attacks from his Democratic rivals, who asserted that new spending would not make up for his earlier cuts.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Mina Tannenbaum

title: Memorial for Paul Draper
description: A memorial service is to be held for Paul Draper, the tap dancer, on Saturday at 1:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, in Manhattan. He died in September. Participants will include Larry Adler, the harmonica player, who appeared with Mr. Draper in the 1940's.

title: G.O.P. Bill On Schools In New Jersey Is Presented
description: In their first effort to revise Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's school financing plan, Republicans proposed legislation today that would spare wealthy suburban school districts from deep budget cuts and cap spending for all of the state's school districts.

title: MetroStars Keep Donadoni
description: The MetroStars and Roberto Donadoni have reached an agreement in principle for a new two-year contract though Donadoni had been rumored to be moving to Italy or signing with Real Madrid.

title: An Early Bird Mars Theory On Dinosaurs
description: In an analysis of new fossil discoveries in northeastern China, American and Chinese researchers have found evidence that they say casts serious doubt on the widely held theory that birds are direct descendants of dinosaurs.

title: Cards' Fassel May Lead The Post-Reeves Giants
description: There are times when an assistant coach becomes a hot name in the National Football League. Norv Turner was one several years ago. Dave Wannstedt was another. Now, Jim Fassel, the offensive coordinator of the Arizona Cardinals, is hot, and he is the man the Giants want to hire to replace Dan Reeves as head coach at the end of the season.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The winners of the 1996 Council of Fashion Designers of America Awards, announced yesterday at the Mayfair Hotel in Manhattan, included some familiar faces and a few new ones.

title: Records Signal Lawyer's Role In Texaco Suit
description: A Federal grand jury investigating the scandal at Texaco Inc. has obtained records indicating that a company lawyer gave instructions on how to withhold damaging documents from plaintiffs suing the company for racial discrimination, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Prospects of Bonding With a You, a Me and a Them
description: Sometimes Bruce Nauman pulls out all the stops, sometimes he exhibits restraint. His current double exhibition in SoHo, at the Leo Castelli Gallery and Sperone Westwater, is in the second category. A seemingly quiet affair several degrees removed from the haranguing, in-your-face expressionism of video installations like ''Clown Torture'' and ''Rats and Bats (Learned Helplessness in Rats, II),'' the two shows remind us of the range of Mr. Nauman's Jekyll-Hyde sensibility. For a change, the four pieces on view, two at each gallery, give you time and space to think for yourself.

title: In Shift, Prospects for Survival Will Decide Liver Transplants
description: An organization that controls the allocation of organs for transplant voted yesterday to change substantially the rules for determining which dying patients get livers, giving those with the best prospects of survival top priority. In doing so, the group made a rationing decision that has been shunned by most of American medicine.

title: Muslim Rioters in Bosnia Attack a U.S. Army Column
description: American soldiers were attacked today by rioting civilians, presumably Muslims, after the soldiers raided a Bosnian Army camp and confiscated several tons of weapons and ammunition.

title: The Russians Are Coming, to Big Board Trading
description: A piece of the new Russia goes on sale today on the New York Stock Exchange. Russia's leading cellular telephone company, Vimpel-Communications A.O., is set for a roughly $90 million initial public offering as the first Russian company to be listed on the Big Board. When trading begins, investors will be able to buy part of a young company run by former Soviet military scientists who, according to the prospectus, have been making money hand over cellular handset.

title: A Grieving Chicago Manages a Wistful Smile
description: Having lived the last days of his life with a buoyant openness about his lethal cancer, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin left this city a final gift when he died early this morning: the chance to mourn and remember him without the added burden of shock.

title: Paying Back Student Loans
description: The Assembly unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would allow state boards and agencies to suspend the professional or occupational license of anyone who defaults or fails to make payments on a student loan guaranteed by the state or Federal governments. The bill, which goes to the Senate, was originally aimed at the 125 doctors in the state who owe $6.6 million in loans, said Ricky Trappe, an aide to Assemblyman Walter J. Kavanaugh, Republican of Somerville. But the Assembly expanded it last month to include all licensed professionals.

title: For Children
description: 'Contemporary Art in Asia'

title: 2 Charged in Rap Killing
description: Two Irvington teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged in the killing of a childhood friend of Tupac Shakur who had witnessed the fatal shooting of the rap artist in Las Vegas on Sept. 7. The body of Yafeu Fula, a member of Mr. Shakur's backup band, was found Sunday morning in an apartment building in Orange. He had been shot once in the head.

title: Bond Prices Move Higher On New Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities turned higher yesterday after three Government reports indicated continued subdued economic growth and little inflation. The reports appeared to validate the Federal Reserve's decision on Wednesday to leave interest rates unchanged.

title: Yankees Go Shopping on a Budget
description: The awarding of baseball's Cy Young and most valuable player prizes is over. Now the hunt for bigger trophies, as in free agents, begins.

title: Slugger Slips By Kid: Gonzalez Wins M.V.P.
description: Juan Gonzalez is known as Igor because of the kind of strength he demonstrated in hitting five home runs in four playoff games against the Yankees. Nevertheless, the Texas Rangers' outfielder was never sure he could hold off enough of the other strong men in the American League to win the most valuable player award.

title: Leonard Back at 41
description: SUGAR RAY LEONARD has spent 8 of the last 12 years away from boxing, but he will make another return, at nearly 41, for a pay-per-view middleweight fight in February against HECTOR (MACHO) CAMACHO at the Atlantic City Convention Center.

title: Indian and Kazak Officials Trade Accusations in Air Collision
description: Indian aviation officials have become embroiled in a finger-pointing battle with officials of the Kazak airline that was one of the two carriers involved in the collision on Tuesday that killed 349 people.

title: Tenants Wary as Members Of Raided Group Go Home
description: Tensions flared yesterday between a secretive underground organization in Brooklyn and the tenants who live alongside them as members of the group began returning home after being arrested during a raid in which a stockpile of illegal weapons was found.

title: Celebrating Many Lucas Samarases
description: No one can accuse Lucas Samaras of a foolish consistency. There may be a few things he hasn't tried in his long trajectory as an artist, but give him time. At 60, he's still on an upward curve. And to celebrate his midcareer birthday this fall, Pace Wildenstein, his dealer since 1965, has gone all out, devoting its expansive square footage uptown and down to a Samaras mini-retrospective covering more than 30 years. Flashily theatrical, yet cunningly thought out and wrought, his wildly varied works make a knockout display.

title: INSIDE
description: Hospital Coverage Extended

title: 18 Indicted on Murder and Drug Charges
description: Eighteen people identified as members of a violent, multimillion-dollar crack gang, including a former New York City housing police officer, were indicted yesterday on racketeering charges that involved 11 murders and drug dealing that terrorized Harlem and Bronx neighborhoods for the last decade.

title: Messinger Ads Criticize Store Plan and Mayor
description: As the City Council prepares to hold hearings next week on a zoning plan for suburban-style superstores, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, plans to run a series of radio commercials this weekend that harshly criticizes the effort and its most prominent advocate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Golden Books Selling Unit
description: Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc. has agreed to sell its Penn Corporation unit to the closely held Peacock Papers Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed. Penn's primary asset is Beach Products, which makes party goods. Golden Books, based in New York, is a publisher of children's books.

title: Making Metaphors of Art and Bodies
description: ''YOUR inheritance as an artist is from the whole world,'' says Kiki Smith, whose own sculptures and drawings have roots all over the place. ''Of course, you have to be responsible interpreting other cultures, but you're allowed to be wrong. Things come from the cross-fertilization.''

title: Jail Lifts No-Vacancy Sign
description: Overcrowding at the Hudson County Correctional Center has eased somewhat, allowing the jail to resume routine admissions, officials said yesterday. ''The no-vacancy sign has been lifted,'' said Edward DeFazio, the first assistant county prosecutor. The inmate population yesterday was 2,169, down from 2,190 on Wednesday, when some prisoners were housed in holding cells without toilets and beds, officials said.

title: A Battleground of Sexual Conflict
description: Even though Army recruits are told that soldiers and sex do not mix, well before they are told how to load a rifle, daily life in uniform is full of conflict between the sexes.

title: Art in Review
description: Joseph Marioni

title: Despite Setbacks, Labor Chief Is Upbeat Over Election Role
description: John J. Sweeney is sounding unmistakably upbeat nowadays even though Republicans assert that big labor was the big loser in last week's elections.

title: Texas Sues To Halt Move By Blue Cross
description: Attorney General Dan Morales of Texas filed suit yesterday seeking to block the merger of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois. The suit said Texas Blue Cross, a nonprofit corporation, was a charitable asset that could not be removed from the state.

title: Diner's Journal
description: One of the most irritating ways to spend an evening is rushing through dinner so you can make it to a movie and then getting caught in traffic. The owners of the Screening Room have a better idea: dinner right in the movie theater.

title: A Broken Clown With a Baleful Heart
description: As with a veteran London cabbie or an experienced sailor, there are actors you would trust to take you almost anywhere. Brian Murray is one of them. Whether he is playing a sainted gay clergyman (''Racing Demon'') or a boorish businessman (''Entertaining Mr. Sloane'') or a dizzying array of parts (''Travels With My Aunt''), Mr. Murray is a remarkable stage resource. His name on a cast list is one of the closest things in the theater world to a quality guarantee.

title: New York State Success Rate for Cardiac Bypass Surgery Leads Nation, Survey Shows
description: The chance of dying from cardiac bypass surgery in New York State is lower than that reported in any other state and is the lowest since the state began surveying the results of the operation five years ago, state health officials reported yesterday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Ruling Class

title: Jogger Is Raped and Sodomized During Daylight Run in Prospect Park
description: A 30-year old jogger was raped and sodomized yesterday morning in Prospect Park, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE FOOTBALL

title: Stocks Set Records, With Dow Over 6,300
description: Stocks rose to records yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average past 6,300, as inflation and retail sales reports bolstered investors' perception of a low-inflation economy. Computer shares led the advance.

title: 1996 Was Year of Discontented Voter, Poll Shows
description: Compared with 1992, the 1996 elections left voters disappointed with the candidates, the press, the pollsters, the talk show hosts and even themselves.

title: Household Spending Declines in Japan, Again
description: Japanese household spending fell 4.4 percent in September. The worst decline since last year's Kobe earthquake, it was a sign that the economy may be headed back into a recession, economists said. The greater-than-expected drop, the fourth in the last six months, was the result of poor weather and a bacteria scare that kept shoppers from stores, a Management and Coordination Agency official said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: ''He was very informal, very precious to me. I said: 'My friends call me Eppie, Your Eminence. You call me Eppie.' He said: 'Don't call me Your Eminence. Call me Joe.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Play Misty for Me'': that's what JONATHAN SCHWARTZ, the deejay, played for CLINT EASTWOOD, who directed and starred in the 1971 movie of that name.

title: College Idealism Was Fertile Soil for Fringe Group
description: Jennifer Kling left Williams College here to join the National Labor Federation in Brooklyn with dreams of organizing the poor to create a more just world.

title: New Starter Says Jets Need New Attitude
description: Soon after he became a Jet, Carl Greenwood sensed that there was trouble on this franchise. Screwball things seemed to happen; there was no vocal leadership, no accountability.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: STAR GAS PARTNERS L.P., Stamford, Conn., a propane distributor with a market capitalization of about $117 million, said it was pursuing talks with several companies that are interested in buying it.

title: Art in Review
description: Cindy Sherman

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Boycotts Rarely Have Impact on Bottom Line
description: In the early 1970's, a group of black, left-leaning students called for a boycott of Gulf Oil to protest the company's operations in Angola, which had been fighting to win its independence from Portugal. Protests were held on college campuses, investors were urged to sell Gulf stock, posters of Portuguese soldiers holding up the severed head of a black African under the words, ''Boycott Gulf'' adorned the walls of many black students' rooms.

title: In Pittsburgh, White Officer's Acquittal Brings Protest March
