description: Scores of Pittsburghers marched in front of the Allegheny County Courthouse today, protesting the acquittal there on Wednesday of a white police officer charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a black motorist.

title: Indigenous People Are Creating A Far-Reaching Capital Base
description: One day before he was scheduled to fly 3,000 miles from Washington to close a deal with a native Alaskan company called the Arctic Slope Regional Corporation, Andrew Kho, a banker, was told to hold off his trip. Jacob Adams, Arctic Slope's boss, was out whaling in the icy seas off Alaska's northern coast.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lower-priced co-ops sell again in once-troubled buildings in boroughs outside Manhattan.
description: BELIEVING that the market for affordably priced cooperatives in New York City boroughs outside of Manhattan is beginning to improve, some developers who have taken over troubled buildings are selling apartments again.

title: Lease Fraud Lawsuit Filed
description: Last year, Ramsey Nissan ran newspaper advertisements offering to lease Pathfinders at $199 to $222 a month, officials say. But during a one-month period in 1995, all of the Pathfinders leased by the dealership cost more than the advertised price. Yesterday, the state filed a lawsuit accusing Ramsey of defrauding consumers in 99 out of 106 leasing transactions conducted between Sept. 10 and Oct. 10, 1995. Gerry Fede, Ramsey's chief financial officer, said the dealership did nothing wrong. ''It's our policy to make our customers happy,'' he said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Alomar Umpire Denies Cursing
description: The umpire John Hirschbeck denied tonight that he provoked Robert Alomar into spitting at him by cursing at him.

title: Board Rates Washington's School System 'Deplorable'
description: For many residents of the District of Columbia, nothing has better symbolized the sorry condition of the city than the public school system. Criticized for years by parents and city leaders as incapable of providing a proper education, it has long been offered as prime evidence that the nation's capital was falling apart.

title: Home Video
description: Judging Films by Covers

title: HYATT INVESTING IN INTERACTIVE FLIGHT TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Hyatt Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to invest up to $160 million in Interactive Flight Technologies Inc., a developer of in-flight video entertainment based in Phoenix. Hyatt would receive warrants giving it the right to buy up to 10 percent of Interactive Flight stock at $9.875 a share. It would also acquire up to $1 million of Interactive Flight stock in the open market. Interactive Flight's stock was up 12.5 cents at $11.50 in Nasdaq trading.

title: MICROSOFT AND TCI END A PARTNERSHIP
description: The Microsoft Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. have severed the partnership agreement that gave TCI, one of the nation's largest cable-television operators, a 20 percent stake in Microsoft's on-line service. Microsoft in October returned the $125 million investment that a TCI unit made in the Microsoft Network, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In the filing, Microsoft attributed the break in the partnership to the evolving nature of the on-line industry.

title: Art in Review
description: Andrea Zittel

title: Italian Hero of Bribe Inquiry Quits as He Becomes Target
description: A former magistrate who became a national hero for his role in uncovering a corruption scandal resigned from Prime Minister Romano Prodi's Cabinet tonight after being informed that he himself is once again the target of an investigation.

title: Adrift in Fiery Layers of Memory
description: CHRISTMAS in Cairo, 1938: an exquisite sequence in ''The English Patient,'' one of so many in this fiercely romantic, mesmerizing tour de force. In the courtyard of the British Embassy, soldiers sit at tables baking in the sun while a bagpipe plays ''Silent Night.'' The heat is overwhelming. And the effect is one of dizzying incongruity, as if all the conventions of ordinary life had been suspended. The world has palpably been turned upside down.

title: Man Guilty Of Murder In Setting Student Afire
description: A Brooklyn man was found guilty yesterday of kidnapping and murder for setting afire a 20-year-old college student he once professed to love like a sister.

title: Art in Review
description: Matthew Ritchie

title: In Defense (and Praise) of Fatness
description: EAT FAT

title: Spain Votes to Join NATO Command
description: The Spanish Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to permit Spain's full participation in NATO's military structure, after 14 years in which Madrid has been an alliance member but never had its own officers as NATO commanders.

title: VERMONT FINANCIAL SERVICES TO BUY EASTERN BANCORP
description: The Vermont Financial Services Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Eastern Bancorp for cash and stock estimated at about $24.23, or $89.1 million. Vermont Financial, which is based in Brattleboro, Vt., is the parent of Vermont National Bank and United Bank, a Massachusetts savings bank. Eastern Bancorp is based in Dover, N.H. Under terms of the agreement, Eastern Bancorp's shareholders would receive stock or cash equal to $7.25 plus 0.49 times the average closing price of Vermont Financial stock for 20 trading days before the closing. Eastern Bancorp's stock gained 50 cents yesterday, to $22.625, in Nasdaq trading while Vermont Financial dropped 93.75 cents, to $35.5625.

title: Bosnia Foes Told to Make Peace in 2 Years or Lose Economic Aid
description: The United States and the European countries overseeing the still-fragile peace in Bosnia gave formal notice today to leaders of all three of the war-ravaged country's ethnic groups that economic aid would end two years from now at the latest if peace has not taken hold completely by then.

title: On Ledger Paper, the Fall of the American Indian
description: Near the beginning of the exhibition titled ''Plains Indian Drawings, 1865-1935: Pages From a Visual History'' at the Drawing Center is a remarkable picture.

title: CIC Privatization Is Called Off
description: France called off the $1.9 billion privatization of the regional banking company CIC today and accused the management of the bank and its state-owned parent of failing to help with the sale. The Finance Minister, Jean Arthuis, announced the cancellation of a selloff tender that began in August but said that he was determined that the bank would be sold eventually.

title: New York City's Tattered Textbooks
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's surprise announcement that he had found $70 million for public school textbooks had all the earmarks of a conciliatory political gesture from a man who has been squeezing New York City's education budget for three years and has often quarreled with his school chancellors. But the fact that the Mayor is gearing up for his re-election campaign takes nothing away from his decision to allocate part of the city's increased tax revenues to textbooks. The textbook problem in New York City has been a scandal for more than a decade. Yet the ultimate solution lies not in one-shot fixes but in rationalizing the funding formula by which textbook aid flows from Albany.

title: Queens Man Convicted In Burning of Student
description: A Brooklyn man was found guilty yesterday of kidnapping and murder for setting afire a 20-year-old college student he once professed to love like a sister.

title: With Some Price Cuts, BT's Earnings Ease
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said today that its earnings fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in the fiscal second quarter as it reduced prices to meet regulatory requirements and faced a higher bill for staff cuts.

title: So, Who'll Shoot J. R. This Time Around?
description: ''Dallas'' is back, as shamelessly dopey as ever. The occasion is a two-hour movie on CBS tonight called ''Dallas: J. R. Returns.'' More to the marketing point, also returning are the original cast members Larry Hagman, Patrick Duffy, Linda Gray and Ken Kercheval. And just to sweeten the pot, Mr. Hagman and Mr. Duffy get co-executive producer credits. There's money to be made in these proliferating television ''reunions.'' (Coming up soon: a revisit to ''Knots Landing,'' a ''Dallas'' spinoff).

title: Ex-Soviet Spy Free as C.I.A. Chief Calls Arrest by F.B.I. a Mistake
description: The Director of Central Intelligence helped free a retired Russian spy today, convincing the Justice Department that his arrest was a mistake that could provoke Moscow to seize retired C.I.A. officers doing business in Russia.

title: Pentagon Broke News on Gulf War Exposure
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * Mediacom Worldwide, New York, the media division of Grey Advertising, has opened additional offices in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Bombay and Delhi, India; Melbourne and Sidney, Australia, and Buenos Aires. Mediacom also acquired the media buying agency Scandinavisk Media Consult in Oslo and merged it with its existing Mediacom office in Oslo.

title: On USAir's New Name
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lively Legacy, A Come-Hither Air
description: WHO would have thought there could be such bliss in being played for a patsy?

title: Pentagon Broke News on Gulf War Exposure
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside Art
description: Raising a Museum's Profile

title: Area Code Consternation
description: The recent decision by the state Board of Public Utilities to add two area codes in northern and central New Jersey has caused consternation. Yesterday, the State Assembly passed a resolution asking the Federal Communications Commission to allow the new area codes to be assigned to new and existing cellular telephones, beepers, computer data lines and fax machines, which would spare residents and businesses from having to relinquish familiar telephone numbers. The sponsor of the resolution, Paul DiGaetano, Republican of Passaic and the Assembly's majority leader, said he did not know if the F.C.C. could be pressured to move quickly enough to affect New Jersey, where the new area codes will be created next year.

title: Lowe Direct Gets An Ameritech Account
description: The Ameritech Corporation in Chicago said yesterday that it had named Lowe Direct in New York to handle direct marketing for its Security Link subsidiary, which sells and installs residential and commercial security systems. The account, with billings estimated at more than $10 million, had been handled for two years by DDB Needham Chicago, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: $25 and Under
description: The front door of this tiny new Indian vegetarian restaurant is bedecked with glitter, suggesting a sumptuous room within. Guess again.

title: Large British Retailer to Buy U.S. Credit-Data Company
description: Great Universal Stores P.L.C. said today that it would acquire an American credit-data company, the Experian Corporation, for $1.7 billion.

title: MAINE REPUBLICAN IS SEEN AS LEADING FOR DEFENSE POST
description: As the jockeying intensifies over President Clinton's choices for his national security team, William S. Cohen, the retiring Republican Senator from Maine, has emerged as the leading contender for Secretary of Defense, Administration officials said today.

title: 2 Chicago Agencies Plan to Merge
description: Two Chicago agencies, Grant/Jacoby Inc. and Pitzel & Pollack Advertising, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge and would operate under the Grant/Jacoby name. Terms were not disclosed.

title: In Rural China, Iodine Holds Key to Health
description: To the Editor:

title: While We Slept
description: ''Drug money'' used to mean just one thing -- the fortunes manipulated by drug criminals. Last week, while America slept, it took on one more meaning: the gobs of money contributed by a few rich Americans determined to put across state ballot-propositions that would widen the use of narcotics, and without penalty.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Last Dance

title: PINNACLE FINANCIAL IN A STOCK SWAP FOR INDIANA FEDERAL
description: Pinnacle Financial Services Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Indiana Federal Corporation in a stock swap valued at $113 million. The combined company plans to retain the Pinnacle name and be based in Valparaiso, Ind., where Indiana Federal has its headquarters. Indiana Federal operates 16 branches in Indiana and has assets of $809 million. Pinnacle has 31 branches in Michigan and Indiana with assets of $1 billion. Under the agreement, Pinnacle would exchange one share for each of Indiana Federal's 4.7 million shares. Pinnacle stock closed at $24 a share, down 75 cents, on the Nasdaq. Indiana Federal stock gained 16 percent, or $3.25, to close at $22.75 a share.

title: Art in Review
description: Jeffrey Brosk

title: RISCORP CONSIDERS A SALE OF THE COMPANY
description: Riscorp Inc. said yesterday that it would consider a sale of the company in light of a recent plunge in its stock price and disappointing earnings. The company, a provider of health care services in workers' compensation cases, formed a committee to consider its options, including its sale, to improve its share price. The move comes as Riscorp reported lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings and warned that it would probably fail to meet fourth-quarter estimates. It also comes amid an investigation of political contributions by top executives. Shares of Riscorp, based in Sarasota, Fla., dropped $2, to $4.375, giving the company a current market capitalization of $163 million. The company's shares traded as high as $24.50 in May.

title: For the Mailmen Lost in a Maze, Amazing News
description: Never mind that he was raised here and is now general manager of the Nicaraguan Post Office. Just like the other 1.5 million residents of this city whose streets have no names and no numbers, Jose Ernesto Gonzalez often has trouble finding his way around town.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13

title: New Publisher Named for Times Books
description: Random House, the book publishing arm of Advance Publications, said yesterday that Peter Bernstein, the corporate editor at U.S. News & World Report, would become the new publisher of its Times Books unit, which Random House has sought to shift in a more popular, and profitable, direction.

title: SUN AMERICA IS BUYING ANNUITY RESERVES FROM JOHN ALDEN
description: Sun America Inc. said yesterday that it would buy $5 billion worth of annuity reserves from the John Alden Financial Corporation for undisclosed terms. The acquisition would include substantially all of John Alden's annuity business and comes as the company focuses on its health insurance business, said Chris Wells, a spokeswoman for John Alden, which is based in Miami. The company said in March that it would sell its annuity and credit life and disability units. Sun America, based in Los Angeles, recently said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was considering a purchase worth $200 million to $300 million, said Karel Carnohan, a Sun America vice president. Analysts in March estimated John Alden's annuity business could fetch $275 million.

title: Grandson Taking a Step in Legend's Shoes
description: As grandmothers are wont to do, Rachel Robinson reached over to give her grandson Jesse some money as she said goodbye to him one recent afternoon. The small token of affection for her grandson was made rather unusually, though, as Rachel Robinson tucked some bills in the top of his left football stocking.

title: A Christmas Fair and Flea Market at Brick Church
description: A Christmas fair, featuring one-of-a-kind doll houses, stationery that can be personalized, linens, jewelry and children's clothes, stocking stuffers, topiaries and wreaths, will be held next week at the Brick Church, 62 East 92d Street in Manhattan. There will also be a flea market and raffles. The hours are Monday, 4 to 8 P.M. (admission, $5); Tuesday, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. and Wednesday 10 A.M. to 3 P.M.; admission is free on Tuesday and Wednesday. Information: (212) 289-4400.

title: Changes Planned for Leading Indicators
description: Seeking to sharpen an important tool for predicting the economy, the Conference Board said today that it would drop two components of its Composite Leading Index and replace them with a gauge of interest rates.

title: Cool Hands For Spanish Fevers
description: Alicia de Larrocha brings the Spanish piano repertory to New York with such regularity that we naturally begin to attach the qualities of her playing to the properties of the music itself. No one else can make the enormous complication of Granados's ''Goyescas'' sound so elegantly serene as Miss de Larrocha managed to do at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. In playing this music so well she, in a curious way, almost misrepresents it.

title: Icons Meet: Bugs, Daffy And Jordan
description: ''Space Jam'' may well be the only film in which Looney Tunes characters openly discuss merchandising tie-ins. As Daffy Duck asks Bugs Bunny when the subject of mugs and T-shirts comes up, ''You ever see any money from that stuff?''

title: Honors
description: * Richard Hochhauser, president of Harte-Hanks Direct Marketing, New York, was named the 1997 chairman of the Direct Marketing Association, New York. Patricia Campbell, senior vice president for new product development at the Advanta Corporation, Horsham, Pa., was named vice chairwoman and chairwoman-elect.

title: In the Magical Highlands With a Day to Find Love
description: ''Brigadoon,'' the 1947 Lerner and Loewe musical, should not work as well as it does. This escapist fantasy is almost unredeemably sentimental.

title: Art in Review
description: Carl Andre

title: Shoe Company, With 1,250 Jobs, Is Moving to White Plains
description: Taking advantage of this city's glut of office space, Nine West Group Inc. is consolidating its Cincinnati and Stamford, Conn., operations and moving its headquarters here.

title: Police Thyself
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Accuses Harrick
description: JIM HARRICK lied to U.C.L.A. officials eight separate times during their investigation of a recruiting dinner, according to an internal report released by the school.

title: Managed Care Officials Agree To Mastectomy Hospital Stays
description: Hoping to fend off Federal regulation, officials of managed health care plans said today that they would cover at least one night's hospital care for women who undergo mastectomies.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Striptease

title: The Election Changes Little; Business Can Live With That
description: In the days since the election, business leaders have concluded that the results amount to nothing much -- and are quite pleased by the prospect.

title: 2 Accused of Stealing Funds At Queens Home for Retarded
description: A married couple who operated a home for mentally retarded adults in Queens were arrested yesterday and charged with embezzling an estimated $500,000 in Medicaid funds provided for running the home, where a New York State commission had found squalid conditions.

title: Accounts
description: * Foreman & Clark, Minneapolis, to Hunt Adkins, Minneapolis, to handle advertising and marketing for the men's apparel retail chain, which had been handled in-house.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about the air collision this week in India referred incorrectly to the hometown of two women who had been waiting in New Delhi to board one of the two planes involved. The city, Bishkek, is in Kyrgyzstan, not Kazakstan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Dow Tops 6,300 On Signs of Slow Growth

title: Subways And Manners? Hell-o-o!
description: WELL, now, the Transit Authority wants to make better people out of New Yorkers, sensitive souls who step aside on subway platforms, who allow riders to get off trains with some grace, who do not pile in the moment the doors open, turning rush hour into a rugby scrum.

title: Taiwan Concern Seeks To Buy Mother's Cake
description: The President Enterprises Corporation, Taiwan's largest food company, is negotiating to buy the Mother's Cake and Cookie Company, a United States baker, for as much as $200 million, a move that would double its share of the United States cookie market, President executives said yesterday.

title: Motorola Names Founder's Heir as Chief
description: Motorola Inc. said today that Christopher B. Galvin, its 46-year-old president and chief operating officer, would succeed Gary L. Tooker, 57, as the telecommunications and semiconductor giant's chief executive on Jan. 1.

title: The Spoken Word
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. The Mayor will be interviewed by Jeff Greenfield, an author and commentator for ABC News. Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $18. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: Cardinal Bernardin Dies at 68; Reconciling Voice in Church
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago who as a moderate church leader was at the center of almost every major development in American Catholicism since the late 1960's, died early yesterday at his residence. He was 68.

title: Officials in St. Petersburg Call Racial Unrest 'Calculated'
description: City officials said today that the second bout of disturbances to erupt here after a white police officer fatally shot a black teen-ager was a ''calculated event'' by groups of youths. The officials added that the young people had been partly incited by a black militant group that threatened violence if the officer was cleared of criminal charges.

title: Wal-Mart's Censorship Should Carry Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: Insidious Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHERN STATES POWER ACQUIRING BOLIVIAN POWER
description: The Northern States Power Company said yesterday that its NRG Energy Inc. unit had agreed to acquire the Bolivian Power Company for $182 million. Northern States, which is based in Minneapolis, said it would begin a direct offer to the shareholders of the Bolivian electric utility of $43 a share sometime next week. Northern States said Bolivian Power's largest shareholder, Liberty Power-Cogentrix Bolivia Inc., had agreed to tender its 17.1 percent stake in support of the bid.

title: G.I. ADVANCE PARTY ARRIVES IN RWANDA
description: A vanguard of 43 American soldiers landed today in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, to begin laying the groundwork for an international force to rescue Rwandan refugees trapped in a war zone in eastern Zaire.

title: New Time Warner to Combine Film Units
description: Weeks after its $7.4 billion acquisition of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. was completed, Time Warner Inc. is now moving rapidly to reorganize the unwieldy film operation it inherited in the merger.

title: Shares of Sanofi Fall on Drug Test
description: Shares of Sanofi S.A. fell sharply today, a day after a study found that an experimental blood thinner works a little better than aspirin in warding off heart attacks and strokes in people who have clogged arteries.

title: Wal-Mart's Censorship Should Carry Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: Manhattan is an island, but you wouldn't know it from the restaurants. Waterside places are remarkably rare here.

title: When He's Hot, He's Hot: Starks Shows the Way
description: The relationship between John Starks and Knicks fans has always been on the edge, teetering between euphoria and depression.

title: Wal-Mart's Censorship Should Carry Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: Agreement On a Deal Unraveling With Time
description: Bud Selig signaled his intention yesterday to keep trying expeditiously to produce a new labor agreement for Major League Baseball, but his counterpart with the players injected a note of labor reality into the stalled process.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Man Ray at Rue Ferou'

title: Court Weighs Limited Seats At Bomb Trial For Victims
description: The trials of the two men accused of bombing the Federal Building in Oklahoma City will be broadcast live on closed circuit television from the courtroom here to the victims in a courtroom in Oklahoma City. But the preparations for the broadcast have raised difficult questions that lawyers and the judge in the case wrestled with today.

title: Goodbye, and Mostly Good Riddance
description: As he packs away plaques and proposals by the boxful, Representative Pat Williams ends a life in politics with wonder at the money of it all.

title: Shares of UAP Surge On News of AXA Merger
description: The shares of UAP surged and AXA fell yesterday on the first day of trading since the two French companies agreed to form the world's second-largest insurer. AXA said Tuesday that it would take over UAP in a 45 billion franc ($9 billion) stock swap. UAP shareholders would receive four AXA shares and four ''certificates of guaranteed value'' for 10 UAP shares. AXA valued the offer at 146.45 francs per UAP share.

title: Date's Swan Song Could Be vs. Seles
description: Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and Kimiko Date showed up at the All-Star Cafe yesterday to share the honors at the draw for next week's Chase Championships, a year-ending competition for the world's top 16 women.

title: Whose Inauguration Is It?
description: Seemingly chastened by the controversy over dubious contributions that dominated the closing weeks of the campaign, President Clinton has announced new curbs on special-interest fund-raising for his second inauguration. He has promised to limit individual and corporate contributions to $100 and require broad disclosure of loans and gifts.

title: A campaign by the U.S. Postal Service has drawn fire and a lawsuit from Federal Express.
description: THE Post Office used to like to brag that not even the elements prevented its carriers from moving the mail. More recent pronouncements, however, have been met with more than eyes rolling heavenward.

title: People
description: * Arthur Sweetser was named to the new position of executive vice president and client services director at Gearon Hoffman Inc., Boston. He had been a senior vice president at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Dartmouth

title: Foods Exert a Growing Appeal That Isn't Just for Jews
description: The smorgasbord of kosher foodstuffs jockeying for attention in the Meadowlands Exposition Center here is dizzying, from kosher-for-Passover unleavened taco shells to fleecy tufts of kosher cotton candy; kosher bonbons made in Belgium, kosher baby food made in France, kosher cannoli, kosher ravioli.

title: Welfare Plan Gives Power To Localities
description: Just as the Federal Government has turned over the major responsibility for running welfare programs to the states, Gov. George E. Pataki is proposing to transfer to local governments broad new powers to decide what necessities to give many of the state's poorest people, and for how long.

title: North-South Divide in Italy: A Problem for Europe, Too
description: As the capital of a province with an unemployment rate of 33 percent, the highest in Italy, the last thing Crotone needed was the recent flash floods that knocked out its bridges, flooded its basements with mud and shut down its few remaining factories. Damage was estimated at $300 million.

title: Art in Review
description: Andy Spence

title: Tourist Tax Is Defeated
description: The City Council defeated a proposal last night that would have imposed a $4-a-day tax on rented houses, apartments, hotel rooms and other accommodations for tourists. Councilman Bill McCarthy, who proposed the tax, had said year-round residents were footing the bill for the municipal services received by the thousands of tourists who visit Ocean City in the summer. But Councilman Chris Terrels, who was in the 5-to-2 majority that rejected the tax, said, ''I'm not underwriting tourists, they're underwriting me,'' The Associated Press reported.

title: It's Time For Redskins To Exit
description: SPORTS teams in America, and environs, insist on nicknames, for some reason. This has been going on for a hundred years. Most of the nicknames are so dumb they are beyond the pale of rational discussion. Why, for example, anyone would want to go around calling himself a Raptor, or a Net, or a Heat -- or, for that matter, a Blue Devil or a White Sock or, in the case of the Scottsdale (Ariz.) Community College athletes, an Artichoke -- ought to be fodder only for a psychiatrist's couch.

title: Durable Serena's Song Retires as Richest Filly
description: Serena's Song, the richest filly in racing history, who ran against colts in the 1995 Kentucky Derby and five other races, is being retired to the life of a broodmare and will race no more.

title: Death of a Scientist
description: Vladimir Nechai, director of Russia's Chelyabinsk-70 nuclear complex, was buried on Nov. 1. He had shot himself.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Ex-Mayor Has Heart Attack
description: Anthony DeFino, who served as Mayor of West New York for 24 years before deciding not to seek re-election last year, suffered a heart attack Monday night and remained in a coma yesterday at Palisades General Hospital, his wife said. Patricia DeFino said her 60-year-old husband, who once weighed more than 600 pounds, had slimmed down considerably but has had chronic breathing problems.

title: G.M. CHANGES TOP MANAGEMENT OF ITS DELCO UNIT
description: The General Motors Corporation announced a shake-up yesterday at the top of the Delco Electronics Corporation as part of a plan to make the electrical auto parts business more competitive. Gary W. Dickinson, 58, will retire on Jan. 1 from his post as president and chief executive of Delco, after a three-year tenure. He will be replaced by Michael Burns, 44, who was general manager of Delphi Thermal Systems, a unit of Delphi Automotive Systems, G.M.'s other auto parts company. General Motors is struggling to improve both Delco and Delphi. The shake-up was reported in yesterday's Wall Street Journal. General Motors also said yesterday, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, that labor strikes in the United States and Canada would cost the company $700 million in the fourth quarter, while increased retirement benefits would cost it $170 million.

title: NBC and Fox in Denial Over N.F.L. Ratings
description: It's the darnedest thing: A. C. Nielsen has misplaced football viewers. They were there last year. Now they're AWOL. Or so NBC and Fox allege.

title: Helping the Poor Obtain Justice
description: The deep slash in funding for the Federal legal services program combined with new restrictions on the types of cases legal services lawyers may handle means that tens of thousands of needy Americans with legal problems cannot obtain access to the justice system. In New York City, where there are now fewer than 200 legal services lawyers to serve a large population of impoverished clients, many needy families will be without help in fighting eviction from their homes or seeking protection from spousal abuse.

title: A Well-Connected Canadian in Charge in Zaire
description: Sometimes the biggest challenge of being a diplomat is figuring out how to grab the attention of your own government.

title: Infant Formula Additive
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking a Second Chance In a Rather Busy Apartment
description: Carl Ritchie is a promising playwright who knows how to construct a comedy. But ''Family Values'' suggests that Mr. Ritchie has a way to go before he writes an original, first-rate comedy.

title: A Horn Among the Strings
description: The distinguished American composer George Perle had never thought of writing a work for horn and string quartet until he was approached by the busy horn player David Jolley. Mr. Perle's work, completed last year, received its New York premiere on Tuesday at a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and it was clear that all involved were happy to add it to the scant repertory for this unorthodox instrumental contingent.

title: Lotto Whisks Winner From Chickens to Nest Egg
description: Niki Barkoutsis doesn't figure to be helping out much behind the counter of her family's Chirping Chicken fast-food outlets anymore.

title: Liquor Ads, TV, Toasters and Mixed Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Much Filth
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Winter Won't Wait for Fall, Thoughts Are Already Heading South
description: The most remarkable sight here after a four-foot snowfall this week is not the National Guard clearing streets or the shoulder-high snow banks, but the leaves still covering many of the city's oaks and maples.

title: Strong Apparel Sales Lift Gap's Earnings
description: Gap Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose nearly 15 percent in the third quarter, bolstered by strong sales at each of its specialty apparel chains, particularly the Old Navy stores.

title: Films From Israel At Manhattan Festival
description: Israeli films, many of them having their United States premieres, will be screened this weekend at the 1996 Israeli Film Festival at the Angelika 57 Theater, 225 West 57th Street, Manhattan. The series, which features introductory remarks by the directors and discussions after the screenings, runs through Nov. 26.

title: Rescue Mission to Africa
description: President Clinton has responded humanely and judiciously to the challenge of saving a million desperate refugees trapped by war in eastern Zaire. He has offered to send a contingent of American troops as part of a Canadian-led international force, provided certain reasonable ground rules are honored. The most important is that the rival armies between which the refugees are now caught agree not to interfere with the international operation. Now, the Administration must assure United Nations acceptance of its conditions and secure the approval of Congressional leaders.

title: Nell Blaine, 74, Painter Who Blended Styles
description: Nell Blaine, a widely respected New York landscape painter and watercolorist, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 74 and had homes in Manhattan and Gloucester, Mass.

title: Drifting, and Singing, Through Paris
description: Jacques Rivette's leisurely musical fantasy ''Up-Down-Fragile'' is not a movie to quicken the pulse of those who like their cinema taut and action-packed. This quirky semi-improvised homage to old-time MGM musicals sprawls over nearly three hours, and not much really happens. But once you've adapted to its gentle loping pace, the movie, which opens a 10-day engagement today at Anthology Film Archives as part of a monthlong Rivette retrospective, exerts an oddball Gallic charm.

title: SUIT FILED OVER ROCKEFELLER CENTER SALE
description: A group of shareholders of the former Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. has filed a lawsuit charging that David Rockefeller, Goldman, Sachs and others committed securities fraud in their $1.2 billion purchase of the company earlier this year. The suit contends that Mr. Rockefeller, Goldman, Sachs and the company's management knew but did not tell shareholders that the buyers were in talks to sell to the General Electric Company's NBC unit the space the broadcaster leases in the New York landmark, Rockefeller Center, for $440 million. As a result, shareholders were forced to sell their stakes at an artificially low price, the suit says. The sale of the company was approved by shareholders before the Rockefeller-Goldman group reached the agreement with NBC. The defendants called the suit meritless. The suit, filed yesterday in Federal court in Delaware, seeks unspecified damages or rescission of the sale.

title: Coach Dismissed
description: Wright State dismissed Coach RALPH UNDERHILL yesterday, four days after he was charged with shoplifting. Underhill, 55, who coached the Raiders for 18 years, was accused of taking vitamins from a store near the university campus in suburban Dayton on Monday.

title: 'B-1 Bob' Was Here
description: The last time I caught Bob Dornan's shtick, the joint was jumping. ''B-1 Bob,'' as the Congressman is known, was spritzing his one-liners from the stage of the Washington Hilton ballroom, as the closing act on the Friday night bill at the Christian Coalition's September ''Road to Victory'' convention. In a parade of lugubrious speakers -- you don't know what it is to be comatose until you've heard Dick Armey describe his spiritual journey -- Representative Dornan had snap, crackle, pop. Berating the gay-rights movement, he observed, ''It's as if the road to Selma were also the road to Sodomy!''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Beliefs
description: The State Department this week released the names of 20 outstanding American religious leaders and scholars who will form a new Advisory Committee on Religious Freedom Abroad.

title: Fed Minutes Show Little Dissent Over Policy
description: Despite widespread speculation that there had been a rift within the Federal Reserve at its September meeting over the issue of whether monetary policy needed to be tightened, minutes of the session released today showed that a strong majority saw no compelling case for raising rates at a time when the economy was slowing from its overheated pace earlier in the year.

title: Residue of Deadly Acid Found By Trash Collectors in Bronx
description: Just two days after a city sanitation worker died from exposure to hydrofluoric acid that was improperly disposed of in Brooklyn, two city trash collectors discovered canisters with residues of the deadly chemical in a recycling container in the Bronx yesterday, city officials said.

title: Go Slow on Digital TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission is poised to issue standards for transmission of digital television -- broadcasts with the picture quality of movie theaters and the sound quality of CD's. The standards, in draft form, are backed by the broadcasters but opposed by parts of the computer industry. Most commissioners -- only the chairman, Reed Hundt, resists -- have lined up behind the broadcasters even though the staff has been flooded with conflicting technical and economic studies submitted by the industries whose financial fortunes will be dictated by the commission's decision.

title: POP
description: A Billie Holiday Disciple

title: Quality Candidates Only
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Prices in Retreat As Investors Take Profits
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday, as investors chose to take profits on this week's market run-up.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: For Purcell and Britten,

title: On Choosing Judges, Pataki Creates Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: ZAIRIAN REBELS ROUT FOES, FREEING REFUGEES IN CAMPS; AID MISSION NOW UNCERTAIN
description: Hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees streamed homeward from eastern Zaire today, appearing to break a military and political deadlock that had threatened to cause a human catastrophe on a grand scale.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about J. Kevin McNiff, a former New York State corrections official, misstated the given name of one of his sons. He is John McNiff, not Joseph.

title: Hospital Beefs Up Security
description: Last week, two patients with criminal records escaped from Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital by climbing over a fence surrounding an outdoor smoking area. They were captured by the Morris Plains police about an hour later. But in the hope of sparing Greystone from future embarrassment, and to improve the institution's relationship with the surrounding communities, officials announced new security measures yesterday. Fences on hospital property will be modified and patients who request permission to go outside to smoke will be carefully screened, said John McKeegan, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services.

title: Utah Senator Scolds Critics Of Prosecutor In Whitewater
description: Departing from post-election expressions of bipartisanship, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee, today accused President Clinton of unleashing ''attack dogs'' to smear Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating Whitewater and related matters.

title: Oh, All Those Wacky Celebrities!
description: Pete Townshend of the Who, having just bought a Martin guitar from Ron Wood of the Rolling Stones for $10,000, was trying to persuade Jimmy Page of Led Zeppelin to buy his Rickenbacker guitar. When Mr. Page declined, Robert Plant of Led Zeppelin squeezed Mr. Townshend's arm, looked conspiratorially at his girlfriend, the Indian singer Najma Akhtar, and bought Mr. Townshend's Rickenbacker: for $27,500. The two rock stars hugged, with Mr. Plant's blond tresses falling over Mr. Townshend's receded hairline.

title: A Distant Departure From Bosnia
description: Common sense dictates that after a year of imperfect peace, Bosnia is not ready for NATO forces to go home on Dec. 20, as originally planned. But Americans ought to have no illusions about what can be accomplished by prolonging their stay, nor should they accept President Clinton's facile assertion yesterday that he was announcing a new and different military mission. Mr. Clinton delayed America's exit from the current mission. To assure that further delays do not develop, the Administration should sharpen the withdrawal strategy Mr. Clinton outlined. It must also obtain Congressional approval for the extended American presence.

title: Bugs Bunny Is New Tenant At 1 Times Sq.
description: One Times Square, the stark white tower that anchors New York's pre-eminent expanse of neon and serves as a national symbol of New Year's Eve with its stroke-of-midnight ball drop, is getting a new tenant: Tweety Bird.

title: Shopping (Wisely) Is Winner's First Act
description: Even with millions of unexpected dollars in her investment portfolio and a 23-year-old head on her shoulders, Niki Barkoutsis, the lottery winner from Astoria, Queens, is not one to spend foolishly.

title: Renault Says Sales Were Down in 9 Months
description: The troubled French auto maker Renault S.A. said yesterday that its sales in the first nine months of 1996 were down nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 135.8 billion francs, or $26.7 billion, from the period a year ago. Most of the sales decline was in commercial vehicles.

title: Of Vampires and Lesbians, With Humor
description: Jawole Willa Jo Zollar has changed very little but grown a lot, to judge by her ''Bones and Ash: A Gilda Story,'' a work of majestic theatricality and eloquent detail that opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Ms. Zollar is still drawn to the lives of women as subject matter. But the chattering, hair-braiding young girls of earlier pieces have become the lesbian vampires of ''The Gilda Stories,'' the novel by Jewelle Gomez on which Ms. Zollar's new piece is partly based. And Ms. Zollar clearly still believes in the theatrical power of simplicity, though ''Bones and Ash'' sweeps through a century and several cultures.

title: Orthodox Sacred Works, With a Dash of Glamour
description: Despite the starry presence of the baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, the concert of sacred music by the St. Petersburg Chamber Choir at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening seemed a departure for Great Performers at Lincoln Center, and a happy one. As if to prove a new seriousness of purpose, the series is to present a similar group in March, the Chorovaya Akademia, with no recourse to glamour.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CASINO AMERICA INC., Biloxi, Miss., said its Isle of Capri unit had laid off 112 employees at Bossier City, La., and another 9 workers at its Lake Charles riverboats after disappointing second-quarter earnings.

title: Fetching T. Rex Fossil May Fetch $1 Million Plus, Expert Says
description: Cut off in the prime of life 65 million years ago, chiseled from a butte in South Dakota in 1990 and seized by the F.B.I. two years later, Sue the Tyrannosaur is headed for the auction block at Sotheby's. She may bring well over $1 million, which would be the highest price ever paid for a fossil.

title: TOM BROWN INCREASES BID FOR PRESIDIO OIL
description: The independent oil and gas company Tom Brown Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its bid for the Presidio Oil Company by $10 million, to $193 million, in return for support from Presidio's creditors. Under the new terms, Tom Brown Inc. will pay $105 million in cash and 5.35 million Tom Brown shares for Presidio Oil. If the deal proceeds as expected, Presidio Oil is expected to file for bankruptcy protection and reorganize its finances. Tom Brown Inc. said all Presidio's creditors had accepted its new offer and the deal was now in its final stage. Presidio Oil is an oil and gas exploration company.

title: Casino Group Splits Up
description: The Casino Association of New Jersey made it official yesterday: its bickering members no longer speak with one voice. The organization has been on the ropes ever since it lobbied against a bill (which later became law) allowing Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of the Mirage Corporation, to recoup much of the cost of cleaning up a toxic waste site where a new resort is planned. That move cost the association four members that favored the legislation. Two others had quit earlier, leaving the group with only six members -- three of them owned by Donald Trump.

title: Russians Do Fine On the Big Board
description: The American depository receipts of Vimpel-Communications A.O., the first Russian company to trade on the New York Stock Exchange, soared yesterday in their first day of trading.

title: Looking at Death, Both in Fear and in Fun
description: Of all the innovators who set out to extend the boundaries of the American theater over the last 30 years, few have had a more enduring influence than Joseph Chaikin. If there are any doubts to that claim, Mr. Chaikin's mesmerizing staging of an updated version of Susan Yankowitz's ''Terminal'' at Performance Space 122 dispels them.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend yesterday about the sale of prints at the Whitney Museum of American Art misstated the price of three Cy Twombly prints. They cost $30,000 each, not $30,000 for the three.

title: Explore Tunnel Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Kohlberg Kravis Jumps Into Duty-Free Shop Fray
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York buyout firm, has stepped into the fray over DFS Group Ltd., the closely held empire of duty-free stores.

title: Accord Reached in Suit Over East River Bridges
description: Hoping to end a four-year battle that has delayed repairs of its deteriorating East River bridges, New York City has reached a settlement with people who consider sandblasting a health risk and has agreed to new environmental safeguards on bridge-repair projects.

title: And the Nets Thought It Could Not Get Worse
description: The normally colorful and bubbly John Calipari walked through the door looking as flat and dull as a day-old party balloon.

title: C.I.A. Chief Visits Watts To Counter Crack Talk
description: John M. Deutch came in from the cold today.

title: Diversity Is Good for Business
description: One of the most perplexing problems faced by American executives today is diversity and how corporations should address it. In 1993, I joined the Denny's chain to guide it through widely publicized customer charges of discrimination, and learned what works in integrating diversity into corporate culture. Recent news reports have once again demonstrated how important these lessons are.

title: Parent's Nightmare Ends Well
description: Tiffany Winfield stepped out of her car Thursday night, leaving the motor running and the doors unlocked, so that she could buy some takeout food. Snuggled in an infant seat in the back, her 11-month-old daughter, Jasmine, slept cozily. Minutes later, Mrs. Winfield was swept into a parent's worst nightmare: her car, with two men in it, was backing away. She ran after them, pounding on the side and screaming: ''My baby! My baby is inside!'' The car sped away, but the nightmare ended well. $(Page A1.$)

title: As Thousands of Refugees Leave Camps in Zaire, U.S. Reassesses the Need for Military Force
description: With hundreds of thousands of Rwandans leaving refugee camps in Zaire for home, the United States has begun to reassess the need for a military force, led by Canada, to rescue the refugees and open the way for delivery of relief aid, senior Pentagon officials said today.

title: Stocks Take A Wild Ride And Close Up
description: After an eight-day surge, the stock market had a volatile up-and-down day yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average leaping almost 65 points before giving up all but a point of the gain by early afternoon. The index later rebounded, closing 35.03 points higher.

title: She Sees Unelected LegislatureAs Violating Hong Kong Pact : Beijing Reneges, Thatcher Alleges
description: BEIJING  China is breaking the treaty it signed to take back Hong Kong from England next year, former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said Friday.

title: Childs's Return a Necessity for the Struggling Knicks
description: Charles Oakley mentioned two weeks ago how fortunate the Knicks were to have lost Chris Childs to injury during what Oakley called an ''easy part'' of the schedule.

title: Another Senior Funds Executive Resigns From Fidelity
description: Fidelity Investments, which in the last year has seen its market share stop growing and has faced investor unrest over the lagging performance of some of its top mutual funds, lost another senior funds executive this week.

title: Key's Future In the Balance As Yanks Talk
description: Jimmy Key, the winning pitcher in the last game of the World Series, will have to wait until today to find out if he will continue to be a member of the Yankees or if he can be a free agent.

title: In Letter to Rape Case Accuser, Juror Assails Defense Lawyer's Remarks
description: A juror who voted to convict Alex Kelly of rape broke her silence about the deliberations today because she said she was offended by the defense lawyer's remarks about Mr. Kelly's accuser.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Texaco Agrees to Settle Discrimination Suit

title: Metro-North Gets Real on Snow Delays
description: Ten months ago, Metro-North rolled cockily into the worst blizzard in half a century and took a pummeling. Chastened, it has lowered its expectations for the next great storm, and it is warning riders to do the same.

title: Magic Loses Hardaway For Several Weeks
description: The Orlando Magic's early-season fortunes suffered a blow yesterday when the team learned that ANFERNEE HARDAWAY's ailing left knee will require surgery that could sideline the All-Star point guard up to six weeks.

title: No Headline
description: ''I just want to say to all the mothers who can learn from my mistakes -- don't ever do this.''

title: Opening Up T.S. Eliot In All the Empty Places
description: Deborah Warner's stage version of ''The Waste Land'' is a reimagining of the T. S. Eliot poem in visceral dramatic terms. In the one-woman play, which is scheduled to open tomorrow at the Liberty, a long unused theater on West 42d Street, Fiona Shaw is both the voice of the poem and the characters who inhabit its landscapes, actual and mythic.

title: Parking and Politics Intersect as Giuliani Rolls Back $40 Meter Fines
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani raised the fines for expired parking meters outside central Manhattan in July, angry merchants tied black balloons to meters outside their stores. City Council members wrote belligerent letters and threatened legislation. Callers filled the Mayor's usually affectionate radio show with invective.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: One Times Square: Historic Highlights
description: 1904 -- The building, known as Times Tower, is completed by The New York Times at the south end of Long Acre Square, which is renamed Times Square. The Times boasts that its building is the tallest in New York City, which is true only if several subbasements extending far underground are counted.

title: Industrial Output Increases in Japan
description: Japan's industrial production for September rose 1.5 percent from the previous month, as auto makers raised output to meet demand for new models, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said yesterday. That is up from the 1 percent growth in the Government's preliminary report, on Oct. 29.

title: Bridge
description: Each year the International Bridge Press Association makes awards for outstanding deals. During the world championships on the Greek island of Rhodes last month, the Sender Precision Award for the best defense, named for Henry Sender of Nashville, went to the diagramed deal.

title: A New Bernstein Podium for an Audience of Surfers
description: During his lifetime, Leonard Bernstein was probably the world's most media-savvy musician, someone who made full use of radio, television, books, recordings and video, not only as conduits for his own performances, but also as instruments through which he could convey his passion for music to both aficionados and newcomers. Now, six years after his death, his estate is keeping up with technology on his behalf.

title: White House Says Commerce Aide Sought Fund-Raising Job in Meeting With Clinton
description: The White House disclosed for the first time today that at a meeting with President Clinton last year, John Huang made a pitch for a senior fund-raising post at the Democratic National Committee.

title: Showalter Cheers Yanks
description: Barely three weeks after his former team won its 23d World Series championship, BUCK SHOWALTER was back in New York City yesterday for the first time since he refused to return as manager of the Yankees last October. These days, Showalter is busy building the Arizona Diamondbacks for their major league debut in 1998.

title: Car Hits Bus in New Jersey, Causing Injuries and Tie-Ups
description: A New Jersey Transit bus traveling against the flow of car traffic in a special bus lane collided head-on with a car yesterday morning on a busy highway in Weehawken, a short distance from the Lincoln Tunnel, bringing morning rush-hour traffic nearly to a standstill for more than two hours.

title: 'The Big Man' Is a No-Show on the Non-Campaign Trail in Zambia
description: ''I must apologize the city has had no water for a month,'' Sunday P. Mwila said, explaining why the toilet in his bathroom did not flush.

title: Ex-Garbage Chief Sentenced
description: The former head of Newark's sanitation division was sentenced to 5 years and 10 months in prison yesterday for diverting more than $7 million in city money to businessmen and organized crime figures in return for more than $500,000 in kickbacks, Federal prosecutors said. Salvatore Juliano, the sanitation chief from 1980 to 1986, pleaded guilty in 1993 to approving hundreds of invoices from vendors for supplies and services that were never delivered. Some of the vendors, who paid kickbacks to Mr. Juliano in return for their payments, were linked to the Lucchese crime family.

title: Alger Hiss, Divisive Icon of the Cold War, Dies at 92
description: Alger Hiss, the erudite diplomat and Harvard-trained government lawyer who was convicted of perjury in an espionage case that became one of the great riddles of the Cold War, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Just a New York Minute! High Minds Thrive on Our Subways.
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Interview With Clinton: 'Global Economy' and the U.S.
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton by The New York Times on Thursday, as recorded by the White House:

title: Refugees Flee War in Western Afghan City
description: Thousands of refugees fled today for makeshift camps on the outskirts of Herat, in western Afghanistan, after jets belonging to opponents of the fundamentalist Taliban militia bombed the airport here.

title: The 'Second Chance' Or the Real Motive?
description: CHRISTIAN PETER was bound to resurface, the brute out of Nebraska was just too good; you got up slow when he hit you, especially if you were not a football player, or were a woman. The very qualities that made him socially dangerous made him enormously attractive as a defensive tackle. But in explaining their decision to sign him, the Giants opted to sound moral rather than pragmatic yesterday. General Manager George Young said, ''He deserves a second chance.''

title: Texaco to Make Record Payout In Bias Lawsuit
description: In the largest settlement ever in a racial discrimination case, Texaco Inc. agreed yesterday to pay more than $140 million to resolve a Federal lawsuit brought by its minority employees.

title: Life in the Fast Lane
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES FALL AT HEALTH MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS
description: The shares of Health Management Systems Inc. fell 34 percent yesterday after the company said its fourth-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of the company fell $7.625, to $14.50. Health Management said it expected to report net income of 15 cents to 16 cents a share for the quarter that ended on Oct. 31. The company had been expected to earn 22 cents a share, the average estimate of 13 analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. Health Management is a health care information processing company.

title: Peru Crash Is Attributed to Maintenance Error
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that the crash of a Boeing 757 off Peru six weeks ago, killing all 70 people aboard, had probably occurred because maintenance workers forgot to remove the tape-and-paper covers they had put over sensors while polishing the plane, and it urged safety officials in the United States to take steps to prevent such errors.

title: Islanders Get a Nice Lead, But Just Can't Live With It
description: Prosperity has been difficult to deal with for the Islanders.

title: School Board in Washington Is Stripped of All Its Authority
description: The District of Columbia board of education was stripped of its powers today when the city's financial control board created a board of trustees to take over management of the school system.

title: 2 French Rappers Get Jail for Insults to Police
description: PARIS  Two singers from the French rap group NTM received prison sentences, fines and a ban on performing Friday for insulting the police during a concert in the Mediterranean port of Toulon, a stronghold of the far-right National Front.

title: Nevada Mining Shifts Underground to Get the Deep Ore
description: More than a thousand feet below the snow-covered hills of northern Nevada, miners toil alone or in pairs in sweltering tunnels separated by absolute darkness. They are digging for gold.

title: De La Hoya to Return
description: OSCAR DE LA HOYA will return to the ring for the first time since beating JULIO CESAR CHAVEZ when he defends his World Boxing Council 140-pound title Jan. 18 against the undefeated MIGUEL ANGEL GONZALEZ.

title: On Critical Decisions, Science Beats Out Beliefs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Better-Safe-Than-Sorry Strategy for 49ers' Young: Agent Suggesting Retirement
description: Steve Young has suffered two concussions in the last three weeks, and everyone close to him is concerned.

title: Starting Date Set for Trial On Oklahoma Bombing
description: Jury selection in the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh, one of two men charged in the Oklahoma City bombing, will begin on March 31, almost two years after the April 15, 1995, blast that destroyed the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building and killed 168 people. Mr. McVeigh's co-defendant, Terry L. Nichols, will stand trial afterwards.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about the New York City Opera revival of ''Brigadoon'' at the New York State Theater misidentified the choreographer of the ballet ''Appalachian Spring.'' She was Martha Graham, not Agnes de Mille.

title: Conrail Fight: Neither Side Can Afford To Be Loser
description: Forget Tyson and Holyfield. The next round in a much bigger heavyweight boxing match, pitting the transportation giants CSX and Norfolk Southernagainst each other in the battle for the Eastern railroad crown, opens in Federal District Court in Philadelphia on Monday. And crowding around the ring will be arbitragers, analysts, shareholders, railroad executives, lawyers and investment bankers with a stake in the outcome.

title: KCS ENERGY TO BUY OIL AND GAS UNIT OF MIDAMERICAN
description: KCS Energy Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Intercoast Oil and Gas Company, the oil and natural gas unit of the Mid-American Energy Company, for $210 million in cash and 435,000 common stock warrants. The agreement amends a deal reached last month. KCS Energy said the deal would expand its natural gas and oil base and would double both average daily production and reserves. The warrants being issued to MidAmerican have a four-year term and an exercise price of $45 a share. MidAmerican Energy is a utility holding company formed through the merger of Midwest Resources Inc. and the Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company.

title: Israel Allows Use of Physical Force in Arab's Interrogation
description: The day after the Israeli High Court issued a temporary injunction preventing the use of ''physical pressure'' in the interrogation of a Palestinian detainee, it acceded to an appeal from the secret police to continue using methods that, according to human-rights groups, constitute torture.

title: Law on Repetitive Motion Injury Is Approved
description: After years of debate, California regulators approved on Thursday the nation's first law intended to curb the growing problem of repetitive motion injuries at work.

title: Surrender in False Rape Case
description: A 32-year-old Elizabeth woman who was charged last March with falsely accusing two male inmates of raping her at the Union County jail turned herself in yesterday, prosecutors said. The woman, Alveda Torrado, spent several months in Puerto Rico because ''psychologically, she wasn't ready to surrender,'' her lawyer, Mark A. Blacher, said.

title: Russia Is Re-Creating A Telephone Monopoly
description: RAO Rostelecom, Russia's main long-distance phone company, confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to be taken over by a local phone network, RAO Svyazinvest, re-creating a Government telecommunications monopoly broken up in 1992. Under the proposed plan, the Russian Government will transfer its 38 percent controlling stake in Rostelecom to Svyazinvest to create one company that would sell shares to Western investors next year.

title: Trolley Wires Delay Trains
description: Trolley wires that fell on a Metro-North Railroad track in New Rochelle, N.Y., delayed thousands of commuters in New York at rush hour yesterday. Capt. Anthony Ashby of the Metro-North Police Department said that the wires fell on the tracks just before 6 P.M., disabling an eastbound train on the New Haven Line and three of the four tracks between Mount Vernon and New Rochelle. All trains on the line suffered delays, Captain Ashby said.

title: THEATER
description: Through the Ages,

title: Holtz's Plans No Clearer After Speech
description: If Lou Holtz has decided to return for a 12th season as football coach at Notre Dame, to challenge Knute Rockne's school record for victories and to lead the Irish into an expanded and modernized stadium next year, he chose an unusual way to express his intentions yesterday.

title: As Glory Fades for Cadillacs, a Failed Dealer Sues G.M.
description: The convertible glided along the city streets, engine humming, finish glowing, fins sailing. It was a 1950's Cadillac Coupe de Ville, top of the line, best of the best. To Dick Gidron, a skinny boy from the south side of Chicago, it was glory on wheels.

title: PETROLITE MOVES TO BLOCK FORCED SALE BY SHAREHOLDER
description: The Petrolite Corporation, a chemicals company, said yesterday that it was considering a partnership to block attempts by a major shareholder to force the sale of the company. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Petrolite jumped $4.75, to $42.25. The shareholder, William S. Barnickel & Company, said that it had received indications from third parties wanting to buy Petrolite for at least $456 million, or $40 a share. Barnickel owns 47 percent of Petrolite stock. A committee of independent Petrolite directors said yesterday that it, not Barnickel, should be allowed to sell or merge the company, contending Barnickel had an ''acknowledged conflict of interest.'' Petrolite did not say what that conflict was.

title: Ethics Charge Is Rejected
description: Transportation Commissioner Frank J. Wilson did nothing improper when he discussed job possibilities with two companies that might benefit from a contract for an electronic toll collection system for the state's toll roads, Edward Gross, acting executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, ruled yesterday. But Mr. Wilson's problems are far from over. Lockheed Martin IMS Corporation of Teaneck, the company that complained about Mr. Wilson's conduct, said it would sue to have Mr. Gross's decision overturned. And the state Executive Commission on Ethical Standards plans its own investigation, said Carl Golden, a spokesman for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: As Valujet Crash Hearing Nears, Board Seeks Better Fire Gear for Planes
description: The Transportation Department has decided to seek new rules requiring fire safety equipment in all airline cargo compartments, officials said on Thursday night, on the eve of hearings into the May crash of a Valujet DC-9 that investigators believe such equipment could have prevented.

title: Campaign Scandal Charges Heighten Russian Rivalries
description: A Russian newspaper published today what it said was a transcript of a taped meeting that suggests that President Boris N. Yeltsin's chief of staff plotted to cover up a major financing scandal during this year's presidential campaign and then lied about it.

title: Enforcing Subway Etiquette
description: The top executives of the Transit Authority are periodically seized with the notion they are running the London Underground or some other orderly urban transportation system. Their latest idea is to speed the loading of subway trains by asking New Yorkers to develop a more refined sense of subway etiquette.

title: Risking Protests, Giants to Sign Troubled Husker
description: The Giants are bracing for what could be a wave of negative publicity in the wake of their decision to sign the former Nebraska defensive tackle Christian Peter, who has a history of violent behavior toward women. The Giants are standing firm behind their decision, saying that everyone deserves a second chance as long as he has earned it.

title: U.S. READY TO KEEP A FORCE IN BOSNIA 18 MONTHS LONGER
description: Saying Bosnia still reaps ''a bitter harvest of hatred,'' President Clinton announced today that the United States was prepared to keep thousands of troops in the shattered Balkan nation for an additional 18 months.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Nov. 6 about ''The Clash of Civilizations and the Remaking of World Order'' by Samuel P. Huntington misstated the year in which George F. Kennan, under the pseudonym X, wrote an article for Foreign Affairs in which he made the case for containing the Soviet Union. It was 1947, not 1948.

title: Reeling Rangers Depart For a Crucial Road Trip
description: Struggling through an early-season malaise, and without a victory in their last five games, the Rangers begin a six-game trip that they insist will be a chance to change their fortunes rather than a mandate to save their coach's job.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: The Military's Moment of Truth
description: The accusations of sexual harassment and assault of female recruits at the Aberdeen Proving Ground's Army Ordnance Center in Maryland and at other camps around the country have heightened the debate over the role and rights of women in the military. Clearly, sexual misconduct in the military is not exclusively a Navy problem, as it was rather foolishly perceived to be after the Tailhook convention.

title: A Secret Disclosed Imperils the Career Of State Dept. Aide
description: Richard Nuccio's story, as he tells it, is a cautionary tale of what can happen in Washington when you pass along a secret: you might face a criminal investigation and perhaps the loss of your career.

title: Four on Council Denounce Messinger's Ad Spending
description: Four City Council members attacked Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, yesterday for using tax money to pay for radio commercials that they called blatant campaign ads aimed at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: U.S. Is Reassessing Need for Zaire Force
description: With hundreds of thousands of Rwandans heading home from refugee camps in Zaire, the United States has begun to reassess the need for a multinational military force to rescue the refugees and open the way for the delivery of relief aid, senior Pentagon officials said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7

title: Prudential Unit Agrees to Settlement
description: Prudential Securities Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $18 million to settle charges related to the bankruptcy of the Foundation for New Era Philanthropy.

title: Injuries Will Result
description: To The Editor:

title: Neighborhood S.R.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: P.S.A.L. Quarterfinals

title: Murder Verdict Is Father's Last Gift
description: In the early hours of the morning of his daughter's 22d birthday, Thomas Antonakos drove to her grave in a Staten Island cemetery and delivered the gift he had prayed so long and hard for: news that one of the men accused of kidnapping her and setting her body ablaze had been convicted.

title: Spaniard Pregnant With 7
description: A Spanish woman who has had fertility treatment is pregnant with seven fetuses and wants to give birth to all of them, according to the hospital that is treating her.

title: House Freshmen Label Themselves Pragmatic
description: Remember the last House of Representatives? The one whose Republican Speaker branded Democrats ''the enemy of normal Americans?'' The one whose Democrats seized the Speaker's chair one night and decorated it with his caricature, clad in a diaper?

title: Leaders? Defense's Debate Rages On
description: Carl Greenwood's contention that the Jets are a team without strong leaders and with players who lack discipline reverberated throughout the locker room today. The remarks he made on Thursday seemed to bother middle linebacker Marvin Jones, but were played down by Coach Rich Kotite.

title: Juror Attacks Defense In Rape Trial Impasse
description: A juror who voted to convict Alex Kelly of rape broke her silence about the deliberations because she said she was offended by the defense lawyer's remarks about Mr. Kelly's accuser.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Piano Duo of Many Styles,

title: Time Warner-Murdoch Feud Entangles MCI Satellite Plan
description: Time Warner Inc. is taking its cable-television feud with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to the skies.

title: PERFUMANIA TO BUY AILING NATURE'S ELEMENTS
description: Perfumania Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Nature's Elements Holding Corporation, which is operating under bankruptcy court protection. Financial terms were not disclosed. Perfumania, a retailer and wholesaler of perfumes and fragrances based in Miami, said the transaction included 34 operating stores in the Northeast. Nature's Elements stores sell cosmetics, treatments, bath and body products, and candles. The agreement was approved by the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Newark and is expected to close early next week. Nature's Elements, of Edgewater, N.J., filed for bankruptcy protection in April 1995.

title: The Decadent Decade
description: Such is the decadence of the 1990's that millionaires who fancy themselves rich now have multimillionaires rolling on the floor in laughter. A million is small change these days.

title: Jazzman as Star, and Liking It
description: Punching the air on the final downbeats, using body language to imitate the opposing lines in his solos, Joshua Redman was a complete entertainer during an early set on Thursday at the Bottom Line. It becomes him, now that he is a celebrity; in the 24 hours before the concert, the tenor saxophonist had been on two television talk shows. This kind of tinderbox star-power rarely happens to jazz musicians, and he is keeping up enthusiastically with its demands.

title: Simple
description: To the Editor:

title: A Surreal Day on Afghans' Eisenhower Highway
description: Thirty years ago this summer, the grandest of all American aid projects in Afghanistan was completed with the official opening of a paved highway linking Kabul, the capital, with Kandahar, the country's second biggest city.

title: Ruth E. Moskowitz Dead at 60; Judge and Civil Rights Activist
description: Ruth E. Moskowitz of Brooklyn, a justice of the New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died on Nov. 2 at Mount Sinai Medical Center. A native and lifetime resident of Brooklyn Heights, she was 60.

title: Splitting Hairs, With Surgical Precision
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the murder conviction of a Brooklyn man for setting a 20-year-old college student on fire omitted the given name of the prosecutor in some editions. He is Assistant District Attorney Eugene Reibstein.

title: A Conflict As Orange Meets Army
description: FOR the most part, Jim Ridlon will adhere to the ritual he has followed for 22 seasons as radio color commentator for Syracuse University football.

title: Israeli Segments
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT ADMITS HE AND INDONESIAN HAD POLICY TALKS
description: President Clinton has acknowledged in an interview that he twice discussed policy about Indonesia and China with James T. Riady, the Indonesian financier, Democratic contributor and longtime friend of Mr. Clinton who is at the center of several inquiries into the influence of foreign money in Washington.

title: They Just Don't Get It About Rape
description: The Connecticut trial of Alex Kelly on rape charges, which ended last week in a hung jury, had a number of disturbing aspects. One of the most outrageous was the testimony of Dr. Michael Baden, the former New York City medical examiner and an expert witness for the defense, about the alleged victim's injuries.

title: Copper Surges as Stockpiles Show 21st Consecutive Drop
description: Copper prices surged yesterday as the 21st consecutive decline in stockpiles at the London Metal Exchange muted speculation that copper in unregistered Dutch warehouses would flood the market.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Uncivil War: South Bronx Vs. the North
description: THE audience inside the auditorium at Intermediate School 182 in the Bronx stood as one, faced the flag and, hands over hearts, intoned the Pledge of Allegiance. They were there for a community school board meeting, which for the uninitiated probably conjures up images of discourse in the public square and democracy in action.

title: It Just Keeps On Sinking, And Sinking and Sinking
description: The Freddy Krueger of ocean liners, the Titanic is the ship that won't stay sunk. We are now in the early stages of an epidemic of Titanic tales, including a Broadway musical promised for spring (will the iceberg sing?) and a monster Hollywood movie in the works, directed by James Cameron of ''Terminator'' fame. But the first fictional versions were turning up almost before the survivors were dry. As Steven Biel notes in his new book, ''Down with the Old Canoe: A Cultural History of the Titanic Disaster,'' an actress named Dorothy Gibson survived the shipwreck and starred in a movie version with a tacked-on romantic subplot a month after the ship smashed into the killer iceberg in April 1912. From the start, if the word Titanic has spelled doom, it has also spelled disaster movie.

title: Honda Net Gains Almost 300% In Half-Year as U.S. Sales Surge
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that its earnings soared almost 300 percent in the fiscal first half of the year as sales, particularly in the United States, rose strongly.

title: Ending Dialogue, Ruling Mexican Party Dilutes Reforms
description: The political party that has long dominated Mexico has broken off nearly two years of talks with the opposition on broad electoral reforms and used its legislative majority to impose its own limited reform.

title: Why We Are Rude
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Oklahoma City Trial Set

title: Car Is Stolen With Baby in It, But Nightmare Ends Happily
description: Just after 8 P.M. on Thursday, Tiffany Winfield stepped out of her car, leaving the motor running and the doors unlocked, and went into a strip mall restaurant in Burlington Township, N.J., for a takeout order. Snuggled in an infant seat in the back, her 11-month-old daughter, Jasmine, slept cozily, the picture of serenity in her pink snowsuit with green trim and fur-lined hood.

title: Sprint Showdown
description: DONOVAN BAILEY of Canada, the Olympic gold medalist and world record-holder at 100 meters, and MICHAEL JOHNSON of Dallas, the Olympic champion and world record-holder at 200 meters, will be in Toronto on Tuesday to announce their much anticipated head-to-head 150-meter race.

title: Dollar Off vs. Yen as Traders Doubt Commitment to Strength
description: The dollar fell yesterday against the yen, touching a seven-week low, amid lingering doubts that Japan and the United States were committed to a stronger dollar. It was little changed against other major currencies.

title: HANK WILLIAMS. GARTH BROOKS. BR5-49?
description: New York is the last major radio market in the nation not to have a country-music station. As New Yorkers who are, despite the handicaps, country-music fans, we have a few observations on your article.

title: Why Corporate America Needs Strong Accounting Standards
description: A MAJOR reason that America's financial markets are the fairest and most efficient in the world is that our financial disclosure system is the most comprehensive and reliable in the world.

title: Where Toys Need Not Inspire Any Fear
description: A GROUP of veterans and a group of medical students in New Haven have joined forces to promote nonviolent, creative toys, hoping to discourage those that mimic war and glorify personal aggression.

title: Penn State Sets Back Michigan With Defense and Special Effort
description: On an afternoon when Penn State's offense seemed unable to find its way into the end zone, the special teams provided a timely alternate route in a scruffy 29-17 victory over Michigan.

title: Cheers for Cozza
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE KINDEST CUT
