description: Just when I thought I'd read all I ever wanted to read about breast cancer, along comes Melissa Bloch's upbeat Lives column ''The Kindest Cut'' (Oct. 6), demonstrating that creative thinking in the face of misfortune can help us reshape our lives, with renewed vitality.

title: Any Novel Can Be Shaped Into a Movie
description: MICHAEL ONDAATJE'S novel ''The English Patient'' is rich with poetic language, its narratives-within-narratives mirroring the layers of identity the book explores. While Hana, a young Canadian nurse, cares for a severely burned patient in a deserted Tuscan villa at the end of World War II, we gradually learn her life story. And we also hear the patient's story as he tells it to Hana, his fragmented memories surfacing slowly. ''He remembers picnics, a woman who kissed parts of his body that now are burned into the color of aubergine,'' Mr. Ondaatje writes.

title: The United States of Andy
description: IN RETROSPECT, ANdy Warhol's 1985 appearance on ''The Love Boat'' must now be seen as an emblematic event: one of those epochal moments that point to the direction our culture has taken as it slouches its way toward the millennium.

title: Free Events Proliferate As Holidays Approach
description: WITH holiday budget balancing on the near horizon, it is nice to find a number of free concerts available. Today at 2:30 P.M. , for instance, the cellist Arthur Cook and the pianist Deborah Gilwood bring works by Beethoven, Brahms and Villa-Lobos to the Warner Library in North Tarrytown. Today at 3 the Bronx Symphony Orchestra plays Tchaikovsky, Rossini, Paganini and Saint Saens at Columbus High School at 925 Astor Avenue near Pelham Parkway in the Bronx. That program, conducted by Darin Lewis and featuring the violinist Ilya Lehman, will be repeated next Sunday at 3 in the auditorium of the Bronx High School of Science. For driving directions, the number to call is (718) 601-9151.

title: Welfare And the Working Poor
description: PROFITS may be surging on Wall Street, giving a nudge to the once-torpid economy of New York State, but the recovery hasn't yet turned into bountiful opportunities for would-be burger-flippers or cashiers. So when Gov. George E. Pataki of New York unveiled his plan last week for scaling back welfare to comply with a new Federal law, he also drew attention to a new national conflict: When welfare recipients start looking for jobs to replace their shrinking welfare benefits, they will be competing with the working poor, who are barely surviving on what they make now.

title: Ms. Steinberg And Mr. Lange
description: Elizabeth Steinberg, a daughter of Kathryn Steinberg and Robert M. Steinberg, both of New York, was married last evening to Jeffrey Scott Lange, the son of Linda Lange and Jack Lange, both of Los Angeles. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Ready. Aim. Start Bonding! Corporate Lessons in Guns
description: ON a hilltop skeet range in upstate New York, 12-gauge in hand, Russ Krull had hit target after target -- and had yet to fire a single shot.

title: Maribeth Colton, Julian Z. Nickell
description: Maribeth Diann Colton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Phillips Colton of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Julian Zapple Nickell, the son of Margit Aramburu of Tiburon, Calif., and Walter W. Nickell of Palo Alto, Calif. The Rev. Charles Maher officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Providence.

title: Karma Chameleons
description: THE LAW OF LOVE

title: They're Like Nasdaq, and Coming to Europe
description: A new breed of stock exchange that specializes in small companies is springing up in Europe.

title: A Gala Time Had by All
description: The Urban League, City Opera, Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, Historic Hudson Valley and Gilda's Club benefit, and Lena Horne is saluted.

title: Tania Isenstein And James Berger
description: Tania Beth Isenstein, a vice president in the employee relations department at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, was married last evening to James Evan Berger, the general counsel in the Mayor's Office of City Legislative Affairs. Cantor Ramon Gilbert officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: The Nazi Question Is a Side Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Collecting Books, and Writers, Too
description: HERMAN A. ESTRIN, universally known as Doc, is the evangelist of New Jersey writers and the state's champion of elegant technological writing. For precisely half a century, he has taught English at New Jersey Institute of Technology here. And he singlehandedly put together New Jersey Literary Hall of Fame.

title: Debra E. Corrodi, C.S. Foster 2d
description: Debra Ellen Corrodi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Corrodi of Radnor, Pa., was married yesterday to Charles Saunders Foster 2d, a son of Louise G. Poer of Atlanta and C. Allen Foster of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Dr. George E. Hollingshead performed the ceremony at Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: One of the interesting questions that often arises in discussions about the quality of education is, How accurate are the tests that indicate the quality of education is declining? The multiple-choice test on your cover demonstrates the importance of examining the tests not only for biases but also for plain old accuracy. Question No. 5 gives three choices for the meaning of the phrase ''to veto a bill'': a) pass it, b) withdraw it or c) refuse to sign it. The key to the answers said that ''c'' is the correct choice; among the choices, it is closest to the correct one. The right answer, however, should be ''to return the bill unsigned to the legislature (in a timely manner).'' Merely refusing to sign a bill can result in its enactment.

title: In Race Against Death, A Raceway Plays a Part
description: ELMSFORD RACEWAY here has become almost a mandatory stop for some children who are, in effect, racing against death. So says Luis Del Rosario, owner with his wife, Barbara, of the model-car racing center on North Saw Mill River Road. As a member of the Elmsford Rotary, Mr. Del Rosario has helped raise money to bring children from foreign countries to the United States for delicate, lifesaving heart surgery they could not get at home, either because of lack of money or lack of medical expertise.

title: Once Again, the Hoffa Name Rouses the Teamsters' Union
description: It was 10 below zero in the frozen-food warehouse, and suddenly the whirring of the forklifts stopped as bundled-up workers rushed over to meet James P. Hoffa and hear him vow to restore the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to the greatness it had under his fabled father.

title: President Clinton on Riady
description: For weeks, the White House has been saying that all those visits to the White House by James Riady, the Indonesian financier and Democratic contributor, were ''social.'' Actually, President Clinton said in an interview with The New York Times, he talked about policy issues with him twice -- once when Mr. Riady wanted Mr. Clinton to see President Suharto of Indonesia, and more recently when the billionaire praised America's engagement with China and said it needed to do even more.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Americans No More

title: Couples Wary on Same Sex Adoptions
description: CARRYING a suitcase containing 45 pounds of Earth's Best baby food, a portable crib and seven pieces of luggage, the Pavlon-Blum family took off last summer for a five-week trip to Europe. The baby food was to insure 5-month-old Ethan would eat right, and the crib would give him the comfort of the same bed every night.

title: A Mainstay With Vibrant Italian Food
description: THE most enthusiastic eater I know adores Giulio Cesare. He is a man who talks, cooks and savours food with gusto and this is his favorite Long Island restaurant. He often wondered aloud why I had never been to this 25-year-old Westbury mainstay.

title: Show of Quilts Fills Walls of the Neuberger
description: THE warmth and color of 28 contemporary quilts at the Neuberger Museum here afford a respite from the grayness of short November days. Filling the walls of three galleries, the quilts by 19 artists were culled from more than 1,000 in the collection of Ardis and Robert James. The Jameses, who live in Chappaqua, have been collecting since the emergence of the contemporary quilt movement in the 1970's.

title: Blaming the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Pizza in Darien, Pizza in New Canaan
description: THE Gates-Centro-Tequila Mocking Bird culinary empire rolls on. The newest enterprise of the seven-restaurant mini-conglomerate is Centro Ristorante and Bar in Darien. Situated in the long, two-level, rail-separated space formerly occupied by Bugbee & Brownell, the newest Centro shows some semblance of the same decorating flair as the earlier, wittier versions in Fairfield and Greenwich. A long expanse of wall near the entrance is engagingly painted with a mouth-watering still life, and the ceiling resembles a blue sky dotted with clouds and jubilant angels.

title: The China We Left Behind
description: AS A CHILD IN SUNNYVALE, CALIF., Mark Leong used to dread the occasional visits of Fong Quong Zong, or Gon Gon, as he called his grandfather. The whole family would go to San Francisco's Chinatown for exotic Chinese meals that tasted awful and spend hours with relatives who spoke the incomprehensible dialect of Toisan County in southern China -- the area Gon Gon left in 1923 to seek his fortune in Chicago.

title: DIARY
description: DOWNSIZING

title: Penguins Still the Cure For the Ailing Rangers
description: If only the Rangers could play the Pittsburgh Penguins more often they might not be struggling to rise from the depths of the Atlantic Division, the Eastern Conference and the entire National Hockey League. Their coach's job security might not be a subject of open debate. The age of the team, its high payroll and its motivation might not be so criticized so often.

title: A Free-Speech Right to Arts Funds? No Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope
description: TWENTY years ago the joke went, ''A tornado hit Camden and did $10 million worth of improvement.'' In 1990, a tornado did touch down in North Camden, but only those of us who live here could tell outsiders what it had destroyed. The abandoned houses untouched by the twister were identical to those that had been damaged.

title: Those 403(b) Blues Fade at Nonprofits
description: JANE D. SCHWARTZ was excited when she learned that the Federal Government had authorized a new kind of plan for her retirement investing. ''I think our investment choices are too conservative now,'' she said. ''I haven't been able to take full advantage of the bull market.''

title: The Dos and Don'ts of Bipartisanship
description: When John F. Kennedy won the White House in 1960 with 49.7 percent of the vote, he wisely reached out and appointed Republicans to head the Treasury and Defense Departments, the National Security Council and the Central Intelligence Agency. Not since Franklin D. Roosevelt had leaders of the other party served in such critical positions, but Kennedy knew he needed fortification in two areas where he felt vulnerable: high finance and national security.

title: As Old Offices Languish, the New in Newark Lease
description: IT was once a prestigious corporate address in downtown Newark. But in the last five years, as the operator's lease wound down, there was a marked decline in capital investment in the classic, 1930's office tower at 744 Broad Street, leading tenants to move out and more than doubling the building's vacancy rate to about 70 percent, brokers and the owner say.

title: A Master Awaiting Acclaim
description: ONE OF A CRITIC'S MOST irksome and unrewarding duties is continually having to bemoan the unjust neglect of one contemporary composer or another. The reader must reasonably surmise that the neglect is often just, the composer's music so hellishly boring that no one wants to sit through it. Yet in the case of Hans Werner Henze, none of that is true. Honest.

title: HANK WILLIAMS. GARTH BROOKS. BR5-49?
description: Nashville has long rejected artists who not only revere country's roots but who also have a gift for making the music relevant. Remember how warmly Nashville embraced K. D. Lang, whose sweet country crooning makes me want to grow up to be a cowgirl?

title: A Rock in the Dark
description: I woke to the tinkle of falling glass; I was up and pulling on my robe even as it fell. ''There's an accident,'' I mumbled, running barefoot down the stairs.

title: Double Dealing
description: Under Robert Siodmak's taut moody directio, everything clicks in the colorful pulpy crime melodrama CRISS CROSS (1949), about an armored car robbery and its aftermath. But Burt Lancaster (pictured) as the doomed protagonist and Yvonne De Carlo as his cunning exwife are expert as are Dan Duryea, Stephen McNally and a half dozen others. The plot is unsurprising but the pace is brisk, and the picture looks stylishly designed. It makes a consistently enticing eyeful. WEDNESDAY at 9:30 A.M. on AMC.

title: Frank Morrell, 70, Expert on Epilepsy
description: Frank Morrell, Armour Presidential Professor of Neurological Sciences at Rush Medical College in Chicago and founder of the Rush Epilepsy Center, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Chicago. He was 70.

title: Campaigning at the U.N.
description: Anticipating the start of a Security Council debate this week on who will be the next Secretary General of the United Nations, Egypt last week nominated the incumbent, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, its favorite son. The Clinton Administration wants a quick vote so it can veto his reelection. Administration officials say that he took too long to get reforms moving -- and anyway he once said he would serve only one term. (Every Secretary General has had two).

title: An Opposing View On Learning to Read
description: I read Charles Richardson's Oct. 20 letter in which he responded to the Sept. 29 article "Will All Pupils on Long Island Read by the Third Grade?"

title: Yes, There Is a Double Standard
description: Three years ago, as a Marine Corps recruiter, I faced a difficult decision. During my interviews with a woman seeking admission to Officer Candidates School, she was combative and defensive. Then she insulted a drill instructor, a punishable offense in the military. By any measure, this performance should have disqualified her from consideration.

title: HANK WILLIAMS. GARTH BROOKS. BR5-49?
description: I read Peter Applebome's article ''Hank Williams. Garth Brooks. BR5-49?'' (Oct. 27) and thought, How ironic. The New York Times's hometown no longer has a country-music radio station. WYNY 103.5 FM's country-music format was supplanted by disco early this year.

title: Women Who Lead
description: To the Editor:

title: Salinger the Crash Theorist Raises More Eyebrows Than New Questions
description: A Boeing 747 had exploded and crashed. Hundreds had died. The tragedy was cloaked in mystery.

title: The Eye of the Artist on Other Artists
description: RED GROOMS is the reigning humorist in American art. His art can be described as knowingly naive or sophisticated, and it is the latter quality that is on view at the New Britain Museum of American Art. Mr. Grooms's ''Personal Art History'' is a host of constructions, drawings, paintings and prints that comment on art and well-known artists contemporary and historical. To appreciate the exhibition fully, viewers need to have some art history under their belts.

title: Worst Fighting in Bosnia Since U.S. Troops Arrived
description: Americans soldiers in Bosnia were caught near a fire fight last week between Muslims refugees and Serbs around the village of Gajevi.They were then attacked by a Muslim mob for confiscating weapons and ammunition.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: The issues raised by Mosle were all too familiar to me, a British teacher living in America. Ten years ago, we witnessed the introduction of the National Curriculum in Britain, despite the opposition of unions, some politicians and many in the academic community. Our curriculum has undergone some changes, but the outcome is that the quality of teaching has improved. Standards are better. All those in the system now know what is expected of them.

title: For Juries, the Truth vs. the Whole Truth
description: OUTSIDE of court, some people said Alex Kelly smirked on television. Some were willing to bet that the jury would convict him in minutes on the charge that he raped a 16-year-old girl in Darien a decade ago.

title: The Lives It Costs to Save Lives
description: AT first, anything that improved the crashworthiness of a car was good for everybody: shatter-proof windshields, padded dashboards, crumple zones and the like. Then came the air bag.

title: A Company Defies All Labels
description: IN its four seasons, Luna Stage has suffered the slings and arrows of mistaken identity.

title: Bronx Man Is Arrested in Shooting at Firehouse
description: A Bronx man has been arrested for firing a high-powered shotgun into a city firehouse two months ago, the police said yesterday.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: Mosle's article calling for national education standards is swimming against an overwhelming tide of three decades of education ''reform'' that has brought about mediocrity in public education.

title: Turning a Bad Beating on L.I. Into a Movie
description: A FEW days before the shaving cream and eggs went flying on Wincott Drive, Mark Schiffer recalled another Halloween on that Melville street eight years ago.

title: Stores and Cars: A Dubious Model of Change and Growth
description: Imagine that it is 1976, the year of the Bicentennial, the year the Oldsmobile Cutlass was America's best-selling car. Say you are driving up Route 17, approaching the Route 4 interchange. There are two lanes of traffic in either direction, separated by a grass median. There are mom-and-pop stores galore. Gas station after gas station. Woods in the distance.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column in the Styles pages last Sunday with a report about the National Book Foundation's awards dinner misstated the surname of the husband of the fiction winner, Andrea Barrett. He is Barry M. Goldstein, not Barrett.

title: We Interrupt This Ad for Our Stock Symbol
description: IS it a portent of a stock market top? A few companies are putting their stock symbols in their ads, alongside the messages that push their products and polish their images.

title: Up the Social Ladder With Barbara Walters
description: AT Mortimer's or Daniel's by day, a benefit for the New York Public Library or the Historical Society by night -- wherever socialites assemble, it seems -- there is Barbara Walters. A driven professional and arguably America's best-known television personality, Ms. Walters seems to be relishing a parallel new career as a society leader.

title: Children and S.S.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE PROMISE OF REST

title: In a South Carolina Town, a Klan Museum Opens Old Wounds
description: For decades, a piece of rotted rope dangled from a railroad trestle just outside this little town, a reminder of the last lynching in Laurens County. It was back in 1913, but people still talk of the black man wrongly accused of rape, and the white mob that hanged him.

title: John R. Border, 70, Specialist In Saving Lives After Traumas
description: John R. Border, a trauma specialist at the State University of New York at Buffalo whose groundbreaking work helped prevent fatal organ failure after surgery for severe injury, died on Monday at his home in suburban South Wales, N.Y.. He was 70.

title: The Really, Really Big Sound
description: TWICE a day, our house shakes and a deep rumbling sound rattles the windows. This is the closest thing to an earthquake we ever feel on Long Island. But no need to panic. It is just one of the local teen-agers driving by in his sound system. Every year he packs louder and louder stereos into his old Camaro. Now it's little more than a pair of giant speakers on wheels.

title: Nicholas Nickleby and Smike, Together on Stage Once More
description: FIFTEEN YEARS AGO, Broadway theatergoers fell in love with two then-unknown English actors named Roger Rees and David Threlfall. They starred in ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the now-legendary Royal Shakespeare Company production based on the Dickens novel. The play was presented in two parts over eight-and-a-half hours, and a ticket to both halves cost $100.

title: Bugs and Michael Work the Fast Break
description: Set It Off

title: Watching Those Who Watch Fidelity
description: A reader writes:

title: Hell's Own Cookbook
description: In Memory's Kitchen

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Nov. 3 about development in the Manhattan Valley section referred incorrectly to one site, the August Aichorn Center for Adolescent Residential Care. It is privately run, not an annex to the Spofford Juvenile Detention Center. It opened in May 1991, not two years ago. It occupies two buildings, not three.

title: Mayor Apologizes
description: San Francisco Mayor WILLIE BROWN telephoned ELVIS GRBAC on Friday to apologize for calling the 49ers quarterback ''an embarrassment to humankind'' after his performance in the 49ers' 20-17 loss to Dallas last week.

title: Miller & Son
description: THE PHYSICAL RESEMBLANCE between Arthur Miller and his son, Robert, is striking. Both are tall and lanky, though Robert dresses like a California hippie and his father seems the epitome of the Connecticut Yankee. Like many children of celebrities, Robert has struggled for a long time to carve out his own professional identity. Now, at the age of 49, he has finally produced his first movie -- a film version of Arthur's 1953 play about the Salem witch trials, ''The Crucible,'' with a screenplay by the playwright.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday comparing the number of American voters with Americans in other categories referred incorrectly in some copies to the number who carry credit cards. The number, according to the Nilson Report, a California newsletter, is 111 million, not 111.

title: Breaking Out in a Rash of Rilke
description: YOU'RE SO BEAUTIFUL

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MAKER OF SAINTS

title: Bad Shots in the Spying Game
description: OH, for the cold war, when life was simpler, when spies and spycatchers played by unwritten rules as formal as the structure of a sonnet. Their lives today are more like free verse, famously defined by Robert Frost as playing tennis without a net.

title: Value Warriors
description: JOYCELYN ELDERS, M.D.

title: The Past Is Dead in Asbury Park, but the Future Is Arriving
description: The cold wind whipped an old newspaper like a tumbleweed down the deserted boardwalk. It whistled past rusty girders in a condominium tower that has been frozen for years in mid-construction.

title: The Accidental Violist
description: PERHAPS STARDOM IS AS much preordained as painstakingly achieved. A few artists are born with the talent and charisma needed to capture the imagination of the public. Only the means by which they will win fame remains to be determined.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Aaron Copland's house in Cortlandt misidentified the composer who contracted Alzheimer's disease after being photographed. It was Copland, not Leonard Bernstein.

title: Decency and Civility Taught on a Deadline
description: To the Editor:

title: Women in Sports Still an Issue . . .
description: SEVERAL hundred athletes gathered at Marymount College here recently to discuss the role of sports in their lives. The audience, made up of girls from 26 different high schools in the county, had some questions. Among them were these:

title: City Streets Offer No Place for Cyclists
description: The death of Rosemarie Brodie, a bicyclist, on York Avenue leaves me disgusted by the city's response (''The Perils of City Cycling,'' Nov. 3).

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: It is neither the structure of a school nor the specific curriculum students work with that determines whether children are well educated or not. The one thing that really matters is good teachers. Anyone who has had more than one of them knows that great teachers can vary widely in what they teach and how they teach it. Strict or not strict, memorization or analysis, projects or papers, Russian Revolution or Aztec architecture, you may well forget content and pedagogical style. But the experience of working with that teacher remains.

title: New Britain Tries to Cope With Drug Traffickers
description: DAWN broke over the Mount Pleasant housing development in New Britain as the police teams swept through. A few minutes earlier, more than 50 state and city police officers had entered three apartments, searching for people wanted on drug charges. Now, with a half-dozen suspects locked away in a confinement van, investigators were combing through hallways and alleys, hunting for stragglers.

title: Shift in Manhattan Valley Disturbs Some Residents
description: As a resident of Manhattan Valley I resent the focus of your article ''SoHa Loses Blight, Gains Acronym'' (Nov. 3).

title: In Days of Old, Recyclers Were Bold and Banded Together
description: The Americans of Bob Dole's youth, that hardy race of can-doers who cared about their neighbors and pitched in together in times of crisis, had nothing on the first generation of New Jersey recyclers.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THIS NOBLE LAND

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Deadline Looms on Inspections
description: LOCAL LAW 10, passed in New York City in 1980, requires owners of buildings higher than six stories to inspect them once every five years to insure that the facades are structurally safe. The next deadline is Feb. 21 -- and ''there's a lot of last-minute scrambling going on,'' said Alan S. Epstein, president of A. Epstein & Associates, a Manhattan engineering consulting company. ''It's shocking, but there are a lot of buildings out there that haven't even had their inspections done.''

title: Late Flurry By Devils Turns Back Lightning
description: Hockey coaches, hoping to inspire their teams, often change goaltenders when trailing by two goals or more going into the third period. Jacques Lemaire's decision to insert Mike Dunham in place of Martin Brodeur this afternoon made the coach of the Devils look like a genius.

title: Dartmouth Wins the Ivy League With 11 Yards to Spare
description: Brown extended Dartmouth to the last play, one that ended 11 yards short of the Green goal, in the game for the Ivy League championship today. Jason McCullough's last pass for Brown, to tight end Paul Choquette, gained 18 yards, but then the final whistle sounded. Dartmouth had won, 27-24.

title: Sabbath Dinners That Break Bread, And the Ice
description: Last year, when 100 of the city's literary elite opened their doors to tables full of strangers for the ''Table of Contents'' dinners to benefit the New York Public Library, the gossip columnists and paparazzi were out in force. Last Friday night, when some 185 Jewish families did the same, but for a different cause -- to promote Judaism among the 2,000 young Jewish singles and married couples who attended -- the scene was much quieter, but no less intense.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'CRYPTOGRAM' OPENS

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: A Sinatra Fan Gets His Turn As a Celebrity
description: ED SHIRAK took in a slow breath. The phone was ringing again. No surprise, it was a reporter again, this time for one of the local papers. ''I'll call you back,'' Mr. Shirak promised, his face flushed. He tried to sound cheery, but couldn't quite pull it off.

title: New Flights to Florida And in the West
description: Carnival and America West are adding flights to Florida, and Delta recently began service between Phoenix and Los Angeles.

title: BENEFITS
description: Regards to Broadway

title: The Baron of Red Hook
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Gregory O'Connell was a police detective assigned to the First Precinct in the Wall Street area, tracking everyone, he said, ''from bums in the street to the most sophisticated white-collar criminal.''

title: Sacramento Adds A Waterfront Market
description: A public market opened in the heart of the Old Sacramento historic district in September.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: On the Trail

title: Lili S. Sugita and Craig H. Foster
description: Lili Sawayanagi Sugita, a production coordinator for television commercials in New York, was married yesterday to Craig Hugh Foster, a managing director in fixed income trading at CS First Boston, the New York investment bank. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the New-York Historical Society.

title: . . . While Men Of Philosophy Market Pillows
description: There was a time when Stephan Shaw couldn't even find work flipping burgers at a fast-food restaurant. Perhaps the recession was to blame. Perhaps it was because he was a philosophy major.

title: Dolphin Encounters At a Bermuda Resort
description: Bermuda-bound travelers who are looking for something beyond golf, tennis and beachcombing may want to consider a new feature at the Southampton Princess resort: dolphin encounters.

title: Confronting High Birth Rate For Teen-Agers
description: TAKIMA GONZALEZ, a high school senior here, grew up long before she wanted to. For her, turning Sweet 16 had less to do with parties and pretty dresses than it did with a baby daughter called Shy-Nel and a boyfriend who was a father in name only. Instead of dreaming as other young women often do about college and a family someday in the future, this young woman struggles in the present to balance motherhood and schoolwork and loneliness.

title: For Clinton, a Rest in Hawaii on Way to Economic Talks in East
description: Stealing a brief respite before the first foreign trip since his election to a second term, President Clinton arrived in Hawaii Friday night, hoping to gird himself with a weekend of relaxation for state visits to Australia and Thailand and for an Asian-Pacific economic conference in the Philippines.

title: Spoils to the Victors, Grudgingly
description: Things were not all they appeared to be on the lovey-dovey Yankees this year. Despite the impression that the World Series champions were a hotbed of chemistry and camaraderie, a contrary feeling existed in some areas of the clubhouse. The negative aspect of the atmosphere didn't undermine the team's winning effort, but it emerged in the players' voting for post-season shares.

title: The Big Man Can Deal
description: MICHAEL JORDAN, DRESSED IMPECCABLY in a gray suit, royal blue polo sweater, no socks and two-tone loafers, is sprawled elegantly in a chair at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan. He appears to be back-lit -- he has that movie-star glow. The usual all-pro assortment of people (trainer, friend from college, family member, Ahmad Rashad) are milling about, and David Falk has just arrived. Falk is Jordan's agent, as well as the agent for Juwan Howard, Patrick Ewing, Alonzo Mourning and a dozen other National Basketball Association stars, including the latest college sensation to enter the pros before finishing college, the 76ers' Allen Iverson. Falk, 46, is tall, though not N.B.A. tall, and looks like some sort of very determined bird. He seems to be concentrating -- surveying the terrain, considering the options. ''I went over to see my best friend this morning,'' Falk says.

title: The Texaco Iceberg
description: Small wonder that Texaco settled its race-discrimination suit on Friday. It was really the old tip-of-the-iceberg story, with a twist: the tip may have been an illusion, but that doesn't mean there wasn't one heck of an iceberg underneath. For Texaco, the icy tip was a report of racial slurs caught on tape. Texaco quickly said those tapes were flawed -- that ''niggers'' was really ''St. Nicholas.'' But people quickly looked at the rest of the tapes -- and a company that despite its equal-opportunity pronouncements was almost lily white. No apologies rumbling down from the executive suite could change Texaco's employment statistics, and civil-rights leaders like the Rev. Jesse Jackson started calling for a national boycott.

title: All About Control
description: To the Editor:

title: A California University Opens Dorm for the Business-Minded
description: Although Kai Zhu, a 20-year-old student at the California Institute of Technology, is majoring in physics, he says he could see himself having a career as a businessman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Music On Their Minds
description: WE KNOW THE FEELING: ALL THE notes are there, perfectly played; the tempo seems right; each phrase is properly articulated; all dynamic markings are strictly adhered to. And the music is dead.

title: Washington Spiffs Up Its Airports
description: The nation's capital is served by two major airports, one charmingly antique but inadequate, the other just inadequate. But both are in the midst of major improvement projects, at a combined cost of $2 billion.

title: Company Loses Bid On Huge Contract For The Pentagon
description: Narrowing a hotly contested battle to build a one-size-fits-all combat aircraft for the Navy, the Air Force and the Marines, the Pentagon yesterday eliminated the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the contender that had the most to lose from being cut.

title: Manhattan Vs. Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: For Spacious Skies
description: HOME FROM NOWHERE

title: Airport Security
description: To the Editor: I am appalled by the lack of security at Newark Airport.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BENEFIT SEMINAR

title: Groomed for a Seat on a Nonprofit Board
description: TOM WILKINS was a little hesitant when he found out he had been accepted into Project Blueprint, a program run by the United Way of Eastern Fairfield County that is dedicated to training minority leaders how to be effective board members of nonprofit organizations in the Bridgeport area.

title: Geralyn Lederman, Geoffrey Schmalz
description: Geralyn Sylvie Lederman, a daughter of Roslyn Lederman of New York and the late Murray Lederman, was married last evening to Dr. Geoffrey Chaucer Robert Schmalz, a son of Marcia Seal of Sayreville, N.J., and George Schmalz of Akron, Ohio. Cantor Robert Abelson performed the ceremony at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: Surviving in a Tough Business, and Doing So With Panache
description: IF his hair weren't so white and his accent lush and foreign, the man greeting us at the entrance to Fromagerie might not get away with his little joke about the composition of our party. (We are three women and one man, wink, wink.) But I think Markus Peter could say anything and I would entrust myself to his care for an evening.

title: For Third Quarter of '96, a Housing-Closing Record
description: WESTCHESTER real estate offices reported a record 2,572 closings during the third quarter of this year, a 17 percent increase over the previous high of 2,205 set in the third quarter of 1994.

title: Despite Pact, Croats Find Ways to Bar Serb Exiles
description: Dana Dukic appeared at the city hall in the Croatian town of Zadar a few days ago, dropped his new blue Croatian passport on the desk of a city official and said that after five years in exile he was ready to return home.

title: Adding Storage Space Around the Home by Installing Shelves
description: ONE way to add storage space to your home is by installing shelves on vacant wall space. Wall-mounted shelves are simple -- they consist of the shelf itself and a few pieces of hardware like as wall brackets, or vertical standards, and brackets. They are cheaper than bookcases, but, depending upon your wall structure, they may not be able to support heavy weight.

title: A Niche in Mount Kisco for Spanish Food
description: THIS hideaway on a hill overlooking busy Mount Kisco has been pleasing diners with tasty contemporary Spanish cuisine for the past dozen years. The cozy, low-ceilinged dining areas -- some with fireplaces -- are a tad out of plumb, the way simple, older Colonials are wont to be, and the decor, while attractive enough, would not make the pages of architects' magazines.

title: Tyson's Story Could Have More Chapters
description: Mike Tyson's life has become the rap opera of our time, grit and juice, as much a window on race and celebrity as the trials of O. J. Simpson or Muhammad Ali's journey from ridicule to beatification. Don't count out Tyson quite yet; if he doesn't find a way to self-destruct in the next few weeks, he may yet find a way to reinvent himself. That he has survived this long is more of an upset than Evander Holyfield's technical knockout.

title: Rebecca Carda And Iain D. Leigh
description: Rebecca Joy Carda, a classical pianist, and Iain Dennis Leigh, an investment banker, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Walter Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE COURTS OF LOVE

title: Raymond Is Loved. What's Not to Love?
description: ''EVERYBODY loves Raymond,'' says Robert, a droopy 40-year-old 6-foot-8-inch, 270-pound police sergeant who lives with his parents. ''I go to work and people shoot at me. Ray goes to work and people do the wave.''

title: Ramp Is Closed Where Boys Were Drowned
description: The boat ramp at the lake where a South Carolina woman drowned her two sons in 1994 will close and monuments to the boys will be moved because of safety recommendations adopted by a state agency on Friday.

title: Hlasek Retires
description: JAKOB HLASEK, 32, announced his retirement from competitive tennis last week, saying ''it was time to turn the page.'' Hlasek won 5 singles titles, 20 in doubles and just over $5.5 million in a career that spanned 14 years. (Reuters)

title: Solid Comfort, in Distinct Enclaves
description: TWO contrasting aspects of Port Washington strike a visitor to this North Shore Long Island area notable for its extensive waterfront, top schools, easy commute to the city and strong sense of place.

title: Conflict In The West
description: THE COMANCHEROS (1961), THURSDAY at 8 P.M. on TNT, is a wild and woolly caper about a Texas Ranger and his gambler prisoner who join forces as sense and sensibility are cheerfully tossed to the wind with captivating results. The title refers to a band of white renegades including John Wayne (pictured), Lee Marvin, Stuart Whitman and Nehemiah Persoff. Ina Balin adds a touch of beauty to this strenuous fun. Directed by a free-wheeling Michael Curtiz.

title: Deductions Coming For Long-Term Care
description: LOOKING to a future where far more people will require long-term care, the Government is beginning to encourage Americans to pay for it themselves. The carrot being offered is a tax deduction for individuals and employers on the purchase of long-term-care insurance. The stick is criminal penalties for some people who, instead of financing their own long-term care, try to become eligible for Government-paid care by shifting assets to family members or trusts.

title: Irish Food, Fresh and Real
description: EVEN as I berated my Irish-born grandmother for the absence of spices and strong statements in her cooking, I began to suspect that she was operating on a higher plane than the practitioners of the more piquant cuisines I loved. But she held in contempt dishes designed to conceal inferior quality; for her the cook's job was merely to guide the best ingredients to the table in as near their natural state as possible. The secret of this approach lies, of course, in being able to recognize -- and obtain -- the perfect foods. On a recent trip to County Cork (reputedly one of the most interesting food areas in Ireland), I learned that this is what the so-called Irish cooking revolution is all about.

title: How a Stalled Submarine Sank North Korea's Hopes
description: Somewhere in the mountains near the gash of barbed wire and trenches that divides the Korean Peninsula, a single North Korean commando is thought to be hiding in the woods, trying to sneak back home again.

title: Iowa Fields Forever
description: DHARMA GIRL

title: Theatrical Ghosts Lose Haunt
description: To passers-by, the sight of construction workers at the Anderson Theater on East Fourth Street and Second Avenue is a testament to the East Village's growing fortunes as a magnet for developers. But for those old enough to remember, the scaffolding and other signs of demolition are painful reminders of a vanished world, when Second Avenue below 14th Street was the epicenter of Yiddish-American culture, home to a half-dozen theaters and a string of cafes and restaurants that bubbled until dawn with talk of theater, poetry and politics.

title: Edwin Friedman, 64; Led Workshops On Leadership
description: Edwin Howard Friedman, a family therapist and consultant on leadership who wrote and conducted workshops on those subjects, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 64.

title: Canada Likes the Peacekeeper's Mantle
description: AT a busy intersection in Ottawa, there is a sculpture of a radio operator, a watchman and an armed sentry standing atop walls that are split to symbolize irreconcilable differences. When the bronze and stone were placed above the traffic in 1992, Canada became the first nation to erect a monument to peacekeeping.

title: The Reinvented State
description: The drive from New Brunswick to Trenton -- something we do more often than we like to think about -- takes us down U.S. 1, a classic four-lane highway out of the 1930's.

title: Accord Must Be Possible On 23d Street Restaurant
description: Concerning your article ''Shuttered Restaurant May Return, With Smaller Footprint'' (Oct. 27), when I was younger, I would eat at this restaurant when it was called Pier 62. What I always remembered loving about the restaurant was that it always felt like an outdoor cafe. You could sit and eat in a warm climate while it was snowing outside. Or you could watch the sun scorching all the people while you were inside, cool and fine.

title: The City That Can Sub for All of America
description: TAKE A RIGHT AT the downtown train station and look for the worst neighborhood, the most desolate street, the filthiest garbage-strewn alley. This is as scary as it's going to get.

title: Angels With Attitude
description: It seems that there actually are angels in America -- not only on the Broadway stage, but in inner-city Detroit. And these aren't the wistful greeting-card cherub variety or the swirly seraphim found peeking from the inspirational-book racks. The winged humans in David Sosnowski's wry, dry first novel are angels with attitude. RAPTURE (Villard, $23) starts off with Zander Wiles, a small-time Motor City drug dealer who one day feels a strange itching and weeks later finds himself with a pair of nine-foot black wings growing out of his back and an increased magnetic field emanating from his chest cavity. Zander eventually heads for New York, gets himself an agent and becomes the first angel to go public. However, the angel epidemic is on the rise, as is public awareness. A college student named Cassie O'Connor cross-references her symptoms at the campus library to find that she might have ''the flu, food poisoning, AIDS or that new, weird one -- Angelism.'' The novel's allegorical structure allows Mr. Sosnowski to skewer the whole spectrum of modern culture as he chronicles a newly self-aware minority going through all the trials of joining a suspicious society. Congress encumbers them with legislation and religious pundits weakly rationalize their existence, but the Angels go on to gain that true pinnacle of acceptance -- their own mainstream marketing niche. The Feathered Nation soon has its own bars, movie theaters (featuring ''perch-style seating''), support groups, bumper stickers, pop slang and militant factions. As the book's plot kicks in, the alert reader will figure out that Zander's flight path is destined to cross with Cassie's, and the witty, arch angel banter they engage in as their romance unfolds is one of the book's greatest delights. J. D. Biersdorfer

title: Votes on Marijuana Are Stirring Debate
description: By approving initiatives to permit the use of marijuana for medical purposes, California and Arizona voters have touched off a nationwide battle between Americans who want to hold the line against illegal drugs and those who think it is time to challenge other longstanding prohibitions against drug use.

title: Blaming the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Loved and Hated, He Wants to Be Borough President
description: In the political caldron of the Lower East Side, where fire fights among anarchists, AIDS activists, Orthodox Jews and Puerto Ricans are common fare, the battle lines are not easy to decipher. But one division is always clear: those aligned with the district's combative Council member, Antonio Pagan, and those who despise him. ''When it comes to Antonio, there's no middle ground,'' said Adam Silvera, a Democratic district leader in the East Village.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Those Little Big Men: Nets Find a Way to Win
description: He did not waver. And he did not wince, either. Coach John Calipari came up with a lineup and stuck with it -- no matter what -- finding a way to deliver on his promise to the small but rowdy crowd gathered at Continental Arena tonight.

title: Mary T. Clark, James C. Vines 3d
description: Mary Thompson Clark, the daughter of Frances T. Clark of New Haven and John Phelps Clark of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to James Colvin Vines 3d, a son of Mary Vines-Long and J. C. Vines Jr., both of Montgomery, Ala. The Rev. Shepard A. Parsons, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Center Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: Liz Forker And T.R. Larsen
description: Helen Elizabeth Forker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Eugene Forker of Venice, Fla., was married yesterday to Thorvald Richard Larsen 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Larsen Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. John E. Halborg officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Latin King Leader, Another View
description: You recently published an article (''A Federal Prisoner States Her Case,'' Oct. 20) concerning Beatrice Codianni-Robles, a former high-ranking member of the Almighty Latin Charter Nation (the Latin Kings) who currently is serving a 210-month term of imprisonment in a Federal prison after pleading guilty to violating the RICO statute.

title: Adrienne Dix, Joshua Narrowe
description: Adrienne Beth Dix, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. Dix of Chappaqua, N.Y., is to be married today to Rabbi Joshua Avraham Narrowe, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Morton H. Narrowe of Stockholm. The bridegroom's father, the chief rabbi of Stockholm, is to perform the ceremony with Rabbi Zvi H. Friedlander at Lake Isle Country Club in Eastchester, N.Y.

title: Net Worth
description: HIGH LATITUDES

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: Until now, the search for a core curriculum has been beset by religious and political bickering. Standardized testing has already been under attack by equity advocates who feel that bad results mean discrimination. Making standardized testing national would be a legal nightmare.

title: Sign Here, And Make That for $2,500
description: WHAT The Waterman Signe Boucheron fountain pen, which has a translucent blue barrel, an 18-karat-gold cap and a list price of $2,500. Only 3,741 have been made. The number is the sum of the years in which the two companies that designed it were founded: Waterman, the French-based pen maker that is now owned by Gillette, in 1883, and Boucheron, the Parisian jeweler, in 1858.

title: Regine Traulsen, William J. Diamond
description: WHEN William J. Diamond describes the charms of Regine Traulsen, he tends to pull out his key ring for illustration. Among several regular-looking keys is a gold one with a large square top that catches the eye.

title: Dog and Man at Harvard
description: DOG LOVE

title: Swallowed Again and Again
description: THE FACULTY OF USELESS KNOWLEDGE

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: I suspect that a fan letter to an airline is pretty rare, but here goes.

title: Plenty of Pain and Gain
description: For months Evander Holyfield's sparring partners had been beating him up.

title: Alyssa B. Coller, Adam C. Shapiro
description: Alyssa Brook Coller, a daughter of Barbara and Dr. Barry S. Coller of New York, was married last evening to Adam Charles Shapiro, the son of Melissa Satterlee of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Philip Shapiro of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Hospitals' Use of Satellite Centers Is Growing
description: PATRICIA LIVIOLA does not plan to have her baby at a hospital. Instead, she plans a natural childbirth, attended by a nurse-midwife, at the Elizabeth Seton Childbirth Center at 222 West 14th Street.

title: Hidden and Unspoiled: Some Natural Gems in Rare Preserves
description: THERE are many natural wonders on Long Island, some of them so unspoiled for so long that they hardly get attention.

title: 2 Conjugal Shows of Striking Differences
description: A 25-YEAR retrospective by Edgar and Toby Buonagurio fills the Hostos Art Gallery here, and works by Robert Goodnough and his wife, Miko, are on view in the Museum Gallery of the White Plains Public Library.

title: First Eagle Fund of America
description: AS co-managers of the First Eagle Fund of America, Harold J. Levy and David L. Cohen describe themselves as value investors -- but not typical ones.

title: Panama Coffee Test
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disappointing 'Saturday Night Live'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Turn in the 'Asian Way'
description: A look at the numbers at this week's Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting in the Philippines provides the latest indication that Asian political leaders need not control their citizens so markets can be free. The new growth statistics challenge a familiar argument made by several Asian rulers that political freedom hurts economic growth and, more broadly, is alien to Asian values.

title: For Lawyers, A.A.R.P.'s Seal
description: SHOULD you find a lawyer the same way you would a plumber? The American Association of Retired Persons is hoping to persuade its members to give it a try.

title: Police Arrest Man In Beating Death Of 3-Year-Old Boy
description: A Brooklyn man has been charged with murder in the beating death of his girlfriend's 3-year-old son, the police said yesterday.

title: Arbitration Rules Would Give Some, Take Some
description: INVESTORS who are abused by their stockbrokers face new limits on the amount of money they can get for egregious misbehavior under rules adopted on Friday by the regulatory arm of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: John Cummings, 60, Veterinary Professor
description: John Francis Cummings, the James Law Professor of Veterinary Medicine at the College of Veterinary Medicine of Cornell University, died on Nov. 3 in Tenafly, N.J. He was 60 and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Cherishing the Memory of Nikolais, but Moving On
description: AS A BOY GROWING UP IN a Brooklyn orphanage during the Depression, Murray Louis dreamed of becoming a doctor or a chemist; he craved certainty. When the nomenclature of bones and the taxonomy of elements eluded his grasp, he opted for a career as a dancer and choreographer. Yet even after creating 100 works for the stage, Mr. Louis still thinks of himself as a scientist. Like the choreographer Alwin Nikolais, he believes that dance should be about ''motion, not emotion.''

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about films with lesbian heroines misstated the surname of the director of ''All Over Me,'' which is to be released in March. She is Alex Sichel, not Fichel.

title: Chocolate Sells
description: To the Editor:

title: Beach Assets
description: EACH year for the past 18, I have walked the New Jersey coastline from Cape May to Sandy Hook, visiting every town along the coast and talking to people about their lives. I have enjoyed days of cloudless blue skies, when the beaches were crowded with visitors from Manalapan to Montreal. I have seen storms come in over the Atlantic that forced a retreat from nature's threat, and I have seen man's own threat in 1986 and 1987 when medical waste and debris washed up on shore and polluted our water, forcing many beaches to close.

title: BIBLE DISCUSSION GROUP
description: I was fascinated by Kamenetz's article. The novelist Nessa Rapoport is quoted as saying: ''The Christians were so quiet and the Jews were so verbal, it was hilarious. But I think the Christians were exhilarated by the Jewish freedom of reading.'' Perhaps. But perhaps that's a projection. Maybe they were thinking, Christopher Lasch was right. This is truly the age of narcissism.

title: This Bud's Not for You, Or Baseball
description: IF he were a batter, he would be hitting .050. If he were a pitcher, his record would be 1-10. If he were a manager, his team would be adrift in last place.

title: In Living Cardboard
description: ''There has never been anyone like Elvis Presley in the history of recorded music.'' So begins Paul Dowling's introduction to his ELVIS: The Ultimate Album Cover Book (Abrams, $24.95), and the author's enthusiasm builds from there. Spare on text, the book is essentially a catalogue of 226 album covers, courtesy of Mr. Dowling, who claims the largest Presley record collection in the world. These covers illustrate the evolution of Presley from beautiful androgynous pop icon to scary lounge lizard. Mr. Dowling serves up tiny snippets of the arcane about the covers, like the fact that the gold lame suit Elvis wore on the cover of 1959's ''50,000,000 Elvis Fans Can't Be Wrong'' was designed by Liberace's couturier, Nudie, and was said to have cost $10,000. But what's really interesting is the way RCA subtly manipulated the images of Elvis to suit the tastes of a particular country. So, for example, on his second album, 1956's ''Elvis,'' the Mexican release features the King with jet-black hair and eyebrows, looking every inch the mariachi -- while the English release features a foppish Elvis in a velvet poet's shirt that would have looked splendid on Byron. One needs an obsessive interest in Presley, or record marketing, or both, to enjoy this book. Still, one can't help but admire Mr. Dowling's passion. And in a nicety not lost on Elvis fans, the author dedicates the book to his own mother. Surely the King would approve. Judith Newman

title: Portraits in Depth, Familial and Otherwise
description: A FEW years ago, Karen Sevell Greenbaum, an artist in Croton, N.Y., began creating portraits that combine photographic elements and collage, portraits she says touch the hearts of the people who commission her work.

title: From Therapy to Politics
description: CHILDREN, RACE, AND POWER

title: In Africa, Peacekeeping Is Too Little, Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: Look, Ma, No Gas!
description: Don't try to tell Jack Smith that electric cars are a pipe dream. Mr. Smith, chairman of General Motors, drove one of the company's first electric models onto a transporter last week in Lansing, Mich. On Dec. 5, they will be available for lease at 26 Saturn dealerships.

title: A Genre Divided By Region
description: To the Editor:

title: Unbalanced Budget Talk
description: The last time Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had to haul his boss up short, the ever-loquacious President talked too much about the dollar -- and briefly sent the markets haywire. Last week Mr. Clinton did the same to Congress. In an overlong answer to a short question, he seemed to accept that the Republican majority in the Senate would pass a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.

title: Love in the Stacks
description: A HISTORY OF READING

title: Bugs and Michael Work the Fast Break
description: Space Jam

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 39 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the ways exhibitions change as they travel from one museum to another omits part of the surname of the woman in charge of exhibitions at the Bard Graduate Center in New York. She is Nina Stritzler-Levine, not Levine.

title: Q AND A
description: Scythian Gold in Russia

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: War Is Hell. So Is Regulating Sex.
description: AMERICAN admirals and generals like to boast that they carry around contingency plans for wars, riots and even hurricanes. But they're still stumped when it comes to solving one of their most basic problems: sex.

title: Size of Texaco Discrimination Settlement Could Encourage More Lawsuits
description: Texaco's decision to settle a Federal discrimination lawsuit provides evidence of how vulnerable consumer-oriented corporations can be to bad publicity and outside pressure as they deal with employee accusations of racial or sexual bias.

title: That Unfamiliar Fall Favorite, the Anemone
description: THERE is the last rose of summer. There are the ubiquitous mums. There are sturdy asters. Collectively, these flowers mark the end of the season. Few gardeners would add anemones to the list, but it is time to give this overlooked flower its due.

title: Mamie, as More Than a 1950's Woman
description: When people remember the former First Lady Mamie Doud Eisenhower, who died in 1979, it is usually for her short, girlish bangs, her predilection for pink and her breezy, housewife manner.

title: How a Quack Becomes a Canard
description: On the night of july 17, T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded and crashed off the coast of Long Island, killing everyone on board. For months, investigators have focused on three possible causes -- a bomb, mechanical failure or a terrorist missile -- but what really happened remains a mystery.

title: Q. & A.
description: Offering Plan and Disclosures

title: Yankees Offer Key Arbitration
description: After unsuccessfully trying to sign Jimmy Key to a new contract yesterday, the Yankees nevertheless went ahead and offered him salary arbitration, keeping him from the free-agent market and a possible move to the Baltimore Orioles.

title: On and Off the Slopes
description: RECOGNIZING that the traditional ski-all-day-every-day vacation is becoming passe, ski resorts across North America are reinventing themselves as upscale amusement parks on snow, encouraging guests to participate in everything from snow tubing to dog sledding, from hot-air ballooning to ski jumping. At the same time, the prospect of drawing more people to the mountains has never been brighter, resort operators say, citing the proliferation of new easy-to-turn ski designs and a huge population of children who are ripe to become skiers and snowboarders.

title: A Full-Court Press In Special Effects
description: IF HOLLYWOOD EXCELS IN any two areas, it would be in size and speed. The industry's newest big-fast movie arrived on Friday in the form of ''Space Jam,'' a hyperactive collision of Bugs Bunny and Michael Jordan, making his feature-film debut. The film is a combination of traditional animation, computer-generated imagery and live action.

title: Jane L. Schwartz, Steven Kantor
description: Jane Lynn Schwartz, the daughter of Dr. Harvey N. Schwartz of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and the late Carol Schwartz, was married last evening to Steven Kantor, the son Mr. and Mrs. Norman Kantor of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Bruce Block officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: The Fixer
description: NOBODY comes to a subway station to stay.

title: Synagogue on Fourth Street May Be Hard to Find
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope to Meet Castro as a Possible Prelude to Papal Trip to Cuba
description: Pope John Paul II will meet on Tuesday with Fidel Castro, the Vatican said today in a brief announcement that suggested that a trip to Cuba by the Pope is under active discussion.

title: The Growing Nonprofit Partnership With For-Profits
description: TROUBLE not of their making has made partners of Carlton Collier and Martin Horwitz, one from the nonprofit world, the other a private owner.

title: Agendas
description: ASKED to recall my life 20 years ago, I did what any organized person would do. I looked at my 1976 datebook. It was filled with Hadassah events, Indian Guide meetings, chorus rehearsals and concerts, working the bingo games at the Jewish Center, etc. -- a full but perhaps unsurprising schedule for a suburban New Jersey housewife with a 6-year-old son.

title: G.O.P. Rock No More
description: It will be at least another week before election officials finish the drawn-out ballot count in the Congressional race between Rep. Robert K. Dornan, the blustery, hard-right Republican from Orange County, and his liberal Democratic challenger, Loretta Sanchez. But what is already clear in this contest, one of half a dozen House races still undecided, is that whether or not the in-your-face Congressman is able to hold off a loss, Orange County is no longer the bastion of all-white, conservative Republicanism.

title: Kevorkian Partner Faces Cancer and Felony Charges
description: Janet Good has taken to sleeping in a bit, ever since the doctors told her she had terminal pancreatic cancer last year. But on Tuesday she had to get up early, so that she could be driven to Ionia County, halfway across Michigan, to be charged with four felonies.

title: University of Minnesota Regents Drop Effort to Modify Tenure
description: After months of protest by faculty members, the University of Minnesota's governing Board of Regents has abandoned a plan to make it easier to dismiss tenured professors from most of its campuses, but it passed such a measure for the law school.

title: Some Reactions On Breast Cancer
description: I was surprised at the attack by Geri Barish on Bea Tusiani's piece $(''I Got Breast Cancer. Why Me?,'' Oct. 13$) about the Long Island Breast Cancer Study Project $(Nov. 3$).

title: Miss Schottenfeld And Mr. Bogaev
description: Barbara Lisa Schottenfeld, a lyricist and composer for musical theater, and Paul Harry Bogaev, a conductor and arranger for theater and films, are to be married today in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner is to officiate at the St. Regis.

title: From D.C., With Love
description: The Head Spook spoke.

title: Violence Kills 1 And Injures 3 In Rockaways
description: A Queens woman was found murdered in a Far Rockaway nursing home yesterday, less than a block from a home where a 6-year-old girl and her parents were seriously wounded shortly after midnight during a push-in robbery.

title: Entrances, Exits and Many Acts In Between
description: IN 1976, the Paper Mill Playhouse was referred to as ''winter stock'' and the McCarter Theater had declared its independence from Princeton University just three years earlier. So much for New Jersey's oldest established professional theaters in America's bicentennial year.

title: Suit in Player's Death
description: The family of a Pasadena, Tex., high school sophomore who died after a football practice has sued the school district, charging violations of league regulations on hot-weather workouts and medical emergencies.

title: Loosening the Timetable for Bringing G.I.'s Home
description: ON one level, President Clinton's decision to keep American troops in Bosnia way past their one-year deadline is a blatant about-face.

title: Bugs and Michael Work the Fast Break
description: Ransom

title: It's Lonely. Even if You're Not at the Top.
description: When I heard that Gabriela Sabatini and Kimiko Date were quitting the professional tennis tour, I smiled and then I laughed out loud. I was happy for them that they had found a way to leave. They are free now. For months, my own goodbye to the game has flickered on and off as I struggled with my indecision about walking away from a habit I have had since I was 6 years old.

title: From Runway To Broadway
description: WITH the Yankees riding high, and the gaudy new Times Square dazzling rather than intimidating tourists, New York is drawing record numbers of visitors. But getting into Manhattan quickly and reasonably remains a daunting prospect for out-of-towners, especially those coming through La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark Airports.

title: The Hot Pursuit
description: ''Where is this Mr. Bikel? Take me to him now.''

title: Let's Be Honest About Sex in the Military
description: When Congress decided in 1978 to integrate women into Army units, the Pentagon was told to make the rules. There were bound to be consequences. Now the Army and the rest of the uniformed services confront a problem arising from the regulations put in force 18 years ago.

title: A Show on the Road May Take Many Forms
description: Correction Appended

title: . . . And at Iona, Athletes Toe the Academic Line
description: THE Rev. J. D. Concannon, a 62-year-old Christian Brother and academic adviser to athletes at Iona College, says he has a strategic advantage in the location of his second-floor office at the Mulcahy Center on the campus here. A water fountain stands against the wall several feet from a his open door. The weight-training room is around the corner and down the hall.

title: One Man's Time Line, Somewhat Warped
description: In which, as a public service, we bring readers up to date on the vital events in New Jersey history that occurred before this section existed.

title: Neighbors Feel Squeezed by Baruch's Tower Plan
description: For more than a decade, Baruch College, one of the nation's largest business colleges, has wanted to consolidate some of its sprawling campus onto a single block at 24th Street and Lexington Avenue. But for the last year or so, one neighborhood obstacle or another has frustrated the college.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 2

title: Maureen Scully, James McFadden
description: Maureen Scully, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Scully of White Plains, was married yesterday to James Francis McFadden, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael McFadden of San Francisco. The Rev. John Ring performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Chapel of Divine Compassion at Good Counsel Academy in White Plains.

title: Rooftop Restaurant At a London Landmark
description: A new restaurant atop the eight-story Art Deco Oxo Tower in London opened in September. Situated on the South Bank of the River Thames near the reconstructed Globe Theater, the Oxo Tower Restaurant, Bar and Brasserie provides views of St. Paul's Cathedral and beyond to the Canary Wharf Tower.

title: Star-Crossed
description: In ROMEO AND JULIET (1968), the director, Franco Zeffirelli, knows what to do with color, camera, stunning sets and Shakespeare. This is a movie, not a photographed play, and for once the young lovers are actually played - beautifully - by two teen-agers, Leonard Whiting and Olivia Hussey (pictured, with Pat Heywood). Michael York, and Milo O'Shea head the supporting cast. The picture rings poetically when it should and crackles aptly when needed. Crowning the technical expertise is a beautiful musical score. This is sensitive and thumping good Shakespeare - a screen novelty - FRIDAY at 8 A.M. on SHOWTIME.

title: The Mile-High Pedestal: Denver Is Elway's City
description: Come to this city, look around, flip on the radio, and there are constant reminders of where you are. You have just entered John Elway country.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: LOVE - hedonistic, obsessive, hopeless and highly romantic - courses through four exceptional films on this week's schedule.

title: So Sue Me
description: Last December, Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, promised $1 million to the first American who could prove this statement false: ''In November 1995, the U.S. House and Senate passed a balanced budget bill. It increases total Federal spending on Medicare by more than 50 percent from 1995 to 2002. . . .''

title: Pulling Up Roots, and Leaving Some Behind
description: You can actually see the stars from Red Hook, that little elbow of Brooklyn that sticks out into the Buttermilk Channel, just across the harbor from the Statue of Liberty and south of the towering weight of Manhattan.

title: Hustling Starks Saves Bumbling Knicks in the Fourth Quarter
description: Jeff Van Gundy summoned the trouble-shooter again. John Starks brought his gadgets, fixed things just so and enabled the Knicks to sneak out of Madison Square Garden yesterday without a galling loss.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: War Before Civilization

title: A Boy in Drag: Three Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish Shop Rebuffed on Firings
description: Upper West Side fish lovers who are also union supporters may choose to bypass Citarella, the popular market at 75th Street and Broadway for a few more months. On Friday, the National Labor Relations Board's regional director, Daniel Silverman, brought what he called the equivalent of a ''labor indictment'' against the store over the dismissal of three workers in August.

title: Decline and Fall
description: REMEMBER the ''National Urban Policy'' announced by President Jimmy Carter in mid-1976? How long ago it seems. That announcement, instead of heralding a concerted effort to breathe new life into urban America, ushered in the era of urban denial. Not since then has there been any serious discussion of a national response to the continuing decline of the nation's recreational, cultural and commercial core -- its cities.

title: Skiing the Web: A Virtual Trail Map
description: THE World Wide Web is so full of information and inspiration for planning ski vacations that you could spend the whole season on the Internet rather than the lift. Typing the key words ''ski OR skiing'' in the Alta Vista search engine, a popular index, is definitely not the way to go; it brought up about 100,000 sites. Here are some places to start. It is by no means an exhaustive list, but all these sites lead to others.

title: How Brief Is the Music Of the Young
description: IN THE GRAND FINALE OF ''The Rolling Stones Rock-and-Roll Circus,'' a 1968 concert film that has just been released on video, the Rolling Stones walk offstage and sit with their arms around audience members to sing their ballad ''Salt of the Earth.'' Mick Jagger and Keith Richards sway and laugh as Pete Townshend and Keith Moon of the Who, who also participated in the event, clown around in front of them, dancing in circles with seat cushions on their heads.

title: Cozza Bids Farewell at the Bowl, and Yale Says Goodbye
description: From the great two-way end of the mid-1930's, Larry Kelley, the second player to win the Heisman Trophy, to Calvin Hill to Brian Dowling to Rich Diana to Gary Fencik -- former Elis all -- they came by the hundreds to the Yale Bowl today to bid farewell to the longest enduring Yale football coach, Carmen Cozza.

title: Rena Convissor, Howard Milchberg
description: Rena Convissor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Convissor of South Orange, N.J., is to be married there today to Dr. Howard Milchberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Milchberg of Niagara Falls, Ontario. Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein is to officiate at Congregation Beth El.

title: A Domestic Sensualist
description: UNDER THE TUSCAN SUN

title: INSIDE
description: Misery After India Crash

title: A Yankee Contrast
description: BECAUSE I learned to cross-country ski a decade before I went downhill skiing, I'm partial to downhill experiences that have the essence of cross-country. To me that means lots of moving, and seeing lots of trees and other elements of the wilderness. In short, I like my winter sports to pit me nose-to-the-wind against nature.

title: Subway Planners' Lofty Ambitions Are Buried as Dead-End Curiosities
description: In the best science fiction movies, there are parallel universes, worlds within worlds, secrets locked in forgotten codes. And so it is with the New York subways, which were envisioned to go far more places -- in a skein of routes that might dazzle present-day straphangers -- under bold plans that have faded into distant memory.

title: As Greenways Expand, So Do Uses
description: JOANNE G. FEENEY of Glastonbury normally uses her Rollerblades along a highway or in a cemetery, but she's a bit apprehensive in both places. ''In cemeteries you feel uncomfortable because it's not a playground, and on the road it's just not safe,'' she said.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Works That Create and Hold Energy
description: Calvin Albert

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Bugs and Michael Work the Fast Break
description: Special Effects

title: Dentists on the Lookout for Child Abuse
description: REPORTS of child abuse and neglect are rising at an alarming rate all over the country. More than two million cases are now reported annually, about 30,000 in Connecticut alone. With about 65 percent of all cases involving injuries to the head and neck region, dental personnel are in a position to detect possible abuse of their patients.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Leading With My Chin

title: It Takes a Lot More Than a Mall to Make a Real Jersey Girl
description: She wore a pink skin-tight off-the-shoulder blouse, a black-and-white polka-dot mini-skirt and hot pink stilettos. Her earrings looked like janitors' key rings. Her nails were iridescent talons. As for her hair, it was not just big; it was a huge brown tangle, like one of those starlings' nests wedged in the pin oaks in Liberty State Park.

title: The Accompaniment To Hitler's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Trotting Out the Turkey
description: Though Thanksgiving is traditionally associated with the Pilgrims' first feast, in 1621, it was not until 1863 that it was made a national holiday by President Lincoln and celebrated annually on the last Thursday of November. The traditional turkey dinner still prevails as the meal of choice, with 95 percent of Americans consuming 535 million pounds of turkey, Many restaurants and food stores in the city prepare take-out turkey dinners with various side dishes and desserts. Here's what some cost, along with prices for turkeys you prepare at home. KIMBERLEY STVENS

title: Farm Life as Metaphor For Real Life
description: After reading ''As Season Ends, Work Doesn't'' (Nov. 10), I found myself caught by one particular sentence: ''And as more mature, we change the blend to accept the other varieties,'' John Halsey was referring to apples, but I was thinking of human beings.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: One of your test questions demonstrates the reason that some people are suspicious of biases in standardized tests. The question is: ''Promises and pie crusts are made to be ---- . The answer is, ''broken.'' Says who? Some of us would not consider that to be an acceptable answer. How about substituting another question and answer: ''Promises and women are made to be kept.'' Don't like that one either, huh?

title: 'The Rules' and Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Survivors Likely in Sex Shops War
description: To City Hall, Times Square's purple age of sex is fading as quickly as the last reel in a 25-cent peep show. Only 24 sex shops exist today, down from a peak of more than 120 two decades ago, and these are under fierce legal attack by the city.

title: Texaco's Penance
description: After more than two years of battling a Federal suit, Texaco folded its hand last week, agreeing to the largest settlement ever in a racial discrimination case: more than $140 million. What changed the company's defensive posture was a tape of a meeting at which Texaco executives were planning the destruction of documents demanded in the lawsuit. They were also heard denigrating minority groups.

title: For Troubled Co-ops, Active Boards Can Be A Key to Recovery
description: LIKE an old melodrama, the Saga of the Troubled Building begins merrily. As the opening credits roll, it is the late 1980's, and ecstatic buyers are lining up in front of newly converted condominiums and co-ops, waving signed contracts.

title: Some Reactions On Breast Cancer
description: Having read Bea Tusiani's ''from the heart'' article and Geri Barish's mean-spirited vitriolic response, I feel compelled to comment. Ms. Barish ''corrects,'' ''takes issue with'' and ''is disturbed by'' Ms. Tusiani's normal response to abnormal circumstances.

title: Charles Hagen, 78, Biology Professor
description: Charles William Hagen Jr., a professor emeritus of biology at Indiana University who researched the basic chemistry of plant development, died on Nov. 5 at Meadowbrook Retirement Community in Bloomington, Ind. He was 78.

title: A Minimalist Approach To Meetings
description: AS the business world grows increasingly global and complex -- a game of chess, not checkers -- directors have an ever bigger job to do. Shareholders have been demanding for at least a decade that directors monitor company operations more closely, adding to the pressure. A post that once seemed honorary now requires time and effort.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Lisa Carver
description: Carver edits the zine Rollerderby. Her first nonfiction collection, ''Dancing Queen: A Lusty Look at the American Dream,'' is being published this month by Owl Books.

title: YES, VIRGINA, THEY DO
description: After viewing Disney's live-action version of ''101 Dalmatians,'' opening next week, your kids may look to you and ask: ''Do people really skin dogs to make coats?'' You can truthfully say: Um, Disney doesn't. (''Our animals were treated better than most humans,'' boasts the movie's zoologically correct press kit; ''cast and crew were made to walk through foot baths of disinfectant before entering a 'puppy area.' '') But don't mention Ulaan Baatar, Mongolia, where overabundant stray dogs are gunned down, skinned and made into parkas that are popular with Russians. But surely pup couture can't happen here? Don't be so sure. Moenkhtsetseg, the owner of a Mongolian dog-pelt company, has suggested, Cruella-like, using dog farms to usher in the age of mass producton and foreign exports.

title: Macy's Teaches Finer Points of Clowning Around
description: They came to learn the finer points of stutter walking, limbo dancing and jumping around in a manner that will not scare small children. Some learned to walk like a cactus; others learned to wobble like a bowling pin. There were makeup tips (nothing dissolves grease paint better than vegetable oil) and etiquette tips (removing any part of one's costume along a parade route is uncouth).

title: The Magical Touch Of Marcel Carne
