description: MARCEL CARNE'S FATE was melancholy indeed: he outlived his productive career by 45 years, and new ways of looking at movies diminished the reputation of some of his best work even before it could become decently dated. Yet Carne, who was 90 when he died in a Paris suburb on Oct. 31, was the man who made ''Les Enfants du Paradis'' (1945), widely regarded as a masterpiece and the most critically acclaimed, most popular French film of all time.

title: 20 YEARS: UP FRONT
description: Twenty years after The New York Times inaugurated a separate Sunday section for New Jersey, the rearview mirror gives a clear view of the difficulties of change. But a look ahead finds hope, resilience and renewal. It's true in the inner cities and the sprawling suburbs, and it's true along the boardwalk in the Asbury Park that Bruce Springsteen first sang about two decades ago.

title: Exterminators Held in Use Of a Poison Inside Homes
description: Beth Hobdy did not become suspicious of the man who sprayed her house near here last month for roaches and ants until her two toddlers began vomiting and running high fevers.

title: In China, a Taste Of Buy-Me TV
description: WHEN JINGWEN has a symbol of China's rising affluence tucked away near the dinner table in his two-bedroom apartment just outside Beijing.

title: Up From the Screw Cap: A Wine Snob's Primer
description: A WINE expert says: ''Ah, a 1983. A difficult year, 1983. Excellent in Margaux and St. Julien but a disaster in St.-Estephe.'' That he couldn't tell a Margaux from a Mondavi or a 1983 from a 1938 doesn't matter. Jargon carries the day.

title: THE KINDEST CUT
description: Who would have thought that plastic surgery -- that frivolous surgical discipline that allows women to torture their bodies to conform to tortured images of physical inadequacy -- would provide the opportunity for a symbolic second chance following a diagnosis of breast cancer. While no woman would rejoice at the prospect of mastectomy and reconstruction because it allows you to sneak in a tummy tuck and acquire perky new breasts, the rejoicing comes when this surgery can reshape the body that betrayed you, giving your mind and spirit the opportunity to catch up.

title: The Youngest Ex-Cons: Facing A Difficult Road Out of Crime
description: They get out of jail, still young enough to go back to school.

title: Basketball Player Picks Duke U.
description: SCHOOL was out on Nov. 5, but the library at the high school here was full. Students, faculty members, parents and reporters sat and eagerly awaited Elton Brand's decision. Brand , a 6-foot-8, 238- pound senior, is possibly the state's best high school basketball player. The after-school crowd had assembled to hear which college he had chosen to attend next year. A television camera rolled.

title: Rebels With Plows
description: Rural Radicals

title: Weird, From Somewhere Beyond Real
description: AT HIS DEATH IN 1978, THE GERMAN-BORN painter Richard Lindner was known in both the United States and Europe for figure paintings that were monumental, heraldic and almost unnervingly precise. The individual figures were challenging by reason of their exuberant physicality. To that was added the peremptory strangeness of their accouterments (or lack of them).

title: What's in a Name? An Affront, Say Several Tribes
description: In the language wars between whites and Indians, peace has prevailed over this windswept patch of the Plains, a land where life is defined by farming, fishing and Friday night blackjack.

title: To Arms! The Americans Are Coming!
description: O. K., I give up. I'm wearing my rollerblading helmet.

title: A Daring Tale Of Female Beauty And Its Price
description: THE THREE WOMEN SIT SIDE by side on flimsy plastic chairs, the kind molded to fit the mean-average shape of no human who has ever existed. There are other characters in Lisa Loomer's moving, exuberantly sardonic comedy, ''The Waiting Room,'' now at the Vineyard Theater, but this early image, a frieze of women from different historical epochs, is the one that dominates the play and exemplifies its liberating method.

title: 'The Tailor of Panama'
description: To the Editor:

title: Spirit of '76: Byrne's School Parity Battle Still Reverberates
description: Former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne remembers the confrontation of 1976 well.

title: People Who Like Streisand
description: IN a town where Babs bashing is as common as name dropping, people were mostly saying nice things after last Sunday's premiere of Barbra Streisand's ''Mirror Has Two Faces'' at the Ziegfeld Theater on West 54th Street.

title: Steven J. Chait, Lisa F. Ross
description: Lisa Faith Ross, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Ross of Wantagh, L.I., is to be married today to Steven Jonathan Chait, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan S. Chait of New York. Rabbi Howard Morrison is to perform the ceremony at Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Proposed Budget Holds Line on Rise In Property Taxes
description: PROPERTY owners in 20 of Westchester's 25 towns and cities would see their taxes stay the same or drop next year under County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed $962.6 million 1997 budget released last week.

title: The New Science
description: THE SCIENTIFIC REVOLUTION

title: Still Wandering, on Cable
description: With a peculiar frequency, a click of the cable remote shows the Fordham Baldies hanging out at the corner of Fordham Road and Grand Concourse, the foot chase through 1963 central Bronx alleyways, the familiar strip poker game and the apocalyptic football game.

title: Choosing the Playwrights Who Can Go Home Again
description: ROMULUS LINNEY, Lee Blessing, Edward Albee, Horton Foote, Adrienne Kennedy . . . The list of the Signature Theater Company's past writers-in-residence reads like a course in contemporary American drama. With Sam Shepard's work currently in production and Arthur Miller in the wings for the 1997-98 season, the tiny company is cornering the market on yearlong celebrations of individual playwrights.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: In what was billed as an argument about the need for, and promise of, national standards in education, Sara Mosle made clear only the importance of a content-rich, multiyear curriculum (''The Answer Is National Standards,'' Oct. 27). Unfortunately, the specification of curriculum has little to do with ''standards'' as they are currently being adopted in many states. These standards most often focus on general educational goals rather than on required course content and thus allow for a variety of curricular implementations.

title: Nathan Hale's Schoolhouse, Looking for a Home Again
description: NATHAN HALE, Connecticut's official state hero, was hanged by the British as a spy on Sept. 22, 1776. His schoolhouse, however, goes marching on . . . and on . . . and on . . .

title: Passion's Flash Point
description: IF the lilt of language were all, ''The Mai,'' by Marina Carr, would give audiences the pleasure of savoring words and restore to theater the rite of pure listening. But there is an elusive place where content and style coexist, and Ms. Carr, the 32-year-old playwright who is all the rage in Ireland, takes exclusive possession of that place. Those who feel left out of ''The Mai'' can go elsewhere.

title: With Each Day, a Triumph
description: As mornings go, this one seemed ordinary: fog masked the hills west of Austin, a light wind fluttered flags, the temperature promised another shirt-sleeves day. About 7:30, rain began falling for half an hour and everybody said that was a good thing because there had been a bit of a drought in central Texas.

title: Forget Formalities In the West 40's
description: FRICO BAR ++

title: Brought to You by the Letter F (for Film)
description: FINALLY someone answers the age-old question from childhood ''Won't you tell me how to get, how to get to Sesame Street?'' Sesame Street intersects with 42d Street in a festival of short films opening Tuesday at the New Victory Theater.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/

title: In Love With Revolution
description: The Long Affair

title: Oyster Day
description: THANKSGIVING DID NOT RISE FROM THE grateful hearts of Pilgrims who might have been feeling a burst of patriotism or a need to celebrate one of their new homeland's native birds. Rather, the establishment of the holiday was meant to wrap up the agricultural year and, in doing so, eclipse Christmas, according to Sandra L. Oliver, who publishes The Food History News, a quarterly newsletter, in Islesboro, Me., and is an inveterate debunker of Pilgrim mythology. Christmas was the most popish of holidays, Oliver said as a way of explanation.

title: Year-Old School Looks Worn
description: Some might consider the 750 students at Public School 4, at 160th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, lucky to be attending a new $21 million school. But the building already needs major repairs, according to school board members, parents and Public Advocate Mark Green. Among the problems: a leaky roof, a buckling gym floor, lack of ventilation, an oil leak in the boiler room and a loud hum on the first floor caused by faulty installation of a water pump.

title: No Headline
description: ''Little Red Riding Hood.''

title: Born to Run
description: NOT to be presumptuous about it, but the biggest change in New Jersey in the past 20 years has been the change in me, as I have evolved from reluctant resident (I first moved to the Garden State in 1972, because I couldn't afford rents in Manhattan) to ardent patriot and champion of my adoptive home. Like Walt Whitman (another guy who moved here), I now throb with the pulse of New Jersey.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MARX, DECEASED

title: A Death Reminds Sanitation Force of Its Unseen Hazards
description: It was Michael Hanly's grin on the recruitment poster that beckoned new employees to the New York City Sanitation Department. ''We need good people,'' the sign read. ''Join the best.''

title: Dig In and Make Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Many Rules, But Not for All
description: IF Japan's leaders are to be believed, this nation is about to embark on the deregulatory path followed by the United States in the last two decades -- loosening restrictions on its airlines, telephones, banks and brokerages and other industries. In the recent Japanese election, candidates fell over one another telling voters that Japan's economic growth, entrepreneurial spirit and public well-being are being suffocated by too much regulation and an overbearing bureaucracy.

title: Farming Fluke in Open Water
description: AT the foot of Sterling Avenue in Greenport, where not long ago fishing boats docked in the early evening with catches that they had gone out for at dawn, a cement unloading dock has been transformed into an outdoor restaurant.

title: Fly the Pinstripe Skies
description: What's so bad about the word ''air''? After all, it suggests something essential, life-sustaining and, even better, a pair of Nikes.

title: Packers Will Measure Their Progress Against the Cowboys
description: The playoff victory over the 49ers in San Francisco that put them in the National Football Conference championship game last season was a major breakthrough for the Green Bay Packers. Now, Green Bay needs to win at Dallas on Monday night to move to the next level.

title: BIBLE DISCUSSION GROUP
description: Ours is a culture that over the years has managed to debunk Mom, Dad, teachers, academicians, government leaders and even the flag (''In the Beginning There Was a Bible Discussion Group. And Then PBS Came Calling.,'' by Rodger Kamenetz, Oct. 20). And now with the Bill Moyers program ''Genesis: A Living Conversation,'' our last vestige of sanctity has fallen. In calling the patriarchal family ''dysfunctional,'' maligning Abraham, our spiritual father, and referring to God with expletives, Rabbi Burton L. Visotzky deals yet another blow to a society already reeling from lack of values and morals.

title: 250 Choristers, One for Each Year of Princeton
description: ANYONE who has ever tried to plan a wedding is amazed at the diverse elements that have to be coordinated: date, place, budget, music, rehearsal, ushers and attire, not to mention social diplomacy. In fact, the list hints suspiciously at the challenges of producing Saturday's concert tribute to the 250th anniversary of Princeton University.

title: But Is It Art?
description: ''I am not really interested in clothing as a conceptual art form,'' says Issey Miyake. So much for the vast majority of recent collaborations between artists and designers. At a moment when fashion seems eager to ingratiate itself to galleries and museums, Miyake's decision to inaugurate a ''guest artist series'' for his Pleats Please collection might at first glance be mistaken for just another high-flown attempt to immortalize the ephemeral. Which in fact is not the case. The first project in the series -- a pleated sheath printed with an image by Yasumasa Morimura -- has just been released, and it announces a different, more interesting intention.

title: Canada Sends First Rescue Troops to Rwanda
description: Canada's Defense Ministry said today that it had flown an advance reconnaissance team of 24 soldiers and three Hercules transport planes to Kigali, Rwanda, in the first operation of a Canadian-led international rescue mission for eastern Zaire that was authorized Friday by the Security Council.

title: Wool on the Go: A Knitter's Yarn
description: SOMEWHERE over Texas, lumbering along in a four-propeller plane with nothing to do but look out at the wing or watch the hands knitting next to me, I decided to make a scarf for my pinball-playing boyfriend. It was 1958 and the beginning of a lifelong relationship for knitting, travel and me.

title: Learning Proper Way to Serve in a Restaurant
description: MY worst restaurant nightmares are full of service disasters. They include:

title: Class Act
description: IT was 1976.

title: Trouble on Mount Rushmore
description: Critics of multiculturalism predicted that the movement would aggravate racial and cultural differences, eroding ties that bind past to present and American to American. But a glance at just about any medium -- film, literature, commerce, art -- confirms that the multicultural impulse has broadened common culture dramatically, exposing America as never before to the richness of its identity.

title: A Preservationist Lists 35 Modern Landmarks-in-Waiting
description: Never known as someone shy about taking a stand, Robert A.M. Stern has produced a list of 35 modern monuments he thinks should be New York City landmarks. For the most part, they date from after World War II into the 1960's -- and they are not always pretty. ''But they may be very important technologically, or historically, or culturally,'' said Mr. Stern, an architect, author and teacher.

title: City Streets Offer No Place for Cyclists
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER WEST SIDE

title: Urging Girls to Make a Difference
description: THE invitation called for an afternoon tea for mothers and daughters. In a room with high ceilings and decorated with gaily colored balloons, women and girls sipped tea and punch, nibbled on cucumber sandwiches and cookies and wore what may have been the highest concentration of velvet, pearls and patent leather recently seen in the county.

title: A Bellwether Still? Don't Be So Sure
description: Another onetime Southern governor and Democrat was running for President 20 years ago, and his Republican opponent was another moderate former member of Congress from the Midwest. What has happened since then may say something about where New Jersey has gone in the intervening two decades.

title: Airport Security
description: To the Editor: On Aug. 22, my husband and I left for Istanbul by way of Frankfurt on Lufthansa out of Newark Airport. A skycap took our baggage at the curb, depositing the baggage near the counter. And we waited in line nowhere near our bags. We finally got to the counter, our bags were checked through and we were given boarding passes and seat assignments on the leg from Frankfurt to Istanbul.

title: Anybody Want a Comics Company?
description: In the world of Wall Street, it is possible to control a company without having even a nickel of real economic stake in it.

title: Campaign Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: Considering the Once and Future Whitney Museum
description: SOMETIMES JUST SHUTTING up can be a powerfully creative act. This is one message that comes through from the small but valuable show now on view in the lobby gallery of the Whitney Museum of American art. Organized by Nicholas Olsberg of the Canadian Center for Architecture, the exhibition, ''Breuer's Whitney,'' focuses on the museum's own building, the inverted ziggurat of dark granite, designed by Marcel Breuer, that opened 30 years ago.

title: Prematurely Correct
description: Pearl S. Buck

title: Army Looks Less Than Perfect In Dome
description: They had not felt this way in more than a year. That alone is a memorable achievement for the Army Cadets, a football team that had to scramble a year ago for a break-even season that saved the job of Coach Bob Sutton. Army had conceived a winning formula with the simplest and most responsible of suggestions: the Cadets would merely seek to become a 1-0 team each week.

title: Still Hopping After All These Years
description: AS a pioneer of television and of children's television, Bob Keeshan, created and starred in ''Captain Kangaroo,'' a fixture on CBS for 38 years. The program fell from grace in the early 1980's when its morning time slot was turned over to network news.

title: Wolves' Howl Could Return In Adirondacks
description: A few years back, when Hank Fischer of the Defenders of Wildlife was trying to convince hostile Western ranchers to accept the reintroduction of gray wolves to Yellowstone National Park, he was sometimes met with a counterchallenge: Since Easterners are so interested in wolves, ''why don't you introduce them to New York City or Washington, D.C.?''

title: Welfare Proposals Hurt Elderly Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: No Drills Needed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: That Heavenly Jingle

title: Birds on Your Runway? Scare Them Off With Tougher Birds
description: Steve Garber, a biologist, stopped his car at the end of Runway 4L at Kennedy International Airport as a silver-bellied jumbo jet rumbled into the night sky. ''Look!'' he said, ignoring the plane but pointing out toward the water. ''See? Right there. There they go.''

title: A Small Mercy
description: JACOB THE LIAR

title: Sour Notes on Apartments
description: Some Astoria residents are singing an angry refrain over a multimillion-dollar plan to convert the old Stern's department store warehouse on Ditmars Boulevard into an apartment complex.

title: New Rules on Liver Transplants
description: After much agonizing, an organization that makes rules that allocate livers for transplants has decided to introduce rationing. The United Network for Organ Sharing had always reasoned that the sickest patients should have top priority. But this group includes those whose livers suddenly failed, from a viral infection or toxin, and those whose livers have been deteriorating for decades, like people with alcoholic cirrhosis or viral hepatitis. These people are about half as likely to survive a transplant.

title: Vail
description: Growing up in the Berkshires, I spent many winter afternoons shivering in chairlift lines, trying to imagine a ski hill where the descent would take more time than the ascent.

title: When the Bills Are Over the Top
description: THREE layoffs in in the past six years left the Litchfield County man with a mountain of debt that forced him into bankruptcy. The job he holds now as sales manager for a small contracting supply business grows more uncertain every day as the company's sales dwindle. The 35-year-old man and his wife, who have two young children, have put their home up for sale.

title: OUTBREAK
description: 1. Flu season starts this month, and experts say this year's big threat -- type A Wuhan, an offspring of the 1968-69 Hong Kong strain that killed 34,000 Americans -- is particularly nasty. 2. Can you block the virus without taking a vaccine jab? Not really. Even wearing a paper mask in the office will only ''help'' alienate your pals. 3. One theory has it that some flu viruses incubate in the intestinal tracts of wild aquatic birds, whose feces infect land-based birds, pigs and then humans. 4. Yikes: 1899, 1918, 1957, 1968 -- we're about due for another global pandemic, which occurs when a virus's genetic makeup suddenly changes. Dr. Robert Couch of the Baylor College of Medicine says the only question is ''when and where and how bad it will be.''

title: Forbidden Fruit
description: SILK

title: Giuliani Offers Support For Pataki's Welfare Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani praised Gov. George E. Pataki's new welfare plan yesterday, saying that it would address what the Mayor maintained were flaws in the new Federal welfare law. But Mr. Giuliani said he was worried that the Governor might be trying to scale back benefits for some families too much.

title: Creatures Worthy Of Standing Guard
description: AMERICAN architecture, like American culture, is a blend of influences from world history. In ''Guardians at the Gate: Symbols Of Power and Protection in American Architecture,'' an exhibition at the Bendel Gallery of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center through March 9, stone lions, gargoyles, green men and other architectural artifacts from American buildings and Gothic Revival artists hold court. The form and function of these formidable silent guardians are explored.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about living in Mount Kisco, N.Y., misstated the name of a mall on Route 117. It is the Manufacturer's Outlet Center of Westchester County, formerly called the Mount Kisco Bazaar Mall.

title: Vast Influx Jams Road Leading From Zaire
description: Facing an avalanche of ragged humanity, Rwandan troops and aid workers gave up on holding Rwandan refugees in a temporary camp near the border today, and instead directed them to march straight into this country without any formalities.

title: Just the Morals, Please
description: IT'S ALIVE!

title: For Brain Injured, Center Offers New Skills
description: VISITORS to the Datahr Rehabilitation Institute's new daytime activities center here may be met at the door by Chris Trottier. Although a car accident deprived him of the ability to speak, his lively blue eyes express an alert curiosity. His fingers spell out questions by pointing to letters on a chart he carries in his wheelchair. The chart is smudged and frayed from constant use.

title: Digital Days
description: COMPUTER

title: New Paris Import: Pondering the Big Questions at Cafes . . .
description: Love must be unconditional to be true.

title: The Villain Is Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to Keep the Pews Filled, in Black and White
description: Through the windows of the Presbyterian Church of Teaneck,leaves the colors of the rainbow could be seen swirling in the wind of yet another spectacular autumn, lending the sunlit morning the feel of eternity. Inside a meeting room, half a dozen people had just read in Deuteronomy that the poor would never ''cease out of the land.''

title: Seeing Special Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowned
description: I WAS Miss New Jersey in the bicentennial year of our country, and my most vivid memory of 1976 is of parades in every small town in New Jersey. I discovered towns that I never knew existed. It was a time of excitement about our country's birthday. Watergate and the Vietnam War were behind us, and there was a sense of pride in America. Everything was red, white and blue.

title: From Studio Apartment To Petite Palazzo
description: WHEN one thinks of delightful excess -- of tassels and brocades and Chinese silk bed covers -- a large apartment on Central Park West or Park Avenue comes to mind, not a studio apartment in a postwar building.

title: Williams's Desire to Play for Giants Is Not Diminished by Pain
description: Brian Williams has kept the injuries quiet, and played through the pain, because he doesn't like to whine. At times this season, his ankles have felt as if someone with metal cleats had stepped on them. His elbow? Don't ask.

title: Tribute to a Friend
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Mechanics of the Soul
description: How Brains Think

title: Firming Up? No Sweat! Well, Maybe Just a Little
description: You think you can hide behind those bulky November clothes? That all those layers of wool are camouflaging all the extra pounds rolling in on these chilly nights, when hot cocoa and Oreos, chased by a few chocolate-chunk granola bars and Ding Dongs, seem like the best idea in town? Think again: your calories are showing.

title: Neo-Georgian 1904 Rowhouses, Urban and Urbane
description: THE full-height scaffold on 52 West 74th Street is unusual -- most rowhouse renovations merit only a hanging work platform. But then the entire row at 18-52 West 74th Street is unusual -- an urbane neo-Georgian group of 1904 in a neighborhood of high-stoop Victorian brownstones. They were among the last private houses built on the West Side, and the final development project of the Clark family, 20 years after they built the Dakota.

title: The Just-Do-It Shrink
description: ''Jan! Welcome to the program.''

title: Parenthood: The Eighth Financial Wonder of the World
description: KIDS, cars and gifts get heavy play in the December crop of personal-finance magazines.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: Mosle's article is excellent, but she and the supporters of national standards in education don't stretch far enough. To them, the phrase ''rote learning'' seems to have acquired a negative connotation, much like the word ''liberal'' has to politicians. Thus, she writes, in reference to Jeffrey Litt's successful teachers, they ''were not promoting bloodless rote learning,'' and later she asserts that ''standards advocates are not arguing for a return to rote learning.''

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: As a humanities teacher at an alternative secondary school in East Harlem, I can attest to the fact that rigor need not be neglected within progressive education. In my classes, and throughout my school, students are taught to support their claims with evidence, to take into account multiple points of view and varying perspectives, to make connections to broader trends and wider issues, to determine relevance and significance and to make suppositions about further extensions of any issue raised within the classroom.

title: One (Illegal) Way to Get a Driveway: Cut Up the Sidewalk
description: Where front yards are often slabs of concrete and street parking is often a find, it is understandable that some homeowners have taken to creating their own driveways by slicing out a piece of the sidewalk. But the so-called curb cuts are usually illegal, and usually irk neighbors.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: TINISIMA

title: A Hostage to Compulsion
description: A LIFE OF PICASSO

title: Indian Air Disaster's Aftermath Is a Mix of Official Indifference, Price-Gouging and Pity
description: When Rajendra Pun arrived today at the All-India Institute of Medical Sciences, he was one of the lucky ones. Others had to wait for days and fight off ''coffin touts'' and other exploiters before they had a chance to identify family members killed in the world's worst midair collision, west of New Delhi on Tuesday night.

title: Memories of Bliss
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Creativity Ventures, Must Madness Follow?
description: HOWEVER MUCH PRODIGIOUS talent may fascinate us, it is not universally welcomed by those endowed with it. As a performing musician for 30 years and a child psychiatrist for 20, I have had the privilege of watching the growth and development of dozens of children with such talent in the performing arts. Few are unequivocally thrilled with the power and drive to create and perfect their talent.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BLACK ALLEY

title: Profiles in Cheesiness
description: ''There once was looming shame,'' says Paul Crute, referring to Dallas's taboo grande -- the Kennedy assassination. ''But things change.'' Obviously. Blame Oliver Stone's ''JFK,'' but Dealey Plaza has mutated into a busy conspiracy theme park, with self-anointed ''researchers'' on hand every day peddling forgotten-witness videos and autopsy pictures. Now into the kitsch comes Crute, driving a restored Lincoln Continental convertible limousine. For $25, his new tour ''transports'' customers to 1963, letting them ride along on Kennedy's fateful route -- complete with recorded gunshots. He's all booked up for Nov. 22, but here's a front-seat report.

title: 20 YEARS: PEOPLE
description: They did things that mattered. Some had their hands on the levers of power, and some were found to have had their hands in the till.

title: Immigration Law Loosens a Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: School's Critics Fix on Tree
description: Pitting residents of one Park Slope block against a prestigious private school, a debate over development has turned into a rancorous squabble over a 135-year-old oak tree.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: In my view, any serious approach to education standards has to address a critical issue. Should we, as both Asian and European countries have done, set up a two- or three-tier level of standards that, at an early age, sets the aspiring student onto an academic or vocational track? It is hard to envision Americans buying into this type of rigid program.

title: Something Rotten in Ulster
description: The Last of Deeds

title: Nicole Gresham And George Perry
description: Nicole Kristine Gresham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Gresham of Kansas City, Mo., was married yesterday to George Stuart Perry, the son of Mrs. Josiah Knowles Adams Jr. of Prouts Neck, Me., and the late David Reed Perry. The Rev. Philippa A. Turner performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: With Fall Comes Aroma of Braised Meat
description: BRAISED meat dishes are immensely practical. They can be made in one pot and improve when cooked a day or more in advance. They give off comforting, rustic aromas of thyme, rosemary, wine and spices -- the sort of kitchen smells associated with fall.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 17, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Dell, $7.50.) A troubled woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler in Montana. 2 4 SILENT NIGHT, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.99.) A family finds adversity and renewed courage during a Christmas visit to New York. 3 3 SONG OF SOLOMON, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/Penguin, $11.95.) A black man's search for his family's history. 4 4 ABSOLUTE POWER, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $7.50.) Political intrigue, sex and murder in Washington's high circles. 5 2 CONTAGION, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $6.99.) A physician seeks to learn why a deadly epidemic has struck a group of hospitals and clinics. 6 5 THE WEB, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $6.99.) Alex Delaware encounters a series of macabre events on a tiny Pacific island. 7 5 INTENSITY, by Dean Koontz. (Ballantine, $7.99.) On a weekend visit to a Napa Valley farm, a young woman contends with a serial killer. 8 9 THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Scientists visit a Costa Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs. 9 4 PRIMARY COLORS, by Anonymous. (Warner, $6.99.) The progress of a certain Southern governor and his wife on their way to the White House. 10 4 PANDORA'S CLOCK, by John J. Nance. (St. Martin's, $6.99.) Airports refuse to allow a trans-Atlantic plane that bears a passenger carrying a deadly virus to land. 11 58 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) A murder trial recalls the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. (+) 12 5 FROM THE HEART, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $6.50.) Strong women meet strong men in three short novels. 13 18 THE FIRST WIVES CLUB, by Olivia Goldsmith. (Pocket, $6.99.) Three women conspire to get even with the men who divorced them. 14* 2 A DANGEROUS MAN, by Rosemary Rogers. (Avon, $6.99.) In 1846, an ex-Texas Ranger helps a woman escape the shackles of California society. 15 7 THE JUDGE, by Steve Martini. (Jove, $6.99.) An attorney defends a judge he doesn't like against murder and other charges. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 25 SLEEPERS, by Lorenzo Carcaterra. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The true story, the narrator claims, of four boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take. 2 86 REVIVING OPHELIA, by Mary Pipher. (Ballantine, $12.50.) The everyday dangers that beset teen-age girls. (+) 3 10 A CIVIL ACTION, by Jonathan Harr. (Vintage, $13.) A lawsuit brought by Massachusetts householders against industrial polluters. (+) 4 3 RUSH LIMBAUGH IS A BIG FAT IDIOT, by Al Franken. (Island/Dell, $6.99.) A television comedian's comments on the political scene. 5 6 LONGITUDE, by Dava Sobel. (Penguin, $10.95.) The story of John Harrison, the 18th-century Englishman who invented the chronometer. 6 6 HIGH TIDE IN TUCSON, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) Essays about motherhood, nature and other topics by the novelist. 7 32 THE LIARS' CLUB, by Mary Karr. (Penguin, $11.95.) A poet recalls her childhood as a member of a troubled family in East Texas. (+) 8 3 MISS AMERICA, by Howard Stern. (Regan Books/Harper Paperbacks, $7.99.) Anecdotes and fulminations from the radio talk show host. 9 2 THE REAL WORLD DIARIES. (MTV/Melcher Media/Pocket, $18.) A new collection of behind-the-scenes stories and photographs related to the television show ''The Real World.'' 10* 35 HOW THE IRISH SAVED CIVILIZATION, by Thomas Cahill. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) As the Roman Empire disintegrated, Irish monks copied Western literature. (+) 11 6 IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.) The First Lady on ways to create a better society for children. (+) 12* 678 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) Inspiration. (+) 13* 112 EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Bantam, $5.99.) A woman's near-death experience. (+) 14* 8 A FEVER IN THE HEART, by Ann Rule. (Pocket, $6.99.) Accounts of six crime cases that occurred in Washington and Oregon. 15* 147 CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (Harper Perennial, $12.) A psychotherapist discusses spirituality and daily life. (+) Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 5 THE RULES, by Ellen Fein and Sherrie Schneider. (Warner, $5.99.) The authors offer 35 ''time-tested secrets for capturing the heart of Mr. Right.'' (+) 2 8 IT'S A MAGICAL WORLD, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $14.95.) A new collection of ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 3 1 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE woman's soul, compiled by Jack Canfield, Mark Victor Hansen, Jennifer Read Hawthorne and Marci Shimoff. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Inspiration. (+) 4 112 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE SOUL, compiled by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen. (Health Communications, $12.95.) More inspiration. (+)

title: Zairian Tutsi Family, Now Stateless, Runs for Its Life
description: As a melancholy Zairian rumba blared on the grimy river ferry's loudspeakers, the Rev. Theophile Gakounzi sat his wife and infant son on the upper deck, gathered their few belongings around them and set out to start life anew across the river in Congo.

title: Lehman Advances In P.S.A.L. Playoffs
description: Lineman Chris Smith of Lehman High School has had a bitter taste in his mouth since last November, when Lehman was trounced in the Public Schools Athletic League quarterfinals by Canarsie, 32-6. That afternoon, Smith vowed that things would be different in 1996.

title: Holiday Bargains With a Twist
description: Though retail stores are beginning early holiday sales, other places sometimes offer better bargains and more unique merchandise. MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday with an article about Intermediate School 235 in Long Island City, which is operating far below capacity, misidentified a teacher there. He is Som Mehta, not Douglas Avila.

title: Does the First Amendment Protect For-Sale Signs?
description: MOST homeowners take it for granted that they can put a ''for sale'' sign on their own property.

title: Take-Home Pay?
description: You work 50 hours a week. You eagerly tackle company projects on weekends. So what's the big deal if you take home a ream of paper for your laser printer? The answer may depend on your company. Some may not mind a few odds and ends disappearing once in a while, but they may balk if you take home the printer instead of the paper. How does your company handle these matters? Has anyone ever been dismissed as a result? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Passion for Order
description: I FIRST met Diana Trilling in what I could have sworn was the summer of 1977 but turns out, upon my checking the date with someone who was there, to have been two years later. (Since Diana was such a rigid and exacting chronicler of her own time and place, it seems important to pin these facts down and not let them scamper about.) So it was the summer of 1979: I was staying with friends on Martha's Vineyard, and Diana -- who hadn't yet vacated Chilmark, and the uncomfortable proximity of Lillian Hellman, for Wellfleet -- invited us all for dinner.

title: 'Seton Who?'
description: I WILL never forget the event which made me proud to be a New Jerseyan and which put on the map a theretofore little-known university situated in South Orange. That event was Seton Hall University's trip to the 1989 Final Four.

title: How Native Soil Nurtured a Master Of Modern Design
description: IN THIS GRAY CITY, WITH ITS steep rows of sandstone terrace houses, the architect and designer Charles Rennie Mackintosh found a natural habitat for his architecture and interior design. Like a poet using traditional forms as a scaffold for new ideas, Mackintosh drew from the starkness of medieval Scottish architecture to create a distinctive modern style.

title: A Boy in Drag: Three Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Is Released; Surgery for Rijo
description: THOMAS HOWARD is on the free-agent market and JOSE RIJO is headed for another operation.

title: Hildegarde Fillmore Smith, Editor, 98
description: Hildegarde Fillmore Smith, a former fashion and beauty editor at the women's magazine McCall's, died on Monday in her garret apartment at the National Arts Club on Gramercy Park South.

title: World Is Less Crowded Than Expected, the U.N. Reports
description: A new survey by the United Nations has found that the world's population is growing almost everywhere more slowly than expected even a few years ago. The study also found that the number of people being added to the world each year has begun to fall sooner than anticipated.

title: With Elections Over, The Board Races Begin
description: THE 1996 elections are barely over, but another race is already on for many losers, retirees and defectors from the Clinton Administration, and it ends in the corporate board room. A few companies have put out the word that they would like political insiders on their boards -- despite investor questions about such celebrity directors -- executive recruiters say.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: Much of Mosle's argument hangs on a single unexamined anecdote about the failure of ''methods'' proposed in a teacher-training course -- like hands-on learning in science. Her boat story ends in a description of messy little hands and nay-saying colleagues, without a single reference to whether or not the students actually learned anything. Yes, it was messy, but the first thing I would have asked is, What did they they find out about buoyancy? And what did she learn about teaching?

title: Scenic Mountains Scarred by Illegal Border Crossings
description: In some canyons, it looks as if hundreds of Hansels and Gretels have scattered trails of trash behind them, marking the route from Tijuana.

title: Cincinnati Doings
description: To the Editor: Several weeks ago we visited Cincinnati and attended two excellent productions at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, the premiere of ''The Notebook of Trigorin,'' the Tennessee Williams adaptation of ''The Seagull,'' with Lynn Redgrave, and the premiere of ''Songplay,'' the songs and music of Kurt Weill.

title: Alma Kitchell, Radio Pioneer, Then a TV One, Dies at 103
description: Alma Kitchell, a pioneering radio singer who became a pioneering talk show host, sang in the first televised opera and capped her career by presiding over the first television cooking show, died on Wednesday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 103.

title: Global Forces Batter Politics
description: THROUGHOUT much of the world today, politics lags behind economics, like a horse and buggy haplessly trailing a sports car. While politicians go through the motions of national elections -- offering chimerical programs and slogans -- world markets, the Internet and the furious pace of trade involve people in a global game in which elected representatives figure as little more than bit players. Hence the prevailing sense, in America and Europe, that politicians and ideologies are either uninteresting or irrelevant.

title: 'Hair' in a New Style for the 90's
description: HAIR'' in 1996?

title: No Special Pool
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bugs and Michael Work the Fast Break
description: Swingers

title: For a Staunch Republican, Ousting a Rival Superseded Party Unity
description: Over the years, Arthur Bramwell has become accustomed to being something of a standout.

title: In Africa, Peacekeeping Is Too Little, Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL ROADS LEAD TO MINTZ
description: I am offended by the notion that the United States has no national cuisine (Food: ''All Roads Lead to Mintz,'' by Molly O'Neill, Oct. 27). We may not have the long culinary tradition of a country like France, but there are many dishes besides hamburgers (some of them very fine) that are found only in this country (or are prepared in an unusual way here). Some examples are fruit breads (zucchini or banana), blueberry or corn muffins, Boston baked beans, fried chicken and biscuits, boiled lobster with drawn butter, Maryland soft-shell crabs, pancakes served with maple syrup, corn on the cob and the various kinds of chili that originated in the Southwest but are now eaten all over the country. Cheddar cheese and Monterey Jack are as American as brie is French. We have characteristic American pastries -- brownies and apple, Key lime and pecan pies.

title: Glen Stein and Patricia VanDeMark
description: Dr. Patricia Beck VanDeMark, a pediatric anesthesiologist at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York, is to be married today to Glen Richard Stein, a vice president in the investment banking group at Prudential Securities in New York. Rabbi Melissa Crespy is to perform the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Cincinnati Doings
description: To the Editor: Former and current Cincinnatians must have loved What's Doing in Cincinnati (Oct. 13). But your correspondent left out a few key items:

title: Tax Refund Ruling: Shoreham Revenge
description: FOLLOWING the brief diversion of a national election, attention on Long Island has turned again to the Shoreham nuclear power plant, an enduring nemesis with an astounding ability to torment years after its gates shut forever.

title: Mute Inglorious Wizards
description: NARCISSISM AND PHILANTHROPY

title: Doing the Numbers: 20 Years of Change
Dripping With Customer Service
description: THE hotel was part of a national chain renowned for the quality of its accommodations, and the Houston version was no different. Everything was attractive; everything was clean. I enjoyed the restaurant and bar. When it was time to leave I pressed the appropriate buttons on the TV to tell the desk I was on my way out, and the hotel could charge my bill to the same credit card I showed when I arrived.

title: U.S., Hands Off Guam! (Please?)
description: PERHAPS if Guam contacted Japan or China, asking to be invaded, its complaints would be taken more seriously by Americans. But Guam is a dependable American base, ever loyal, and no one in Washington pays attention to a quiet little mouse. So these days, the mouse is wondering whether to roar.

title: A Preservationist's List of 35 Modern Landmarks-in-Waiting
description: Following is the complete list of candidates for landmark status and their architects suggested by Robert A. M. Stern, discussed in the Postings column on page 1 today:

title: Denizens of the Okavango Delta
description: BARRIE and Elaine Pryce have opposite theories about how to maneuver their outboard dinghy through a herd of half submerged and grumpy hippopotamus. Barrie barges ahead full throttle, confident that the animals will get out of his way. Elaine prefers to slow down and pick her way between the slicks left where the animals submerge. Either system seems to work. Their boat has never been overturned.

title: Irwin Brodsky, 86, Expert on Stock Tax
description: Irwin A. Brodsky, who began his career as a messenger at the Wall Street firm of J. W. Seligman & Company and rose to become its general manager, died of cancer on Nov. 7 at Franklin General Hospital in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: The Trials of Victimhood
description: The Oklahoma City bombing trial is proving to be an awkward test case for the victims'-rights movement. When Congress passed the Victims Rights and Restitution Act of 1990, it probably never envisioned a calamity that would produce more than 1,200 ''victims'' (blast survivors and surviving family members), each with the right to attend all criminal proceedings. But Richard Matsch, the U.S. District Court judge running the case in Denver, has insisted that his duty to give defendants a fair trial is paramount, an attitude that has riled many victims and family members.

title: Speak of the Devil
description: BEHIND THE CRYSTAL BALL

title: From Field and Stream to House and Street
description: When I was growing up in Flemington in the 1970's, we bought our eggs from the Cervenkas' farm up the road. Once a week, we drove down the long lane between cornfields to where the farm buildings sat. Next to the barn was an egg room, with a cold cement floor that smelled of straw. My sisters and I would count out the eggs while our mother talked with Mrs. Cervenka.

title: Janet Reno's Future
description: The big jobs at the Defense and State Departments are getting most of the attention in the Cabinet shuffling game that is now under way. But from the standpoint of political sensitivity and ethics, President Clinton faces no more important decision than whether to allow Janet Reno to remain as Attorney General.

title: Beguiled By Asian Influences
description: YOU have learned to love lemon grass, to cook with coriander, to eat ginger chicken and banana-leaf rice. Your home has a futon, rattan chairs, a Japanese paper screen.

title: Jets Lack Leadership, And the Losses Mount
description: ''Isn't there anyone here to kick 'em?'' Donald Evans wondered after he became a Jet in 1994. ''They just accept losing. You need some monster bad guy around here.''

title: Pain in the Knees
description: To the Editor: I was most interested in reading ''Carry-On Bags'' in Letters on Travel (Sept. 29). This problem is second only to the ones created for me by the discourtesy that too many passengers exhibit.

title: Agency's Exit Derails Dream
description: At various times over the past decade or so, the city and the state touted grand plans to develop the Brooklyn waterfront. And each time, it seemed, a problem cropped up to thwart those plans.

title: Singers in Recital, Dancers on Stage
description: THE singing season has arrived. This afternoon at 3, Mozart is the composer as the Danbury Concert Chorus and Symphony perform the Coronation Mass, Veni Sanctus Spiritus, Regina Coeli and Ave Verum Corpus at St. Peter's Church. The soprano (and New Haven resident) Barbara Yeichner is soloist, with James Papp (a graduate of Danbury High School, now choral music director at Fairfield High) on the podium. There is no admission charge, but donations will be received.

title: Crew Overreached by Suspending Bronx Board, U.S. Rules
description: The Justice Department has dealt Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew a major blow in his continuing struggle to control the city's troubled school districts by ruling that he overreached his authority last summer when he suspended the entire school board of District 12 in the South Bronx and blocked its appointment of a superintendent.

title: Fade to Black?
description: AT 87, Steve D'Inzillo can still rally as loud and strong as he did half a century ago when he led hundreds of the rank and file into the great strike of 1937. Wearing an eye patch and a hearing aid, his fist raised toward the dingy ceiling of union headquarters in Times Square, Mr. D'Inzillo shouted into his microphone the other day: ''We are facing a crisis never before faced by this union. We are on the verge of extinction!''

title: Why They Lose It at the Movies
description: Moviegoing has always had an intensity that goes beyond the film at hand. The longtime film critic Roger Ebert of The Chicago Sun-Times explores this subject in ''Roger Ebert's Book of Film,'' an anthology of writing on movies that will be published tomorrow by W. W. Norton. This article is adapted from Mr. Ebert's introduction to the volume and from his introduction to one of the excerpts.

title: Amy P. Dennin, William R. Kolb
description: Amy Patricia Dennin, the daughter of Rita and Lawrence P. Dennin of Norwalk, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Robert Kolb, a son of Geraldine and Robert F. Kolb of Brookfield, Wis. The Rev. Walter C. Orlowski performed the ceremony at St. Matthew Roman Catholic Church.

title: Genetic Potential
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bridge to Past Tense
description: NOWHERE WAS THE drug issue of greater concern in the recent Presidential campaign than among grammarians. When President Clinton was asked in the second joint TV appearance why he had delayed for three years a bill requiring certain warning labeling on cigarettes, he replied: ''We took comments, as we always do, and there were tens of thousands of comments about how we ought to do it. That's what drug it out.''

title: Bad Teeth, Calculated Malice And Other Stops Along Memory Lane
description: THE death of Alger Hiss last week at the age of 92 was the last chapter in one of the nation's most bizarre and contentious espionage cases, one that led to the perjury conviction of Mr. Hiss in 1950 after a former Soviet agent, Whittaker Chambers, accused him of being a Communist spy while working for the State Department in the 1930's. Mr. Hiss spent the rest of his life denying the charge.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: From Room to Room
description: Interior decoration, when honed to a highly refined art, invariably involves folding the past into the present. In my own obsession to study, copy and learn from the beautiful rooms of Nancy Lancaster, Lee Radziwill and Min Hogg, pictured on these pages, I long ago discovered that the same pieces of furniture appear again and again in their homes, like the faces of old friends peering out from yellowed photographs.

title: Tracey Gray and Jeffrey Goodman
description: Tracey Robin Gray, a daughter of Wendy and Harold B. Gray of Jericho, L.I., was married last evening to Jeffrey Mark Goodman, the son of Marilyn Goodman and Justice Budd G. Goodman, both of New York. Rabbi Michael Katz officiated at Temple Israel of Great Neck, L.I.

title: A Re-Inventor of His World and Himself
description: PAISLEY PARK, THE STUDIO COMPLEX Prince built in this Minneapolis suburb, is abuzz. On a 10,000-square-foot sound stage, workmen are rolling white paint onto a huge runway of a set, preparing it for a video shoot later in the day. In a mirrored studio down the hall, two dozen dancers are rehearsing. Upstairs, an Olympic gymnast, Dominique Dawes, is trying on a wispy lavender costume. A sound engineer is editing a promotional CD; a graphics artist is putting the final touches on a logo. Through it all strolls the man in charge, attentive to every detail. A hole in the gymnast's leotard? A bit of choreography that needs broadening? As songwriter, video director and record-company head, he takes responsibility for everything, makes all the final decisions and couldn't be happier about it.

title: Jackson Hole: The Thrills Feel Seismic
description: THE little 19-seat propeller plane took off from Denver into clouds trailing a spring storm, and followed the Continental Divide northwest to Jackson Hole, Wyo. Over the Wind River mountains the clouds began to shred; I saw veins of creeks and bonelike ridges of conifers black against fresh snow. Skiing through that snow would be as light as flying through these clouds.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 17, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 8 THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (Viking, $23.95.) Murder results when sons in line to inherit a family fortune seek their long-missing black sheep brother. 3 3 6 DESPERATION, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) Visitors to a small mining town in Nevada encounter terrifying forces. 4 4 3 MY GAL SUNDAY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) (+) 3 3 35 THE ZONE, by Barry Sears with Bill Lawren. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $23.) Diets to prevent disease and enhance mental health. (+) 4 4 32 SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+)

title: Her Brother's Keeper
description: A QUIET LIFE

title: Senators Score Three in Third to Beat Isles
description: Hold Zigmund Palffy and his linemates scoreless and one thing is fairly certain: the Islanders are in trouble.

title: Decisions On Trustees Are Ahead For Fidelity
description: THE board of Fidelity Investments, which oversees Fidelity's empire of 236 mutual funds, with assets of $427 billion, will soon get its first new members in three years.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: TV Detective Is Feeding Soul Fusion to Theatergoers

title: A Young Comic On Cosby's Turf
description: LAST SUMMER, WHEN the producers of Bill Cosby's new sitcom, ''Cosby,'' offered Doug E. Doug a major role in the CBS series, the young man accepted without qualms. A stand-up comedian who starred in the popular Disney movie ''Cool Runnings'' in 1993 and briefly had a sitcom himself that year, he felt more than ready to hold his own in prime time.

title: Oil-Patch Bargain? Looking at a Union Pacific Spinoff
description: LAST winter may have been a dispiriting one for most large American oil companies, but their stocks have gushed up nicely since April. No wonder: energy prices have soared and the industry's cost-cutting measures have borne fruit.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SHOWTUNE

title: Last Laugh
description: NEW JERSEY: Landfill of Opportunity.'' No more.

title: A Boy in Drag: Three Views
description: To the Editor:

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: BILL GATES EXPRESS

title: Mary P. Mullen, Harold J. Burstein
description: Dr. Mary Patricia Mullen, a chief resident in medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital, and Dr. Harold John Burstein, a fellow in medical oncology at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, both in Boston, are to be married today in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. John MacInnis is to perform the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church.

title: Book Details Klan Role in Smithtown's Past
description: SOME residents of Smithtown have been shocked to learn that their town was once a gathering place for the Ku Klux Klan.

title: The Inside Track for Cable
description: THERE'S A TELEVISION SOAP NOW playing in New York that deserves to play nationally, in prime time. Corporate barons as rich and shifty as those who once populated ''Dallas'' are wildly battling over media turf, terrain that promises to gush gold for much of the next century.

title: When One Good Turn Deserves Another
description: THE sky is blue, the few remaining leaves are brown and the passenger is quickly turning green.

title: A Blast From the Icy Past
description: Something old is new again. The 1960's fitted short coat has returned, balanced with skinny pants, giving a fresh silhouette to a coat style originally designed for the miniskirts and bell bottoms of the Age of Aquarius.

title: Almost-Expected Collision
description: The 349 victims of the world's worst mid-air collision between two passenger aircraft -- a Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and a Kazakstan Airlines Ilyushin-76 -- were still lying in the smoldering wreckage when a torrent of accusations made it plain that pilots flying into New Delhi, and the air traffic controllers guiding them, were less surprised that the crash had occurred than by the fact that it had not come sooner.

title: A Time of Growth in Museums and Galleries
description: IF the visual arts are demonstratively more visible in New Jersey now than they were 20 years ago, the change is largely due to a single bold stroke. In 1987, voters approved by a 2-to-1 margin a bond issue that, in part, authorized the New Jersey State Council on the Arts to give $40 million to cultural institutions. Much of the money has gone to art museums and alternative spaces. In a sense, an era of expansiveness has concluded, for the last of the money was dispensed in July.

title: Some Reactions On Breast Cancer
description: In the Nov. 3 letter to the editor from Marilie Gammon, Ph.D., responding to the article ''I Got Breast Cancer, Why Me?'', she states that only two factors listed by Ms. Tusiani -- early menarche and family history -- have been clearly associated with an increased risk for breast cancer. Dr. Gammon evidently missed two items listed by Ms, Tusiani -- X-rays and CAT scans, which are sources of ''ionizing radiation,'' a nonhereditary, nonreproductive-related, scientifically established risk factor for breast cancer. In fact, an internationally recognized expert on radiation health effects, John W. Gofman, M.D., Ph.D., has calculated in his book ''Preventing Breast Cancer: The Story of a Major, Proven, Preventable Cause of This Disease,'' that, during the years 1920-1960, exposure to medical X-rays where the breasts were in the field of exposure, especially at younger ages, is responsible, along with co-factors, for a large share of the current breast cancer epidemic in the United States.

title: Northern Exposure
description: WHERE are you from?''

title: Linda Danovitch and Peter Bicks
description: Linda Ann Danovitch, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart H. Danovitch of Washington, was married there yesterday to Peter Andrews Bicks, a son of Robert A. Bicks of New York and the late Patricia Bicks.

title: Author of 'Primary Colors' Talks Politics
description: IF not for a teacher who inspired him to write, Joe Klein says he would not be what he is today -- a well-known political reporter and columnist and as ''Anonymous,'' the author of the recent best seller ''Primary Colors.''

title: On the Wings of Hawks, Good Environmental Tidings
description: I parked my car but did not walk up to the hawk-watching platform at Cape May Point State Park, not yet. Instead I stepped to the sighting board for the seasonal tally of migrating hawks is maintained.

title: H.M.O.'s Using Federal Law to Deflect Malpractice Suits
description: Health maintenance organizations, which care for more than 60 million people, are telling courts across the country that they cannot be held responsible for medical malpractice in cases involving patients who receive care through employer-sponsored health plans.

title: What Backlash?
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Lost in Park May Get Harder
description: It's easy to get lost in Central Park, and to some it's even fun, but come Spring, three-sided kiosks showing maps, park attractions and rules will make the park a lot easier to navigate. Eventually, 42 signs are planned for the park's interior and perimeter.

title: Has Wealth Ruined Chile? Neighbors Think So
description: On a recent flight to Santiago, two young Chilean executives sitting in first class sipped champagne to celebrate a big business deal they had just closed in Buenos Aires.

title: New York Hype
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: County Sees a Resurgence in Office Space
description: THE forlorn steel skeleton of 287 Corporate Plaza, a visible symbol of the recession from Exit 5 of the Cross Westchester Expressway, is now in the process of being transformed into a 133,000-square-foot, state-of-the-art office building more than a decade after the original work began.

title: The Knicks Can't Seem to Get a Grip
description: For the Knicks, winning ugly is still in style.

title: Electronic Spin Doctors for Cars
description: IMAGINE you are driving down an icy road and another vehicle pulls into your lane. You swerve, but your car fishtails, perhaps sending you into a spin.

title: Seats on Too Many Boards Spell Problems for Investors
description: TO shareholders weary of watching corporate mishaps with little, if any, discernible intervention from boards, all directors are suspect. But some, to paraphrase George Orwell, are more suspect than others.

title: Columbia Is a Winner But Is Not a Champion
description: Columbia began its season with great promise, winning its first six games. With that early success came hopes of an Ivy League title, and with the hopes came pressure -- something not usually felt by Columbia, with its long tradition of losing.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Suspect With a Lengthy Record Is Charged in a Queens Killing
description: A man with a long criminal history has been charged with murdering a woman in Far Rockaway, Queens, on Saturday, the authorities said.

title: The Companies Want to Know: Like a Little Cyber in Your Cafe?
description: First they put computers where we work, then they pushed computers where we live. Now, the computer companies are going after us where we eat and drink.

title: Tobacco's Pros and Cons on the Web
description: Joe Camel and the Marlboro man seem to be everywhere, from billboards to racing cars, but they're missing in action on the World Wide Web. Tobacco companies say they have avoided the Internet as part of a campaign to convince regulators that their advertising is not aimed at teen-agers.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Tapping His Way From Africa

title: France for the French? A Test of Voters' Testiness
description: A political and economic stalemate afflicts all of France these days, and this city of 36,000 people, 45 miles west of Paris, exemplifies it.

title: Magazines Increasingly Lend Titles to Other Products
description: Better Homes and Gardens greeting cards, real estate services, garden centers. Popular Mechanics plumbing supplies, work boots, stock-car racing videos. Martha Stewart Living painted flower buckets and cake decorating kits. Harper's Bazaar beach towels. Family Circle classical music CD's.

title: A Sampler at Barnard
description: Four choreographers were represented on a program presented by the Barnard College dance department on Saturday night at Miller Theater at Columbia University. And so it was surprising how many of the dances looked similarly disaffected, filled with rising and drooping young female bodies.

title: For Offbeat Casting, This Is the Man to Call
description: The Vampire situation is looking good. Against the odds, Bernard Telsey, the casting director for ''Rent,'' has found a quorum of 15 doo-wop-proficient Hispanic actors to play the members of the Vampire gang in the workshop version of Paul Simon's new musical, ''The Capeman.'' Not easy. Now there's a new problem. Who will play Lazarus? More to the point, who is this guy Lazarus anyway?

title: A Canadian Duo Unafraid to Sing About Hard Facts
description: You can always count on Kate and Anna McGarrigle to get down to basics on at least one song on an album. And on ''Matapedia'' (Rykodisc), the Canadian duo's first recording in six years, their new song ''Why Must We Die?'' poses ultimate questions in spare, sinewy verses. ''We are meat, we are spirit/We have blood and we have grace,'' begins this unsentimental hearthside ballad that becomes a blunt, understated cry to the heavens.

title: C.I.A. Employee Is Accused Of Giving Secrets to Russians
description: Federal authorities have arrested a career employee of the Central Intelligence Agency on charges of passing highly classified information to Russia for several years, law-enforcement officials said tonight.

title: Another Battle Begins Over Fire Boxes, as Critics Attack the One-Button System
description: Nearly seven months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council ended an almost two-year battle with a compromise to shrink the city's fire alarm box system, the administration's efforts to shape a new system have started yet another fight.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: A Party of Movements,

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The New Pentagon Reality Behind McDonnell's Loss

title: Say Yes to Superstores
description: New Yorkers like to think of themselves as trend setters in shopping, but in one crucial respect they have been behind the times. Only recently have big ''super stores,'' long popular throughout the country and in the suburbs, appeared in city neighborhoods. Now Mayor Rudolph Giuliani wants to make it easier for stores like Kmart, Home Depot and others to be built on city sites currently zoned for manufacturing. The City Council is resisting, in part because its members rely on political contributions from small retailers in their districts. The Mayor's approach is basically sound, however. There may be room for refinements, but the Council should give its approval.

title: Accounts
description: * Tia's Tex-Mex Restaurants, Dallas, a unit of Ruby Tuesday Inc., to Berry-Brown Advertising, Dallas, to handle advertising and marketing, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: The likely new sheriff in Broadcast Town is less industry friendly than the last.
description: FOR the network anchors, the defeat of Senator Larry Pressler on Nov. 5 injected a rare note of drama into an otherwise humdrum night of election coverage. On an evening when the G.O.P. solidifed its grasp on the United States Senate, Mr. Pressler, a Republican from South Dakota, was the sole G.O.P. incumbent to lose his seat.

title: Russia's Mars Craft Fails and Crashes in Southern Pacific
description: The remnants of an unmanned Russian space probe that failed to break out of Earth's orbit re-entered the atmosphere above the southern Pacific Ocean west of South America tonight and apparently crashed into the sea, American officials said.

title: The Hispanic Political Tide
description: Bob Dole received a smaller proportion of the Hispanic vote than any Republican Presidential candidate in 25 years, and that is bad news for the G.O.P..

title: Speak Softly But Carry A Big Wallet
description: THE caprice of American politics. Where else but in a country enamored of both populism and wealth could a super-rich Republican persuade Democratic New York City to turn its government upside down?

title: B. J. Magness, 72, Is Dead; Company Became Cable Giant
description: Bob John Magness, 72, a onetime cottonseed salesman who mortgaged a cattle ranch to start a business that grew into Tele-Communications Inc., one of the nation's biggest cable companies, died Friday in the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville. He was the chairman of the corporation, which is based in Englewood, Colo.

title: An Odd Rift Develops Between an Author and Borders, a Chain Promoting His Book
description: Ever since he filmed the docu-comedy ''Roger and Me'' at the nadir of the 1980's recession, Michael Moore has gained fame and money playing the guileless Everyman who skewers corporate America. Little did he suspect that an Everyman corporation might someday skewer back.

title: Springsteen Makes Amends
description: Some Asbury Park residents were a bit bitter when the local hero Bruce Springsteen chose Freehold as the spot for his first small-venue concert in the area earlier this month. They need not have been concerned. Mr. Springsteen, a longtime local fixture and mythologizer of the Boardwalk whose first album was called ''Greetings From Asbury Park,'' will perform at Asbury Park's recently remodeled Paramount Theater on Nov. 25 and 26, the ticket agency Ticketmaster said yesterday. The concerts will benefit the Boys and Girls Club of Monmouth County, club officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Are These the Super Broncos?
description: AS the Broncos trooped into their locker room after yesterday's 34-8 thumping of the Patriots, several were smiling and shouting, ''10 and 1, baby, 10 and 1.''

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Pushing Hard and Sending

title: Deciding Which Patients to Save
description: The board of the organization that decides who gets liver transplants voted last week to change its rules for patients facing imminent death. Those who might benefit the most will go ahead of others who are also very sick but less likely to benefit. In many regions there are not enough livers for every patient who needs a transplant. Rationing is inevitable. But the prospect of weighing one patient's survival against another is an ethical quagmire. The board of the United Network for Organ Sharing deserves credit for tackling the troubling issue, though some experts say its recommendations come up short.

title: Refugee Flow Into Rwanda Said to Slow In Third Day
description: For a third straight day, hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees trudged back into their homeland today, part of a column of people nearly 40 miles long snaking into the green hills of this Central African country.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Hard-Liners Are Regarded as Likely To Succeed Croatia's Ailing President
description: The passing of President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, who lies seriously ill with cancer in a Washington hospital, would probably strengthen hard-line nationalists who are openly hostile to the American-brokered Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia and who care little for democracy, say Western diplomats here.

title: Profit Squeeze for Publishers Makes Tenure More Elusive
description: Michael Parkhurst knew that his doctoral dissertation on the German sociologist and philosopher Theodor Adorno would not compete for sales with Oprah and Dennis Rodman.

title: Allegations on Tests Prompt Blood Center Investigation
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration and the Manhattan District Attorney's office are conducting criminal inquiries into allegations that the New York Blood Center, which supplies about 80 percent of the blood to New York City hospitals, manipulated some test results on blood donations being screened for H.I.V., hepatitis and other infectious agents.

title: Costly Clout for Drug Makers
description: New Jersey's biggest industry is not shy when it comes to lobbying, Federal finance reports show. The state's pharmaceutical companies spent more than $5 million during the first half of this year to make sure they were heard in Washington, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Merck and Company spent $1.98 million on lobbying from Jan. 1 to June 30, while Johnson & Johnson spent $860,000 and Schering-Plough spent $800,000. Drug makers weighed in on issues as varied as Medicare, trade with China, immigration reform and patent laws. The companies' lobbying successes included changes to the Food and Drug Administration and preserving tax credits.

title: Tenants Are Anxious as Group Returns
description: A week after the police raided the headquarters of a heavily armed fringe group in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, some group members were back yesterday, busily bagging leaves, sweeping, painting -- and making some of their tenants and neighbors exceedingly nervous.

title: Maximizing Mozart And Taking On Verdi
description: Right now, Renee Fleming seems to be doing just about everything right. On Saturday evening the American soprano sang Fiordiligi in the Metropolitan Opera's first performance this season of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte.'' Her lustrous, nuanced performance was a demonstration of what is possible when a gifted singer nurtures her voice, chooses roles wisely and takes chances without being reckless.

title: Hatred at Large
description: ''IFOR has succeeded beyond our expectations,'' President Clinton said last week. He was announcing that U.S. troops will remain in Bosnia for a year or more after the Implementation Force overseeing the Dayton agreement ends its mission next month.

title: No Headline
description: ''The odds are that fewer Miltonists will get tenure; before long, there won't be enough around to train the next generation.'' JAMES SHAPIRO, of Columbia University, lamenting cutbacks by university presses. $(A14:4$)

title: The Personal, the Political And Where They Meet
description: Billy Bragg, the radical, sentimental cockney busker, is back with a new album, ''William Bloke'' (Elektra) after a four-year break. It was a paternity leave to raise a boy named Jack, and in a solo performance at the Beacon Theater on Friday night, he was at pains to demonstrate that he hadn't gone soft. He sang about a new ''socialism of the heart''; he lambasted a friend who had compromised his ideals and his vote after having a child: ''Where are the principles of the friend I thought I knew?/I guess you let them fade from red to blue.''

title: Step Aside? Who, Me?
description: ATransit Authority worker in an orange vest -- part of New York City's new campaign to speed up the subway system -- approaches you at a crowded subway stop at rush hour. ''I'm gonna ask you to step aside so passengers can get off the train,'' he says.

title: Microsoft Sees Big Internet Loss
description: Microsoft says it will probably lose more than $1 billion over the next three years on its Internet and news services before they broke even.

title: Quality of Life Is Up for Many Blacks, Data Say
description: Four years ago, officials here in Marion County decided to make an all-out effort to curb the stubbornly high level of births among unmarried women, a problem that affected a cross-section of the county, but was particularly acute for blacks.

title: State Senate Debates Welfare
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed welfare overhaul will be taken up -- and possibly voted on -- today by two State Senate committees. The Governor's plan would shift about $150 million in government spending into child care, job training and transportation programs to help move welfare recipients into the workplace in accordance with new Federal welfare policy.

title: U.S. Shifting Its Payments to Direct Deposit
description: The Federal Government is scrambling to find ways to force all recipients of its money -- from the most sophisticated military contractor to the oldest Social Security pensioner -- to receive payments electronically rather than by paper checks.

title: No Points for Style, but Jets Make Losing an Art
description: The Jets continued their wild ride to nowhere today. But say this for the team with the National Football League's worst record -- it makes losing entertaining, even compelling.

title: Reeves Was the Last To Know About Peter
description: Even as they traveled here to the desert, some 2,500 miles from New York, the Giants continued to take heat for their decision to sign Christian Peter, the Nebraska defensive lineman who has been a pariah in the National Football League since the Patriots drafted him last spring and then reneged on his rights because of his violent behavior toward women.

title: Columbia's Tuition
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: You've seen the movie. Now eat the dinner.

title: As the Shoreham Well Runs Dry, a School District Struggles With the Bottom Line
description: It seemed too good to be true. For two decades, the small but growing school district here reaped a tax bonanza from a large property, enabling educators to finance their dream programs.

title: Traffic Deaths by Distraction
description: If you are reading this sentence while driving a car, please put the newspaper down or pull over. According to the State Division of Highway Traffic Safety, the leading cause of fatal traffic accidents in New Jersey last year was not drunken driving, speeding or inclement weather, but simple inattentiveness. Of 719 fatal accidents, 154 were caused by drivers engaged in such distractions as using a car phone, combing hair or reading, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Drunken driving caused 115 of the fatal accidents.

title: 'Food Summit' Ends With Usual Earnest Vows
description: The World Food Summit, probably the last of the decade's United Nations-sponsored international gatherings, ended here today on familiar notes: a vague pledge to do better, sharp words from poor nations against rich ones, Vatican opposition to population control and American reservations about an internationally recognized right to be fed.

title: Waiting for Clinton: Allies Still Hope for U.S. Leadership in Crises
description: After a hard campaign, President Clinton wanted a vacation. He is in Hawaii now, but only after a confusing week of crisis management and personnel decisions that left him looking buffeted by events, rather than using his new mandate to take charge of them.

title: With an All-New Cast
description: O.K., so I won by eight points, and all those polls showing an 18-point spread right up through the final weekend were wrong. It's a lucky thing the Republicans never knew they were in single-digit range, and the media were misled by those polls into thinking it was no real horse race.

title: Denver Riding High After Its 10th Victory
description: When you get one team playing at 10 miles per hour and the other at 100 m.p.h., when you get one team making the game look so cumbersome while the other team makes everything look so fluid, you get 34-8.

title: Russia's Mars Probe Drops Back to Earth
