description: A Russian space probe aimed at Mars failed to break out of orbit after being launched yesterday, and its remnants plunged back to Earth and into the South Pacific, American officials said.

title: Power Lines and Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: A small thing like a new bump maker might make mountains if understood differently.
description: ALTHOUGH the Patent and Trademark Office awards about 2,000 patents each week, only occasionally do they include breakthrough devices not thought of before, like the telephone, or brilliant adaptations of everyday items, like the intermittent windshield wiper.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results yesterday misstated a number drawn in the Connecticut Cash Lotto for Nov. 16. It was 35, not 3. A corrected listing appears today on page B8.

title: Foundation Sends Out A Lifeline To Libraries
description: In a time of high-profile philanthropy, it did not look like much: a library table covered with $927.20 worth of new children's books. The 62 titles ranged from ''Armadillo Rodeo'' to ''My Rotten, Redheaded Older Brother.''

title: Schools Chief Vows to Press Battle on Troubled Districts
description: From a Brooklyn church pulpit, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew vowed yesterday to continue his battle against troubled school districts despite a Federal ruling last week that said he overstepped his authority in removing several ousted board members in the South Bronx.

title: Apple Software Leader Quits; New Questions for Company
description: The executive in charge of Apple Computer's troubled operating systems division for the last two years resigned Friday, raising new questions about the company's ability to sort out its problems and differentiate its Macintosh operating system from Microsoft's Windows 95 program.

title: OPPOSITION LOOMS FOR WELFARE BILL OFFERED BY PATAKI
description: Now that Gov. George E. Pataki has released his long-awaited plan to reconstruct the state's $4 billion welfare system, the debate has shifted to the Legislature, where many Democrats are already vowing to block major portions of his initiative.

title: Artists are trying to enhance the image of the ho-hum enhanced CD.
description: THE so-called enhanced CD, which records digital music, graphics and video on the same disk, generated so little spark when it hit the market two years ago that it did not even deserve to be called a flash in the pan. But because of the pervasiveness of computer CD-ROM drives and the creative perversity of independent artists and entrepreneurs, the idea may yet ignite.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
description: A partial list for this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: Boycott of Texaco Is Seen as Focusing on Wrong Target
description: Kenny Smith, a black copy-machine technician, had heard the Rev. Jesse Jackson urge people to boycott Texaco stations to protest Texaco's treatment of its minority employees.

title: Don't Bank on Iron to Curb Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind McDonnell Loss, New Military Reality
description: When the Pentagon dropped the McDonnell Douglas Corporation from the field of competitors to build a new multipurpose combat aircraft, it was signaling in as dramatic a fashion as possible that the old networks and priorities of what President Dwight D. Eisenhower once called the military-industrial complex have been overtaken by a new reality.

title: Please Keep Off Bus Stop
description: Bernard Uleano's front yard may not be a bus stop for much longer. The Teaneck Township Council is scheduled to take a preliminary vote tomorrow on a measure to remove a New Jersey Transit stop from a public right of way that cuts into Mr. Uleano's property.

title: U.S. Publications Focusing on Africa Fade
description: Crises in Africa, like the current troubles in Zaire and Rwanda, are one of the few guaranteed ways the continent draws media attention, as representatives of relief agencies, governments and sometimes international military forces descend and try to cope with the situation.

title: Teen-Age Crime Starts Long Before Teens
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: DANNY GLOVER, the actor, knew William M. Kunstler, the lawyer, only in passing. But he was always an ardent admirer of the late Mr. Kunstler, whose clients varied from the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Chicago Seven to the Black Panthers and some of the suspects in the World Trade Center bombing.

title: Democratic Committee Drops Fund-Raiser Who Is Under Fire
description: The Democratic National Committee said today that, as part of its post-election cutbacks, it had dismissed John Huang, the senior fund-raiser who was suspended last month following reports that he had solicited hundreds of thousands of dollars in questionable contributions.

title: A U.S.-British Assault on High Phone Rates
description: Some might call it a British-American attack on Europe. United States officials say it is more like a liberation campaign -- from the astronomical telephone prices charged by monopoly telephone companies on the European Continent.

title: Teen-Age Sweethearts Charged With Murdering Their Baby
description: Last winter, before the nightmare began, they were high school sweethearts in the wealthy suburbs of Bergen County, N.J. He was co-captain of the soccer team, she a promising artist. Their world was one of lavish homes with manicured lawns, expensive cars and caring families who valued education. They would graduate in May, go to college in September. Horizons seemed unlimited.

title: Bridge
description: The race to win the most master points in a year, once called the McKenney championship and now named the Barry Crane Top 500, is regularly dominated by professionals from the West Coast and the Southwest. Jim Becker's victory in 1991 was the only East Coast success in the last 35 years.

title: Redskins Make a Stand, and Stand Alone
description: It had been so embarrassing a week ago, surrendering 522 passing yards to Boomer Esiason and the Arizona Cardinals, losing the game and, in the eyes of many, any legitimacy as heirs to the wobbly crown in the National Football Conference's Eastern Division.

title: Some Patients Object to Rule Change on Who Gets Scarce Livers
description: The decision to move people with chronic liver disease out of the most urgent category on the waiting list for transplants has alarmed patients and angered some doctors, highlighting longstanding disagreements in the field about the fairest way to dole out the nation's insufficient supply of donated livers.

title: 'Guy in the Highchair' Is Getting Care He Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Aims to Regain Semiconductor Leadership
description: Japan's Government and semiconductor manufacturers are starting a series of consortiums and cooperative research programs on a scale not seen since the project two decades ago that catapulted this nation into the front ranks of the world's computer chip producers.

title: Remedial Education Mess Isn't Court's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hand-Held Computer Is Introduced Once Again
description: Ever since John Sculley, Apple Computer Inc.'s former chairman, coined the term personal digital assistant to describe a new breed of hand-held computers that he promised would revolutionize modern society, the computer industry has been struggling to live up to Mr. Sculley's vision.

title: Memory and Desire: Hearing Eliot's Passion
description: A chatty observation about the weather isn't the worst way to get a conversation going, even if you're all alone on a dark, ratty stage that looks like a fire trap.

title: Credit Offerings During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Islanders Trade Kasparaitis for Smolinski
description: It took Mike Milbury about two months. But the coach and general manager of the Islanders finally got his man.

title: Non-Communist Is Elected Romania's Leader
description: After seven years of government rooted in the Communist past of the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Romanians made a clear break today and elected a mild-mannered geology professor and reformer, Emile Constantinescu, as President.

title: Museums Speak in Celebrity Voices
description: In a darkened room at the American Museum of Natural History, visitors exploring ''Leonardo's Codex Leicester: A Masterpiece of Science'' watch an eight-minute film explaining the backward scrawl and intricate drawings that fill the 18 unbound sheets of one of Leonardo da Vinci's notebooks. The narrator's voice is Italian and terribly sexy:

title: On Prison Computer, Files to Make Parents Shiver
description: Anchored to the windswept prairie by a grain elevator and a dead-end railroad track, this town of 900 people seems as remote from the dark side of cyberspace as it is from the lights of Times Square.

title: Conservative Republicans Gained in Northeast
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: You've seen the movie. Now eat the dinner.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: One Vote for News On Grander Themes
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial of a Deposed Leader Offers Contrasting Views of the Latin Kings
description: There is plenty of grisly drama inside a Federal courtroom in Manhattan where Luis Felipe, also known as King Blood, is on trial on charges of orchestrating the murder of his rivals from a prison cell in upstate New York.

title: Stanford and UConn Live Up to Rankings
description: That wasn't the Final Four of women's college basketball on ESPN yesterday. It only looked like it.

title: Transit Prepares for Winter
description: Let it snow, New Jersey Transit officials say: the agency's 820 trains and 1,900 buses are ready for winter. Workers have changed fluids and tires, checked out special signaling equipment and outfitted train cars with winter brake shoes.

title: Aches and All, Graf Set To Defend Garden Title
description: After two years without a sponsor, the event that declares the ''world champion'' of women's tennis -- known for most of its 18 years as the Virginia Slims Championships but now called the Chase Championships -- has a new sponsor and a new tournament director but the same address: Madison Square Garden.

title: Bridge
description: The race to win the most master points in a year, once called the McKenney championship and now named the Barry Crane Top 500, is regularly dominated by professionals from the West Coast and the Southwest. Jim Becker's victory in 1991 was the only East Coast success in the last 35 years.

title: Equity Offerings That Are Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Japan Increases Its Surplus in U.S. Trade
description: Japan's surplus in merchandise trade with the United States grew for the first time since February 1995, the Finance Ministry said today, as a falling yen led Japanese auto makers to increase exports.

title: Eastern Europe's Practical Voters
description: A wave of elections held in formerly Communist Europe in the last few months confirms that the new democracies there have found a new ideology -- competence. Incumbents lost in almost every fair election. Most were former Communists who came to power over the last few years in victories that suggested Eastern Europeans were nostalgic for Communism. Now it seems that in all these elections voters were searching for clean and effective government.

title: How a Landmark of American Merchandising Deflated Its Own Balloon
description: THE RAIN ON MACY'S PARADE

title: Two New Standards For Wireless in Duel
description: At a cellular telecommunications convention this spring in Dallas, the head of Primeco Personal Communications made a bold prediction for his company's introduction of the new type of wireless telephone service known as P.C.S.

title: Ayer Promotes 2 Creative Directors
description: N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York promoted two top creative executives to share responsibilities overseeing the agency's creative output.

title: New Type of Fire Box Is Assailed for Delays
description: Nearly seven months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council ended an almost two-year battle with a compromise to shrink the city's fire alarm box system, the administration's efforts to shape a new system have started yet another fight.

title: An Elephant's Tale
description: The cigarettes are awfully cute. They're called Jumbos and there is an elephant on the front and the back of the box. On the side is a little man in the moon blowing smoke rings. And on each individual cigarette, where the brand name usually goes, is a tiny drawing of an elephant.

title: Arriving Rwandans Find Home Not So Sweet
description: It was a bittersweet homecoming for Magdalena Nyirandeme. Like thousands of other Rwandan Hutu refugees, she shuffled into her home village on Saturday night with her few belongings propped on her head. Her nine hungry children stumbled behind her.

title: Childs Is Close to Returning
description: The Knicks (7-2) hope Chris Childs will be ready to rejoin them when they meet the Magic tomorrow night in Orlando.

title: Playoff Hopes Have Vanished For the Giants
description: One thing the Giants players say they will not do, no matter how depressed and devastated they seem to be now, is quit.

title: Research firms say they can tell companies if sponsoring an event is worth the money.
description: WHEN the Federal Express Corporation paid $2.5 million to become the official sponsor of the Orange Bowl, it wanted to know whether it was getting its money's worth.

title: Holtz Drops Hints, But Gives No Answer To the Big Question
description: Lou Holtz, choosing his words with uncharacteristic restraint, sounded more and more like someone putting his house in order yesterday. But the worst-kept secret in football remained that way.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Report of Lights In Area of Crash
description: A flight crew reported seeing lights streaking in the sky while flying Saturday night off the southeastern coast of Long Island, in the general area where Trans World Airlines Flight 800 crashed, investigators said yesterday. Investigators said there were meteor showers visible in the area that night.

title: Purcell's Evocation Of Dido's Doomed Love
description: Scrambling to fill its schedule on an ever leaner budget, PBS's ''Great Performances'' tonight reaches back to the 17th century with a production, made for the BBC and WNET, of Henry Purcell's only opera, ''Dido and Aeneas.''

title: In Irish Jail, Jets and Sharks Rumble Again
description: Outside the high stone walls of Mountjoy Prison, Ireland is engaged in a national debate over what to do about rising crime. But inside the gray walls of the 600-inmate prison two gangs of prisoners were allowed to stomp each other for about two hours on Saturday night as guards stood and watched and the audience, including the American Ambassador, Jean Kennedy Smith, sat and applauded.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the settlement in the racial discrimination lawsuit against Texaco Inc. misstated the surname of one plaintiff in some editions. A picture caption with the continuation of the article repeated the error in some editions. The plaintiff is Sil Chambers, not Roberts.

title: Cutting Federal Deficit to Zero Is a Good Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: An Illness Pivotal for Balkans

title: The Ever-Shifting Paradigm of Trade Shows
description: The computer industry has about 900 events a year, not counting swap meets, user group gatherings, chat room mixers and private conferences. Amongst these events are the big trade shows like Comdex, Interop and Windows World. Comdex, which begins its annual meeting today, is the big daddy with about 200,000 showgoers hoping to do a deal, meet a contact, sight Bill Gates and maybe learn something.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Rocks Come to Life and Giggle

title: Virginia Cherrill, 88, Actress in 30's Films, Including 'City Lights'
description: Virginia Cherrill, a 1930's actress who starred as a beautiful, blind flower girl in the classic Charlie Chaplin silent film ''City Lights'' (1931), died late Thursday in a hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 88 and had settled in Santa Barbara in 1950.

title: Packard Bell Hires Saatchi Executive
description: Mike Gold, former president of the New York office of the M & C Saatchi Agency, has joined a client, Packard Bell NEC Inc., in the new position of senior vice president for advertising and corporate communications.

title: Its Leader Dead, a Fringe Group Lives On
description: Even as a young man -- before he formally declared war on northern California -- Gerald William Doeden was known as a fast-talking con artist who got away with cashing checks in bars signed ''Jesus H. Christ'' and could quote Shakespeare from memory by the yard.

title: Valuejet and a Contractor Are Due to Face Each Other
description: Top executives of Valujet Airlines and Sabretech, the two companies that blame each other for the crash of a Valujet DC-9 in the Everglades last May, will testify this week at hearings by the National Transportation Safety Board that are expected to be far more confrontational than most plane crash inquiries.

title: Eager Germans Drive Up Deutsche Telekom on Opening Day
description: It just goes to show what a little salesmanship can do.

title: Trial Begins for 2 in Arson Killing of Token Booth Clerk
description: On the chilly night of Nov. 26, 1995, Harry P. Kaufman emerged from the inferno of a Brooklyn subway station and stumbled into the arms of a police officer, screaming: ''They blew up my booth! I can't believe they blew me out of my booth!''

title: Treasury Prices Post Slight Drop
description: Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday, as a lack of economic data and the prospect of auctions later this week discouraged active buying.

title: Eftsoons and All That
description: I took the bridge to the 21st century and ere long an antique traveler met I thereon. And a glittering eye had he.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO., New York, named John McDonnell chief financial officer of its travel related services unit, which includes its charge and credit card operations. Mr. McDonnell, who has been at the company since 1978, was previously senior vice president and corporate comptroller for information delivery.

title: Friesz and Brown Out for Season
description: Seattle Seahawks quarterback JOHN FRIESZ broke a bone in his right leg and will miss the remainder of the season. Friesz began the season as RICK MIRER's backup, but, after the team went 1-4, Friesz started the next six games, winning four of them. Friesz apparently sustained the injury late in the first quarter of a 17-16 loss Sunday to Detroit, Coach DENNIS ERICKSON said yesterday.

title: Sale of Truck Stake Aids Profit at Investor A.B.
description: Investor A.B., the main financial vehicle of the Wallenberg family of Sweden, said yesterday that its nine-month profit more than quintupled after it sold half of the truck and bus maker Scania A.B. Pretax profit rose to 11.591 billion kronor ($1.76 billion). The results included a one-time gain of 12.4 billion kronor ($1.88 billion) from the Scania sale in April. Net profit rose to 11.354 billion kronor ($1.72 billion), from 2.064 billion kronor in the first nine months of last year. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Pipeline Set To Expedite Kazakstan Oil
description: Major oil companies and the Governments of Russia, Kazakstan and Oman have agreed to build a $1.5 billion pipeline, clearing a bottleneck that has prevented large amounts of the Central Asian republic's oil from reaching Western markets.

title: California's Good Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: No Restrictions Planned On Bus-Subway Transfers
description: Starting next July, riders who use Metrocard will be able to transfer free between any subway line and any bus route, transit officials have decided, after concluding that a transfer restricted to certain changes in direction could be too complex for them to handle and for riders to understand.

title: Blood Center Is Reviewing Its Procedures
description: The New York Blood Center said yesterday that it would immediately review its procedures in response to Federal and state investigations into possible problems with the center's methods of screening donated blood for infection.

title: Israel to Expand Jewish Settlement in West Bank
description: Taking another step to enlarge Jewish settlements in the West Bank, the Israeli Defense Minister has approved plans for a major expansion of the Orthodox town of Immanuel, authorizing construction that would more than double its population.

title: Paradise Lost: Biosphere Retooled as Atmospheric Nightmare
description: The exotic species of ant known as Paratrechina longicornus, or the crazy ant, named for its speedy and erratic behavior when excited, somehow managed to kill off all the other ants over the years, as well as the crickets and grasshoppers.

title: Wyndham Hotel Purchase
description: The Wyndham Hotel Company said today that it would buy the Doubletree Hotel in Salt Lake City from City Hotels S.A., a Belgian real estate company, for $44 million. Under the deal, which is expected to close in January, the hotel's name will be changed to the Wyndham brand name. Wyndham, a hotel operator based in Dallas, said it would upgrade the hotel's 381 rooms.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BIRMINGHAM STEEL CORP., Birmingham, Ala., signed a definitive agreement to acquire the assets of Ivaco Inc.'s steel plant in Cartersville, Ga., for about $43 million in cash through a newly formed joint venture with Ivaco. The joint venture will be called Birmingham Southeast L.L.C.

title: GOODYEAR TO BUY 60% OF SOUTH AFRICAN TIRE MAKER
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company agreed yesterday to pay about $121 million for 60 percent of Contred, a tire division of South Africa-based Anglovall Industries. Goodyear said the purchase price included assumed loans; a factory in Uitaenhage, Cape Province, that was bought from Goodyear in 1989; a chain of 195 retail stores, and a retreading operation with 41 plants. Contred's combined sales for the year ended June 30 were $400 million, according to Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio. The acquisition is part of Goodyear's plan to smooth over earnings cycles by broadening its geographic base.

title: British Gas Shares Soar; Possible Shell Bid Is Seen
description: The shares of British Gas P.L.C. soared in heavy trading yesterday after reports that the company was in merger talks with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. Over the weekend, a newspaper, The Sunday Telegraph, reported that Shell had prepared secret documents detailing a proposed takeover and had discussed them with British Gas's chairman, Richard Giordano.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the involvement of Apple Computer Inc. and the Intel Corporation in technology theme restaurants and coffee shops misspelled the given name of a founder of Electronic Cafe International. He is Kit Galloway, not Kip.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on Sunday in the Arts and Leisure section misidentified the group that is to appear on Thursday at 8 P.M. at the Landon Gallery, 1926 Broadway at 64th Street. It is the Concert Royal. (The Bachanalia Festival Orchestra is to appear at the gallery this Sunday.)

title: Fiat Operating Profit Off 32% in 9 Months
description: Struggling with a weak Italian car market, Fiat S.p.A. reported yesterday that its operating profit fell 32 percent for the first nine months of the year. The Turin-based auto maker blamed sagging sales in Italy and a slowdown in demand for industrial vehicles. It also cited strong price competition from rivals and costs associated with new models.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Industrials Slip 1.12 As Profit Taking Halts Rally

title: Untamed Politically, but Not as Preachy
description: How could you miss in America with a guy like Tom, a self-made owner of an empire of upscale restaurants who believes in the overriding merit of hard work, revels in his rat-race survival with limousines and designer casual wear, and attracts a lover 20 years his junior?

title: Typical Relief Check This Year Was Worth Half That of 1970
description: Cash welfare benefits in the typical state have lost half their purchasing power in the last quarter-century, a Congressional committee reported today.

title: Spy Suspect Seemed Like the Best and the Brightest
description: Very few people at the Central Intelligence Agency rise from trainee to station chief in a decade, but Harold J. Nicholson did.

title: Tone It Down, He Urged Hemingway
description: THE ONLY THING THAT COUNTS

title: Driver Fleeing Police In a Stolen Truck Kills Two in Newark
description: A woman and her daughter were killed in Newark yesterday when the driver of a stolen tractor-trailer cab slammed into their car as he tried to escape the police, officials said.

title: In the Land of the Big Ditch, le Carre's in Hot Water
description: Throughout his career, the British novelist John le Carre has always focused on the big issues: the cold war, the arms trade, the collapse of the Soviet bloc. So when he began spending time here a couple of years ago, Panama's upper crust felt flattered that their little country had become the object of his attentions.

title: Argentina Battles Outbreak Of Deadly Rodent-Borne Virus
description: Argentina is struggling to control a deadly outbreak of a rodent-borne virus that has killed seven people in the last three months and left five others in danger of death.

title: Patterns
description: Edgy Men's Wear at Barneys

title: For Retailers, Sheer Is Impractical
description: When the last breast was bared and the final derriere exposed by the wave of transparent clothes shown on runways in the spring ready-to-wear collections, retailers went back to showrooms to put the pencil on their orders for clothes that will carry the weight of the spring season.

title: Dinkins Under Lights Again on Crown Heights
description: Nearly three years after he left office, former Mayor David N. Dinkins was sharply questioned once again yesterday about his handling of the 1991 Crown Heights racial violence, as part of a lawsuit by Hasidic Jews who contend that Mr. Dinkins initially withheld police protection from Hasidic victims.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about ambulette service for disabled Medicaid patients in New York misstated what one user said about the Metropolitan Transit Authority's bus service for such patients. The user, Kathleen Egan, said she was often unable to reserve a seat, not that she was never able.

title: Canadians Keep Pressing for African Aid Mission
description: As support dwindled among allied nations and resistance grew at home, Canadian leaders tried today to keep alive the international aid mission they planned to lead in Central Africa.

title: Close Aide to Clinton Urged Less Candor Over Indonesian
description: In the final days of the campaign, the White House withheld major details of the discussions between President Clinton and a prominent Indonesian family despite recommendations for fuller disclosure by the two lawyers on the White House team that was created to handle such sensitive political inquiries, Administration officials say.

title: People
description: David Ward was named to the new position of senior vice president, responsible for media and the primary research departments at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston. He had been senior vice president and strategic planning director at Bozell Worldwide, New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Why Suspect Valujet Cargo Got Aboard
description: The old airliner equipment suspected of setting Valujet Flight 592 on fire, causing the Everglades crash that killed all 110 people aboard, had sat harmlessly for months on a shelf at a maintenance contractor's hangar here in Miami, according to documents released today.

title: Cable-Phone Concern Gets A Setback
description: The RCN Corporation, a fledgling media company that is challenging Time Warner and Nynex in the cable and telephone business, faces a murky future after the Government rejected an application by one of its sister companies to transmit video over telephone wires.

title: Reduce the Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Company Tests
description: MOST major pharmaceutical companies report a surge in research on new psychiatric drugs.

title: Huber Is Upset by Majoli in Chase Opener
description: Last year Anke Huber pounded the blue tennis carpet at Madison Square Garden so relentlessly that she came close to toppling Steffi Graf in their five-set marathon final to decide the winner of these coveted year-end championships.

title: Claude Ake, 57, Nigerian Scholar and Activist
description: Claude Ake, a prominent Nigerian political scientist who was a visiting professor at Yale, died on Nov. 7 when the Boeing 727 on which he was a passenger crashed into a lagoon in a mangrove jungle 25 miles northeast of Lagos, Nigeria. He was 57, and his permanent home was in Port Harcourt, Nigeria.

title: Europe Fights Child Labor in Rug Making
description: Listening to the radio two years ago, Jacques Zwahlen heard news that led him to believe that a new venture designed to lift his company like a magic carpet might also have the potential for a crash landing.

title: U.S. STANDS ALONE AGAINST U.N. CHIEF
description: The United States stood defiantly alone today in its opposition to Boutros Boutros-Ghali as the Security Council began the process of selecting the Secretary General who will lead the United Nations into the next century.

title: The Joys of News Radio For the Home Computer
description: IS your computer ready for news, all the time? Airmedia Live broadcasts bulletins over the airwaves otherwise used by pagers. To pluck the data from the ether takes the Newscatcher, a pyramidal receiver about four inches tall from Global Village Communication Inc. The device demands a computer with Windows 95, 16 megabytes of RAM, 30 megabytes of disk space and a free serial port; it costs about $150, including one year of basic service.

title: Jury Gets Immigration Case
description: Deliberations began yesterday in the trial of the third-ranking immigration official in New Jersey, who is charged with falsifying documents that enabled aliens to enter the country illegally. Prosecutors said John F. Lonergan, a supervisor in the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Newark office, accepted gifts from immigration brokers in return for helping their clients enter the country. But the defense said the case was based mainly on allegations by an informant who has served time for perjury. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Japan's Best Player Seeks a Life Beyond the Top 10 of Tennis at the Age of 26
description: At 26, Kimiko Date is a youthful yet unrepentant retiree who finds the prospect of tuning out tennis after an unanticipated climb into the top 10 intoxicating. Not to mention logical. To her, it makes perfect sense to quit while she's ahead.

title: Old House Will Travel, By Barge
description: Anthony Quinn looked it over but ultimately settled for a more secluded getaway in Rhode Island. Diana Ross was said to have expressed some interest but quickly backed off.

title: Hailing 1,150 New Jobs
description: Two major corporations will expand their operations in New Jersey, bringing 1,150 new jobs to the state, Governor Whitman said yesterday. Lucent Technologies, the state's third-largest employer, with a work force of 1,750, will open two new high-technology centers in Piscataway and Eatontown, the Governor said.

title: U.S. Backs Safir on Sending Police to Dominican Republic
description: The Clinton Administration yesterday publicly endorsed an initiative by the New York City Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, to station a few police officers in the Dominican Republic to aid in the investigations of drug dealers who operate there and in New York City.

title: After 11 Seasons, the Holtz Era at Notre Dame Will End
description: Lou Holtz has informed at least two of his superiors that he plans to step down as coach of the Notre Dame football team. After more than four days of intense speculation about his future, Holtz will make his resignation public at a news conference this afternoon. He may pursue a job with the Minnesota Vikings.

title: African Self-Sufficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Lines and Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Help Still Needed in Central Africa
description: The refugee crisis in Central Africa is eased but not over. Substantial American help is still needed. But with relief agencies now able to reach about half the refugees without security escorts, the need for United States military forces needs to be carefully reassessed.

title: Female Legislators Push Generals for Answers
description: Venting the anger of Congress for the first time since a major scandal about sex abuse in the Army became public 10 days ago, a dozen female House members challenged four top Army generals today about widespread cases of sexual assault and harassment and said they would pay close attention to the Army's response.

title: Failing L.I. Aquarium Sheds Name and Debt
description: With the help of antibiotics and 15 pounds of fresh mackerel and herring a day, a harbor seal found stranded and near death six months ago on a Long Island beach is about to be set free.

title: Losses May Signal End of Gambling's Lucky Run
description: The congregation's opinion of gambling fitted as snugly with the Rev. David Hatfield's view as his low-slung brick church did with the neat houses across the road. The members of the Woodland Heights Baptist Church did not need much persuading that casinos were bad.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about an investigation against an Italian magistrate who led an inquiry into widespread Government corruption misstated the date of the beginning of the broader scandal. It was 1992, not 1991.

title: Feat of the Minuscule: Scientists Make Abacus With Carbon Molecules
description: SCIENTISTS in Switzerland have invented an ultraminiature abacus, in which spherical carbon molecules sliding along microscopic copper grooves act as the counting beads for performing arithmetic calculations.

title: Yankees on 'Seinfeld'
description: Still basking in celebrity because of the Yankees' World Series victory, BERNIE WILLIAMS and DEREK JETER will appear in Thursday night's episode of ''Seinfeld,'' playing themselves on the NBC comedy series.

title: Cordell Hull Reagon, Civil Rights Singer, Dies at 53
description: Cordell Hull Reagon, whose powerful tenor voice spread the message of the civil rights movement throughout the United States and Canada in the 1960's as a member of the Freedom Singers of the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, was found dead on Nov. 12 in his apartment in Berkeley, Calif. He was 53.

title: Mystery of Russian Spacecraft: How Did It Fall Back to Earth?
description: One day after a plutonium-carrying Russian spacecraft was reported to have landed harmlessly in the Pacific Ocean, a mystery emerged about when it re-entered the atmosphere and where it fell.

title: Beyond Those Satin Innuendoes
description: The first unexpected exposure of naked skin in the new production of Noel Coward's ''Present Laughter,'' a play never before known for its anatomical explicitness, occurs very early in the first act. What is seen is only a bare, middle-aged midriff. But in Coward's world, where silk pajamas are usually as close as one gets to the altogether, it's like sipping from a Champagne glass and discovering it's been filled with straight gin.

title: It's a Challenge to Get Third Graders Up to Standard
description: These are critical days for Ted Kesler and the 32 children in his Upper West Side classroom.

title: Kellogg Will Buy Lender's Bagels From Kraft
description: Expanding its presence in breakfast foods, the Kellogg Company said yesterday that it would buy Lender's Bagels from Kraft Foods Inc. for $455 million.

title: Sport as Big Business Takes Toll on Big Ten
description: Bill Mallory shed tears at Indiana. Jim Wacker held back tears in Minneapolis. Jim Colletto stepped aside gracefully at Purdue. Lou Tepper was firmly shown the door at Illinois.

title: Newborn Boy Found Dead in L.I. Movie Theater
description: A cleaner found the body of a newborn in a movie theater restroom this morning, and the authorities said the infant had died of asphyxiation.

title: Nobel Laureate Fears a Ban on Co-Winner
description: An exiled East Timorese independence activist who shares this year's Nobel Peace Prize with a Roman Catholic Bishop from East Timor fears his co-laureate may be prevented from traveling to Oslo to accept the award on Dec. 10, or barred from returning to Indonesia if he makes the trip.

title: Hearing Personalities Evolve
description: Sonny Rollins

title: A Surprise in Toyland: Mattel to Buy Tyco
description: Barbie will now drive a Matchbox car into the future.

title: Physicists Invent Lens for Focusing X-Rays
description: A TEAM of physicists in France and Russia has invented a new kind of lens that promises to make X-ray focusing easier, cheaper and accessible to many more users than in the past.

title: Beethoven, Stripped Of Modern Luxuries
description: Anyone who has ever told an anecdote knows that stories about the past have lives in the present. In the telling, details change to fit the teller. Secondhand accounts become firsthand; friends of friends are now personal friends; wished-for retorts are fantasized into real ones. Playing old music is anecdotal, too. Two concerts over the weekend by Nikolaus Harnoncourt and the Chamber Orchestra of Europe -- part of a five-event survey of the Beethoven symphonies at Carnegie Hall -- showed us this.

title: Stocks Climb in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks closed higher today after giving up ground in the two previous sessions. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was ahead 159.51 points, or more than seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,955.88. The Nikkei closed down 133.36 points on Monday and declined by 101.31 points on Friday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHARLES ANSON, the press secretary to QUEEN ELIZABETH II, has resigned to become a group corporate relations director at Grand Metropolitan, the British food and drink conglomerate, according to yesterday's edition of The Evening Standard of London. Instead of coping with the continuing fallout from the collapsed marriages of Princes Charles and Andrew, Mr. Anson will handle the accounts of companies like Burger King, Haagen-Dazs and Smirnoff. In his new job, which is to begin on Feb. 1, Mr. Anson will be paid more than $332,000 a year, according to The Standard.

title: Big Japanese Property Company Is Bankrupt
description: One of Japan's flashiest real estate companies was forced into bankruptcy today, with more than $6 billion in bad debts, heightening concerns about the impact on the financial institutions that are owed the money.

title: Jets, Battered in Body and Mind, Are Still Soul-Searching
description: What do you expect when your quarterback gets hit in the jaw and swallows a tooth? It's life as a Jet.

title: South Africa Ebola Scare Eases; Case Tied to Gabon
description: A brief panic over the first appearance of Ebola fever in South Africa seemed to abate today when officials said they had discovered the source: a doctor from Gabon who was treated in a Johannesburg hospital three weeks ago.

title: Shanahan Is Making the Difference for Denver
description: Scan the Denver Broncos' roster, and there is little there to scare you. This is not the most talented team in the National Football League. Yet, with five games to play, the Broncos are 10-1. And their only loss was by 3 points at Kansas City eight games ago. Denver has even atoned for that by hammering the Chiefs in the rematch, 34-7.

title: Book Publisher
description: To the Editor:

title: Exodus From Zairian Camps Left Many Refugees Behind
description: The river of refugees returning to Rwanda dwindled to a trickle today, but another half-million remained cut off from international aid, somewhere in the hills and valleys around Bukavu in the south.

title: Biker Gets Mixed Verdict
description: A Gloucester County jury acquitted a motorcycle gang member yesterday of intentionally killing a police sergeant during a routine traffic stop in May 1995, and was unable to reach a verdict on a felony murder charge, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Glow of Health, With Help
description: It used to be that a woman powdered her face to reduce shine. But the latest trend is to enhance shine -- or glow, as the beauty experts prefer to say. The idea is not to look sweaty, but healthy and outdoorsy.

title: Van Gundy Delivers A Message To Starters
description: Jeff Van Gundy is more interested in smoothing over the rough spots than he is in demolition. He likes some of what he sees in some of his starters, namely Patrick Ewing. But he is not enthralled by the play of several others immediately after tip-off.

title: W. R. GRACE IN FIRST OF FOUR PLANNED UNIT SALES
description: W. R. Grace & Company agreed yesterday to sell its Amicon unit to the Millipore Corporation for $125 million in cash. Amicon, based in Beverly, Mass., makes molecular separation and purification products, and has annual sales of about $60 million. The deal would expand Millipore's business of analyzing and purifying liquids. Millipore, based in Bedford, Mass., had 1995 sales of $595 million. The deal with Millipore follows Grace's announcement last month that it would sell four businesses for more than $300 million. Grace, based in Boca Raton, Fla., also plans to sell Grace TEC Systems, Grace Specialty Polymers and Grace Cocoa.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Police Search Nationwide for Student Accused of Murdering His Baby
description: The college student accused of helping his girlfriend kill their newborn son after she gave birth in a Delaware motel room was the subject of a nationwide police search last night after he failed to surrender to face murder charges.

title: Helping Shakespeare Make an Easy Crossing
description: Americans are still touchy about their right and readiness to do Shakespeare (among other classics). In turn, the English can be lofty and possessive. But as Gertrude Stein said, they have their own history of their literature, and that is their own affair.

title: INSIDE
description: Revisiting the Valujet Crash

title: OFFICIALS OUTLINE 2-YEAR BETRAYAL WITHIN THE C.I.A.
description: Federal authorities said today that a Central Intelligence Agency career officer charged with spying for Moscow offered himself to Russian intelligence officials two years ago at the height of the furor over the C.I.A.'s last major espionage case.

title: No Headline
description: ''It's nice to have another specimen and from another part of the anatomy. I think we now know Homo existed probably as early as 2.5 million years ago.''

title: Supreme Court Upholds Police Methods in Vehicle Drug Searches
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that once the police have stopped a car for a traffic infraction, they may go on to request the driver's permission to search the car for drugs without first informing him that the routine stop is over and that he is, in fact, free to go on his way.

title: Booksellers End 3-Year Lawsuit
description: Ending nearly three years of litigation between publishers and bookstores, the American Booksellers Association said yesterday that it had settled an antitrust lawsuit against Random House.

title: Children's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Just the Facts
description: Long before Israel's election last spring, Benjamin Netanyahu's enemies, homegrown and Western, warned that if he won the economy of Israel would swiftly be shot to bits.

title: Jaguars Release Rison
description: ANDRE RISON, a four-time Pro Bowl receiver signed by the Jacksonville Jaguars to boost their passing game, was released yesterday for what Coach TOM COUGHLIN described as a lack of performance.

title: TEXACO STOCK SKIDS AFTER SETTLEMENT TERMS DISCLOSED
description: Shares of Texaco Inc. fell sharply yesterday, as investors reacted to an offer of more than $140 million to settle a race-discrimination lawsuit. Shares fell $2.75, or 2.7 percent, to $98.375, wiping out a gain made on Friday, the day the settlement was announced. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed until after the stock market closed on Friday. ''Investors are having second thoughts on the settlement,'' said George Friesen, an analyst with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Romania's Anti-Communist Revolutionary
description: To many Romanians the triumphal victory of Emil Constantinescu, the bearded academic elected President on Sunday, and the clean sweep that his opposition party made from top to bottom in Romanian politics mean the final completion of a democratic revolution that they believe was stolen from them seven years ago.

title: Who Spends More
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERMET TO ACQUIRE SUDBURY FOR $195 MILLION
description: The Intermet Corporation said late yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sudbury Inc. for $195 million, expanding its position as the nation's largest independent casting foundry. Intermet would pay $12.50 a share for each of Sudbury's 15.6 million shares. The price is a 25 percent premium to Sudbury's closing price of $10. The combined company would have annual sales of $845 million, 56 percent more than Intermet's 1995 revenue of $541 million. Sudbury, based in Cleveland, supplies parts and services to the automotive industry. Intermet, based in Troy, Mich., makes iron castings used in brake parts, steering components and other auto parts as well as for construction equipment and air conditioners. The deal was announced after the close of the market. Shares of Intermet fell 25 cents yesterday, to $12.25.

title: Research on Brain Leads to Pursuit Of Designer Drugs
description: MOVE over Prozac, Xanax and all the other balms for the distressed in current vogue: scientists are heralding a new generation of designer drugs, psychiatric medications more powerful, quicker acting and with fewer unwanted effects.

title: New Bird Found in Brazil Forest Owes Survival to Cocoa
description: OVER the last decade, some 20 new bird species have been found in the remote tropical forests of South America. None of them, however, have astonished scientists quite like an acrobatic treetop species with bubble gum-pink bill and legs that has been found nesting along one of Brazil's busiest highways, and owes its survival to the human craving for chocolate.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review of ''The Waste Land'' on Monday misstated the nationality of the actress Fiona Shaw. She is Irish, not English.

title: GTE-Air Force Contract
description: The GTE Corporation said today that it had received a contract worth up to $400 million to provide support for all management information systems at 20 Air Force sites in the United States. GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., said the contract's value would depend on the number of tasks performed at each site. Work is expected to be completed in November 2001. GTE will provide services for communications and computer systems.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Flees the Law
description: Convicted of fraud and corruption and apparently distraught over a pending Federal prison sentence, Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., a former Somerset County prosecutor, snipped off an electronic bracelet that monitored his confinement at home yesterday, disappeared in his car and was declared a fugitive from justice, the police said. Mr. Bissell had been scheduled to be sentenced tomorrow. $(Page A1.$)

title: Auto Industry 'Celebrity' Followed by Controversy
description: Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua is probably the auto industry's closest approximation of a celebrity, though whether of the Bonnie and Clyde variety, or the Einstein, is hotly debated, particularly in Detroit.

title: Separate Trade Pact by Canada and Chile
description: Bypassing a deadlock in Washington over whether to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to include Chile, Canada today signed its own accord to open trade with Chile.

title: Heat Names Pfund General Manager
description: The Miami Heat hired RANDY PFUND as general manager yesterday and announced the resignation of DAVE WOHL, executive vice president of basketball operations.

title: Welfare Proposals Softened
description: Two State Senate committees approved a package of bills yesterday that would make major changes in the state's welfare system. With some exceptions, welfare recipients would be required to take a job or join a government work program within two years and would be denied benefits after five years.

title: Is VW's New Plant Lean, Or Just Mean?
description: At first glance, the work force at Volkswagen's truck and bus factory here seems like any other, clad in unremarkable gray uniforms. But look at the pockets, and you will see the key to what Volkswagen executives call the factory of the future. The names stitched there are Rockwell, Cummins, Remon and MWM. What are conspicuously scarce are Volkswagen workers.

title: Falcons' Odomes Injured in Crash
description: NATE ODOMES of the Atlanta Falcons was charged with drunken driving yesterday after an early-morning crash in which his Porsche slammed into a tree in the suburbs north of Atlanta. The accident occurred less than 24 hours after he started at cornerback in a 17-15 victory over the New Orleans Saints.

title: Q&A
description: Cryptozoology

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: N.C.A.A. Tournament

title: Faced With Prison, Ex-Prosecutor Flees Home in New Jersey
description: Convicted of mail fraud, embezzlement and abuse of power, and facing a sentence of at least eight years in a Federal prison, a former prosecutor today snipped off an electronic bracelet that monitored his confinement at home, disappeared in his car and was declared a fugitive from justice.

title: Virtual Casinos, Real Stakes
description: Same scams, different medium. That's what I thought as I perused the Internet on my home computer one sleepless night 18 months ago, and found the same kind of phony cancer cures and get-rich-quick schemes I have prosecuted for years under state consumer fraud laws.

title: Althea Gibson's Long Days
description: DAVE,'' the woman with a frail voice said over the telephone, ''I'm dying.''

title: In Newly Released Tapes, Nixon Is Heard Grasping for Reassurance
description: The National Archives today made available for public listening audiotapes made covertly in the White House from 1971 to 1973 that show an unguarded President Richard M. Nixon veering abruptly from moments of maudlin self-pity to sometimes profane defiance as he tried to contain the Watergate scandal.

title: A. S. Blumberg, 75, Professor Concerned With Equal Justice
description: Abraham Samuel Blumberg, a prominent criminologist and sociologist whose provocative opinions of law enforcement and the legal establishment drew the wrath of J. Edgar Hoover, died on Nov. 11 at the Pacific Regent Health Center in San Diego. A resident of San Diego for the last 10 years, he was 75.

title: Toys 'R' Us: Peak Season All This Year
description: Toys ''R'' Us has reached the top of some fairly big hills this fall. In October, it acquired Baby Superstores for $407 million in stock, eliminating a competitor and considerably accelerating the growth of its own Babies ''R'' Us stores. A new format, Kidsworld -- an emporium of everything from diapers to Barbie dolls to pacifiers -- has been introduced to great fanfare.

title: Shift in Zoning On Megastores Is Challenged
description: Nearly two years ago, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed sweeping zoning changes that would allow huge warehouse-style stores to move into New York City's manufacturing areas, he called the changes a key component of his plans to revive the city's economy by adding jobs, raising new tax revenue and keeping consumers from spending money in the suburbs.

title: First Chicago in Asian Alliance With Bank
description: The First Chicago NBD Corporation said today that it would form an alliance with Standard Chartered P.L.C. of Britain that gives First Chicago customers access to banking services in the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Mets' Hundley Undergoes Surgery
description: Mets catcher TODD HUNDLEY is expected to be in good health by spring training after undergoing surgery to remove a bone spur from his left wrist yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan.

title: No Impromptu Request
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Deadline on Conrail Unfair, Witness Says
description: CSX Corporation's proposal to acquire Conrail Inc. for $8.5 billion will succeed unless a deadline of Wednesday is removed, an expert witness for the Norfolk Southern Corporation said today in Federal court.

title: N.B.A. Time Tunnel: Half-Century Is a Half-Truth
description: ''The N.B.A. at 50'' is catchy and marketable and wrong. Sure, the National Basketball Association's says it is 50, but it's really 47. To believe the N.B.A. is 50 is to celebrate the United States Bicentennial in 1973 or mark George Burns's centenary at 97. It's a slam dunk on Father Time.

title: Solidity, Versatility and Economy
description: WE were prepared to say nice things about Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh Performa 6400/ 200 computer when all of a sudden Apple cut the price. Now we are compelled to say even nicer things about it.

title: LESLIE FAY TO SPIN OFF SASSCO DIVISION
description: As part of its reorganization plan, the Leslie Fay Companies, based in New York, said yesterday that it would spin off its Sassco apparel division and distribute new shares of Leslie Fay to creditors. Leslie Fay, the women's apparel company that filed for bankruptcy protection in 1993, filed its reorganization plan yesterday with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The filing said the company would distribute 3.4 million new Leslie Fay shares and would keep its main divisions, which include Nipon, Outlander and Castleberry. The Sassco division would assume the unit's debt. Leslie Fay will seek court approval on Thursday for its plan to exit Chapter 11.

title: Russia's Loose Uranium
description: ''Loose Nukes'' begins with the warning that chaos and corruption in the new Russia are putting tons of nuclear material at risk and devotes much of the rest of the hour to reports of smuggling. The detective work of Sherry Jones, though inconclusive about the sources of the uranium and plutonium that have been spirited to Germany and Czechoslovakia, is loaded with suspicion that Russian scientists are in on it and Russian officials are covering up.

title: Chief Executive Named at Thompson
description: Chris Jones, co-president of the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York, has officially been named as chief executive, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Jones, 41, will succeed Burt Manning, 65, who will continue as chairman. As co-president, Mr. Jones had shared responsibilities with Peter Schweitzer, 57, who will become the sole president as he continues as the global business director on the agency's Ford Motor Company account.

title: LOCTITE RECOMMENDS REJECTION OF HENKEL BUYOUT BID
description: The Loctite Corporation of Hartford said yesterday that a special committee of its board had recommended that shareholders reject an unsolicited buyout offer of $57.75 a share, or $1.1 billion, from Henkel K.G.a.A. Both companies specialize in adhesives. Loctite said the Henkel offer did not fully account for the benefits that Henkel, based in Dusseldorf, Germany, would receive, and that it was seeking other potential buyers in an effort to sell the company at a price ''that fully reflects its value.'' On the New York Stock Exchange, Loctite's shares were unchanged yesterday at $59.875.

title: State Closes Another Well
description: State officials have closed a second well in Toms River after finding a ''fragment of a molecule that may be associated with'' a cancer-causing agent, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The chemical, acrylonitrile, is found in a material used to make coffee cups, pen barrels and airline trays.

title: Reeves And Young Drifting Apart
description: A day after the Giants' uninspired 31-23 loss to the Arizona Cardinals, the relationship between Coach Dan Reeves and the front office seemed to unravel a bit more.

title: Schools Investigation Widens
description: Thirty-four more Newark public school employees, including 25 teachers, were suspended with pay yesterday in the continuing investigation of an insurance fraud scheme. Twenty-five other school employees were suspended last month.

title: Zaire Rescue Still Depends on Military Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Leaders Of Democrats In the House Are Re-elected
description: House Democrats re-elected Representative Richard A. Gephardt as minority leader today, and he pronounced them ''excited about our win in 1996.''

title: Chess
description: Two improbable winners tied for first place in the elite Fontys International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, in late October: Boris Gelfand of Belarus and Jeroen Piket of the host country. Each scored 7-4 and got a prize of $11,810.

title: Correction
description: A letter yesterday concerning a 1985 Supreme Court decision on providing remedial education services to parochial school students referred incorrectly to a religious group. The organization is Agudath Israel of America, not Agudath of Israel.

title: Genuine Appreciation Fostered by Bogus Art
description: The allure of the fake hangs over art as over no other aspect of culture. A composer who copies is quickly forgotten; a writer who does the same is dismissed as a plagiarist. But an art forger has the quality of a brilliant rogue about him, a person who has somehow managed to foil the system. His works may be admired grudgingly, but they are still admired. To make an Old Master painting, or a Greek vase, or a Roman bust so good that it can fool the experts is something of an achievement, a very different thing from copying Mozart's notes or Shakespeare's lines.

title: Ousted School Officials Return, But Crew, Digging In, Bars Them
description: Preparing for a showdown over his authority to control the city's troubled school districts, Chancellor Rudy Crew bucked a Justice Department decision yesterday and refused to let school board members he had suspended in the South Bronx enter the school district offices.

title: 2.3-Million-Year-Old Jaw Extends Human Family
description: An upper jaw found in the Hadar badlands of northern Ethiopia is being hailed as the most convincing and earliest definitively dated fossil of the genus Homo, to which living humans belong.

title: Pacers Start Off By Playing Catch-Up
description: The best thing the Indiana Pacers can say about their season is that they still have 74 games left.

title: CS Holding Indicates Profits Have Weakened
description: CS Holding, the parent of Credit Suisse and CS First Boston, indicated yesterday that its third-quarter profit had dropped as income from interest, trading and commissions fell from first-half levels. CS Holding also said provisions for bad debts remained high while costs rose. The Zurich-based company announced bad-debt write-offs of 1.1 billion Swiss francs ($860 million) in July.

title: Hazards Seen At One-Fifth Of Schools
description: Physical conditions at one in five New York City schools are so poor that they pose a hazard to students and teachers, according to a Board of Education report prepared earlier this year.

title: Fleeting Chance to Fix Schools
description: State legislators from both parties appear close to an agreement that would give New York City's Schools Chancellor the power he needs to run a high-quality school system. But the timing is critical. Unless a final agreement is reached next month, the political will to achieve reform will probably evaporate.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: It's Time to Wake Up to Drug War's Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Gets $28 Million Billings
description: Two offices in the Latin American network of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide have been awarded accounts with combined billings estimated at $28 million.

title: Price of Natural Gas Surges; Cold Stirs Fear of Shortages
description: Natural gas prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as concerns grew that a cold winter could create spot shortages.

title: Old TV shows, buried in our memory, are reborn to sell.
description: MADISON AVENUE, always adept at plundering the past, has found another vein of creative inspiration to strip-mine: television series of the 1950's through the 1980's.

title: White Sox to Sign Belle, According to Reports
description: When the Cleveland Indians all but ended their relationship with Albert Belle by withdrawing a five-year contract offer of about $40 million, all eyes turned to Florida, where the Marlins seemed destined to make Belle the highest-paid player in baseball.

title: Files Suggest British Knew Early Of Nazi Atrocities Against Jews
description: They crouched in makeshift booths in dank, secret parts of wartime England, poring over the coded radio traffic flowing from the commanders of Nazi Germany. With some brilliant coups, and much plodding labor, the British code-breakers tracked the progress of the German Army on its march across Europe.

title: HORIZON/CMS IN DEAL FOR PACIFIC REHABILITATION
description: The Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Pacific Rehabilitation and Sports Medicine Inc. for $6.50 a share, or $56 million, plus the assumption of $22 million in debt. The deal would expand Horizon's outpatient rehabilitation business and would increase the number of Horizon's clinics to 290. Shares of Pacific Rehabilitation, based in Seattle, rose 56.25 cents, to $6.0625. Shares of Horizon rose 25 cents, to $10.75. Last November, Horizon, based in Albuquerque, N.M., made an offer for Pacific Rehabilitation, but talks ended in March when the companies could not agree on terms.

title: Accounts
description: Beringer Wine Estates, St. Helena, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the wine maker, which had been handled by Publicis/Bloom, New York, a unit of Publicis S.A. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Unocal to Sell Gas Stations To Tosco
description: In its biggest move yet to become a national force in refining and selling gasoline, the Tosco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy all the refining and marketing assets of the Unocal Corporation for about $1.4 billion.

title: Hewlett-Packard Income Is Down 4.4% in Quarter
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported a drop in earnings for its fourth quarter today, falling short of Wall Street analysts' estimates and its own internal forecasts. But the company said order growth rebounded in the quarter, after sluggish orders in the third quarter.

title: Packers Come Knocking Again, but Cowboys Slam the Door
description: Stop taking measurements for new a crown. The king is not dead yet.

title: A Generic Fighter Plane
description: Tight budgets, advanced technologies and the end of the cold war are at last bringing some sanity to the way the Pentagon buys new weapons systems. Lockheed Martin and Boeing have been selected as the surviving bidders in a competition to build a reasonably priced fighter plane that can be modified for use by each of the military services. The plan puts an old and honorable idea into practice. The logical notion of a generic fighter plane has been around for decades, but was always trumped by service rivalries and members of Congress eager to keep the aircraft plants running back home.

title: The Two Alger Hisses
description: Arthur Koestler once said that the basic problem with the Alger Hiss case was bad casting. If only the handsome Mr. Hiss and his accuser, the rumpled and portly Whittaker Chambers, could have swapped roles, Americans would have found it easier to swallow Mr. Hiss's past as a Soviet spy.

title: Corrections
description: The Last Chance listing in Weekend on Friday misstated the closing date for the Off Broadway show ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' at the Henry Street Settlement, Harry De Jur Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, on the Lower East Side. The show has been extended through Dec. 1.

title: Help or Hindrance?
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Board Plans a Suit Against Yale
description: Lawyers for the National Labor Relations Board said yesterday that they plan to charge Yale University with acting illegally by punishing teaching assistants who staged a grade strike last December in a drive to unionize.

title: Lockheed to Close 8 Plants To Cut Costs After Purchase
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that it was closing eight plants in four states to cut operating expenses following the $9.1 billion acquisition of most of the Loral Corporation.

title: Generous Rangers Give One To Flames
description: Here's a new theory on the travails of the Rangers. Call it the fear of leading. Give them a tight game, especially in the third period, and they seem to find a way not to win.

title: Thai Civics: New Leader, but Votes Are Still for Sale
description: When the police burst into a home in rural Buriram Province last year they found what they were looking for: plastic bags containing 11.4 million baht in small bills -- worth $456,000 -- and stacks of small cards bearing the photographs of three local political candidates.

title: Taking the Yuck Out of Thanksgiving
description: THANKSGIVING can be tough for children, even the ones who fit the definition of ''generally well behaved'' (a definition clearly invented by, and for, parents). Youngsters would really prefer macaroni and cheese while wearing a T-shirt, rather than sitting down at a fancy table at the wrong time of day with grandparents, aunts and uncles they do not see very often.

title: Careers Are Among the Casualties Of C.I.A.'s Latest Security Breach
description: The careers of the bright new graduates of the Central Intelligence Agency's school for spies are blighted: the F.B.I. fears that the class lists and curriculum are sitting in a Russian safe.

title: The Inspass system for hassle-free entry into the United States is being expanded.
description: AFTER three years of apparent fraud-free use at Kennedy International Airport in New York, Newark International Airport and Lester B. Pearson International Airport in Toronto, the Inspass system will soon be in place at eight more airports. Its purpose is to provide frequent travelers hassle-free entry into the United States.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Weighing College President's Annual Worth to Adelphi
description: A state panel considering the removal of Adelphi University's trustees concludes 27 days of hearings today, having painted a much fuller -- yet not quite complete -- picture of a central issue: compensation for the Adelphi president, Peter Diamandopoulos.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Battered Women Learn to Cut Costs and Take Control
description: Pamela Russell was married just three months when her husband punched her. She chose not to wait for an encore.

title: Singapore's Support of Myanmar Is Not Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wrong Man for a Sensitive Job
description: Despite having held on to Congress, many Republicans agree that our party suffers from a major image problem. But now that we have time to fix it, Congressional Republicans are readying themselves for yet another self-inflicted sucker punch. Enter Representative Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican expected to be named chairman of the House Government Reform and Oversight Committee.

title: Date Plays On While Seles Exits in Pain
description: Retirement was in the air last night at Madison Square Garden. But instead of watching Kimiko Date of Japan play the last match of her career, spectators at the Chase Championships watched in disbelief as Date's formidable but ailing opponent, Monica Seles, retired from what became her final match of 1996 because of a crippling pain in her chronically sore serving shoulder.

title: Separating The Grease From the Gravy
description: EVEN before fat became the commonplace foe it is nowadays, it was the cook's enemy. Who wants to serve greasy gravy?

title: Under U.S. Pressure, Bosnia Dismisses Official Linked to Iran
description: Bowing to American pressure, the Bosnian Government has dismissed a top civilian defense official who the United States said was a fervent Muslim nationalist with very close ties to Iran. The decision clears the way for the delivery of $100 million of American military hardware to the Muslim and Bosnian Croat armies, part of an effort to bring them to equal strength with the Bosnian Serbs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Obstruction Charge For Ex-Texaco Official

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about a decision by the Pentagon to narrow the bidding for a new fighter plane to Boeing and Lockheed Martin referred imprecisely to Boeing's history as a military contractor in some editions. While the company has not built a fighter plane since the 1930's, it has produced several types of bombers, and, as noted in the chart with the article, has worked on the B-2 bomber.

title: Bank of America Is Put in Review
description: The Bank of America unit of the BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it had placed in review its combined corporate image and retail accounts, with billings estimated at $50 million to $70 million. The corporate account had been handled for six years by the San Francisco office of Ketchum Advertising, a unit of Omnicom Group, while the retail account had been at Evans Group in San Francisco and Seattle for four years.

title: SHARES OF TICKETMASTER DECLINE IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The shares of Ticketmaster Group Inc. fell yesterday in the first day of trading as investors were concerned the ticket seller would not be able to expand into new businesses and markets. The shares closed at $14.125, compared with an offering price of $14.50, as 2.7 million shares were traded. The provider of ticketing services for sports and music events based in Los Angeles sold 7.25 million shares to raise $105 million.

title: South African English (With Home-Grown Spice)
description: Looking for just the right word to describe either how fine it feels to be South African or how good a gelatinous hippopotamus's hoof tasted in 1847?

title: Global Pact on Computers May Be Nearing
description: Clinton Administration officials expect two major meetings in the next month to set the stage for a global agreement abolishing tariffs on computer and software products.

title: Accounts
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn, Kalamazoo, Mich., to Lally, McFarland & Pantello/Euro RSCG, New York, a unit of Havas Advertising, to handle advertising for Camptosar, a cancer treatment. The account had been at the Ferguson Communications Group, Parsippany, N.J., a unit of WPP Group. Billings have not been determined.

title: From Prodigy's Concert to Sundance Hit
description: Ten years ago, Scott Hicks, an Australian documentary film maker living in Adelaide, noticed a brief newspaper article about a onetime child prodigy and classical pianist named David Helfgott who was performing again after years of living in obscurity.

title: SIZE OF U.S. FORCE BOUND FOR AFRICA IS CUT BELOW 1,000
description: Pleased with the relatively peaceful homecoming of more than half a million Rwandan refugees in recent days, the Clinton Administration has drastically scaled back plans to dispatch up to 4,000 troops to Central Africa and now intends to send at most 800 to help distribute relief aid, Administration officials said today.

title: The Fattening Of America
description: THE next time you hear about a friend's low-fat diet, the next time you see a kitchen stocked with low-fat cookbooks and fat-free snacks, consider this: Three of the fastest-growing foods in America are hamburgers, french fries and chicken nuggets.

title: Contraceptives to Go To Rwanda Refugees
description: Aid destined for Rwandan refugees from United Nations agencies and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies will be the first to include contraceptives and other sexual health services, the United Nations says.

title: Round One in the U.N. Fight: A U.S. Veto of Boutros-Ghali
description: In the first round of voting today on who will be the next United Nations Secretary General, the United States used its veto to stop the Security Council from recommending a second term for Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

title: Dried Cranberries: Timely and Versatile
description: OUT of fresh cranberries? Don't worry about it. Dried cranberries can be a versatile alternative.

title: Investment Adviser Admits $65 Million Fraud Against Her Clients
description: An investment adviser working out of her home in Tenafly, N.J., pleaded guilty yesterday in a case in which prosecutors said she had stolen more than $65 million from clients in one of the largest and longest-running such fraud schemes.

title: The Interpublic Group is linking up with an Internet broadcaster in a new media expansion.
description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies is expanding its interests in new media by going into the interactive advertising business with a client of one of its agencies.

title: Columbus Circle Project Needs a Clear-Cut Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sony expansion adds to San Diego's reputation as a center of technological manufacturing.
description: SONY ELECTRONICS INC. is adding a warehouse and distribution center the size of six football fields to its already substantial manufacturing complex in San Diego.

title: Jefferson and Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKAMERICA IS GIVING STOCK OPTIONS TO ITS EMPLOYEES
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it would award stock options to 91 percent of its employees in the next three years as an incentive to increase productivity and improve customer service. Under the plan, 85,000 employees would be granted options to buy 50 to 90 shares twice a year for the next three years, depending on their salaries. The options to be granted next month would allow employees to buy shares at Monday's average price of $95.125. Shares of BankAmerica, the third-largest bank in the United States, rose $2 to close at $98, after trading as high as $99.625. The company, based in San Francisco, has 358.8 million shares outstanding.

title: PHOENIX CANADA OIL OFFERS TO BUY BOX ENERGY
description: The Phoenix Canada Oil Company said yesterday that it would offer to buy the Box Energy Corporation for $239 million in cash or stock. Phoenix Canada plans to offer $12 a share for Box Energy's 3.25 million class A voting shares and $11.40 each for the 17.55 million class B nonvoting shares. It said its offer would be either in cash or a combination of cash and stock. Phoenix Canada, an oil company based in Toronto, did not say when it planned to make a formal offer. While not ruling out a possible sale, the chairman of Box Energy, Don D. Box, said the company, which is based in Dallas, planned to focus on drilling new oil and gas wells. Box's class B stock rose $1.3125, to $9.3125, and the class A shares 75 cents, to $9.25.

title: Belle Signs the Richest Deal: 5 Years, $55 Million
description: The Chicago White Sox made Albert Belle the highest-paid player in baseball yesterday, signing the free-agent slugger to a five-year contract worth a guaranteed $55 million that made the City of Big Shoulders look more than ever like the City of Big Bucks.

title: Three Large Retailers Report Impressive Earnings Gains
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation's fiscal third-quarter earnings more than doubled as a cost-cutting drive and higher sales at Target offset declining sales at the company's department store and Mervyn's chains.

title: In a Mystery, Holtz Quits Notre Dame
description: Without any explanation of substance, any hint at his future, or even a sense of relief after a difficult decision, Lou Holtz, the Notre Dame football coach, today walked away from an existence he has coveted or lived for much of his adult life.

title: Mama Tish's, a firm's latest public offering, falters.
description: LANDMARK INTERNATIONAL EQUITIES, the small brokerage firm best known for bringing public a company controlled by Oliver North, is still in business. But just barely.

title: October Starts Of Housing Fell by 5.1%
description: For months, analysts puzzled over the housing construction market's seeming disregard of last winter's sharp rise in interest rates that pushed mortgage costs higher and cut down on buyers. No more. Figures issued today showed that builders in October broke ground on the fewest new houses in a year, as activity tumbled for the second consecutive month.

title: 'Rent' on the Road With a New Life, Beginning in Boston
description: Adding a new chapter to its remarkable rags-to-riches story, ''Rent'' opened for the first time in a road production, at the Shubert Theater here on Monday night. The performance was attended by the New York cast as well as the parents and sister of the musical's creator, Jonathan Larson, who died of an aortic aneurysm at the age of 35 in January, shortly before ''Rent'' began previews at the New York Theater Workshop.

title: Opting for an Early Warning When E. Coli Is Suspected
description: IT was the day before Halloween and officials at the Seattle-King County Health Department had to make a decision quickly. Should they go public with their finding that there was a strong link between a recent outbreak of illnesses due to E. coli bacteria found in Odwalla apple juice, or wait for further proof? More than 700 illnesses and four deaths were reported three years earlier in the Northwest during an E. coli outbreak traced to hamburgers sold at a fast-food chain.

title: Singapore's Support of Myanmar Is Not Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Dead in L.I. Car Crash
description: Four people were killed and one person was seriously injured around 4 P.M. today when a car sped out of control and crashed along the Northern State Parkway near Exit 38.

title: Corrections
