description: A front-page article yesterday about the discovery of a 2.33-million-year-old jaw, described as the earliest definitively dated fossil of the genus Homo, which includes humans, misstated the period during which anatomically modern humans are thought to have arisen. It was 200,000 to 100,000 years ago, not 200 million to 100 million years ago.

title: Clinton, Golf in Mind, Visits An Understanding Australia
description: The White House calls President Clinton's four-and-a-half-day trip to this continent of kangaroos and koalas a state visit. And indeed, Mr. Clinton opened a round of friendly talks here today on trade, military cooperation and the environment with fanfare appropriate for a longtime ally.

title: KMART SHARES RISE 17% ON RUMOR OF A TAKEOVER
description: The stock of the Kmart Corporation surged 17 percent yesterday in heavy trading, partly on a rumor that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company has an interest in buying the retailer. A Kmart spokeswoman said the company would not comment on rumors. A Kohlberg Kravis spokeswoman also declined to comment. Traders said Kmart shares could have also benefited from expectations for a strong earnings report today. Kmart is expected to report a break-even third quarter, according to analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. The company lost 26 cents a share a year ago. Kmart shares were up $1.625, to $11.25 each, on the New York Stock Exchange. Nearly 14.9 million shares were traded.

title: Add Dance and Cocteau, Then Stir
description: ''Les Enfants Terribles,'' which opens tonight for four performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is the final work in a Jean Cocteau trilogy presented there by Philip Glass. First came ''Orphee,'' in 1993, then ''La Belle et la Bete'' the next year. ''Les Enfants Terribles'' incorporates song, dance and theater to tell the story of two precocious French children alone together in a bizarre dream world of their own making. Seeking a director as well as a collaborator in the adaptation, Mr. Glass turned to Susan Marshall, an internationally known American modern dance choreographer.

title: New Jersey Women Advance
description: New Jersey women earn higher salaries than women in most other states, and are more likely to rise to management positions, a nonprofit organization reported yesterday.

title: AIRLINES IN ACCORD ON DISASTER PLANS
description: The State Department and the seven leading United States airlines have reached an agreement intended to speed notification of American victims' families in the event of air disasters abroad.

title: Smoldering Fire Fueled By a Late Field Goal
description: Some of the Packers, most notably defensive end Reggie White and linebacker George Koonce, were upset Monday night when Dallas Coach Barry Switzer called a timeout with 20 seconds left in the game, and the Cowboys leading by 18-6, to allow Chris Boniol to kick a 37-yard field goal and tie a National Football League record for most field goals in a game.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Monday about ''The Rain on Macy's Parade: How Greed, Ambition and Folly Ruined America's Greatest Store,'' by Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg, misstated the date of the meeting at which R. H. Macy & Company shareholders approved a buyout proposal by the company chairman, Edward S. Finkelstein. It was June 19, 1986, not 1996.

title: Knicks and Celtics
description: An Internet site devoted to pro basketball's oldest rivals, the Knicks and the Celtics -- including coverage from The New York Times and The Boston Globe, statistics, photos and forums -- is on line at: newyork.boston.com

title: One-Woman Family At Play With Death
description: Uh-oh. Cancer. The first time the disease is mentioned in ''Julia Sweeney's 'God Said ''Ha!,'' ' '' alarm bells go off in your head. Am I, you wonder nervously, going to have to sit through an alternately depressing and predictably uplifting evening about dreary hospital waiting rooms and unfeeling medical personnel?

title: 9 More Brokers Barred in License Scandal
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers permanently barred nine securities brokers in the New York area from the industry today and fined them, some as much as $50,000, for paying impostors to take their licensing exams.

title: Bill Doggett, 80, Keyboard Player And Rhythm-and-Blues Innovator
description: Bill Doggett, a pianist and organist who was best known for his 1956 blues hit ''Honky Tonk,'' died on Nov. 13 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Erwin Savelson, 89, Reporter and an Editor
description: Erwin Savelson, the founding editor of The Metropolitan Star, the magazine of District 1 of B'nai B'rith, and a longtime volunteer in Jewish community affairs, died on Monday at the Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 89 and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Philadelphia Strike Settled, But Musicians Are Wary
description: The musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra voted on Monday evening to accept a three-year labor agreement and to end an acrimonious 64-day strike that began on Sept. 16. Although the ratification vote was narrow -- 54 to 47, with 2 abstentions -- the musicians and the management agreed to resume performances immediately.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: F.B.I. to Hunt Teen-Ager in Baby's Death
description: Frustrated that the New Jersey teen-ager accused with his girlfriend of killing their newborn son had not turned himself in, the police in Delaware declared him a fugitive last night and called in Federal officials to find him.

title: Justice, Not Profit, Demands Diversity at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Groups Accepting Donations to Africans
description: Following is a list of private American organizations accepting contributions for relief services in Rwanda and Zaire. Agencies listed are members of Interaction, a Washington-based association of more than 150 nonprofit relief groups with offices in the United States; Interaction compiled the list.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Pollution Agency Criticized
description: An Ocean County grand jury that indicted a Lakewood auto junkyard last year for fouling wetlands and groundwater with motor oil and gasoline found that the real culprit in the case was the State Department of Environmental Protection. So on Monday, the grand jury criticized the department for lax enforcement against Tilton Used Auto Parts and for failing to regulate the state's 200 junkyards.

title: Some Routine Lab Tests May Be Unnecessary
description: THE little plastic specimen cup and the blood vials with the brightly colored caps have long been essential elements of that time-honored ritual, the medical checkup. But judging from recent research, the cups and vials, and the tests they represent, may be about as useful as the unclosable gowns that complete the examining-room experience.

title: Tough Laws, Serving Time, Going Home
description: NO one believed Joel Proyect would serve time.

title: Out of the E.R.
description: Sherry Stringfield, who plays the talented but troubled Dr. Susan Lewis on NBC's ''E.R.,'' will make her final appearance on the series tomorrow night, after deciding to walk away from this starring role on the most popular show on television.

title: Yankees Sign Pennington
description: Before the winter is over, the Yankees may sign a more established left-handed reliever like Mike Stanton, but for now they have Brad Pennington, a left-handed reliever who has spent parts of the past four seasons with Baltimore, Cincinnati, Boston and California.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Monday about a PBS presentation of Purcell's opera ''Dido and Aeneas'' misstated the original purpose of Hampton Court, the palace near London where the opera was filmed. Hampton Court was built in the early 16th century for Cardinal Wolsey; Henry VIII took it over after the Cardinal's death.

title: Calipari Resisting A Contract Addition
description: It doesn't seem possible, but Coach John Calipari had to think today about what would happen if he were fired.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: A Milestone, Then Back to Work
description: The shot-blocker from Georgetown, whom Coach John Thompson told to stay in the paint and not worry about shooting long jump shots, tonight reaffirmed his stature as one of the game's most productive scorers.

title: Natural Gas Climbs Again As Unseasonal Cold Persists
description: Natural gas prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as energy prices continued to gain on forecasts for colder weather.

title: Europe Plans Inquiry On Alliance in Platinum
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it would open an antitrust investigation into the Anglo American Corporation's purchase of shares in Lonrho P.L.C. because of concern that the alliance would reduce competition in the platinum industry. Anglo American of South Africa has built up a stake of 25.9 percent in Lonrho, the British hotel and mining conglomerate.

title: U.S. Set to Seize Property of Fugitive Ex-Prosecutor
description: Law enforcement officials widened their search today for a convicted former New Jersey prosecutor who disappeared on Monday, and the Federal Government won the right to seize four properties that he had posted as bond, including his mother's condominium.

title: Isles-Kings Trade
description: The Islanders stepped back into the trade market yesterday when they sent the minor leaguer CHRIS MARINUCCI to the Los Angeles Kings for NICK VACHON, another minor leaguer.

title: Genetic-Disease Bias Banned
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed into law yesterday a bill that bans health insurance companies from denying access to or setting higher rates for individuals who are genetically predisposed to certain diseases. The bill also prohibits employers from using or requiring genetic tests in the workplace. The Legislature approved the measure in June, but the Governor sought a technical revision. The measure was sent back to her last Thursday.

title: Romanian Sensed Victory From Letters Detailing Corruption
description: When Romania's President-elect started to receive a tide of letters during his election campaign with detailed complaints about official corruption, he began daring to think that victory was possible, his campaign manager says.

title: Pop Art Wins Another 15 Minutes
description: Sotheby's had a 60's moment at its sale of contemporary art last night. Pop Art took a star turn as buyers eagerly fell for hearts and flowers.

title: CD RADIO STOCK FALLS 46 PERCENT AFTER LICENSE RULING
description: The shares of CD Radio Inc. lost 46 percent yesterday after a panel appointed by Federal regulators said the company should not get a preferential satellite radio license. The unanimous recommendation means the company must apply for a regular license. The stock plunged $3.875 a share, to $4.50, in Nasdaq trading. CD Radio, which was founded in 1991, devised a technology to deliver 30 channels of compact disk quality music and 20 channels of news and information nationwide through mini-satellite dishes on roofs of vehicles. CD Radio hoped to get a special pioneer preference license, given to those who pioneer communications technology.

title: Officials Seize Records Of Jewish Charity Group
description: Federal and city agents seized records from a politically influential social-services group in Brooklyn yesterday, and an investigator said they were examining whether government money and charitable contributions to the group had been illegally diverted for other uses.

title: Personal Health
description: DO you often get angry at: your boss, spouse, children, colleagues, inefficient grocery clerks, unfriendly service personnel, people who do not do what they were told, friends who fail to arrive on time, strangers who jostle you, drivers who cut you off or who drive too slowly?

title: Disputes Slow Help for Rwandan Refugees
description: Five days after hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees began walking home in droves, the relief operation meant to help them has become bogged down in disputes between the United Nations and Rwandan authorities over how and where to deliver supplies, aid workers say.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?'' That's not a request. It's a song title.

title: General Motors Output Lags Behind Demand for New Models
description: The General Motors Corporation has a mixed blessing this autumn: It finally has some popular new models, but under its manufacturing schedule the new cars and mini-vans are arriving in dealerships in a trickle, not a flood.

title: Percussion Prodigy Follows in Dad's Drumbeats
description: BARELY visible behind his drums, Sam Sanford Jr. stretched his neck, rolled his shoulders and pumped the bass pedal like a frantic motorist coaxing a balky engine. He smiled broadly with each hit, filling the room with a thumpa-thumpa shock wave that rattled floors and lungs.

title: Sony Mulls a Public Sale of Entertainment Assets
description: The Sony Corporation's president, Nobuyuki Idei, said today that a newly completed overhaul of its troubled entertainment division could eventually lead to a public stock sale in the unit.

title: F.C.C. Isn't Missing Data on Digital TV
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pope's Visit to Cuba
description: Like Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to the Vatican in 1989, Fidel Castro's meeting with Pope John Paul II yesterday was infused with political as well as religious meaning. The Polish Pope, who helped accelerate the collapse of European Communism, agreed to visit Cuba, a largely Roman Catholic island that is one of the last redoubts of Marxist rule. The Catholic-educated Mr. Castro, in power nearly 37 years, had never before met with a pope.

title: Crew Asks U.S. to Review School Ruling
description: Continuing his fight for control over a troubled South Bronx school district, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew asked the Justice Department yesterday to reconsider its decision that he had violated the Voting Rights Act by suspending the district's board members and replacing them with his own appointees.

title: American Air Is Said to Plan Big Jet Order
description: American Airlines plans to announce tomorrow an order for several hundred new Boeing jets, worth close to $6 billion, to be delivered through the year 2020, according to people familiar with the company's plans.

title: B. A. Quarles, 92, Scholar on Black History
description: Benjamin Arthur Quarles, a scholar who wrote about the role of African-Americans in the founding of the United States and in its early history, died on Saturday at Prince George's Hospital in Cheverly, Md.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: No Headline
description: ''Do I represent a danger to the security of the United States? No. Did I smuggle something? Am I Noriega or Saddam Hussein?''

title: A 'Smarter' Air Bag
description: To the Editor:

title: Wednesday- Night Shuffle
description: Shuffling its Wednesday night sitcom lineup, ABC announced on Monday that next week ''Ellen'' would move from 8 P.M. to 9:30, ''The Drew Carey Show'' from 9:30 to 9 and ''Grace Under Fire'' from 9 to 8.

title: Match Race: Who's The Fastest Human?
description: MICHAEL JOHNSON and DONOVAN BAILEY will settle the argument of who is the world's fastest human, with the winner to get $1.5 million.

title: Rangers Have Questions But None of the Answers
description: Rangers Coach Colin Campbell is no philosopher. But he sure is doing some soul-searching these days over his struggling team. The Rangers' 5-3 loss to Calgary on Monday night left them with a 1-5-1 record in their last seven games.

title: Zoning Battle Is Early Issue For Campaign
description: Stepping up the political battle over superstores, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is running radio commercials to promote his plan to allow the stores in some areas. And yesterday, he harshly attacked Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a probable mayoral candidate, who is running ads against the plan.

title: Valujet Fire May Have Been Roaring Inferno, Expert Says
description: The fire that brought down Valujet 592 may have reached 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit, hot enough to burn stainless steel, according to testimony today by a National Transportation Safety Board expert, who showed a videotape of a roaring, white-hot fire fed by oxygen generators of the kind the DC-9 was carrying.

title: A Mayor Slides Off His Pedestal
description: There are those who will now assert that they knew all along that Willie L. Brown Jr. would slip, that it was only a matter of time and hubris before he would stop being ''the wildly popular Mayor of San Francisco'' and become just the Mayor.

title: Investigators Identify Remains of Victim In Flight 800 Crash
description: Using DNA testing, medical investigators have identified another victim of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, lowering the number of missing victims to 15 of the 230 people who died in the July crash.

title: Future Sentence Challenged
description: When a 15-year-old girl who was caught driving without a license failed to show up for community service earlier this year, Municipal Court Judge Bennett E. Bozarth's options were limited by her age. So he sentenced her to serve 14 days in jail in May 1998, after she turns 18. But the girl's lawyer said there was a problem with Judge Bozarth's novel sentence: it is illegal and unconstitutional.

title: Orange County Jail Term Set
description: The former treasurer of Orange County, Calif., Robert Citron, was sentenced today to one year in jail and ordered to pay $100,000 in fines by a state judge for his role in the county's bankruptcy.

title: Wheatley Shows Skills, but Reeves Still Likes Hampton
description: Rodney Hampton and Tyrone Wheatley are close friends. They often socialize together. On Monday night, they joined other National Football League players at a SoHo club to mark the release of a rap record they made.

title: Allied Colloids to Buy CPS Chemicals of U.S.
description: The Allied Colloids Group, a British chemical producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CPS Chemicals of Old Bridge, N.J., for $390 million. CPS owns two plants, one in Old Bridge and the other in West Memphis, Ark. Allied Colloids said the acquisition would help lower manufacturing costs and open markets in the United States.

title: Union Sues a Medical Center For Millions in Pension Funds
description: A hospital workers' union went to court this week to collect almost $14 million owed its pension and benefits fund by the Interfaith Medical Center of Brooklyn, prompting the hospital to lay off 330 employees.

title: Extending a Hand to Ancestral Ghosts in China
description: ''Time to cast out demons of your anger.'' So goes the counsel from a little old lady of a ghost who materializes in the back of a taxicab in ''Golden Child,'' the new play by David Henry Hwang at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

title: Networks Are Created and Managers Made Accountable
description: A decade ago, diversifying work forces may have seemed relatively simple. Companies set quotas for hiring minorities and women, then filled them by holding job fairs, recruiting at black colleges and adopting inner-city schools. They assigned the new hires to mentors, and gave them special training. They offered flexible hours for working mothers. For good measure, they put the old guard through prejudice-awareness workshops.

title: Judge Rejects Move to Block CSX-Conrail Merger Deal
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation failed to thwart a giant railroad merger between its rival, the CSX Corporation, and Conrail yesterday, when a Federal judge in Philadelphia refused to grant a preliminary injunction blocking the $8.5 billion deal.

title: Bring In the Funk
description: Last winter I took my sons to 42d Street to survey the boarded-up theaters and, from a proper distance, the last few porn storefronts. ''I want you to remember this,'' I said, ''because when you bring your own children here, it will look completely different.''

title: Ex-Baseball Chief Gives to Fairfield U.
description: Fay Vincent, whose initiatives when he was baseball commissioner included making the major leagues' health insurance plans available to players of the old Negro leagues, is now helping the needy in another way.

title: Boutros-Ghali vs. 'Goliath': His Account
description: When Boutros Boutros-Ghali visits Japan, he inevitably makes a quiet pilgrimage to an obscure shrine in what an aide calls ''some godawful far-reaching corner of Tokyo.'' There, with incense drifting around him, the Secretary General pauses alone for a moment or two and bows.

title: Heart-Valve Candidate Dies
description: An 11-year-old Ecuadoran girl who flew to this country to have a heart valve replaced died yesterday after arriving at Newark Airport, officials said. The girl, whose name was not released, was to have had the operation at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York but was taken to Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark, said Michelle Weiss, a hospital spokeswoman.

title: U.S. Trims Troops Plan For Rwanda
description: WASHINGTON  The United States has decided not to send ground troops to central Africa, citing the voluntary return of hundreds of thousands of refugees to Rwanda, and will send no more than 1,000 support troops for humanitarian assistance, Defense Secretary William Perry said Tuesday.

title: Odelein Makes Impact on Devils' Offense
description: When Devils defenseman Lyle Odelein makes his mark on a hockey game, it usually takes the form of a crunching body check or a knockout punch. But tonight, he tried a different method.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Army and Navy

title: Another Manic Tuesday: Knicks Hold On
description: When the drama ended, Patrick Ewing reached his milestone, Chris Childs made his debut and the Knicks had come away with a rare and rather wild victory tonight at Orlando Arena.

title: Packer Is Sentenced
description: TYRONE WILLIAMS of the Green Bay Packers was sentenced yesterday in Lincoln, Neb., to six months in jail for a 1994 shooting that happened while he was at the University of Nebraska.

title: Andreas Freund, Former Times Editor, 71
description: Andreas Freund, for many years an editor and correspondent of The New York Times, died here on Sunday, family friends said. He was 71.

title: E.P.A. and Arizona Factory Agree on Innovative Regulatory Plan
description: As part of a broad experiment intended to change the way environmental laws are enforced, the Environmental Protection Agency today granted a huge computer-chip factory in Arizona extraordinary flexibility to operate under simplified permits in exchange for the company's pledge to do better than the law requires in controlling pollution.

title: Immigration Official Is Found Guilty
description: A Federal jury convicted the third-ranking immigration official in New Jersey today on charges that he helped aliens enter the United States illegally and accepted lavish gifts in return.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE American wine drinker's love affair with chardonnay continues to be as passionate as ever. Red wines have gained in popularity in recent years, with merlot and zinfandel now sharing the spotlight with cabernet sauvignon. Among white varieties, however, chardonnay has no serious competition.

title: Utility Seeks Partner to Aid Power Needs
description: A big Georgia utility said yesterday that it was turning to an outside power-marketing company to supply half its electricity needs in an effort to cut its costs by tens of millions of dollars over more than a decade.

title: Paternity and Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex-Crime Inquiry Of Belgian Official Unsettles Coalition
description: BRUSSELS  Speculation about the stability of Belgium's coalition government intensified Tuesday after Parliament authorized an investigation into charges that Deputy Prime Minister Elio di Rupo had sex with minors.

title: Foote, Cone Wins Work for Sara Lee
description: Sara Lee Bakery said yesterday that it had named Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago to handle integrated advertising and promotions for its grocery division, which markets products like frozen pies. The account, with combined billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million, had been at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York for six years.

title: GULF SOUTH MEDICAL TO ACQUIRE GATEWAY HEALTHCARE
description: Gulf South Medical Supply Inc., based in Ridgeland, Miss., agreed yesterday to acquire the Gateway Healthcare Corporation for about $38.8 million. Gulf South said the price consists mostly of cash in addition to warrants to purchase 450,000 Gulf South common shares. Gateway Healthcare, based in Richmond, is a privately owned distributor of medical supplies and related products to long-term-care facilities and office-based physicians. The acquisition would add 38 field sales representatives and nine distribution centers for Gulf South, which reported 1995 sales of $120.3 million. Gulf South distributes medical supplies and related products to the long-term-care industry. Its Nasdaq-traded stock closed at $25 yesterday, up $1 a share.

title: Treasury Prices Show An Advance
description: Treasury prices advanced yesterday for the first time in three sessions after a surprise slump in home building buoyed expectations for a slowing economy and restrained inflation.

title: Tender but Bland Birds Flock to the Feast
description: THE turkeys that most Americans eat for Thanksgiving are turkeys -- losers that are mass produced and bland. Come to think of it, most Americans probably have no idea how turkey is supposed to taste, since so many turkeys these days have been treated with a chemical stew to make them seem juicier.

title: Rate of Sexual Diseases in U.S. Is Highest in Developed World
description: The United States has the highest rate of sexually transmitted diseases of any developed country in the world and no effective national system to combat the epidemic, a panel of health experts said today.

title: By Standing Firm, Jets Will Try to Go Forward
description: Even the cliches do not apply to the Jets, who inhabit a football world all their own.

title: Color-Coded Bus Stop Signs Replacing Old, Cryptic Ones
description: For New York City bus riders who despair of finding any useful information from the cryptic signs currently posted at bus stops, help is on the way. The Transit Authority has begun to replace the city's 18,000 bus stop signs.

title: Leonard F. Rothkrug, 68, Lawyer and Expert on Zoning, Dies
description: Leonard F. Rothkrug, a combative Brooklyn-bred lawyer who proclaimed his specialty and rank -- Zoning 1 -- on the license plates of his limousine, died Friday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 68.

title: An Instinct to Deceive
description: What will it take to persuade this White House to tell the truth simply and promptly once a scandal is brewing? Apparently not even the advice of two lawyers of uncontested loyalty to President Clinton can overcome the cover-up instinct that has made a quagmire of Whitewater and is turning the Indonesian fund-raising affair into a matter that neither Congress nor the Attorney General can ignore.

title: Garry as Larry, Host Of Ego and Its Acolytes
description: When a series starts off great and just keeps getting better, it's television-classic time. And as ''The Larry Sanders Show'' racks up its fifth 13-week season, that's precisely what is happening on HBO at 10 P.M. on Wednesdays. Starring Garry Shandling, this is the ultimate take on prime-time talk-show hosts, riddled with ego trips, paranoia, back-stabbing, incipient insanity and all those other little quirks that make show business so confoundedly endearing. Leno and Letterman have to play the game straight-faced. Mr. Shandling, using a fictional facade, gets hilariously to the heart of the whole loony business.

title: F.C.C. Chief's View On Liquor Ads
description: Reed E. Hundt, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, reasserted yesterday that his agency has jurisdiction over television and radio advertising by the distilled spirits industry now that the industry has decided to end its decades-long voluntary ban on such commercials.

title: Giuliani's Health Policy Adviser Resigns
description: Maria K. Mitchell, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's chief health policy adviser, who has led City Hall's effort to dismantle the public hospital system, is resigning her post to head a new consortium of hospitals and medical schools aimed at reinvigorating biomedical research in New York.

title: The Arab Burden
description: I asked President Hosni Mubarak the other day what qualities he would like to see in the next U.S. Secretary of State. The Egyptian leader remarked that Warren Christopher was the ideal Secretary for the past four years. His low-key, lawyerly style was well suited for a period in which Israelis and Palestinians were driving the peace process by themselves and the U.S. role was to ease them over the bumps. But with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu having replaced Shimon Peres, and with the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations soon to reach the knotty final-status issues, the U.S. may again need a Secretary of State with more of the Jim Baker, in-your-face style of diplomacy, Mr. Mubarak gently suggested. ''With no Rabin, no Peres, the President will have to select a Secretary of State who works differently,'' he said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How about the possibility of a billet-doux from Angie Dickinson? Macho mail from Norman Mailer?

title: U.S. Readies $100 Million Erie Canal Plan
description: The Federal Government is on the verge of announcing a $100 million revitalization of the waterfronts along the Erie Canal and its connecting waterways, a plan aimed at increasing tourism in a region that has been hurt by a sharp loss of jobs.

title: A Bizarre Ancient Caste Yields Up Its Secrets
description: THE INVISIBLES

title: London Electric Bars Comment on Possible Bid
description: London Electricity said yesterday that it would not comment on a report that the Entergy Corporation of New Orleans was planning a takeover bid of $:1.2 billion ($2 billion).

title: A Tape Shows Israeli Police Beating Arabs
description: Captured on an amateur videotape as they beat and kicked Palestinians near a checkpoint outside Jerusalem, two Israeli border policemen were arrested today and denounced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as unfit to serve in the Israeli security forces.

title: Where the News by Night Is the Food
description: STARTING tonight at 6, Eli Zabar's VF News, a newsstand and cafe at 444 East 91st Street, will dim the lights and put on party clothes every evening to become a real restaurant, Across the Street. Seen Lippert, a chef who worked with Alice Waters at Chez Panisse, will take over in the open kitchen, with a menu based on ingredients from Mr. Zabar's Vinegar Factory food market, which is directly across the street. The menu will change daily. On Sundays only, there will be a set meal without choices. Reservations: (212) 722-4000.

title: INSIDE
description: Cocaine Is Cocaine

title: Trading Scandal at Sumitomo Causes $1.9 Billion Loss, Its First
description: The Sumitomo Corporation announced a loss of $1.9 billion today for the first six months of its fiscal year -- the first loss in the giant trading company's 77 years -- as a result of huge losses from unauthorized copper trading.

title: Selig Calls a Meeting
description: As outrage reportedly spread today among owners over the Chicago White Sox's $55 million signing of Albert Belle, word also spread that Bud Selig would call an owners' meeting for next Tuesday in Chicago.

title: Casino Net Down in Quarter
description: The casino industry spent tens of millions of dollars during the summer months to lure visitors with free drinks, food, rooms, entertainment and coins. The heavy spending on promotion -- $162.9 million from June through September, up from to $132 million the summer before -- cut deeply into the industry's profits, state regulators said yesterday.

title: Another C.I.A. Betrayal
description: Compared with the years they spent fumbling the Aldrich Ames case, the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation pursued suspicions about Harold Nicholson with alacrity and admirable coordination. On Monday Mr. Nicholson, a fast-advancing C.I.A. official, was charged with selling sensitive secrets to Russia.

title: Leader of Latin Kings Is Convicted in Slayings
description: The leader of one of New York City's most notorious gangs, the Latin Kings, was convicted yesterday by a Federal jury on charges of orchestrating the murders and attempted murders of rivals from his prison cell in upstate New York.

title: Shuttle Blasts Off on Mission With 2 Scientific Satellites
description: The nation's oldest space shuttle, the 15-year-old Columbia, blasted into orbit today carrying the oldest astronaut ever to fly in space, 61-year-old Dr. Story Musgrave. Neither showed any effects of age.

title: Influx Of Money To Expand Edison
description: The Edison Project, the for-profit educational venture founded in 1992 by the media entrepreneur Christopher Whittle, announced yesterday that it had raised an additional $30.5 million to finance expansion of the company.

title: New Jersey Town Tries to Find a Way to Save Its Free Preschool Program
description: Peter Appelbaum spent three years scouring the school systems of North Jersey, hoping to find one so impressive that he would have no qualms about enrolling his children. He settled on Montclair for many reasons, but one, he says, stood out: the free, racially integrated prekindergarten program that the public schools have run for nearly three decades.

title: U.S. to Settle for $4.8 Million In Suits on Radiation Testing
description: The Federal Government has agreed to pay $4.8 million as compensation for injecting 12 people with radioactive materials in secret cold war experiments.

title: The Proof Is in the Stuffing
description: LET'S not be coy. Stuffing -- not turkey, cranberries, sweet potatoes or pie -- is what Thanksgiving is all about.

title: CITICORP INCREASES STOCK BUYBACK BY $4 BILLION
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it would buy back an additional $4 billion of its stock and extended the period for the repurchases by a year, to the end of 1998. The New York-based company has now authorized a total of $8.5 billion of stock repurchases since the buyback was first announced in June 1995. As of Sept. 30, it had repurchased a total of 51.1 million shares for $3.8 billion. The shares would be repurchased in both open market and private transactions. Citicorp's stock gained $1.75 yesterday to $107 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Making Strange Even Stranger
description: Sometimes the members of the Kronos Quartet behave like dancers who strap on roller skates to go rock climbing. Their double perversity -- wrong task, wrong tools -- was on display last week when, in the second of three concerts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, they offered Perotin's ''Viderunt Omnes'' with artificial reverberation. The original 12th-century piece owes its magnificent strangeness to vocal matters: how one voice must be steady while the others skitter above, how the text can be stalled on one syllable while this goes on. Heard on strings, the music was denatured. Given added echo, it was sentimentalized.

title: Cutting the Fringe
description: I thought we had made it. My daughter had decent grades, good board scores, a successful preliminary interview at the private college of her dreams. The shaved head, purple hair, secret forays to after-hour clubs and failed chemistry Regents exam didn't seem to add up to much after all.

title: People
description: Michael Rich, promotion director at Money magazine, New York, a publication of Time Warner Inc., will retire in January. There are no plans to name a successor.

title: MARVEL TO CUT 115 WORKERS AT ITS COMIC BOOK BUSINESS
description: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to dismiss 115 people, or one-third of the work force, at its comic book business, as the company looks for ways to stop losing money. The job cuts are in addition to 28 positions that are vacant. Marvel, which is controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman and is based in New York, employs 1,100 people. The move comes a week after Mr. Perelman offered to pay $350 million for 410 million new Marvel shares to help save the company from filing for bankruptcy. Marvel is in violation of its debt covenants and reported its fourth consecutive quarterly loss last week.

title: Theater in Review
description: Ages of Sin Against Blacks:

title: Sales Pitch Doesn't Work For Holtz
description: HE has always been one of these guys who could sell you anything. He could have made a great door-to-door salesman, apologizing for taking your time and then displaying this handy-dandy 29-use kitchen tool.

title: Paying to Keep Those Checks in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Disparity Urged in Cocaine Sentencing
description: On the assumption that crack cocaine creates more addicts and promotes more violence than powdered cocaine, Federal law for a decade has dealt far more harshly with crack dealers and users than with others caught with more traditional forms of the illicit drug.

title: Food Notes
description: Plans for Thanksgiving

title: Charge of Impeding Justice Filed Against Former Texaco Executive
description: The former Texaco executive who recorded senior company officers belittling minority groups and planning the destruction of documents that had been demanded in a discrimination lawsuit was charged yesterday with obstruction of justice.

title: Rating the Ratings
description: Skeptics said there was no way that the people formulating a television ratings system for use with a future V-chip could meet their January deadline. But the ''implementation group,'' assembled by Jack Valenti of the Motion Picture Association of America, now expects to unveil its proposed ratings system on Dec. 18 or 19, said some of those who have been working on the project.

title: Pasta Topped by a Sauce Infused With Brandy
description: This is a simple variation on the traditional Italian pasta with vodka sauce -- a dish, frankly, I have never understood because vodka has no flavor.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Antic and Wacky, Sometimes Nonsensical
description: ''The Architecture of Seeing'' is built out of a multitude of images, some of them bright, others bizarre. Some also seemed blurred in this collaborative work, which Patricia Hoffbauer and George Emilio Sanchez presented on Sunday afternoon at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Protect American Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt and More Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Signs Unveiled For Bus Riders
description: For New York City bus riders who despair of finding any useful information on the cryptic signs posted at bus stops, help is on the way. In a response to complaints from riders, the Transit Authority has begun a two-year campaign to replace the city's 18,000 bus stop signs. The new signs are designed to be more prominent on the street, easier to read and will give the number of the bus and its final destination.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHYSICIAN SALES AND SERVICE INC., Jacksonville, Fla., a distributor of medical supplies, said it would acquire X-Ray Corp. of Georgia and Chesapeake X-Ray Corp. for $18 million in stock and the assumption of $6.8 million in debt.

title: Pope Meets Castro at Vatican and Agrees to Visit Cuba
description: Pope John Paul II, who helped bring about the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, accepted an invitation today from President Fidel Castro to visit Cuba, one of the last Communist outposts, sometime next year.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Poll of Voters Gives Giuliani an Early Lead
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would defeat any of his potential Democratic challengers if next year's election were held today, according to a poll released yesterday, but he continues to get negative ratings from New Yorkers on his handling of education and the city budget.

title: Hubble Telescope Reveals Galaxies Housing Quasars
description: Ever since the discovery of quasars, the universe's most powerful objects, in 1963, astronomers have been trying to figure out where they reside and what forces could account for the tremendous energies coming from such distant sources not much bigger than the solar system.

title: Clinton Asks For Fairness On Money Issue
description: President Clinton suggested today that repeated questions about his ties to Indonesian business interests were unfair, and he likened them to the initial reports that identified Richard Jewell as a suspect in the bombing at the Olympics in Atlanta this summer.

title: Theater in Review
description: Delivery Men on Tricycles And Computer Hackers

title: New Yorkers Allowed to Pursue Money Awards in Rights Cases
description: Sweeping away years of lower court rulings, New York's highest court said today that people can seek monetary damages from the state government for violating their rights under the State Constitution.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Sold Belongings Before Fleeing, Lawyer Says
description: In the months before he fled from house arrest and became a fugitive, a former Somerset County Prosecutor raised more than $3,600 by selling the family's chinaware, silverware, crystal and some furniture, his wife's lawyer said today.

title: Adelphi Ruling in January
description: As it concluded hearings yesterday on the turmoil at Adelphi University, a state panel said it expected to issue a decision in January on whether to remove the school's trustees.

title: Jones Wants to Step Up in Class
description: Roy Jones Jr. will fight for the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight championship on Friday, but his mind is wandering to bigger goals.

title: TA ASSOCIATES JOINS FIGHT FOR ALTAMIRA
description: TA Associates Inc. said yesterday that it was considering making an offer of $782 million, or $582.8 million (United States), for Altamira Management Ltd., which would top the bid by the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company of Toronto. TA Associates, a Boston-based venture capital firm, said it was acting on behalf of private equity partnerships and other investors. TA Associates said it would offer $38 a share for Altamira, a closely held Canadian mutual fund company, if Manufacturers Life released Altamira from its existing agreement offering $32 a share for the 69.5 percent of Altamira that Manufacturers Life does not already own. The Almiria Capital Corporation, a Montreal-based company that owns 30.5 percent of Altamira, is seeking an injunction to block the Manufacturers Life deal.

title: COMPUSERVE TO DISCARD AN ON-LINE SERVICE
description: The Compuserve Corporation said yesterday that it was scrapping its eight-month-old Wow service, which was aimed at children and novice users of computer on-line services. Compuserve, the second largest on-line service after America Online Inc., said it would discontinue Wow on Jan. 31 because of high costs. It will instead focus on other areas, such as the European market. Compuserve started Wow in March, but it never caught on. Customers bypassed on-line services, signing up instead for direct Internet access and leaving Wow with only 92,000 customers as of the end of July.

title: Police Report More Violence In Some Areas
description: Despite a continuing citywide drop in crime, several neighborhoods in southern Queens, northern Brooklyn and the Bronx have experienced an unusual upsurge in murders and shootings this month, according to a police report.

title: All Colombia Is a Smugglers' Cove (It's an Old, Old Custom)
description: Despite the filth on the streets, the stench of exhaust fumes and the pandemonium of peddlers' cries, the shopping district here is Colombia's busiest, attracting people from all walks of life.

title: $31 Million for Prime Broadway Spot
description: When the bidding got hot, soaring past $25 million to $28 million, then $30 million, it might have seemed as though one of the world's great treasures was on the block -- a van Gogh, perhaps, or an offshore oil field -- instead of a tawdry-looking street corner in Times Square.

title: Bomb on Flight 800 Called 'Less Likely'
description: The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 said yesterday that he now believes it is ''less likely that a bomb or a missile'' caused the plane to explode, killing all 230 people on board.

title: Americans Straddle the Average Mark in Math and Science
description: In the most comprehensive study of science and mathematics achievement by students around the world, students in the United States ranked slightly below average in mathematics and slightly above average in science, according to an international comparison of 41 countries released yesterday.

title: Fire Raises Fears About Safety Lapses In Eurotunnel
description: PARIS  Despite assurances from the Eurotunnel consortium that rescue work went according to plan following a major train fire under the English channel, investigators Wednesday focused on apparently major safety lapses that could have had disastrous consequences had the train been carrying hundreds of passengers.

title: Sutton Gets an Extension
description: Army Coach BOB SUTTON was given a three-year contract extension yesterday through the 2000 season. Sutton became head coach in 1991. This season, he coached Army to its best start since 1949. Army is 9-1 for the season. Sutton's six-year record at Army is 33-31-1. (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: Just in time for Christmas, POPE JOHN PAUL II's latest book is to be published in the United States and Canada by Doubleday.

title: Disputing a Control Theory
description: To The Home Section:

title: Panel Disputes Studies on Gulf War Illness
description: The chairwoman of a Federal panel investigating the illnesses of veterans of the 1991 Persian Gulf war said today that she believed that gulf war veterans were clearly experiencing more health problems than other veterans, and that Iraqi chemical weapons and other chemical agents might be to blame for many of their ailments.

title: Gifts: Indulging the Quirks
description: WHY not take a cue from this age of specialization and finally say goodbye to the generic gift -- like brandied fruitcakes ordered by the dozen, for friend and foe alike, on a computer-generated gift list.

title: Reeves Stands Stolid Amid The Tempest
description: Late last week, the National Football League's commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, wanted to remind teams to watch their p's and q's when trying to hire a coach who already has a contract with another club. So he sent out a memorandum stating that no team is to approach a head coach who is already signed. In other words, no tampering.

title: With the Mud Flying, Race for Mayor Begins
description: And suddenly, in a furor of radio ads and accusations, the 1997 mayoral campaign has begun on a distinctly rancorous note, very possibly foreshadowing the tone for the year to come.

title: A Farewell To 'E.R.,' Blood, Guts And Fame
description: For Sherry Stringfield, the decision to walk away from the fame and fortune that came with her starring role in ''E.R.'' was a simple choice.

title: Robert B. Gingrich, Speaker's Father, 71
description: Robert B. Gingrich, a retired Army officer, died yesterday at a hospital near his home in Harrisburg, Pa., hours before his son, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, was unanimously renominated by the Republican majority for a second term as Speaker of the House of Representatives. He was 71.

title: Tenants Lose in Garbage Suit
description: In a defeat for apartment tenants, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Morristown's ordinance restricting taxpayer-supported garbage collection to property owners did not on its face violate the State or Federal Constitutions.

title: Kuehne Turns Professional And Will Team With Woods
description: KELLI KUEHNE, whose dominance of the women's amateur circuit most closely approximates that of TIGER WOODS in the men's game, announced yesterday that she is following in Woods's tracks.

title: SOUTH JERSEY INDUSTRIES SELLS UNIT FOR $55 MILLION
description: South Jersey Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Morie Company unit to the closely held Unimin Corporation for about $55 million in cash. Morie, based in Millville, N.J., operates sand and gravel plants in New Jersey, Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee, supplying the materials to businesses including car makers and foundries. Unimin, based in New Canaan, Conn., mines and sells silica sand, high-purity quartz and other minerals in 30 plants in the United States and units in Canada, Britain and Scandinavia.

title: Iona Makes a Big Point By Beating Seton Hall
description: The optimism of a new season turned into a dismal debut for Seton Hall tonight as the Pirates were beaten by Iona, 79-66, in a first-round game of the Chase N.I.T. at Continental Arena.

title: All Female Crews?
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Makes Slopes Steeper for Americans
description: It came down hard and heavy, a severe and unexpected budget cut at United States Skiing just when the athletes were ready to slip into their skis and snowboards for the new season.

title: Tacky Start for a Mayoral Race
description: The New York City mayoral campaign has heated up before the public had time to get over the bad taste of the national elections, with their overload of special-interest money and the collapse of any real limits on campaign spending. The events of this week should put the public on alert. The city appears to be heading for a no-holds-barred political fight, and the spirit of local campaign-finance laws has already been violated.

title: Small Nets Could Face Big Test With Hill
description: Maybe it's denial, because first Kendall Gill has to admit there's a problem. And he's not about to do that, even when the issue comes in the form of Grant Hill.

title: Single-Parent Vacations, Without Losing Child or Mind
description: LYNN HIESTAND wouldn't consider taking a major trip without her favorite travel companion. Together, they have toured China and Israel and have enjoyed a safari in Africa, scuba diving in the Florida Keys and basking in the Arizona sun.

title: Furniture by Artists At Warehouse Prices
description: EVER craved an Ettore Sottsass sculpture but winced at the price tag? Then head to the Studio Warehouse, a sale of furniture and accessories by 250 artists, designers and architects. Prices are 25 to 75 percent below retail, from $15 to $15,000, and some of the proceeds will benefit the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS.

title: Elisa's Death: A Year Later, Hints of Hope
description: A YEAR has passed since Elisa Izquierdo died, killed by her mother in the worst case of child abuse the authorities said they had ever seen. The 6-year-old could have been saved. But she was failed by every institution and government employee who might have changed her deadly fate.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Tutorial for Young Saudis On Ways to Toil for Money
description: Twice a day, six days a week, Saudis in their 20's file into sleek classrooms here to master something new: work.

title: Extortion Charge for Officer
description: A Passaic police officer and a former member of the Passaic police force were indicted yesterday on Federal extortion charges stemming from an Aug. 7 incident in which a customer of a loan-sharking operation was stabbed.

title: Still Playful After All These Years
description: EVA ZEISEL is a fabled ceramist, but she is a realist, too. ''Nobody employs a 90-year-old designer,'' she said with a laugh. Pity. Ms. Zeisel is as creative now as in the 1940's, when she designed whimsical dinnerware for top manufacturers. So she has gone into business for herself, she said, ''to have my playful ideas produced by small American shops.'' Her latest notion is ''Lacy Walls,'' terra-cotta modules that can be stacked into room or garden dividers and, Ms. Zeisel said, ''make a palace out of a kitchen.'' At about $25 a module, they are at Munder-Skiles, 799 Madison Avenue (67th Street); (212) 717-0150.

title: Hong Kong's Freedoms Imperiled
description: The signs are mounting that when China regains control of Hong Kong next July 1, Hong Kong's citizens will lose many of their freedoms. Beijing has steadily backtracked on the promises made in its agreement with Britain to grant Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy and maintain its way of life for 50 years. The latest indication came last week, when a committee of 400 Hong Kong citizens carefully chosen by Beijing took a preliminary vote to choose the new chief executive.

title: GTE Raising A Latin Stake
description: The GTE Corporation said today that it would buy as much as $200 million in shares of Compania Anonima Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela, or CanTV, in the company's planned stock offering.

title: Prize to Adrienne Rich
description: Adrienne Rich is the winner of the 1996 Tanning Prize for excellence in poetry, given by the Academy of American Poets. The prize, established with a $2 million gift from the painter Dorothea Tanning, consists of a $100,000 cash stipend. Ms. Rich's most recent book of poetry is ''Dark Fields of the Republic: Poems 1991-1995,'' published by W. W. Norton. She is to receive the award in a ceremony next spring.

title: On the Trail of a C.I.A. Man: Trips and Big Cash Transfers
description: At 10:11 A.M. on June 27, Harold J. Nicholson, a veteran C.I.A. officer, slung a camera bag over his shoulder and locked his $300 room in the Garden Wing of the Shangri-La Hotel, then slipped out of the lobby, past the luxury cars in the driveway and into the elegant streets of Singapore.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about plans to replace New York City bus stop signs misidentified the agency making the change. It is the Department of Transportation, not the Transit Authority.

title: An Empire's Days of Glory and Days of Bitterness
description: AMERICAN DREAMERS

title: Investigation Into Charity Is Detailed
description: Investigators looking into the finances of a politically connected social-services group in Brooklyn will examine consulting contracts that the group gave to people with ties to a state assemblyman, an official familiar with the investigation said yesterday.

title: F.T.C. Said to Reach Agreement On Improper Auto Lease Ads
description: The Federal Trade Commission is planning to announce on Thursday that it has reached an agreement with five auto makers accused of improperly advertising auto lease deals, according to people familiar with the agreement.

title: In Boston, Nothing Is Something
description: At a time when experts are trying to understand why homicide rates in many cities are dropping, Boston has one of the most impressive statistics of all: not a single juvenile under 17 has been killed by gunfire since July 1995.

title: Cable and Wireless Reports 9% Rise in Profit
description: Signaling a recovery from its financial problems of 1995, Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose a higher-than-expected 9 percent in the six months that ended on Sept. 30 because of cost cutting and increased sales.

title: Jets Trying to Revive Not-So-Special Teams
description: The worst unit on the team with the worst record in pro football was sent to work today without having lunch.

title: Too Busy to Look Ahead
description: To The Home Section:

title: Calendar: Sales, Film, Talk and Tree Auction
description: Ceramics Plus Crafts

title: In the Gubernatorial Swim
description: James E. McGreevey, a Democratic State Senator who is the Mayor of Woodbridge, chose the seaside yesterday to announce that he was officially testing the waters for a gubernatorial race.

title: Q & A / General Khin Nyunt : Burma:An Inside View Of the Military's Control
description: For two decades Burma was shut off from the rest of the world under the military dictatorship of General Ne Win. In 1988, after he announced his retirement, the doors burst open and riots raged throughout the country. Within months, the military quelled the protests by forming the State Law and Order Restoration Council. In 1990, the council, under Lieutenant General Khin Nyunt, allowed elections, resulting in an overwhelming majority for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her National League for Democracy. Six years later, Burma is still under military rule, languishing in poverty and accused of numerous abuses of human rights. In Rangoon, General Khin Nyunt was interviewed by Barbara Victor, an author and journalist.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about Federal hearings into the crash of Valujet flight 592 in the Florida Everglades referred incorrectly to an official of the National Transportation Safety Board. Bernard Loeb, shown conferring with John Goglia, a member of the safety board, is a staff official, not a fellow board member.

title: Events: Exhibitions and Lectures
description: Swedish Glass Design

title: For a Wanderer, To Err Is Divine
description: IT started with a romantic idea. Robyn Davidson, who had already won fame with her book ''Tracks,'' about crossing the vast deserts of western Australia alone with four camels and a dog, saw a group of nomads in Pushkar, in western India: she imagined the wonders she could behold, the delights she could experience and the profound insights she could have if she traveled with them for a season's migration through the grazing lands of Rajasthan.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an agreement between the State Department and seven airlines to speed the notification of victims' families in the event of air disasters abroad referred incorrectly in some editions to the company involved in the explosion of a jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland. It was Pan Am, not T.W.A.

title: Rice to Stay With Red Sox
description: JIM RICE, whose future had been in question during Boston's 50-day search for a manager, will return as the Red Sox hitting coach, the team said yesterday, a day after hiring JIMY WILLIAMS as manager. (AP)

title: Now, Ads Bound For Coffee Tables
description: ''ZONA HOME.'' ''The Table: Diane von Furstenburg.'' ''A Tiffany Christmas.'' ''The Ikea Book of Home Design.''

title: After a Bald Flash, Magic and Grace From Louis
description: The sadly underrated virtues of craft and professionalism could be expected from Murray Louis, a choreographer for more than 40 years. But Mr. Louis also seems to have come into a time of renewed vitality and imagination, which, coupled with his refreshing literateness, made for an exhilarating evening when Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance opened on Tuesday night in a two-week season at the Joyce Theater.

title: Bowne in Joint Venture
description: Bowne & Company, based in New York, and the Williams Lea Group of London have formed a joint venture to provide services to multinational companies, law firms and financial institutions. The joint venture, called Bowne Williams Lea International, will offer services like document creation and distribution. Bowne, a financial printer, has also acquired the financial-printing business of Williams Lea for an undisclosed amount of cash. The unit's revenue is $12 million.

title: This Sea Wall Is Really Art For the Daring
description: SAILORS bobbing off the North Shore, an area of old summer estates some 40 miles north of Boston, don't need to look for a lighthouse. Now, they can keep their bearings with the help of a monumental sea wall designed by Priscilla Randall.

title: North Korea's Heir Seems in Charge, but a Grim Winter Looms
description: As wintry cold spreads across the Korean Peninsula, North Korea is desperately short of oil and food and lacks a president. But it at least appears to have someone in charge.

title: All Aid Is Political
description: Nothing better illustrates the lessons and risks of humanitarian intervention than the fast-changing situation in Central Africa. It reminds us that intervention (just like nonintervention) is an inherently political action with inescapable political consequences.

title: Addressing Bias Complaints
description: Officials at Schering-Plough Corporation will hold the company's second meeting with employees today to discuss black workers' complaints of racial discrimination at the company's Kenilworth plant, said a spokesman for the pharmaceutical concern, whose headquarters are in Madison.

title: Bias Suits Against Wall St. Firms
description: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson called on Texaco Inc. last week to urge the oil company to address racial discrimination, he arrived in the glare of television lights. But three years ago, a similar visit to Smith Barney Inc. received scant publicity. His workplace concern then: allegations of not only racial, but also sexual, discrimination made by a politically connected investment banker at one of Wall Street's biggest brokerage firms.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, misstated the year of the assassination of his grandfather, a former Egyptian Prime Minister. It was 1910, not 1904.

title: U.S. to Ease Banks' Way in Selling Stocks And Insurance
description: Frustrated by years of Congressional inaction, the chief regulator of national banks announced the adoption today of a new rule to make it easier for many banks to offer additional financial products, like securities and insurance.

title: On-Demand Printing
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The credits listing with a theater review yesterday about ''Julia Sweeney's 'God Said 'Ha!' '' misspelled the director's surname in some copies. She is Beth Milles, not Miles.

title: PACIFIC GAS TO BUY TECO PIPELINE IN TEXAS
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, based in San Francisco, said late on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Teco Pipeline Company for $380 million. Teco, based in Corpus Christi, Tex., owns a 500-mile pipeline in Texas that stretches from Waha, near Midland, to Katy, near Houston. The company, which also has gas collection and processing centers and a gas marketing unit, had 1995 revenue of about $534 million. The Pacific Gas Transmission Company unit of Pacific Gas already operates pipelines in the Pacific Northwest and Australia. Closely held TRT Holdings has a majority stake in Teco and said it was selling Teco to focus on its recently purchased Omni Hotel chain.

title: Sleight of Hand Signals
description: The game of football espionage has been played for years. How weird do things get when the season slips away?

title: Executive Shifts On the West Coast
description: West Coast offices of two agencies have named new leaders.

title: Be thrifty and invest well, and then wait for the huge tax bill.
description: GOOD news for the affluent and thrifty: the 1996 law raising the minimum wage also suspends the 15 percent tax on ''excess distributions'' from retirement savings. Trouble is, the suspension of the tax lasts just three years. And what very few Americans understand, a new study argues, is that Washington has long been chipping away at retirement tax breaks, creating huge potential tax liabilities for millions of baby boomers and their heirs.

title: Bob Dole's last campaign has led to another, but this one is on behalf of Air France
description: BOB DOLE is flying right from a Presidential campaign into an advertising campaign.

title: Social Security Workers Held In Frauds Using Credit Cards
description: Federal officials announced the arrests of a group of Social Security Administration employees yesterday, charging them with passing confidential information on at least 1,000 people to credit-card thieves for bribes as little as $10.

title: WATSCO AGREES TO BUY UNIT FROM INTER-CITY
description: Watsco Inc. agreed yesterday to purchase the Coastline Distribution Inc. unit and four factories owned by the Inter-City Products Corporation for less than $50 million in cash. Watsco, which makes residential central air- conditioners, will pay less than $50 million for Coastline, the Toronto-based unit that distributes heating and air-conditioning products, and four branches, Ronald Newman, Watsco's vice president for finance, said. He declined to give the exact price. The 1996 revenue for the businesses Watsco is acquiring is estimated to be $94 million, the company said.

title: Gretzky and Messier Are on Familiar Ice
description: Seventeen years ago, a pair of wide-eyed teenagers first skated together in a tiny arena on the University of Alberta campus.

title: Smoltz Takes the Money and Stays in Atlanta
description: One giant leap for hitters, a smaller but no less significant step for pitchers.

title: Now He's Bipartisan
description: In the campaign, President Clinton worked hard to frighten voters into believing Republicans were ''making severe cuts in Medicare.'' Terry McBrayer, Kentucky's Democratic chairman, put it this way: ''I think the white-haired people are scared and that ultimately helps us.''

title: Teen-Ager Sought in Baby's Death Is Expected to Surrender
description: The Bergen County teen-ager accused with his girlfriend of murdering their newborn son will turn himself in on Thursday morning, his lawyer said today.

title: The Sound and The Jury
description: The Gidget of murder trials was back, with less jangle, more frosting, shorter shag, tidier clothes.

title: Sales of Home H.I.V. Tests Are Brisk, But Concern Persists Over Propriety
description: At a Rite Aid drugstore in Manhattan recently, a man handed the pharmacist a slip of paper he had torn from a pad hanging next to the condoms. After the pharmacy section cleared out, she gave him a bag with a home H.I.V. test inside.

title: Democrats To Return Another Gift Tied to Huang
description: For the third time in recent weeks, the Democratic Party has announced that it is returning a large donation solicited by John Huang, the former senior finance official and protege of a billionaire Indonesian family at the center of several Congressional inquiries.

title: The Pop Life
description: With some of the pop world's biggest stars -- Madonna, Barbra Streisand, Whitney Houston -- appearing in new films, many of the holiday season's most anticipated releases are soundtracks. Along with the regular holiday boom in new movies, film scores and compilations are flooding into stores and scattering all over the pop charts. Here are a few of the season's more notable soundtracks.

title: Make This Inauguration Day the People's
description: To the Editor:

title: Sic Transit Lou
description: Anyone who thinks college football is a game needs to check with Lou Holtz. What was supposed to be the greatest Notre Dame dynasty since Knute Rockne produced just one national championship in 11 years under Mr. Holtz's leadership. Since then the program has sputtered toward mediocrity. Notre Dame is one of those places where only undefeated seasons and regular crowns guarantee employment.

title: 42% of School Budget Is Shown Reaching New York City Classes
description: After decades of clamoring by parents and political officials, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday threw open the books of the Board of Education, giving an unusually detailed accounting of how the nation's biggest school system allots its money. The bottom line is that only 42 percent of the system's $8.2 billion budget finds its way directly into the classroom.

title: Extra Tests for Olajuwon
description: Although HAKEEM OLAJUWON's heartbeat was back to normal yesterday, the Rockets center remained hospitalized in Houston as doctors performed further tests.

title: Chiroscience Of England In U.S. Pact
description: Chiroscience Group P.L.C., a specialty chemical and drug development company based in Cambridge, England, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Darwin Molecular Corporation, a biotechnology company with a prominent group of backers, in a stock swap valued at about $120 million.

title: CYTYC STOCK SOARS ON ACCEPTANCE OF ITS PAP TEST
description: Shares of the Cytyc Corporation jumped 23 percent yesterday after the company said the United Healthcare Corporation, based in Minnetonka, Minn., had accepted Cytyc's Thinprep Pap test for coverage in health insurance plans. Shares of Cytyc rose $4.4375, to $23.4375. Analysts said the decision by United Healthcare, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, could mean that four million to six million of Cytyc's Pap tests would be used annually. The Thinprep test uses a thin film to analyze cervical cells and is an advance over the older Pap smear, United Healthcare said.

title: The Cloakrooms of Russia, the Dens of Dragons
description: Winter has slowly begun to muscle its way back to its natural place at the center of Russian life. Furs are starting to emerge from storage. So are hats and boots. It is the season when mud gives way to snow and people tape their windows shut against the cold.

title: Channel Tunnel, Hit by Fire, May Stay Closed for a Week
description: The rail tunnel under the English Channel, shut down since a fire ripped through a freight train on the way to Britain on Monday night, may remain closed until the end of this week, officials said today, as a British-French safety commission reviewed emergency procedures.

title: At 83 and 88, Glass Artists Thrive Anew
description: REDISCOVERING late, once-great designers is all the rage. But when the talents being celebrated are still alive -- and still working, despite the frailties of age -- the attention is especially gratifying.

title: Harnessing TV's Power to the Power of the Page
description: Oprah Winfrey has an unfailing sense of how to reel in her viewers. ''The greatest writer of our time comes to my house for dinner!'' she promised halfway through Monday's show, urging the audience to stay tuned for Toni Morrison, the guest on the Oprah's Book Club segment.

title: Gas Leak Caused Blast at Queens Church
description: Fire Department investigators have determined that a thunderous explosion that destroyed a Presbyterian church and two houses in Queens in September was caused by natural gas that seeped from an improperly installed seal on a high-pressure gas line.

title: Retailers Left Out of Computer-Stock Boom
description: The holiday season is when the consumer is king of the personal computer industry. So the recent fall in the stock prices of computer retailers like CompUSA, Circuit City Stores and Best Buy has some investors and analysts scratching their heads.

title: Value Names Gray Kirk/VanSant
description: Value Rent-a-Car in Boca Raton, Fla., a division of Mitsubitshi Motor Sales of America, has named Gray Kirk/VanSant Advertising in Baltimore to handle its account, which had been at Harris Drury Cohen in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for five years. Billings were estimated at $7 million.

title: Rwandan Road Is Lined With Lost Children
description: By early afternoon, there were already 15 children in the tent set up at the side of the road in the village of Mikunga. They huddled together in one corner, some using the ragged bundles they carried for pillows.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOSEPH GRANO JR. was in his late teens, planning on a career as a math teacher, when he left college to join the Army's Special Forces and fight in Vietnam.

title: Assailing Giuliani, Bratton Won't Rule Out Mayoral Bid
description: William J. Bratton, the former police commissioner who resigned after a falling out with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, strongly criticized the Mayor yesterday and said he had not ruled out running in the Democratic mayoral primary next year.

title: Romania's Communist Legacy: 'Abortion Culture'
description: Dorina Ciuplan, a 40-year-old mother of three teen-agers, recalled with a mixture of terror and emotion the nine self-induced abortions she endured during Communist rule under Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: A Colt in Baltimore Is Now 'Pops' in Dallas
description: In a locker room swarmed daily by members of the news media intent on catching proclamations from stars named Emmitt, Troy and Deion, there is a stiff-legged lineman who is left pretty much alone to wobble from training room to dressing stall. Each step brings a grimace. Ray Donaldson is like a worn, jagged rock rolling through another day of his 17th and final National Football League season.

title: Fresh Signs of Buoyancy In the German Economy
description: German business confidence shot up in October and growth in the money supply remained above the Bundesbank's target, dimming the chances for cuts in the interest rate, as Europe's largest economy swings into gear.

title: Sanchez Vicario Finds A Pace That Advances
description: Considering that her opponent owned the serve that has broken every speed limit on the women's tour, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario took a healthy attitude into her first-round match at the Chase Championships last night. ''The more pace, the better,'' said the Spaniard, who has made a career of undermining the pace and power of her peers with her own most powerful weapon, her ability to retrieve any and every ball sent in her direction.

title: Christopher, in Beijing, Sees Better Relations With China
description: Seeking a fresh start in tattered relations with an emerging superpower, Secretary of State Warren Christopher met today with China's leaders and said he was hopeful of a better, more stable relationship in the future.

title: Sol Levine, 74, Expert on Medical Sociology, Dies
description: Sol Levine, a researcher and writer on medical sociology, died on Sunday at the New England Medical Center in Boston. He was 74 and lived in nearby Brookline.

title: Accounts
description: * Pharmacia & Upjohn, Kalamazoo, Mich., to Creatability, Coral Gables, Fla., as the first agency to handle advertising and public relations aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers for its consumer health care division, which markets such products as Cortaid and Dramamine. Billings were not disclosed, but Advertising Age estimated them at $14 million.

title: ANDREWS OFFERS $171 MILLION FOR TOY BIZ SHARES
description: Andrews Group Inc., the investment company owned by Ronald O. Perelman, said yesterday after the close of trading that it had offered to buy the outstanding shares of Toy Biz Inc. for $19 a share, or about $171 million. The Andrews Group said it planned to make Toy Biz, the New York-based toy maker, a unit of its struggling Marvel Entertainment Group unit, which produces comic books and trading cards. Earlier, shares of Toy Biz rose 87.5 cents to $18.25. Last month, the Andrews Group said it would buy the 67 percent stake in Toy Biz held by its two founders for an undisclosed amount, adding that it would buy the remaining shares in the future. The Andrews Group had also said that it would spend $350 million for newly issued Marvel stock at a steep discount in exchange for cash or Toy Biz stock. Andrews said yesterday that the offer to buy the rest of Toy Biz was contingent upon completion of the Marvel investment.

title: False Alarms for Mets
description: Don't get excited thinking the Mets will acquire either White Sox third baseman ROBIN VENTURA or Braves first baseman FRED McGRIFF.

title: Parents in Hartford Urge State-Run Magnet Schools
description: Seven years after filing a lawsuit that led the State Supreme Court to rule that Hartford's schools are illegally segregated, a group of Hartford parents today presented their ideas for addressing the problem.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18

title: Bridge
description: Bridge players who own a computer can improve their playing skills nowadays for a modest price, since software has improved markedly in the last five years.

title: Treasury Report Will Oppose Federal Taxes on Internet Sales
description: The Treasury Department, struggling to devise a tax policy that keeps up with the rapid growth of electronic commerce, will publish a draft report today that outlines the Administration's opposition to new Federal taxes on the Internet but underscores its determination that the global computer network not become a haven for tax evaders.

title: Tensions Rise in Rwanda as Refugees Seek to Reclaim Homes
description: The old Tutsi woman leaned on her stick and spat at the ground when asked about the Hutu refugees who have come to reclaim the house she lives in. Three of her children were murdered by Hutu militants, she said, and she was not feeling charitable toward the refugees.

title: Unit of NEC Narrows Review
description: NEC Technologies, a division of the NEC Corporation that makes computer peripheral products, has narrowed a review on its account to six agencies from 12. The account, with billings estimated at $15 million, has been at Hampel/Stefanides in New York for two years.

title: Of Rape in the Military and Trysts in the Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Kmart Profits Top Estimates As Revenues Decline 1.6%
description: The Kmart Corporation reported its second straight profitable quarter yesterday, after two years of disappointing results.

title: Black Heart Risk Found To Differ by Birthplace
description: Doctors have noted for years that black Americans are more likely than whites to suffer from diseases of the heart and circulatory system, and to die of them. But researchers now say there is evidence that this increased risk is not shared equally among blacks.

title: Ailing Agassi Is Trounced, Fined and Out of Tourney
description: The whistles no compliment from a European crowd -- rose to a crescendo. It was the sound of Andre Agassi striking bottom.

title: Wharton's Other Talent
description: WHAT decorator doesn't revere the novelist Edith Wharton? After all, Wharton, above, obsessed by the home as a spiritual mirror, probably invented the profession in 1897 with an influential how-to manual, ''The Decoration of Houses.'' It remains in print thanks to its good advice, said Theresa Craig, the author of ''Edith Wharton, a House Full of Rooms: Architecture, Interiors and Gardens (Monacelli, $45). ''Like, if you can't afford a room of really good furniture, then invest in one or two pieces,'' Ms. Craig said. ''As long as everything else is simple and well made, whether new or old, you can't go wrong.'' Today at noon, Ms. Craig is to talk about Wharton's style -- above, her library near Paris -- at Urban Center Books, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3592.

title: Concerted Effort Can Fill University Press Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Bucks for Belle
description: Albert Belle, until Tuesday an outfielder for the Cleveland Indians, has now signed a five-year contract with the Chicago White Sox for $11 million a year, making him by far the highest-paid player in baseball. Mr. Belle's stupefying deal provides grist for statisticians and for students of life's little ironies.
