title: Vest Saves Officer In Newark Shooting
description: A Newark police officer was saved by his bulletproof vest last night when he was shot in the chest during a scuffle with two men in the city's South Ward.

title: Two Airlines Shipped Devices Cited in a Crash, Board Hears
description: Until recently, Delta and Trans World Airlines were improperly shipping oxygen generators of the kind that are blamed for the Valujet crash on May 11, a Transportation Department official testified today at a hearing into that crash.

title: Bar Boxing Vs. Regulations
description: For the last six Mondays, the Viper Lounge has invited boxers to put on gloves, climb into a ring and go rounds of less than a minute.

title: No Headline
description: ''Before, we were a very rich country. Now things are coming down a bit. That means we can't just collect money. We have to learn, we have to train, we have to concentrate and we have to work.''

title: G.O.P. Leader Tries to Replace Ethics Panelists
description: Representative Dick Armey, the House Republican leader, is trying to replace most of the members of the ethics committee, which is considering charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT WORSENS, AND GAP WITH CHINA GROWS
description: As President Clinton prepares to press top Chinese officials to open their market more fully to American goods, the Government reported today that the trade deficit with China rose in September to another record. It was part of one of the widest overall monthly trade gaps posted by the United States in years.

title: Stick to Limits on Law On Independent Counsel
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Rises As China Talks Near

title: As Debate Over Megastores Rages, One Opens in Queens
description: As the dispute over the future of superstores in New York City continued to boil at City Hall, one of the biggest of the so-called warehouse stores, Costco, opened its doors in Queens yesterday, selling food and household goods in bulk at low prices. And judging by the crowds, New Yorkers appeared eager to welcome the store, a staple of suburban shopping.

title: Natural Gas Rises as Search Quickens for Winter Supplies
description: Natural gas prices continued their climb on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as the prospects for dwindling inventories this winter set off a race for supplies now.

title: President Is Re-elected in Zambia, but Vote Is Called Tainted
description: Frederick J. T. Chiluba has easily won re-election as President of Zambia, but the country's most important election-monitoring group declared today that the elections ''cannot be said to have been free and fair.''

title: Relief-Plan Politics Discussed at U.N.
description: Officials from countries planning an international force to assist in relief efforts in Rwanda and eastern Zaire met here today to discuss the political situation in which this force will have to operate.

title: Chicago, Joined by an Array of Dignitaries, Bids Farewell to Cardinal Bernardin
description: It was a very long goodbye, and it had to be. For three days, all Chicago, Catholic and non-Catholic alike, seemed to be bidding farewell to Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, whispering one last prayer and blinking away a final tear for a soft-spoken religious leader whose life and death touched so many here.

title: A de Kooning 'Woman' Tops the Year's Art Sales
description: The contemporary-art market skyrocketed last night at Christie's, where Willem de Kooning's 1949 ''Woman,'' a powerful portrait of a woman seated like a Renaissance Madonna, sold for $15.6 million, the highest price paid for an artwork at auction this year. The painting also broke the $10 million barrier for contemporary art, the first work to do so since the art market took a nose dive in 1990.

title: HORIZON/CMS TO SELL 15 REHABILITATION CENTERS
description: The Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation has said that it has agreed to sell its interest in 15 rehabilitation centers in California to Regency Health Services Inc. for $42.3 million. Horizon, based in Albuquerque, N.M., will receive about $36.3 million in cash and about $7 million of promissory notes, the company said late on Tuesday. The proceeds will be used to pay off debt, Horizon said. Regency, a nursing-home operator based in Tustin, Calif., also plans to buy Horizon's Meridian Neuro Care business, which operates six centers in California, Horizon said. The operations sold to Regency generated about $66 million in revenue in its last fiscal year. Regency had revenue of $416.1 million last year. It expects to complete the purchase by year's end.

title: A Cigarette Spoof With a Serious Message for Teen-Agers
description: Here are some names to puff on: HBO and Consumer Reports Television celebrate the American Cancer Society's Great American Smokeout tonight with ''Smoke Alarm: The Unfiltered Truth About Cigarettes.'' But don't be put off by the credentialism. This sobering spoof, directed at the under-18 set, is anything but stuffy.

title: In Unholy Matrimony, Till the Lease Is Up
description: Always flitting around the periphery of the television schedule is the kind of show that is not a breakout hit but has just enough intriguing energy to merit attention. At the moment, ''The Drew Carey Show,'' on ABC, is one example. Another is Fox's ''Ned and Stacey,'' now back for a second season.

title: Nestle Sales Up 5.7% In First 10 Months
description: Nestle S.A. said yesterday that its sales rose 5.7 percent to 48.3 billion Swiss francs ($38.6 billion) in the first 10 months of the year, and its chairman forecast a full-year profit of more than 3 billion francs ($2.4 billion).

title: Agency Seeks A Role in Texaco Case
description: A Federal agency asked yesterday to be allowed to intervene in a discrimination suit settled last week by Texaco Inc., raising the possibility that the record agreement may have to be renegotiated.

title: 3 Singers With Something to Prove
description: The supposed death of the art song recital is a perennial cause for lamentation in some circles, but whenever the mourners take up their doleful chorus, I wonder where they have been. Singers who are in New York to work at the Metropolitan Opera, and others just passing through, offer an almost nonstop parade of recitals -- true recitals, not collections of opera arias -- and these performances attract the largest, most committed and most passionately opinionated audiences in the classical music world.

title: Political Gambling
description: The gamblers won a ballot initiative in Arizona, where voters called on the Governor to sign a casino deal with Indian tribes -- though he gutsily says he won't. And in Detroit, citizens fearful of losing business to a casino in Ontario voted to build a defensive one of their very own. That's two scores for the crapshooters.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Is It Too Late for Sod?

title: From Japan to Italy, Proposals Pour In for L.I. Land
description: Another message from Italy was left this morning on the part-time Mayor's answering machine. In halting English, the caller wanted to know, please, whether the village had received her submission, thank you very much.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AT&T CORP., New York, said its three-way split will be completed on the last day of the year with the spinoff of NCR Corp. Shareholders will receive one share of NCR for each 16 shares of AT&T they hold.

title: S.E.C. Sues Wall St. Firm For Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued the CS First Boston Corporation for securities fraud yesterday in connection with a 1994 underwriting of $110 million in pension bonds for Orange County, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about farmers' preparations for winter referred incorrectly to one farm and misspelled the name of its town. The town is Ancramdale, N.Y., not Ancrandale; the farm is Ancramdale Farms, not Farm.

title: Artists and Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Baby Death Is Expected to Surrender
description: The New Jersey teen-ager accused with his girlfriend of murdering their newborn child plans to turn himself in this morning, his lawyer said.

title: A Magnate Is Kidnapped and 2 Are Charged
description: A prominent industrialist was kidnapped on Tuesday, and two men, at least one a career criminal, were arrested after payment of a $500,000 ransom and the springing of a trap by the police and the F.B.I.

title: Will Bridges Be the Next Frontier?
description: BRIDGES hold a special place in the imagination. They span mysterious depths, soar to giddy heights, raise a few goose bumps of fear at the slight risk of crossing. There's even a nursery rhyme commemorating the 1830 collapse of one of the most famous, London Bridge.

title: Organize
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Dispute on Veterans' Health

title: CHRONICLE
description: Given the marital woes of her children, QUEEN ELIZABETH II is giving some thought to burnishing the tarnished luster of the institution of marriage at the approach of the golden anniversary of her marriage to PRINCE PHILIP.

title: What's Publishable
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Laughs, a Few Victories
description: From the corner lockers of the defensemen to the lockers of the forwards and the goalies, there is laughter everywhere at the Devils' training facility here.

title: Runway Collision Renews Concerns About Towerless Airports
description: Like thousands of other small airports and landing fields from Alaska to Florida, the airport at Quincy, Ill., where 14 people perished on Tuesday when two planes collided on a runway, did not have an air traffic control tower.

title: Giving and Getting a Recital
description: As part of the prize for winning this year's Young Concert Artists International Auditions, Gregory Turay, an American, was presented on Sunday afternoon in a recital at the 92d Street Y. And young is the applicable word for this gifted tenor.

title: Girl's Killer Evades Trial Under Death Penalty Law
description: A jobless grocery clerk from Kingston, who might otherwise have been the first person to stand trial under New York State's new death-penalty law, pleaded guilty yesterday to bludgeoning a 7-year-old girl to death with a rock.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Criminal Act Is 'Less Likely' In Jet's Crash
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's lead investigator in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 said yesterday that he now believes it is ''less likely that a bomb or a missile'' caused the plane to explode, killing all 230 people on board.

title: Former Justice Official May Face More Whitewater Scrutiny
description: Webster L. Hubbell, the longtime friend of the President who once occupied a Justice Department office next door to the Attorney General, was transferred to a halfway house here today in anticipation of his release soon, a spokeswoman from the Federal Bureau of Prisons said.

title: McKesson Named Supplier
description: Omnicare Inc. said today that it had reached a five-year agreement for the McKesson Corporation to become its sole primary supplier of wholesale pharmaceuticals and related services. Omnicare provides pharmacy and consulting services for long-term health care facilities. It said it expected purchases to exceed $350 million in the next 12 months and added that they might exceed $2 billion over the length of the contract. The company previously purchased pharmaceuticals through a supply contract with the Foxmeyer Drug Company under an agreement signed in 1995. McKesson recently acquired the health care distribution business of Foxmeyer.

title: Pretty Heady Stuff: A Spinning Mason Is All Smiles
description: The muscular player with an inscription shaved into his scalp was wagging his tongue and bobbing his head as the final buzzer sounded. He hopped and skipped off the Charlotte Coliseum floor, feeling good about his team and himself.

title: In Baseball, Reinsdorf Smiles Alone
description: IF George Steinbrenner or Ted Turner or the California Angels' mascot, Mickey Mouse, had signed Albert Belle to a contract worth $15 million a year, no one would have been surprised.

title: H.M.O. Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Progress for School Bill
description: The Senate Education Committee approved a bill yesterday to revamp school financing, but it added money to prevent wealthier school districts from losing state aid -- as they would have under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's original proposal -- unless their enrollment has declined. Although the bill, which now carries a price of $260 million, would increase spending slightly for poorer students, Democratic lawmakers predicted that it would not satisfy the State Supreme Court mandate for parity in spending between rich and needy districts. The bill now goes to the Senate Appropriations Committee.

title: Elderly Man And an Aide Found Slain In His Home
description: An elderly man and his home health care worker were found dead yesterday at his elegant house on a rise in an affluent section of Eastchester, N.Y., the police said.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: U.S. Set to Allow Reactors to Use Plutonium From Disarmed Bombs
description: In spite of protests from its own arms control specialists, the Clinton Administration is on the verge of relaxing a two-decade-old Federal policy intended to keep nuclear weapons out of the hands of terrorists and rogue states.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Mullen Advertising Selected by Nextel
description: Nextel Communications, a wireless communications company in McLean, Va., yesterday named Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Executive Changes
description: NGC CORP., Houston, named Thomas M. Matthews, a former Texaco executive, as president, succeeding Chuck Watson, who will continue as chairman and chief executive.

title: Mexican Output Rises 7.4%, Eclipsing Economic Forecasts
description: The Mexican Finance Ministry reported today that the economy surged by 7.4 percent in the third quarter, compared with the similar period a year earlier, exceeding economists' expectations.

title: Bet You Can't Make Just One
description: The face on the Air France ad you saw in yesterday's paper was, indeed, former Presidential candidate Bob Dole, lending his presence to a promotion for $299 tickets to Paris.

title: George Ginsberg, 97, 'Penny Philanthropist,' Dies
description: George C. Ginsberg, a retired commercial photographer often called ''the penny philanthropist''for his modest but loyal contributions to scores of charities, died on Monday at his home in Springfield, N.J. He was 97.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''When we started, it would have seemed just a joke that there would be a woman President of the United States,'' BETTY FRIEDAN said yesterday. ''It's not a joke anymore. There may be a woman President in my lifetime.''

title: Security Isn't Political For South Koreans
description: To the Editor:

title: Severe Storms in Northwest Leave 12 Dead
description: Severe storms that took the Pacific Northwest by surprise this week have caused at least 12 deaths, with record rains in Oregon, unusually early snow in western Washington and the worst ice storm on record in Spokane.

title: Even Johnson Is Singing 'I'm Tired of This' Blues
description: The mile-a-minute smile suddenly slowed to a frown today when Keyshawn Johnson put on his Jets jersey to go to work.

title: A SoHo Sampler: Short List for Prize
description: LIKE politicians and porn stars, the Guggenheim Museum seems to be a step or two beyond embarrassment these days.

title: Japanese Bank Waits for Ruling
description: Asahi Bank, one of Japan's biggest banks, is waiting for regulators to rule on possible irregularities at the bank's New York branch in June, a company spokesman said today.

title: Canadians' Failure: Indians and Eskimos
description: Canada's policies toward its Indians and Eskimos have been a shameful failure and their plight will only grow worse if these polices are not changed, according to a commission that spent five years and $43.5 million studying the condition of the country's indigenous people.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Talk about people who don't have a prayer!

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Jumping the Gun on 'Laughter'

title: Shell Oil's Own Little Problem
description: The Shell Oil Company and Texaco Inc. are contemplating a multibillion-dollar merger of their refining and marketing operations in the U.S. Last week, in a letter to employees, the president of a Shell subsidiary expressed concern about the race discrimination controversy swirling about Texaco.

title: Compuserve Changes Focus To Home Office And Businesses
description: In abandoning its fledgling, family-oriented Wow service, the Compuserve Corporation is trying to reinvent itself once again, building a computer network for home office and small-business customers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an auction for a prime site in the Times Square area misstated the address. It is on the southwest corner of Broadway and 47th Street, not the northwest corner.

title: The Crisis in Belarus
description: Few former pieces of the Soviet empire have fared worse than Belarus, a land of 10 million people wedged between Russia and Poland. Economic stagnation and political extremism have brought the country to the brink of dictatorship and civil conflict. What happens in Belarus matters a great deal because this forgotten country owns a small but lethal arsenal of 18 nuclear missiles left behind by Moscow when the Soviet Union collapsed.

title: Union Forum Is New Tool To Air Woes Of Workers
description: Labor unions are forever complaining that the judiciary is stacked against them, so now they have created a tribunal that they know will side with them 100 percent of the time: the New York Workers' Rights Board.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Two or Three Things I Know About Her

title: Southern Italy Doesn't Merit Bad Reputation
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Stora North America Corp., Stamford, Conn., to Anderson & Lembke, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as the first North American agency for the paper products company. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Rudolf Schlesinger, 87, Expert On the World's Legal Systems
description: Rudolf B. Schlesinger, a professor emeritus at the Hastings College of the Law whose studies of the world's legal systems are an important resource for those overseeing commercial links with other countries, died on Nov. 10 at his home in San Francisco. He was 87.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''Look!'' says my friend, holding up one of the long, thin pumpernickel rolls. ''It's a cigar!''

title: 7 Admit Guilt in Kickbacks
description: Seven people pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in a kickback scheme that may have involved 200 school employees from Newark and other cities, Attorney General Peter Verniero told The Associated Press. The authorities said the workers submitted fraudulent insurance claims for psychiatric treatment they never received. They said the scheme's mastermind was a Ridgewood psychologist, Dr. Carl Lichtman, who pleaded guilty in May to conspiring with more than 200 people to bilk insurers. Dr. Lichtman has been cooperating with investigators and has agreed to repay more than $2 million.

title: Times Co. Raises Dividend to 15 Cents
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that its dividend payment would be increased for the first time since 1990.

title: Zap! And Off To Do Battle With Aliens
description: ''Resistance is futile,'' say the ads for ''Star Trek: First Contact,'' quoting one of the film's kitschier lines. Not so: resisting ''Star Trek'' on the big screen has never been easier. The series now lacks all of its original stars and much of its earlier determination. It has morphed into something less innocent and more derivative than it used to be, something the noncultist is ever less likely to enjoy.

title: If you must pay a bribe, don't let it distort the accounting
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission wants to send a message to companies, particularly foreign ones: If you pay bribes, either disclose the practice or make sure that they do not distort your financial statements.

title: J.F.K. to Add Foam Device To a Runway To Slow Jets
description: Kennedy International Airport is about to become the first in the country to have a runway extension made of a kind of cement foam meant to slow an out-of-control jet to a safe stop.

title: British Economic Growth May Lead to Rates Rise
description: The British economy grew 2.4 percent in the third quarter of this year over a year earlier. This was the highest rate of growth since the second quarter of 1995. The number was revised from an initial estimate of 2.3 percent, the Office of National Statistics said yesterday.

title: U.S. TO EASE RULES TO MAKE AIR BAGS LESS DANGEROUS
description: Faced with mounting public anxiety over the danger that air bags pose to small adults and children, the Transportation Department has decided to allow drivers to have the air bags disconnected and manufacturers to make bags that inflate more slowly, Government and private safety experts said today.

title: Johnson Coming Up Shy in the Crunch for Knicks
description: The primary concern in July was having enough basketballs to go around. Free agency and trades had transformed the Knicks into a potent offensive team. Suddenly, they had the talent; all that was missing was sacrifice.

title: Dick Armey's War on Ethics
description: Despite his obfuscating comments yesterday, there is only one way to interpret Representative Dick Armey's effort to replace most members of the House Ethics Committee, which is considering charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich. Mr. Armey, second in command to Mr. Gingrich, wants to rig the committee to get the Speaker off the hook without a full, fair investigation. Corrupting the House ethics process in this way is all the more egregious coming just weeks after a campaign in which Mr. Gingrich relentlessly attacked President Clinton on ethics and corruption issues.

title: Cornhusker Suspended
description: Nebraska linebacker TERRELL FARLEY, 21, was suspended yesterday after being arrested for the second time this year on a suspicion of drunken driving. The police said Farley's speeding car hit two parked cars during a pursuit late Wednesday night, and said he tried to run away from officers.

title: On Eve of African Relief Talks, Aid Donors Argue Over Numbers
description: A day before a major meeting to plan an international military mission in Central Africa, the United Nations, governments and relief agencies disagreed today over the central question of how many Rwandan refugees are still trapped in neighboring Zaire.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Nov. 14 about studies of the health of veterans of the Persian Gulf war misstated the given name of a member of a White House panel that studied the issue. She is Dr. Andrea Kidd Taylor, not Andrew, an occupational health consultant with the United Automobile Workers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: BUYOUT SPECULATION PUSHES BAUSCH & LOMB STOCK HIGHER
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc.'s stock rallied yesterday amid speculation that the company could be the target of a $48-a-share bid from Johnson & Johnson. Officers were not available for comment at either company. The speculation about a deal was advanced by an article in Financial World magazine quoting Philip Foreman, a money manager at Composite Research and Management, as saying that Johnson & Johnson could be a buyer of Bausch, a maker of contact lenses and sunglasses. The shares of Bausch & Lomb, which is based in Rochester, were up $2.25, to $35.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where 2.5 million of its shares were traded. Johnson & Johnson shares were up 75 cents, to $52.125, also on the Big Board. Johnson & Johnson is the market leader in the contact lens market, while Bausch & Lomb is No. 2.

title: The End for Palmer Stadium
description: Sports fans will sit in the crumbling stands of Princeton University's Palmer Stadium for the last time Saturday, as the Tigers play Dartmouth's Big Green, the team they opposed in the first game at Palmer in 1914. The 82-year-old stadium is being demolished to make way for a new $45 million, 30,000-seat stadium.

title: They Studied, They Came, They Bid Feverishly
description: Collectors arrived prepared for Sotheby's and Christie's important fine art auctions in Manhattan, which ended on Wednesday night. Throughout the sales this week and last, they showed up with their dealers and advisers in tow. And everyone seemed to have done his homework. The high prices and record sales that accumulated during the auctions reflected a new breed of informed buyer.

title: Home Video
description: The Window Wars

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AK STEEL CORP., Middletown, Ohio, an integrated steel producer, announced plans to build a $1.1 billion steel finishing plant near Rockport, Ind., creating about 400 jobs.

title: Melding Past and Present in Portugal
description: The salt of fresh sea air, the smell of hot, baked soil: nature arrests the senses at the beautifully organized survey of recent Portuguese architecture now at the Architectural League. But it is an aggressively urban project, set well apart from Portugal's rugged landscape, that ultimately steals the show: Joao Santa Rita's design for a subway station in Lisbon.

title: Publisher Seeks to Update a Classic, to Cries of 'Thuggery'
description: The Dictionary of American Biography is a classic, a masterpiece of historical scholarship on a monumental scale. But like many classics, it is showing its age. It has begun to seem a little out of date.

title: French Book Fair Writhes, Poisoned by Politics
description: With its unemployment rate close to 25 percent and its high-rise suburbs full of jobless North African immigrants, Toulon amounts to a troubled France in miniature. But a decision by the city's rightist Mayor to quash a literary award to a prominent Jewish writer has shocked a nation that had assumed that such acts belonged to the past.

title: Olajuwon to Begin Supervised Workouts
description: Two days after being hospitalized with an irregular heartbeat, Rockets center HAKEEM OLAJUWON, 33, was released from the Methodist Hospital in Houston yesterday after tests, including an exercise stress test, showed no problems.

title: Owners to Meet
description: BUD SELIG, baseball's acting commissioner, confirmed he had called for an owners meeting next Tuesday in Chicago, but he said he did not know whether owners would vote again on the labor deal that was rejected Nov. 6. (AP)

title: COCA-COLA SHARES DROP ON FEAR OF LOWER EARNINGS
description: The stock of the Coca-Cola Company dipped yesterday, a day after remarks by the chief executive raised fears that the company would fail to match Wall Street's earnings expectations for the year. Shares of Coca-Cola closed at $50.625 yesterday, down $1 a share, on New York Stock Exchange trading of 5.7 million shares. Roberto C. Goizueta, the chairman and chief executive, told Chicago executives on Wednesday that the company would report 1996 operating income of about $4 billion. Coke's operating income last year was $4.09 billion. A spokesman said Mr. Goizueta's comment was not ''intended to be any kind of forecast.''

title: GAYLORD TO BUY WORD RECORDS FROM THOMAS NELSON
description: The Gaylord Entertainment Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Word Records and Music from Thomas Nelson Inc. for $110 million. Word Records, a contemporary Christian music company with annual sales of $100 million, has nine record labels and a music publishing business. Gaylord Entertainment is a cable and country music company whose holdings include the Grand Ole Opry and the Nashville Network. Nelson publishes Bibles and other religious materials. Both companies are based in Nashville. The deal is to close early next year. On the New York exchange, Gaylord shares lost 25 cents, to $21.375, and Nelson shares also lost 25 cents, to $13.50.

title: Tours of Artists' Studios And a Benefit Auction
description: From afternoon tours of artists' studios to an evening auction in SoHo, a full day of art is being offered tomorrow by Artwalk NY to benefit the Coalition for the Homeless.

title: Toys 'R' Us Picks Wells Rich Greene
description: Toys ''R'' Us said yesterday that it had formally awarded Wells Rich Greene BDDP Advertising in New York the creative responsibilities for all broadcast advertising by signing a contract with the agency. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Clintons Down Under: Sweet and Sour
description: Here in the land down under, President Clinton is, by his own immodest admission, feeling ''on top of the world.''

title: 3 Concerns Join Forces To Buy STN Atlas
description: Rheinmetall A.G., the utility Badenwerk A.G. and British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that they would jointly pay 550 million marks ($367 million) to buy STN Atlas Elektronik. Rheinmetall, a German auto parts and weapons maker, said that after the takeover it would control STN, a unit of the bankrupt shipping concern Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G. Rheinmetall and Badenwerk will hold 51 percent of STN. British Aerospace will take 49 percent. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Phantom

title: Community Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Show New Drive But Stall in the Fourth
description: The Nets were up against a team that had become as bright a development in this town as the chrome fender. Only the Bulls had been as shiny. Only the Bulls had beaten the Pistons.

title: Nine-Month Profit Rises By 24%, ING Reports
description: The Dutch banking and insurance company ING Groep N.V. said yesterday that its nine-month profit rose by 24 percent, to 2.34 billion guilders ($1.4 billion). The results, up from 1.88 billion guilders ($1.12 billion) a year ago, were about in the middle of analysts' expectations. (Reuters)

title: Politics Defeating Love In Contemporary Cuba
description: In contemporary Cuba, that old expression ''the almighty dollar'' really means something. Whereas the average Cuban doctor, paid in pesos, earns the equivalent of $3 a month, a prostitute can earn $50 a night. Most stores in Havana won't even accept pesos. That's why the discos in the city's tourist hotels swarm with ''nice'' Cuban women working as bar girls. It's why, in Leon Ichaso's beautifully photographed black-and-white film ''Bitter Sugar,'' a Cuban psychiatrist leaps at the opportunity for employment as a journeyman pianist in a hotel playing ''Besame Mucho'' night after night.

title: For Blacks, Economic Gain Is Limited to a Few
description: To the Editor:

title: Chuck Howard, 63, Pioneer TV Sports Producer
description: Chuck Howard, a former producer at ABC Sports and winner of 11 Emmy Awards, died yesterday at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 63.

title: Wetteland Is Waiting
description: The free-agent pitcher JOHN WETTELAND, who anchored the Yankees' bullpen this past season with 43 saves and starred in the World Series with 4 more, has yet to receive a contract offer from his former team. But there is no panic.

title: Floridians Talk Big About Roy Jones
description: The largest crowd to watch an indoor boxing match in Florida is expected to jam the Ice Palace on Friday night to watch Roy Jones Jr. try to capture his third different title in three years.

title: Elmo Langley, 68, Nascar Pace-Car Driver
description: Elmo Langley, a former race-car driver who achieved his greatest fame by circling race tracks at speeds more suitable to public roads, died yesterday in Suzuka General Hospital in Suzuka City, Japan, apparently of heart failure. He was 68.

title: Temple Re-signs Coach
description: Temple has extended Coach RON DICKERSON's contract despite a four-year record of 5-38. The extension comes five games after Dickerson resigned -- then changed his mind -- after a 53-52 loss to Pittsburgh. (AP)

title: Giuliani Dares Bratton to Run Against Him Next Year
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday enthusiastically dared former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton to run against him in the mayoral race next year, suggesting that Mr. Bratton would quickly be exposed as a one-note candidate.

title: Buoyed by Fans, Becker Outlasts Sampras
description: Pete Sampras did not play Davis Cup this year. He is not planning on doing so next February. But like it or not, he played something closely resembling it today.

title: Giuliani Is Said to Choose Chief for Hospital Agency
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has chosen Rosa M. Gil, a senior vice president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, as the new chairwoman of the agency, which runs the city's public hospitals and clinics, according to several people who have been briefed by City Hall.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Reach Another Record on Big Board
description: Short interest, which has grown every month this year except in July, now equals 1.6 percent of all Big Board shares.

title: Joan Paterson Kerr, Editor and Author, 75
description: Joan Paterson Kerr, a picture editor and author, died yesterday at her home in New Haven. She was 75.

title: Egypt Irked, But Softly, At the U.S. On U.N. Veto
description: With an American veto at the United Nations blocking Boutros Boutros-Ghali from a second five-year term as Secretary General, the muttering in his native Egypt is about the arrogance of American power. Was the torpedoing of the Secretary General, President Hosni Mubarak wanted to know, some new kind of democracy? Or was the action by a 14-to-1 vote, as the newspaper Al Ahram declared, evidence of veto abuse? .

title: Diplomacy vs. Semantics on China Visit
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher came to booming Shanghai today to sound a hopeful theme of ''cooperation'' between the United States and China in the next century, based on common interests of trade and security.

title: RUSSIAN MILITARY LOSES SATELLITES
description: In a vivid demonstration of the problems afflicting this country's once-proud space program, Russia has been without photo-reconnaissance satellites for nearly two months, Russian and Western scientists say.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Still No Smoking Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Pick Up the Pace, America. 1-2-3. 1-2-3.
description: To the Editor:

title: Kawasaki May Invest In New Rolls Engine
description: Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. of Japan said yesterday that it was considering investing in the development of Rolls-Royce P.L.C.'s new Trent 900 jet engine. Kawasaki has taken part in the development of the previous versions of the British engineering company's Trent line, a Kawasaki spokesman said. (Dow Jones)

title: Sentencing Of Bissell Was Put Off Three Times
description: The sentencing of a former New Jersey prosecutor, now the object of a worldwide manhunt, was postponed three times from early September to mid-November, giving him, as it turns out, about two and a half months of extra time to plan his flight.

title: Homely Soup, Dressed Up and Ready to Go
description: IN the soup business, passion rules.

title: With Surplus, Last Phase of Pataki Tax Cut Will Be Early
description: In a New Year's gift to taxpayers, New York State plans to move up by three months the last phase of Gov. George E. Pataki's three-year income tax cut plan.

title: A Meaningful School Budget -- at Last
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew deserves enormous credit for offering the most detailed accounting of a school budget in New York City's history. Such efforts were thwarted for decades by a failure of political will -- and a chaotic records system that held previous administrations at bay. The 41-volume document released this week will require fine-tuning in future years, but it already gives the clearest view yet of how the school system spends the $8 billion it receives each year. By allowing line-by-line spending comparisons among districts that perform well and those that fail, the budget accounting could lead to reallocation of scarce funds.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Palmer Stadium

title: Parents Offer Ideas On Rating TV Shows
description: Most parents would like any television ratings system to identify potentially objectionable content in programs rather than simply label them as suitable for certain age groups, according to a random survey of members of the Parent-Teacher Association.

title: Woman Wins Sex Bias Suit
description: Martha Mogull was in her late 40's when she began working in the largely male world of commercial real estate, but she caught on fast, her lawyer said yesterday. In 1981, Ms. Mogull, now 66, brokered a $58 million sale for the Teaneck office of CB Commercial Real Estate Services Group, said the lawyer, Bruce L. Atkins of Hackensack. But not long after, she complained in a sex discrimination lawsuit against CB, she was taken off major accounts and deprived of leads that would have brought her new business. In 1992, she was dismissed. On Wednesday, Ms. Mogull, of Fort Lee, won a $6.5 million verdict, including $5 million in punitive damages, against the company in Superior Court. The company said it would seek a new trial.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Botha Denies Role In '88 Church Bombing
description: Former President P. W. Botha today denied any involvement in the bombing of a church headquarters in 1988 and told the retired Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, chairman of the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, that he had done nothing that would warrant applying for amnesty.

title: 'Only a Matter of Time'
description: Aleksandr I. Lebed is the Russian general who became a politician and has no doubt that he will be Russia's next president. He says 25 years as a paratrooper taught him to talk concretely. In New York this week he used one word to describe Russia's efforts to prevent its nuclear warheads and materials from being stolen for terrorists or by rogue missile crews: ''unsatisfactory.''

title: Mingo Is Renamed; Texaco to Uniworld
description: There have been developments at two agencies that specialize in marketing to black consumers.

title: Guerin Shoots to Head of Class
description: Helping the United States capture the World Cup last summer has done wonders for Bill Guerin of the Devils. The experience of winning the coveted World Cup, the summer after winning the Stanley Cup, has raised his confidence to higher levels. But it has also apparently made him a favorite with the fans.

title: Schoolgirl's Harassment Complaint Is Rejected
description: In a Federal court case that educators across the country are anxiously watching, a jury in Binghamton, N.Y., yesterday rejected a girl's contention that the teasing and abuse she endured from boys as a sixth grader constituted sexual harassment.

title: Both Sides Toughen On Hebron
description: Seven weeks after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, agreed to mount an urgent effort to conclude the transfer of Hebron to the Palestinians and push forward on a broader peace, negotiations have ground tensely to a halt.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 13
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Emotion to Vie With Words As Simpson Takes the Stand
description: Can they rile him?

title: VLSI TO END PRODUCTION AT ITS SAN JOSE PLANT
description: VLSI Technology Inc. will end production in its wafer fabrication plant in San Jose, Calif., by the end of 1997 and dismiss about 300 workers there. VLSI said it would take a charge of between $100 million and $120 million in the fourth quarter of 1996 to cover the shutdown. In the fourth quarter the preceding year, VLSI reported net income of $18.3 million on revenues of $184.3 million. The company said its San Jose plant had been underused since it began shifting to new markets in 1995. VLSI now focuses on providing semiconductorsfor telecommunications products. VLSI's stock jumped $4.50, to $25, on Nasdaq.

title: C.I.A. Officer Indicted by Jury On Sole Charge
description: A Federal grand jury returned a one-count indictment today against Harold J. Nicholson, the career C.I.A. officer who was arrested on Saturday, charging him with conspiracy to commit espionage for Russia.

title: Aviation Agency Assailed at Hearing for Role in Valujet Crash
description: Investigators today criticized the Federal Aviation Administration for a lack of inspection muscle in overseeing Valujet Airlines and shipments of hazardous materials in the months before the airline's May 11 crash.

title: Times Company Names 2 Senior Vice Presidents
description: The New York Times Company announced the appointments of John M. O'Brien and Solomon B. Watson 4th yesterday as senior vice presidents.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 12 with a television review of ''Top Gun Over Moscow,'' a ''Nova'' program about tourist rentals of Russian jet fighters, included an incorrect identification provided by the series for the pilot shown. He was John Karasawa, an electronics specialist, not Jeff Ethell, an aviation writer.

title: One Airline's Shift to a One-Maker Fleet
description: American Airlines and the Boeing Company left out few superlatives in announcing a widely expected agreement yesterday, in which American will buy 103 jets and perhaps hundreds more over the next 20 years as the carrier moves toward an all-Boeing fleet.

title: From 'Eden' to 'Desire'
description: By no coincidence, many of the tars who appeared in Elia Kazan's films did their most vital and voluptuous work under his direction.

title: Coney Island Housing Project Complete
description: One of the latest housing developments in the New York area has sprung up in the Coney Island neighborhood of Brooklyn, with the unmistakable outline of the Parachute Jump on the horizon.

title: INSIDE
description: Cisneros to Step Down

title: They Love to Rock as Hard as Men Do
description: Courtney Love is one rock performer who has never been at a loss for words. And in ''Not Bad for a Girl,'' Lisa Rose Apramian's noisy documentary study of female hard-rockers, she is given the movie's parting shot. Instead of having to get the football captain, she advises, ''Be the football captain.''

title: No One Knew Holtz Like NBC Knew Holtz
description: One of the joys of watching Lou Holtz coach Notre Dame was to observe him in tough televised moments: exhibiting the contentiousness and loopiness of H. Ross Perot and the nonsensical streams of consciousness of Casey Stengel.

title: For Children
description: 'Sites of Chinatown'

title: $25 and Under
description: When Pamela Decaire had dinner one evening on Prince Street this year, a dream came to life. At Bistrot Margot, a little piece of Paris transported to the eastern edge of SoHo, she met the chef, Alioune Ndiaye, and tasted his gutsy, dead-on bistro fare.

title: Rangers Extend Deals
description: The first division title in Texas's franchise history has prompted the Rangers to extend the contracts of General Manager DOUG MELVIN and Manager JOHNNY OATES. The team announced yesterday that one year has been added to both contracts, extending them through 1998. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in some editions of Business Day on Wednesday about the barring of nine brokers from the securities industry misstated the duration of the Series 7 national licensing test for brokers. It lasts six hours, not three.

title: Martin Selects Head Of Direct Marketing
description: The Martin Agency in Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has promoted Judy Carpenito, senior vice president and managing director of Martin's New York office, to executive vice president in charge of Martin Direct, the agency's direct-marketing operations.

title: No Headline
description: ''He did something wrong. But we're not sure what he did wrong.''

title: Giants Primed for Cowboys The Second Time Around
description: If the recent past is any indication, the Giants will be nice and relaxed when they play host to Dallas on Sunday. Quarterback Dave Brown is a part of that. He was so relaxed in the second game against Dallas last season that he ran over Deion Sanders, then skipped back to the huddle, doing the kind of strut that Sanders usually does.

title: Italian Woman Wins World Cup Slalom
description: Emerging from the shadows of her more illustrious teammates, the small but powerful Sabina Panzanini of Italy pulled off her second World Cup career victory here today by winning the Cafe de Colombia giant slalom event.

title: Rangers Lose On Night Fit For Partying
description: It was billed as a homecoming for Mark Messier and Wayne Gretzky, but it was the Edmonton Oilers who did the celebrating tonight.

title: Paramount Shifts Media Duties
description: There was account activity yesterday involving companies owned and partly owned by Viacom Inc.

title: Art in Review
description: Lester Johnson

title: Diverse Diana Corp. to Split Into Two Separate Companies
description: The Diana Corporation said today that it would split into two separately traded companies -- a maker of telecommunications equipment and a distributor of such equipment and of food.

title: Ex-Celtic Found Dead
description: Phil Hankinson, a former basketball player at the University of Pennsylvania and a reserve on the Boston Celtics' 1973-74 championship team, was found shot to death in his car along Interstate 64 in Shelbyville, Ky., on Tuesday, authorities said yesterday.

title: U.S. Approved Equipment Sale to China Despite Hint of Misuse
description: A Congressional inquiry has found that the Commerce Department approved the sale of American machine equipment in 1994 despite advance warning that China might use the equipment for military rather than civilian purposes.

title: Rookie With a Daunting Pedigree
description: He can count his mentors on two hands. There is the English professor, the grouser, the general, the legend, the legend 1A and the couch potato. They are all old enough to be his father -- one actually is -- and, during U.C.L.A.'s rotten egg of an opener, one of them even passed him a crib note.

title: Stocks Gain in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks rose here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 72.77 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 21,216.11. The Nikkei lost 46.62 points on Thursday.

title: Gas Prices Keep Advancing As Cold Weather Is Forecast
description: Natural gas prices surged yesterday for the sixth consecutive session on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid growing concern that inventories were uncomfortably low as winter approached.

title: School Spending Disparities Beg Repeated Query: Why?
description: From the outside, they look a lot alike, two neat, brick-walled elementary schools built more than 40 years ago.

title: Nature Is Not a Liberal Plot
description: As Republicans prepare to begin a second term in control of Congress, a deep skepticism exists in the electorate about the party's commitment to protecting the environment. Polls indicate that the environment is the voters' number-one concern about continued Republican leadership of Congress.

title: The Long Reach of War, Tearing Up a Family
description: A troubled Vietnam veteran seething with rage against his upright Texan family and his inevitable explosion during a Thanksgiving celebration: the situation sounds familiar to the point of triteness. But ''The War at Home,'' James Duff's adaptation of his play ''Home Front,'' which ran briefly on Broadway in 1985, still finds moments of wrenching sadness in its microscopic examination of an all-American family torn apart by the Vietnam War.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Loses 11.55 Points, As Investors Take Profits

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Boys

title: H.M.O. Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Gucci Reports 69% Rise In 3d-Quarter Revenue
description: The luxury goods maker Gucci Group said yesterday that its revenues jumped 69 percent in the third quarter, helped by strong sales of leather goods and shoes. Still, Gucci stock dropped $3.50, to $74, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters)

title: Giuliani Can't Seek $220 Million of Airport 'Back Rent,' F.A.A. Says
description: Federal officials have dealt Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani a major setback in his effort to recover $500 million that he contends the Port Authority owes the city in back rent for Kennedy International and La Guardia airports.

title: Santa, Take That! Need That Toy.
description: ''Jingle All the Way'' is about Howard Langston, a workaholic mattress salesman who has been too busy to notice his cute little son, Jamie. Or that all Jamie wants for Christmas is a plastic superhero named Turbo Man, available at toy stores everywhere. There's only one catch: it's Christmas Eve and all the Turbo Men are gone. So Howard has to race through toy stores, chase all over town and even slug Santa to make his son's holiday wish come true.

title: A Christmas Fair
description: ''A Swedish Christmas,'' St. Luke's School's annual Christmas fair, will be held this weekend at 487 Hudson Street, at Christopher Street, in the West Village. The fair will feature Scandinavian-inspired crafts, a silent auction, a children's carnival, a karaoke room, a smorgasbord (tonight) and a raffle (a trip for two to Sweden, a shopping spree at Ikea and dinner at Aquavit in Manhattan). Admission is $3 for adults and $1 for children. Hours are tonight, 5 to 10, and tomorrow, noon to 5 P.M. Information: (212) 924-5960.

title: A Fusion Inspired By Cocteau
description: A dance-opera spectacle is what the composer Philip Glass and the choreographer Susan Marshall call their collaborative venture, ''Les Enfants Terribles: Children of the Game.''

title: They're Dining on Quail And Whining About Life
description: If the rich are indeed different from you and me, maybe it's because they just don't have a clue. That's certainly the impression left by ''Far Harbor,'' John Huddles's earnestly pretentious portrait of eight extremely well-heeled yuppies in a Long Island shoreline mansion dining on quail in tangerine sauce and playing truth games.

title: Falling in Love With Movies and Communism
description: INSIDE OUT

title: Clinics to Pay $187 Million In Billing Case
description: The Laboratory Corporation of America has agreed to pay $187 million in civil and criminal penalties to settle Federal charges that it billed Medicare and other programs for unnecessary blood tests, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Petrobras Finds Big Deep-Water Oilfield
description: Petrobras , the state-owned Brazilian oil company, said yesterday that an oilfield in very deep water contained reserves of about 1.3 billion barrels of oil, more than double previous estimates, making it one of the largest discoveries in recent years.

title: HUD Makes Housing Grants
description: Single-family housing has sprouted throughout Mercer County in recent years, but many elderly residents seeking affordable apartments have been overlooked. Yesterday, the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development awarded $6.6 million to the Presbyterian Homes of New Jersey Fund to build 85 one-bedroom apartments -- the first low-income housing for the elderly in West Windsor Township, said Steve LaPrevost, the agency's building director. Other programs in Union Township, South Brunswick and Readington Township received a total of $18.2 million from HUD.

title: Alger Hiss Disgraced His Country, Twice
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Tribe, Shedding Ashes of an 'Evil Place,' Gets a Chance at Rebirth
description: All that stands on the windswept bluff where Gregory Rich's house used to be is a tall wooden cross, put there by the Innu Indians to recall the fire nearly five years ago that killed six of their children, and seared the image of this remote community on the conscience of Canada.

title: African Publications
description: To the Editor:

title: When Artistry Equaled Ambition
description: THE great Glaswegian architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh didn't merely design furniture and buildings; he made superb, functional works of art. The sense of his artistry -- evident in the fine lines of his drawings, the pungent details of his facades and signature high-backed chairs, the satisfying wholeness of his buildings inside and out -- has a life force of its own, and it can carry you easily through the beautiful, illuminating survey of his achievement at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Prodigy With as Many Scars as Gifts
description: As ''Shine'' begins, the adult David Helfgott (Geoffrey Rush) appears pitiably, trying to come in out of the rain. Clearly damaged somehow, David fidgets and chatters nervously, keeping his eyes half-shut, clutching too eagerly at the people he sees. He repeats words frenetically and chuckles oddly at words that really aren't funny. ''Ridiculous tragedy'' is one of the phrases he mutters.

title: Bond Prices Slip, Despite Weak Data
description: Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday after meandering for most of the session.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: From Cell, to Cells, to Life, All Caught by Photography
description: In 1965, the Swedish photographer Lennart Nilsson won acclaim for a Life magazine picture essay on the development of a fetus into a baby. His 1983 television documentary, ''Miracle of Life,'' which displayed in even more remarkable detail the earliest incarnations of what would turn out to be a human being, proved an all-time PBS hit. Now, using the same skills and some new techniques, he brings to ''Nova'' the yet more ambitious ''Odyssey of Life.''

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in Manhattan that close soon:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 13 about Canada's offer to lead an international force to help Rwandan refugees included an erroneous given name supplied by the Pentagon for an American officer heading a team sent to Africa to assess the situation. He is Maj. Gen. Edwin P. Smith, not Edward.

title: Art in Review
description: Jean-Pierre Pincemin

title: Teen-Ager Surrenders In Infant Death
description: Amid a frenzy of television cameras, microphones, reporters and the just plain curious, the New Jersey teen-ager accused with his girlfriend of murdering their newborn child walked into a downtown office building with his mother and father this morning and gave himself up.

title: Housing Secretary Resigns, Citing Finances
description: Henry G. Cisneros, the most visible Hispanic official in the Clinton Administration, resigned as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development today, citing financial reasons.

title: OLSTEN SHARES FALL ON REPORT OF STRONG COMPETITION
description: The shares of the Olsten Corporation fell 27 percent yesterday after the company said its fourth-quarter profit would be hurt by competition for its staffing and health care businesses. Olsten derives almost half its revenue by providing home nursing care and helping manage hospitals. As more people move to managed care, Olsten is treating fewer patients and making less for each one. It is also being hurt by changes in the staffing business. Big clients are forcing companies like Olsten, which is based in Melville, L.I., to compete for national contracts, reducing the amount they get for each employee they place. Olsten stock fell $5.375 a share, to $14.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 20 Are Killed By Explosion In Downtown Of San Juan
description: A five-story building exploded this morning in the heart of the downtown Rio Piedras shopping district, killing at least 20 people, most of them women. The police reported that 80 people were injured, some seriously, and had been taken to area hospitals.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about Raymond Chretien, the principal United Nations negotiator in Central Africa, included an outdated reference to one requirement for Rhodes scholarships. In the 1960's, when Mr. Chretien turned down the prize, Rhodes scholars were required to be unmarried, but the restriction was dropped in 1995.

title: For Both Car Makers and Consumers, a New Sales Factor
description: ''I want to be loved by you, just you,'' Marilyn Monroe croons seductively, as a mini-van smashes into a wall. Another accident caused by a driver daydreaming?

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Independence Day

title: Art in Review
description: Darrel Ellis

title: Art in Review
description: Rochelle Feinstein

title: Celebrating Lionel Hampton, Straight Up
description: Though Monday night's benefit for Jazz at Lincoln Center, which doubled as the first Lincoln Center Awards ceremony, had its share of fine music, its importance went beyond the program. A decade ago, filling Avery Fisher Hall with an upper-middle-class audience of businessman and celebrities paying up to $100 to support a jazz program at Lincoln Center would have seemed like an impossibility. But clearly things have changed; the full house, there to celebrate Lionel Hampton, liked its sentimentality straight up, but the audience also knew when to clap.

title: Love as Blood Sport, With Everyone Losing
description: WHEN Roger Rees storms a citadel of virtue, he comes well armed. Playing the ironically named Hero, an alcoholic French aristocrat, in the Roundabout Theater Company's mostly uninspired revival of Jean Anouilh's ''Rehearsal,'' he sets out to disenchant a purity-girded young woman with a stunning arsenal of actorly weapons.

title: 24 Injured as Fire Guts a Building in Harlem
description: A four-alarm fire gutted a two-story commercial building on 125th Street near the Apollo Theater yesterday morning, sending 18 firefighters and 6 civilians to hospitals. No one was seriously hurt.

title: U.S. Panel Approves Use of Artificial Skin
description: A United States Food and Drug Administration panel has recommended that Advanced Tissue Sciences Inc.'s artificial skin product be approved for treating severe burns.

title: N.I.T. Matchups Are Set
description: Indiana and Saint Louis will play each other tonight in a second-round game of the Chase Preseason National Invitation Tournament for the right to go to Madison Square Garden next Wednesday. So will Iona and Evansville.

title: Post-Soviet Russia Returns Successfully to Eurobonds
description: Post-Soviet Russia went to the Eurobond market for the first time yesterday to the applause of investors, who snapped up $1 billion in bonds, twice what had been expected.

title: Evelyn Hooker, 89, Is Dead; Recast the View of Gay Men
description: Dr. Evelyn Hooker, a psychologist who defied conventional wisdom and greatly emboldened the fledgling gay rights movement in the 1950's by finding there was no measurable psychological difference between homosexual and heterosexual men, died on Monday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 89.

title: House G.O.P. Softens Stance on Ethics Panel
description: The House Republican leadership retreated but did not surrender today on its idea of replacing members of the House ethics committee, which is considering charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Lowe Direct settles a dispute with five former top executives who left to open a breakaway agency.
description: AN out-of-court settlement was reached yesterday in a contentious legal dispute between Lowe Direct, the direct-marketing division of Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, and five former top executives of Lowe Direct who left unexpectedly last month to open their own breakaway shop.

title: Seize the Day
description: There is a new assertiveness in America's foreign policy, a greater willingness to lead in the post-cold-war world. The change traces back to President Clinton's decisions last year on Bosnia. Now it faces a defining test in Bosnia.

title: Restaurants
description: Dozens of new restaurants have opened this fall.

title: Bellcore Agrees to Purchase By Big Research Company
description: Trading seven masters for one, Bellcore said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Science Applications International Corporation, the nation's largest privately held research and engineering company.

title: Yankee Gear Seen Around The World
description: THIS was the evening after the Yankees had won the World Series. While the Yankees were still washing the Champagne out of their hair, a man and his daughter were flying back toward Geneva.

title: Forever Dada: Much Ado Championing the Absurd
description: NOT so long ago a friend who knows a lot about art mistook a pile of bricks on the terrace of the Marlborough Gallery in Manhattan for a sculpture. It was an honest mistake: who in a room full of modern art hasn't at one time or another hesitated in front of the thermostat or the fire extinguisher and wondered whether they were works on view? If you want to know when and how this peculiar situation came to pass, the answer is in ''Making Mischief: Dada Invades New York,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: 29 Arrested in Tax Fraud Scheme Described as New York's Largest
description: In what was described as the largest tax fraud case in the history of New York City government, Federal prosecutors announced the arrests of 29 people yesterday. Three of the 29 were present or past city employees, including the former head tax collector in Brooklyn.

title: From Suspect in Murders To a New Life in America
description: In the last days of spring in 1985, Pedro Antonio Andrade was a leftist guerrilla commander so committed to overthrowing the United States-backed Government of El Salvador, officials say, that he helped plan the most violent attack on Americans of El Salvador's civil war: the shooting of four off-duty marines and nine other people as they dined at sidewalk restaurants in the Zona Rosa section of San Salvador.

title: Scientists Zero In on a Gene Linked to Prostate Cancer
description: Scientists have approached within harpoon range of a gene linked to prostate cancer, the commonest tumor in men and their second greatest cause of death by cancer.

title: 8 Arrested in Southwest in Crackdown on Trade in Eagle Parts
description: In the largest crackdown in recent years on the black market in eagle parts, agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service carried out raids today in Arizona, Colorado and New Mexico, arresting eight men and issuing citations to eight tourist shop owners.

title: Art in Review
description: Henri Matisse

title: How Capote Blurred Border Between Fact and Fiction
description: Published in 1965, Truman Capote's ''In Cold Blood'' recounted the 1959 murders of a family in Holcomb, Kan., and in the process changed the nature of crime reporting forever. Whether for better or worse is still a matter of contention among journalists and historians. Focusing closely on the killers, Capote was thought by many to lose sight of the victims. A 1967 film directed by Richard Brooks and starring Robert Blake and Scott Wilson as the murderers offered a semidocumentary version of the story, blurring further the line between fiction and reality. Now, on Sunday and Tuesday, CBS offers yet another version of ''In Cold Blood.''

title: Tulane Coach Fired
description: BUDDY TEEVENS, who upgraded his players' graduation rate but could not upgrade Tulane's record, was fired as coach yesterday. Teevens, who has a 2-8 record this season and is 11-44 at Tulane, had one year left on his contract. (AP)

title: 3 Released After Bail Is Reduced To $1,000
description: Three people who were still in jail more than a week after the police found a cache of weapons in the Brooklyn headquarters of a group described as a leftist cult were released yesterday on sharply reduced bail.

title: Police Sued in Wife's Abuse
description: The former wife of a former Atlantic City police officer sued the department Wednesday, accusing officials of ignoring her pleas for help after her husband repeatedly abused her and even shot at her in October 1990. The former officer, Lawrence D'Alessandro, is serving a prison sentence after pleading guilty to assaulting the new husband of his ex-wife, Donna Hansell, last March. Ms. Hansell's lawsuit named her brother, Dennis Reilly, an Atlantic City police officer, as a defendant. Plaintiffs have won a total of $4 million against the Police Department this year.

title: Panel Details How Canada Failed Tribes
description: A commission that spent five years and $43.5 million studying the condition of Canada's Indians and Eskimos concluded today that Government policies for the last 150 years had been a shameful failure. If not fundamentally changed, the panel warned, these policies would condemn many of the more than 800,000 indigenous Canadians to worsened poverty, disease and anger.

title: Barnett Says No Thanks to Job at Notre Dame
description: Gary Barnett, who was apparently the leading candidate to replace Lou Holtz as Notre Dame's football coach, withdrew from consideration today, even before the interview process could begin.

title: Once Was Too Much: Graf Beats Davenport
description: For Steffi Graf, getting revenge isn't personal, it's protocol.

title: Mary Duschl, 45, Ballet Administrator, Dies
description: Mary Louise Stack Duschl, a former artistic administrator for the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, died on Wednesday at her home in Pittsburgh. She was 45.

title: Big Board Reports Sharp Gain in Profit
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its third-quarter profit soared 42 percent, to $17.6 million, as trading volume and the number of companies joining the Big Board both rose.

title: Venezuelan General Indicted in C.I.A. Scheme
description: A Federal grand jury in Miami has indicted a Venezuelan general who led a Central Intelligence Agency counter-narcotics program that put a ton of cocaine on the streets of the United States in 1990, Government officials said today.

title: Will New York Give Business a Break?
description: New Yorkers are divided on many issues, but we all seem to agree on the need to create more jobs in the city's five boroughs, where the unemployment rate is significantly higher than the national average.

title: Protect Nonbelievers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Thousands of players are in San Francisco today for the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, which began yesterday.

title: Bonilla's Compass Points To Miami
description: Whichever way Bobby Bonilla went, he was going to be reunited with an important figure from his winning days in Pittsburgh. Go south, and Jim Leyland would be his manager again. Go west, and Barry Bonds would be his teammate again.

title: On the Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Drops Bid for Power Over Schools
description: Removing a large stumbling block to changing how New York City's schools are governed, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani effectively withdrew his demand for sweeping control over the city's school system today. Instead, he threw his support behind a narrower plan intended to rid the sprawling system of corruption and inefficiency.

title: Returning in Triumph From TV to Broadway
description: Joel Grey has left the building, having recorded his number ''Mr. Cellophane,'' the lament of a milquetoast husband whom people ''look right through.'' Now it's Bebe Neuwirth's turn. ''I need to not have something right in front of my face when I sing,'' she tells the producer. Unfortunately, that includes microphones. With this setup she won't have a good day, she says good-naturedly, ''and then I'd start feeling like a big old jerk.'' The problem is worked out with a change in body angle, and the music, for ''I Can't Do It Alone,'' begins. Ms. Neuwirth's powerful voice fills Studio 1 at the Hit Factory. She nails every emotion -- effortlessly, it seems -- and virtually every note.

title: Why F.A.A. Ignored Contractor Hired by Valujet
description: The Federal Aviation Administration did not scrutinize a contractor that may have been largely at fault in the Valujet crash because the airline itself did not identify problems with the contractor, an agency official told investigators today.

title: As Electricity Rates Are About to Be Cut on L.I., All Sides Stake Out Positions
description: With a state panel about to complete a plan to lower electricity rates on Long Island, all sides in the decades-long debate appear to be staking out positions, floating trial balloons and maneuvering for advantage.

title: Penney in Accord To Sell Some Stores
description: J. C. Penney Inc. said today that it had reached a tentative agreement with Federal regulators to sell an unspecified number of stores to resolve antitrust concerns from its planned $3.3 billion acquisition of the Eckerd Corporation.

title: On Liver Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: P.G.& E. SELLS STAKE IN INTERGEN TO BECHTEL ENTERPRISES
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said yesterday that it was selling its stake in Intergen to its partner Bechtel Enterprises Inc., resulting in a gain of at least $70 million. P.G.& E., based in San Francisco, and Bechtel formed Intergen early last year to develop and operate electric power plants outside North America. Bechtel Enterprises, also based in San Francisco, is a subsidiary of the Bechtel Corporation. The sale, which requires approval from Intergen's customers, is expected to close by March 1. The gain, equal to 17 cents a share, will be recorded either this quarter or in the first quarter of 1997. The company would not disclose the purchase price. P.G.&E. is expected to report earnings of 63 cents a share this quarter, according to an IBES International Inc. poll of seven analysts.

title: Chinese Cut Out the Middleman in Cashmere
description: As they have for centuries, rural herdsmen in this arid land of northern China still comb the softest of soft hair off the underbelly of a mountain goat and sell the precious harvest to roving merchants by the ounce.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7

title: Mashburn to Have Surgery on Cheek
description: Dallas Mavericks forward JAMAL MASHBURN will undergo surgery today to repair a broken cheekbone, and will be sidelined two to four weeks. TONY FAY, the Maverick spokesman, said Mashburn would have to wear a protective mask for another four weeks after he returns.

title: How We Got Here
description: Harry Truman, who once was widely despised, is now just as widely beloved. This is easily explained. He was the last President of a gloriously romantic age we shall not see again.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: New Jersey Transit Chief Steps Down
description: Under attack for discussing job prospects with several companies seeking business from New Jersey, the state's Commissioner of Transportation resigned yesterday to take a job with a subsidiary of one of the companies.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: North New Jersey

title: POP
description: Going Home to the 60's

title: Time for a Broader Asian Agenda
description: During the cold war, Washington saw its role in Asia as clearly defined -- containing the spread of Soviet-backed Communism. The region today defies easy classification. While East Asia is the world's fastest-growing region economically, it is also an arena where four of the world's most powerful countries -- Japan, China, Russia and the United States -- are awkwardly working out new relationships with each other. The Clinton Administration has yet to devise a policy that adequately balances American economic and security interests in this vital region.

title: Princeton Library Is Closed
description: With the end of the semester looming, many Princeton University students were not pleased about having to take a study break while the main library on campus was closed. Firestone Library was shut down Wednesday after a maintenance worker found loose asbestos in an air duct, officials said. The library was to remain closed until 9 A.M. tomorrow, when 50 asbestos-removal workers were expected to have completed their labors, said Justin Harmon, a spokesman for the university.

title: Modernizing a Bank Law
description: The chief regulator of about one-third of the nation's banks announced this week that he would allow the banks under his control, on a case-by-case basis, to more easily enter securities and insurance markets. Eugene Ludwig, Comptroller of the Currency, has thereby outflanked an antiquated law passed during the financial turmoil of the Depression that serves no modern purpose.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Thursday with a television review of ''Smoke Alarm: The Unfiltered Truth About Cigarettes'' on HBO omitted the show's producer. He is John Hoffman.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Dutch Bank In $1.9 Billion Deal for S.&L.
description: The ABN-AMRO Bank of the Netherlands agreed yesterday to buy the Standard Federal Bancorporation of Michigan for $1.9 billion in cash, the highest price ever paid for a savings and loan institution.

title: Executive Changes
description: DONNA KARAN INTERNATIONAL INC., New York, named Dewey K. Shay, a Morgan Stanley & Co. executive, as senior executive vice president and chief administrative officer.

title: Fearing a Rate Rise, Shippers Await 2d Front In Rail Merger
description: Susann D. Felton was in the midst of negotiating railroad contracts last month to handle six million tons of coal a year for the Potomac Electric Power Company when the CSX Corporation disclosed an agreement to buy Conrail.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD EXPANDS BUYBACK BY UP TO $1 BILLION
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to $1 billion in common stock on the open market. The company did not set a date by which the repurchases were expected to be completed. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said about $230 million remained under earlier buyback authorizations, bringing the new total to about $1.23 billion. Since the beginning of 1994, the maker of computers, printers and related products has repurchased a total of 61.5 million shares. A spokesman said the company had 1.01 billion shares outstanding as of Oct. 31. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, Hewlett-Packard stock closed at $54 a share, up $1.125.

title: Trade Talk Is Swirling About Bradley
description: He has been underwhelming and overpaid. Yet Shawn Bradley continues to draw interest from teams curious about his potential, and the Nets appear ready to listen.

title: Not All Neighborhoods
description: To the Editor:

title: Checketts Says Campbell and Smith Are Safe
description: Like Elvis Presley and alien spacecraft, Dave Checketts is sometimes seen where he really isn't. The president of Madison Square Garden, on the telephone from the New York area today, scoffed at reports that he has been traveling with the reeling Rangers on their Western Canadian road trip.

title: Exchanges Discuss Revisions Of Rules on Market Plunges
description: Representatives of the nation's stock exchanges are discussing a possible relaxation of the so-called circuit breakers that halt stock trading if share prices plunge, a regional stock exchange official said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rally Broadly; Dow and Nasdaq at Records

title: Italy Moves to Rejoin Europe's Currency System
description: A week after the Italian Parliament enacted a 1997 budget intended to assure Italy a place in Europe's single currency, the Government took the next step today, requesting a meeting of European officials on Saturday to consider the re-entry of the lira into the European exchange rate mechanism.

title: Police Union Posts Reward for Bissell's Arrest
description: For police officers in one town in Somerset County, now is a fine time to avenge an old grievance against Nicholas L. Bissell, the former County Prosecutor who has been a fugitive from justice since Monday.

title: Landlord Admits Illegal Fund Raising
description: A landlord pleaded guilty to illegally soliciting political contributions from tenants that were used for Republican races, including Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaigns. The tenants were asked to make the contributions in exchange for leases on rent-controlled apartments. It is illegal for New York City landlords to solicit payments for such apartments above the legal rent ceiling.

title: Pascrell to Join Transit Panel
description: U.S. Representative-elect William J. Pascrell of Paterson received a plum assignment Thursday night, when House Democratic leaders appointed him to the Transportation Committee. Mr. Pascrell, a Democrat who unseated William J. Martini, a Republican freshman, said he had sought the assignment.

title: JAZZ
description: Targets of Opportunity

title: Coach Dreams of Closing In on Bulls
description: Jeff Van Gundy called it clarification day. He talked about who will handle the ball at the end of a game, what is expected of each player and, most important, why the Knicks look nothing like the Bulls in November.

title: In Australia, Clinton Takes a Dip by the Great Barrier Reef
description: With Secret Service counter-assault teams poised to stave off stray sharks, President Clinton plunged into the sparkling blue-green waters of the Great Barrier Reef today, snorkeling his way past legions of iridescent fish, marveling at a giant clam and emerging unscathed.

title: How a Killing Roused Irish Conscience
description: Shots from a .45-caliber handgun were fired at her through the window of her cottage as she put her 5-year-old son to bed. The country's most notorious criminal beat her up and threatened to sodomize her child and kill her entire family. An intruder in a crash helmet forced his way into her home, held a gun to her temple for agonizing seconds, then lowered it to her thigh and pulled the trigger.

title: DSP ENDS PLAN TO MERGE WITH PROXIM
description: The stock of DSP Communications Inc. jumped yesterday after the company said it had ended plans to buy Proxim Inc. DSP and Proxim agreed to call an end to the proposal because of the 27 percent price drop in DSP stock since the transaction was announced on Oct. 29. DSP, which makes chip sets for wireless products, had planned to buy Proxim, a wireless-equipment maker, for $400 million in stock. The companies now say they ''should pursue a working partnership outside the context of a merger.'' They cited ''joint product and marketing initiatives'' and the development of wireless voice and data products. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, stock of DSP rose $2.75 a share, to $40.75, in trading of more than three million shares.

title: News Corp. Sells Stake in Fairfax
