description: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's global media company, confirmed yesterday that it had sold its stake in the Australian publisher John Fairfax Holdings Ltd. The Sydney Morning Herald reported yesterday that Mr. Murdoch had sold his 4 percent stake.

title: When One Man's Helicopter Is Another Man's Headache
description: As anyone who lives in Westchester and works in Manhattan knows: if the Hutchinson River Parkway is backed up, head for the Saw Mill; if the Major Deegan is a mess, pay the toll on the Henry Hudson Bridge; if the radio says ''gridlock alert,'' check the train schedule.

title: STATE TELLS CREW TO SEIZE CONTROL Of 42 BAD SCHOOLS
description: The State Education Commissioner ordered the New York City Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, yesterday to take direct control of 42 failing city schools and improve them. If they do not get better, the Commissioner said, the state could force them to close.

title: Nippon Telegraph Says Profits Surged
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the Japanese telecommunications giant, reported yesterday that profits jumped 63.9 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30. Its share price on the Tokyo Stock Exchange surged 41,000 yen ($369), to 820,000 yen ($7,387).

title: CERNER STOCK JUMPS AS COMPANY REJECTS BUYOUT OFFERS
description: The stock of the Cerner Corporation gained 24 percent yesterday on news that the company had received and rejected unsolicited buyout overtures in recent months. The company, a developer of health care data bases and other clinical information services, did not identify the entities that had ''expressed interest in acquiring or combining with Cerner.'' The company disclosed on Thursday that it had communicated to those potential suitors that management was ''strongly committed'' to pursuing its own strategy. Cerner also said directors had approved a poison pill anti-takeover defense plan. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Cerner's stock was up $2.75 at $14 a share.

title: From Welfare to Work, Without a Car
description: During the Great Depression, Ira Gershwin wrote ''Nice work, if you can get it.'' In today's sprawling metropolitan areas, you're more likely to hear ''Nice work, if you can get to it.''

title: TECO TO BUY LYKES ENERGY FOR $300 MILLION
description: Teco Energy Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Lykes Energy Inc. for $300 million in stock as part of a continuing asset sales effort by the closely held Lykes Brothers Inc. Teco, parent of the Tampa Electric Company, said it would give Lykes Energy about 12.1 million Teco shares. The specific number depends on the average market price of Teco's shares for a specified period before completing the sale in mid-1997, Teco said. Lykes Energy includes Peoples Gas System Inc., a gas distributor in Florida. It will remain a separate unit of Teco after the sale. Lykes recently sold its meat processing division to Smithfield Foods Inc. for $37.2 million.

title: Overcoming Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Mayor Drops School Demand
description: Mayor Giuliani effectively withdrew his demand for broad control over the school system and would give the Chancellor more power. Page 21.

title: Cablevision Criticizes Phone Wiring
description: With competition in Connecticut for cable and phone service heating up, one of the state's largest cable companies charged today that Southern New England Telephone's new telecommunications lines are endangering utility workers and the public.

title: From Hero To Heroin And Back
description: Before the high school basketball players in ''Hoop Dreams'' were even born, before the N.B.A. was the big-money publicity machine it has become, there were boys from poor urban families whose talent was squandered, misused or cheaply sold before they made it to the pros. One of the most compelling of these real-life stories is that of Earl Manigault, a playground legend of the 60's, whose ability might have rivaled that of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, his contemporary. Instead, he detoured into heroin addiction and prison. By the time of his personal redemption, it was much too late for his career.

title: In Belarus, Where Europe Meets Russia, a Worrying Deadlock Over Who Is Really in Charge
description: Alarmed about growing turmoil in neighboring Belarus, Russia has attempted to forge a compromise between the nation's autocratic President and his main opponents.

title: M.T.A. Metrocard Contract Under Review
description: The Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is investigating the authority's $296 million contract with the company that made the Metrocard system, amid charges by the company's competitors that they have not been given a fair chance to bid for some of that business.

title: Earnings for Sega Climb Nearly 16%
description: The Japanese game machine maker Sega Enterprises Ltd. said yesterday that its profit grew nearly 16 percent in the first half of its fiscal year, thanks to robust sales.

title: TV's New Jew
description: For weeks now Americans have been groping with a momentous question: Will Ellen, the popular ABC sitcom heroine, come out as a lesbian? At a time when cuddly gay characters are as ubiquitous on TV as doctors, it's hard to see what the fuss is about. Far more startling was an uncloseting that took place on ''The Larry Sanders Show'' Wednesday night (to be repeated on HBO early next week): Hank Kingsley came out as a Jew.

title: Helping Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Drops Charges Against Indians in Fire
description: Charges of abandonment against the Canadian Indian parents of five children who died in a fire have been dropped, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported this evening. The case brought national attention to the plight of Indians.

title: Victory of 5 Redistricted Blacks Recasts Gerrymandering Dispute
description: The re-election of five black members of Congress, in districts recently redrawn to eliminate black voting majorities, has sharpened the debate on a crucial legal and political question: Is it still necessary to gerrymander legislative districts along racial lines to insure minority representation?

title: INSIDE
description: Success at Subic Bay

title: Company Briefs
description: JAN BELL MARKETING INC., Sunrise, Fla., adopted an anti-takeover plan to avert an attempt by Ocean Reef Management Inc. of Aventura, Fla., to buy the jewelry distributor for $4 a share, or about $100 million.

title: Charges Dismissed in Silicon Valley Trade Secrets Case
description: A rare criminal indictment that grew out of a dispute over trade secrets between two computer software companies in Silicon Valley was quietly dropped this week.

title: Richard Koontz, 56, a Printing Executive
description: Richard H. Koontz, a longtime executive at Bowne & Company, one of the world's largest financial printers, died at his home in Ridgewood, N.J., on Wednesday. He was 56.

title: Reacting to the World and One Another, Humanly and Not
description: From the 1950's until his death in 1993, Alwin Nikolais created a dance-theater of visual marvels. Many were on view on Wednesday night when Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance presented an all-Nikolais program at the Joyce Theater.

title: Purdue Names Tiller as Coach
description: JOE TILLER, who has led Wyoming to a 10-1 record this season, yesterday was given the task of trying to reverse a 12-year cycle of losing at Purdue University.

title: 2 Weeks After Election, Dornan Loses Seat
description: After a vote count that dragged on for more than two weeks, Representative Robert K. Dornan, the most blusterous Republican conservative on Capitol Hill, finally went down to defeat today, narrowly vanquished in his bid for a 10th term by a liberal Democrat and political novice, Loretta Sanchez.

title: House G.O.P. Said to Seek Ouster of 6 In Ethics Unit
description: Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, called today for the replacement of the six ethics committee members who would serve as a jury if an investigating subcommittee recommended charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich, Democratic officials said tonight.

title: Autopsy Shows Baby Found In Bin Was Born Healthy
description: The baby found dead in a Dumpster outside a Delaware motel was born healthy, according to autopsy results released yesterday.

title: Jones Jr. Wins W.B.C. Title
description: A wild controversy was averted tonight when two sets of judges -- one from the World Boxing Council and another from the Florida State Athletic Commission -- both unanimously voted Roy Jones Jr. the World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion.

title: Sloan Simpson, 80, an Ex-Model Who Married a New York Mayor
description: Sloan Simpson, the beautiful young fashion model who married New York's handsome postwar Mayor, William O'Dwyer, divorced him after his term as Ambassador to Mexico and then became a darling of the jet set as the ruler of Acapulco society, died yesterday at her home in Dallas. She was 80.

title: Who Needs This Committee on Religious Freedom Abroad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Banks Report Profit After Red Ink
description: Japan's 10 largest banks, which have been saddled with bad debts at home and some of which have had problems with regulators abroad, reported first-half profits today, barely pulling themselves out of the red ink they disclosed for the last fiscal year.

title: Rutgers Forbids Ethnic Jokes
description: The Rutgers University Senate approved a sweeping anti-harassment policy for its employees yesterday that would prohibit ethnic jokes, insulting gestures and obscene voice mail messages. The vote came after the Academic Freedoms and Responsibilities Committee, a faculty group, failed to limit the sanctions so professors would not be punished for ''one dumb remark,'' said Kenneth Carlson, chairman of the committee.

title: Testifying at His Civil Trial, Simpson Says He Is Innocent
description: The accusations came in a sudden rapid-fire barrage at day's end: You had gloves, you had a hat, you had sweats, you had a knife. You confronted Nicole Brown Simpson, and you killed her. And you killed Ronald Goldman, didn't you?

title: Remember, Not All Big Stores Will Be Super
description: To the Editor:

title: Massacre of Refugees in Burundi Reported
description: United Nation officials said today that nearly 300 Hutu refugees returning to Burundi from Zaire late last month were massacred as they sought refuge in a village church.

title: A Triumph for City Schools
description: It is not every day that New Yorkers get to see their elected officials coming together on a contentious, highly politicized issue, and producing an important and useful agreement. But yesterday's series of announcements on reforming New York City's public school system was such a moment.

title: Cowboys' Secondary All Hands, Giants Say
description: The Giants players respect them but, basically, they think that the Cowboys defensive backs maybe cheat a little too much.

title: Some Changes In Stock Rules To Be Delayed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed yesterday to delay by a few months some parts of its new order-handling rules that are aimed at revamping the Nasdaq stock market. But it did not change any major parts of the rules.

title: Our Cures for the Drug Problem Make It Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Avalanche And Roy Sneak Past Islanders
description: A year ago, the Islanders would have been ecstatic to come out of a road game with a hard-fought, one-goal loss to the defending Stanley Cup champions.

title: Arrest in Baby's Drowning
description: A 38-year-old woman was charged yesterday with drowning her baby in a bathtub, Essex County prosecutors said. The woman, Wilma Holder, was arrested around 3 A.M. after police officers responding to a report of a death came to her apartment and found her newborn son lying in the tub, said Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office. Ms. Holder was taken to University Hospital in Newark for postnatal treatment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about ambulette service for disabled Medicaid patients misstated the frequency with which a woman who uses the M.T.A.'s bus service had been denied a seat, and a correction in this space on Tuesday also misstated it. The woman, Kathleen Egan, was denied a seat 8 of 61 times in September and October. She was not denied a seat ''often.''

title: Amid the Cheers forAPEC, Critics Assail 'Globalization'
description: QUEZON CITY, Philippines  Proud claims ofeconomic successes by the Philippines are expected Sundayas 18 leaders of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation open a conference in Manila.

title: Calls Pour In From Owners Of Property In Tax Case
description: One day after New York City officials warned property owners that they would be tracked down if they paid bribes to have their taxes reduced, investigators said yesterday that they had heard from several dozen property owners, their lawyers and their relatives.

title: Two-Headed Beast
description: To the Editor:

title: White Couple Are Guilty In Attack on a Black Boy
description: In the late afternoon of Jan. 5, a 10-year-old black boy limped home from his white neighbors' house and told his father that the white family had taken him to the woods, tied him to a tree, hit him with a crowbar, fired two shotgun blasts past his head and choked him with a belt. Then, the boy said, they threatened to kill his family if he told.

title: Why a King Is Making A Rabbi a Don
description: MITCHELL SERELS'S three boys have been humming the theme from ''The Godfather'' around the house. Their father is about to be made a Don, so it's understandable that they're acting like little wiseguys. It isn't every day a rabbi is honored with such a title.

title: African Aid Effort Mired in Dispute Over Scope of Mission
description: The future of an international military effort to save starving refugees in Africa became mired in uncertainty today as Governments and aid agencies meeting here disagreed over the number of Rwandan refugees remaining in Zaire and the scope of any mission to help them.

title: Is Mexico's Press Free, or Just Taking Liberties?
description: ''Monica's Addiction Revealed!'' screamed the headline in an opposition newspaper here this month, reporting that the young Mayor of this border city, Monica Garcia Velazquez, was suffering from cocaine addiction and had been hospitalized for an overdose.

title: Army Broadens Its Inquiry Of Sex Abuse Accusations
description: The Secretary of the Army today ordered his top investigator to take over a widening inquiry into complaints of sexual abuse at Army training centers around the nation.

title: BRC SELLS ELECTION BUSINESS FOR $59.3 MILLION
description: BRC Holdings Inc., a data processing company, agreed yesterday to sell its election business to the privately held American Information Systems Inc. for $59.3 million. The business provides ballots and other election supplies and services. American Information Systems, based in Omaha, will pay $35 million in cash, provide a $17.5 million note and give BRC a 19.9 percent stake in the company. The election business generated about $35.2 million of revenue in the first nine months of the year, 30 percent of BRC's total revenue during that period. BRC, which is based in Dallas, said the sale allowed it to focus on providing data processing services to local governments and health care companies, as well as consulting business.

title: Zairian Crisis Part of Broad Web Of African Subversion and Revolt
description: From the moment that fighting broke out in eastern Zaire last month, resulting in a rout of the Zairian military and a crisis involving more than a million refugees, the question many asked was: Where could the potent rebel force that ignited this conflagration have suddenly sprung from?

title: French Scientologist Sentenced After Church Member's Suicide
description: The founder and former head of the Church of Scientology in Lyons was convicted of fraud and involuntary homicide today in the death of a church member who committed suicide after going heavily into debt to pay the sect for counseling sessions.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing

title: Fighting for Their Films
description: When residents learned that the Rialto, Westfield's only movie theater, would be replaced by Banana Republic and Baby Gap stores, many complained that the change would force them to chauffeur their children to the movies and would harm the character of their downtown. Hundreds of protest letters were sent to Gap Inc., which owns the two store chains, said Michele Picou, the manager of Westfield MainStreet, a preservation group.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: An Ensemble That Embraces

title: Music and Words, Passing in the Night
description: ''Elegy for Young Lovers'' at the Juilliard Opera Center represents music's graceful pursuit of a literate libretto. Music wins the chase, eats its prey, enjoys a few nice aftertastes but suffers a certain postprandial indigestion as well.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the arrest of a man accused of firing a shotgun into a Bronx firehouse included a police official's incorrect description of the ammunition in some editions. The shells used in the shooting are usually sold only to law-enforcement agencies; they are not meant for hunting wild animals.

title: Two Roads Lead Back To New York
description: WHEN Ray Haskins and Fran Fraschilla shake hands before the tip-off at Alumni Hall this afternoon, they will come together after a journey that has taken 13 years to complete.

title: No Headline
description: ''Never.''

title: Dominican Leader Draws Line on Plan to Help New York in Drug War
description: Reacting to an outcry in his own country, the new Dominican president and his top aides have suggested that there are serious limits to how closely they would cooperate with the New York City police in tracking down drug suspects.

title: P.C., but Not 'Most Talented'
description: As the editor in chief of the 1965 edition of The Halls of Ivy, the yearbook of Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey, I was shocked and dismayed to read that the editors of a high school yearbook in Cromwell, Conn., have chosen to discontinue the time-honored tradition of polling the class to select the top seniors.

title: Davie Close To Being Next Coach Of the Irish
description: As Lou Holtz worked to contain the emotions of his final game at Notre Dame Stadium as head coach of the Fighting Irish, university officials appeared prepared today to execute a seamless succession. All indications were that Bob Davie, the team's defensive coordinator, would be named head coach, perhaps as soon as Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday comparing spending by two public schools in New York City reversed their identities in some editions. As demonstrated by the related chart and the rest of the article, it is Public School 64, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, that spent more -- almost double the spending of P.S. 136 in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Viola Announces Retirement
description: FRANK VIOLA, the left-hander from Long Island who won 176 games, a World Series ring and the Cy Young Award in 14 years in the major leagues, announced his retirement at the age of 36.

title: Steinbeck, a World-Class Homebody
description: Elaine Steinbeck, John Steinbeck's widow, can spot her husband's name on the spine of a book in many languages, including Russian and Greek. Once she was in Yokohama and, at sea with Japanese , she asked a book-store owner if he had any books by her favorite author. He thought for a moment, then said, yes, he had ''The Angry Raisins.''

title: Water Rustlers Come Up Dry
description: The water thieves of South 19th Street were not going to get away with it this time, Newark utility officials vowed. Tenants in a house in the city's South Ward owed more than $11,000 in unpaid water bills, but every time the city shut off their water, it was somehow turned back on.

title: Abdus Salam Is Dead at 70; Physicist Shared Nobel Prize
description: Abdus Salam, a Pakistani physicist whose work helped reveal the underlying unity of two of the fundamental forces of nature, died on Thursday at his home in Oxford, England. He was 70 and had been suffering for years from a disabling neurological disorder.

title: Democratic Party to Return $450,000 More Linked to Huang
description: The Democratic Party announced this evening that it would return $450,000, its largest refund to date, from an Indonesian couple who were solicited by John Huang, the former top party finance official at the center of inquiries under way in Congress and in three Federal agencies.

title: Jets' Duffy Becomes a Force On a Mix-and-Match Line
description: Roger Duffy still manages to keep his head up. No small accomplishment for a center.

title: Landlord Guilty of Asking Tenants for Political Gifts
description: A real-estate executive who was once a major Republican fund-raiser pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he illegally solicited political contributions from tenants that were used for Republican races, including Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaigns.

title: Devils' Loss To Capitals Ends Streak For Brodeur
description: Martin Brodeur looked at the bright side after the Devils' 5-1 loss to Washington tonight at Continental Arena.

title: Worldwide Persecution
description: To the Editor:

title: Subic Bay, Minus U.S., Becomes Surprise Success
description: When President Clinton and 17 other world leaders gather here on Nov. 25 for an economic conference, they will stay in new luxury villas built on the site of ammunition bunkers at what was once one of America's main overseas military bases.

title: HORIZON CELLULAR TO SELL ASSETS TO DOBSON
description: The Horizon Cellular Group, a provider of cellular telephone service, agreed yesterday to sell certain cellular properties in Pennsylvania and Maryland to the Dobson Communications Corporation for $75 million. The properties being sold cover a population of 410,000, and the sale is expected to close early next year, according to Horizon, which is based in Malvern, Pa. Dobson is a telecommunications company based in Oklahoma City. Horizon said it had now sold or contracted to sell all of its cellular properties for $577 million.

title: U.S. AGENCY PLANS TO REDUCE DANGER POSED BY AIR BAGS
description: The Department of Transportation said today that it would try to require auto makers to install new, more advanced air bags within two years as part of a package of steps to reduce the danger the safety devices posed to children and small adults.

title: Hidden Motive
description: To the Editor:

title: Novotna Wins, With No Time For Feelings
description: Once again, there was a handshake instead of a kiss. Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and Jana Novotna may share 15 doubles titles, but there is no love lost between them, especially on the singles court.

title: A Religious Quilt That Is Largely Patchwork
description: One of the great themes in recent American religious history involves the passing of Protestantism as the dominant cultural force, and the transformation of the nation's religious landscape into something much more complex.

title: Sampras Makes Semifinals
description: Instead of playing against 15,001 opponents, Pete Sampras played against just one today. Predictably, he fared better. A 6-4, 6-4 victory over Yevgeny Kafelnikov earned Sampras a place in Saturday's semifinals at the ATP Tour world championship. Now, all Sampras needs to do is find a way to beat Goran Ivanisevic and then, probably, Boris Becker, the hometown favorite, who beat Sampras with the crowd's full backing Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Alger Hiss on Nov. 16 misstated the dates on certain State Department dispatches that Whittaker Chambers produced as evidence that Mr. Hiss had been a spy. The documents, which Mr. Chambers said Mr. Hiss had stolen, were all dated 1938, not 1937 and 1938.

title: Unabom Trial Won't Begin Till Late '97
description: A Federal district judge today set a trial date of next Nov. 12 for Theodore J. Kaczynski, the man suspected of mailing or planting 16 bombs that killed 3 people and wounded 23 in a cross-country campaign of anti-technology terror that lasted 17 years.

title: NU SKIN ASIA PACIFIC STOCK SOARS IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: Stock of Nu Skin Asia Pacific Inc., a distributor of personal care and nutritional products, jumped yesterday in its first day of trading. The company, based in Provo, Utah, sold 9.1 million shares for $23 each in its initial offering, raising $209.3 million. After trading as high as $30.875, Nu Skin's stock closed at $28.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. More than 6.8 million shares were traded.

title: In Britten's Complex 'Dream,' A Balance of Light and Dark
description: LIKE MANY ANOTHER ICONIC work of art, Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' has been subject to false assumptions and glib interpretations. Some productions treat it as a relentlessly light comedy, glossing over its disturbing elements: stolen infants, partner-swapping, thinly veiled pederasty. Other productions, plunged in darkness, completely miss the giddy brightness of the play, with its fairies who mischievously mix in the lives of mortals, its hapless rustics who aspire to be tragedians and its wondrous (and prescient) explorations of the unconscious. The right balance has eluded many fine directors.

title: Slowly, Hoboken's Riverfront Plans Near Reality
description: THE selection last month of a developer for a key building in Hoboken's attempt to revitalize its waterfront comes at a time when plans for developments on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River are receiving new impetus, but with construction to begin only when a major tenant is secured.

title: Holtz Wins His 100th And Says His Goodbyes
description: Surrounded by upraised gold helmets after his 100th, most one-sided and most emotional victory as head football coach at Notre Dame, Lou Holtz said goodbye today.

title: Teaching Army's Teachers Gets Tougher
description: The lesson of the day in Staff Sgt. Allison Smith's classroom here at the Army's Drill Sergeant School is succinctly scrawled on a pale-green blackboard: ''Authority.''

title: So, the Stars Are Gone: Big East Is Still Potent
description: It will be difficult for the Big East to match the star appeal it enjoyed last season when, for the first time in college basketball history, three players from the same conference were named to the Associated Press all-America first team.

title: Furor Over Plan for Dam in Montana
description: The Yellowstone River, which flows down a boulder-studded course out of the mountains of Yellowstone National Park and north into the Paradise Valley, has always been famous as one of the West's last major undammed rivers.

title: The Hard Sell
description: WHERE have all the sandwich boards gone?

title: Right Off the Runway and Into the Salon
description: FOR those seeking deep meaning in fashion, men's runway shows can prompt mighty deep queries: how are today's men envisioning themselves? Like ancient hunter-gathers, Renaissance scholars, Enlightenment dandies, 1970's swingers? What do distressed leather shirts, silk gazar tunics, thigh-high boots, western wear, paisley ascots or plastic shirts really mean about today's masculinity?

title: A Spot for Thai Tastes in White Plains
description: IT is easy to understand why Thai cuisine has obtained a permanent niche in the county. Borrowing a bit of this and that from already popular Chinese and Indian cuisines, Thai cooking adds its own distinctive touches in the haunting tastes of lemon grass and Kaffir lime leaf, the tang of lime juice, flavor-smoothing coconut milk, the use of chilies from mild to incendiary, to mention a few items from a long list that each dish from this cuisine requires.

title: Cold Cash
description: The onset of winter usually promises at least one cold. The following is a look at some over-the-counter remedies and the comparative costs. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: Native Festivals, Not the Pilgrims'
description: KOOWONKUMISH means welcome in the language of the Wampanoag, the tribe that greeted the Pilgrims in 1620. Matt Whitecloud, a teen-ager with Wampanoag roots, greets the audience at ''Harvest Ceremony: Beyond the Thanksgiving Myth'' at the National Museum of the American Indian this weekend.

title: Suddenly Seeing Spots
description: JUST for the record, the Dalmatian that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani walked into Radio City Music Hall on Monday was provided by the New York Fire Department.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 1, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 9 THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (Viking, $23.95.) The disappearance of a 3-year-old brings a family anguish and redemption. (+) 2 2 2 ''M'' IS FOR MALICE, by Sue Grafton. (Wood/Holt, $25.) Murder results when sons in line to inherit a family fortune seek their long-missing black sheep brother. 3 1 SILENT HONOR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $24.95.) The attack on Pearl Harbor has tragic consequences for Japanese-American families. 4 4 4 MY GAL SUNDAY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) An ex-President and his Congresswoman wife investigate four crimes in the capital. 5 5 4 THE LAWS OF OUR FATHERS, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.95.) The trial of a probation officer for his mother's murder recalls the turbulent 60's. 6 3 7 DESPERATION, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) Visitors to a mining town encounter terrifying forces. 7 6 13 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) A World War II veteran meets an old flame. 9 7 4 THE TAILOR OF PANAMA, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $25.) A research scientist's study of genetic components brings her frightening experiences and romance. 11 1 SAY YOU LOVE ME, by Johanna Lindsey. (Morrow, $22.) (+) 7 8 10 ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $24.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood. 8 5 4 AMERICAN TRAGEDY, by Lawrence Schiller and James Willwerth. (Random House, $27.50.) An inside look at the O. J. Simpson defense team. 9 1 DOWN IN THE GARDEN, by Anne Geddes. (Cedco, $49.95.) A collection of photographs of infants dressed up as flora and fauna, with brief comments. 10 7 9 HOW GOOD DO WE HAVE TO BE? by Harold S. Kushner. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) Ten tales. 12 10 7 LOVE, LUCY, by Lucille Ball with Betty Hannah Hoffman. (Putnam, $24.95.) A posthumous autobiography. 13 15 37 UNDAUNTED COURAGE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The story of how Thomas Jefferson sponsored Lewis and Clark's exploration. (+) 14 1 CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam, $19.95.) Events in the Clinton White House as reported by an F.B.I. agent formerly on duty there. (+) 16* 12 2 FOREVER, ERMA, by Erma Bombeck. (Andrews & McMeel, $22.95.) (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+)

title: Randi Feldman, Steven Newman
description: Dr. Randi Michele Feldman, a clinical child psychologist, was married last evening to Steven Elliot Newman, a sales executive. Rabbi Shalom Stern performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Shalom in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE HAND I FAN WITHBy Tina McElroy Ansa.Doubleday, $23.95.

title: Students Go on Strike For Right To Organize
description: Demanding that the University of California recognize their union, hundreds of graduate students who serve as instructors at the system's three largest campuses walked off the job this week, resulting in scores of canceled classes, improvised off-campus classrooms, and a pre-holiday lull around the state's usually bustling college greens.

title: Children's Rights vs. Dogs: It's No Contest
description: To the Editor:

title: No, Sir, You Are Absolutely Not a Crook
description: IT is no surprise that people in power prefer to hear honey-soaked evaluations of their performance and often surround themselves with people inclined to provide them.

title: Principal's Transfer Hits Nerve
description: Sparking a storm of protest from parents and an investigation by the Schools Chancellor, the principal of Bedford-Stuyvesant's only magnet school for the gifted and talented has been temporarily reassigned to the district office.

title: Referendum Heartens Peconic Advocates
description: THE five East End towns, seeking to proclaim themselves a rural and resort fiefdom that is overtaxed and ill served by suburban masters from the west, are on fire to secede from Suffolk County to form a new Peconic County.

title: Losers in Your Portfolio? A Housecleaning Deadline Is Near
description: ALTHOUGH the stock market has posted another huge gain so far this year, many portfolios still have losers -- Digital Equipment or Apple Computer, say, or maybe Bethlehem Steel.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: SUN DANCERBy David London.Simon & Schuster, $23.

title: Steffi Graf To Face The Future For Title
description: They aren't exactly the ghosts of women's tennis past and women's tennis future. But Steffi Graf and 16-year-old Martina Hingis will cross paths and generations today in the final of Chase Championships.

title: A Surprising Finding On School Spending
description: The superintendents who oversee New York City's elementary and middle schools have long complained that the city's sprawling high schools soaked up a disproportionate share of precious education dollars.

title: The Princess Brides
description: Cinderellas are likable icons. They never connive. They never plot. They don't even manipulate. They are graceful, innocent magnets drawing their princes inevitably into their field. Their job profile is simple: the shoe fits, and they wear it.

title: Inmates Learn to Cook For Jobs After Release
description: THOMAS MYERS will be spending Thanksgiving at the Norwood E. Jackson Correctional Facility here. Although his eight-month sentence for possession of stolen property is nearing an end, he will still be here Thursday, a day when a great many Americans are sitting around cheery dining-room tables, filling up on turkey and stuffing with family and friends.

title: The Voyage In: Virginia Woolf
description: The literary critic Queenie Leavis, who had been born into the British lower middle class and raised three children while writing and editing and teaching, thought Virginia Woolf a preposterous representative of real women's lives: ''There is no reason to suppose Mrs. Woolf would know which end of the cradle to stir.''

title: Grace Under Fire
description: Marian Anderson was a woman of such quality, compassion and modesty that her humanitarian efforts alone would warrant our adulation. But she was also blessed with a matchless voice - a voice with so much warmth, richness and mobility that Arturo Toscanini was moved to call it a voice ''heard once in a hundred years.''

title: For Just Plain Pilgrims, A Certain Splendor
description: TO THE PILGRIMS, ANY LARGE and important piece of furniture made for sitting was called a great chair. But today, one type is so distinctively American that the experts have dubbed it the Great Chair. Thronelike and brooding, the Great Chair has unusual squarish legs and a back carved with motifs not seen on other chairs made elsewhere at the time.

title: Nancy Saltsman, James Sheed
description: Nancy McKay Saltsman and Alexander James Sheed were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Sandra H. Stayner performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: State Secret Of the Day? Pick a Name
description: Webs of intrigue are spun with the thinnest of threads. Banal encounters become fierce lobbying campaigns. The words and deeds of the heirs apparent (real or pretend) and of their supporters and detractors are analyzed with the vigor once invested in the ranking of Soviet septuagenarians.

title: Who Could Not Have Known of the Holocaust?
description: To the Editor:

title: Montclair's Artists Make Their Presence Known
description: It's official: Montclair is teeming with artists. In what it touts as the first official artist census of a town, the Montclair Arts and Cultural Alliance has tallied the number of artists living in the town, which New York magazine has called ''the Upper West Side of the suburbs.''

title: Helene Finegold, John C. Gammon
description: Dr. Helene Finegold, an anesthesiologist in Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to John Conti Gammon, the director of provider relations at the University Health Network, a health maintenance organization in Pittsburgh. Judge Martin Wekselman of the Court of Common Pleas in Pittsburgh officiated at the Concordia Club.

title: A Small Park Proves That Size Isn't Everything
description: IF YOU THINK THERE CAN BE NO such thing as a lush void, go to the new Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park at the edge of Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. The heart of this 3.5-acre public park is a great rectangle of lawn, utterly empty, absolutely flat and tightly enclosed by a brick walkway, low granite walls and gently curved, backless teak benches. Somehow it manages to feel as rich and as sensual -- and as tranquil -- as a thousand acres in the country, and it is a minor miracle.

title: A Prescription From the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Slipsliding Between Animation and Reality
description: IN THE BEGINNING WAS THE cartoon -- Mickey Mouse, Snow White, Pinocchio, the Little Mermaid. And the Disney lords saw that it was good.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on page 22 of the Travel section today, with a Frugal Traveler column about China, includes an outdated address for the China National Tourist Office. It is now at 350 Fifth Avenue, Suite 6413, New York, N.Y. 10118.

title: Ms. Zajac, Mr. Kleinhandler
description: Laura Felice Zajac and David Mitchell Kleinhandler are to be married today in North Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Bennett F. Miller is to officiate at Congregation B'nai Tikvah.

title: Boston Beer: The Sad Fall Of an I.P.O. Open to All
description: THE lesson of this story: Be careful -- you may get what you ask for.

title: Mystery Shipwreck Lost in Old Lyme
description: A NOR'EASTER in November 1994 uncovered the remains of a mysterious wooden sailboat embedded in the sand and peat on Griswold Point in Old Lyme. But a Nor'easter last month washed away all remnants of the shipwreck -- before archeologists or historians were able to solve its mystery.

title: The Blues: Capturing a Few of the Greats in American Music
description: THE blues are as dependent on convention as almost any other kind of music, but built in is a requirement for spontaneity. Therefore, viewers should not blink at the improvisational look of ''Rhythm and Blues,'' a sprawling show at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport.

title: State Faces Loss of a Seat In Congress
description: CONNECTICUT is expected to lose one of its six Congressional seats when representation is reapportioned after the next census in 2000, and that prospect promises some bruising political battles to come.

title: Finding Out About Vaccines
description: IN August, a Tennesseean who had been fishing in the Amazon Basin returned home and died of yellow fever. His death was the first confirmed yellow fever death in the United States since the 1920's, according to Dr. Robert B. Craven, the head of the yellow fever-spotted fever section of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Fort Collins, Colo.

title: Scraping By
description: ROSA LEE

title: L.I. Vines
description: Holiday Quenchers

title: WHY NEGATIVE ADS ARE GOOD FOR DEMOCRACY
description: In ''Why Negative Ads Are Good for Democracy'' (Nov. 3), John Tierney's claim that studies ''have repeatedly shown that journalists are more liberal than the average American'' ignores the fact that almost all such studies have been conducted by conservative groups, with an obvious ax to grind. It also ignores other contrary statistics, like those indicating that most of the members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors favor Republicans and that newspaper publishers also tilt heavily toward the G.O.P.

title: Vote Underlines District Split
description: In the face of an emotional volley of criticism from parents, teachers and politicians, members of Community School Board 15 voted Wednesday to invite educators to apply for the job of district superintendent.

title: Knicks Find Themselves At Iverson's Mercy Again
description: The Knicks have seen Allen Iverson twice, and already they have seen enough.

title: A Prophet of Modernism: Gertrude Stein
description: What is the difference between a literary icon and an ordinary writer? The writer is sometimes read, the icon almost never; a symbol is independent of readers. The writer transfigured into symbol leaves behind such earthbound circumstances as reputation, controversy, acclaim, fame -- even the highest degree of fame. All these are swallowed up in the Representation of an Era. Consider those 60's luminaries (they are all male) who have come to personify -- indelibly and incontrovertibly -- one liberating image after another: the mystical vagabond, the Whitman-esque bard, the macho rebel, the generational clown, the soused ex-prodigy. Of their celebrated passions, only a handful of stray phrases and shock-worthy gestures survive. They have ascended -- or fallen -- into legend.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Various Positions

title: For Satellite Dishes, Too, It's Location, Location ...
description: TRADITIONALLY, the roofs of office buildings have been a headache. They are there mostly to keep the rain and snow out and the heat and air-conditioning in. Periodically they need expensive repairs.

title: The Hip Talk Show That's Realer Than Real
description: BACKSTAGE ON THE SET OF ''The Larry Sanders Show,'' the award-winning HBO sitcom that exposes the inner workings of a late-night talk show, Garry Shandling, the show's creator and star, was being a perfectly gracious host. Until he suddenly threw out his guest, a visiting journalist.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 10 about the book cover designer Chip Kidd misstated the given name of a translator of the New Testament. He was Richmond Lattimore, not Richard.

title: Maryellen Ryan, Mark G. Lamson
description: Maryellen Teresa Ryan, the daughter of Ellen and Michael E. Ryan of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Mark Grimm Lamson, a son of Anne and John Lamson of Statesville, N.C. The Rev. Parker Ogboe performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary in Lone Tree, Iowa.

title: The World Was His Cloister
description: In A MAPMAKER'S DREAM (Shambhala, $18), James Cowan pretends to have found and translated the journals of a Venetian cartographer -- a cloistered monk named Fra Mauro, based on a real 15th-century figure -- who has set out to create a map of the world without ever leaving his cell. Instead, travelers and informants come to him, and he attempts to give shape to their visions. Thus we hear about the Vatican emissary to the Mongols and about the Devil worshipers of Mosul (who believe that Jesus will reign eventually, but only after the Devil is through). We also learn of ''a mysterious race of men who hop about on one huge foot the size of an umbrella, whereupon they use this same foot to shade themselves during the full heat of midday,'' and of other people who determine their fate by ''the call of seven sacred birds.'' Fra Mauro admires the courage of the explorers, fretting sometimes that he isn't really living his life. But, after a time, he comes to believe that the world he hopes to capture resides in the human consciousness and can only be sought after there. Mr. Cowan's book is beautifully written, if slightly static. (The reader sometimes wishes Fra Mauro would simply get off his duff.) More a series of meditations than a narrative, it will have special appeal to lovers of arcane knowledge, a group to which the author obviously belongs. David Guy

title: A Case Of Mistaken Identity
description: The story in the Nov. 3d d section regarding development plans by the Village of Sands Point states that Norman Blankman is, among other things, a ''public relations man.'' That is incorrect. To the best of my knowledge, Norman Blankman is not now nor ever has been in the public relations business.

title: Poorer in Pocket, Theater Lives On
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Mixed-Income Village for Downtown Atlanta
description: SPURRED partly by last summer's Olympics spectacle and partly by a national push to revamp public housing, this city is razing two dilapidated, low-income projects that have long been a public embarrassment and replacing them with new housing.

title: A Great Country, But Hard to Get Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Works That Are Small But Big in Artistry
description: The Collector's Eye

title: Phobia Clinic, 1st in U.S., Offers Road to Recovery for 25 Years
description: IMAGINE what it would be like to experience crossing the street as if you were crossing an ocean -- terrified that you would be stranded halfway. Imagine stepping into an elevator and being unable to control the thought that the cable would snap, and it would plummet to the bottom. Imagine spending years trapped inside your house, too paralyzed by fear to walk out the front door.

title: Use of Road Salt Endures Despite Concerns
description: DESPITE global warming, snow still falls through the winter on much of the nation, ice still forms on highways and road department spreader trucks still pour salt on the problem.

title: Lions Eke Out Victory in Closing Minutes
description: Fifty-one years after Columbia last won eight games, the 1996 Lions matched that achievement yesterday with a come-from-behind 31-27 victory over Brown before a crowd of 5,175 at Wien Stadium.

title: Making Comparisons in a Grim Search
description: IT was my job to arrange for the cremation. I was grateful for the task. Making calls, gathering information, is enough like what I ordinarily do to offer a kind of normalcy; for three days we had been sitting at a hospital bed in what we had finally come to accept was a deathwatch.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 25 about trading in unlisted stocks overstated the fraction of foreign issues among the ''pink sheets,'' a forum for those stocks. About 6 percent of the pink sheet stocks, not a majority, are from foreign companies, according to the National Quotation Bureau, which compiles a listing of 13,000 such stocks. The article relied on information collected by the National Association of Securities Dealers from its members; its estimate is based on stocks that actually trade.

title: Cold Hands Still Awaiting Holiday Cheer
description: ON a gray afternoon like the dead of December, a thin, stooped man with sharp cheekbones was standing by the Route 495 off-ramp, wearing a worn flannel shirt and summer pants.

title: Unsolved Mystery
description: My Dark PlacesAn L.A. Crime Memoir.By James Ellroy.Illustrated. 355 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: The Dish On Dishes: Growth
description: IT took nearly eight years for the nation's retailers to sell the first one million color television sets, four years to sell the first million VCRs, and three years to sell the first million compact disk players. By contrast, according to statistics compiled by the Satellite Broadcasting & Communications Association, a trade association in Alexandria, Va., it took only one year, from mid-1994 to mid-1995, for retailers to sell the first million 18-inch digital satellite dishes, making the product one of the fastest-selling consumer electronic items in history.

title: St. Michael Deflates Anthony Title Hopes
description: ST. ANTHONY'S (9-2), of Huntington, L.I., bidding for an unprecedented fourth straight Catholic High School Football League AA title, was stopped short in yesterday's 21-7 championship loss to MOUNT ST. MICHAEL (9-2), of the Bronx, at Mazzella Field at Iona College. St. Anthony's, which had not been outgained all season, lost the yardage battle to Mount by 330-261.

title: Salvia's Relationship To the Menorah
description: Your gardening colum on salvia $(''Love It, Hate It, the Ubiquitous Salvia Persists,'' Oct. 6$) brought to mind a fascinating interpretation of the plant developed in Israel.

title: Exotic Habitats in St. Louis
description: New gardens for exotic birds and Chinese plants have opened in St. Louis.

title: Who Needs This Ad Most?
description: YOU know a commercial has plucked a nerve when the most startling thing about it is not the sight of wild chimpanzees aping famous lines from movies like ''The Godfather,'' ''Star Wars'' and ''Animal House.''

title: Grand Illusion
description: THE ESSENTIAL GOMBRICH

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: CITY OF DARKNESS, CITY OF LIGHT

title: Adults Re-Create Children at Play
description: THEY jump and skip, talking of fire drills, getting left back and playing monster. Then the bullies come, taunting and pelting them with anti-Semitic slurs and with fists.

title: Catherine Murphy, Juan L. Garcia
description: Catherine Margaret Murphy, an assistant district attorney in Kew Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Juan Luis Garcia, a senior vice president at the Dreyfus Corporation, the mutual-fund company in Manhattan. Msgr. Lawrence J. McAlister performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan.

title: Devils Get Short End of Capitals' Sticks
description: The Devils scored the first two goals tonight against Washington, a luxury for them. But for the second night in a row they lost to the Capitals, this time by 4-3 at USAir Arena.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Our Little Chickadee: Mae West
description: My stepsister Beth was Mae West on long Saturdays of chores at our childhood home -- a farm with many acres and lots of work to be done that none of us wanted to do. There were 10 of us from two different families, all under 16, sexually curious and hormonally imbalanced. All of us kids in the yard raking up leaves, on the driveway filling potholes, scraggly and tired and sweaty. My stepbrother Danny would do his John Wayne imitation, spurting out great one-liners to amuse us younger kids and to kill the time. Beth, normally shy and quietly beautiful in jeans and a ratty T-shirt, rake in hand, would wiggle across the yard, thrusting her hips this way and that, jutting her undeveloped breasts forward. ''Is that a banana in your pocket or are you just glad to see me?'' she'd ask in a raspy, slick but clear voice. And we'd all crack up.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE INSIDE OUTSIDE BOOK OF LIBRARIES. By Julie Cummins. Illustrated by Roxie Munro. Dutton. $15.99. (Ages 5 and up) Short blocks of text accompany lively illustrations of the outside and inside of libraries from Ocracoke Island, N.C., to the Library of Congress to Folsom State Prison to the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln, suggesting a wide range of places and ways to find information and inspiration.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 4 about plans to renovate a Philadelphia building as headquarters for a law firm misidentified the home city of the project's architects, Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates P.C. The architects have offices in New York City and London, not Chicago.

title: Walter E. Hoffman, 89, Dies; Judge in Agnew Proceeding
description: Judge Walter E. Hoffman, who took his turn at historic proceedings that disgraced Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and branded a fellow judge as a felon, died on Thursday at Sentara Leigh Memorial Hospital in Norfolk, Va. He was 89.

title: Umpire's Rage, Father's Fight
description: On the 52-inch television set in John Hirschbeck's living room, the moving images seem unreal, a parody of Norman Rockwell's America. Almost nose to nose, an umpire, a manager and a star baseball player are screaming as they jostle for position near home plate. Suddenly, the player spits at the umpire, a hurricane spray on this large screen.

title: Changes in Laws Spur Immigrants to Citizenship
description: DURING the pledge of allegiance to the flag, Gladys Imogene Reid, 89, placed her right hand firmly on her heart and -- though barely 5 feet tall -- stood triumphant among more than 200 immigrants who were naturalized here earlier this month. A native of Jamaica, the diminutive grandmother was the most senior in the standing-room-only crowd that day, part of a nationwide crush of people seeking citizenship in the United States.

title: A Tie-In Lies Low
description: IF you enjoyed watching Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sinbad fighting over Turbo Man in ''Jingle All the Way'' this weekend, try finding the gotta-have-it-now action figure yourself. While New York City is already littered with puppy-related deals in anticipation of next week's opening of Disney's ''101 Dalmatians'' remake, there's not a single Turbo Man to be found in Manhattan.

title: Princeton Eating
description: To the Editor: As a resident of Princeton, where parking is already a problem, I am reluctant to encourage tourism. However, I feel it is a disservice to leave the reader of Susan Spano's article, ''In Princeton, a Brief Ivy Interlude'' (Oct. 13), with the impression that there are only two places to eat.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a military training exercise at the Aberdeen Proving Grounds in Maryland misidentified four soldiers. They are officers, not trainees.

title: A Dream Engine Becomes Reality
description: TWO Japanese auto makers have succeeded in developing a new type of gasoline engine that can deliver substantial improvements in fuel economy without sacrificing power.

title: News for Next of Kin
description: Those with family and friends in an airplane crash abroad wait agonizing hours to learn the fate of their loved ones.

title: Celebration Becomes Time Of Mourning
description: It was supposed to be a grand day for Susan Ballenzweig. One hundred and fifty friends and relatives were to fill the West End Synagogue in Manhattan yesterday to celebrate her 50th birthday with the bat mitzvah she missed as a girl. Instead, it was a day of mourning.

title: Back to Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A report on the Playing in the Neighborhood page on Nov. 10 about a bird-watching tour of Prospect Park misidentified the tour guide. He was Paul Keim, president of the Brooklyn Bird Club. (John C. Muir is executive director of the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment, which sponsored the tour.)

title: A Maestro of the Magic Arts Returns to His Roots
description: DAVID SETH KOTKIN WAS BORN IN Metuchen, N.J., 40 years ago; David Copperfield was born when David Kotkin turned 18, at the suggestion of the wife of a New York Post reporter. Which is why his passport reads ''David Kotkin, a k a David Copperfield.''

title: Choices for Eating Out on Thanksgiving
description: THERE are communities where no one eats out on Thanksgiving Day. Long Island is not one of them.

title: A Rich Tapestry
description: A PASSAGE TO INDIA (1984) is a stunning movie, subtly culled by a master director (David Lean) from E.M. Forster's classic novel about British colonial India and a clash of East-West cultures triggered by an ugly, ambiguous incident. Well performed by a swarming cast and atmospherically photographed on location, the drama hinges on the enduring friendship of a noble Indian (Victor Banerjee) and a strong, free-thinking Briton (James Fox). Judy Davis, Alec Guinness (above) and a wondrous Peggy Ashcroft perform superbly in other key roles. But the real stars are a pictorially magnificent India itself, Forster's original blueprint and Lean's exquisitely evocative and wise imprint. Finally, a fitting swan song for a great director - WEDNESDAY at 11:30 P.M. on DISNEY.

title: Plan to Enliven Downtown Stamford Draws Dissent
description: FOR almost half of the 30-year urban renewal period that has transformed Stamford from small town to big city, a four-acre downtown parcel called Blocks 8 and 9 has remained a pocket of small stores, restaurants, parking lots and empty lots amid the office towers.

title: The Murder Case Immortalized by Capote
description: THE day the Clutters were found murdered, my father started locking the doors. It is a ritual he has repeated every night since Nov. 14, 1959, when two drifters walked into a Kansas farmhouse in search of a safe and, finding none, killed the farmer and his family. As a child, I would listen to my father trace the perimeter of our house, in the next county over, latching screens and sliding bolts. On those vast, lonely plains, the locking of doors was our lullaby.

title: Synagogue to Open In Pleasantville In an 1847 Church
description: A SYNAGOGUE will open here next month in a former church, marking the first time in this village's 301-year history that Jews will have their own house of worship.

title: For TriBeCa, 49 More Lofts
description: A 1905 Renaissance Revival structure that was built as a refrigeration plant in TriBeCa is to become 49 condominium lofts as part of a $15 million conversion. The 10-story building with addresses at 27 North Moore Street and 22 Ericsson Place -- once known as the John Ericsson Ice House -- is to be developed by Jack Lefkowitz and Joseph Pell Lombardi, who is also the project's architect.

title: Here Come the Brides to Grand St.
description: Not long ago, the intersection of Grand Street and the Bowery was a cluster of nondescript tenements and warehouses. Now it's Wedding Central, a sort of downtown answer to the Brooklyn emporium Kleinfeld's or Vera Wang on the Upper East Side.

title: Lost Without Qualms in Beijing
description: Correction Appended

title: Perot's Breather for Reform Party Is Giving Way to Discord
description: When Ross Perot conceded on Election Day, he urged supporters of his Reform Party Presidential bid to take a well-deserved rest and recharge their batteries for 1997. Now, just two weeks after President Clinton's re-election, Mr. Perot and others in the party are feuding over its direction and leadership.

title: At Rockefeller U., If There Are Pickets, It Must Be Friday
description: The first one, officials at Rockefeller University say, was three years ago, when members of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals dumped used cat litter on the campus, at 66th Street and York Avenue.

title: CONCERN IS VOICED OVER THE QUALITY OF ECONOMIC DATA
description: Almost every business day, the Government produces economic statistics that affect financial decisions, from buying a new house and expanding a business to monetary policy and the Federal budget.

title: Rachel Weiner, M.S. Singerman
description: Rachel Anne Weiner, a daughter of Barbara and Gerald Weiner of Highland Park, Ill., was married last evening in Chicago to Matthew Seth Singerman, the son of Geri and Martin Singerman of New York. Rabbi Dov Taylor performed the ceremony at the Hotel Inter-Continental Chicago.

title: Immortal Hair
description: While Jane Austen is celebrated for her writing, Amelia Earhart for her flying and Madame Curie for her research, Madame de Pompadour is famous for her hair. We shudder; we wince. What an ignoble fate for the style dominatrix of the court of Louis XV, to go down in history for her hairdo! And yet it is no small accomplishment for a woman to have immortal hair. First she has to be a prominent figure. Then she must find a style that so perfectly suits her, physically and psychically, that she and it become one and the same. Finally, her coiffure must also embody the spirit of the age. In an epoch of hair extravagance, when ladies wore miniature re-enactments of naval engagements in their tresses and doorways were heightened to accommodate these wonders, only Madame de Pompadour's wave transcended the era to achieve a place in the lexicon.

title: The Luxury-Decontrol Wars
description: JUST beyond the season of glad tidings, virtually with the drop of the New Year's ball, unwelcome letters from landlords will start popping up in mailboxes at fashionable, rent-regulated buildings, heralding what one landlord lawyer has dubbed ''the hunting season.''

title: Silky Crooners Who Can Rap, Rest Assured
description: ON THE WAY TO A SEDUCTION, some men brag and some men beg; they promise unfailing virility and, if absolutely necessary, undying love. And when they're making their offers in pop songs, they do so with a delicate combination of pride and self-effacement. They have to be skilled without threatening the virility of the Casanova who's playing the recording; the songs have to be memorable but discreet, supplying reassuring words and slow-dancing grooves while staying in the background. New albums by Blackstreet, Keith Sweat, Babyface and Tony Toni Tone are all created to fulfill a perennial pop function: to set a romantic mood. And they provide current answers to an age-old question: what do men think women want?

title: 3 Cemeteries Are Haunted By Vandals
description: As the sun lies down, the gates are locked shut on Bayside Cemetery because there are such things as ghouls.

title: Aerobic Training At Danbury High
description: I just finished reading the article (''Kicks and Burn, for Athletes,'' Nov. 3) describing the innovative use of aerobic training for members of the Darien High School football team.

title: Only the Wheeler-Dealers Seem to Win in This Game
description: EVER wonder who's foolish enough to play three-card monte with those street-corner hustlers? As most anyone with a lick of sense knows, the game is fixed. No one ever makes a dime, except for the guy who's holding the cards.

title: Rhyme It, Sing It, Dance It, Do It
description: DENISE HYND of Stamford said she could never find a book or cassette to hold the attention of her children -- 2-year-old Victoria and 4-year-old Nicholas -- for very long.

title: A Home Needed for Arts in the Three R's
description: AN-MING TRUXES is the founding executive director of the Connecticut Alliance for Arts Education, a determined grass roots group that promotes the arts in schools.

title: Homebody on the Range: Dale Evans
description: Once, I worked on a ranch in Wyoming, pretending to be a cowgirl. Our trail cook was a woman named Rose, who dressed in vintage Western clothing and sang Hank Williams songs. Rose kept a photograph of Roy Rogers and Dale Evans at hand always, believing in her heart that Roy and Dale were her true parents. Rose believed she had been separated from Dale Evans ''as a tiny little baby.''

title: Pumpkin Pie You Can Eat in a Cone
description: At my family's Thanksgiving dinner, dessert has become the responsibility of my husband and me. Jim makes the apple pies from scratch, and I make the pumpkin. (I cheat, using frozen shells and canned pumpkin.) The special little something we've added is seasonal ice cream.

title: Harry and Louise Were Right, Sort Of
description: REMEMBER the frightening things that were going to happen if the Clinton health care plan passed? Like losing the right to choose a doctor or a health plan? How about the slow death of old-fashioned medical insurance and the like-it-or-not march into health maintenance organizations? Not to mention restricted benefits and even rationing.

title: Children's Group Playing to Help Children
description: ON a Sunday morning, while most of their friends were still sleeping, three Long Island teen-agers assembled in a Glen Cove living room.

title: HAZING DAYS
description: A few years ago, in my 40's, I joined a sorority. It wasn't a voluntary act; I was forced to join. We like to say in my breast-cancer support group that the initiation is horrendous but it guarantees membership in a great sisterhood. Without doubt, I'd never have met and bonded with many of these women had it not been that we share horrors -- from the moment we hear the dread diagnosis through the ordeals of treatment and on to living with the physical and emotional scars.

title: Marijuana Farms Are Flourishing Indoors, Producing a More Potent Drug
description: From the outside, the house looked like any other in the inner-city neighborhood -- bars on the windows, a palm tree or two, a dog in the yard. But inside, past the kitchen, a sticky, pungent smell led to four rooms where 727 marijuana plants in various stages of maturity thrived.

title: The True Believer: Margaret Thatcher
description: Women, do you want to lead your country without going the widowhood route? Study the progress of Margaret Thatcher.

title: Paris or Bust, 90 Years Later
description: WHEN the first Peking to Paris Motor Challenge was run in 1907, a 7-liter Itala won handily, covering 10,000 miles in two months. The second-place finisher, a Dutch-built Spyker, pulled in a week later.

title: Northeast Corridor Line Shut Down
description: Yesterday's derailment shut down Amtrak's service to its Northeast Corridor, as well as to much of New Jersey Transit's operations.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A CITY IN WINTERBy Mark Helprin.Illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg.147 pp. New York:Ariel/Viking. $22.50. (All ages)

title: Women in Ancient Rome, Marble Portraits and Urns
description: FROM slave to empress, the roles of Roman women are illustrated in ''I Claudia: Women In Ancient Rome,'' an exhibition on view through next Sunday at the Yale University Art Gallery.

title: Horse Show's Remnants Removed
description: THE Hampton Classic is long over, the 1,400 horses exhibited during the weeklong festivities have moved to greener pastures but what the horses left behind was removed just last week.

title: West Enders Say Traffic Ignores Commercial Ban
description: Thirty years ago, Rhoda Bauch pulled up her Central Park West stakes and went in search of quiet on West End Avenue. Then, as now, the avenue was lined with elegant buildings with doormen, was all residential except for the business of therapy, and banned commercial traffic.

title: Loehmann's Camaraderie, And for Men, Cheap Thrills
description: To the Editor:

title: On Coping With Breast Cancer
description: As a Long Island woman who was recently diagnosed with breast cancer, I applauded the courage and emotional honesty of Bea Tusiani's opinion article, ''I Got Breast Cancer. Why Me?'' (Oct. 13) and was shocked at the harsh response from Geri Barish, president of 1 in 9: The Long Island Breast Cancer Action Coalition. (Letters to the Editor, Nov. 3).

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 3 about Hollywood stars at a benefit for the Cinema Arts Center of Huntington misidentified the actress with Roddy McDowell. She was Jane Powell, not June Allyson.

title: Putting the Pleasant in Pleasantville
description: AMERICAN DREAMERS

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: AS temperatures drop, the best of the week's movies offer concurrent chills and thrills and an antidote in the form of warm sentiment and romance.

title: Unification Church Gains Respect in Latin America
description: When missionaries from the Unification Church came to South America in the early 1970's, they faced hostility in many countries, where the teachings of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the church's spiritual leader, were considered sacrilege.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: But First, Dessert
description: THE plan is to dine at the Shubox Cafe and then see ''The First Wives Club.'' But we're having so much fun eating and talking that we skip dessert, and even then we miss the first five minutes of the movie. Missing a part of ''The First Wives Club'' isn't a problem -- none of us really likes it -- but missing dessert at the Shubox Cafe is cause for true sorrow.

title: Mah-Jongg Leads Church to Evict Senior Center
description: The click-clack of the mah-jongg tiles echoed in the senior center's basement, coming from a windowless, cluttered storage room where 20 elderly Chinese immigrants sat around five small tables.

title: The Human Face of a Budget Cut
description: I EXPECTED a mass exodus of the crossing guards,'' Gary Iacobacci said, shaking his head in amazement. ''I thought they'd pack it in. But it just didn't happen. Most of them are still out there.''

title: Supply and Demand
description: Do you sometimes see the company supply room as an extension of your supply cabinet at home? Does the copying machine at work come in handy in your role as secretary of the P.T.A.? Workers often take company property home, or use it for personal business. How does your employer handle the problem -- and how outrageous has it become? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Rail Europe Gears Up for 1997
description: Rail Europe has announced the 1997 prices and rules for its Europasses, the first-class train tickets for a limited number of countries on the Continent. There is one major price rise: the companion ticket for two people traveling together will cost 60 percent of the price of the first ticket rather than 50 percent.

title: Strong Franc, No Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: As Subway Doors Close Faster, Green Urges Additional Sensors
description: The city's Public Advocate, Mark Green, urged the Transit Authority yesterday to install safety sensors on all subway doors before enforcing a rule that would require conductors to close all doors within 45 seconds. Without sensors, closed circuit cameras and platform mirrors, passengers may be caught, dragged and injured by moving trains, he said.

title: Sex, Not Drugs, Is a Long-Watched Hotel's Downfall
description: For years, neighbors have described the Castle Hotel, at 36 West 106th Street, as a blight, a haven for drugs, prostitution and crime.

title: Very Guarded Residents Say Private Police Need Policing
description: The predominant law-enforcement authority of the New York Police Department spans every inch of the city with one exception -- the private community of Sea Gate.

title: Where 'Timber!' Is Never Heard and Trees Die of Old Age
description: IN this corner of Somerset County, there is a tract of forest where the towering oaks and hickories have been able to live out their days without threat of the monotonous chop of an ax or the screeching rip of a chain saw.

title: HAZING DAYS
description: A strong feeling of homoeroticism and sadomasochism permeates the pictures of hazing rituals at a select Eastern men's college, featured in your photo essay ''Hazing Days,'' by Anne Matthews and C. Taylor Crothers (Nov. 3). Unfortunately, once they graduate, some of these students will seek membership in the select fraternity of men who hold high public office. Will they then run vicious negative ads defending the traditional American family against a rising tide of homosexuality?

title: Convenience, but Off the Beaten Path
description: STUYVESANT SQUARE is often confused with Stuyvesant Town, the enormous middle-income development that looks down on it just to the east. The neighborhood itself -- several blocks surrounding the four-acre Stuyvesant Square Park bisected by Second Avenue -- is dominated by schools, hospitals and more hospitals.

title: Kenyan Visa
description: To the Editor: A year ago, I began planning a summer trip to Kenya to visit my brother and his family in Nairobi.

title: Drownings May Show Illegal Immigrants Are Taking More Risks
description: At least four men were swept to their deaths off a Gulf of Mexico sandbar this week, and an immigration research group sees a connection between this latest fatal incident involving would-be immigrants and increased Federal border enforcement.

title: Causing a Stir
description: From Amelia Simmons to Martha Stewart, the icons of the American kitchen reflect society's view of women. Indeed, the kitchen has always been a safe place to be competent. Lately it has even become a little sexy. It also offers the possibility of advancement.

title: Buckeyes Discover Every Rose Has a Thorn
description: Ohio State fans are going to start calling their annual game against Michigan the Angst Bowl. The Buckeyes were rolling along, undefeated heading into their regular-season finale, with a Rose Bowl bid locked up and a possible national championship in their future. Then along came Michigan, and it all fell apart for Ohio State.

title: Internet Growing, From the Intimate To the Cosmic
description: PEOPLE ask me to describe the Internet and the World Wide Web,'' Ed Rochelle of Dix Hills said. ''I ask them to imagine Jericho Turnpike, stretching the length of Long Island, with everything on it -- residences, wineries, stores, the Miracle Mile. Then imagine Jericho Turnpike wrapped around the Earth 10 or 20 times.''

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Deborah Skolnik, T.P. Enders
description: Deborah Jeanne Skolnik, a daughter of Rebecca and Edward Skolnik of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married today to Theodore Peter Enders, a son of Yvonne and John Enders of Erie, Pa. Justice Francis Nicolai of State Supreme Court in White Plains is to officiate at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Surprising L.I.U. Takes A Big Step Up
description: There were enough subplots in yesterday's meeting between St. John's and Long Island University to make it more interesting than the season-opening mismatch it appeared to be. Fran Fraschilla was making his debut as St. John's head basketball coach and Richie Parker was finally playing his first college game for L.I.U.

title: County Points Way To Cultural Sites
description: DO you know the way to the Westchester Conservatory of Music? (Hint: Follow Route 22 to White Plains. Turn at the green-and-white county sign at Soundview.) Going to the Emelin Theater? (Take Mamaroneck Avenue into Mamaroneck. Turn at the green-and-white county sign at Prospect.)

title: The Girls Next Door
description: At the age of 12, my friends and I were all tomboys. We were the ones who read ''Little Women'' and wanted to be Jo. (She cut off all her hair and left town, two inspired pieces of action.) We loved Brenda Starr, intrepid newspaperwoman, preferred Lois Lane to Superman and took Wonder Woman into our hearts. We checked out every single Nancy Drew mystery from the library and formed our own Nancy Drew Club. But when we became teen-agers, these fictional females suddenly seemed childish.

title: Sreemoee Mukherjee, Chetan Vaid
description: Sreemoee Mukherjee, a market-planning analyst at Wyeth Ayerst Laboratories, the pharmaceutical manufacturer in St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Chetan Vaid, a second-year resident in internal medicine at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. Dr. Anand Mohan performed the Hindu ceremony at the Parsippany (N.J.) Hilton.

title: Heads or Tails, a Star Investor Will Fill His Pockets
description: THERE are some people you just don't want to encounter on the opposite side of the table when you are making a deal. They are savvy business people who always seem to know when a market has bottomed out and when it has peaked. If they are buying, you sure hate to be selling.

title: Felicia D. Stoler, Alan S. Wellman
description: Felicia Dawn Stoler, a daughter of Francine and Jeffrey Stoler of Morganville, N.J., is to be married today to Alan Scott Wellman, a son of Pat and Bert Wellman of Oceanside, L.I. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, is to officiate at the Headquarters Plaza, a hotel in Morristown, N.J.

title: First the Cash, Now the Stamps
description: Just in time for the holiday mail, A.T.M. card holders in New Jersey can buy stamps for greeting cards from the same automated teller machines that dispense cash. The Princeton-based Summit Bank is the first in New Jersey to have joined the United States Postal Service and 60 banks in 30 other states in offering stamps at 181 of its A.T.M.'s.

title: New Commissioner Outlines Strategy for Mount Vernon
description: THIS summer change came to the Police Department here under a wave of anticipation and optimism. The city's police force was, in the view of some residents and officials, augmented by the mayoral appointment of a new commissioner, John S. Pritchard 3d.

title: Romania's New President Promises a New Broom
description: When Nicolae Ceausescu was toppled seven years ago, many Romanians expected a clean break with the past. They finally got it last Sunday when they elected as President Emil Constantinescu, 57, a former geology professor and member of the Christian Democratic Peasant Party. Mr. Constantinescu, who comes to the position with strong anti-Communist credentials, pledged that Romania would become truly democratic, that market principles would shape its economy and corruption would be tackled. He nominated as Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea, the young Mayor of Bucharest who swept ex-Communist bureaucrats out of city hall. Mr. Constantinescu cautioned Romanians to be patient, though. So much damage had been done by the previous Government's reluctance to embrace market reform, he said, that change would be painful. JANE PERLEZ

title: Dues Blues: Nonpaying Workers Irk Federal Unions
description: JOHN CRABTREE, an equipment specialist who works for the Coast Guard in Elizabeth City, N.C., says working conditions would have to be awful before he would even consider joining the aviation machinists union, which represents him. ''As a Federal employee, I don't see where the union could help me,'' he said.

title: Be Assured: Boredom Will Not Set In
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Kirwan-Taylor, Mr. Lorentzen
description: Helene Aspen Clarke Kirwan-Taylor, the daughter of Michele Royal of Palm Beach, Fla., and Peter R. Kirwan-Taylor of London and Hong Kong, was married yesterday to Matthew Bertles Lorentzen, a son of Cornelia Pollard of Palm Beach and the late Per A. Lorentzen. The Rev. Robert Pollard 3d, the bridegroom's stepfather, performed the ceremony in Palm Beach at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, where he is a priest.

title: What's in a Wink?
description: By any definition, I am a flirt.

title: At Wake Forest, Duncan Will Show His Staying Power
description: As it turns out, Tim Duncan was always calm, cool, relaxed; in the marvelous patois of his native Virgin Islands, always ''on the lime'' or ''limin'.''

title: Learning to Beat A Fear of Flying
description: OUR flight was halfway between New York and Washington, D.C., when we felt the plane drop out of the sky. That is, the aircraft lost altitude so suddenly and dramatically that the passengers gave a collective gasp.
