Gripped with gut-wrenching terror, my knuckles white and my face contorted in a mask of horror, I was convinced not only that I was about to die violently but also that I would have several more minutes to be conscious of this inevitability, as our plane plummeted to the earth in a ball of fire.

title: HAZING DAYS
description: Your article focuses on the undeniable debauchery, danger and damage of fraternity hazing. But why do ''Many who stay believe all their lives in the mystic ties of brotherhood''? Why is the male rite of passage universal, across so many cultures? It obviously fulfills a need. Many of us who cherish what we learned about ourselves in those rites know that it goes beyond the yearning at all costs to belong, or to act out primitive needs to express anger, cruelty and power.

title: Fish Gotta Swim . . .
description: THE slot machine in the fish tank isn't real. But ''the fish like it,'' Donald (Skip) Uricchio said.

title: Victim Status: Frida Kahlo
description: There is a moment in the early life of Frida Kahlo that uniquely illumines the evolution of her myth. It is not one of her many luckless moments -- not her childhood contraction of polio, nor the bus accident that fractured her skeleton and left her in unremitting pain, nor any of the more than 30 operations that followed; it is not even her first, ill-omened glimpse of Diego Rivera, the great painter who married her and then deceived her at every opportunity. It is the moment, apparently sometime in her 18th year, when, gazing into the mirror, she resolved to stop trimming her eyebrows -- to let those two sumptuous pieces of fur grow into one. It is when she found, you might say, the pluck to not pluck -- a decision she would never regret. For those eyebrows made possible the Cult of Kahlo: They were the providential precondition of her celebrity.

title: Rangers' Road Trip Gets Longer By the Day
description: Tonight's Ranger defeat their third in succession, their seventh in nine games -- had a new wrinkle. They held a 2-0 lead, a rarity, before being blitzed by the Canucks. The final score was 5-3 for Vancouver.

title: Eclectic Offerings for the Holiday
description: THE volume of concert activity always takes a nosedive during Thanksgiving week, but today's calendar remains crowded.

title: Rerouted Copters Jar Ears to East
description: For the residents of the Upper East Side, already indignant about horn-honking traffic tie-ups at the Queensboro Bridge, the agreement by helicopter operators that went into effect Oct. 1 promised at least one source of peace and quiet: the skies.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: FYI 2

title: Q. & A.
description: A Noisy Neighbor In a Co-op

title: Variations on a Theme
description: THE MUSIC

title: A Crowded Docket for Courtroom Addicts
description: THE RECENT NEWS FROM Showtime was inevitable. Two years of a national obsession with O. J. Simpson, televised trials and the second-guessing of jurors was enough to persuade the cable channel to try to remake ''12 Angry Men,'' Sidney Lumet's 1957 classic film about a jury in a murder case. But Showtime may have competition: Mr. Lumet himself.

title: Police Say Mother Left Children Home Alone
description: A Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday on child endangerment charges after police officers found her three young children, including twin infants, left home alone in her Prospect Heights apartment.

title: A Bermuda Restaurant Reopens, Refurbished
description: Compass Point, the beach resort on Nassau in the Bahamas, reopened its restaurant this month after a $1 million expansion.

title: Capturing Slices of Jewish Life in America
description: WHICH photo disturbed you?'' the French-born photographer Frederic Brenner asked gleefully, his eyes widening.

title: Monumental Art, but the Wind and Rain Care Not
description: IN THE 1960'S A HANDFUL OF REBELLIOUS young artists left their mark on the landscape -- both geographical and cultural -- by making the first earthworks. These site-specific cuts, mounds, holes and jetties, created in places like the Mojave Desert in California or Massacre Dry Lake, Nev. -- far from Eurocentric culture and the world of museums and art galleries -- represent some of the most radical gestures in 20th-century art.

title: The Bet Is Off; Trousers Are Back On
description: Two Bergenfield mail carriers, Steve Nason, and Ron Filera, haven't worn long pants on the job since they made a bet in December 1994 to see who could last longer wearing shorts. Now the bet is about to end.

title: Thanksgiving, and Goal to Go
description: IF there is comfort in certainty, New Jersey is one of the more comfortable places around, and nothing has been more certain over the years than the Big Game, whether in city, suburb or countryside. Four days from now, on Thanksgiving, high school football squads will meet to play out once again their longstanding annual rivalries, wrapping the holiday morning in expectations that will soon become uniquely American memories.

title: Jim Crow on the Bench
description: SHADES OF FREEDOMRacial Politics and Presumptions of the American Legal Process.By A. Leon Higginbotham Jr.Illustrated. 304 pp. New York:Oxford University Press. $30.

title: Who Cares What the Owners Think?
description: When it comes to corporate democracy, the railroads have always been leaders in finding ways to make sure that ordinary shareholders are not allowed to make trouble for the bosses who run the companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about the use of computers in televised coverage of elections misidentified the computer used by CBS to maintain some of its records. It was manufactured by IBM, not Cray Research. The article also misstated the job title of the CBS executive who supervises election-night coverage, Lane Venardos. He is a vice president.

title: Canadian Psychos
description: TRAPLINES

title: We Shall, Alas, Seek Our Own Hamlets and Lady Macbeths
description: To the Editor:

title: Culture and Its Discontents
description: Making Gender

title: Harald A. Rehder, 89, Expert on Mollusks
description: Dr. Harald A. Rehder, a zoologist emeritus at the National Museum of Natural History of the Smithsonian Institution, died on Nov. 10 at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 89 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Death by Discrimination?
description: One of my first assignments as a reporter was to interview a cartoonist who lived on Chicago's Gold Coast, a sliver of affluence set between Lake Michigan and a nasty housing project. Killing time before the interview, I stopped at a jeweler and asked the price of a watch in the window. The manager ducked into a storeroom and led out an enormous Doberman, straining at its leash. With a snarl that matched the dog's, she said, ''Now, may I help you?'' The cartoonist was not much better. She opened the door a crack then shut it in my face.

title: Imagining How 2 Peoples Discovered Each Other
description: For a social-studies assignment this year, fifth graders at Central Elementary School in East Brunswick were encouraged to look back in history and answer this question: If you were an American Indian child, how would you feel when you saw strange people coming to ''discover'' your land? Here are some answers from the class taught by Mary Ann Sovino, past president of the New Jersey Council for the Social Studies.

title: Brew Pub Returns a Tradition to Westchester
description: IF you've got it, flaunt it. The two huge copper brewing vessels, visible tools of the brewer's trade, that fill the window of 179 Mamaroneck Avenue here, draw attention to the arrival last month of the Westchester Brewing Company, described as the county's first brew pub.

title: Taxes? Who Cares? Now Some Funds Do
description: WHEN wealthy people hire someone to manage their money, they assume the manager will consider tax issues. After all, after-tax return is what counts in determining how much money you keep.

title: Honors Go to Two Disease-Resistant Elms
description: AWARDS are the thing at the close of the year. They go to actors, record manufacturers, television shows, products -- and even plants.

title: No Headline
description: ''Am I out of the picture completely? I'd like to serve with a President who also speaks with an accent.''

title: Two Faces of Evita
description: EVA PERON

title: How Movie Magic Fares on the Stage
description: SCREEN adaptations of stage musicals (there must be hundreds) rarely recapture the fervor of the original, but at least a movie lasts. Stage transplants of screen musicals (there are perhaps seven) never seem to keep step with their matchless sources.

title: Correction
description: A review of Alice Munro's ''Selected Stories'' on Oct. 27 misidentified the principal character in one story. The protagonist of ''Differently'' is Georgia, not Gloria.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE CARDIFF TEAMTen Stories.By Guy Davenport.New Directions, $22.95.

title: Most Valuable Player
description: I first heard about Babe Zaharias from my mother, who couldn't have been less of a sports fan; though she alluded mysteriously to athletic glory in her youth, by the time I was born she was resolutely sedentary and took all her exercise at the ironing board. Nevertheless, she followed Zaharias's career, especially her stunning comeback in 1954, when less than a year after undergoing surgery for intestinal cancer, she won the U.S. Open by 12 strokes. And when Zaharias died in 1956, I remember my mother explaining to me that the world had lost a ''great sportswoman.'' The term in her mind had less to do with actual athletic accomplishment, perhaps, than with style and daring; my mother also used it to refer to another idol of hers, the cigar-smoking equestrian Eleanora Sears.

title: On Coping With Breast Cancer
description: The letters on breast cancer in Long Island by Dr. Marilie Gammon of the Columbia School of Public Health and Geri Barish raise many questions that badly need public examination. I am an epidemiologist invited in 1992 by the One In Nine group to help counter the official assertion at that time that the high rates in Long Island reflected the ''dominant influence of affluent Jewish women.'' This attempt to ''blame the victim'' rather than look for environmental causes led Lorraine Pace of the One In Nine group to organize her neighbors in West Islip to produce colored maps that revealed some blue-collar neighborhoods in which every other home appeared to have been affected in recent years.

title: The Third Sex
description: THE INVISIBLES

title: ADVENTURES OF A REPUBLICAN REVOLUTIONARY
description: Goldberg mentions that Neumann missed votes in the Congress to go deer hunting with his son. What he doesn't say is that one of those skipped votes was the most important one last year in Congress, namely, on the G.O.P.'s plan to balance the budget by the year 2002. In fact, Neumann's most concrete vote on the budget was to shut down the Government twice, which, of course, expanded rather than reduced the deficit.

title: Montessori Advantages In Early Education
description: Three recent special reports, ''Will All Pupils on L.I. Read by the Third Grade,'' ''Making Reading a Total Experience'' and ''In the 3d Grade in Long Beach, Reading is Often a Team Effort,'' published on Oct. 6, 20 and Nov. 3, respectively, and a Nov. 3 advertisement, ''Where We Stand,'' by Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, raise the same problematic question: ''What can be done to dramatically improve education in America?''

title: Karen Levine And Robert Dekle
description: Karen Levine, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Levine of Boston, and Robert Dekle, the son of Kazue Ouchi Dekle of Washington and the late Bernard Dekle, were married yesterday. James G. Mullen Jr., a justice of the peace and the town clerk of Milton, Mass., officiated at Maison Robert, a restaurant in Boston.

title: Miss Rosenstein And Mr. Moore
description: Gertrude L. Rosenstein and Nelson R. Moore were married in New York on Thursday at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton performed the ceremony.

title: INSIDE
description: Yeltsin Orders Withdrawal

title: Where Special Children Get Help
description: ON a rolling campus where Canada geese were meandering among groves of fruit trees, neatly dressed students walked in quiet lines to the gymnasium, played computer games in a classroom and conducted experiments in a science laboratory.

title: Passengers Tell of Accident: 'We Were in a Swamp'
description: It was just past 6:30 yesterday morning, and Bill Hayes had started working on his laptop computer when the Amtrak train he was riding on hit something and started to shake. A jolt made him slide off his seat, and his glasses were knocked off his face.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: RIVERDALE

title: Salvia Resembles The Menorah
description: Your gardening column on salvia (''Love It, Hate It, the Ubiquitous Salvia Persists,'' Oct. 6) brought to mind a fascinating interpretation of the plant developed in Israel.

title: Disneyland Paris Adopts Notre Dame
description: WHEN it comes to marketing, the French often seem proud to be associated with anything Disney, much though that may disgust purists. In the medieval walled city of Carcassonne, hawkers insist that its towers and spires were what Disney had in mind as the setting for ''Sleeping Beauty.'' Others say it was one of the Renaissance chateaux in the Loire Valley.

title: Corrections
description: An article about northern Florida on Nov. 10 in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misstated a telephone number for Wakulla Springs Lodge and Conference Center. It is (904) 224-5950.

title: A Good Cigar Is Part Connecticut
description: FRANK TOPPER has seen his family's cigar business through many ups and down during his 43-year tenure, but he has never seen a boom like the one of the last two years.

title: Colleen Martin, Christopher Nilan
description: Colleen Marie Martin, a daughter of Mary Gaffney Martin of Rhinebeck, N.Y., and the late Richard L. Martin Sr., was married yesterday to Christopher William Nilan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Nilan of Atlanta. The Rev. Stephen Churchwell performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Atlanta.

title: A Choreographer's Inspiration to the Dance
description: HE studied painting at Syracuse University, and 45 years later he still goes to museums to look for ideas. Besides his own LP's, he listens to tapes and CD's that arrive in the mail. Sometimes he commissions music (which he says he doesn't know much about) for his company. Yet Paul Taylor is acclaimed not as a painter, nor as a musician, nor as a patron, nor as a chief executive. The world knows him as a dancer turned choreographer, a master at making dances.

title: Cutting Lumber In Private Forests
description: THE state's long-dormant lumber industry is back, changing the nature of privately owned forests and raising questions about the effect on the native forest as a whole.

title: ADVENTURES OF A REPUBLICAN REVOLUTIONARY
description: Jeffrey Goldberg's ''Adventures of a Republican Revolutionary'' (Nov. 3) neatly illustrates the great distance that separates political ideals from the political process. Mark W. Neumann, a freshman Republican Congressman from Wisconsin, came to town with an ideology, stuck with it and was ostracized by his colleagues as a reward for his integrity. Though opposed to his politics, I can't help admiring his efforts.

title: Helping Native Canadians
description: The sheer weight of the sweeping, five-year, five-volume study on Canada's Indians and Eskimos released on Thursday made it almost impossible for anyone to question the report's conclusion that Canadian policies for dealing with the country's original people has been a disaster. Dissent came only on the report's recommendations for how to start over.

title: Wetteland's Agent Says He Will Meet With Teams
description: As a closer, John Wetteland is accustomed to waiting around until the ninth inning. But Wetteland's lead agent has grown weary of waiting around for the Yankees. So, Tom Reich said yesterday, he plans to meet with other interested clubs beginning tomorrow.

title: The Game Ends for Cozza As Harvard Holds Off Yale
description: Eion Hu enjoyed his last game at Harvard Stadium today, while Carm Cozza, the Yale coach who is retiring, endured his.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ART AT SILVERMINE

title: The Lady Vanishes: Amelia Earhart
description: Amelia Earhart symbolizes modern woman's invasion of the male world of daring action and adventure. As an aviator, she broke barriers and made the machine age her own. As a recreational athlete and automobile driver, she embodied fitness, energy and breezy mobility.

title: ADVENTURES OF A REPUBLICAN REVOLUTIONARY
description: It's very easy nowadays to tell whether your feature story will cast a positive or negative light on its subject. The reader need only look at the cover photo. When you disapprove (as with Mark Neumann's politics), it will be an extreme and repellent close-up -- eyes, nose and mouth only, with every pore, hair follicle and furrow in sharp focus. The reader's natural reaction is physically to push him (and his politics) away.

title: In an Age of Con, Cynical Makes Sweet Music
description: WHO COULD HAVE guessed it? The time could not be more right for Walter Bobbie's exciting revival of ''Chicago,'' the John Kander-Fred Ebb-Bob Fosse ''musical vaudeville'' that has just settled in for what should be a long run at the Richard Rodgers Theater.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Let There Be Black Light

title: Houdinis' Plot Is Cleared Up, and Then Thickens
description: It's a mystery, with a little touch of sleight-of-hand.

title: U.S. Giving Lighthouses To Towns In Maine
description: She earns her paycheck as town manager on an island off the coast of Maine, but Sue Lessard's unofficial job involves watching over a small lighthouse perched precariously on a bluff overlooking the cold ocean.

title: Amtrak Derailment in Secaucus Marsh Injures 32
description: An Amtrak fast-mail train approaching New York with 108 passengers and crew members derailed as it crossed a Hackensack River swing bridge on a desolate New Jersey meadowland early yesterday. After sideswiping an oncoming passenger train, six cars of the mail train plunged down a 30-foot embankment.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HONORING SCARLETT

title: Havana Rumba
description: SEVEN months have passed since the United States enacted legislation to punish both Americans and foreigners doing business in Cuba and declared the country dead, but the corpse continues to dance to an Afro-Latin beat. And with the Pope coming, there's reason to celebrate popular culture in Havana. Notes from one week reveal a life of the soul, a unique city style that is grim and vibrant and defiant.

title: It's Not Just Actors Who Suffer the Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: The Drama Queen
description: EVEN IF YOU didn't know that ''Over the Rainbow'' was one of Marilyn Monroe's favorite songs, you still might have guessed that it was one of the two selections played at her funeral in August 1962. For one thing, the international anthem of inarticulate longing, with its prepubescent diction (''way up high'') and nap-time similes (''troubles melt like lemon drops''), seems to reflect the childlike naivete that always lay just beneath Monroe's sexpot exterior. But even more, it links Monroe directly to Judy Garland, who made the song famous and who died in remarkably similar circumstances: a faltering career, yet another failed marriage, and final and maybe intentionally high dose of barbiturates.

title: Hammer-and-Chisel Art Is Heart of a Studio
description: FOR Sebastiano and Ron Mineo, ''student-centered learning'' imparting knowledge through lively interactive discourse -- has long been a family legacy and instinctive way of teaching.

title: The Achiever: Helen Keller
description: She remains not quite 7 years old for many of us, suspended in the revelatory moment in 1887 that crowns William Gibson's play ''The Miracle Worker.'' Helen Keller stands ignorant at the pump while her teacher, Annie Sullivan, works it rapidly, and with the simultaneous spilling of water and spelling of w-a-t-e-r into her palms, she suddenly intuits that everything on this earth has a name. The well of knowledge! Still a child when I first watched a child actress enacting Helen's real-life epiphany, I hardly understood the well's literary aptness. But Helen's cry -- that elemental wa -- pumped water up from some deep source into my own eyes and briefly blinded them.

title: Big Rivalry Becomes a Big Rout For Undefeated Arizona State
description: Its hope for a matchup of undefeated teams in the Rose Bowl -- with a chance at the national championship on the line -- had vanished hours earlier in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Pierre, Is That a Masonic Flag on the Moon?
description: IN the days before the Internet, when rumors had to make their way by boat and horseback instead of by waves and wire, it took perseverance to assemble the pieces of a really good conspiracy theory.

title: Crime
description: Get in the car and throw away the map. James Crumley is back at the wheel, in BORDERSNAKES (Mysterious Press/Warner, $22), for another bone-rattling road trip across the mythic face of America. Although the two rusty-dusty knights on this manic vision quest for honor, retribution and excellent stimulants are no strangers, they are teamed up here for the first time -- to memorable effect. Milo Milodragovitch, who passes for a private eye in his Montana cow town, is on the trail of the crooked banker who cheated him out of his inheritance. C. W. Sughrue, a wild man from West Texas, wants to meet the guy who sent a gunman out to hunt him down. When these two saddle tramps climb into Milo's cherry-red Eldorado and take off across Texas, sharing the narrative as they share the booze and drugs, the smart folks head for the hills.

title: Indubitable Achievements
description: Between 1962 and 1971, Esquire featured one remarkable cover after another, each conceived and designed by Madison Avenue's Wunderkind, George Lois. They were nothing like Norman Rockwell's mythic paintings of an ideal America, created for The Saturday Evening Post. They were acerbic critiques of contemporary society, politics and manners that subverted the conventions of mainstream magazines. Many were dramatic photographs or photomontages, some were caricatures and one was just type ('' 'Oh my God -- we hit a little girl': The true story of M Company From Fort Dix to Vietnam''). They were not fettered by extraneous text, thus creating an impact like that of a poster. Of the 70 covers reproduced in COVERING THE '60s: George Lois, the Esquire Era (Monacelli, paper, $35), with anecdotal annotations by Mr. Lois, the most memorable are icons of the age, with trenchant cover lines: ''The Confessions of Lt. Calley,'' featuring a smiling portrait of the court-martialed leader of the My Lai massacre, surrounded by young Asian children; ''The final decline and total collapse of the American avant-garde,'' showing Andy Warhol drowning in a can of Campbell's tomato soup; ''The Passion of Muhammad Ali,'' showing the boxer like St. Sebastian, with arrows piercing his body; and ''Nixon's last chance. (This time he'd better look right!)'' with a profile of the 1968 Presidential candidate having his face made up. There are also lesser known covers, including portraits: Joseph McCarthy's henchman, Roy Cohn, with a halo over his head to illustrate what Mr. Lois calls a ''self-serving piece . . . in which he rationalized his skulduggery''; Norman Mailer in a King Kong suit, holding Germaine Greer -- ''The literary male chauvinist monster goes ape for the female liberationist doll,'' Mr. Lois writes; Jack Nicholson in the nude, illustrating a story on the high jinks of Hollywood (the only Lois cover to be killed on press). Here are the histories of a magazine in its golden age, a critical period of American social and political turmoil and the legacy of a remarkable graphic designer and commentator.Steven Heller

title: An Economy of Happily Ever After?
description: AS the White House and Congress prepare to attack the big issues that could shape the economic landscape for years to come, Washington is bathed in something of a rosy glow.

title: Living Up to Their Portraits
description: Andrew WyethA Secret Life.By Richard Meryman.Illustrated. 447 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $35.

title: LET OUR CHILDREN GO
description: I had reservations about John Tierney's recommendations in his article ''Let Our Children Go'' (The Big City: Oct. 6). However, it is exactly the type of stultified, institution-first thinking exemplified in Margarita Muinelo's letter (Nov. 3) that drives humanists to seek solutions outside the domain of public education.

title: Kathelyn Sue Steimer, 48, AIDS Researcher
description: Dr. Kathelyn Sue Steimer, a leading researcher in the quest for an AIDS vaccine, died on Nov. 16 at her home in Benicia, Calif. She was 48.

title: 'New York Jets Go Rolling Along'
description: Twenty years later, both Lou Holtz and the Jets are still trying to overcome the past and figure out how to read the future.

title: Why a 401(k) Option May Deserve a Look
description: IT'S time to start thinking about how much to squirrel away in that 401(k) plan next year. You may want to consider something that is often quickly dismissed: after-tax contributions.

title: Shut Up and Eat!
description: Eating, wrote M. F. K. Fisher, is ''basically brutish''; it is ''a physical function, like breathing or defecating.'' Throughout Fisher's long career as America's finest food writer, she never lost sight of that fact. She knew, of course, that eating could be refined beyond its animal necessity. It might bring pleasure in such subtle and complex ways that the mere alleviation of hunger ranked as almost an art. Fisher thought well enough of both food and writing to perfect a hybrid genre, starting with ''Consider the Oyster'' (1941) and ''How to Cook a Wolf'' (1942), that gently folded recipes into stories. But she never attributed to food a dignity or power that it cannot possess. Her highest praise for any dish, from bread and cheese to truffles, was to declare it ''good.''

title: A Library for Stewart, 'Star Trek's' Captain
description: WHEN the latest installment of the venerable ''Star Trek'' movie series, ''Star Trek: First Contact,'' opened on Friday, a good measure of the attention focussed on Patrick Stewart as Capt. Jean-Luc Picard. Likely to be overlooked is the continuing mission of a group based on Long Island to show that the rest of Mr. Stewart's career is as much or more interesting than portraying the captain of the Enterprise.

title: Yeltsin Orders Withdrawal Of Troops In Chechnya
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin today ordered the withdrawal of virtually all of the remaining Russian forces in Chechnya, in a move that will deprive Moscow of even a face-saving military presence in the breakaway region in southern Russia.

title: ATP Champion Will Be a Familiar One
description: While Pete Sampras was making a stirring run to the United States Open title in September, Boris Becker was home in Munich, watching on television.

title: BENEFITS
description: Variety at the Copacabana

title: The Heir at The Amsterdam News
description: WHEN she was 7 years old, Elinor R. Tatum says, she announced to her parents that she wanted to be the first black Jewish president. When she was 14, she asked her father, Wilbert A. Tatum, the vocal, and at times controversial, editor in chief and publisher of The Amsterdam News, why he had never run for public office. He told her he thought he could accomplish more where he was, running New York's largest and the nation's oldest continuously published black newspaper.

title: The Man Behind the Front
description: Inside OutA Memoir of the Blacklist. By Walter Bernstein. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Ajit Hutheesing, Helen E. Armstrong
description: Helen Elizabeth Armstrong, a violinist, was married yesterday to Ajit G. Hutheesing, the founder and chairman of International Capital Partners, an investment management firm in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Martin Montonye, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's house in Greenwich, Conn.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: The Rough Air of the 80's
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Sacrifice
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International

title: The Spies Didn't Come In From The Cold War
description: THE monument to Felix E. Dzerzhinsky, the first head of the Soviet secret police, is gone. But tucked away inside the intelligence service headquarters in Lubyanka Square is the K.G.B. museum.

title: The Dread Possessing a Child
description: THE essence of David Mamet's ''Cryptogram'' is hidden, mysterious, codified. Isn't that just what the title says?

title: Travel Videos
description: To the Editor: The review of travel videos by Suzanne Carmichael in the Practical Traveler column (''Video Guides: a Road Test,'' Oct. 20) seemed unduly harsh to me as a travel filmmaker and video producer. It seems only right to look at the other side.

title: DIARY
description: THE AIR-BAG DEBATE1,600 Saved, 51 DeadOn the safety front, people tend to fixate on the heart-rending anecdote and ignore the statistic. A plane crashes, and the media go crazy, seeming to forget how vastly safer it is to fly than to drive to the corner for milk. A child dies from a fast-expanding air bag, and people forget the positive. ''What's getting lost,'' one safety advocate said, is that air bags ''have already shown their incredible payoff'' -- an estimated 1,600 lives saved, compared with 51 deaths traced to them. The goal now: save the 1,600 and the 51, too. The Transportation Department weighed in last week, moving to allow drivers to have air bags disconnected and let car makers come up with bags that inflate more slowly. Those both have their own risks, though, so other ideas are emerging, like ''two-speed'' air bags and even ''smart seats'' that sense the size of the passenger. Smart drivers might help, too.

title: Teaching Youths the Risks of Smoking
description: JOEL GURIN of Scarsdale, the editorial director of Consumers Union, never smoked, he said, perhaps because his mother died of lung cancer when he was a teen-ager.

title: Travels in Limbo
description: I HAVE just returned from a new kind of vacation. It is the between-jobs, between-homes vacation, the second of its type for my husband and me.

title: WHY NEGATIVE ADS ARE GOOD FOR DEMOCRACY
description: Tierney asserts that ''negative ads are good for democracy.'' Yet, he concedes that they peddle deception, paint false portraits of candidates, increase cynicism toward the political process and depress turnout. What's good here?

title: Shadowland
description: REBECCA (1940), Alfred Hitchcock's first Hollywood classic, remains the dowager empress of all romantic thrillers. It's a superb version of Daphne du Maurier's best selling novel about the new young bridge (Joan Fontaine above, with Laurence Olivier) of a brooding, aristocratic widower haunted by the spirit of her predecessor, the fabled hostess of a spectacular Cornwall estate. The marvelous plot unfolds stunningly, with the director's subtle and atmospheric brush strokes of tension and his stellar cast, including Judith Anderson, George Sanders and Florence Bates. Franz Waxman's eerie musical theme hooks you immediately. This is top, classy Hollywood via David O. Selznick, after his ''Gone with the Wind.'' Another milestone - THURSDAY at 12:30 P.M. on CINEMAX.

title: The Racism We Condemn
description: We emerged from a dream-like political campaign, in which almost nothing of substance was said about racial issues, only to find that from St. Petersburg, Fla., to Pittsburgh the problems of alienation, resentment, contempt and enmity are still with us. And now, out of Texaco's corporate headquarters, out of its executive suite in White Plains, N.Y., comes evidence of unacceptable racist attitudes, and even the possible obstruction of justice.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 1, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Dell, $7.50.) A woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler.

title: In Manila, Asians Pore Over Washington's Inner Truths
description: Anyone wondering why Asian business leaders showed such intense interest in the inner workings of the American political system this fall -- and such eagerness to contribute to both Democrats and Republicans in record amounts -- could find the answer this week in the sprawling ballrooms of the Shangri-la Hotel here.

title: Downtown Actor, Uptown Ambitions
description: HE'S GLOWERING DOWN HIS distinctively broken nose with a sullen look in those controversial Calvin Klein CK Be ads. He's a beautiful corpse through most of Abel Ferrara's ''Funeral.'' He's the charmingly conniving leader of a band of petty criminals in Alan Taylor's ''Palookaville.'' He's on the runway modeling Anna Sui clothes during Fashion Week.

title: HAZING DAYS
description: As a college fraternity president at the University of Illinois in 1959, I put a stop to the paddling portion of the initiation and modified other rites.

title: Virgin Territory
description: MICHAEL AULT IS content. At 1 A.M., he is sitting in his new SoHo club, Chaos, a loft on Watts Street whose red velvet settees are currently occupied by an extraordinary concentration of beautiful young women with long legs and high cheekbones. ''Models are the most wonderful turbocharged creatures,'' Ault says. ''I worship them.'' Today, like all days, he has been on the phone with dozens of them.

title: The Company First
description: To the Editor:

title: St. John's Wins In First Round
description: St. John's soccer team got rid of bitter memories of four straight first-round defeats by overwhelming Fordham yesterday, 5-1, in the opening contest of the 1996 National Collegiate Athletic Association championship. The freshman Jimmy Buscemi had two goals and an assist.

title: Way Before the Turnpike
description: PICTURE, if you will, a land with dense forests and pristine waters, abundant in wildlife, populated by people innocent in the ways of commerce. Then imagine the place discovered by foreigners from lands with sophisticated economies, who see big profits behind every tree.

title: Affirmative Action: Can Whitman Stand Firm?
description: While the naughty boys in the executive suite at Texaco were engaging in bigoted banter, the conservative wing of the Republican Party was proclaiming America's public and private institutions free of discrimination, and calling for an end to racial preference programs. At about the same time the people at Avis, the car rental agency, were reportedly refusing to rent cars to black customers, legislation was being debated in 26 states to repeal or significantly roll back affirmative action programs.

title: For Sons of Liberty, A Family of Painters
description: IN 1772, A 40-YEAR-OLD PLANTER from northern Virginia had his portrait painted by a 31-year-old artist from Annapolis. For both men, it was a moment just before the sunrise of fame. Three years later, George Washington became Commander in Chief of the Continental Army. Charles Willson Peale hit his stride in a long career of distinction in many fields, including natural science and art.

title: A Case of Cold War Immorality
description: Morality was often a casualty of American conduct in the cold war, but some of the tradeoffs made in the name of enhanced security were truly shameful. One of the most despicable has just come to light. A Salvadoran guerrilla suspected of involvement in the 1985 assassination of four off-duty United States marines in San Salvador was protected, paid and eventually resettled in California by the American Government in exchange for providing information about rebel military plans.

title: Full Day: Classics, Jazz and Dance
description: THOUGH the volume of concert activity is always turned down Thanksgiving week, today's program seems as full as ever. It begins at 3 o'clock when the Stamford Symphony plays the Palace (and youngsters are admitted free with ticket-holding grownups). The group's music director, Roger Nierenberg, has chosen Mozart's Symphony No. 39, Wagner's Siegfried Idyll and, with Robert McDuffie as guest soloist, Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto.

title: A $30 Million Rain Forest Is Growing in the Bronx
description: There is no way around the basic injustice inherent in a zoo: it's a prison, even if it looks like a park, for animals taken out of their natural habitats.

title: A Fresco Saved
description: To the Editor: The magic name of Sansepolcro jumped out in Paul Hofmann's Oct. 13 article, ''Great Art in Small Places.'' The magnificent fresco of Piero della Francesca, the ''Resurrection,'' brought to mind an incident in World War II that led to the saving of this treasure.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: MARATHON

title: At Chemical Weapons Depot, the Target Is Tenants
description: Among the real estate salespeople who have worked to dismember the nearly 300 military installations that Washington has closed in the last decade, Charles J. Finley faces one of the toughest challenges.

title: What President Was That?
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Could Not Have Known of the Holocaust?
description: To the Editor:

title: Up in Smoke
description: Life Without Water

title: Crack v. Cocaine: a Wash
description: For a decade, Congress has mandated harsher prison sentences for sellers and users of crack cocaine than for those involved with powder cocaine, reasoning that crack spawns more crime. Last week, two addiction researchers reported that the differences between the two were so small as to make the 100-to-1 disparity in sentences excessive. Writing in the Journal of the American Medical Association, Dorothy K. Hatsukami and Marian W. Fischman also argued for treating offenders for cocaine abuse instead of locking them up. Their study has not changed thinking on Capitol Hill, where tough drug laws remain popular with constituents. CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

title: First, Keep the Jury Wide Awake
description: BREVITY.

title: Brawny, but None Too Tall, Cincinnati Has High Hopes
description: He has the nation's top power forward and, according to many preseason polls, the nation's top college basketball team. The one thing Coach Bob Huggins of Cincinnati does not have is abundant height. He speaks of his centers as if they were nesting dolls, one inside the other, each one growing succeedingly shorter until he is left with a potentially troubling miniature in the post.

title: Many Icons, Few Iconoclasts
description: ''The iconography of her face,'' the film critic Gene Siskel wrote in TV Guide of Marilyn Monroe, ''red lips, platinum hair, blue-shadowed eyes -- resembles an American flag.''

title: The Shadow Knows
description: I don't want to pay Bruce Lindsey's salary any more.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: Management Fees: Defying Gravity?

title: A Brand That's in Your Face
description: The three calls to the Ghetto Cookies headquarters came late at night, the voices filled with indignation and disgust. Ghetto is such a nasty, ugly word, the callers charged. Certainly not a proper way to describe tasty morsels that bring to mind after-school snacks and Christmas parties, not rundown apartment buildings and poverty.

title: WHY NEGATIVE ADS ARE GOOD FOR DEMOCRACY
description: Has it occurred to Tierney that applauding the use of the word ''liberal'' as a hated term, in negative election ads, would leave only ''conservative'' and ''moderate'' as acceptable political positions? Does he think this is also good for democracy, or is he ready to accept this step toward group-think -- as long as it helps his ideological side? And how long will it be before conservatives will use ''moderate'' as a political curse word?

title: The Games That Children Play
description: THEY jump and skip, talking of fire drills, getting left back and playing monster. Then the bullies come, taunting and pelting them with anti-Semitic slurs and with fists.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: EVERYONE IS ENTITLED TO MY OPINION

title: Why We Spy on Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Date Set in a Florida Lawsuit Against Tobacco Companies
description: In a ruling hailed as a victory by anti-tobacco groups, a Florida judge has set a trial date for next Sept. 8 in a statewide class-action suit against leading tobacco companies that accuses them of causing illness.

title: In Japan, a Perch For Astro Boy
description: Osamu Tezuka, known as the Walt Disney of Japan, developed the modern Japanese form of comics and animation in the decades after World War II. A new museum showcasing his art has opened in the Kansai region of Japan. The Osamu Tezuka Manga Museum (manga means comic or cartoon in Japanese) is in Takurazuka City, about half an hour's train ride from Osaka.

title: Model of Decorum: Naomi Campbell
description: She was once called by the Vanity Fair columnist George Wayne ''the biggest brat in the modeling business.'' She was once reported to earn $1 million per year. She was said by her booker at the time to be displeased that Christy Turlington earned more from her lips alone. She was once fired by her modeling agency on the grounds that ''no money or prestige could further justify the abuse that has been imposed on'' staff and clients. She was publicly rebuked in gossip magazines. She was informed at the time that her agency would not employ her again if she were ''the last model on earth.'' She was rehired by this agency after six months.

title: 20 Years at the Table, From Cottage Cheese to Calamari
description: TWENTY years of watching Connecticut restaurants come and go -- or, more happily in some instances, come and stay -- inspires some observations about the ever-changing scene in the Nutmeg State.

title: Two Ways to Invest While Dancing to a Beat
description: Q. I've been following a dollar cost averaging strategy for investing in mutual funds. A friend says I could do better with ''value averaging,'' especially if the market enters a downturn. What is value averaging?

title: Sacred Monster: Martha Graham
description: From time to time, she would interrupt the intermediate-level dance class I used to take at her school on East 63d Street. We would hear the door creak, whichever of her dancers was teaching that evening would stop dead in the middle of demonstrating a phrase, and we, the students, would turn around to stare at the advancing monster, the scarlet mouth, the rolling, mascaraed eyes, the lacquered chopsticks plunged into her tied-up hair, the listing, weaving walk as she made her way toward the front of the big, old mirrored studio. If the class was just beginning, we would still be doing the floor work, contracting and spiraling our bodies from various sitting positions on the bare wood floor. Softly, the teacher would command us to stand, but we would already be scrambling to our feet, and as Martha wove through our ranks she would snarl, and pinch and slap us, evidently enraged by our sloppy posture, our dishevelment, our general lack of presence.

title: Rx for Doctor-Patient Dialogue
description: Q. How should physicians and patients address one another?

title: The Proud, Neglected Sweet Potato
description: Benjamin Patten believes in sweet potatoes.

title: Pack Hands Out 22 Assists In the Nets' 3-Guard Attack
description: It is considered bad manners from the first time a child climbs into a crowded sandbox. No one likes someone who doesn't share.

title: Honky-Tonk Angel: Patsy Cline
description: My mother said her name with slightly pursed lips: ''Patsy . . .'' -- no last name needed, vowels squeezed a little by disapproval but the tight mouth holding back a barely contained thrill. Patsy Cline was wicked and fabulous when both qualities really meant something, before they were cheap ideas used to market more flaccid talents. She was a source of fascination, distrust and raw, if hidden, admiration. But not judgment: there was nothing to attach judgment to because she, Patsy, did not judge herself.

title: Honors for 2 Disease-Resistant Elms
description: THE Agricultural Research Service, part of the United States Department of Agriculture, recently announced one of its biggest awards, and the winners were trees. In the long quest to find American elm trees resistant to the deadly Dutch elm disease fungus, two new varieties, Valley Forge and New Harmony, have been found worthy of introduction.

title: Jill R. Malkin, Geoffrey J. Addeo
description: Jill Robin Malkin and Geoffrey John Addeo, coordinators at television shows in New York, were married yesterday in New Hyde Park, L.I. The Rev. Michael J. Torpey, a Roman Catholic priest and the bridegroom's uncle, officiated at Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church.

title: NEW YORK & CO.
description: A Quiet Day at the Library Following the Market

title: Washington
description: Washington turns luminous during the holidays. The majestic architecture and classical lines of the landscape, much of it the vision of Pierre Charles L'Enfant, are a fitting backdrop for fetes and merrymaking. Even politics are cast aside for the moment as lawmakers and lobbyists revel in the less Grinchy pleasures of the season.

title: Not a Beagle in Sight
description: There'll be dalmatians everywhere next week, and not just in theaters. Here, dance students from Babylon, L.I., rehearse on the ''101 Dalmatians'' float that will bark its way through the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. (Associated Press)

title: Castro, the Pope and Me
description: ON the first day of fifth grade, the two young women who would be our teachers started out by asking a question not unusual for the place and time -- Cuba in 1973 -- but one that felt a bit out of order. We were just learning each other's names and there they were, two strangers in miniskirts, asking who among us believed in God.

title: Beware a Global Economy's Many Consequences
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana Contreras And Gerald Raia
description: Diana Contreras, a daughter of Alba L. Zelaya of the Bronx and a stepdaughter of Saverio F. Bello of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Lieut. Gerald Paul Raia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel A. Raia of Stillwater, N.Y. Msgr. Anthony J. Dalla Villa performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he is the rector.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK

title: Decoding the Holocaust
description: More than 50 years after the end of World War II, the Holocaust still challenges historians with questions -- not just why the genocide took place but who knew when it began and said nothing.

title: Long Hill Doesn't Say No to Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: An Explorer Either Lost Or Clearing A New Path
description: TRICKY, THE ENGLISH DANCE music maverick, is one of the most important musicians recording today. A former miscreant from the streets and jail cells of Bristol, he has been rearranging the face of pop music from the outside. In his hands, loping beats cobbled out of sound effects and laid-back vocals that forebode and reverberate as if delivered from the barrel of a shotgun have been turned into a new lounge music for a society on the edge of cataclysm. A fast-moving, instinct-driven chameleon, he has in the last three months released three albums, each one an attempt to prove that he can approach any style of music (be it punk, hip-hop or pop) and do it differently and better than anyone else.

title: They Sit and Wait So Others Can Serve
description: HAS any bird ever given so much? Feast for Pilgrims and centerpiece of countless Thanksgiving tables thereafter, it is now rejuvenating the sport of hunting. Such is the gift of the turkey.

title: A Voyage to Gauguin's Hideaway
description: WHILE sipping cafe au lait in a cafe in Tahiti in French Polynesia, my husband, Joe, and I noticed two young men with elaborate tattoos sitting at the next table. We struck up a conversation and learned they were woodcarvers visiting from the Marquesas Islands, 740 miles northeast of Tahiti. A cultural revival is taking place there, they said proudly, a renaissance of tattooing, drumming, dance -- traditions once banned by French missionaries in the 19th century. They invited us to visit their lush volcanic islands which, according to Marquesan legend, were born of the the sea and the sky.

title: Architecture Was Never So Wearable
description: Seen around town: women with an independent fashion spirit, wearing coats and suits that assiduously move fashion forward through their architectural cuts and sculptural fluidity. The designs, which achieve their inventive shapes through the frequent displacement of ordinary seams and darts, are from Geoffrey Beene, a master designer whose work stands out from the unrelenting minimalism of other coats. Some of his styles are shaped with color blockings;

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Berlin Rises In the East
description: Modern facades, restored historic buildings, new restaurants and elegant shops in the formerly Communist Mitte district of Berlin testify that this area has become the symbol of the city's rebirth.

title: Self-Fulfilling Prophets
description: The need to be enlightened and enfolded in bliss is probably best satisfied by God. Alas, God does not appear on talk shows or in the pages of Vanity Fair. And it is easier to wave the wand of the remote control than to look for a Higher Power (unless, of course, you happen to be in a 12-step program). Secular ideology and pop culture speak other words: find a role model and persuade yourself that with a little effort you can approximate her. Our icons are women who cast themselves as role models. They are more approachable than God -- at least we think they are. And they're available.

title: Coming Soon to a Prozac Nation
description: If you liked Prozac, you'll love what's coming next. Neuroscientists are proclaiming that the ''Decade of the Brain,'' an intensive program of basic research started by the National Institute of Mental Health, is about to pay off in a new generation of much-improved psychiatric drugs.

title: Michele A. Mecca, Patrick J. Fabbio
description: Michele Ann Mecca, a financial analyst at Salomon Brothers, the New York investment bank, was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Fabbio, the director of business development at Biomatrix, a biotechnology company in Ridgefield, N.J. The Rev. James D. Daley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas the Apostle in New York.

title: The Sphinx: Greta Garbo
description: Of the Swedes who made it big in Hollywood, Garbo was the star of the silent movies era; my mother, Ingrid Bergman, was the star of the sound era. That's how the press classified them.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: High Ups in High Boxes

title: Officers in 'Dirty Thirty' Helped Destroy Community
description: To the Editor:

title: In Prison, a Club That Uses Chess to Keep Emotions in Check
description: Rahway may be best known as the home of East Jersey State Prison, a 100-year-old institution commonly referred to by the name of its host community of 25,000. Rahway inmates were shown bluntly counseling teen-agers in the 1979 television documentary ''Scared Straight.'' But a lesser-known program with gentler intent is the Chess Club, founded last spring by James Spann, 49, of Newark, convicted of sexual assault and being an accessory to murder.

title: Coach Montana? Players Share Post-Reeves Fantasies
description: All the predictions have been heard on talk radio. All the speculation has been seen in the papers. The most talked about subject when it comes to the Giants is the naming of their future head coach.

title: Island Hopping in Fiji
description: AS we settled into our hotel near Nandi International Airport on the main Fijian island of Viti Levu, the television was ablaze with scenes of a curious assemblage of V.I.P.'s. On that April day McDonald's had opened its first restaurant in this nation of 320 islands scattered some 1,100 miles north of New Zealand, and the event was celebrated with a festive private party worthy of a visiting prime minister. My companion, Rosalie, and I fell asleep oddly comforted by the report. If Fiji had resisted the golden arches until now, it was a measure of how unspoiled the islands remained.

title: 3 Countries Benefit From Nursing School
description: THE quiet campus of the College of New Rochelle here, with its serene neo-Gothic buildings, secluded chapels and grassy quadrangles, would appear to have little in common with the exotic atmosphere of Ho Chi Minh City, the high-tech polish of Seoul or the uncertainties of St. Petersburg.

title: Now in the H.M.O.: Yoga Teachers and Naturopaths
description: AFTER AT&T began offering acupuncture to its management employees as an option in one of its health insurance plans in January, the company said ''less than a handful'' of workers sought treatment. Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest H.M.O., had more success, saying it had strong demand at its clinics in California that offered acupuncture and other alternative medical services.

title: Karate Kids
description: Ten IndiansBy Madison Smartt Bell.264 pp. New York:Pantheon Books. $23.

title: 'Born to Rebel'
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. and V.D.
description: Compared with other countries in the developed world, the United States has the highest rate of sexually transmitted diseases and no effective system to combat them, a panel of health experts said last week.

title: What Does It Take to Win Elections?
description: EVERYONE, it seemed, was talking about election reform this year but no one, it seemed, was really doing much about it. Well, almost no one.

title: Sometimes, Election Euphoria Doesn't Last
description: Rarely has Wall Street celebrated election results as exuberantly as it did the re-election of Bill Clinton and the continuance of Republican domination of Congress.

title: Tough Issues Need A Tougher Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Picturesque Block Unlike the Usual Rowhouse Street
description: DROP by the restoration work on the town house at 180 East 75th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues. The orange stucco facade is charming, but just as picturesque is the block itself, a mixed bag of residences that do not resemble the typical East Side rowhouse block. The block seems pleasantly irregular, but its current look was fashioned by a single plan in the early 1920's.

title: Savage Loving
description: DAMNED TO FAME

title: Inmates Get Tough, Sheriff Gets Tougher
description: Sheriff Joseph M. Arpaio of Mariopa County, Ariz., heard the national mantra: Get tough on prisoners. He put 1,000 prisoners in tents in the desert, banned coffee to save money and put women on chain gangs (calling it a blow against discrimination). He also banned cigarettes, replaced hot meals with bologna sandwiches and ordered all underwear dyed pink -- to deter theft.

title: No Soft Shoulders Waiting for Novotna
description: IT has been three years plus since Jana Novotna draped her head on the shoulder of the Duchess of Kent and had herself a good cry after blowing a 4-1 lead and losing to Steffi Graf in the Wimbledon final.

title: On Bridge That Has Served Fast Trains and Slow Tugs, Investigators Find Troubling Sign
description: For years, the Portal Bridge has quietly served its purpose to transportation and commerce. It has withstood the weight of trains rumbling across its back, and it has swung open to make way for tugs and barges to glide along the Hackensack River below.

title: Public Enemy No. 1: Martha Stewart
description: Naturally, people hate Martha Stewart. She's rich. She's blond. And now, she's even thin. What's weird is what they claim to hate her for.

title: Escape Artist: Tina Turner
description: I have never been a Tina Turner fan. More specifically, I am not a fan of the present-day Tina, she of the shortened, blond-streaked wigs, strange, self-invented elocution and Hanes Hosiery ads. In watching that Tina, one cannot help but be reminded of Michael Jackson's dramatically erased face. Like Michael, today's Tina seems less interested in being a unique stellar presence than a crossover act; she also seems to be trapped within the gilt-edged frame of her enormous popularity -- a popularity based in part on her dramatically ''candid'' post-Ike self-exposure, to which I have become inured and Tina has been martyred: self-confession as performance.

title: November Sweeps
description: Aiding several causes, from lupus research to the Ronald McDonald House.

title: Orchestra Finds Means of Survival In Hard Times
description: UNDER OTHER circumstances, it might be tempting to castigate the Czech Philharmonic for unadventurous programming in its Avery Fisher Hall concert this afternoon. Along with Brahms's Violin Concerto, which has already had two high-profile performances in New York this season, comes predictable Bohemian fare: Dvorak's ''New World'' Symphony and ''The Moldau'' from Smetana's ''My Country.''

title: Psychiatrists Hired for 2 Held in Baby Death
description: Lawyers for two New Jersey teen-agers accused of murdering their newborn boy have hired psychiatric experts, signaling that they may use a mental-health defense.

title: Adding to the Holiday Menu Without Risks
description: IN most families, to tinker with the traditional Thanksgiving menu is to court disaster. Substituting mashed potatoes for the candied sweets, adding mushrooms to what had been for years a plain bread and herb stuffing or replacing pumpkin pie with pumpkin cheesecake can be risky business. Complaints may replace emptied plates.

title: Wolves at Our Door
description: The wolf is the ultimate symbol of untamed nature. New York's Adirondack State Park is the closest thing to untamed nature anywhere in the Northeastern United States. Conservationists therefore believe that wolves and the Adirondacks would make a perfect match. Further studies will be necessary to determine whether their instincts are right. But if they are, the Eastern timber wolf -- fangs and all -- should be given a warm welcome.

title: The Instant Family
description: Instead of being with my family in Delaware as planned, I was spending a miserable Thanksgiving Day stuck in

title: HAZING DAYS
description: Having been both a fraternity member and, later, alumni president of my chapter, I can say that your photo essay graphically addresses the side of fraternity life that, thanks to efforts like yours, is presumed by many to be the only justification for their existence. I will not deny that abuses occur, nor will I attempt to excuse them. However, it is my experience that successful efforts have been under way for some time, on the part of college administrators, national fraternity organizations, insurance companies and undergraduates themselves, to curb abuses and to adapt fraternities to the expectations of college life in the 1990's.

title: Who Could Not Have Known of the Holocaust?
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton Eating
description: To the Editor: As a 10-year resident, I can attest that Susan Spano selected many of the highlights of Princeton. But she missed some of my favorite culinary hotspots.

title: Changing Patterns of Commuting
description: IN the spring, employees of the Philip Morris Capital Corporation will be transferred to Stamford from the Westchester County offices of Philip Morris International. That's to make room for Kraft Food International, another Philip Morris subsidiary, which is leaving White Plains for the Rye Brook location, explained K. Richmond Temple, a spokesman for Philip Morris Capital.

title: Help Wanted: Coaches Go To and Fro
description: THE chairs are out there on the dance floor, but the music won't start for another six weeks.

title: A Stick Figure: Twiggy
description: There was a time when dinosaurs walked the earth. You could usually find them in the kitchen. They had curvy bodies and fleshy, deliciously rounded arms and shoulders, and you could hear them coming by the reassuring lcick, click, click of their heels. They were skilled in the Stone Age arts of ironing and medning and comforting their young. They wore red lipstick, spent hours filing their nails and had hair made of an unmangeable substance that had to be cleaned and curled by professionals. Their pointy brasand prehistoric girdles created artificial shapes withtiny midsections, but under theirshirt-waist dresses their bodies were natural, built for hugging and for eating homemade gingersnaps right off the cookie sheet. Back in the land before time, when big breasts were more important than thin thighs, the ideal woman was an hourglass with wavy hair, a pretty name and a nurturing soul, a woman as sexy as Marilyn and as demure as Jacqueline. It was 1967.

title: For Downtown Traffic, Growing Pains May Turn Critical
description: During a typical evening rush hour at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, the traffic police wrestle with cars backed up for six blocks. All around them, the area is teeming with office workers heading home, parents buying groceries and teen-agers cruising. It is evidence that Downtown Brooklyn is outgrowing itself.

title: More Splendors
description: To the Editor: The report ''Pharaohs' Treasures in Houston'' in Travel Advisory (Sept. 15) was misleading in saying that ''this is the first time the Pelizaeus Museum has permitted such an extensive selection of its objects to be shown outside Germany.'' The exhibition, ''Splendors of Ancient Egypt,'' had its premiere at the Florida International Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla. Houston was the second stop.

title: Artful Premises, Tapas and More
description: BARCELONA, one of our favorite cities in Spain, has now lent its name to a wine bar in South Norwalk, and indeed the tiny spot more than deserves a rating of Good; in fact, it's verging on Very Good, showing infinite promise as a fun spot. A hole in the wall it isn't, though the space is minuscule. Artful design creates a fashionable atmosphere of black walls and ceiling with metal ductwork and pipes exposed, copper-hued leather banquettes and a long bar opposite high-style stools and tables.

title: Rwanda's Past Again Vies to Be Prologue
description: JEAN VATILI has never felt so powerless. He returned to Rwanda last week along with hundreds of thousands of other Hutu refugees and, like many others, found that his property had been confiscated by Tutsi immigrants.

title: The Swan: Anna Pavlova
description: One of the first biographies I ever read was about Anna Pavlova. When I was 11, I took it out of the library, just before seriously beginning my own study of ballet. Even the name of this woman born half a world away had an enchanted quality to it: the two v's were winged water birds, and the word ''love'' -- slightly in disguise, altered by an a -- also made an appearance. Her story gripped me, of course. The legendary prima ballerina was born in St. Petersburg in 1881 during the cold whiteness of a Russian winter. When she was 8, her mother took her to a performance of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' and Anna experienced an epiphany -- a baptism by ballet. This and only this was what she wanted to do with her life, and two years later she was admitted to the Imperial School of Ballet. Her exceptional gifts were immediately visible, and after graduating, at 18, she made her company debut in a pas de trois in ''La Fille Mal Gardee''; she never danced in the corps de ballet.

title: Corrections
description: A table with the Behind the Wheel column in the Automobiles section last Sunday misstated the type of engine in the Volkswagen GTI VR6. It is a V6, not an in-line 4.

title: Empty Seats
description: Boy, did I open up a can of worms after the film ''Paradise Lost,'' which I co-directed with my partner, Joe Berlinger, bombed at my local theater in Montclair. I wrote a rather harsh letter to my fellow citizens that appeared in The Montclair Times.

title: Best Friend, but Worst Co-Renter
description: Everybody knows the New York apartment market is nightmarishly tight. How could it get any worse?

title: Juggling Family Finances to Optimize College Aid
description: BEFORE any of their three children were in college, Neal and Betsy Boudette of Clifton Park, N.Y., took measures to increase their chances of getting financial aid, steps that included reducing their income and taking money out of their children's names.

title: The Dining in SoHo Is Snug but Worldly
description: ERIZO LATINO *

title: A Lethal Lure for Speeders
description: Two unmarked police cars with radar guns cruised the 1.7-mile stretch of Rockaway Boulevard from Guy R. Brewer to Brookville Boulevard last Saturday night. The glassy strip of blacktop is six lanes wide and unfettered by traffic lights. It was just past 8 P.M. when they clocked a late-model Mercedes sedan doing 75 in the 40-mile-an-hour zone. The driver, a well-dressed Long Island businessman, was arrested for driving with a suspended license and his car was impounded.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE CAR THAT COULD

title: The McCarthy Era
description: In the dead of August in San Diego, not far from the convention center where the Republicans would soon convene to nominate Bob Dole, the mammoth Sam Goody's record emporium is hosting a different sort of convocation. For several hours, hundreds of teen-age boys bearing CD's, posters, hats, shirts and copies of Playboy magazine have lined up, awaiting the arrival of Jenny McCarthy, 1994 Playmate of the Year and co-host of ''Singled Out,'' MTV's campy dating-game show.

title: Mark Trauner, 35, a Top Amateur Golfer
description: Mark Trauner, one of the New York metropolitan area's best amateur golfers in the 1980's, died at his home in Boulder, Colo., last Sunday. He was 35.

title: ADVENTURES OF A REPUBLICAN REVOLUTIONARY
description: Neumann is absolutely right -- the Federal deficit is about ethics and morality, and it is, by far, the biggest problem we face. It weakens the country and exerts a creeping, negative influence on everything we do.

title: Ms. Leibowitz And Mr. Berfond
description: Nanette Leibowitz, the daughter of Ellen Leibowitz of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Dr. Dudley Leibowitz, is to be married today to Jeffrey H. Berfond, the son of Nancy and Sydney Berfond of Brooklyn. Rabbi Alfredo S. Winter is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Teen-Agers and a Baby
description: Not two weeks ago, their lives and dreams stretched before them. Today, they are behind bars, and tomorrow they may be indicted on murder charges.

title: Assisted Living Is Coming, With Health-Care Option
description: AT age 86, W. Howard Chase, a retired professor of international relations at the University of Connecticut, still travels extensively as a private consultant on business management.

title: The Morgan Dynasty, a Football Family From Brielle
description: SONS following fathers onto the playing fields is part of the tradition at the high schools in Manasquan and Point Pleasant, but there has never been anything quite like the Morgan Dynasty.

title: Finding Peace This Season
description: How do you deal with the frenzy of the Christmas season?

title: Ms. Gladstone And Mr. Martin
description: Elizabeth Anne Gladstone, a daughter of Alexandra and Ted S. Gladstone of Greenwich, Conn., was married in New York last evening to David Gary Martin, the son of Arlene Schramm and Anthony A. Martin, both of London. Rabbi Paul Steinberg performed the ceremony at the Union League Club.

title: John Elwood and Courtney Simmons
description: Courtney Simmons, a lawyer in Washington, and John Patrick Elwood, a law clerk to Associate Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court, were married yesterday in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Edna Jacobs Banes performed the ceremony at the Old Presbyterian Meeting House.

title: Q and A
description: Amazon and Machu Picchu

title: THE ANSWER IS NATIONAL STANDARDS
description: While Sara Mosle notes serious problems in public education, the national standards she suggests are not the answer (''The Answer Is National Standards,'' Oct. 27).

title: Surveying Realism in Celebration of Hopper
description: IN the case of ''Realism at 7 A.M.,'' a show by 25 painters that marks the 25th anniversary of the Hopper House Art Center here, nothing is what it seems to be. For one thing, the display is named for ''7 A.M.,'' the master's image of a storefront presumed to be here, but it is anything but Hopper revisited. For another, it is Realism chosen by Richard Milazzo, who, in his catalogue essay, doubts that the mode is up to the task of conveying ''the experience of reality.''

title: Crista B. Demasi, Aaron C. Clark
description: Crista Beth Demasi, a daughter of Janet and Rudolph Demasi of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Aaron Christopher Clark, the son of Nancy and Robert Clark of South Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Highbrow vs. Low
description: To the Editor:

title: Deciding on the Right Staple Gun for Quick Fastening Jobs
description: STAPLERS are useful for quick fastening jobs. They can drive three or more staples in the time it takes to hammer one nail. Staplers can be used to secure fabric, carpet padding, ceiling tile, screening, wire, poster board and weather stripping.

title: With Sugared Tea and Caustic Rules, An Afghan Leader Explains Himself
description: IN the way he receives guests at the old royal palace here, Mullah Mohammed Hassan seems like a kind and generous man, in an out-of-this-century kind of way.

title: Phillips Gallery Buys Its Building
description: Phillips International Fine Art Auctioneers, which last summer was wondering where to go after its lease ran out -- developers had purchased their rented building on East 79th Street and announced plans to rip it down and build a 20-story condominium tower -- has bought the building from the developers.

title: Pirate Owner Promises To Remain in Pittsburgh
description: Skeptics abound in Pittsburgh like rivers and bridges. One faithful fan, in fact, a lawyer, acknowledged last week that he believed he had been the lone holdout, and now he, too, was convinced that the Pirates were on their way out of town.

title: The Brass Tacks of Music, or, Who Needs Hi-Fi?
description: MUSIC WIELDS ITS POWER over mind and heart in strange and multifarious ways. How else to explain certain clarifying moments of discovery, those life-altering encounters with the great works of Brahms or Beethoven scaled down to the meager sound of an old clock radio?

title: Lisa Steinberg, Mark Goldberg
description: Lisa Beth Steinberg, a daughter of Barbara and William Steinberg of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Mark Jay Goldberg, a son of Susan and Leonard Goldberg of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Paul Siegel officiated at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains.

title: HAZING DAYS
description: A sentence in your piece jumped out at me: ''They turn up in shopping-mall Dumpsters, blindfolded and au naturel.''

title: The Voice and the Spirit of Lena Horne
description: LENA Horne has mellowed. The old resentments still crop up (the years on the nightclub circuit that she hated; the indignities she suffered in Hollywood; her reputation as a dazzling but shallow beauty). But at 79, she has reached an age at which acceptance comes more readily. ''I'm not afraid to be old,'' she says.

title: The Intricate Ballet of Plotting a Season
description: THE SIGNS OF A NEW BALLET SEASON were everywhere at Lincoln Center one recent afternoon. Two young soloists with the New York City Ballet headed across the plaza toward the stage door of the New York State Theater, walking with the confident glide of dancers at the refreshed start of the performing year. In the theater lobby, ticket buyers scrutinized the glossy brochure announcing the repertory for the company's fall season. The season opens on Tuesday with what is billed as an ''all-American'' program, featuring a performance of George Balanchine's ''Slaughter on 10th Avenue,'' then moves on to ''The Nutcracker'' before returning to the regular repertory in January.

title: Ted (Don't Fence Me In) Turner
description: FORGET his company's $7.5 billion merger with Time Warner Inc. Forget his war of words with Rupert Murdoch over cable news in New York City. Forget even his Atlanta Braves' flameout in the World Series.

title: THE ANSWER IS NATIONAL STANDARDS
description: I had only to read the title of Sara Mosle's article to know that an adult at last understands the travesty of public education in the United States, and is publicizing a plan that makes sense. As a 15-year-old who has attended public schools all my life, I constantly see classmates, who probably can't spell ''undeserved'' and ''ridiculous,'' get A's.

title: Island's Wines Shine At a Closed Tasting
description: LONG ISLAND winegrowers are old hands at mass tastings in New York City. Since the early 1990's, they have gone to Bridgewaters, at the South Street Seaport, and Windows on the World to pour for hundreds of ticket-buying potential retail customers.

title: The Hunt for the Creature That Ebola Calls Home
description: From the eternal damp of the rain forest floor, where the daytime darkness and the loud chatter of monkeys and birds overhead reinforce a suffocating sense of closeness, Krowah Bleou sets out each day, shimmying up a ladder toward the treetops.

title: The History of Harlem
description: To the Editor:

title: Trinidad Shoots for Redemption, and Cup
description: At Aston Villa of the English Premier League, fans belt out the Sinatra standard ''New York, New York'' and tailor the lyrics to their star forward, singing, ''It's up to you, Dwight Yorke, Dwight Yorke.''

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Love, Lucy

title: Piles of Storied Jewish Books Are Languishing in Lithuania
description: Tens of thousands of rare Hebrew and Yiddish texts lie in dusty heaps in a Roman Catholic church here, desiccated and forgotten. Many date from the 17th and 18th centuries, when this city became an unrivaled center of Jewish intellectual and spiritual innovation.

title: The Echoes Of History Resounding
description: SOME COMPOSERS COMPOSE HISTORY. William Billings, who was born 250 years ago last month, was one of them. The simple, bright voices that sing out from ''A Land of Pure Delight,'' a compact disk of Billings tunes from Harmonia Mundi France, have a brief and fragile charm. They do not live; they are reflections of another life. Archeology and art separate in this repertory.

title: The Margaret Factor
description: It is a truth not universally acknowledged that those whom the gods would destroy they first make great -- and name them Margaret.

title: Ms. Koppelman And Mr. Katz
description: Suzanne Koppelman, a daughter of Sarah L. Koppelman of Tenafly, N.J., and Murray Koppelman of New York, was married last evening to Richard Allan Katz, a son of Thea and Henry Katz of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Amy Ehrlich officiated in the Pegasus Suites at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Hundreds Call Government Phone Line to Ask About Air Bags
description: As more people have grown concerned about whether the air bags designed to keep them safe in a car crash could accidentally kill them, the Department of Transportation has been flooded with phone calls from people seeking safety advice.

title: Police Arrest 70 at a Queens Brothel So Bold That Employees Handed Out Fliers on the Street
description: Trying to curtail both the supply and the demand for prostitution in Jackson Heights, Queens, investigators carried out a two-pronged raid yesterday that led to the arrests of 70 people in a Roosevelt Avenue brothel so brazen that its employees handed out fliers on street corners, the police said.

title: Suits Accuse Dominican Ex-President of Misdeeds
description: During seven terms as President, Joaquin Balaguer often seemed invincible to his countrymen. But now, barely three months after leaving office, he is a target of three lawsuits that accuse him of misappropriating at least $740 million in Government funds and ordering the killing of two opponents.

title: Heroine Worship: The Age of the female icon.
description: It's the 90's, and the pantheon we've built to house the women in our minds is getting crowded. Elizabeth Taylor, Eleanor Roosevelt, Oprah Winfrey, Alanis Morissette, Indira Gandhi, Claudia Schiffer, Coco Chanel, Doris Day, Aretha Franklin, Jackie Onassis, Rosa Parks -- they're all there, the dead and the living side by side, contemporaneous in our imaginations. On television and in the movies, in advertising and magazines, their images are scattered across the landscape of our everyday lives. Their presence is sometimes decorative, sometimes uplifting, occasionally infuriating. The criteria for appointment to this ad hoc hall of fame that takes up so much space in our thoughts and in our culture may at first glance appear to be utterly random. In fact, irrespective of their achievements, most of these women have been apotheosized primarily on the basis of their ability to appeal to our fantasies.

title: North, South, East and West, Women's Game Gaining Fans
description: The sweep by the United States team to the Olympic gold medal in Atlanta gave more people the opportunity to take notice of women's basketball. Now the college season is starting -- a few big games have already been played -- and the fire continues being stoked.

title: Sinn Fein Says I.R.A. Might Renew Cease-Fire
description: In its most positive statement in months on the Northern Ireland peace effort, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said today that it could persuade the I.R.A. to restore its cease-fire if Prime Minister John Major of Britain agreed to allow Sinn Fein to take part in peace talks, which have been stalled for nearly six months.

title: Replacing a District 14 Mainstay
description: The death of Mario DeStefano, the superintendent and former teachers union leader in District 14, has left his deputy temporarily in charge and the district school board looking for a permanent replacement.

title: Drawn to Gospel, if Not Gospels, Foreigners Arrive by Busload
description: Almost 200 white tourists, most of them Europeans, had been standing outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem for 45 minutes on a recent Sunday morning when one of the three ushers in charge of crowd control broke the bad news.

title: In the Park, a Friendship Outlives Flight 800
description: Judith Yee, a longtime West Village resident, will finally be laid to rest.

title: Abecedarians, Take Note: Classes Multiply
description: NOTHING, it appears, is sacrosanct anymore.
