title: Some Spicy Meatball: Sophia Loren
description: Forget Venus and Mona Lisa. La Bella Sophia may well be Italy's most breathtaking work of art. First, there's her amazing body -- the anatomy of perfect abbondanza(ital). Then there's the face -- not traditionally beautiful, yet as strong as espresso, and brimming with wondrous contradictions: Neapolitan eyes that flash as much with intelligence as with indignation, too-generous lips that curve as much with humor as with desire.

title: Ms. Sequeira, And Dr. Sayan
description: Annmarie Sequeira, a clinical case manager at Elizabeth (N.J.) General Medical Center, was married yesterday to Dr. Osman Rafael Sayan, an internist in the emergency room at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. Msgr. Richard A. Behl performed the ceremony at St. Francis Cathedral in Metuchen, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the political effects of global economic forces referred incorrectly to the originator of the idea of ''imagined communities,'' referring to the conceptions people have of nationhood. He is Benedict Anderson, professor of government at Cornell University; the mention of Benedict Arnold was inadvertent.

title: Always the First Lady: Eleanor Roosevelt
description: I unbuttoned Eleanor Roosevelt's dress. I was very nervous, though she did her best to make it easy for me.

title: His Humble Pie Is Full of Chutzpah
description: It was a testament to his catlike political instincts that Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco was able to find a bright side last week to the local uproar over his withering verbal attack on the backup quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers, Elvis Grbac.

title: That's the Ticket
description: To the Editor:

title: Drivers Have to Watch Out For Riders Who Don't Care
description: To the Editor:

title: What Price Progress? Battle Lines Drawn in the Watershed
description: Last month's Planning Board meeting in this quiet, wooded town didn't figure to draw more than the usual crowd of five. It was, after all, the night of Game 2 of the World Series between the Yankees and the Braves.

title: Slippery Slope
description: Seduced by DeathDoctors, Patients, and the Dutch Cure.By Herbert Hendin.256 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $27.50.

title: Team Full of Veterans Leaves Rangers Few Options for 'Adjustments'
description: Despite their poor record, the Rangers try hard, even as they lose most of their games. Despite holding only the 22d-best winning percentage in the 26-team National Hockey League going into last night, they aren't blaming each other or their coach.

title: Memories Of Roseland
description: To the Editor:

title: Mean Business Is Sad Business
description: IT'S hard to believe, but Albert J. Dunlap, the chairman and chief executive of the Sunbeam Corporation, seems to have outdone himself this time. In announcing work-force cuts of more than 50 percent at Sunbeam almost two weeks ago, ''Chainsaw Al,'' as he is known, exceeded even the Draconian expectations that he had created for himself in previous slash-and-burn efforts at Scott Paper, Diamond International and Lily-Tulip.

title: Ethiopian Fold Art Thrives in Israel
description: ADDIS ABABA, 1976. It was the plain charm of the black pottery gazelle high up on a back shelf of the shop that made me reach for it. But when I turned it over in my palm I was amazed to find a Star of David deeply etched on its back. I had wanted to visit the Ethiopian Jews in Gondar, but a war was going on, and the closest I got to Gondar was that sculpture of the gazelle, which I took home with me and have treasured ever since.

title: Taking Sides in the Superstore Fight
description: Even as the political battle over the future of superstores in New York City grew heated and occasionally rancorous last week, executives at Price Costco, a major name in warehouse stores, congratulated themselves for opening two new stores in Brooklyn and Queens, where sales easily matched expectations.

title: Hardiness Wins Elms An Honor
description: THE Agricultural Research Service, part of the United States Department of Agriculture, recently announced one of its biggest awards, and the winners were trees. In the long quest to find American elm trees resistant to the deadly Dutch elm disease fungus, two new varieties, Valley Forge and New Harmony, have been found worthy of introduction.

title: An India Less Than Congenial
description: A COUPLE of years ago, two strikingly beautiful Indian women brought home to an ecstatic nation the titles of Miss World and Miss Universe, a double first. The country went wild. A Hollywood-style superstar cum political hobnobber, Amitabh Bachchan, took the next step. Why stop at titles? he asked. Bring the whole spectacle here . Last week, before the finals of the Miss World competition in Bangalore, India's high-technology city, he was upbeat. Show them we can do it, he said. Who knows? The Olympics might be next.

title: Jane Schwartz and Steve Kantor
description: AMONG her friends, Jane Schwartz is known as the best tennis player and, by far, the most particular about love. Although she used to go out so often she was nicknamed ''the blind date queen,'' she rejected suitors the way the soup man on ''Seinfeld'' rejects customers: the smallest detail could disqualify them.

title: In Japan, Old Problem Undermines New Leader
description: As Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto tries to press ahead with his campaign for deregulation, his new Government's credibility is under attack because of two corruption scandals.

title: The Voice of America: Kate Smith
description: In 1942, a nationwide poll listed the three most popular women in America as Eleanor Roosevelt, Helen Hayes and Kate Smith. Three years earlier the Roosevelts summoned Smith to the White House to sing for the King and Queen of England, and introduced her simply with, ''Your majesties, this is Kate Smith. This is America.'' Yet who remembers Kate Smith today? Mainly grandmothers with first names that barely exist -- names like Mabel, Gertrude and Edna.

title: Skin Games
description: INDIAN KILLER

title: Mismanaged Care
description: Health Against Wealth

title: Knocking on the Door: A Tree-Eating Beetle That Will Stay for Dinner
description: George Koeck wasn't frightened until he saw the pictures.

title: If Not Us, Them
description: The decision by President Clinton to keep U.S. troops in Bosnia for another 18 months should be called ''Operation I Really Mean It This Time.''

title: Valerie Breier, Peter Weitzner
description: Valerie Kaye Breier, a daughter of Leah and Harvey Breier of New York, was married last evening to Peter Daniel Weitzner, the son of Sylvia Schonberg of New York and Martin Weitzner of New Orleans. Rabbi Brooks R. Susman performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence, L.I.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: COMING OF AGE: The Story of Our Century

title: When the Marching Ends, Career Paths Hit Barriers
description: MEN and women who must search for jobs after leaving the armed services will probably face more heartache and disappointment than they encountered in military life. Unfortunately, most of these men and women, particularly from the enlisted ranks, lack the necessary skills for job-hunting in the civilian work force.

title: Keeper of a Hallowed Broadway Tradition
description: OPENING night for a Broadway musical guarantees two things -- a full house and Gloria Rosenthal of Valley Stream. Mrs. Rosenthal has been to so many Broadway theaters on opening night that she has lost count.

title: Life at Sea
description: A LONG VOYAGE HOME (1940) with John Wayne (above, with Ward Bond), Thomas Mitchell, Ian Hunter, Wilfrid Lawson, Barry Fitzgerald and Mildred Natwick is John Ford's briny masterwork, expanded from four short plays by Eugene O'Neill about the crew of a small transatlantic cargo freighter during the early years of World War I. Superbly photographed and played, the result is flowing, moving cinema with no hint of stage boards. The hearty crew and a lovely saloon cameo by Mildred Natwick bring it to life memorably. Ship to shore, the four dramatic vignettes are linked by the haunting little ballad, ''Harbor Lights'' - SATURDAY at 3 P.M. on BRAVO.

title: Popular TV Show Helps Enliven a Neighborhood
description: As Sharon Bondroff walked home one day in the spring, she was horrified to see a man lying on the sidewalk and another man standing over him, pointing a gun. A police officer stood at the corner, apparently oblivious to the scene behind him. Ms. Bondroff raced over.

title: High Schools Get Less Aid Than Elementary and Middle Ones
description: The superintendents who oversee New York City's elementary and middle schools have long complained that the city's sprawling high schools soaked up a disproportionate share of precious education dollars.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 6/

title: Lauren Kaskel, Randolph Slifka
description: Lauren Anne Kaskel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kaskel of New York, was married last evening to Randolph Watkins Slifka, a son of Jacqueline W. Slifka and Alan B. Slifka, both of New York. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony at Roseland in New York.

title: The Unmistakable: Katharine Hepburn
description: ''Hello, Dexter'' (spoken warily). ''Hello, Gawdge'' (spoken disapprovingly). ''Hello, Mike'' (spoken breathlessly). Only one voice does one hear -- only one face does one see. It could never be otherwise.

title: The Fairest of Them All: Elizabeth Taylor
description: She has lately stepped gracefully down a few notches from her pedestal, but her image is in fact indelible, and she's earned the right to a certain voluntary eclipse. Now in her middle 60's, an age at which Marlene Dietrich was still appearing nightly in sequins and feathers, mesmerizing live audiences in Las Vegas, Elizabeth Taylor is a select apparition, visible only here and there.

title: Hospitals Press for Expansion of Organ Transplant Units
description: With managed health care putting increasing pressure on hospitals to be more competitive, six New Jersey hospitals have applied to open new programs for heart, liver and kidney transplants.

title: Nativism, U.S.-Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Meridel Le Sueur, 96, Reporter And Children's Book Writer
description: Meridel Le Sueur, who reported on the plight of the poor during the Depression and celebrated the free spirits of early Americans in her fiction for children, died on Nov. 14 in Hudson Memorial Hospital in Hudson, Wis. She was 96 and had lived in the hospital's residential unit in nearby St. Paul, Minn., for the last few years.

title: A Refreshing Stop for Weary Shoppers
description: THE shop-till-you-drop crowd will be off and running this Friday. With Thanksgiving a bit late, Hanukkah coming early and Christmas just around the corner, the panic will be on.

title: Travel Videos
description: To the Editor: Being a travel video fan (I often amuse myself with borrowed library tapes while on the treadmill), I enjoyed reading the article on video guides.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: RACING

title: What Can Be Learned Outside Textbooks
description: To the Editor:

title: Audrey Hepburn: The Thoroughbred
description: Everyone was in love with this beautiful gazelle of an actress, but none of her qualities -- innocence, freshness, unspoiled charm, grace, aristocratic bearing -- seem to entirely explain her popularity. Certainly not innocence, since she often played rather sophisticated and knowing young women, like Holly Golightly. The fresh beauty that everyone responded to was not quite it, either. Elegance comes closer -- that joyous lightness of touch and piquant slenderness that contrasted so tellingly with the heavier, more voluptuous Marilyn, Lana or Ava.

title: Why One Flight 800 Theory Fit All
description: THE wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 was still a tangled mess on the floor of the Atlantic Ocean, but in many quarters the verdict was already in: This was Lockerbie off Long Island.

title: Flogging Books With the Duchess
description: IT was a spin machine that left no stone unturned.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Shoreham nuclear plant misstated the interest accruing on a $1.1 billion tax judgment against Suffolk County, the Town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham-Wading River School District. The daily amount is $188,000, not $1 million.

title: Equity Offerings That Are Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Bridge
description: Two major titles were decided Saturday at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in San Francisco.

title: Prosecutor Goes Against Tide in Going After Kevorkian
description: Raymond Voet, the prosecutor in this small and mostly rural county in western Michigan, had just come back from his usual lunchtime jog with the sheriff to receive a call from the Medical Examiner's office.

title: 32 Works of Art by Masters Left to Met and the Modern
description: Florene May Schoenborn, a department store heiress who became a passionate collector of modern art, bequeathed 32 works by masters like Picasso, Brancusi, Bonnard and Braque to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art. Mrs. Schoenborn died in August 1995 at the age of 92.

title: Strengthening New Yorkers' Rights
description: Constitutional provisions safeguarding individual rights do not mean much if people are prevented from seeking meaningful redress when their basic liberties are violated. That is the driving principle behind last week's ruling by New York's highest court, the Court of Appeals. The ruling opens the door for people to seek monetary damages from state government for violating their rights under the State Constitution.

title: What the Allies Knew
description: The revelation that British cryptologists had deciphered reports of mass executions of Jews in German-occupied areas of the Soviet Union as early as June 1941 -- seven months before the Nazis instituted the Final Solution -- is being denounced as a scandal of some sort. The question is, what sort?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: YEVGENY YEVTUSHENKO, 63, who draws a weekly audience of 15 million for his poetry show on Russian television, is promising a ''strange lecture'' hereabouts next week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Currency System To Readmit the Italian Lira

title: Charges in Flag Incident
description: Normally, Ocean City detectives said, the act of taking down the American flag flying outside Ocean City High School and substituting a Confederate flag would be considered a prank. But because racial tensions at the school have been growing this year, the two students arrested last Friday for the flag-switching have been charged with theft and disorderly conduct and the incident will be prosecuted as a bias crime, the police said.

title: Trenton-Camden Trains
description: A proposal to run passenger trains between Trenton and Camden for the first time since the 1960's comes up for a vote tomorrow. New Jersey Transit's board of directors is scheduled to vote on a measure to begin engineering studies and solicit bids on a contract to design and build the light-rail project, which would run on 53 miles of track that runs from Trenton to Camden and then swings east to Glassboro. The service would connect with the Northeast Corridor line, which currently runs from New York to Trenton.

title: A Drive to the Mall to Shop on Line (Huh?)
description: A mall would seem the least likely place to shop on the Internet for skirts, shorts and parkas. After all, a computer image can hardly compare with miles of racked and shelved clothes that can be touched for quality and tried on for comfort.

title: People
description: * Judd Harner was named to the new post of client services director at Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York. He had been an account director at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, New York, a unit of Havas Advertising.

title: Opposition Builds To Ads for Liquor
description: The uproar is intensifying over the decision by the distilled spirits industry to lift its voluntary ban on advertising on television and radio, as some prominent opponents step up their efforts to prohibit liquor commercials.

title: Palestinians Rely on Israel's Economic Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * SFGT Advertising, Philadelphia, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $9 million: West Coast Entertainment, Philadelphia, to handle advertising for the video retailer, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis, and Ryder Move Management, Miami, a unit of Ryder TRS Inc., to handle advertising for the relocation company, whose account had been at HMS Partners, Miami.

title: Above the video game combat, Mario, the Everyman, grasps for immortality.
description: I AM balancing on the red point of a giant arrow, sweeping through space, waiting for the right moment to leap over a precipice. I have reached this dizzying point by climbing over blocks that continually turn like cogs in a giant mechanism. I even managed to get past a huge pendulum sweeping across my path, which looked like a Crayola version of Edgar Allan Poe's horrific blade.

title: After Nintendo's victory, more Japanese companies may say they'd rather fight than pay.
description: JAPANESE companies have long had a reputation of being quick to sign licensing agreements with American patent holders. Worried that American juries might hand out multimillion-dollar awards in patent infringement suits, many Japanese concerns have preferred to avoid possible litigation by paying hundreds of thousands of dollars in fees for patents that may be of dubious merit.

title: Some second thoughts about whether and how to use chat sites on the Internet as a marketplace.
description: ADVERTISERS for the most part have either ignored on-line ''chat'' or poked fun at the phenomenon. For instance, a print advertisement for Sauza tequila mockingly chides: ''You have a great sex life. On the Internet.'' And a print ad for Dewar's Scotch confides, ''It's not so much the 'chat room' as it is the sitting-home-alone-by-yourself part that concerns us.''

title: No Blind Eye
description: President Suharto of Indonesia must have reckoned that the world would soon forget about his occupation of East Timor. It is a small far-away place, half an island 300 miles north of Australia. Distant governments would surely conclude that there was no practical way to make him disgorge his conquest.

title: Coke Replaces Pepsi As Grammy Sponsor
description: The Coca-Cola Company has signed a multiyear agreement to become the exclusive soft-drink sponsor for the annual Grammy Awards ceremonies, covering advertising, marketing and promotional activities. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Broken Bars on Drawbridge Are Blamed in Amtrak Crash
description: Federal investigators said last night that an Amtrak train derailed on a swing bridge in New Jersey on Saturday because a rupture of two small plates left two connecting rails piggybacked, one atop another, instead of end to end.

title: The Bells Want F.C.C. to Make Providers Share Internet Costs
description: Depending on whom you believe, Pacific Telesis has either stumbled across the first evidence of a potentially disastrous breakdown in the nation's telephone network or is being cynically alarmist to further its regulatory agenda.

title: Michael Jackson's 'HIStory' shows the growing stature of global marketing.
description: WHO had the last laugh in the Michael Jackson ''HIStory'' debacle?

title: Child-Abuse Panel Urges Looser Secrecy Laws
description: A year after the death of Elisa Izquierdo at the hands of her mother led to the loosening of secrecy laws in child abuse cases, a state panel has recommended easing those laws even further to aid investigators and prosecutors.

title: Clinton and Chinese President Agree to Exchange State Visits
description: Despite deep and unresolved differences, President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China agreed today to exchange state visits over the next two years. They would be the first such extended meetings between their nations since the massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen Square in 1989.

title: Big Stores Have Lower Prices, Mayor Says
description: Trying to demonstrate the benefits of superstores, the Giuliani administration released the results of a survey yesterday that it said showed large supermarkets had better prices than smaller grocers.

title: Parts Makers for Interactive TV Languish
description: When Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television operator, announced the suspension of most of its new hardware orders last month, it was a loss of face for the cable giant.

title: Dime Bancorp Unit Is Moving to Florida
description: Dime Bancorp Inc. said Friday that it would move its mortgage lending operations to Tampa, Fla., as the New York City-based savings institution prepares to expand its business nationally.

title: Terror in the Air, and Frantic Rescue From the Sea
description: When two passengers burst out of their seats and ran up the gangway to the cockpit, Hiwot Tadesse, a flight attendant, thought they were having a fight. When a third followed them, holding something in his gloved hands, she knew the plane was being hijacked.

title: Behind the Masks, More Enigmas
description: LONDON  Everything seemed straightforward about Chinese history as we used to think of it, beginning with the ascent of the Shang dynasty some time in the 15th century B.C. and gradually leading to the fusion of the rival states of China into a single empire.The neat construction has now crashed.

title: Hong Kong Putting on a Brave 'Face'
description: HONG KONG  There is a lot of "face" being practiced in Hong Kong seven months ahead of the 1997 transition. Not just the ancient Chinese custom relating to respect, but a very brave face on the populace masking nerves over the transition.

title: Croatia's Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Star Who Charted Her Own Course
description: Back in the segregated 1940's, a white youngster's impressions of black people were likely to be formed by Tarzan movies and the occasional documentary featuring ''savages'' going through exotic rituals in ''darkest Africa.'' Then, in 1943, came two all-black movies, ''Cabin in the Sky'' and ''Stormy Weather,'' and suddenly the days of the film industry's racist claptrap, intentional or unthinking, were numbered. A star in both of those films was Lena Horne. She has been an even bigger star, indeed an American treasure, ever since. Deservedly so.

title: E.P.A. ADVOCATING HIGHER STANDARDS TO CLEAN THE AIR
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is recommending tighter national standards for emissions of the chemicals and particles that form smog and soot, some of the most pervasive and unhealthy forms of air pollution.

title: A Riddle: What Is Catholic, Jewish and Stateless?
description: In 1990, Regina and Alexander Deriev and their son, Denis, took advantage of the new religious freedoms in the Soviet Union and were baptized into the Roman Catholic Church. In 1991, they immigrated to Israel.

title: Oversight Committee Needs Burton at the Helm
description: To the Editor:

title: TLC Settles Suit, Setting Aside a Troubling Use of Bankruptcy
description: Members of the rhythm-and-blues group TLC and lawyers for LaFace Records and Pebbitone Inc., which brought the group to public attention in the early 1990's, signed a settlement this weekend, ending a yearlong battle over how the fruits of TLC's success should be divided.

title: Wide-Open Electronic Spaces
description: Ensemble 21 began its concert on Thursday at the Miller Theater by presenting three composers who have been associated with the Institute for Acoustic-Musical Research and Coordination in Paris, a connection that gradually came into view as the works became more electronic.

title: Time Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey via E-Mail? Is Nothing Spared?
description: Computer users can harvest a world of information about Thanksgiving on the World Wide Web, with sites ranging from the picture-book ideal of the holiday to the business that it can create.

title: Sampras Bests Becker in a Classic Duel
description: Boris Becker's final gale-force backhand struck the net, and Pete Sampras threw both arms wearily in the air and staggered in the general direction of his coach, Paul Annacone.

title: Magazine Guides That Help the Surfers
description: The competition among Web magazines is turning into a demolition derby.

title: Texas Meeting Seeks A Rebirth of Populism
description: In 1877, a group of poor and angry farmers gathered in the hill country of Texas, vowing to fight the banks, railroads and other ''monied interests.'' It was the spark that set off the Populist movement, a network of cooperatives and political action that grew into one of the largest democratic insurgencies in the nation's history.

title: Flutie Audition Is Cup Victory
description: For the past seven seasons, Doug Flutie has kept Canadian Football League scoreboards percolating. He is the fourth-leading passer in league history with 35,850 yards. He has won five most valuable player awards.

title: State Courts to Close
description: Except for appeals and emergencies, state courts will be shut down this week while judges go back to school. The 21st annual Judicial College offers the state's 440 judges in the supreme, superior and administrative law courts refresher courses on topics ranging from opinion writing to intellectual property rights to child sexual abuse, said Richard Saks, chief of judicial education for the state's Administrative Office of the Courts. Temporary courtrooms will be set up at the college for hearings on urgent matters, and judges will still be on call to set bail, Mr. Saks said. ANDY NEWMAN

title: From Captivity in North Korea to Success in Hollywood
description: It sounds like a James Bond film.

title: Not the Usual Farewell: Editors Quit and Are Sued
description: Editors come and editors go, and when the three unhappy stars of Orchard Books quit three months ago to start a new imprint at another publishing house, it seemed to be just one more realignment in an industry that is losing old loyalties by the minute. Some authors would follow them, if business proceeded in the usual way. Some wouldn't.

title: Babel's Wife Recalls With Sorrow
description: AT HIS SIDE

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a proposal to overhaul the Compuserve Corporation referred imprecisely to H & R Block's plans for its 80.1 percent stake in the company. While Block intends to shed the holding, it has not decided whether to do so through a sale, through a spinoff to shareholders or by some other means.

title: Problem Isn't Superstores, But Silly Laws
description: LISTENING to New York City's pitched debate over superstores is like having to listen to post-election debates between Bill Clinton and Bob Dole. It seems a little irrelevant.

title: Patrolling the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Clinton Foresees Role in Welfare Overhaul
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has suggested that she wants a ''formal role'' in monitoring how the new welfare law is carried out. But she and the White House have made it clear that any such effort will be nothing like the role she played in drafting health care legislation three years ago.

title: Rate Cuts Revive Ailing Stock Markets
description: SHANGHAI  Only a few months ago, China's domestic stock markets were languishing. Poor performance and low volume in the country's two stock exchanges combined with an apparent policy-making logjam in Beijing left investors and brokers doubtful of the markets' future.

title: Agency Struggles to Meet the Demand for a Sacred Treasure
description: As a closed circuit camera scanned for intruders, Dennis Wiist swung open a heavy vault door to reveal his sacred treasure: rows of plastic bags, each suspended by a meat hook, each containing one frozen eagle.

title: Knicks Hold a Showdown But Just Barely Show Up
description: The problem, as Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy sees it, is lack of resolve and tenacity. John Starks and Larry Johnson believe it can be attributed to the old Knicks not wanting to step on the tender toes of the new Knicks.

title: Decoding What 'Screen-Agers' Think About TV
description: Douglas Rushkoff, paid channeler of the mindset of Generation X, was telling a roomful of television people at Discovery Communications how to make hit shows.

title: Lebedtime Story
description: The Russian general, standing ramrod stiff in a business suit, waved aside another plate of American food. ''Bread, salt and onions,'' he requested.

title: Cowboys' Offense Runs as Smith Sits
description: In the final quarter of the Cowboys' 20-6 loss to the Giants today, Emmitt Smith was sitting on the bench. Alone. While the Cowboys' offensive unit was on the field.

title: Child With Inner Jaguar In a 60's Dreamscape
description: The line between fur and flesh isn't the only blurred distinction in ''Juan Darien,'' Julie Taymor and Elliot Goldenthal's cosmic puppet show about a jaguar cub that turns into a baby boy. In this dark, liturgical pageant of transformations, which opened at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center last night, states of reality and forms of existence bleed like bright silks in hot water.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Vegetarian Bus Driver Wins Some Lettuce
description: A bus driver in Orange County, California, who was dismissed for refusing to pass out promotional coupons for free hamburgers because of his strongly held beliefs as a vegetarian, has accepted a $50,000 settlement from the county transit authority.

title: INSIDE
description: Refugees Emerge in Zaire

title: Reduced H.M.O. Fees Cause Concern About Patient Care
description: After signing up large numbers of New York doctors and establishing a seemingly unshakable position here, health maintenance organizations are radically changing the way they pay physicians and have begun to reduce reimbursements.

title: Interfaith's Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Surveys Manila Bay: What, No Corncob Pipe?
description: Bill Clinton came into office self-conscious about the military, his salutes less than crisp and his interest in foreign affairs sporadic at best. All that has long since changed, his aides insist, pointing to Mr. Clinton's new reputation in Asia as the President who sent carriers into the Taiwan Strait this year as a warning to China.

title: Robitaille Is Unhappy With His Ice Time
description: While losing most of their games this season, the Rangers have been remarkably free of rancor. The players haven't complained in public about ice time or line combinations or overall strategy.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about a jump in the shares of Bausch & Lomb Inc. referred incorrectly to comments about the company by Philp Foreman, a money manager at Composite Research and Management. He said Bausch & Lomb might be a takeover candidate; he did not say Johnson & Johnson might be a buyer.

title: Train Service Resumes, With Delays
description: All of Amtrak's service and most of New Jersey Transit's operations were restored yesterday, officials for the railroads said, but delays of 45 minutes or more were reported.

title: Miscellany
description: * David Pearson Associates, Coral Gables, Fla., a public relations agency specializing in travel accounts, agreed to merge with another public relations agency, Rubin Barney & Birger, Coral Gables. Terms were not disclosed. Pearson's five employees will join Rubin Barney as the Pearson Group.

title: Hold Applause, People
description: To the Editor:

title: Weapons Against Sex Crime
description: The man who pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting and killing Amanda Wengert, 6, in 1994 had a history of peering into houses to watch children, but the authorities did not know about it until after Amanda, of Manalapan Township, was killed. A bill scheduled to be voted on in the State Senate today would make it easier for the police and prosecutors to track such behavior, which experts believe can be an indicator of future, more serious crimes.

title: A Chance To Escape The Streets
description: Two high school basketball stars hope to escape from war-zone neighborhoods and bleak futures through their ability on the court. Sound familiar? No, it's not ''Hoop Dreams,'' last year's much-praised documentary about two Chicago basketball players, but ''L.A. Champions.''

title: Justice, Klieg Lights, the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Felon Obsessed With Spotlight
description: When he was not on his Slim-Fast liquid diet, Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. would occasionally leave his office here for lunch, with his aides in tow. In those years, before he became famous as the fugitive former prosecutor who provoked an international manhunt after fleeing house arrest on Nov. 18, he was a local celebrity here, the self-proclaimed toughest county prosecutor in New Jersey.

title: President of Belarus Pushes Referendum to Expand Power
description: Defying the West, East European nations and his own Parliament, President Aleksandr Lukashenko went ahead today with a referendum on giving himself near-absolute power.

title: Clinton's Chinese Counterpart: A Weak Old Panda?
description: President Clinton can certainly sympathize with Jiang Zemin.

title: Japan's Newest Young Heartthrobs Are Sexy, Talented and Virtual
description: Shiori Fujisaki is a 17-year-old high school junior with long reddish hair and dreamy eyes who is about to release her first record. Shingo Hagiwara is a 21-year-old college sophomore who idolizes her. He goes to nearly every event at which she appears and has bought calendars, posters, watches and mugs with her picture on them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: 2 Die as Woman Hurls Children and Herself Off Bronx Building
description: A 23-year-old woman threw her three children from the roof of her 14-story apartment building in the Bronx yesterday morning and then jumped to her death, the police said. Doctors worked frantically last night to save two of the children, who remarkably survived the fall.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Himalayas Offer Clue to Legend of Gold-Digging 'Ants'
description: The fabulous tale of the giant ''ants'' that dug up gold in a far-off El Dorado and enriched the Persian Empire has circulated for some 2,500 years. Historians have variously recorded it as fact, mocked it as extravagant and passed it along the ancient grapevine.

title: Jets Come Up With Footage for a Horror Film
description: Before the game was 10 minutes old, the Jets' season seemed to flash before them like some out-of-control replay: the little plays that became big mistakes, the blown chances, the defensive lapses. In short, a microcosm of the reason the Jets were to fall to 1-11.

title: Litmus Test Is Next In Giants' Laboratory
description: YOU can't run with it or pass it or catch it. You can't tackle it or block it. But you know when you have it. And you know when you don't have it.

title: Giants Find Reason in Reeves's Rhyme and Dismantle the Cowboys
description: Early this week, Giants Coach Dan Reeves did something that has not been done much before, if ever, in the macho world of pro football. He read a poem to his team.

title: Charge Taken For Acquisition
description: Computer Associates International Inc. said Friday that it would take a third-quarter charge of $598 million, or $1.60 a share, for its $1.19 billion acquisition of Cheyenne Software Inc.

title: Rape as Public Problem, Not Just Effect of War
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: CHRONICLE
description: Kissing goodbye to sweet 16 may be sweet sorrow for some teen-agers, but for HILARY HAHN, it's going to be a gala farewell.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a rise in uncovered short sales on the New York Stock Exchange -- shares of stock that have been borrowed and sold but not yet covered by repurchase -- misstated an increase in such positions in Columbia/HCA Healthcare. They rose 4 percent when taking into account a 3-for-2 stock split that increased the number of the company's shares by 50 percent. The rise was not 56 percent.

title: Justice, Klieg Lights, the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Terence Donovan, 60, Society Photographer
description: Terence Donovan, a London truck driver's son who became an eminent fashion and society photographer whose subjects included Margaret Thatcher and the Princess of Wales, was found dead at his studio in West London on Friday. He was 60 and lived in London.

title: Even the Bills' Fans Have Their Worries
description: WE loaded the bus at the terminal in this city's desolate downtown.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about magazine publishers' practice of lending their brand names to other products misstated the title of Efrem Zimbalist 3d, a Times Mirror executive. He is chief executive of the company's magazine division, not of the parent company.

title: Union Leader Is Indicted
description: A leader of a union that represents 800 Essex County employees was indicted on charges that he beat a supervisor at the county-run mental hospital, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Joseph Calabro, the assistant business manager of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 1158, is accused of hitting the supervisor, Edward Ambio Jr., numerous times in the face with a ''blackjack or similar-type weapon'' on Oct. 5, 1995, according to the indictment handed up Friday. Mr. Calabro, 34, attacked Mr. Ambio, supervisor of housekeeping at the county Health and Rehabilitation Center in Cedar Grove, in retaliation for personnel decisions at the hospital, said Chuck Davis, a spokesman for the state Attorney General.

title: American Drug Aid Goes South
description: American programs to fight cocaine in Latin America have long depended on an unholy alliance. The United States has sent hundreds of millions of dollars in weapons and equipment to armies with atrocious human rights records and a greater desire to fight guerrillas than drugs. Achieving American goals in the region -- combatting cocaine and promoting democracy and human rights -- depends on preventing the aid from going to thugs or being used in counterinsurgency wars. Recent developments show that the United States needs to do more to insure that its assistance is not misused.

title: The 49ers 'Finish With Fire' In Victory
description: Something kept clicking in San Francisco linebacker Ken Norton's mind before kickoff. Norton had this feeling that today's game between the 49ers and the Redskins would be close. Maybe it would even go into overtime.

title: Improving 4 State Hospitals
description: Unannounced inspections and undercover surveillance of employees at the state's four psychiatric hospitals would begin under a bill to be voted on in the State Senate today. The bill is one of eight on today's agenda that are aimed at improving conditions at the hospitals.

title: 'Forest People' Joining The Exodus From Zaire
description: Ten days after the first flood of Rwandan refugees began to return from Zaire, pouring over the border here, the ''forest people,'' who have hidden in remote wooded areas for nearly a month, are beginning to arrive.

title: Seeking Lessons in Valujet Crash: Experts Say Road Is Long
description: Within three days after Valujet Flight 592 went down in flames in the Everglades in May, investigators had a fairly clear picture of what occurred. Now, after six months of investigation and a week of hearings, they also know how many of the factors of the accident were created -- but not quite how to stop them from cropping up again.

title: CHRONICLE
description: This is the story that asks the question: Just what is a 35-year-old woman with a $22.5 million divorce settlement, a five-bedroom palace apartment in London and two children wholly supported by their royal father to do with the rest of her life?

title: Malraux Joins the Greats in the Pantheon As the French Exult in the Pride of Image
description: It is no doubt a measure of the importance that France gives to culture that the 20th anniversary of the death of Andre Malraux was celebrated here this weekend as a great national occasion. After all, it was Malraux who, as De Gaulle's Culture Minister from 1959 to 1969, decreed that the arts should be part of the lives of ordinary Frenchmen and women and not simply of the Parisian elite.

title: Stocks Gain in Tokyo
description: Stocks closed higher here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues climbed 77.46 points, or an increase of nearly four-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 21,293.57.

title: A Great Injustice
description: Angela Thompson, who spent her childhood being bounced from relative to relative, ended up with an uncle who was a drug dealer in Harlem. In 1988, when Angela was 17, the uncle was the target of a major police investigation. The cops knew that Norman Little was a bad guy. He already had three felony and five misdemeanor convictions, and the drug operation he was running was a large one. Now they were about to nail him good.

title: Train Derails, Injuring 10 In the Subway
description: Two rear cars of a Manhattan-bound No. 6 train in the Bronx were wrenched off the tracks early yesterday when a small chunk of a switching mechanism apparently broke off as the train changed from local to express tracks just south of the Hunts Point Avenue station.

title: Graf Goes From Hot to Cold to Champion in Five Sets
description: She did it the hard way, she did it the merciless way and, as usual, she did it despite wincing from a catalogue of aches and pains.

title: Technology Is Only as Good (or Bad) as Its User
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''It is yet another step up in the level, quality and distinction in the collection of modern art in the city. In one fell swoop, these works cover a major chapter in the history of art. PHILIPPE DE MONTEBELLO, on the bequest of 32 works by masters to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art. $(A1:2$)

title: This Time, It's a Last-Minute Tip That Tumbles the Broncos' Way
description: Ed McCaffrey's first thought was that he should tackle the Minnesota defender who seemed to have grabbed John Elway's tipped pass near the Viking goal line. But the Bronco receiver kept watching the ball and it just stayed in the air.

title: U.S. Smartly Capitalizes on a Mental Lapse
description: Noon in the Caribbean may be prime time for sunbathing, but it can be brutal for soccer. The idea in today's World Cup qualifier was to make the United States play at midday in sauna-like conditions, in hopes the visitors would become as limp and soggy as their sweat-soaked uniforms.

title: Iconoclastic Scholars of Jesus to Consider Doctrinal Revision
description: For more than a decade, the biblical scholars who belong to the Jesus Seminar have provoked excitement, apprehension and outrage, among lay people and academics alike, in their attempt to sift the New Testament to discover what they say is a purely historical picture of Jesus.

title: Milton C. Mumford Dies at 83; Led Lever Brothers in the 60's
description: Milton C. Mumford, chairman of the Lever Brothers consumer products empire in the 1960's, died Saturday at his home in Pebble Beach, Calif. He was 83.

title: Songs Sung Off-Key: Reliving Life's Unforgettable Flubs
description: ''The Springhill Singing Disaster,'' a one-woman show by Karen Trott initially produced by Playwrights Horizons, has reopened at the 47th Street Theater, 305 West 47th Street in Manhattan, in a slightly revised form. It is directed by Lonny Price, with sets by Derek McLane, lighting by Phil Monat and costumes by Gail Brisard. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley's review, which appeared in The New York Times on June 23, 1995.

title: Irish Take a Risk on a Coach Who Knows the Pull of the Dome
description: At the time of year when the impersonal, high-stakes mating dance between coaches and universities reaches a frenzy, there is this reminder about the attraction of Notre Dame, and the pull that begins long before children grow into recruits or aspiring coaches become job candidates. Lou Holtz has his grade-school memories of marching out to the Victory March at dismissal. Soon after Digger Phelps became basketball coach a quarter-century ago, he remembered an ambitious handwritten note to Ara Parseghian.

title: Bridge
description: Two major titles were decided Saturday at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in San Francisco.

title: Greer Lankton, 38, a Sculptor Who Turned Dolls Into Fantasy
description: Greer Lankton, an artist known for her flamboyant doll-like sculptures, was found dead in her apartment in Chicago last Monday. She was 38.

title: Credit Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: A New Language Is Adding Depth to the Flat Computer Screen
description: As new business uses for the Internet erupt, the lusterless, two-dimensional computer desktop display is rapidly giving way to a richer, three-dimensional representation that can be simultaneously viewed by dozens or even hundreds of computer users. Electronic shopping malls, real estate tours, businesses, political groups and even professional sports teams are rushing to virtual reality.

title: McDonnell Douglas's Troubles
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which manufacturers military and civilian aircraft, suffered two blows in recent days that have left some experts wondering whether the company has a future. First, the Pentagon announced that it had rejected McDonnell Douglas's bid and would turn to either the Boeing Company or the Lockheed Martin Corporation to build the next generation of fighter jets. Then, American Airlines announced that it would replace its McDonnell Douglas jets with Boeing aircraft.

title: Anniversary of an Abduction
description: Five years ago today, Mark Himebaugh's mother told him she was going on an errand for 20 minutes. It was 3:15 P.M., the last time she or anyone else saw the 11-year-old boy. Several leads yielded no answers: his sneaker found on the shore of the Delaware Bay, a few blocks from his house; an unfamiliar little girl spotted with him earlier on the day he disappeared; a detour that brought out-of-town traffic through his neighborhood that day. The boy's parents are separated, but neither is a suspect, the Middle Township police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Industries Set Standards For Crystal-Clear TV

title: A PLAN TO REVAMP SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has completed a plan to gradually shift thousands of children from special-education classes to regular classrooms, and to prevent thousands more from being labeled as special-education students in the first place.

title: CBS Is Being Beaten by ABC, and Geography
description: You can't say CBS wasn't warned that its college football mix of Big East and Southeastern Conference games was geographically flawed. So far this season, its 3.3 national Nielsen rating is 45 percent below ABC's 4.8.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS OFFERS TO BUY 2 COMPANIES
description: Applied Materials Inc., a leading producer of semiconductor equipment, offered yesterday to pay $285 million for two Israeli companies that make semiconductor inspection and measurement systems. Applied Materials, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would begin a tender offer of $18.50 a share, or $175 million, for Opal Inc., a maker of electronic microscope systems that measure dimensions of integrated circuits. It also said it would pay $110 million in cash for closely held Orbot Instruments Inc., which makes optical systems that inspect patterned silicon wafers. Shares of Applied Materials fell $1 yesterday, to $37.625. Shares of Opal jumped $6, to $18.125.

title: Hong Kong Panel Doesn't Answer to Beijing
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the expectations for O. J. Simpson's testimony in his civil trial misstated in some editions the plea of Mark Fuhrman, the former detective, to a charge of perjury over his testimony at Mr. Simpson's criminal trial. A correction in some copies on Saturday repeated the error. Mr. Fuhrman pleaded no contest to perjury; he did not plead guilty. In the criminal trial, he testified that he had not made racist remarks, but he was later shown to have made such remarks.

title: RANGER OIL TO ADD SOME GAS RESERVES OF GULF CANADA
description: Ranger Oil Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy land and natural gas reserves in northeast British Columbia from Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. for about $21.7 million. Ranger Oil, based in Calgary, Alberta, said the acquisition included natural gas reserves estimated at 46 billion cubic feet and about 50,000 acres of land in a section of the Canadian province known as the Helmet-Midwinter area. The company said the acquisition would increase its natural gas production in the area by about 17 million cubic feet a day, to a total of 55 million cubic feet a day. Gulf Canada Resources, a unit of Olympia & York Developments Ltd., is also based in Calgary.

title: Tess Hyman, Aide to Disabled At Sports Events, Dies at 92
description: Tess Hyman, whose efforts for nearly a half-century on behalf of fans in wheelchairs attending Giants and Jets football games earned her the nickname Tess of the Meadowlands, died yesterday morning at her home in Deerfield Beach, Fla. She was 92.

title: CARGILL FINANCIAL IN STOCK DEAL FOR EAPCO
description: The Cargill Financial Services Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Eapco Commercial Properties Inc. for $45.7 million in stock, Eapco said. Eapco, a real estate company based in New York, is traded on the Bern division of the Swiss exchange and has about one million shares outstanding. Shareholders of Eapco would receive $45.75 for each share of Eapco common stock, the company said. Eapco would be taken off the Swiss exchange after the sale has been completed, probably by the end of the year. Cargill Financial, based in Minneapolis, is the financial trading and futures brokerage of Cargill Inc., the private agricultural company.

title: What China Wants
description: It is good that the United States and China have agreed to exchange state visits over the next two years, but the truth is that the road ahead in this critical relationship is destined to remain bumpy.

title: Charging Trademark Violation, Visa Sues American Express
description: Visa opened another front yesterday in its fierce and protracted struggle with American Express, accusing the company in a lawsuit of trademark infringement.

title: In Witness of the New and Nothing but the New
description: For 22 years, the American Composers Orchestra has represented the honest industry of people writing music in this country. You compose them, and we'll play them, it has said to America's more important operatives. Unsurprisingly, the orchestra's history does not comprise consecutive masterpieces. It presents instead a chronicle of how American concert musicians have been thinking about themselves and the world around them. If a lot of this repertory passes through and passes on, it is the process that has been important.

title: A book tells how the effective and often imitated ad campaign for Absolut vodka has fueled sales.
description: IS there enough to say about even a campaign as popular and successful as that for Absolut vodka to fill 274 pages of a book?

title: New Use for Seized Homes
description: Four houses seized from a Camden drug dealer will be used to fight drugs. Yesterday, the Internal Revenue Service turned over two of the buildings confiscated from Walter Holland to the Camden Police Department to serve as substations. The other buildings were given to community groups that work to keep young people away from drugs.

title: LaFontaine Still Out
description: PAT LaFONTAINE, the Buffalo Sabre scoring star, will sit out at least another three months from the aftereffects of a concussion he sustained last month, the team said yesterday.

title: Rival Bid Disclosed in Standard Federal Sale
description: Standard Federal Bancorp spurned a higher takeover offer from Charter One Financial Inc. when it accepted ABN-Amro Holding N.V.'s $59-a-share cash offer, according to a letter from Charter One's chairman that was obtained yesterday.

title: President Named At Ann Taylor
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation named Patricia DeRosa president and chief operating officer yesterday, filling the position left vacant when Sally Kasaks left in August after a long sales slump.

title: Universal Outdoor Buying Competitor
description: The consolidation of the outdoor advertising industry continued yesterday as Universal Outdoor Inc. in Chicago agreed to acquire the Revere National Corporation, a privately held outdoor company in Baltimore, for $125 million in stock.

title: Workings of Split Brain Challenge Notions of How Language Evolved
description: LAST year, a 43-year-old woman who had suffered from terrible seizures since she was 16 underwent surgery to cut the thick band of fibers connecting the left and right hemispheres of her brain. The treatment worked as hoped, stopping epileptic seizures from spreading throughout her brain, and protecting her from the head injuries and burns she had suffered from falls when she suddenly lost all muscle control.

title: Dusty Dictionary Has Charm and Characters
description: To the Editor:

title: No More Mr. Nice Guy: Traffic Crackdown Begins
description: Starting today, more than 300 additional traffic officers will be posted in midtown Manhattan and other major shopping areas in the city and along major roadways to ease traffic congestion during the holiday crush.

title: Fresh Thinking on Special Education
description: Nearly everyone agrees that New York City's special-education system is in horrendous shape. It devours a huge share of the school budget while condemning most of its students to isolation and failure. The chief culprits are a funding formula that rewards schools for segregating disabled students, even those with only minor learning disabilities, and state laws that dictate even minute details of classroom life, making innovation and mainstreaming all but impossible. Both impediments need to change if special education is to have any chance at improvement.

title: Eurotunnel Stock Slumps In Aftermath of Fire
description: The stock of Eurotunnel, the operator of the English Channel tunnel, slumped in trading yesterday amid concern that full tunnel service might not resume for months after last week's fire. Fears over the cost of the closing grew as the French rail authority SNCF said it planned to seek recompense for revenue lost since the tunnel was shut to passengers last week. Eurotunnel has offered only limited freight service since Nov. 18, when a fire gutted one of its two tunnels.

title: Capturing a Grizzly? In the Age of DNA, A Few Hairs May Do
description: DAMIEN MILLER let out a loud whistle of warning as he walked toward his study site, hoping to perk up the ears of any grizzly bears that might be lurking in the woods. Mr. Miller, a biologist with the Wyoming Department of Game and Fish, would love to have some grizzlies visit this patch of spruce and pine forest, but he has no desire for a surprise encounter with a 1,000-pound bear.

title: Carlton in TV Deal In Southwest England
description: Carlton Communications P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Westcountry Television Ltd. for $:85 million ($142.8 million). Westcountry is a private company that holds a television license for southwest England. Carlton is a television broadcaster, programmer and media services company. (Dow Jones)

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: U.S. Inspectors Seeking Flaws In Rail Bridges
description: Federal regulators said yesterday that they planned to inspect all of the nation's 200 or so moving railroad bridges after a misaligned rail on a moving bridge across the Hackensack River knocked an Amtrak train off the tracks early Saturday and sent it careening into a marsh in Secaucus, N.J.

title: 100,000 Serbs Take to Streets Against Milosevic
description: More than 100,000 jeering demonstrators hurled eggs at the state-run television headquarters, blocked city streets for more than eight hours and roared their approval when opposition leaders vowed to shut Belgrade down until the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, was removed from power.

title: Market Room for Both
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea Agrees to Free U.S. Citizen Jailed as Spy
description: North Korea has agreed to free an American jailed as a spy after he stole into the isolated Communist country on a self-appointed mission to convert its people to Christianity, State Department officials said today.

title: Governor's Car Accident Has Mississippi Abuzz
description: For almost three weeks now, there has been an unceasing buzz at Hal & Mal's, a lunch spot just down the street from Mississippi's elegant, whitewashed Governor's Mansion, about the mysterious Election Day car wreck that nearly killed Gov. Kirk Fordice.

title: For Burroughs at 82, A Legion of Fans Under the Influence
description: William Burroughs is contemplating admiration. ''What do you mean it's an anemic emotion?'' he says, brow furled. ''I don't remember having said that.'' Then he reconsiders: ''Well, I shouldn't be held accountable for everything I say casually. I'm very comfortable being the subject of admiration.''

title: The I.R.A. Edges Toward a Truce
description: There are credible reports that the Irish Republican Army is now prepared to restore the cease-fire it broke last January, provided Britain agrees to admit the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein, to the Northern Ireland peace talks. The I.R.A. has given the British, and everyone else, reason to distrust its word and despise its conduct. Nevertheless, its new offer should be carefully tested. If genuine, it represents the best chance in almost a year to halt the violence and promote productive negotiations on Northern Ireland's future.

title: Bus vs. Rail in Monmouth
description: Does Monmouth County need a new rail line to ease its traffic jams, or would more buses do the trick? New Jersey Transit's board of directors is to decide today whether to run more buses on Route 9 or to build a commuter rail link from Lakewood to Monmouth Junction, just north of Princeton Junction, to deal with north-south traffic congestion in Middlesex, Monmouth and Ocean counties.

title: Resisting U.S., Africans Back Another Term For U.N. Chief
description: African nations stood firm today behind a second term for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, setting back American hopes that new candidates might emerge soon to challenge the incumbent.

title: Dow Surges 76.03 to Top 6,500 As Post-Election Rally Roars On
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, continuing its post-election surge, leaped past 6,500 points for the first time yesterday, a move that came only six weeks after the index first topped 6,000.

title: Johnson Nominated
description: MICHAEL JOHNSON, last year's winner, and 10 other Olympic gold medalists were nominated for the 1997 Jesse Owens International Trophy.

title: GNC Picks Deutsch For Image Campaign
description: General Nutrition Centers, owner of the GNC specialty retail chain that sells health foods and vitamins, said yesterday that it had named Deutsch Inc. in New York to handle the creative portion of its account, which had been handled inhouse.

title: 2 Studies Seem to Back Veterans Who Trace Illnesses to Gulf War
description: Two new Government studies show for the first time that veterans of the 1991 Persian Gulf war are far more likely to suffer from a variety of serious health problems than troops who did not serve in the war, a finding that appears to vindicate ailing veterans who have said that their service in the gulf has cost them their health.

title: Feisty, Tender, She Speaks Her Mind
description: A big, elated grin stayed on Ani DiFranco's face all the way through her concert at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night. She beamed when the audience, overwhelmingly female and collegiate, whooped its recognition of favorite songs. And she made her most unruly declarations -- ''I could do a lot of things/and I do'' -- with a conspiratorial smile.

title: A $7.7 Billion Union of Gas, Electricity
description: The Duke Power Company, one of the nation's largest electric utilities, and the Panenergy Corporation, one of the biggest natural gas companies, said yesterday that they would merge in a $7.7 billion stock swap, creating a marketing juggernaut to sell power and other services nationwide.

title: Accounts
description: McDonald's Corp., Manila, to Hemisphere-Leo Burnett, Manila, a unit of the Leo Burnett Co., to handle its account in the Philippines, which had been handled by Basic, Manila. Billings were not disclosed. Burnett now handles advertising for McDonald's in 22 countries.

title: Apple Is Beaten to a Pact For Use of Operating System
description: The Power Computing Corporation, the largest maker of Macintosh clones, has agreed to license a new computer operating system produced by Be Inc., jumping ahead of Apple Computer Inc., which has been seeking an alliance with Be.

title: Battle Against Mexican Mafia Opens New Front in Court
description: In California's prisons and on the mean streets of the state's big cities, especially in the barrios of Los Angeles, it is called la Eme -- the M.

title: Safir Defends Police Mission In the Dominican Republic
description: Denying that he wanted to open a permanent police outpost in the Dominican Republic, New York City's Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, said yesterday that he simply wanted to work with the authorities in that nation to track down criminals whose victims were predominantly Dominican.

title: Excite's Stock Soars on Deal With America Online
description: Excite Inc. agreed yesterday to make its directory the exclusive tool used to search the Internet on America Online Inc. The announcement sent Excite's shares up 61 percent.

title: Report Says Colombia Misused U.S. Aid on Rebel War
description: Acting on advice from United States military advisers, the Colombian military reorganized intelligence operations in the early 1990's, tightening ties between the armed forces and paramilitary fighters who have been accused of killing civilians, a human rights report says.

title: It Appears the Broncos Catch All the Breaks
description: The Denver Broncos have the best record (11-1) in the National Football League, have won eight consecutive games and own a three-game lead in the American Football Conference West Division. When you are that good, you get the right bounces, too.

title: In '96, Gambling Gained New Voter Acceptance
description: To the Editor:

title: Rio Pursues Olympic Bid With Charm
description: The delegates from the International Olympic Committee were given hotel rooms that commanded the most fabulous views, a choice of 27 kinds of fruit in the morning and same-day delivery of The Lagos Times.

title: INDUSTRIES AGREE ON U.S. STANDARDS FOR TV OF FUTURE
description: Ending years of industry squabbling, the broadcasting, consumer electronics and computer industries will announce an agreement today on a technical standard for the next generation of television.

title: Bill Clinton's New America
description: With determined concentration, President Clinton has worked a historic change in American foreign policy. Foreign policy amounts to a nation's political, moral and military stance in the world, its role and values. For America, the change will affect all these, and for ill.

title: People
description: Neilan Tyree was named vice president for business development at McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C., succeeding Charles Whittingham, who left. Mr. Tyree had been director for agency branding at Merkley Newman Harty, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Chess
description: The biggest negative surprise in the Fontys International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, was Anatoly Karpov. He started with a loss to the bright 20-year-old Hungarian grandmaster Zoltan Almasi, and after that could not make any headway toward winning the elite event.

title: French Military Supplier Plans 2,700 Job Cuts
description: Thomson-CSF, the state-controlled military electronics company in France, said yesterday that it would cut 2,700 more jobs next year because of the weak outlook for military-related orders. The company, part of Thomson S.A., is scheduled to be sold to Lagardere S.A. Thomson has been notifying employees in recent weeks about its plans, and the total number of jobs at stake was disclosed yesterday by the newspaper Le Monde.

title: On Tape, Suspect Blames Accident for Fatal Fire in Illegal Garage
description: The fire was an accident, the man told the prosecutor and detectives on the videotape played yesterday in a Brooklyn courtroom. Other men had spilled gasoline on the floor nearby, he said, and it was ignited by a spark from a grinding machine he was using to transfer a vehicle identification number from one car to another.

title: Clinton in Manila: Successes Are Not Spectacular, but Still Useful
description: When Bill Clinton assembled Asia's leaders for their first summit meeting, three years ago in Seattle, he talked grandly about building a ''Pacific community,'' stitching together countries with no natural alliances, few common ethnic ties, vastly different economies and centuries-old rivalries.

title: At Island Plane Crash Site, Sorrow and a Souvenir Hunt
description: In the clear tropical waters rocking the shards of Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961, a variety of emotions rose and ebbed with the tides today.

title: A Welcome Farewell
description: Say this for Representative Bob Dornan of California. He went down fighting. After three weeks of uncertainty, the tally in Mr. Dornan's district shows that he has been narrowly but decisively defeated by the Democratic challenger, Loretta Sanchez, ending one of the least attractive careers in modern Congressional history.

title: A Heisman Candidate Listens to His Own Drummer
description: The scout from the National Football League was watching the passing drill unfold at Florida Field. He was taking notes about every aspect of the Florida Gators, but paying particular attention to the Heisman Trophy candidate and record-setting quarterback, Danny Wuerffel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: A New Area Code Complaint
description: New Jersey's area code woes continue to grow. Hot on the heels of the creation of two new area codes splitting 21 North Jersey towns into two codes, a group of state senators said yesterday that a plan to create a new area code in the southern 609 region in 1998 would split eight more towns.

title: Dow Leaps Past 6,500
description: Stocks extended their post-election rally, with the Dow Jones industrial average surging past 6,500. November is shaping up as the best month for the Dow in almost five years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Monday referred incorrectly to a computer data base compiled by a convicted pedophile in Minnesota. It contained the names of thousands of children, not 99.

title: Dalai Lama Movie Imperils Disney's Future in China
description: The Walt Disney Company is planning on a big future in China: The appetite for animated features like ''The Lion King'' seems limitless, sales of merchandise at Disney-owned ''Mickey's Corner'' stores are growing fast, and Disney's president, Michael Ovitz, has traveled here repeatedly this year to discuss the possibility of opening a Disney theme park in southern China.

title: Strike by French Truck Drivers Slows Commerce to Snail's Pace
description: French truck drivers striking for higher pay and the right to early retirement at full pay blockaded highways, ports and airports all around the country today as a dispute with private employers went into its second week.

title: Harold Israel, 87, Specialist Focusing On Chest Diseases
description: Dr. Harold Louis Israel, who specialized in diseases of the chest, particularly those about which little is known for certain, died on Friday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 87.

title: In '96, Gambling Gained New Voter Acceptance
description: To the Editor:

title: Downsizing Prevails as Customers Resist Paying More
description: It may be every grocery shopper's fundamental right to complain, but in these days of low inflation and competing superstores on every strip, there is less than usual to complain about. Walk down the wide aisles of the Pathmark 2000 supermarket here, for example, and you will see shelves jammed with a record variety of new goods in a time of stable prices.

title: Hevesi Says He Won't Run for Mayor, Citing Family and Desire to Remain Comptroller
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, who had become the great question mark of the 1997 mayoral race, ended weeks of speculation yesterday by taking himself out of the race and announcing that he would instead run for re-election.

title: Sonics Seem Poised to Go One Step Higher Than a Runner-Up Role
description: The Seattle Supersonics still have moments when players yell at coaches, when coaches yell at players and when a team leader like Shawn Kemp complains about his contract.

title: Campbell Has Rejoinder On Robitaille Complaint
description: Luc Robitaille was angry at his coach. But the Ranger coach said the wing's comments may have been more offensive to his teammates.

title: Fire Destroys a Village Hub, and Hurts a Resurgent Downtown
description: An early morning fire destroyed three stores and the beginnings of a retail renaissance today in the heart of this village in northern Westchester County.

title: At Asian Meeting, Support for Free Trade
description: President Clinton persuaded the leaders of 17 other Asian-Pacific nations on Monday to endorse efforts to ''substantially eliminate'' tariffs on computers and other information technologies by the year 2000 as the next step in breaking down barriers among America's biggest trading partners.

title: Q&A
description: Rare Blood

title: Raymond Skinner Clark, 82, Lawyer and Business Executive
description: Raymond Skinner Clark, a lawyer and business executive in New York and Baltimore, died on Friday at the Greater Baltimore Medical Center. He was 82 and lived in Baltimore.

title: Officials Could Not Force Hotel to Update Sprinklers
description: Fire Department officials said yesterday that they had tried for at least the last seven years to force the owners of the 74-year-old Hamilton Hotel in Harlem to install a sprinkler system on floors where residents live.

title: Amateur Pitcher Gets Record Signing Bonus
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays agreed to the largest contract ever for an amateur baseball player, signing the high school pitcher MATT WHITE for a $10.2 million bonus yesterday.

title: Challenged for Explanations, Simpson Gives Few Answers
description: In potentially the most damaging day yet of his civil trial, O. J. Simpson was accused in open court today of failing a polygraph test so dismally that his score indicated ''extreme deception,'' of doctoring his story to conceal his guilt and of planning to kill himself because he could not face a life in prison.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM WOLFE said that although he writes fiction he may be a journalist at heart. Which is another way of saying that perhaps he writes best with an imminent deadline.

title: RADISYS STOCK TUMBLES ON NEWS OF SUIT BY EX-EMPLOYEE
description: The stock of the Radisys Corporation fell 15 percent yesterday on news that a former executive had sued the company, a circuit board maker, contending that it overstated its earnings. According to an article in the Nov. 25 issue of Barron's, Bruce Taylor, a former vice president for operations at Radisys, said that the company, based in Beaverton, Ore., misreported inventory before and after a public offering to maintain the value of its stock. According to the article, Mr. Taylor contended that when he brought his concerns to the attention of the company, he was told it was not his business and was dismissed when he persisted. Mr. Taylor then filed the lawsuit, in an Oregon court. Shares of Radisys fell $7.875 yesterday, to $43.125.

title: A Date With Prosecutors
description: Prosecutors say that Nader Emusov is something akin to a compulsive con artist. In August, the Haledon-based handyman pleaded guilty to bilking 58 homeowners, most of them elderly, out of more than $150,000 by persuading them that they needed repairs, collecting down payments and then not doing the work. A judge released him out on bail until his sentencing on the condition that he stop soliciting business. But prosecutors say Mr. Emusov did not stop, and in September, the judge revoked his bail.

title: AT&T Chief Buys Shares
description: The AT&T Corporation's new president has a stake in how well the company does. Five days after being named to the post, John R. Walter bought 50,000 shares of AT&T at $36.50 each, or $1.825 million, the Washington Service tracking agency said. AT&T compensated Mr. Walter for leaving R. R. Donnelley & Sons to join AT&T on Nov. 1. He used part of that to buy the shares, AT&T said.

title: The Knicks Are Lacking That Old Toughness
description: His boss gave him an indirect endorsement. His players stand by him. Jeff Van Gundy is not alone in the belief that he can get the Knicks running smoothly again.

title: Islanders Set to Announce Sale of Team
description: The Islanders have scheduled a news conference on Long Island Tuesday to formally announce the completion of the sale of the team to John Spano, a Texas business executive from Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: ''It's not like Alabama was going to invade. We didn't need to decide whether to press the button or not.''

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Healthy O'Donnell Rejoins Ailing Jets
description: For a frustrated Neil O'Donnell, the Jets' season that never was became his again today.

title: Noted Lawyer to Defend Youth
description: The family of a New Jersey teen-ager accused with his girlfriend of killing their newborn son has added to their highly paid defense team a Manhattan lawyer who gained prominence in high-profile murder cases that resulted in manslaughter convictions for two young men.

title: Investigators Say Spy Suspect Used a Swiss Bank Account
description: Federal prosecutors disclosed today that Harold J. Nicholson, the C.I.A. officer accused of spying for Moscow, kept $61,000 in a Swiss bank account.

title: LIONORE PLANS TO TAKE OVER FORRESTANIA GOLD
description: Lionore Mining International Inc. of Toronto said yesterday that it planned to buy Forrestania Gold, an Australian nickel and gold mining company, for about $152 million. Lionore said it would first buy a 22.6 percent stake in Forrestania for $26 million. It would then make a friendly takeover bid for the rest of Forrestania's shares for $126 million. Lionore said Forrestania expected to produce as much as 160,000 ounces of gold in 1997 and 175,000 in 1998.

title: Swedish Insurer Bids for Top Mortgage Bank
description: Skandia Insurance A.B., Sweden's biggest insurer, offered 23.1 billion kronor ($3.5 billion) in stock to acquire the nation's top mortgage bank, Stadshypotek, a move that would form one of the largest financial institutions in the Nordic region.

title: Lewis-McCall Bout Set
description: LENNOX LEWIS and OLIVER McCALL will fight for the vacant World Boxing Council heavyweight title Feb. 7, the promoter PANOS ELIADES said yesterday. Eliades said the venue still has to be decided, with Las Vegas, Nev., London and Atlantic City as the prospective sites. (AP)

title: Image of Disputed Tower Depends on Who's Depicting It
description: The clash between the two Bronx Goliaths might be best viewed through the lens of a camera. But whose camera?

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday about a convention of delegates intent on forming a new populist movement referred incorrectly to an article headlined ''Real Populists Please Stand Up,'' written by Ronnie Dugger, who helped organize the convention. The article appeared in The Nation, not in The Texas Observer.

title: White Like Winter Snow
description: A flash of white makes a wonderful contrast to the black that dominates so many fall wardrobes. Fortunately, fashion designers showed a wide variety of white for the season, everything from pants suits to down parkas to evening dresses.

title: U.S. Allots $120 Million for Banks of Erie Canal
description: The Erie Canal, a trench that stretches from Albany to Buffalo, took eight years to build and was completed in 1825 at a cost of $7 million. The effort to revive the canal after superhighways killed off its commercial prospects has taken 40 years and produced a wealth of ideas but little money.

title: Look Cautiously at Jefferson's Views on Race
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Transpositions and Contrasts

title: Holiday Mission in a World of Silly Adults
description: ''A Lilith Thanksgiving,'' tonight's episode of ''Frasier'' on NBC, is in most ways typical of the series: smartly written, cleverly acted and breezily hilarious. Kelsey Grammer and the cast work small comedic miracles from week to week. But, surprisingly, this outing leaves a bitter aftertaste when the turkey is finally devoured. The reason is a running gag that amounts to a mean-spirited stereotype.

title: Corrections
description: The Tracking the Markets chart in Business Day yesterday misidentified a stock that spurted in trading volume last week. It was the Salomon Brothers Fund, a closed-end investment trust -- not Salomon Brothers, a subsidiary of Salomon Inc.

title: 3 Killed and 36 Injured in S.R.O. Fire
description: Fire and blinding smoke roared like a deadly wind through the upper-floor halls and warrens of a six-story, single-room-occupancy hotel in Harlem before dawn yesterday, killing three women and adding raw new terrors to the troubled existence of residents living already on the edge of homelessness, addiction and illness.

title: The Giants' Victory Is Rated PG: Please Gloat
description: Now comes the gloating.

title: Dutch Considering Sale Of State's Stake in KLM
