description: The Dutch Government and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines N.V. said yesterday that they were discussing the possible sale of the state's stake in the carrier. In a statement, KLM and the Government said it was too early to tell whether the exploratory talks would lead to a sale.

title: We Can't Do Business, the Dons Tell a Big Donor
description: What university would turn down a gift of $34 million for a new business school? Hardly any -- except, that is, Oxford, the oldest university in the English-speaking world.

title: Rights Group Says Bosnian Suspects Flaunt Freedom
description: A Bosnian Serb indicted for genocide by the United Nations war crimes tribunal reportedly served until recently as a deputy commander of a police station in Omarska, Bosnia. Another, charged with crimes against humanity, is said to spend most of his evenings at a place in Prijedor called the Pink Bar.

title: Cisneros Tells St. Petersburg To Heal Scars
description: Wrapping up a three-day visit to St. Petersburg, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros said today that any lasting solution to the problems that led to two recent racial disturbances in that city would hinge on effectively addressing the ''historic tension'' between black residents and the police.

title: Open Letter On the Jets Being 4-24
description: LEON HESS

title: On Military Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Asteroid's Shallow Angle May Have Sent Inferno Over Northern Kill Zone
description: SCIENTISTS have reconstructed an almost blow-by-blow account of the catastrophe that overtook the Earth 65 million years ago at the end of the age of dinosaurs.

title: Bradley Disappoints In a Timid Performance
description: Some of them came to see their folk hero, to cheer on Shawn Bradley even if he played for the other team.

title: President of Belarus Wins Referendum on Expanding His Power
description: President Aleksandr Lukashenko was declared the overwhelming victor today in the referendum he organized to expand his power, and he immediately moved to do just that.

title: Higher Bounty for Fugitive
description: The price on a fugitive lawman's head rose $5,000 yesterday, The Associated Press reported. The United States Marshals Service offered the sum as a reward for the capture of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the former Somerset County Prosecutor who fled from house arrest last week, two days before he was to be sentenced on fraud, perjury and abuse of power charges. The new bounty was added to a $1,500 reward offered by police departments in Franklin Township and East Brunswick.

title: Corrections
description: A series of charts in Business Day on Thursday showing how home H.I.V. tests are being marketed and tracing new AIDS cases in the United States carried an incorrect label on one chart. It showed the number of men and women who developed AIDS last year through heterosexual conduct, not the number for all heterosexuals.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL TO BUY AMERICAN STUDIOS
description: PCA International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a rival photography services chain, American Studios Inc., for $66 million in cash, assumed debt and lease obligations. PCA said it would pay $2.50 a share for the 21.4 million shares outstanding at American, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., and operates photography studios in about 2,000 Wal-Mart stores. PCA is based in Matthews, N.C. Shares of American Studios rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $2.125. Shares of PCA rose $2.25, to $18. PCA, known for using digital photography, has recently entered more agreements with mass merchandisers. With the American Studios acquisition, PCA could become the biggest in the business, analysts said.

title: Showdown Over a Financing Gap
description: Since 1976, when New Jersey's Supreme Court ordered the state to come up with a way to end the disparity between the state's richest and poorest school districts, the issue has bedeviled a succession of governors.

title: Man Quits Happening
description: At the grocery checkout a TV Guide promises a report on ''Who's Hot -- Who's Happening -- Who's Sexy.'' Self-pity whispers, ''Buy it and feel depressed about not being included in the roundup.'' Common sense persuades me to keep my money.

title: INSIDE
description: Hotel Catering to Homeless Ravaged by Fire That Kills 3

title: Strong Investor Demand For Indonesian Bank
description: The shares of PT Bank Negara Indonesia rose as much as 53 percent yesterday in their trading debut, as investors scrambled to get a piece of the first Government bank to be sold in Indonesia. The initial public offering -- which raised 922 billion rupiah ($395 million) -- is the first stock sale by the Indonesia Government since the offering of the PT Telkom telephone company a year ago. Telkom had to trim its offering by a third, to $1.6 billion, after investor interest proved weak.

title: Kinship And Skin, And Which Is Stronger
description: A quick glance at her family photos shows that June Cross looks just like her dad. Jimmy Cross was part of a vaudeville song-and-dance team known as Stump and Stumpy, and his daughter inherited his rounded features and deep black skin. Her mother, Norma, is a white woman with the palest white skin and chiseled features. That is why, after Norma left Jimmy in the late 1950's, she sent the 4-year-old June to be raised by a black family in Atlantic City.

title: Unit of MCA Is Acquiring Talk Shows
description: MCA Inc. said yesterday that its television group had agreed to acquire virtually all the talk shows owned by Multimedia Entertainment, including ''Sally Jessy Raphael'' and ''The Jerry Springer Show,'' from Gannett Broadcasting, which acquired Multimedia for $1.7 billion in 1995.

title: Mets Bring in McMichael To Help Shore Up Bullpen
description: The Mets said their priority this winter would be to remake a bullpen that was largely unreliable last season. Yesterday, they took a step in that direction by trading for the right-hander Greg McMichael, who spent his first four seasons in the major leagues as part of the superb Atlanta Braves' staff.

title: SBS TECHNOLOGIES ACQUIRES BIT 3 COMPUTER
description: SBS Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the Bit 3 Computer Corporation, a maker of computer networking hardware, for $24 million. SBS Technologies, based in Albuquerque, N.M., makes electronic components. It said the purchase of Bit 3 would lower earnings in its second quarter, which ends on Dec. 31, by $11 million. In last year's second quarter, the company earned $776,166, or 23 cents a share, on sales of $7.4 million. SBS Technologies paid $20 million for Bit 3, funded by an offering of 1.8 million shares of common stock. SBS said it would pay the remaining $4 million over the next two years.

title: Valujet to Add Flights
description: Valujet Inc. said today that it would add flights from Atlanta to Dallas-Fort Worth, West Palm Beach, Fla., and Fort Myers, Fla., on Dec. 19 with a fare of $49. The airline resumed operations in October after being grounded for three months by Federal authorities as a result of an investigation into the crash in the Florida Everglades that killed 110 people. Valujet said it planned to begin offering special fares of $39, $49, $59 and $69 to all its destinations from Dec. 3 through Dec. 18.

title: Brave and Jolly Pirates of Queensland
description: It takes a brave choreographer and an even braver dance company to produce a three-act narrative ballet these days, though there are signs of a return to such elaborate fare. It takes an even braver choreographer to set a work to the music of Gilbert and Sullivan.

title: Winning Blueprint for L.I.
description: A familiar old schooner would sit in dry-docked splendor, its prow forming a gate to the Village of Greenport, L.I., and riders of an antique carousel would have a grand view of the harbor as they reach for the brass ring.

title: Macho Man: A Strong, Silent Minimalist Cowboy
description: CLINT EASTWOOD

title: Twisted Love From Mother Made Victims Of Children
description: Chicqua Roveal's life was defined by two passions, friends and acquaintances say. One was her love for her children, whom she raised with painstaking care. The other was her bitterness over the love she had not received from her own mother, a habitual criminal who was in prison more often than not, consigning her daughter to the care of strangers.

title: Keycorp Plans to Shed 280 Branches and Cut 2,700 Jobs
description: Keycorp, which built an iconoclastic reputation as the banker to small towns from Maine to Alaska, said yesterday that it would abandon the country for big-city life.

title: COINMACH TO ACQUIRE KWIK WASH FOR $140 MILLION
description: The Coinmach Laundry Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Kwik Wash Laundries L.P. for $140 million in cash and notes. Both companies provide coin-operated laundry equipment services to apartment buildings. Kwik Wash, based in Dallas, serves buildings primarily in Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas and Oklahoma. It also operates about 150 laundromats in Texas. Coinmach Laundry, based in Roslyn, L.I., said the two companies had combined revenues of $248 million for the 12 months that ended on Sept. 27. Coinmach, which went public in July, would pay $125 million of the total in cash. Its stock rose $1 a share yesterday, to $19.25.

title: Owners to Meet Today On Labor Agreement
description: Reject or ratify. Once more into the breach the owners step, given a second chance today to act on a labor deal they resoundingly rejected three weeks ago. Although no one can say what the outcome will be when the owners meet in Chicago today, the talk in recent days was that enough owners were prepared to change their votes to reverse the result.

title: Bell Atlantic Customers Are Put On Hold by Directory Assistance
description: In one of the most extensive directory-assistance failures since telephone operators started using computers in the early 1980's, hundreds of thousands of people from New Jersey to Virginia who wanted numbers were stymied yesterday by a computer software breakdown at Bell Atlantic.

title: JAZZ
description: Taking Piano and Saxophone

title: Steelers Hold Off Dolphins' Final Effort
description: This Monday night tango between Pittsburgh and Miami was not going to end without the trailing team getting one more trip to the floor. One more chance for a terrific two-step.

title: Hyperinteractive
description: ''Phase One is now complete.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEXTWAVE TELECOM INC., San Diego, said it would buy $200 million in wireless telephone equipment from Lucent Technologies Inc. Lucent would have the option to supply another $800 million of equipment.

title: Campbell Division For Overseas Units
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that it had created a division to manage its international businesses and promoted the head of its Pepperidge Farm unit to lead it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CROSS-COUNTRY

title: CHRONICLE
description: VACLAV HAVEL, the president of the Czech Republic, entered a hospital in Prague yesterday, Reuters reported. He is suffering from pneumonia, a spokesman said. He will not attend the summit of the 54-member Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which will take place in Lisbon on Dec. 2 and 3. Last week, Mr. Havel canceled a two-day state visit to Ukraine because of his illness. His condition has not improved in the last week.

title: A notice sent by Everen Securities to a client turns out to be a bit mixed up on trading rules.
description: THE Nasdaq stock market has cleaned up its act in many ways. No longer, for example, can a market maker trade ahead of his customers, as was the practice for generations. That was outlawed under rules announced two years ago. The rules went into effect in June 1995.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: Iraq and U.N. Make Deal on Oil Sales for Aid
description: Iraq and the United Nations announced today that they had reached a final agreement on the long-delayed deal allowing Iraq to sell oil for food and other emergency goods for the country's suffering civilian population.

title: Bond Prices In Mild Rally On New Data
description: A weak housing report and a strong dollar combined to raise the prices of Treasury securities yesterday, with the 30-year maturity leading the mild rally.

title: Digital Christmas? Why Not Wait?
description: AS Santa prepares his triumphant parade down Broadway, thoughts naturally turn to that heartwarming American tradition: buying a computer for the holidays. This year, repeat to yourself the baseball mantra, ''Wait till next year.''

title: After Making Some Strides, Cowboys Suffer a Relapse
description: The Dallas Cowboys, who recently regained their balance after being knocked off stride by an off season of woes and a dismal 2-3 start to the season, are being battered again.

title: Doctors Question Use Of Nazi's Medical Atlas
description: A CLASSIC anatomy atlas, famed for the beauty and fine detail of its paintings, has come under attack because of some none too metaphorical skeletons in its past. A letter appearing in tomorrow's issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association says that the author of the atlas was a leading Nazi who purged the University of Vienna medical faculty of Jews and that the cadavers portrayed in the paintings ''may have been victims of political terror.''

title: Italy Regains Place in Line For Europe's Currency Club
description: With its return to Europe's currency grid today after four years out in the cold, the Italian lira inched closer to the goal posts set for the first currencies eligible for European monetary union in 1999.

title: Young & Rubicam Selected for Account
description: International Home Foods in Madison, N.J., has named the New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc. to handle its consolidated account, with billings of $30 million to $40 million. The account had been divided between Y.& R. New York and Warwick Baker O'Neill in New York.

title: Borland Names Former Apple Executive As Its Chairman
description: Borland International Inc., the struggling software company, said today that it had named Delbert W. Yocam, a former executive at Apple Computer and Tektronix, as its chairman and chief executive.

title: POP
description: Bald and Body-Painted Singer,

title: Death Penalty Pause
description: To the Editor:

title: Kmart Store Is Blocked
description: Because Kmart did not properly inform neighboring landowners that it wanted to build a store on property it owns in Lacey Township, the company will now not be allowed to build one. A state appeals court yesterday threw out the township planning board's approval of a large Kmart store after finding that Kmart's notification to its neighbors of an upcoming planning board hearing did not mention plans for the store, the A.P. reported.

title: F.D.A. Commissioner Is Resigning After 6 Stormy Years in Office
description: Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs who has fought for the regulation of tobacco, worked to standardize nutrition labeling and taken steps to speed the Federal drug approval process, has decided to resign after six tumultuous years at the agency, F.D.A. officials said today.

title: Citing Family, Hevesi Won't Run for Mayor
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi ended weeks of speculation yesterday by saying he would not run for mayor and announcing that he would instead seek re-election. His decision, which ended weeks of speculation, left Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani facing only two opponents who are considered formidable: Ruth W. Messinger and Fernando Ferrer, the Borough Presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Machismo In Rap Atop The Charts
description: Snoop Doggy Dogg

title: As Einstein Letters Sell, Few Bids for Bitter Words
description: Personal letters of Albert Einstein, including some to his first wife that revealed both his tender and darker sides, were auctioned yesterday at Christie's in Manhattan for a total of $878,500. An Einstein scientific manuscript was also sold, for $398,500.

title: Patterns
description: A Tahari Line Is Sighted

title: House Resales Fell by 1.5% In October
description: Sales of existing houses dropped by 1.5 percent in October, the fifth consecutive monthly drop, the National Association of Realtors said today, providing further evidence that the housing market is slowing.

title: 90's Attitude, Visual and Raw
description: To fashion outsiders, the recent Calvin Klein advertising for CK Be, with the pierced, the tattooed and the stringy-haired pushing perfume, seems one more shock tactic by a designer who has mastered that art. But in fact, those ads are one more expert appropriation of a movement by a designer who has mastered that art, too.

title: Schools Must Support Gay and Lesbian Youths
description: To the Editor:

title: Ultrasound and Fury: One Mother's Ordeal
description: IF I had been paying more attention, I might have noticed the plaque outside the room that the obstetrician was ushering us into: Patient Education. And had I noticed, I almost surely would have been alarmed. I was 20 weeks pregnant with my first child and had just had a ''routine'' ultrasound examination. What did I need to be educated about?

title: Pettit Resigns as President Of Lehman Brothers Firm
description: T. Christopher Pettit resigned yesterday as president of Lehman Brothers, just months after he stepped down as chief operating officer and a group of younger senior executives took over the company's main divisions.

title: 2d Teen-Ager Is Guilty in Burning Death of Token Clerk
description: A second Brooklyn teen-ager was convicted of murder yesterday in the death of a subway token clerk whose booth was set afire during a robbery attempt a year ago yesterday.

title: Fending Off Thanksgiving Disasters
description: The in-laws are an hour early - don't even ask how Amtrak managed that. The giblets are nowhere to be found: will there be gravy? Worse, there is no room on the table for the turkey. Your curmudgeonly Uncle Nick almost stumbles onto a dirty little secret: you served takeout. And most of your family is more interested in the results of the football games than in how the children are doing in school.

title: Course on Top 10 Books Holds Not a Single Sleeper
description: This spring, Prof. Kenneth Dauber of the State University at Buffalo will teach a course titled ''The Top 10 Books.'' But the books he will be teaching came as something of a surprise to the professor.

title: Chancellor Plans Evaluations For Special-Education Shift
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is directing school officials to begin to evaluate about 15,000 special-education children with the goal of moving as many as possible into regular classrooms starting as early as next fall, he said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Pete Hamill, a City Voice, To Head The Daily News
description: Pete Hamill, a novelist, former newspaper columnist and, for just five weeks in 1993, editor of The New York Post, was named editor of The Daily News yesterday, putting the editorial reins of the newspaper back into the hands of someone with deep roots in New York City.

title: Fending Off Thanksgiving Disasters
description: The in-laws are an hour early - don't even ask how Amtrak managed that. The giblets are nowhere to be found: will there be gravy? Worse, there is no room on the table for the turkey. Your curmudgeonly Uncle Nick almost stumbles onto a dirty little secret: you served takeout. And most of your family is more interested in the results of the football games than in how the children are doing in school.

title: Devils Trade Peluso
description: MIKE PELUSO, one of the the Devils' chief aggressors the last four years, was sent to St. Louis yesterday, along with a minor league defenseman, RICARD PERSSON, for defenseman KEN SUTTON and a second-round choice in the 1999 draft.

title: Reluctant Baseball Owners Approve Pact With Players
description: Stepping back from the brink of continued hostility with the players, club owners reluctantly ratified a revolutionary agreement today that assured the first labor peace in Major League Baseball in four years.

title: Pirate Player Suspended
description: The Seton Hall starting guard JALIL ROBERTS has been suspended indefinitely by Coach GEORGE BLANEY for violating a team rule, the school said.

title: Angolans and Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk
description: WHAT wine goes with turkey?

title: Fending Off Thanksgiving Disasters
description: The in-laws are an hour early - don't even ask how Amtrak managed that. The giblets are nowhere to be found: will there be gravy? Worse, there is no room on the table for the turkey. Your curmudgeonly Uncle Nick almost stumbles onto a dirty little secret: you served takeout. And most of your family is more interested in the results of the football games than in how the children are doing in school.

title: Dance in Review
description: Matters of Life and Death

title: Aid to Replace Jitneys
description: Since 1915, the jitneys of Atlantic City have been shuttling residents and tourists up and down Pacific Avenue and, more recently, to and from the casinos in the city's marina and inlet districts. But many of the independently owned jitneys are showing their age, said William Penman Jr., president of the Atlantic City Jitney Association, the jitneys' city-chartered regulator.

title: KEYSTONE FINANCIAL TO BUY FIRST FINANCIAL
description: Keystone Financial Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the First Financial Corporation of Western Maryland for $74 million in stock and cash. Keystone, the fifth-largest bank in Pennsylvania, will acquire $345 million in assets and 10 First Federal Savings Bank branches in western Maryland. Keystone, based in Harrisburg, Pa., agreed to pay 1.29 shares or the equivalent amount in cash for each First Financial share. Based on Keystone's closing price on Monday, that is $34.19 a share. First Financial shares rose $1, to $28.75, before trading was halted and Keystone shares rose 12.5 cents, to $26.75.

title: Pie by Pie In Baking's Busiest Season
description: THIS Thanksgiving will be more difficult, with his mother gone, and gone just a month. The mourning candles still burn in the window. There are memorial flowers in a stand near the door. But John Flores is kneading hope into the holiday season, day by doughy day.

title: Sentencing Set for Celester
description: Federal prosecutors asked a judge yesterday to send Newark's former police director, William G. Celester, to prison for 41 to 51 months when he is sentenced on Monday for fraud and embezzlement. Federal sentencing guidelines call for someone in Mr. Celester's position -- he pleaded guilty in July to wire fraud, mail fraud and filing a false tax return -- to receive 30 to 37 months in prison. But in a sentencing memo to Judge Garrett E. Brown Jr. of United States District Court, James B. Nobile, an assistant United States attorney, said Mr. Celester's conduct warranted a tougher sentence because it represented a ''systematic and pervasive corruption of a government function tending to cause the loss of public confidence in government.''

title: U.S. Judge Strikes Down Ban on Talking to Press
description: Saying government employees have a First Amendment right to discuss ''issues of public concern,'' a Federal judge struck down a city policy yesterday that prohibited workers in two New York City agencies from talking with reporters without their agency's permission.

title: Giants' Outlook Takes On Rosy Tint
description: A funny thing happened on Dan Reeves's way out as the Giants' head coach: He beat the defending world champion Dallas Cowboys. Convincingly. Soundly.

title: Campus Job Interviews on a Virtual Path
description: Students at the University of Virginia and at 18 other universities from Maryland to Louisiana have become the first to participate in a new twist to campus recruiting, the ''virtual job fair.''

title: The Mouse Makes a Stand
description: By announcing yesterday that it would go ahead with a film about the Dalai Lama despite threats from China, the Walt Disney Company demonstrated that it would not accept censorship as the price of doing business in China or anywhere else. That is a welcome stand at a moment when the American Government and American companies seem increasingly prepared to set aside important democratic principles in hopes of expanding commerce with China. China must understand that it cannot impose its repressive practices on the free global marketplace.

title: Ramos Will Have Surgery on Knee
description: Tab Ramos, arguably the most skillful American midfielder, will undergo reconstructive surgery on his left knee in the next few days and will be lost to the national soccer team and the MetroStars for at least four to six months.

title: Clinton Hails Thais in Visit At Conclusion Of Asia Trip
description: President Clinton ended his 12-day Asia-Pacific trip today with a 24-hour state visit to this kingdom of glittering temples, teeming waterways and bustling economic development, honoring the 50th anniversary of the reign of its American-born, saxophone-playing King, Bhumibol Adulyadej.

title: Konrad Fischer, 57, a Dealer Who Discovered Many Artists
description: Konrad Fischer, a leading European dealer in contemporary art, died on Sunday in Dusseldorf, Germany. He was 57.

title: Yen Staying at Home
description: Japanese investors big and small are increasingly reluctant to invest overseas, a trend that has raised questions about the country's role as financier to the world. Economists fear that there may eventually be global shortage of capital as a result.

title: CHARTER ONE WITHDRAWS OFFER TO BUY STANDARD FEDERAL
description: Charter One Financial Inc. said yesterday that it had withdrawn its proposal to acquire Standard Federal Bancorp, citing roadblocks built into Standard Federal's agreement to be acquired by ABN-Amro Holding N.V. for $1.9 billion. The Cleveland-based concern said that after reviewing the agreement with ABN-Amro, it ''determined it was economically unfeasible to pursue further merger discussions with Standard Federal.'' It did not elaborate. The move came a day after it was disclosed that Standard Federal had spurned a stock offer from Charter One in favor of ABN-Amro's $59-a-share offer in cash. Charter One characterized its offer as better than ABN-Amro's.

title: Netanyahu, Scorning Critics, Visits West Bank Settlement
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu paid his first official visit to Jewish settlements in the West Bank today, adding new fuel to steadily rising tensions with the Palestinians.

title: Scandal Spurs Bell Atlantic Shift in Mexico
description: Yielding to pressure from the Government, the Bell Atlantic Corporation said today that it would assume management control of the cellular phone company Grupo Iusacell S.A. de C.V., removing Carlos Peralta Quintero, a powerful Mexican executive enmeshed in scandal, from its day-to-day operations.

title: After First Game, L.I.U. Won't Be a Surprise
description: They have already blown their cover. Barely beginning one of the most brutal road schedules in college basketball, they have officially been exposed as dangerous.

title: Now Baseball Must Seize Moment and Market Itself
description: If it is true that baseball's Hundred Years War is finally over, the next 100 days should matter little in the overall scheme of events in the national pastime.

title: Fending Off Thanksgiving Disasters
description: The in-laws are an hour early - don't even ask how Amtrak managed that. The giblets are nowhere to be found: will there be gravy? Worse, there is no room on the table for the turkey. Your curmudgeonly Uncle Nick almost stumbles onto a dirty little secret: you served takeout. And most of your family is more interested in the results of the football games than in how the children are doing in school.

title: Error in Processing of Forms Takes 6,000 Off Welfare Rolls
description: City officials acknowledged yesterday that more than 6,000 people had been wrongly thrown off welfare rolls because of an administrative error, a mistake that could mean hundreds of families will not have benefits over the Thanksgiving weekend.

title: Fugitive Ends His Lonely Flight With a Bullet in a Hotel Room
description: When Federal marshals forced their way into Room 374 of the Colorado Belle Casino in Laughlin, Nev., early yesterday, they found Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. crouched on the floor, a .380-caliber pistol in his hand. As the marshals moved toward him, one of them called the former Somerset County Prosecutor by name.

title: Walt Disney Earnings Soar On Gains in Every Division
description: The Walt Disney Company yesterday reported sharply higher gains in the fourth quarter, helped by record theme park attendance and its ''Aladdin and the King of Thieves'' video.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: High Ambitions for New Isles Owner
description: He tried to call John Pickett once on the telephone, Mike Milbury recalled. Pickett owned the Islanders. Milbury was their new coach and general manager. Although he reported directly to a group of managing partners, Milbury just wanted to say hello to the real boss.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: On a Centennial Tour,

title: A Poet's Power Struggle In the Wild, Cold North
description: The big chill cast by Hans Petter Moland's raw-boned polar adventure film, ''Zero Kelvin,'' is so penetrating that you might want to consider wearing thermal underwear to the Film Forum, where it opens today.

title: Knight Gets Close Look At Two of His Disciples
description: The Bob Knight Assistant Coach and Former Players Club holds a reunion with the master tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Regents Hearings on Adelphi Become a Hydra
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Thanksgiving

title: Group Says Alcohol-Related Traffic Deaths Are Rising Again
description: Drunken driving deaths are up and the push for stricter laws is faltering, Mothers Against Drunk Driving said in a report today.

title: Mark Lenard, 68, an Actor in Classics From Ibsen to 'Star Trek'
description: Mark Lenard, an actor who played leading roles in plays by Chekhov, Ibsen and Shakespeare but was best known as Sarek of Vulcan, the father of Mr. Spock, in the television and film series ''Star Trek,'' died on Friday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cooking With Apples and Pears
description: APPLES and oranges? No, apples and pears.

title: Beatific Vision Approved by the Reich
description: ''Das Buch mit Sieben Siegeln'' (''The Book of the Seven Seals'') is good music run over by history. We should know it better, and indeed, this sizable mid-1930's oratorio by Franz Schmidt might be enjoying a healthy international life and not the provincial one it now leads had it been composed at the turn of the century.

title: Disney Will Defy China On Its Dalai Lama Film
description: The Walt Disney Company, facing a warning by the Chinese Government over ''Kundun,'' a new Martin Scorsese film about the life of the Dalai Lama, said today it intended to release the film anyway.

title: Russia Drops Advisers for Phone Stock Sale
description: The Russian State Property Committee said today that it had dropped its Western advisers, led by N. M. Rothschild & Sons, concerning the planned sale of shares in RAO Svyazinvest.

title: THEATER
description: An Anatomy of Racial Bias,

title: The Murder of a Scholar Swept Up in Dark Forces
description: EROS, MAGIC AND THE MURDER OF PROFESSOR CULIANU

title: Shifts in Families Reach a Plateau, Study Says
description: Shifts in the structure of the American family appear to have leveled off in the 1990's, even as those changes have become embedded in the culture, the Census Bureau said in a study issued today.

title: Rain Knocks Out 4 Subway Lines in Brooklyn
description: Rain water cascading through sidewalk grates and onto subway tracks in Brooklyn knocked out power during the morning rush yesterday on four subway lines that link Brooklyn and Manhattan, stranding thousands of riders in stalled trains and disrupting the commute for tens of thousands more.

title: The Bewitching Power of Lies
description: We've grown so accustomed to seeing classic works transposed to jazzier settings that it's startling to see what Nicholas Hytner has done to ''The Crucible'': played it straight. Yet it is precisely by leaving Arthur Miller's 1953 play so emphatically in the Salem, Mass., of 1692 that Mr. Hytner's vibrant screen version succeeds so well in transcending time and place.

title: Twilight of the Witty But Supremely Shallow
description: Teetering on the brink of revolution, the French aristocrats in Patrice Leconte's discreetly scathing ''Ridicule'' indulge in a decadence that is peculiarly their own. They place the utmost value on cruel, wounding wit, which is used for the entertainment value of humiliating others as well as to define each speaker's precise caste among fellow courtiers.

title: Yanks May Alter Plans After the Rules Change
description: With a new labor agreement finally in place, George Steinbrenner will summon the Yankees' executives to Tampa, Fla., this weekend to devise a strategy that he hopes will allow the World Series champions to successfully defend their title. The meetings may be difficult because the task is difficult.

title: Club Bouncer Acquitted in 'Moshing' Death
description: A Brooklyn nightclub employee was acquitted of criminal charges yesterday in connection with the death of an 18-year-old almost two years ago in what is believed to be the country's only death associated with ''moshing.''

title: CYTOTHERAPEUTICS GETS BIG INVESTMENT FROM GENENTECH
description: Cytotherapeutics Inc. of Providence, R.I., will receive an investment of up to $50 million from Genentech Inc. to help it develop treatments for three diseases. Shares of Cytotherapeutics jumped $1.375 yesterday, to $9.50, in Nasdaq trading. Under the agreement, Genentech will buy $8.3 million of Cytotherapeutics shares to finance development of treatments using brain implants for Parkinson's disease, the companies said. The balance of Genentech's financial commitment will come in the next five to six years. The agreement with Genentech, based in South San Francisco, Calif., also includes research into potential treatments for Huntington's chorea and Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: The Drink Formerly Known as Milk Tastes the Same
description: COMING soon to your supermarket: milk with new names. The milk will look the same, taste the same and be the same. Only the terms on the label will be different.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resignation of Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, misstated a word in a quotation from Matthew Myers, executive director of the National Center for Tobacco-Free Kids. Referring to Dr. Kessler, Mr. Myers said, ''He revitalized a moribund agency, and by moving the F.D.A. into tobacco, he may be responsible for saving more lives than any other official in the last quarter-century.'' He did not say ''quarter-decade.''

title: Fending Off Thanksgiving Disasters
description: The in-laws are an hour early - don't even ask how Amtrak managed that. The giblets are nowhere to be found: will there be gravy? Worse, there is no room on the table for the turkey. Your curmudgeonly Uncle Nick almost stumbles onto a dirty little secret: you served takeout. And most of your family is more interested in the results of the football games than in how the children are doing in school.

title: A Chastened Bowe Is Hoping Less Paunch Means More Punch
description: At times during his boxing career, Riddick Bowe's appetite for food has been greater than his appetite for fighting.

title: Primark Seen Announcing Baseline Purchase
description: The Primark Corporation, continuing its rapid growth in the financial information business, is expected to announce today that it has acquired Baseline Financial Services for $40 million in cash from Bowne & Company and Robert Patterson, Baseline's founder.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fund Investments Surge; Dow Loses 19.38 Points

title: Sheltering Presidents And History
description: ''National Geographic'' comes home tonight, bringing the skills honed in distant climes and among exotic peoples to an exploration of America's most famous building. ''Inside the White House'' uses the state visit last year by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia to get behind the trappings. Instead of showing the First Couple coming at us, the spectator's usual vantage point, the camera trails them, along the way catching glimpses of the noncelebrities who create the impressive scene.

title: In His Way, Reinsdorf Made Peace
description: THERE is hope for the human race. Even baseball owners are, in the extremely long run, capable of that very human trait of being embarrassed by one of their own kind.

title: In an Unexpected Move, Simpson's Lawyer Postpones His Turn to Question His Client
description: O. J. Simpson's lead defense lawyer put an unexpected stop to his client's three-day ordeal on the witness stand this morning, saying he had decided to postpone his turn at questioning until the defense presented its case next month.

title: The Manic and Messianic Life of a Troubled Idealist
description: ''I'm terrified of entering those eerie shadows,'' Kathleen Chang wrote in the last entry of a journal she called her ''Die-ery'' because in it she detailed her plans to kill herself. It was not a new thought. At 14, she found her mother dead in bed, a suicide by overdose of barbiturates, in their home in Riverdale. Even before, young Kathy had slashed her wrists.

title: Refighting The Battle Of the Bulge
description: FOR lunch, Dr. Robert C. Atkins orders a bibb salad with Gorgonzola and a veal paillard. His marketing director, Nancy Hancock, orders the trout wrapped in a potato crust. Really? In front of the doctor who created the high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet, a loyal staff member consorting with dreaded carbohydrates? Quelle horreur!

title: PRESIDENT OF ENRON SAYS HE WILL RESIGN
description: The president of the Enron Corporation, Richard D. Kinder, said yesterday that he would resign, now that Kenneth L. Lay has decided to remain chief executive for at least five more years. Although Enron, a natural gas and electricity company, had offered Mr. Kinder a five-year extension on his contract as president and chief operating officer, Mr. Kinder said he was ready for a change. He said he would probably have stayed with Enron if Mr. Lay, 54, had elected to retire soon.Shares of Enron fell 87.5 cents yesterday to $46.635. Mr. Lay, who also serves as chairman, will assume the duties of president after Mr. Kinder leaves on Dec. 31. Mr. Kinder, 52, has been the president and chief operating officer of Enron for six years and has worked for the company for 16 years.

title: Japan May Approve the Pill, but Women May Not
description: The spread of the birth control pill in the West more than three decades ago is widely regarded as a milestone in the liberation of women and a turning point in social history.

title: Worldcom Leads the List Of Nasdaq Short Positions
description: Worldcom Inc., the No. 4 company in the long-distance telephone sweepstakes, expanded mightily last summer with its $12 billion acquisition of MFS Communications.

title: NBC Wins Rating Sweep in All Categories
description: NBC has won the November television rating sweep, which officially ends tonight, taking all categories and by some of the biggest margins in the network's history.

title: Natural Leader Bides Time With Knicks
description: Pat Riley is not around to wax philosophically about the lethargic Knicks and their three-game losing streak. He has his own problems in Miami. Anthony Mason is carving messages into his scalp to fire up his teammates and fans at Charlotte. Derek Harper's candid comments are bouncing off the locker room walls in Dallas.

title: POP
description: Traditional Brazilian Songs

title: Redskin Aide to Indiana
description: CAM CAMERON, quarterbacks coach of the Washington Redskins, got his first head-coaching assignment yesterday, returning to Indiana as BILL MALLORY's replacement. He signed a seven-year contract. (AP)

title: Elegance Over Technique
description: At 75, the American pianist Grant Johannesen, understandably, is playing with less vigor and technical command. Of course, even in his prime he was not a prodigious technician. His playing has been valued for its musical sensitivity and restrained elegance. These qualities were much in evidence during his recital on Saturday night at the 92d Street Y.

title: Trapped, Fugitive Ex-Prosecutor Kills Himself in a Nevada Hotel
description: Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the tough-talking former prosecutor from Somerset County, N.J., who fled his home to escape a prison sentence for corruption and fraud, shot himself to death this morning as a Federal marshal tried to coax him from a casino hotel room in this small town in the southernmost corner of Nevada.

title: Fending Off Thanksgiving Disasters
description: The in-laws are an hour early - don't even ask how Amtrak managed that. The giblets are nowhere to be found: will there be gravy? Worse, there is no room on the table for the turkey. Your curmudgeonly Uncle Nick almost stumbles onto a dirty little secret: you served takeout. And most of your family is more interested in the results of the football games than in how the children are doing in school.

title: Brunei Bank Buys 13% of Australian Bank
description: A state-owned Brunei bank became the largest shareholder in Macquarie Bank Ltd. yesterday, paving the way for the sultanate to become a major investor in Australian projects like highways and railroads. Brunei Investment and Commercial Bank, a subsidiary of the Brunei Investment Agency, bought 13.4 percent of Macquarie for the equivalent of $123 million from the Hill Samuel unit of Lloyds TSB Group.

title: J. P. Morgan Takes Space For Private Bank Group
description: J. P. Morgan & Company has leased more than 300,000 square feet at 345 Park Avenue, a 44-floor, 1.8-million-square-foot office building at 52d Street. It will be used for the company's private-client business.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Hevesi's Decision Not to Run Cheers Other Mayoral Rivals
description: With Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi now officially out of next year's mayoral race, the announced and soon-to-announce Democratic candidates in the field contend that his decision not to run has made the path to the nomination simpler.

title: Court Forces Florida to Release 400 Prisoners
description: More than 400 violent criminals and sexual offenders are expected to be released this week from Florida prisons, a few months early, despite the objections of state officials and the concern of hundreds of residents who have called the Governor's office to complain.

title: How to House the Homeless
description: City Hall and advocates for the homeless are often at war over how best to shelter New York City's most vulnerable citizens. But in recent years, the two have come to agree on at least one thing -- that the most effective way to care for much of the homeless population is through ''supported S.R.O.'s'' -- single-room-occupancy hotels that provide extensive social services to help people rebuild their lives. The question now is how to develop more of these S.R.O.'s -- but solid ones that add to their communities instead of creating eyesores.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: France to Give Up Groupe Bull Control
description: The French overnment said today that it planned to give up control of Groupe Bull, the country's largest computer maker, by shrinking its stake to less than 50 percent.

title: Run, Spot, Run. Act, Spot, Act.
description: Besides being the occasion for a Christmas merchandising blitz of Santa-shaking proportions, Disney's new live-action ''101 Dalmatians'' is spotty in every sense. Thanks to Glenn Close's delicious villainy, it succeeds in breathing archly theatrical life into the irresistibly monstrous Cruella DeVil. Otherwise, this remake goes to the dogs too often.

title: For First Feast (All Organic), A Hefty Tab
description: IF the colonists were to do it over again, what would that first feast cost? After tracking down as many organic products as possible -- organic was all they knew in 1621, after all -- this much is clear: in 1996 dollars, they would be in the big-spender category.

title: Giving In To Eviction, Grudgingly
description: JIM DAVIS cranked up the volume on his electric guitar yesterday and greeted the rainy dawn with ''The Sky Is Crying.'' He loves the blues, whether he's picking his own licks or blasting the masters from the vast record collection inside his cluttered room at the Gramercy Hotel.

title: Loving Truly, Deeply and, Yes, Madly
description: Savi Gabizon's film ''Lovesick on Nana Street'' brings to the screen a bizarre new species of comic hero: the lovable stalker. The moment Victor (Moshe Ivgi), who operates a pirate television station from his apartment in a northern Israeli village, sets his eyes on Michaella (Avigail Arieli), a pretty blond actress who moves into the neighborhood, he is hopelessly besotted.

title: Drinking and the Holidays
description: As everyone knows, the holiday season drives some people to drink, and many of those who drink will drive. In a survey by the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and Rutgers University's Eagleton Institute, 25 percent of adult New Jerseans who drink indicated that they would probably drink more during the holidays. The same survey of 1,021 people found that 25 percent of drinkers do not use a designated driver.

title: Steering Panel Has the Reform Party's Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Lower Rebel Flag, A Southern Governor Says
description: South Carolina is the last state in the South to fly the Confederate battle flag from its statehouse. Some look to that white-starred blue X on a field of red and hear the roar of cannons. Others hear only the clink of chains.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK CORP., Kalamazoo, Mich., said it would reorganize its operations, put more employees into incentive pay plans and eliminate an unspecified number of jobs.

title: Neighbors At a Loss To Explain A Demise
description: The view from Grandview Road takes in a great swath of the hills of southern Somerset County as they sweep south toward Princeton.

title: A Knighted Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: Messier Leads The Rangers In Triplicate
description: The Rangers tried something different tonight: they actually held on and won a close game.

title: BMW Picks Two Publicis Offices
description: Two offices of the Publicis/Bloom unit of Publicis S.A. were named yesterday to handle two of four new regional accounts for BMW of North America.

title: Motta Is a Winner In Debut With Nuggets
description: His team slumping and attendance declining, BERNIE BICKERSTAFF resigned as coach of the Denver Nuggets, turning over the club to his assistant, DICK MOTTA. The 65-year-old Motta won in his debut last night as the Nuggets beat the Suns, 117-108, in Phoenix. The Suns fell to 0-13.

title: Novell Earnings Nearly Flat With Revenues 22% Lower
description: Novell Inc. yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings that were in line with expectations as cost-cutting helped offset a drop in revenue from the sale of its Wordperfect and Unix divisions.

title: Some analysts see a silver lining to Chiron's cloud.
description: A DAY after the Chiron Corporation's stock fell 17 percent following a failed clinical trial of a new vaccine for genital herpes, some analysts said the event was not entirely negative. At yesterday's closing price of $18.875, up 75 cents, shares in Chiron, which many consider a core biotechnology holding, are now cheap enough to consider buying, they say.

title: The Art of Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsi's holiday-season campaign has promotions with Microsoft and an elf with attitude.
description: DRINK Pepsi, get software.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three years ago JERRY HERMAN sold his Upper East Side town house and moved to Los Angeles. ''I thought I'd come out to California to retire,'' the composer and lyricist of ''Hello, Dolly!'' and ''Mame'' said over the phone from his home in Bel Air. ''I thought I'd have a little peace and quiet.''

title: The Mars of a Million Myths
description: First, there was the meteorite that held the tantalizing possibility that Mars had at one time harbored life. Now, NASA has launched one unmanned craft and plans another to explore our planetary neighbor.

title: Coat Etiquette: It's the Esthetic, Stupid!
description: To the Editor:

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG STOCK GAINS AMID IVAX SPECULATION
description: The shares of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation gained 6 percent yesterday amid speculation that its planned $1.4 billion purchase of the Ivax Corporation may be altered or even collapse. Bergen Brunswig stock gained $1.625, to $28, in trading of almost 1.1 million shares. Since Bergen Brunswig, a distributor, announced its plan to buy the generic drugmaker Ivax on Nov. 11, shares in both companies have slipped. Bergen shares had fallen 24 percent to $26.375 as of Monday reflecting investor dissatisfaction with the transaction as it is structured.

title: Rosalie Ulrich Rosenberger, 97, Lawyer and Housing Advocate
description: Rosalie Ulrich Rosenberger, who practiced law in Nassau County for nearly seven decades, starting even before the county bar association admitted women, died on Sunday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. She was 97 and a 60-year resident of Rockville Centre.

title: All Eyes Await New G.O.P. Act on Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: David Kidd, Lover of Asian Arts, Dies at 69
description: David Kidd, an American expatriate who became so imbued with traditional Chinese and Japanese art and culture that by the end of his career he was teaching Japanese traditions to the Japanese, died on Thursday in Honolulu. He was 69 and had homes there and in Kyoto, Japan, where he was the founding director of the Oomoto School of Traditional Japanese Arts.

title: If Stuff You Must, Don't Undercook
description: THE turkey-cooking world was caught by surprise this summer when the Agriculture Department announced that turkeys should not be stuffed. Doing so ''is an invitation to trouble,'' declared Bessie Berry, the acting director of the department's toll-free help line.

title: S&T BANCORP TO ACQUIRE PEOPLES BANK
description: S&T Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Peoples Bank of Unity for $94 million in stock. S&T Bancorp is a banking company based in Indiana, Pa. Peoples Bank of Unity is a commercial bank in Plum Borough, Pa. The combined company will have assets of about $1.7 billion. Peoples Bank had $288 million in assets as of Sept. 30. S&T Bancorp also said it had rescinded a plan to buy back up to 350,000 shares, or 3 percent of its outstanding stock, over one year. S&T's stock slipped 25 cents yesterday, to $31, in Nasdaq trading.

title: No Headline
description: ''It gives me great personal pleasure that baseball fans can finally now look forward to five years of uninterrupted play.''

title: Ex-Prosecutor Kills Himself
description: Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the famously tough former prosecutor from Somerset County, who fled his home to escape a prison term for corruption and fraud, shot himself to death as a Federal marshal tried to coax him from a casino hotel room. In a 10-minute standoff, Mr. Bissell told one of three deputy marshals who had tracked him from New Jersey that he could not face spending the next decade in prison, Federal officials said. In Mr. Bissell's neighborhood in Montgomery Township, N.J., word of his death spread slowly. $(Pages A1 and B5.$)

title: Secret Lives, Honest Spies
description: The arrest of Harold Nicholson, a high-level officer of the Central Intelligence Agency, again raises the question of how to make, and keep, an honest spy.

title: THEATER
description: Christopher Marlowe Meets

title: Restoring Some Classics After Unjust Neglect
description: Don Byron likes to use jazz repertory to nudge composers from the fringes into public consideration. His music often arrives in the form of an argument, and on his new album, ''Bug Music'' (Nonesuch), he argues for the reputation of the swing band leaders John Kirby and Raymond Scott as underappreciated rebels and genre colliders with a distinct link to Duke Ellington.

title: Opposition to a Mall
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency asked the Army Corps of Engineers last week not to allow a developer build a 2.1-million square foot mall in the Meadowlands in Carlstadt, the agencies said yesterday. The Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., failed to adequately describe how the project would affect the environmentally sensitive wetlands and what the company would do about it, said Rich Cahill, a spokesman for the E.P.A. A spokesman for the Corps, Pete Shugert, said the E.P.A.'s concerns would be reviewed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a breakdown in Bell Atlantic's directory assistance service referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of states served by the company. It is six plus the District of Columbia, not nine.

title: Transit Agencies Endorse Bid
description: Executives from five transportation authorities have recommended that a Moorestown company be awarded a contract to develop an electronic toll collection system for the state's toll roads, bridges and tunnels, officials said yesterday. The proposal by MFS Network Technologies would net the agencies $157 million over eight years, said Edward M. Gross, acting executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. The revenue would come from leasing fiber-optic cable to be laid along the toll roads.

title: Nation of Global Investors Isn't Venturing Too Far Now
description: Tetsuo Ishii stood near a poster of Christopher Columbus, beckoning him to plunk his money into a fund that invests in America.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the effects of an asteroid's impact 65 million years ago misspelled the name of the crater it left beneath the Gulf of Mexico. It is Chicxulub, not Chicxlub.

title: Setting Shakespeare Free In a Cartoon Fairy Tale
description: The Metropolitan Opera put aside its customary search for facts on Monday night and let its fantasy run free. The new Tim Albery-Antony McDonald production of Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' takes its title seriously. It gently urges us to hallucinate: not a normal activity in this house.

title: British Phone Market Welcomes Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTORS' MONEY CONTINUES TO POUR INTO STOCK FUNDS
description: Mutual fund investors, who have greeted every stock market rally this year with a fresh wave of cash for fund managers to invest, continue to register their belief that stock prices can go even higher.

title: A Former Stronghold Turns Against President of Serbia
description: His old blue raincoat flapping in wild gusts of wind, the newspaper editor pushed his way through the demonstrators in the central square of this industrial city like a man with a mission.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 18 about a United Nations gathering to discuss global food supplies misstated the percentage of the United States economy devoted to foreign aid. It is one-tenth of 1 percent, not just under 1 percent.

title: Opulent Intimacy Fit for a Czar
description: IS midtown Manhattan big enough for two high-profile Russian restaurants?

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Unit Chief Changing DDB Needham Jobs
description: John Zeigler, the president and chief executive of Focus GTE in Dallas, a special unit of DDB Needham Worldwide dedicated to that agency's important GTE Corporation account, is leaving to become managing director at DDB Needham Singapore.

title: Our Dark Places
description: The circus isn't broadcast live from the courtroom anymore. The memoirs of the celebrity lawyers are descending to the vanishing point on the best-seller list. The disgraced L.A.P.D. detective who served as the race card won't be dealt again, and the famously blond house guest shows no promise after all of parlaying his self-contradictory improvisations under oath into an acting career.

title: A Tart Approach To Turkey Leftovers
description: Something old.

title: Utility Panel May Make Nynex Compensate Customers for a Merger
description: The staff of the New York State Public Service Commission has recommended that the commission not approve the proposed merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic unless Nynex agrees to compensate its customers for the loss of a potential new competitor in the New York telephone market.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the crash of an Ethiopian Airlines plane into the Indian Ocean misstated its ranking among air disasters in which a hijacking was involved. With the death toll revised yesterday to 125, this crash was the second worst involving a hijacked aircraft, not the worst; 128 people died in 1990 when a hijacked plane crashed in Guangzhou, China.

title: With Snow, Ice and Wind, Spokane Fears Its Trees
description: A few days ago, the trees in this snowbound city in Eastern Washington turned lethal. Ponderosa pines landed in living rooms. Big firs smashed cars in half. Ancient oaks planted by pioneers gave it up with barely a fight.

title: The Big Bang
description: Scene I: Gen. Leontii Shevtsov is learning English.

title: Need some passport information? Well, the State Department will now sell it to you.
description: THE State Department, which got a black eye earlier this year for delays in processing passport applications, has started a ''900'' number that travelers can call for passport information.

title: Officer Acquitted in Bronx Death to Face Hearing
description: The New York Police Department has scheduled a disciplinary hearing in January to decide the professional fate of Officer Francis X. Livoti, who was recently acquitted in the 1994 choking death of a Bronx man.

title: White House Lists Donors for '93 Inauguration
description: James T. Riady and John Huang, two men at the center of questions about Democratic Party finances, jointly gave $100,000 to help pay for public events in President Clinton's inauguration celebration in 1993, the White House said today.

title: Copper Prices Are Up Sharply As Tight Supply Spurs Buying
description: Copper prices surged yesterday as the 12th consecutive weekly decline in London Metal Exchange inventories heightened concern over possible shortages.

title: Cornell's Levitt Cited
description: CHAD LEVITT, Cornell's near-record-breaking running back, was chosen by the Ivy League's eight coaches yesterday as the winner of the Asa Bushnell Cup as player of the year. Levitt missed the league career rushing record by 85 yards when he broke his arm in the next to last game against Columbia. He ran for 1,435 yards this season.

title: Dance in Review
description: Going Bump in the Night,

title: Domecq Importers Opens a Search
description: The Domecq Importers unit of Allied Domecq P.L.C., said yesterday that it had begun a search for an agency to handle advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers for two brands of imported brandy, Presidente and Don Pedro. The account, with billings estimated at more than $1 million, had been handled for more than five years by Robles Communications in New York, which is not participating in the review.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 14 with an article about a fugitive Dominican drug suspect named Santiago Luis Polanco-Rodriguez misstated his business relationship with the Hotel Camino Real and El Gran Almirante Hotel and Casino in Santiago, Dominican Republic. Dominican police officials say the properties are controlled by Mr. Polanco-Rodriguez through third parties; he is not an owner of record.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: Kennedy's Stolen Vehicle Is Recovered
description: When Detective Arthur Masinski and his partner, Thomas Bellino, gave chase to four men who were fighting with baseball bats on Staten Island last month, neither knew where the case would lead.

title: Rapidly Growing Number of U.S. College Applicants Get Early Word
description: Competing to attract good students, a broad range of public and small private colleges and universities are taking a page from more elite institutions by creating or expanding programs in which prospective students learn months earlier than usual whether they have been accepted for admission the following fall.

title: KOLL TO SWAP $194 MILLION IN DEBT FOR STOCK
description: Koll Real Estate Group Inc. said yesterday that it was offering to swap $194 million in debt securities for stock. Koll, a real-estate developer based in Newport Beach, Calif., said the deal would leave it ''virtually debt-free.'' The swap must be approved by debtholders representing 90 percent of Koll's debt securities. Holders of Koll debt will receive either 4,525 or 2,262 shares in the company for each $1,000 of principal, depending on which type of debt they hold. If 100 percent of the offer is accepted, debtholders would own 90 percent of Koll's equity, represented by newly issued common stock. Shares of Koll rose 3.125 cents, to close at 18.75 cents, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: A.A.R.P. in Health Plan Talks With Managed-Care Businesses
description: The American Association of Retired Persons has said that it is in discussions about endorsing managed-care plans for its 30 million members with U.S. Healthcare, Kaiser Permanente and seven other health maintenance organizations in 18 markets across the nation, and that it hopes those plans will be available by mid-1997.

title: University of Alabama Offers 2 Years' Free Rent in Dorms
description: The University of Alabama has announced a program meant to lower the cost of housing for some students while fostering a greater sense of community on campus.

title: COLLEGE SOCCER REPORT
description: Big East

title: CLINTON CONSIDERS MOVE TO SOFTEN CUTS IN WELFARE
description: To soften the impact of the new welfare law on poor people and immigrants, President Clinton wants Congress to restore about one-fourth of the $55 billion that would otherwise be saved by the law over the next six years, Administration officials said today.

title: Dance in Review
description: The Geometry of Bodies

title: Disney to Defy China On Dalai Lama Film
description: The Walt Disney Company, facing a warning by the Chinese Government over ''Kundun,'' a new Martin Scorsese film about the life of the Dalai Lama, said yesterday that it intended to release the film in the United States next year.

title: Japanese Banks to Aid Customers of Hanwa
description: Japanese banks are ready to help ''healthy'' customers who borrowed money from the failed Hanwa Bank by providing loans and other services, the head of the bankers association said yesterday. The Federation of Bankers Associations of Japan said the Finance Ministry wants commercial banks; the Small Business Finance Corporation, a state-run bank for small businesses, and local governments around Osaka, the area Hanwa served, to provide loans to Hanwa customers.

title: Borders in Stock Buyback
description: Borders Group Inc., the retailer of books and music, said today that it would buy back up to $50 million of its common stock. Borders, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., has 37.8 million common shares outstanding. The company said one reason for the buyback was to increase earnings per share by reducing the total number of shares outstanding. Shares of Borders Group were up 87.5 cents, to $36.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Covert Foreign Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Confidence Is Real Victim of Fire Under the English Channel
description: As a symbol of the difficulties of building a closely knit Europe, the 32-mile Eurotunnel linking France and Britain has been full of lessons: plagued by delays, deficits and disagreement, but hailed when it finally opened two years ago as the ultimate in technology, comfort and safety.

title: Circling the Bandwagons To Imitate an Imitation
description: Stone Temple Pilots revealed their fondest hopes when they brought out two members of Aerosmith, Steven Tyler and Joe Perry, in the middle of their concert on Monday night at Madison Square Garden. For a good part of the 1970's, Aerosmith was hugely popular while critics dismissed the band as a dumbed-down Rolling Stones imitation. After a downward spiral of drug problems and waning popularity, Aerosmith re-emerged in the late 1980's with renewed popularity and a modicum of respect.

title: New Questions on Antibiotics for Ear Infection
description: IT is hard to imagine going through childhood without at least one bottle of what children call ''the pink stuff'' or ''the good-tasting stuff,'' otherwise known as amoxicillin. More than half of children have had the antibiotic by the time they are 7 months old, mostly for middle-ear infections.

title: Pen Stroke Has Teacher In Trouble
description: No one disputes that Phyllis Adelsflugel made a mistake when she wrote ''Where are my glasses!'' in bold, blue letters across the cheeks of one of her 5-year-old students.

title: Labor Talks Fail In Germany
description: A third try by German employers and IG Metall, Germany's largest union, to negotiate an agreement on sick pay was abandoned yesterday in Dusseldorf, prompting threats of full-blown strikes.

title: High-Heat Roasting Makes Tom Turkey A Bird of Paradise
description: A STARTLING and relatively new method for roasting poultry can make even today's bland, overbred turkeys memorable. The blast-heat method will produce a crisp-skin bird with moist, intensely flavorful white and dark meat.

title: INSIDE
description: Simpson Testimony Ends

title: Treasury Prices End Day Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities turned mixed yesterday, gaining early on signs that consumer confidence is not rising and that the economy is not growing rapidly, only to fall as some traders began to take profits.

title: Penguin Is Buying MCA's Putnam Berkley for $336 Million
description: In a move meant to combine old-style literary sensibilities with commercial publishing acumen, the Penguin Group, the international publisher, plans to acquire the Putnam Berkley Group, a United States subsidiary of MCA Inc., for $336 million in cash in a deal announced today by Penguin's owner, Pearson P.L.C.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVE BARRY has signed a contract for his first novel. That is as much as he has written so far.

title: Food Notes
description: Eating and Driving: A Warning

title: Caution on Marketing Possibilities
description: The labor deal ratified by baseball's owners yesterday removes a big obstacle to the renewed marketing of the sport, but experts said it won't immediately turn companies skittish about baseball into a gold rush of paying sponsors.

title: Personal Health
description: IS that cold you caught two weeks ago still hanging on? Chances are it is no longer a cold but a sinus infection, and chances are it will not go away on its own. In fact, failing to get prompt and proper medical treatment could result in serious complications or a chronic sinus problem that requires prolonged therapy and even surgery to correct.

title: I.B.M. Allots $3.5 Billion More to Buy Back Stock
description: Despite a rally that has sent its shares up more than 15 percent in the last 12 days, I.B.M.'s board authorized the company yesterday to spend an additional $3.5 billion to buy its own shares on the open market.

title: Hughes Signs Up to Launch Satellites on Japan Rockets
description: Japan's fledgling effort to develop a space business received a major boost today as the Hughes Electronics Corporation became the first company to sign up to launch commercial satellites on a Japanese rocket now under development.

title: A Bloomie Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: A Slow Recovery Is Seen in Japan
description: Japan's most-watched economic indicator, the Bank of Japan's survey of business sentiment, known as the tankan, confirmed that a full recovery was still not in sight.

title: Egypt Adding Corn to Bread: An Explosive Mix?
description: In Egypt, the word for bread and the word for life are the same: aish. And that is where things begin to get tangled.

title: Calipari Can't Predict Future for Bradley
description: Reaching Shawn Bradley can seem as impossible as grasping a hologram, an image of potential that appears unreal and untouchable at times.

title: Stats Prove Jets Can't Find Suitable Alibi
description: If you are still not sure why the Jets (1-11) have the worst record in the National Football League, consider this:

title: Old Revolutionary Is a New Power to Be Reckoned With in Central Africa
description: In the last two months, a rebel force few had ever heard of before has solved a problem in eastern Zaire that the United Nations and Western democracies could not solve in two years.

title: Creative Steelers Are Rolling Along
description: If you are in the opposing coaches' box against the Pittsburgh Steelers, if you are trying to make the calls on offense and on defense against the Steelers' footloose approach on both sides of the ball, here are the items required before you even tackle the task: a full bottle of aspirin; a bag of ice and plenty of elbow room to scratch your head once or twice.

title: Preserve David Kessler's Legacy
description: As he announced this week that he would step down as head of the Food and Drug Administration, David Kessler told a television interviewer: ''We did what we set out to do. We're done.'' Dr. Kessler has made great strides in speeding up the drug-approval process, standardizing food labels and moving vigorously to regulate tobacco. He revitalized a beleaguered agency that had become mired in bureaucratic disarray.

title: Big Financial Merger Announced in Malaysia
description: Rashid Hussain Bhd. said yesterday that it was buying a 75 percent stake in Kwong Yik Bank Bhd. for 2.16 billion ringgit ($857 million) and merging it with Rashid Hussain's banking and securities business. The move will create the largest financial services company in Malaysia. Further consolidations are expected in the crowded Malaysian banking industry, which has 37 commercial banks, including 13 local subsidiaries of foreign banks, serving 19 million people.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Where to Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue at Privately Run Prison Draws High Court's Review
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether prison guards who work for private companies that run prisons in a growing number of states should have the same shield against prisoner lawsuits that guards who work for state agencies now enjoy.

title: Blacks and Redistricting
description: To the Editor:

title: Egyptians Support Boutros-Ghali's U.N. Bid
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbian Leader, Ignoring Protests, Holds a New Election
description: The Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, ignoring protesters in the street, and flouting warnings from the West, pressed ahead today with a new round of voting intended to give his ruling party the victory it was denied at the polls.

title: Kiwi Airlines Gets a Hand
description: Financially strapped Kiwi International Airlines could be back in the air by Christmas with the help of a Maryland surgeon. A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday approved a $5 million loan to the carrier from an investment group led by Dr. Charles C. Edwards, The Associated Press reported. Dr. Edwards joined forces with a former Kiwi suitor, Wasatch International , to come up with the money. The four-year-old airline filed for bankruptcy Sept. 30 and grounded its planes two weeks later.

title: Gerry Cosby, 87, Sports Merchandiser
description: Gerry Cosby, who founded the sporting goods and athletic equipment company that bears his name, died on Tuesday in Stockbridge, Mass., where he had lived for the last 50 years. He was 87.

title: Connect the Dots
description: As post-election revelations come spilling out about more illegal fund-raising and many more unrecorded meetings of the Asian connection in the Clinton White House, the need arises to connect the dots.

title: 2-Inch Letters Rouse A Big War In the Park
description: IT started when some residents of Fifth Avenue looked out their windows one day and saw a blue and orange jungle gym in the park across the street. Central Park, that is. No sooner was that problem resolved than park enthusiasts were horrified by another proposal: to install several information kiosks in the park, each with maps, directions and a donor's name.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANTA CORP., Spring House, Pa., said James W. John, senior vice president for corporate administration, had been promoted to president of Advanta International.

title: Verdict in Infants' Deaths
description: Maria Dolores Montalvo, prosecutors say, was distraught when the father of her two children walked out of their home in Union Beach and moved back in with his parents. So distraught that she filled her car with papers, drove the children to her in-laws' house, parked in the driveway with the toddlers inside, tossed a container of gas and a burning object in and ran as the car exploded in flames.

title: Respectful Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: The National Pastime's True M.V.P.
description: A new baseball labor agreement was so elusive that it defied the intervention of President Clinton. Then Randy Levine came along.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 2d Murder Charge Is Filed
description: The 11-month-old mystery of a young man's disappearance ended yesterday with the discovery of his body and a second murder charge against a man already accused of killing his own great-uncle, Burlington County prosecutors said.

title: Tar Heel Is Reinstated
description: MAKHTAR NDIAYE, the only player suspended by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in DEAN SMITH's 36 seasons at North Carolina, has been reinstated, the school said yesterday.

title: Philadelphians, After Strike, Offer a Violinist's Debut
description: The musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra, under their frequent guest conductor Christoph Eschenbach, tore into Verdi's Overture to ''La Forza del Destino'' on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall as if they had something to prove.

title: Bissell Bragged to the End
description: Even as Federal agents closed in on Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. in an out-of-the-way gambling town on the Colorado River, the fugitive former prosecutor seemed every bit his old self: upbeat, confident, even cocky. ''He was just bragging about how he got away and how he fooled everybody,'' a lawyer for Mr. Bissell's wife said yesterday, recounting a cellular-phone call Mr. Bissell made to his wife the day before he shot himself to death. Legal experts said that Faith S. Hochberg, the United States Attorney who prosecuted Mr. Bissell, but could not bring him back alive, handled the case well. $(Pages A1 and B4.$)

title: Paul Rand, 82, Creator of Sleek Graphic Designs, Dies
description: Paul Rand, a seminal figure in graphic design who made innovative visual identities for some of America's major corporations and book and magazine publishers, died on Tuesday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 82.

title: U.N. Reports 3 Million New H.I.V. Cases Worldwide for '96
description: More than three million people, mostly under age 25, have become newly infected with the AIDS virus this year, officials of the United Nations and the World Health Organization said today. They stressed the need for more vigorous programs to prevent further spread of the virus because it is being transmitted in all countries.

title: In Tower at Kennedy, Rush Hour All Day
description: It was 3:45 on the afternoon when rush hour seems to be all day, the day before Thanksgiving. Five big jets were lined up on the controllers' radar screens for arrival on Runway 31 Left at Kennedy International Airport, part of the mad rush of ''everybody going home to Grandma,'' as the chief air traffic control official put it.

title: Adopting a Cat Gets Complicated
description: IF you're looking to adopt a cat at Christmas, the peak adoption time, be prepared to prove you are the perfect parent.

title: William H. Bowen, 80, Lawyer And Venture Capitalist in Dallas
description: William H. Bowen, a lawyer and venture capitalist, died last Thursday at his Dallas home. He was 80.

title: Awards for Wuerffel
description: Florida quarterback DANNY WUERFFEL, leader of the nation's most prolific offense and the No. 1-ranked team, was chosen winner of two prestigious awards yesterday.

title: Garrett Birkhoff, 85, Mathematics Theorist, Dies
description: Garrett Birkhoff, a retired professor of pure and applied mathematics at Harvard University, died on Friday at his home in Water Mill, L.I., where he had moved from Cambridge, Mass., a year ago. He was 85.

title: Roving Test: Room Scents, Savvy Noses
description: THERE are a million scents in the Naked City. Fortunately, a home-fragrance spray called Bunny is only one of them.

title: The E.P.A.'s tough standards: cost isn't a consideration.
description: AFTER years of hinting, the Environmental Protection Agency now wants to tighten air quality standards for ozone and the tiny particles in dust and soot.

title: Baccarat Crystal Moves From the Table to the Door
description: IN a market deluged with decorative hardware, the announcement of yet another collection of drawer pulls and doorknobs is not usually cause for fanfare. But when the new player is Baccarat, the French maker of gleaming crystal goblets and chandeliers, it attracts the curious.

title: To Portuguese, an Artificial Quake Is Still a Quake
description: Luis Mendes Victor, normally a tranquil seismology professor in Lisbon, had been looking forward to the big explosions. He and his team had chartered a ship and armed themselves with 22 tons of TNT which they planned to detonate at sea.

title: AT&T's Discount-Call Offer Disrupts Japan's Phone Market
description: AT&T shook up Japan's telecommunications market today by offering to provide discount international calls to Japanese customers using a controversial technique that some countries prohibit and which AT&T itself once condemned as unfair.

title: If 'Art' Is for Art's Sake, It's Also a Career Lift For Its French Creator
description: A London theater production that has good roles for both Albert Finney and Tom Courtenay already has a lot going for it. Add to that a clever play with loads of laughs that ends in good time for a 10 P.M. dinner reservation. What more could the Wyndham's Theater ask for? The blessing of critics? ''Art,'' as the 90-minute one-act play is called, has had that, too.
