title: How Not to Book Better Math and Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Returning From Layoff, Kelly Kip Shows Speed
description: Kelly Kip can still run fast. At least, after three months of resting and treatment of a lung infection, he ran fast enough yesterday to beat Confide by two lengths and Oro Bandito by 5 1/2 in the Huntington at Aqueduct for his fourth victory in five starts.

title: 3d Teen-Ager Guilty In Subway Murder
description: A third teen-ager was convicted of murder yesterday in the death of a subway token clerk whose Brooklyn booth was turned into an inferno by robbers using gasoline and matches.

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. The stock and bond markets and the commodity markets in Chicago will reopen tomorrow, but will end trading in the early afternoon; the commodity markets in New York will be closed until Monday.

title: Film Makers Fail to Win Concession in Digital TV Standard
description: This week's landmark agreement on a uniform standard for digital television left a conspicuous group unhappy: Hollywood directors and cinematographers. Despite aggressive lobbying by directors like Steven Spielberg, the film makers received no assurances that their movie images would not be cropped to fit the screens of the next generation of television sets.

title: U.S. JUDGE BLOCKS VOTERS' INITIATIVE ON JOB PREFERENCE
description: A Federal judge today blocked enforcement of Proposition 209, the newly passed California citizen initiative that prohibits the use of race and sexual preferences in state-run affirmative action programs. He said there was a ''strong probability'' that it might be unconstitutional.

title: Elrey B. Jeppesen, Pilots' Friend, Dies at 89
description: Elrey B. Jeppesen, an aviation pioneer, died on Tuesday at his home in Denver. He was 89.

title: Train Kills Worker
description: A high-speed Amtrak train struck and killed a track worker in Secaucus, N.J., yesterday morning shortly after 6 A.M. The worker, Aaron King, 53, of North Bergen, N.J., was hit by a southbound Metroliner about a mile from where another Amtrak train jumped the tracks on Saturday. There was no apparent connection.

title: Messier Soldiers Rangers to Victory Over Avalanche
description: There are certain times during the season when the Rangers' captain, Mark Messier, proves why he has been all but canonized, and tonight was one of those glorious games.

title: Investor Suit Granted Class-Action Status
description: Investors suing 33 Nasdaq market makers received class-action status yesterday to proceed with their 1994 antitrust case accusing the brokerage firms of rigging stock prices.

title: Lithuania Will Share Jewish Books, but How?
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea Frees American, Prompting Optimism on Other Issues
description: North Korea today released a young American missionary whom it had detained on charges of spying, and the Congressman who negotiated the release said North Korea seemed willing to increase cooperation in other areas as well.

title: Bonds End Short Session A Bit Higher
description: Treasury prices ended slightly higher in a shortened session yesterday, retreating from session highs on economic data that were somewhat stronger than expected.

title: Miami Looks to State for Fiscal Oversight
description: Gov. Lawton Chiles is considering whether to establish state financial oversight of the City of Miami after being told by the Mayor that its fiscal problems were dire enough for such a step.

title: Playoff Routes Only Rube Goldberg Could Love
description: Pick up a rock. Aim at the moon. And throw. You have a better chance of hitting it than the Giants do of making the playoffs.

title: Secrets of the Olive And All It's Good For
description: OLIVES

title: Harmful Discipline
description: To The Home Section:

title: Songs for Recitals and Shows
description: Donald Gramm and Bethany Beardslee

title: A Breakthrough for Sharper TV
description: Millions of Americans will spend part of today watching parades and professional football on conventional television. But two Thanksgivings from now, a new generation of television sets will make the viewing much sharper -- with pictures of football plays as vivid as movies and sounds of marching bands as vibrant as CD's. An agreement this week between the computer and television industries will finally break the logjam that has kept digital television, a major advance over today's analogue technology, from the airways.

title: Now It's Neagle's Turn: Four Years, $18 Million
description: One week after giving JOHN SMOLTZ a $31 million, four-year deal, the Atlanta Braves agreed yesterday to a $18 million, four-year contract with DENNY NEAGLE.

title: U.S. BACKS CANADA ON AIRLIFT TO FEED RWANDAN REFUGEES
description: Forgoing the idea of an international military operation on the ground in Zaire and Rwanda, the United States today endorsed a proposal by Canada to deliver food to thousands of Rwandan refugees still in eastern Zaire by dropping it from the air, probably using an airport in neighboring Uganda.

title: Broken U.S. Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pop Life
description: Charlie Louvin

title: Hilton Gets a Gaming License
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation moved one step closer to buying the Bally Entertainment Corporation yesterday when the State Casino Control Commission granted Hilton a gaming license, the A.P. reported. Hilton, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., is looking to buy Bally, which operates the Grand and Bally's Park Place casinos, for $3 billion.

title: Spicy Nibbles Before the Sugarplums
description: Revealingly, the less one sees of the New York City Ballet, the more one realizes how this magnificent enterprise should not be taken for granted.

title: Bre-X Minerals Told To Split Gold Find
description: Bre-X Minerals Ltd., under orders from the Indonesian Government, is in talks to sell 75 percent of its estimated $4.44 billion gold deposit on the island of Borneo to the Barrick Gold Corporation.

title: U.S. Expands Inquiry Into Alcohol Ads
description: In an investigation that expands Government concern about alcohol advertising to the beer industry, the Federal Trade Commission is looking at whether the Stroh Brewing Company is running television ads that are aimed at underage viewers, Government officials said today.

title: Bronx Police Officer Arrested In a Racism Incident Upstate
description: A Bronx police officer has been arrested and suspended from his job for pasting racist and neo-Nazi stickers on the bathroom wall of a bar in Orange County, police officials said yesterday.

title: In Russia, Whistle-Blowing Can Still Be Treason
description: It began with an early-morning knock at the door. Aleksandr Nikitin, a researcher for a Norwegian environmental organization and a former Russian naval officer, was still asleep. But the security police insisted that he quickly dress and come along.

title: No Headline
description: ''I asked Mother if there is anything I could bring. And she said, 'One of those pies.' I just want to make my mom happy.'' DENNIS WEAVER, in a long line at a midtown pie shop. $(B3:3$)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Computer Stocks Rally, But Dow Declines 29.07

title: Trial Ends In Hung Jury In '81 Killing Of a Surgeon
description: A gunshot during a botched robbery ended the life of a young surgeon on a Manhattan street, and the city recoiled from the senseless waste. But public attention is fleeting, and interest in the shooting faded almost as quickly as the echoes of the shot that killed Dr. John Wood in 1981.

title: Mayor Says He Has No Plans To Go to Dominican Republic
description: Only two days after Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced that he and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would travel to the Dominican Republic and increase cooperation with the Dominican police, the Mayor said yesterday that he had no such plans to visit the Caribbean nation.

title: Ward Will Get Starting Nod at Point Over Childs
description: It is not a major roster shake-up or an indictment of Chris Childs, but Coach Jeff Van Gundy's decision to start Charlie Ward on Saturday raises a question:

title: Ex-Prosecutor Was Cavalier In Disregard for Trail He Left
description: Even as Federal agents closed in on Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. in this out-of-the-way gambling town on the Colorado River, the fugitive former prosecutor from Somerset County, N.J., seemed every bit his old self: upbeat, confident, even cocky.

title: Suspension from Board
description: A member of the Newark Board of Education who was indicted last week on charges that he stole more than $6,000 from the Essex County welfare system was suspended from the board yesterday. Terrance Bain was removed from the board of the state-run Newark district by the Education Commissioner, Leo Klagholz, pending further review of his case.

title: A Film in the Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandberg Again a Cub
description: RYNE SANDBERG decided to return to the Chicago Cubs, agreeing to a $3.5 million, one-year contract with a team option for 1998.

title: Political Heavyweights in South Carolina Back Governor on Rebel Banner
description: It was no surprise that many black leaders in South Carolina supported Gov. David Beasley's appeal, in a statewide television address, to remove the Confederate battle flag from the Capitol. Nor was it a surprise when some conservative white state officials called him a traitor and accused him of trading his heritage for a chance to be seen as ''politically correct.''

title: Philip Birnbaum, 89, Builder Celebrated for His Efficiency
description: Philip Birnbaum, the almost anonymous architectural hand behind many of the most imposing apartment towers in New York City, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Judge Makes It Harder for New York to Turn Away Homeless
description: New York City must do a better job of determining whether homeless families have someplace else to go before denying them places in its shelter system, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 18 about a rift between the Borders bookstore chain and an author, Michael Moore, misidentified the labor group trying to unionize a store in Philadelphia. It is the Industrial Workers of the World, not the International Workers of the World.

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Administration Issues Its Proposal For Tightening of Air Standards
description: The Clinton Administration today proposed tighter air quality standards for the nation, saying that children, asthmatics, people who work outdoors and the frail elderly needed more protection from choking smog and soot and that the health and economic benefits would vastly outweigh the costs of new pollution controls.

title: France Acts to End Crippling Truck Blockades
description: With financial aid from a French Government desperate to avoid a repetition of the paralyzing transportation strikes last winter, French truck drivers and their employers tried to reach agreement tonight on a package of pay increases and an early retirement plan to end a crippling blockade of French highways by the drivers.

title: INSIDE
description: North Korea Frees American

title: Conrail Dispatchers in Pact
description: Conrail Inc. and its train dispatchers' union have reached a tentative agreement on a new labor contract. Neither side would discuss details of the agreement, pending a union ratification vote. About 400 train dispatchers are members of the System Committee of the American Train Dispatchers Department of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Winterberry

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: C.H.S.F.L.

title: Upbeat on the Labor Front Around Shea
description: Shortly after the owners approved a new basic agreement with the players on Tuesday, Jerry Reinsdorf, the taciturn owner of the Chicago White Sox, said that the contract would sound a death knell for small-market clubs.

title: Advocates for Children
description: To The Home Section:

title: For Jets' Johnson, Complaints Are Following Frustration
description: It happens to all the great ones, Keyshawn Johnson explained today, following his most frustrating stretch as a Jet. If he doesn't get the ball early, he'll drop the ball late.

title: Bridge
description: Some world-famous players were among the winners in the Open Board-a-Match Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in San Francisco Monday night. Zia Mahmood of Manhattan, Michael Rosenberg of Tuckahoe, N.Y., Peter Weichsel of Encenitas, Calif., and Robert Levin of Orlando, Fla., scored 39.06 boards to take the title, together with Robert Baldwin of Las Vegas.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the crash of an Ethiopian jetliner in the Indian Ocean misstated the timing in some copies. It occurred on Saturday, not Sunday.

title: Long, Nasty And Brutish: Isles Foil The Flyers
description: Oh, this was a dirty little hockey game, full of spite and bile. The fighting, slashing and yapping stretched the length to almost three hours.

title: Judge Halts California Cutoff of Prenatal Care to Illegal Aliens
description: Less than a week before thousands of illegal immigrants in California were to start losing state money for prenatal care because of an order by the Governor, a San Francisco Superior Court judge has blocked the plan, saying the state could not support ordering a cutoff on an emergency basis.

title: A Mood of Looking Inward, Enlivened by Some Twinkles
description: Introspection dominated ''Fresh Tracks,'' a program of premieres. Yet the presentation on Tuesday night at Dance Theater Workshop was most enjoyable when the dancers gazed outward at the world with a twinkle in their eyes.

title: New Textures Add to Vinyl's Virtues
description: IN the world of vinyl wall coverings, one usually puts up with vinyl's industrial look in order to get the benefit of its virtues -- chiefly stain resistance and ease of cleaning. But this new collection from Knoll, which has carried vinyl wall coverings for at least 20 years, has a subtlety missing from most of them: it is not one piece, but woven strands of vinyl-coated polyester. The result feels like fabric and looks a bit like a knit sweater.

title: CRESTAR IS PURCHASING STUDENT LOAN BUSINESS
description: The Crestar Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the student loan business of the Great Western Financial Corporation, including $370 million of loans in California and Florida. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, but Great Western, the second-largest United States savings institution, said it expected an after-tax gain of $13.8 million in the fourth quarter from the sale, which is part of Great Western's plans to focus on its more profitable consumer lending business. The company is also considering selling or creating a joint venture for its mutual funds subsidiary, Sierra Capital Management. The acquisition would increase the student loan portfolio of Crestar, which is based in Richmond, to about $900 million.

title: Mozart's Father, Too, Could Turn a Phrase
description: Most orchestra musicians warm up onstage as the audience drifts in. But the musicians of the Jupiter Symphony seemed to be warmed up with extra intensity on Monday afternoon at the Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church. This scrappy ensemble is always short of funds, so rehearsal time is minimal. Amid the pre-concert cacophony, you could hear individual players trying one last time to shape a solo line or nail a difficult passage.

title: At Last, Baseball Peace
description: When baseball's owners voted on Tuesday to accept a labor agreement they had rejected only three weeks before, they assured baseball's fans of five years of peace and uninterrupted play. The deal took four years and a destructive 232-day strike to accomplish. But we are happy to have it.

title: Cardinal Health to Purchase Owen Healthcare
description: Cardinal Health Inc. said today that it would buy Owen Healthcare Inc. for $27.25 a share, or $496 million, in stock, broadening the range of services it offers to hospitals.

title: Mets Deal Brogna Away To Obtain Bullpen Help
description: Rico Brogna, once considered a cornerstone to the Mets' rebuilding process, became a stepping stone in the team's efforts to rebuild its bullpen yesterday when he was sent to Philadelphia in exchange for a pair of relief pitchers.

title: TODAY'S N.F.L. MATCHUP
description: THURSDAY 12:30 P.M. GAME

title: VACATION BREAK TO ACQUIRE ITS COMPETITOR
description: Vacation Break USA Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Berkley Group, a rival time-share resort developer, for stock worth $225.8 million at Tuesday's closing price. The transaction will leave Berkley shareholders with control of the combined company. Yesterday, Vacation Break shares rose $6 to close at $16.75 in Nasdaq trading. Vacation Break, which has nine million shares outstanding, said it would issue 21 million shares to pay for the closely held Berkley's time-share resorts. Vacation Break markets and finances time-sharing interests in Florida and Bahamas resorts, and the combined company will have resort properties in Virginia, Florida and the Bahamas. Both are based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Large Companies Financing Giuliani's Megastore Radio Ads
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's radio campaign to promote superstores in New York City has raised $67,500, almost all of it from large real estate and construction companies, according to documents released yesterday.

title: A Racial Reversal in a Hit Parade of Oldies
description: It is only near the end of ''A Brief History of White Music,'' a new jukebox-style revue at the Village Gate on 52d Street, that this jolly trifle of a show with a racial gimmick demonstrates what it might have been had it taken itself a bit more seriously. During a tribute to the Beatles, James Alexander, one of the show's three unflappably perky performers, delivers a flowery gospel-style version of ''I Want to Hold Your Hand'' that evokes the ornate, slowed-up treatment Luther Vandross likes to apply to 1960's oldies.

title: A Swiveling, Folding, Lint-Eating Hanger
description: CLOTHES hangers are not, by and large, the most glamorous of household objects. One exception is the folding travel hanger created by Keesjan Klant, a Swiss designer.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Lining Up for a Movie? No, for a Pie
description: This is the first year the Little Pie Company has set out barricades -- not big and blue, police style, but painted a tasteful white -- and it was a good thing, because John Outcalt was standing there in the cold yesterday just before 7 A.M., vaguely threatening violence.

title: Germany Striving to Maintain Ties to Iran Despite Slaying Case
description: FRANKFURT  It takes more than allegations of terrorism and riots at the German Embassy in Tehran to shake Germany's policy of using century-old trade ties as the centerpiece of its diplomacy with Iran.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 19 about research on a new generation of psychiatric drugs misstated a previous affiliation of Dr. James H. Heym, a researcher at Pfizer Central Research in Groton, Conn. He was a research fellow at Princeton, not a professor of psychiatry at Yale.

title: Religion as Spectator Sport
description: Be not forgetful to entertain strangers: for thereby some have entertained angels unawares.-- Hebrews 13:2

title: Calendar: Shows and Talks
description: Mark Hampton's 19th Century

title: Building a Future, House by House
description: MORTAR and cinder block.

title: Guidance, Not Punishment
description: To The Home Section:

title: Summoning The Healing Natural Light Of Outdoors
description: WINTER is coming, and for some people it means not just lower temperatures and shorter days -- but also seasonal affective disorder, a type of depression that hits during the cold months. And most people experience a less severe form, known by a less technical name -- the blahs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Federal aid for development along the Erie Canal rendered a quotation by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan incorrectly. He said the canal was ''where canning began,'' not where cannons began.

title: Welfare Offices Start Issuing Checks to Make Up for Error
description: Welfare offices across the city started issuing emergency checks yesterday to some of the 6,368 people who were thrown off welfare rolls because of a computer error, and city officials said offices would be open on Thanksgiving to assure that the benefits get to families.

title: An Insider's Guide to the Homey Home Office
description: NOW it was my turn. For shame's sake, if for no other reason, it was time to create my own home office. After all, I had spent the last two years immersing myself in other people's work spaces for a book on home offices -- only to find myself writing it in a crowded corner of my bedroom. Tired of seeing piles of photographs next to piles of socks, I couldn't cope with my own disorganization. I felt like Travis Bickle descending into madness in ''Taxi Driver'' -- the scene where he says to Betsy, the campaign worker, ''One of these days, I got to get organizized.''

title: Snow Traded to Giants
description: Anaheim traded J. T. SNOW, a two-time Gold Glove first baseman, to San Francisco for pitcher ALLEN WATSON. The Angels will pay the Giants an undisclosed amount of cash in the deal.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: STROBER SAYS UNSOLICITED TAKEOVER BID IS WITHDRAWN
description: Strober Organization Inc. said yesterday that an undisclosed bidder had withdrawn an unsolicited $35 million offer because it could not obtain financing. Strober, a supplier of building materials based in New York, said it received the bid of $6.50 a share on Nov. 20. The company had agreed earlier to be acquired by a group of private investors for $6 a share in cash, or about $32 million. Strober said that agreement remained in place and was expected to be completed by February. Strober stock fell 25 cents yesterday, to $5.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: A Cultural Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz's New Gig: Go Along and Get Along
description: For its 10th anniversary, the Thelonious Monk Institute gave itself a party. Not a simple party, either: with participants like Stevie Wonder, K. D. Lang, Bill Cosby, Tony Bennett, Natalie Cole and other entertainment stars, it was a party aimed directly at television -- it will be broadcast on Dec. 28 on ABC -- and at the heartland. It will be the first time in nearly three decades that jazz has been on network television in this fashion.

title: A Low-Key Crime Fighter With High-Profile Cases
description: Sitting in her seventh-floor conference room, which looks over the Federal Courthouse, much of Newark and part of Manhattan, Faith S. Hochberg occasionally muses about what she might do if she were not the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: Japanese Stocks Drop
description: Japanese stocks declined sharply here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues had dropped 309.74 points, or 1.45 percent, to 21,035.54. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 72.97 points.

title: Metrocard Holiday Giveaway Project Gets Stalled at the Gate
description: Everyone involved thought it was a great idea: On Friday, historically the busiest shopping day of the year, the Transit Authority and the City Department of Transportation would hand out 20,000 free Metrocards. And that generosity would have purpose: promoting mass transit, combating traffic and bolstering the much-maligned card.

title: Tribute to a 50's House
description: To The Home Section:

title: U.S. to Review Disability Aid For Children
description: The Government sent letters to the parents of 260,000 children today notifying them that the children might lose disability benefits because of the new welfare law.

title: Long and Bitter Sibling Rivalry At Value Line Ends in a Deal
description: The long, bitter dispute between the twins who jointly own 80 percent of Value Line Inc. has been settled -- but on terms that raise intriguing issues for the financial publishing and mutual fund management company's public shareholders.

title: Filling Potholes In 'Road Ahead'
description: IN the techno-future foreseen by Bill Gates, people will have no need to carry money, identification or a watch. They will use a wallet PC, a hand-held computer that stores digital cash and information.

title: Singing Ghosts and Indoor Snow: Must Be Dickens
description: ''A Christmas Carol'' has returned to Madison Square Garden, looking much as it did last year. Same clever sets by Tony Walton that could have come out of a pop-up children's book. Same evocative costumes by William Ivey Long that turn Marley's Ghost and the other ghouls into a Day-Glo chain gang. Same peppy choreography by Susan Stroman that transforms the Fezziwigs' ball into a lavish 19th-century blowout.

title: Thanksgiving Is...
description: Correction Appended

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Concern Aids Japanese Bribe Inquiry
description: Allergan Inc.'s Japanese unit said today that it was cooperating with the authorities in an investigation into bribery involving a professor who conducted studies of an experimental Allergan drug.

title: Indiana and Duke Win, Just Barely
description: Indiana University is an icon of college basketball, winner of national championships, celebrated in books and movies, home ground of the bombastic Coach Bobby Knight. Evansville is, well, Evansville, which struggled last season to a 13-14 record and fifth place in the Missouri Valley Conference.

title: Channel Tunnel May Reopen Next Week
description: French and British officials of the company that operates the Channel Tunnel said today that they had asked safety authorities to let them resume high-speed passenger service linking Paris, London and Brussels next week, despite heavy damage caused by a fire nine days ago on a train carrying trailer trucks.

title: BOSTON INVESTMENT FIRM TO ACQUIRE CENTRAL TRACTOR
description: J. W. Childs Equity Partners L.P., a Boston investment firm, agreed yesterday to buy Central Tractor Farm and Country Inc. for about $156 million. Central Tractor, a retailer of agricultural products and hardware based in Des Moines, said its shareholders would receive $14.25 a share in the two-step transaction, which was announced after the close of stock trading yesterday. Affiliates of the Butler Capital Corporation, which owns 64.5 percent of Central Tractor, will sell their shares for $14 apiece. Childs will then acquire shares held by other shareholders for $14.25 in cash. Central Tractor stock closed yesterday at $11.75 a share, down 37.5 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: At Utah Plant, Safety Debate Rages
description: Packed with one of deadliest nerve agents known to man, aging olive green rockets were stacked on wooden pallets, awaiting incineration. Suddenly, an alarm sounded and all visitors were ordered out of the building, portable gas masks banging at their sides.

title: France Names Chief For GAN Insurer
description: Hours after removing the chairman of the state-owned insurance company GAN, the French Finance Ministry yesterday chose the vice chairman of the rival insurer UAP, to replace him.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BIACORE A.B., the analytical instruments business of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., sold five million American depository shares for $80 million, or $16 each, in an initial public offering yesterday.

title: Creative Solutions To Tame Unruly Papers
description: IF this is the paperless age of the computer, why is it that papers keep piling up on your desk?

title: White House Workfare
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed taking a formal role in the Administration's welfare-reform strategy, fur flew.

title: L.A. Gear Cutting Jobs in Face of Losses
description: L.A. Gear Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 170 jobs, slashing its work force 55 percent, and that its president and chief operating officer, William L. Benford, would leave.

title: Sandra Day O'Connor Wins
description: And the winner of this year's Sandra Day O'Connor Medal of Honor is . . . Sandra Day O'Connor. Since 1992, Seton Hall University School of Law has given the award, named for the first female United States Supreme Court justice, to a woman who exhibits great leadership in world of law. Previous winners have included Hillary Rodham Clinton, the late Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas, and Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund. At Tuesday's award ceremony, Justice O'Connor told law students that lawyers have a moral responsibility to do volunteer, or pro bono, legal work. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of a Metropolitan Opera production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' by Benjamin Britten, misidentified the singer of the role of Bottom in some copies. As reflected in the article and the credits, he was Peter Rose, not Owen Brannigan.

title: Waiting for the Cod, and Good Times, to Return
description: Life on the old English shore of Newfoundland is much as it ever was.

title: Nations Begin Following U.S. Curbs on Corruption
description: Almost 20 years after the United States became the only country to prohibit its corporations from bribing foreign officials to win contracts, the rest of the world may finally be ready to act against bribes and corruption in business deals.

title: Refugees Say Fighting Continues in Zaire
description: While officials in Washington and Canada considered a plan to air-drop food to Rwandan refugees in eastern Zaire, several thousand refugees came out of the war-torn region today, saying that Zairian rebels had Hutu militias on the run and were herding refugees back to Rwanda by force.

title: How to Stay Young
description: To The Home Section:

title: Carnegie Descendant Finds Personal Stake in Historical Study
description: About five years ago, Adrienne Bresnan, then an employee of the New York City Department of General Services, started wondering what had become of the Carnegie libraries of New York.

title: T&N Seeks to Limit Liability for Asbestos
description: T&N P.L.C., a British auto parts maker, disclosed a $:1 billion ($1.67 billion) plan yesterday to limit liabilities related to its former asbestos manufacturing operations. The company said it would take a charge of $:373 million under the plan. T&N has spent more than $:350 million on claims in recent years.

title: Toddler Stabbed to Death; Police Accuse Her Mother
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged yesterday with stabbing her 2-year-old daughter to death.

title: NEOSTAR SELLS 447 SOFTWARE STORES AND IS CLOSING REST
description: Neostar Retail Group Inc. said yesterday that it had sold most of its software stores for $58.5 million and would close the rest. A director of Neostar, Leonard Riggio, formed Software Acquisition Company, which won the bidding at a Federal bankruptcy hearing. Neostar, parent company of Babbage's and Software Etc., was the nation's largest chain of computer software specialty stores. It operated software departments in Barnes & Noble stores before the bookstore chain ended the agreement in July. The company formed by Mr. Riggio, who is also chairman of Barnes & Noble, acquired 447 of Neostar's stores and all of its inventory at the hearing in Dallas. Neostar operated more than 650 stores and employed more than 5,000 workers.

title: Egyptians Support Boutros-Ghali's U.N. Bid
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Milosevic Annuls an Election
description: Western efforts to rehabilitate the image of Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian dictator who bears prime responsibility for unleashing four years of bloody war in the Balkans, were badly damaged by Mr. Milosevic himself this week. By brazenly voiding municipal elections in which his Socialist Party was soundly defeated by an opposition coalition, this political survivor of the Communist era has made it difficult for any Western government to say he is a changed man. Washington should continue to exclude the Milosevic regime from European and international institutions until there is real evidence it has reformed its ways.

title: Tate & Lyle Posts 11% Drop in Profits
description: Tate & Lyle, a British sugar and starch producer, reported yesterday that it had an 11 percent fall in annual profits to $:276 million ($463 million) after an earnings drop of more than 50 percent at its United States corn-milling subsidiary, Staley.

title: Canadian Air Scrambles To Avoid Bankruptcy Filing
description: Government, union and airline officials are scrambling to meet a series of impending deadlines that could keep Canadian Airlines International, the country's second-largest carrier, in the air and out of bankruptcy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a study that compared prices at warehouse-style stores with prices elsewhere misstated the view of Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. Ms. Messinger has criticized the Giuliani administration's plans to change zoning rules to make it easier for such stores to locate in manufacturing areas; she says she does not oppose the stores themselves.

title: Children First
description: To the Editor:

title: Leave It To the Nets: 0-13 Suns Now 1-13
description: They couldn't go 0 for the season. But who would be their first victim?

title: Family Dog Becomes Hero By Foiling A Kidnapping
description: The dog was unimpressed.

title: Some 1996 Thank-You Notes
description: FOR a change, baseball deserves the most thanks this Thanksgiving Day -- the Yankees for winning the World Series for New York again, the owners for finally agreeing to an armistice with the players. But several others also helped to make sports' little corner of the world a better place:

title: Growth Is Revised to a Slightly Slower 2%
description: The Government said today that the economy grew just slightly more slowly in the third quarter than initially estimated, and other new statistics suggested that the nation was continuing to enjoy modest growth and low inflation in the final three months of the year.

title: STERIS TO PAY $75 MILLION FOR BRISTOL-MYERS UNIT
description: The Steris Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the infection and contamination control businesses of the Calgon Vestal Laboratories unit of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company for $75 million in cash. Steris, a sterilization-equipment maker based in Mentor, Ohio, said the purchase would improve its share in the $1.9 billion market. The Calgon businesses are based in St. Louis and have about 400 employees.

title: Providence Is Too Much for a Game L.I.U.
description: The afterglow from Long Island University's upset victory over St. John's last Saturday carried through the first half of tonight's game between the Blackbirds and Providence.

title: Baby's Death Raises Level Of Concern On Air Bags
description: As teams organized by the federally sanctioned Air Bag Safety Campaign distributed leaflets yesterday to motorists at highway rest stops, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration dispatched an investigator to Boise, Idaho, to investigate the decapitation of a 1-year-old girl by a front-seat air bag in a low-speed accident on Tuesday night.

title: Bridge
description: Some world-famous players were among the winners in the Open Board-a-Match Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in San Francisco Monday night. Zia Mahmood of Manhattan, Michael Rosenberg of Tuckahoe, N.Y., Peter Weichsel of Encenitas, Calif., and Robert Levin of Orlando, Fla., scored 39.06 boards to take the title, together with Robert Baldwin of Las Vegas.

title: By Plane, Car and Boat, a Holiday Is On
description: Air fares, gasoline and hotel rooms are more expensive this year than last, and even turkeys will cost almost 8 percent more. But none of that will dampen the holiday spirit for millions of Americans this Thanksgiving, including a record 31.8 million who are expected to travel 100 miles or more from home over the four-day weekend.

title: Bringing Down the Rebel Flag
description: For years, South Carolina has been the only state to fly the Confederate battle flag over its Capitol. Now Gov. David Beasley has responded to the anger and hurt among African-Americans and others and called on the Legislature to lower the flag. In a moving speech Tuesday night, he declared that it was time to ''teach our children that we can live together.''

title: A Meal With Family Alleviates the Burden For a Dying Man
description: Sheila Dean will not say, not out loud, why Thanksgiving is so special this year. She will hint at the reason, whisper about it. For Anthony Dean, the man she lives with and plans to marry and whose name she has already taken, there will be no Thanksgiving next year, the doctors say.

title: AT&T Will Increase Long-Distance Rates
description: AT&T announced that it would raise long-distance phone rates by 5.9 percent, effective on Sunday. The move -- AT&T's largest across-the-board rate increase in nearly three years -- will be felt by a large majority of the company's 85 million residential and small business customers. For the average residential customer, AT&T's monthly bill will go up by 60 cents.

title: Rates Increased 5.9% by AT&T, Its Biggest Rise in Nearly 3 Years
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would raise long-distance phone rates by 5.9 percent -- its largest across-the-board increase in nearly three years.

title: Judge Faults Homeless Policy
description: A judge said New York City must do better at determining if the homeless have someplace else to go before denying them shelter. Page B1.

title: Swiss Protest Mexico's Use of Secret Information in Salinas Case
description: Swiss and Mexican prosecutors investigating the finances of Raul Salinas de Gortari, the scandal-embroiled brother of the former President, have fallen out as a top Swiss official accused Mexico of misusing confidential Swiss banking information.

title: Breast-Feeding Rights
description: Assemblywoman Shirley K. Turner, a Democrat of Ewing, is trying to win the right for women in New Jersey to breast-feed in public. Her bill guaranteeing that right was approved by the Assembly earlier this month, but not before being amended to allow public breast-feeding only if special accommodations were not available. Under the amended bill, a restaurant or amusement park could provide a designated area for breast-feeding and prohibit it elsewhere. ''This sends the wrong message,'' Ms. Turner, a Democrat from Ewing, said Wednesday. ''It tells people there is something wrong with breast-feeding.'' ANDY NEWMAN

title: No Headline
description: ''My guess is there would not have been a Revolution if the weather had been different.''

title: Turkeys, Pies and Friendly Faces
description: Morning brought 66-year-old Rich White into the chrome-filled Harris Diner, just as it had nearly every day since the diner opened 45 years ago.

title: The Marriott Prospers as Three Separate Companies
description: If the experience of the Marriott hotel empire is any guide, the best way for a company to prosper may be to break itself apart.

title: Plan to Cut and Raise Taxes Is Contentious in Maryland
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening needed to look no further than his own family for incentives to propose raising taxes on cigarettes in Maryland. Both of his parents were heavy smokers, and he said he constantly worries about the peer pressure to smoke facing his 16-year-old son.

title: In Dallas, Smith Squashes The Doubts
description: It was a statement drive: 65 yards in 14 plays, in 7 minutes 58 seconds, with Dallas Cowboys running back Emmitt Smith plowing over Washington Redskins safety Brian Walker on the lead draw for a 3-yard touchdown run that put Dallas ahead by 21-10.

title: Peter Hall Forms Repertory Group
description: Sir Peter Hall, the British theater director, announced yesterday that he was forming a new repertory company in London. The Peter Hall Company at the Old Vic will perform seven days a week, with 12 plays in repertory over a 40-week season, beginning on March 4.

title: A Chronology of an International Corporate Feud
In This Family, The Big Feast Is on the Field
description: Carol Bishop is not the type to stay in the kitchen on Thanksgiving and fuss over a sweet potato recipe. Not when Perth Amboy High School's football team is playing its archrival, Carteret, in a home game. Especially not when Perth Amboy's star quarterback, poised to break all kinds of records, is her youngest son, Brad.

title: In Rare Move, Ex-President of Mexico Testifies on Assassination
description: Testifying under oath for the first time in an assassination that rocked Mexico, the former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has denied that he was behind the 1994 murder of the man who was campaigning to succeed him, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Insights Turning Out To Be Funny
description: First come the innocent eyes. Last comes the U-shaped smile of a wickedly mischievous child. In between, come sharp, funny perceptions delivered with dartlike accuracy.

title: G.I.'s in Bosnia, Settled In, Find Time for an Important Visitor
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry shared a Thanksgiving meal with G.I.'s and several Russian soldiers here today, telling them that as peacekeepers they were ''doing the work of the Lord.''

title: In Serbian Leader's Home, Corruption Is Corrosive
description: Many who have achieved political power and wealth under the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, began their lives in this small industrial town.

title: New Look at the Maiden Destined to Save France
description: Jacques Rivette, a founding father of the French New Wave, has turned his attention to one of the most fecund literary and cinematic properties of this millennium in his film ''Jeanne la Pucelle'' (translated as ''Joan the Maiden'').

title: Holocaust Secrecy Now Abets More Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: A Risk Worth Taking
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombians Winning Quick Redress From Courts With Writs
description: Four years ago, Ivan B. was hired to work as a cleaner at a select club in northern Bogota. Quickly, he made his way up the ranks of the kitchen staff to the post of assistant chef. One day, when he had been there about six months, the club's doctor summoned him, tested his blood and discovered that Ivan B. was afflicted with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: They're Hungry. What's a Dad to Do?
description: In television prime time, long devoted to upbeat plots, the working poor are not very popular figures, especially when they hover on the brink of starvation. Showtime, then, gets extra points for tackling ''Hidden in America,'' a cable movie to be shown on Sunday night.

title: A Jewish Heritage Endangered
description: Much of the splendid Jewish literary heritage of Vilnius, Lithuania, sits deteriorating and untended in a Catholic church in the Baltic capital. The thousands of Hebrew and Yiddish texts, many from the 17th and 18th centuries, are nearly all that is left from the Jewish civilization that once flourished there. The papers and books, long hidden under stacks of Soviet farm statistics, deserve better treatment and permanent storage in a place where scholars can use them. Ideally, the collection should remain in Vilnius, but if that proves impractical, the archive should be moved to a center of Jewish scholarship and life like Jerusalem or New York.

title: John E. Moseley, 87, a Pioneer In Radiology and Blood Disorder
description: John E. Moseley, a radiologist who contributed to the understanding of sickle cell anemia and other blood disorders, died last Friday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Washington Heights and Edgartown, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 15 about Army women at Fort Lewis, Wash., and their views of sexual harassment misidentified a soldier who was described as having had a stressful time in basic training. She was Sgt. Shirley Bryant. (Pvt. Marlene Maranville, not shown, had complained of her treatment in basic.)

title: Art in Review
description: Irving Petlin

title: Being a Genius Can Be Tough, And Costly
description: ON a day off from school, Jonathan Estrada is at his computer, engrossed in the kind of overtly educational geography game that parents buy with high hopes, but few expectations, that their children will use it.

title: Questions About a Hospital Deal
description: A majority of the board of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has sided with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in approving a long-term lease of Coney Island Hospital to a commercial company. The Giuliani administration is confident that the deal will save millions for the city, while preserving care for the poor. But before state officials give their required approval, there are important unanswered questions that need to be addressed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday by the Associated Press about a scientist who headed a Pentagon inquiry into illness among veterans of the Persian Gulf war misstated his first name. He is Joshua Lederberg, not Joseph.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Typecasting doesn't bother RABBI MARC SCHNEIER. He makes his film debut on Friday in ''The Substance of Fire,'' starring Sarah Jessica Parker and Timothy Hutton, and he is thrilled with his role as a rabbi.

title: Dismissal of Slovak Editor Called Setback for Press Freedom
description: When Tatiana Repkova was dismissed as editor in chief and publisher of an independent daily newspaper this month, many here viewed it as just another chapter in the continuing efforts of the Government of Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar to control the Slovak media.

title: Study Faults Home Insurers For Big Losses From Disasters
description: In the last few years, the companies that sell homeowners' insurance have lost billions of dollars.

title: Amster Yard Gets European Billings
description: Bacardi-Martini has further expanded its relationship with Amster Yard in New York by naming that agency to handle advertising for its rum brands in European markets outside of Britain. The account, with billings estimated at $35 million to $40 million, had been handled by various local agencies.

title: U.S. Plutonium Policy Won't Risk Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Building Peace in Belfast, One Child at a Time
description: One of the hardest lessons to learn in a world where publicity-seeking politicians propose dramatic instant solutions for every conceivable problem is that positive change usually comes about slowly and requires a sustained commitment to a goal whose achievement is far from guaranteed. ''A Leap of Faith,'' a soft-spoken documentary film about the establishment of the Cranmore Integrated Primary School in Belfast, offers an inspiring case study of people planting a small seed of hope in the bleakest of political climates.

title: G.O.P. Victorious in Washington State Recount
description: The Republican revolution that swept across Washington State two years ago has officially survived a tough challenge this year, with the tally of absentee votes and a recount showing on Wednesday that five of six Republican freshman Representatives had won second terms.

title: Dance Centers Share $3 Million in Aid
description: The Lila Acheson-Reader's Digest Fund has awarded $3 million in grants to 10 dance centers across the United States. The Program for Leading Dance Centers will pair the centers with 30 to 40 dance companies for extended residencies, performances and educational activities over three to four years.

title: It All Starts at the Point For N.I.T. Finalist Duke
description: Basketball coaches will tell you the most important player on the floor is the point guard. Big men can score underneath and shooters can shoot, but neither can do what they do unless a playmaker gets the ball to them.

title: Selig Being Sued in Federal Court by Miami Group Over Expansion Matters
description: Just when Bud Selig has begun talking about a search for a new commissioner, he has become the defendant in a lawsuit in which he is being asked to produce documents relating to his involvement in the departure of the last commissioner, Fay Vincent.

title: THE SPOKEN WORD
description: ''CELEBRATING THE WORD,'' the City College of the City University of New York, North Academic Center, Amsterdam Avenue at 138th Street, Manhattan. Readings and discussions with the authors and editors Carolyn A. Butts, Larry Hanley, Ray Ramirez, Hector Rivera, Jack Agueros and Junot Diaz. Tomorrow at 3 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 650-7496.

title: Republicans Strike Deep In the Heart Of Texas
description: On election night earlier this month, Gov. George W. Bush declared victory in the Lone Star State. ''I think the message to Texans is our state is Republican, and proudly so,'' Mr. Bush said at a victory rally. ''It does look like an overwhelming night for Republicans statewide.''

title: Philip Miller, 90, Dies; Headed Public Library Music Division
description: Philip Lieson Miller, a musicologist and for many years a distinctive presence on the New York cultural scene, died last Saturday at Cabrini Hospital. He was 90 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: East Timor Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Abracadabra! DAVID COPPERFIELD has made his magic collection appear on Broadway.

title: Chelsea's Works in Progress
description: OVER the last three months, the Chelsea art scene has shifted from future to present tense. It is becoming less something to speculate about, more something to experience.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Color Systems in Art and Science'

title: A Caribbean Storm for the Police
description: One day, Police Commissioner Howard Safir's plan to station a handful of officers in the Dominican Republic to track fugitives is alive. The next, it appears dead.

title: Today's Games
description: No. 8 Colorado (9-1) at No. 2 Nebraska (9-1)

title: Of Beauty Beneath The Feet
description: Great art is found in exalted places and close at hand. And few works of art combine grandeur and intimacy as fully as woven carpets do.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Cable Guy

title: A Putnam County project shows the revival of the New York market has extended far north.
description: A TOWN HOUSE development of 116 residences is taking shape here, reflecting the recovery of the new-home market in semirural Putnam County.

title: The Looming Clean Air Battle
description: The Clean Air Act of 1970 -- strengthened by President Carter in 1977 and by President Bush in 1990 -- has greatly improved the quality of America's air. Responding to tough Federal mandates, science and industry have produced cleaner cars, fuels and power plants. The Federal Government now says it will try to draw the regulatory noose even tighter to help hundreds of thousands of people who suffer from respiratory diseases.

title: Rail Accident Stirs Debate About Sensors
description: The derailment last Saturday of an Amtrak passenger train in Secaucus, N.J., has renewed a long-running debate about the feasibility of sensors that can tell when a bridge or its rails have been knocked out of alignment and warn approaching trains to stop.

title: Growing Into a Tree, and Other Excesses
description: For a large part of its short history, photography has been like an eager dog nipping at the heels of painting. In the late 19th century, photographers proved they could do the work of representational painters, only faster and better. The chase was on. Painters distanced themselves by doing things that could not easily be matched photographically: Impressionist landscapes and Symbolist fantasies. But the photographers picked up the scent and ran. And before long, they found themselves not on the trail to Modernism but in the sweetly scented wood of Pictorialist photography. They were lost. And their leader was Clarence H. White.

title: Scenes From a Trial: I'm O.K., You're O.K., O.K.?
description: There came a certain moment in O. J. Simpson's testimony this week that seemed to sum up the entire surreal experience of attending his civil trial.

title: VW Official Is Expected To Resign
description: After three years of fighting accusations that he stole cartons upon cartons of secret documents from the General Motors Corporation, the president of Volkswagen A.G. is expected to resign on Friday. The departure of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua would be a significant turning point in G.M.'s bitter and deeply personal campaign against its former purchasing director.

title: Cease-Fire At Last in GM's Duel With VW?
description: FRANKFURT  After more than three years of legal and public-relations clashes between two of the world's leading automakers, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the embattled production chief of Volkswagen AG, will resign Friday, company sources told German media Thursday.

title: Day Without Art on Sunday
description: When bridges and public buildings go dark from 7:45 to 8 P.M. on Sunday, it will not be a blackout but the eighth annual Day Without Art. This event began as a way to heighten the public's awareness of AIDS and is now observed by about 6,000 cultural institutions across the country. Many museums will shroud artwork; others have mounted special exhibitions that explore the disease or are by artists who have AIDS. In addition, special lectures about the disease and educational pamphlets are planned.

title: Investigators Extend Dredging for Clues at T.W.A. Crash Site
description: Still lacking clues explaining the explosion that destroyed a Trans World Airlines jumbo jet 19 weeks ago, Federal transportation investigators have added 75 more days to contracts with a fleet of scallop boats dredging the underwater crash site for the last few scraps of wreckage.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: New Hampshire

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Redgrave Won't Retire
description: The British rower STEVE REDGRAVE, reversing his decision to retire, said yesterday that he would attempt to win a fifth successive Olympic gold medal at the 2000 Sydney Games. (AP)

title: He Pledges an 'Extraordinary' Effort : Prodi Says Italy Faces Uphill Battle to Euro
description: ROME  Italy's prime minister conceded for the first time Thursday that Rome would not be able to bring the national budget deficit down on time next year to the level required by the Maastricht treaty on European monetary union.

title: Taking the Challenge of Streamlining Credit Suisse
description: Perhaps the most talked about executive in Switzerland is Lukas Muhlemann, who has had success in turning around Swiss Re, the big reinsurance company. That success, in fact, helped him land the job of chief executive at Switzerland's second-biggest banking group, Credit Suisse, where he takes over on Jan. 1.

title: Rangers Rest After Trip, But They Do Not Relax
description: The Rangers left here having salvaged a grueling six-game, 12-day trip with a 5-2 victory against the defending Stanley Cup champion Colorado Avalanche. But as they headed for home, the Rangers still had an overall record four games under .500, and any feelings of satisfaction were brief and muted.

title: Back to the Blackboard
description: Last week, Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani proposed to give the New York City Schools Chancellor greater authority over the decentralized community school districts. But that plan will not solve the public schools' main problem, which is the central bureaucracy of the Board of Education.

title: 2 Step to Safety as a Ditched Plane Sinks
description: A small plane carrying two people on a sightseeing jaunt around Manhattan began smoking over the Statue of Liberty yesterday, but its pilot calmly flew up the Hudson past Battery Park City and looped around for a pinpoint emergency landing in the water at a pier.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Red River Crossings'

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS FOR WEEK 14
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Road Ice Causes 40 Wrecks
description: Icy roads were to blame for at least 40 accidents yesterday on New Jersey highways, The A.P. reported. The traffic calls began as low pressure swept through the region between 3 and 5 P.M., producing scattered flurries and icy patches, said Edward Yandrich, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Brookhaven, L.I. With temperatures in the upper 20's, the dusting froze right away, creating icy roads in some areas. Barry Schafle, a communications operator for the New Jersey state police said, ''There was a multitude of accidents. We were overwhelmed there for a while.'' The worst icing occurred in the central part of the state, between Bordentown and Edison, he said.

title: Guys Being Guys, Bonding and Guzzling All Night
description: Someone from the Board of Health might want to venture over to the Currican Theater and monitor the testosterone levels.

title: French Truck Drivers Refuse to Lift Blockades Despite Compromise
description: Striking French truck drivers refused today to dismantle barricades blocking most main roads for an 11th day, rebuffing a Government-appointed mediator who had wrung concessions from their employers in 75 hours of talks.

title: Jockey May Sue Race Course
description: A state appeals court has ruled that a female jockey who was paralyzed in a racing accident can sue the Atlantic City Race Course for negligence, The A.P. reported yesterday. The jockey, Sidney Underwood, was paralyzed from the waist down when her mount fell on the backstretch, slamming her to the track, in 1992. Ms. Underwood, 33, claims that poor lighting cast a shadow across the track, frightening the horse and causing it to try to stop. The three-judge panel ruled Wednesday that a jury should hear the case.

title: Algerians, Backing Constitution, Seem Poised to Accept Authority
description: Battered by five years of civil war, Algerians appeared today to approve an authoritarian new Constitution that would put an end to the country's troubled attempt to create an open democratic political system.

title: CAP ON BORROWING JEOPARDIZES PLANS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: An obscure provision in the New York State Constitution could soon stop New York City from spending $14 billion on its schools, bridges and other much-needed projects, threatening a plan to clear away decades of decay.

title: Drive to Recall a Mayor
description: Seeking to capitalize on the long Thanksgiving holiday, the Concerned Citizens of West Orange will spend the weekend knocking on doors, heading into the home stretch of a petition drive to recall Mayor Sam Spina. By Wednesday, the group had collected 5,500 signatures, only 232 shy of the total needed to force a recall election. ''It's our hope that a lot of college students will be home for the weekend,'' said Gary Englert, a spokesman for the group. The group faults the Mayor for refusing to ask his son, Robert, to step down as police chief after he was found by a judge to have beaten his wife, and again a year later after he was indicted on charges of tipping off a suspect about a drug raid.

title: Thumping Punk Back To Its Roots
description: When Social Distortion performed on Wednesday night at Roseland, its singer, Mike Ness, dedicated a song to Joey Ramone because ''he remembers what it was like when punk rock was dangerous.'' Mr. Ness has been leading Social Distortion since 1979, when he was a teen-ager in the Southern California suburbs, and has seen punk transformed from an insurrection into a cornerstone of current rock. By staying with punk rock's essentials -- blaring guitars, fierce vocals, brawny drums -- Mr. Ness has become a preservationist, whose punk is a proud culmination of raw-boned 50's and 60's rock.

title: Ballet Master Class
description: Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater, will conduct a master class with three male dancers from the company on Tuesday at 7 P.M. at Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues. The class, part of a series presented by Ballet Theater, will give dancers an opportunity to learn lead roles and solos Mr. McKenzie performed in ''Swan Lake,'' ''Romeo and Juliet'' and ''La Sylphide.'' Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 477-3030.

title: Florida State Triples the Pressure
description: Quick fact: Three of Florida State University's starting defensive linemen run the 40-yard dash faster than any of the Seminoles' regular linebackers.

title: Prison Officer Takes His Life
description: A corrections officer killed himself after shooting his girlfriend four times, injuring her critically, Burlington County prosecutors said yesterday. In what authorities described as a violent episode in a love triangle involving three corrections officers at the state prison for women in Clinton, James Bowles of Willingboro shot Deana Stahl in the bedroom of the home she shared with her husband, Thomas Stahl on Wednesday.

title: Placer Dome Seeks to Buy 2 Mining Concerns for $600 Million
description: Placer Dome Inc. of Canada proposed today to buy Highlands Gold Ltd., a gold producer in Papua New Guinea, and the 24.6 percent it did not already own of Placer Pacific Ltd., which has interests in mines in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The two transactions would have a total value of about $600 million (United States).

title: Art in Review
description: Joe Andoe

title: A Singer Who Also Acts Touches a Youthful Chord
description: The singer Holly Cole's performance at a jampacked Mercury Lounge on Tuesday conjured up an endless list of powerful commercial references for young adults in the post-Bush era: New Orleans, Tom Waits, the film ''Clueless,'' drinking to ease existential pain, and modish dating rituals.

title: Capturing Fontainebleau Forest's Myriad Moods
description: In the picturesque forest of Fontainebleau during the mid-19th century, you sometimes couldn't see the trees for the artists. Although tamed by recreational use, the vast, 42,000-acre tract south of Paris was still wild enough to lend itself to romantic visions and raw impressions of nature, making it a prime hangout for painters and photographers.

title: Britain's Big 'McLibel Trial' (It's McEndless, Too)
description: Even after two grueling, often grindingly tedious years, the case popularly known as the McLibel trial is very much a study in extremes. On one side of an ancient London courtroom sits Richard Rampton, a bewigged libel lawyer for the McDonald's Corporation, ubiquitous purveyor of McNuggets, McRibs and McChicken sandwiches. On the other side sit two dressed-down vegetarians: Dave Morris, an unemployed postman, and Helen Steel, a part-time bartender.

title: Nigeria's Leader Presses Makeover of the Economy and His Image
description: In the face of widespread skepticism from Nigeria's domestic opposition, Nigeria's military leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, is pushing ahead with an effort to spur economic change and enhance his political image.

title: $25 and Under
description: With all the Greek restaurants that have opened in Manhattan in the last two years, it's easy to sound like a broken record, or these days, a compact disk with a repetition defect. The menus are largely similar, especially at the seafood restaurants.

title: Resignation Expected In G.M.-VW Dispute
description: After three years of fighting charges that he stole reams of secret documents from General Motors, a top Volkswagen executive is expected to resign today. The departure would be a turning point in G.M.'s case against the executive, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, and Volkswagen.

title: Nets Shoot, Hustle . . . And Foul
description: The Nets discovered their touch, found their range and came up with everything they had been missing a night earlier.

title: Watters Poses a Problem For Opponents (and Eagles)
description: Ricky Watters is that friend in high school who often annoyed you to the point you could not stand being around him. But he was your friend, so you put up with the nonsense anyway.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Hockey

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about anti-Government protests in Serbia misstated President Slobodan Milosevic's public stance on the outbreak of war in Yugoslavia in 1991. Although Serbia was instrumental in the Yugoslav military response to the secession of Croatia and Slovenia, Mr. Milosevic never formally announced a decision to go to war to oppose the breakup.

title: LVMH Buys Stake In Chateau d'Yquem
description: A major producer of luxury goods, LVMH Moet- Hennessy Louis Vuitton, said today that it would acquire a majority stake in Chateau d'Yquem, a French vineyard known for its sweet white Sauternes wines.

title: Find a Secretary of State Who Stresses Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: One Holiday That Retains Its Meaning
description: In a hectic age, Thanksgiving endures as the surviving cornerstone of the family hearth.

title: Russian Scientists
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen Sets Record as Chiefs Run Over Lions
description: The Kansas City Chiefs and the Detroit Lions today looked like two teams hungry enough to snatch and eat the first thing in sight, but both settled for grabbing at and popping each other.

title: Mount St. Michael Defeats Hayes for Title Once Again
description: MOUNT ST. MICHAEL (9-2) closed out its Catholic High School Football League championship season yesterday by defeating its Bronx rival CARDINAL HAYES, 49-6, for the 16th consecutive time in the 54-year-old Thanksgiving Day series.

title: Lufthansa Says Its Profit Has Declined
description: Lufthansa, Germany's national airline, said today that pretax profit fell slightly in the third quarter amid losses at its cargo unit and rising fuel prices. For the year, it said, earnings will be ''at best'' 10 percent below 1995's level.

title: A Dream Come True, Though Not Exactly The Way He Thought
description: AS a senior at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City, Roshown McLeod dreamed of someday playing a big college game in Madison Square Garden. The dream was so important that he put off another dream, going out West to college, to stay home and attend St. John's.

title: William F. Martin, Oil Executive, 79
description: William F. Martin, a former chairman and chief executive of the Phillips Petroleum Company who guided the company through a huge expansion, died on Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Tulsa, Okla.

title: Argentines Hunt a Sub: Did It Carry Nazi Booty?
description: In the decades after World War II, rumors swirled through Argentina that German submarines carrying Nazi war criminals and booty landed in Patagonia, Argentina's vast southern wilderness.

title: Colombia Drug War Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: From Manhattan Congregation, a 'Flood of Food' to Help the Hungry
description: As an ancient hymn of thanks floated above them, lines of people streamed toward the altar at the Roman Catholic Church of the Ascension yesterday morning, carrying cans and boxes of food for the poor.

title: Julian S. Greenspun, New York Judge, 63
description: Julian Samson Greenspun, a Manhattan lawyer and former justice of the New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died on Nov. 21 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 63 and lived in Mill Basin, Brooklyn.

title: New Kentucky Coach?
description: Kentucky's director of athletics, C. M. NEWTON, has met with the Valdosta (Ga.) State football coach, HAL MUMME, and plans a news conference on Monday.

title: For Star Basketball Coach's Son, Success Comes in Spirals
description: It did not take David Stringer long to discover the difference between his new home in central New Jersey and the one he moved from in the Midwest.

title: Don't Blame King George III. It Was the Weather!
description: Forget what you learned about the American Revolution being caused by the hated Stamp Act, tea taxes and the quartering of British troops in the homes of the colonists. All that may have a minor place in history, but what really sparked the shot heard round the world was poor crops.

title: Visit From Hess Isn't All Sociable, but the Jets Still Leave in Good Standing
description: Leon Hess, the owner whose annual Thanksgiving message to the team usually has a rosy glow, today expressed his disappointment with the Jets' 1-11 season.

title: Who Exactly Owns Teams Nowadays?
description: JOHN SPANO does not look like a conglomerate, and that's a good sign. He looks like a perfectly ordinary baldish, 32-year-old who made enough money in the equipment-leasing business in Dallas to be able to purchase the New York Islanders as a toy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about ''early decision'' programs for college admission referred incorrectly to the growth of such applications at the University of Virginia. They have risen to 2,325 this year from 1,100 in 1991 (not to 1,350 this year from 575 in 1991).

title: Marmots Who Dig Together Get Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: A Comic's Career In Transit
description: John DiResta has found his station in life. It's at the end of the line, in Coney Island. And the story of how this transit police officer got there, to spend his days golfing a Granny Smith into a Coke cup fished from a trash barrrel, talking to an abandoned toy turtle, feeding the indigenous fauna and taking messages for a guy who sleeps in the station, is the funny substance of his show ''Beat: A Subway Cop's Comedy.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL

title: Mother Held in Child Slaying Felt Severe Stress, Police Say
description: Drawing a picture of a deeply disturbed young woman, police officials said yesterday that a 17-year-old Brooklyn mother charged with fatally stabbing her 2-year-old daughter admitted that she committed the crime because she was depressed and irritable over the strains of motherhood.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21

title: Thanksgiving, for Odd Sort of Harvard Expatriate
description: Americans in Europe like Americans in America took time out to celebrate Thanksgiving today.

title: Going to Another Planet? Have a Safe Trip
description: When it is not coming on like an infomercial for NASA, ''Destination Mars'' sets its sights on the complexities of sending humans on a six-month journey to the red planet and enabling them to exist in an artificial atmosphere during the round trip.

title: France's Economy Grew in 3d Quarter
description: France's economy swung back to an expansion in the third quarter, aided by stronger consumption and exports, the Government said today.

title: Beyond the Movie
description: And now maybe we should think a bit about Tibet -- the country, not the movie.

title: In Overtime, Coyotes Get Devils' Goat
description: Except for a second-period lapse tonight, the Devils might have had themselves their fifth victory in their last six road games. Had they scored just once on the power play, the Devils, who went 0 for 5, would have had their second victory away from home in as many nights.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Crow: City of Angels

title: Nigerian Has Surgery
description: The Nigerian star NWANKWO KANU had successful heart surgery in Cleveland, but his Italian club said it was too early to tell if he would be able to play again. The four-hour operation, to correct a weak aortic valve, took place at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation on Monday. News of the surgery was delayed at the request of the 20-year-old player. His team, Inter Milan, yesterday described his condition as good. (AP)

title: Bissell Sought One 'Weekend Like a Normal Person,' Associate Says
description: A former employee who spoke to the fugitive prosecutor Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. two days before he killed himself said today that Mr. Bissell never thought he could escape, but ''just wanted to have one weekend like a normal person'' before he killed himself.

title: The Devil And The Jets
description: My blood, as they say, ran cold. It was Jan. 12, 1969, and the New York Jets had just won the Super Bowl, defeating the mighty Colts of Baltimore 16-7 in the greatest upset in pro football history. Most eyes were on the young Joe Namath as he and the other delirious Jets left the playing field of the Orange Bowl in Miami. I happened to catch a glimpse of the Jets coach, Weeb Ewbank.

title: Macy's 70th Sails On Buoyantly
description: Nursing her three-week-old cold and sucking on the first honey-lemon throat lozenge of the day, Kathryn M. Kramer talked about the strange dream she had the night before the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade yesterday.

title: Home Video
description: New videos are coming from all angles and places. For example, once in rural Georgia a fabric sculptor named Xavier Roberts made a line of cloth figures so lovably ugly he got people to ''adopt'' them at $40 each. In the current movie ''Jingle All the Way,'' frantic parents race to procure the last Turbo Man action toy before Christmas. In 1983 the battle was fought for real over Mr. Roberts's Cabbage Patch Kids.

title: Art in Review
description: Richard Serra

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 16 with the obituary of Alger Hiss misstated the date of the photograph, which showed President Truman shaking Mr. Hiss's hand at a United Nations conference in San Francisco. It was June 26, 1945, not April of that year.

title: 2 Unions Snag Airline Rescue
description: Two of Canadian Airlines International Ltd.'s six unions remained opposed to the carrier's proposal to cut wages as part of a financial rescue plan.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Sharing Cash as Well as Credit

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Flower of My Secret

title: Catherine the Great Shopper, Buying British
description: Thanks to the grabbiness of Catherine the Great (1729-1796), the Russians were the first on the Continent to discover that the British, besides being writers and empire builders, could also make art. Partial as she was to France, Italy and her native Germany, Catherine was drawn to England by her fondness for its literature, and she allowed her collecting and decorating mania to cross the Channel.

title: State Sues Veterans' Group Over Treasures in Armory
description: The scores of armories in New York State often hold hidden treasures behind their nondescript walls: century-old military paintings, Civil War-era uniforms, battle flags and a wealth of other rare trinkets.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. Most markets overseas were open. $(Page D12.$) Today, the stock and bond markets and the commodity markets in Chicago are open but will end trading in the early afternoon; the commodity markets in New York are closed.

title: DINER's JOURNAL
description: The most satisfying dish I've had this week, or maybe even this month, was a simple plate of spaghetti slicked with olive oil and dusted with black pepper and pecorino cheese.

title: Battle on Youth Smoking Brings Hope and Caution
description: She is 15 and has been smoking since she was in fourth grade. She knows it is a mistake but sees no way out.

title: Quaker Oats Shifts Two Cereal Brands
description: The Quaker Oats Company in Chicago has realigned assignments among its agencies by shifting responsibilities for two cereal brands to Bayer Bess Vanderwarker in Chicago from Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York. Combined billings for the brands -- Quaker Toasted Oatmeal, a ready-to-eat cereal, and Quaker Quick 'n Hearty oatmeal -- have combined billings estimated at $16 million to $18 million.

title: Zaire Rebel Approves Food Drop But Rejects Western Military Role
description: The Canadian commander of the United Nations intervention force for eastern Zaire met today with the rebel commander holding the region and won tentative approval for the airdrop of food to thousands of refugees.

title: Light Load Is the Key For Victor
description: They have been running the Fall Highweight Handicap for 83 years at New York race tracks, and it is supposed to indicate which horse can carry high weight and still outsprint everybody else at six furlongs. Yesterday, though, the race was won by Victor Avenue, a 3-year-old colt who carried only 127 pounds, the second-lightest load in the field of 10.

title: Grocers Find On-Line Shopping Services to Be a Mixed Bag
description: Shortly before 6 P.M. in this tree-lined suburb, Peter A. Powell arrived at Roma Kelley's front door with a blue plastic bin and a red Igloo cooler. ''Hi, Pete, how are you?'' Mrs. Kelley asked, holding her 14-month-old daughter, Emma.

title: Philosophical Confusion And Other Weird Stuff
description: If you're among those for whom Christmas time is angst time (a group that seems to include most people over 12), you may want to skip the dancing candy canes and staged readings of Dickens. Consider, instead, another annual tradition in the New York theater, one that speaks directly to perceptions of the world as a lonely, abusive and utterly bewildering planet: Richard Foreman's vaudeville of the aching psyche at the Ontological-Hysteric Theater.

title: Accounts
description: * Sub-Zero Freezer Co., Madison, Wis., to Kerker Marketing Communications, Minneapolis, to handle its account, previously at Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Student Ailey Tickets
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which performs from Wednesday through Dec. 29 at City Center, will offer students movie-priced tickets to performances Tuesdays through Thursdays, except for opening night. Students with identification may buy the best available tickets for $8 from noon to 6 P.M. on the day of the performance at the box office, 131 West 55th Street in Manhattan. Information: (212) 581-1212.

title: Populism at the Pump
description: To the Editor:

title: Samsung Says It Still Wants To Buy Dutch Plane Maker
description: The Samsung Group of South Korea said today that it would continue its efforts to buy Fokker N.V., despite a statement by receivers for the bankrupt Dutch airplane manufacturer that a takeover on the basis of its current plan was no longer possible.

title: English Modernism: A Big Weight to Hang on 1910
description: ON OR ABOUT DECEMBER 1910

title: INSIDE
description: G.O.P. Strength in Texas

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Canada Proposes Steps To Curb Tobacco Use

title: Inside Photography
description: For Adam Stoltman and Alan Dorow, photographers and picture editors, the World Wide Web is almost too good to be true. The Web allows them to showcase photo essays at a tiny fraction of what it would cost to use the conventional print route. And there are other advantages:
