title: Seven ski resorts owned by a single company are bundled as one package in a new campaign.
description: THANKSGIVING is not only the traditional kickoff to the holiday season, but also the time when weather reports become must reading for skiers and snowboarders.

title: A Day to Recall Smoky Halls And Heroism
description: At the Hamilton Hotel in Harlem, Thanksgiving was a day to ask about friends and acquaintances in hospitals, to find out where homeless friends had moved, to swap stories about acts of heroism on a smoky night.

title: Volkswagen's Italian Prices Spur Antitrust Complaint
description: The European Commission said today that it had sent an antitrust complaint to Volkswagen A.G. concerning VW's car-pricing policy in Italy, which the commission said violated trade regulations.

title: A Guide to Pop Albums for Adults
description: THE pop music industry is so fond of giving a catchy name to each hot new sound that nowadays it is tempting to see music as a steadily lengthening list of niche markets with names like alternative, grunge, hip-hop, new jack swing, gangsta rap, and trance ambient. But putting records into niches ignores the broader sweep of pop music history. Trends come and go, but beneath the labeling hubbub, plenty of durable music is still being recorded that resists narrow categorization. Much of this music involves exploring the interplay among broader musical currents -- pop, rock, country, jazz and rhythm-and-blues -- that will remain long after subdivisions have faded into historical footnotes.

title: A Small County's Hopes Dissolve in Accusations
description: The county chief of staff here in Alabama's poorest county boasts of regular trips to Paris, and owes thousands of dollars in travel advances.

title: Westchester Parents Are Divided Between Tradition and Simplicity
description: For years, immigrants have sent their children to the Chinese School of Southern Westchester on Saturday mornings, hoping they will embrace the language and culture of their ancestors.

title: A Custom Stuffed With Subtexts
description: Students marooned far from home, especially those from other continents, can seem slightly curmudgeonly on the topic of Thanksgiving.

title: Philips Electronics to Cut Jobs As It Revamps European Units
description: Philips Electronics N.V. said today that it would revamp its television operations in Western Europe and reduce the labor force at three plants by half, eliminating 1,400 jobs.

title: Opposition to Cigarette Stings
description: The Federal Government has told New Jersey to stop stores from selling cigarettes to minors or risk losing financing for drug abuse programs. The state, in turn, has asked local and county health departments to send minors to buy cigarettes in sting operations.

title: Like a Superhero, Jordan Is There to Save the Bulls if Ever They Should Slip
description: He will take no bows as the next Spencer Tracy, or Denzel Washington, or even Bugs Bunny. ''I'm no movie star,'' said Michael Jordan, who co-stars with the aforementioned bucktoothed wabbit in the current hit flick ''Space Jam.'' ''Let's just say it was a successful venture.''

title: Dutch Drug Tolerance Is Under EU Pressure
description: BRUSSELS  The Netherlands is facing mounting pressure to abandon its liberal drug laws, as most of its European Union partners have lined up behind a French-led plan to wage a Europe-wide war against drugs.

title: Ottawa Talks Set for Aiding Zaire Refugees
description: Diplomats and senior officials from at least 15 nations committed to supporting a Canadian proposal to provide aid to refugees in Central Africa will meet in Ottawa on Friday to discuss the framework for a scaled-down mission to aid refugees.

title: Suffer the Children
description: There are 200,000 child soldiers in the world today, many of them as young as 10. Young girls are impressed into armies, abused, raped, awarded to soldiers as ''wives.'' Over the last 10 years, two million children have been killed in wars.

title: For Children
description: 'Reel to Real for Kids'

title: As Elf Aquitaine's image improves, so do its A.D.R.'s
description: SINCE France's largest oil company, Elf Aquitaine, was privatized by the French Government in 1991, it has struggled to change the perceptions of many American investors that it is still dominated by the state and is unfamiliar with the ways of a competitive marketplace.

title: Political Infighting Halts Indiana City's Salute to a Native Son
description: It was supposed to have been the impetus to transform this gritty blue-collar city into the entertainment mecca of the Midwest. But political bickering and allegations of racism and conflict of interest have halted plans for the $2 billion entertainment complex.

title: Restaurants
description: This is a city of personality Zip Codes, neighborhoods so distinct that people can define themselves by where they live. The very names -- Chelsea, Harlem, Carroll Gardens -- speak volumes about those who live there. Why should restaurants be any different?

title: People Haunted by Anxiety Appear to Be Short on a Gene
description: They are the type of people who own a one-sided bed: the wrong side. They are often anxious, grumpy and self-pitying, viewing the past with regret, the present with suspicion and the future with dread. The traditional tag for them is neurotic, but a better word is kvetch.

title: Manhattan As a Bit Of Prairie
description: EVERY year at this time, Garrison Keillor returns to a comfortable small-town environment that personifies his radio institution, ''A Prairie Home Companion.''

title: THREE VERDICTS FOR AMERICAN FLYWHEEL JAR HONEYWELL
description: Honeywell Inc. said yesterday that a Phoenix jury had returned three verdicts against the company that total $38 million and one verdict in favor of Honeywell for relief to be determined by the court. Honeywell said the litigation was between its Satellite Systems Operation unit and American Flywheel Systems Inc. over a 1993 technology development contract. Honeywell filed suit in September 1994, accusing American Flywheel of failing to pay for work performed. American Flywheel countersued, accusing Honeywell of breaching the contract. Honeywell said it planned to contest the verdicts.

title: Palffy and a Stingy Salo Keep Islanders Stoking
description: Zigmund Palffy gave an early notice of his presence in tonight's game against the Capitals when he zigged and zagged his way into Washington's zone only to be denied twice before the game was 28 seconds old. But the Islanders' elusive right wing was not to be denied the rest of the game at the USAir Arena.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tourism Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Brush Wolves Already Call Adirondacks Home
description: To the Editor:

title: The Greening of Herald and Greeley Squares (They'll Become Parks)
description: A measure of New York City's sense of self-importance is its penchant for giving traffic triangles the more grandiose appellation of squares, as in Foley Square, Duffy Square and Times Square. But two smaller squares, Herald and Greeley, are now truly shooting for the big time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Holiday Sales Open Briskly; Consumer Spending Climbs

title: The Gold Standard
description: Being of a certain generation, my mother didn't hold with the notion that Germany could be forgiven for the Holocaust in her lifetime. She wouldn't buy German products and purported to hold her breath whenever passing over Germany by plane. But she loved Switzerland, and I wonder what she would have made of the news about Swiss bankers helping themselves to Nazi deposits of loot stolen from Jews, some of it possibly gold extracted from the teeth of death-camp inmates. Perhaps the movie whose happy ending enshrines the benign image of wartime Switzerland should be retitled ''The Sound of Money.''

title: Wheat and Corn Prices Tumble During Short Session in Chicago
description: Wheat and corn prices fell in a shortened session on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on signs of waning export demand.

title: Chinese and Indian Leaders Vow to End Border Tension
description: Nearly 35 years after a border war that left China occupying a sprawling region of Himalayan uplands claimed by India, the two countries agreed in principle today on mutual troop withdrawals from disputed areas along their 2,500-mile frontier and pledged that ''neither side shall use its military capability against the other.''

title: Jets' Empty Seats Get Set for Oilers
description: The Jets have their no-shows by the thousands. And Sunday they play host to the team with the no-buys, the Houston Oilers.

title: ROCKWELL AND BOEING SET EXCHANGE RATIO FOR PURCHASE
description: The Rockwell International Corporation disclosed the exchange ratio yesterday for the Boeing Company shares to be issued when Boeing buys Rockwell's aerospace and military business for $3.16 billion in stock and debt. Shareholders are to receive 0.042 of a share of Boeing common stock for one Rockwell share. The number is based on the average Boeing stock price, adjusted for dividends, for the 20 days of trading that ended on Wednesday. Boeing would issue 9.2 million shares to Rockwell shareholders for about $860 million. The transaction would also include Boeing's assumption of $2.2 billion of Rockwell's debt and $100 million in pension liabilities. The shares are to be distributed on Dec. 6.

title: For Pristine Cedar Grove, Options Are Down to Two
description: From a shadowy trail at the north end of this pristine lake, hikers crane their necks to gawk at trees that are 20 stories tall and a millennium old. If they leave the trail and make a way through the cedar cathedral, they see thigh-high ferns, lush ravines and a crystalline river.

title: A Conviction From the Bosnia Tribunal
description: Drazen Erdemovic is not the man most people would choose to be the first person convicted in 50 years by an international tribunal for crimes against humanity. What Mr. Erdemovic did was horrible enough. He was part of the Bosnian Serb army that overran the Muslim city of Srebrenica in July 1995. His job was to take Muslim men in groups of 10, blindfold them and shoot them. His unit murdered 1,200 men in five hours. He probably killed between 10 and 100 people.

title: Yes, Yes, He Is Interested
description: With the primaries still more than six months away, the competition to be the Democratic candidate for governor is heating up. Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive, sent a flier to Democratic officeholders around the state this week touting his credentials to ''lead the state into the 21st century.'' Mr. Janiszewski said yesterday that he sent the flier out to scotch rumors from supporters of other potential candidates that he is not interested in running.

title: Call for Weaker French Franc Helps Push the Dollar Higher
description: The dollar rose against the French franc and the German mark yesterday after another French official called for a weaker franc.

title: Yanks' Hayes And Fielder Want Trades
description: Dusting off a rarely used contractual right, Cecil Fielder and Charlie Hayes, two players the Yankees acquired a month apart in the second half of last season, demanded a trade yesterday. It was the first time a player had exercised that right since Fielder did it four years ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a New York City police officer accused of posting neo-Nazi stickers in a bar in Orange County misstated the neighborhoods covered by the 45th Precinct, where he works. The precinct, in the Bronx, encompasses Co-op City, City Island and Throgs Neck, not Tremont and University Heights.

title: Ruth Miller, 70, Civic Leader In Cleveland
description: Ruth Ratner Miller, a Cleveland business woman and civic leader, died on Tuesday at the Cleveland Clinic. She was 70 and a lifelong resident of the city.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Making Coltrane's Latin Side Come Alive
description: It wasn't until the pianist Eddie Palmieri arrived that the music in Conrad Herwig's first set with his septet at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night gained its real power. Mr. Herwig, a trombonist, has recently released a fine album, ''The Latin Side of John Coltrane'' (Astor Place), a deft exploration of Coltrane's compositions from an Afro-Cuban viewpoint. The show worked through the concept, and until Mr. Palmieri arrived, for the last two compositions of the set, the band had been reverentially contemplating an idea.

title: South Korea Cuts 1997 Growth Forecast
description: South Korea's economic growth rate will slump to a four-year low of 6.4 percent in 1997 because of crumbling exports and slowing capital investment, the Bank of Korea said yesterday. The economy grew 9 percent in 1995 and is expected to grow 6.9 percent this year.

title: Banking Reform Is Responsibility of Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispute on Tarot Lecture Roils a Small-Town Library
description: Most cash-strapped, small-town public librarians know better than to look a gift horse in the mouth. But when books on the occult, bearing titles like ''Buckland's Complete Book of Witchcraft'' and ''To Ride a Silver Broomstick,'' began showing up in the mail by the dozens last summer at the Seabrook Public Library, the head librarian, Elizabeth Heath, admits that she and her staff were ''amazed and confused.''

title: Janet Reno Fumbles
description: Attorney General Janet Reno, rarely reluctant to appoint special prosecutors to look into allegations of corruption, yesterday adopted a strangely cautious and narrow approach toward the mounting evidence of questionable fund-raising by Democratic Party operatives. Her refusal to appoint an independent prosecutor virtually assures a protracted and potentially disruptive Congressional investigation. Ms. Reno would do well to review the evidence and rethink her decision.

title: In the Sierras, Growth and Preservation Are Not at Odds
description: In the villages nestled amid the forests and river valleys of the Sierra Nevada, the environment has always been a battleground, with ''growth'' and ''jobs'' the implacable rhetorical foes of ''no growth'' and ''the environment.''

title: Healing an Area-Code Rift
description: Residents of Kearny and 20 other towns might not have to dial a different area code to speak to their neighbors after all. One unpopular side effect of the plan announced earlier this month to create two new area codes in New Jersey was that 21 towns would be split into two codes. But under a tentative agreement reached by Bell Atlantic and a group of Republican lawmakers yesterday, residents of the split towns could simply dial a seven-digit number even if the crosstown party is in a different area code. The state Board of Public Utilities must review the agreement.

title: REPUBLICANS' CALL FOR A PROSECUTOR IS REJECTED BY U.S.
description: The Justice Department today rejected a request by senior Republican lawmakers to appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate whether Democratic fund-raisers illegally raised millions of dollars for their party's treasury this year.

title: HORSE RACING
description: Flat Fleet Feet is the name, and it's a funny alliterative name that's the bane of race-track announcers. But by any name, she can run. And she demonstrated it again yesterday when she ran away from eight other prize fillies to win the Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Barrasso to Miss at Least Six More Weeks
description: A chronic shoulder injury will keep Pittsburgh Penguins goaltender TOM BARRASSO off the ice for the rest of the year.

title: Japan Urged to End Fixed Stock-Trade Fees
description: A Japanese Government panel has called for scrapping fixed stock-trading commissions, even though the group's chairman acknowledged that many smaller brokerage firms could be driven out of business. The recommendation was one of a dozen made by the panel this week in the first move in Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's program to revamp Japan's markets by 2001.

title: Gunfire Silences a Voice for the Poor
description: Friends always said Buddy Gray, a onetime top high school scholar and athlete from a prosperous family in the bucolic suburban town of Mount Carmel, had the chance to go anywhere in the world he wanted.

title: Would-Be Brewers Got It Just Right, All but the Lawsuit
description: When Douglas Hanlon and Greg Waterbury work in a laboratory at Yale University, the two molecular biologists must control every factor in their experiments.

title: A Young Entrepreneur Makes Food, Not War
description: Daniel Lubetzky has a talent for bringing things together. This 28-year old entrepreneur coined ''sprate,'' a word that combines spread and pate, to describe a line of products that his New York company, the Peaceworks, is marketing successfully in the United States.

title: No Financial Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Algeria Says Charter Passes, But Critics Charge Vote Fraud
description: The Algerian Government announced today that a new Constitution banning Islamic political parties was overwhelmingly approved in a referendum, but opposition parties dismissed the vote as rigged and said it would only heighten tensions in the country.

title: Anti-Fur Groups Wage War on Mink Farms
description: Battle lines have been sharply drawn between anti-fur forces and mink farmers across the United States.

title: Toshiba Profit Off 39% On Lower Chip Prices
description: The Toshiba Corporation of Japan said yesterday that profit fell 39 percent in the first half of its fiscal year because of low semiconductor prices. Toshiba's profit was 16.63 billion yen, or $147.2 million, in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, down from 27.45 billion yen a year earlier. Sales totaled 2.51 trillion yen, up 6.9 percent from 2.35 trillion yen.

title: Canal Enthusiasm
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR CRIMES PANEL IN FIRST VERDICT
description: The international tribunal on war crimes in the former Yugoslavia handed down its first verdict today, sentencing a Croat who served in the Bosnian Serb army to 10 years in prison for his role in the massacre of Muslim civilians in 1995 near Srebrenica.

title: Compromise Needed On Fordham's Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: Failure of Ticket Computer Snarls Amtrak at Busy Time
description: The computer system that controls Amtrak's reservations and ticketing for the entire country broke down yesterday, leaving many riders on the busiest travel weekend of the year standing in long lines as clerks wrote out tickets by hand.

title: Dow Up 22.36 in Light Day; Month Is Best in Five Years
description: Stocks rose in a shortened session yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average ended its best month in nearly five years.

title: U.S. ROBOTICS STOCK GAINS ON NEWS OF DELL PACT
description: The stock of U.S. Robotics jumped yesterday on news, announced late on Wednesday, that the Dell Computer Corporation would offer the company's new higher-speed modem technology on its Dimension desktop personal computers. The faster modems would increase the speed at which people could use the Internet. The devices use U.S. Robotics' so-called x2 technology, which can transmit data at 56 kilobits a second. Modems offered by Dell have a speed of 33.6 kilobits. Dell would begin offering the modems early next year. In Nasdaq trading, U.S. Robotics stock gained $5.125, to close at $78.625 a share, and Dell gained $1.625, to $101.625.

title: HOLLINGER BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN SOUTHAM OF CANADA
description: Hollinger International Inc. said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of 8 million shares in Southam Inc. for $160 million (Canadian), or $118 million (United States), giving it a majority stake in Canada's largest publisher of daily newspapers. Hollinger International raised its stake in Southam, the Toronto-based publisher of The Montreal Gazette, to 50.7 percent from 41 percent. Southam also publishes The Ottawa Citizen and The Vancouver Sun. The acquisition will enable Hollinger International, owner of The Chicago Sun-Times, and its Canadian parent, Hollinger Inc., to combine Southam's financial results with its own, the company said. Hollinger Inc. publishes newspapers and magazines in Britain, the United States, Canada, Australia and Israel.

title: Many Honest Portrayals
description: To the Editor:

title: DNA Science Matches Crash Victims With Families
description: Ronald Yee had come to accept that his sister, Judith, had not just died in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 but that any trace of her had been erased. The remains of both Ms. Yee's cousin and a friend she was traveling with were recovered, but Ms. Yee was not found.

title: Elektrowatt to Spin Off Its Electricity Division
description: Elektrowatt A.G. of Switzerland said yesterday that it would spin off its electricity division to focus on its building services businesses. After the split, Elektrowatt will have building services and engineering revenue of about 5.5 billion Swiss francs.

title: In a Quirky Market for Milk, Consumers and Farms Lose
description: Consumers in much of the country are paying record prices for milk, cheese and many other dairy products. But that has not kept the milk prices paid to the nation's 150,000 dairy farmers from heading into a 25 percent free fall in recent weeks, even as retailers fatten their profit margins.

title: Virgin Group Adds A British Rail Network
description: The Virgin Group, headed by Richard Branson, took over a money-losing rail network, Crosscountry, yesterday. The Government awarded Mr. Branson a 15-year franchise to operate the network. Mr. Branson would get a state subsidy of $:112.9 million ($188.5 million) in the first year to run the network.

title: Power Diners Wonder When, or if, It Will Reopen
description: The old commercial for the Russian Tea Room was joyously, comically precise. But ''just six minutes and 23 seconds from Lincoln Center and slightly to the left of Carnegie Hall,'' the restaurant now sits empty, a grande dame in mothballs.

title: Tuition Aid We Don't Need
description: Many Americans believe the Government should give students from low-income families a chance to go to college and that it should also help middle-income families deal with rising tuitions. Unfortunately, President Clinton seems bent on tinkering with the tax code rather than on strengthening the aid programs aimed at achieving these worthy goals.

title: For Dogs Pursued Pitilessly, Sanctuary
description: Three times in her animal rescue career, Lu Di said, her dogs have been killed. The worst was 1990, when a Beijing policeman named Yang Qing showed up at her dog shelter two bus stops east of the People's University. He was there as part of a citywide cleanup before the Asian Games, held in Beijing that summer.

title: Diverse Programming
description: To the Editor:

title: A Faded Smile As a Memory Of Integration
description: MOST of the childhood pictures in Tricia Regan's scrapbook have faded into pastel-hued squares, tableaux of playtime and polyester from 1970's Canarsie. But one series of photos, the annual class portraits from her grammar school, remains rich and vivid.

title: No Headline
description: ''The kind of price volatility we are seeing is the difference for many between profitability and losing the farm.''

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Nebraska Keeps a Hand in the Title Mix
description: It was far from easy, but Nebraska today maintained its flickering hopes of winning a third straight national championship.

title: Hopes for Lower Rates Spark Europe's Markets
description: PARIS  European stock and bond markets rallied Friday, and so did the dollar, as investors became convinced that a dramatic shift in European interest-rate policy was imminent.

title: Bodego Owner Shoots Youths, Killing One
description: The owner of a bodega in Brooklyn opened fire on a group of five teen-agers who he suspected were trying to steal junk food on Thursday night, killing one, a 15-year-old shot in the back, and wounding another as they ran out of the store, the police said.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Ethnicity and Television Can Both Be With It
description: To the Editor:

title: Day 1 Arouses Retailers' Hopes That Christmas Is on the Rebound
description: By 9:30 A.M. in Atlanta, there were no more Tickle Me Elmo dolls at an F.A.O. Schwarz. At midmorning in Houston, a Target store was nearly toaster-less. And in New York City, J. Crew filled with shoppers by 11:30, while the rest of SoHo was still rubbing sleep from its eyes.

title: Experienced Hand to Fill In For Giants' Injured Center
description: A day after turkey and stuffing, the Giants went back to work today and received bad news: they will most likely be without center Brian Williams, who is suffering back problems, when they play the Eagles in Philadelphia on Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a Federal investigation into whether the Stroh Brewery Company is running television commercials aimed at underage viewers referred incorrectly to two beer brands among those the company spent $4.7 million to advertise last year. Colt 45 and Lone Star were not advertised by Stroh, which acquired both this year.

title: How to Avert a New Oil Crisis
description: The United Nations is allowing Iraq to sell oil for food and medicine, and OPEC agreed this week to keep oil production at current levels for at least six months. But the real global oil issues these days are the rising price of oil, the deteriorating economic and political situation in the Persian Gulf and the costly consequences of shortsighted United States policy in the region.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: P.S.A.L.

title: Bridge
description: Two pairs from the New York metropolitan area battled in a desperately close finish in the Blue Ribbon Pairs at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in San Francisco Thursday night. The winners, by a margin of three match points, were Bob Blanchard and Jim Krekorian, both of Manhattan.

title: New Boat for an Old Trip
description: When George Washington crosses the Delaware this Christmas, he will do it in a brand new boat. After 43 years of re-enactments of the famous crossing that led up to the Battle of Trenton, officials at Washington Crossing Historical Park have replaced four storm-battered replicas of Washington's troop boats with one new (but historically accurate) 60-foot, $50,000 cedar model made in Maine.

title: 150 Flee Smoky Fire On Upper West Side
description: About 150 people, many elderly and disabled, were evacuated from a 27-story apartment building on the Upper West Side last night after a smoky fire broke out in the basement.

title: Bridgeport Dog Track Will Suspend Racing
description: Just a year after a former jai alai fronton in Bridgeport, Conn., was transformed into the $30 million Shoreline Star greyhound race track, the dogs will line up tomorrow for what many believe will be the track's final day of live racing.

title: Raptors Sign 40-Year-Old Free Agent
description: JOHN LONG, who has spent four years playing exhibition basketball games with MAGIC JOHNSON's all-star team, has joined the Toronto Raptors. The 40-year-old Long, who spent 13 seasons in the National Basketball Association, signed a free-agent contract yesterday. Terms were not disclosed. (AP)

title: QUAKER STOCK UP ON REPORT OF TALKS ABOUT UNITS' SALE
description: The stock of the Quaker Oats Company rose yesterday after a trade publication reported the company is in ''substantive talks'' with Pepsico Inc. about the sale of its Gatorade and Snapple beverage divisions. Brandweek, a weekly marketing magazine, said the Coca-Cola Company ''and at least one other group of investors'' were also interested in the businesses. The magazine said Pepsico executives were pursuing talks after balking earlier this month when Quaker Oats asked for $3 billion. The article did not indicate whether that price was for both drink businesses or just for Snapple. On the New York Stock Exchange, Quaker Oats closed at $39.375, up $2.125 a share.

title: After Troubled First Year, Track Suspends Dog Racing
description: Just a year after a former jai alai fronton here was transformed into the $30 million Shoreline Star greyhound race track, the dogs will line up Sunday in what many believe will be the track's final day of live racing.

title: BARNICKEL EXPLORES SALE OF PETROLITE
description: The Petrolite Corporation, a chemical maker, said yesterday that it would work with its biggest shareholder to explore a possible sale of the company. Wm. S. Barnickel & Company, a closely held holding company, owns 47 percent of Petrolite. The two companies also agreed to dismiss pending litigation. Earlier this month, a special committee of Petrolite directors rejected two offers brought to it by Barnickel and advised Petrolite to explore other combinations. In September, Petrolite proposed to buy as much as 55 percent of Barnickel's outstanding Petrolite stock for $38.50 a share. In Nasdaq trading, Petrolite's shares were unchanged yesterday at $44.

title: Don't Bash Beavers
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs
description: Next Thursday, only a few hours before the beginning of Hanukkah, a holiday centered on the struggle to preserve Jewish identity, Jewish leaders will again find themselves grappling with that topic.

title: Planning to Close Its Landfill, New York Will Export Trash
description: Hoping to close its Fresh Kills landfill by 2001, New York City plans to begin sending other cities and states nearly 15 percent of its daily flow of residential garbage next year, officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A small picture on Thursday with an article about Carnegie libraries in New York City, showing some children's chairs stacked on a table in the foreground, carried an incorrect caption. The scene was at the Spuyten Duyvil Infantry and Preschool, formerly the Kingsbridge branch library, in the Bronx; it was not the Schomburg branch in Harlem.

title: No Surcharge on Insurance
description: A Federal agency that had threatened to begin levying a $50 surcharge on property owners' flood insurance premiums tomorrow has relented, citing good faith efforts by Sea Isle City officials, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Shoddy building code enforcement and oversight of flood management regulations by the city prompted the threat by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which considers the entire island a flood hazard area.

title: Water and Air First
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Send Two to Minors
description: The Rangers sent two rugged rookies, Eric Cairns and Sylvain Blouin, to their minor league farm team in Binghamton, N.Y., yesterday. Cairns is a defenseman and Blouin is a forward.

title: It Was a Month to Make the Bulls Wish for More Elections
description: While the Dow Jones industrial average did not hit another record close yesterday, it did manage to finish November with the best monthly rise since December 1991 and the best election-year November since 1928.

title: Companies Face Deadline On New Health-Care Funds
description: Companies and insurers that provide health coverage for employee groups face a deadline of midnight Monday to inform the state whether they will contribute to state funds to subsidize health care for the poor and for physician training.

title: President Out As VW Seeks G.M. Truce
description: Thomas Andersson had already been unnerved once by his two roommates, when he walked in to find they had moved in paper-shredders and were busily destroying documents in the house they shared in Wiesbaden, about 20 miles from here.

title: Shrinking Safety Net Cradles Hearts and Hopes of Children
description: Nothing conspicuous in Christopher and Jennifer Cundiff's appearance says they are poor: not the neat navy blue soccer shirt and blue jeans Christopher wears, or Jennifer's white Mary Janes with a white rose button on each strap. Nor do they act deprived. Blond Jennifer, 6, bounds out of the schoolhouse door, while Christopher, 9, runs to his mother yelling, ''I got me an orange juice today!''

title: Refugees Tell of Youths Killed on March Back to Rwanda
description: Jean Badeke wore the look of a worried man as he waited for a truck to take him the last 15 miles to Rwanda. Five days ago, he said, rebel soldiers had led his 18-year-old brother away from a column of refugees walking back to Rwanda.

title: My Hospital, Dying a Slow Death
description: Every evening as I take the freeway home after a day of seeing patients and teaching medical students at El Paso's sole county hospital, I whiz by ''Pill Hill,'' the area around Sierra Medical Center, where my colleagues in private practice work.

title: QUINTILES COMPLETES PURCHASE OF INNOVEX
description: The Quintiles Transnational Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its purchase of the closely held Innovex Ltd. for stock and debt worth about 23 percent less than when the sale was disclosed. The purchase makes Quintiles the leader in independent research for drug makers, leapfrogging past Corning Inc. The combined company has about 7,000 workers in 20 countries. Quintiles said it exchanged about 10 million shares for Innovex and agreed to pay off about $60 million in Innovex debt. Shares of Quintiles rose 75 cents yesterday to close at $60.50, valuing the stock at $605 million. On Oct. 7, when the sale was disclosed, the Quintiles stock closed at $78.781. Since then, it has declined about 23 percent, reducing the purchase price by about $182.8 million.

title: Plans for a Waterfront Hotel
description: While Jersey City's resurgent waterfront has attracted the development of millions of square feet of office space and thousands of new workers to fill it, the area still lacks a hotel. So city officials welcomed a plan announced Wednesday by a group including Hartz Mountain Industries and former Representative Frank Guarini to build a 200-room hotel and conference center a block from the Hudson River.

title: Nets Hope To Avoid An 0 for 4 Out West
description: Everyone was milling about, gathering brushes and shaving kits, and yet Kerry Kittles sat with a towel pressed against his eyes for the longest time in the locker room. It was not tears he was trying to absorb, but disbelief.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Are Higher in Quiet Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities gained in quiet trading yesterday as the market closed early.

title: Off-Duty Officer, Out Shopping, Foils Bronx Payroll Robbery
description: An off-duty New York City police officer thwarted a payroll robbery while shopping with his 7-year-old son in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: It Is Prime Drive Time for Skins Game
description: The novelty had worn off, the interest had waned and the ratings were headed somewhere south of Baja. The Skins Game, that paradigm for golf Trashsport, that made-for-TV exercise in bogus bonhomie, seemingly had run its course after last year's event garnered yawns punctuated by occasional shrugs.

title: W. Donald McNeill, 78, a U.S. Tennis Champion
description: W. Donald McNeill, who won the 1940 United States tennis championship in a stirring upset of Bobby Riggs, died on Thursday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 78.

title: Arch Patton, 88; Devised First Survey of Top Executives' Pay
description: Arch Patton, one of the best-known management consultants of the post-World War II era, died on Nov. 23 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 88 and lived in Bronxville.

title: Nigerian Star Recovering From Surgery
description: NWANKWO KANU of Italy's FC Internazionale soccer team was doing well yesterday, four days after heart surgery. Kanu, who led Nigeria to the Olympic gold medal last summer in Atlanta, could be released from the hospital in a few days, a doctor said.

title: Germany Acquits East-West Go-Between of Extortion Charges
description: One of the most enigmatic figures of the cold war was acquitted on extortion charges by a Berlin court today, in the latest chapter in a long-running legal battle over his shadowy role as a go-between for the former East and West Germany.

title: Company Briefs
description: BEHRMAN CAPITAL, which manages a private equity fund specializing in management buyouts of growth companies, said it had become a majority shareholder of Condor Systems Inc., a military electronics contractor in San Jose, Calif.

title: A Rock of the Modern Age, Arthur Miller Is Everywhere
description: When Arthur Miller was in Alaska to receive an award this year, he and a local environmental official went fishing for salmon in Prince William Sound. As they passed an iceberg, Mr. Miller's companion leaned over the side of the boat, chopped off pieces of blue glacial ice and threw them into the bucket with the fish. ''That ice is probably millennia old,'' the playwright said in a recent interview. ''Eight-million-year-old ice! It doesn't melt.''

title: Unclog the Plumbing System
description: New York City is a chronic victim of what might be called the ''too many rules, too little enforcement'' syndrome. The plumbing trade is a staggering example. According to a study by the city's Public Advocate, barriers to getting a plumber's license are so high that the city has only one-fifth the number of master plumbers per capita as Philadelphia or Cleveland. Meanwhile, New York does not crack down on non-licensed plumbers, or adequately discipline the licensed ones who break the law. In the end, the city has the worst of both worlds -- high costs and little protection from bad workmanship.

title: The X-Mail Files
description: Mrs. Clark G., of Cactus Flat, Nev., is vexed by ''The X-Files,'' a TV show about two F.B.I. agents on the supernatural beat. Or the space-alien beat. Or -- thank Heaven for Bob Dole! -- whatever.

title: Robert J. McCloskey, State Dept. Spokesman, Dies at 74
description: Robert J. McCloskey, a career diplomat who served as the State Department's spokesman during the Vietnam War, rose to become an Assistant Secretary of State and later was appointed Ambassador to Cyprus, the Netherlands and Greece, died on Thursday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 74 years old.

title: End All Stereotyping
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Cowboys Try to Steady Their Ship
description: It has been such a strange season for the Cowboys that even some of the players are not really sure what is waiting just around the corner.

title: Robert Ossorio, 73, Arts Patron and Ballet Company Founder
description: Robert Ossorio, a patron of the arts and a founder of the Manhattan Festival Ballet, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after being hit by a bus. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Gay Camelot Goes Home to Find It's True
description: At the opera as in life, the story of the assassinated homosexual politician Harvey Milk is filled with bigotry and repression, violence and guilt.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about creating a home office misspelled the surname of the designer. He is David Mullman, not Mullmann.

title: Advances and Anxieties In Treatment of AIDS
description: When the AIDS crisis crept into public view back in the early 1980's, television's concern was largely limited to perfunctory news reports. It was 1985 before a television movie, ''An Early Frost,'' dared tackle the subject, however gingerly. Gay men and drug addicts were not perceived as desirable advertising targets.

title: Sales Boom on Black Friday
description: With crowds lining up at 5:30 A.M. to snap up the next generation of Nintendo games and Route 17 backed up for miles around the malls of Paramus, New Jersey merchants pronounced Black Friday a success, or at least a big improvement over last year's model. ''I spoke to five regional and national department and discount stores here, and they all said the sales figures for today were above the figures for last year,'' said Melanie Willoughby, president of the New Jersey Retail Merchants Association. At the Newport Centre Mall in Jersey City, the associate marketing director, Sarah Liddle, noted a sharp increase in bags. ''Last year there were a lot of people browsing in the mall, but they weren't buying,'' she said. ''This year there are bags everywhere.''

title: 'No Big Deal' Is Suddenly A Big Deal
description: THIS is a classic day in college football.

title: Rested Knicks Take On Kings
description: The Knicks will find out today whether a five-day layoff will help put an end to their poor play.

title: Aid for Refugees Approved; Airdrops Are Possible
description: Diplomats from 14 countries met in Ottawa today and gave formal approval for a relief mission that could airlift food to refugees in eastern Zaire if necessary. The mission is to be based in Entebbe, Uganda, and reconnaissance flights from there will search eastern Zaire for refugees.

title: Slovakia Joins in Medical Screenings of Gulf Veterans
description: The Government of Slovakia has announced that it will provide comprehensive medical examinations to Slovak soldiers who participated in chemical detection units in the Persian Gulf war of 1991, after reports that some of the veterans have fallen seriously ill.

title: Killer of Two Abortion Clinic Workers Is Found Dead of Asphyxiation in Prison Cell
description: John C. Salvi 3d, who shot two people to death and wounded five others at two area abortion clinics in 1994, ended his troubled life today in a maximum security prison outside Boston, the prison authorities said.

title: INSIDE
description: A Killer Kills Himself

title: Depressed, Bissell Fled Without Plan, Lawyer Says
description: An associate who spoke to Nicholas L. Bissell in the months before he became a fugitive presented a portrait of a man who went from being someone known for his street smarts and confidence to someone who became so depressed and confused that he fled New Jersey without any real escape plan.

title: French Trucker Strike Ends With Indirect Defeat for Government
description: After 12 days of gradually tightening their stranglehold on the economy of much of Western Europe, striking French truck drivers began lifting barricades blocking major highways today after union and employer negotiators signed an agreement resolving most of the issues in dispute.

title: Fashion Trends Encourage Fur Sellers
description: Whether on the runways of Paris, the covers of fashion magazines or the streets of Manhattan, fur is in vogue again.

title: Kabul's Museum: The Past Ruined by the Present
description: On a recent visit to the ruins of the National Museum of Afghanistan, where he served as curator, Najibullah Popal turned momentarily to pause beside a gaping hole in the masonry.

title: Patterson (Or Was It Jordan?) Sparkles
description: Andrae Patterson plays no favorites.

title: Seminole-Gator Game Is Perfect Matchup
description: The game, as it is played around here at the end of November, is nasty and personal under any circumstances. When Florida State meets Florida, a onetime college for women challenging the school that has traditionally dominated the state's landscape, the emotions cannot be overstated. ''It doesn't matter if we were ranked the last two teams in the country,'' said Thad Busby, the Florida State quarterback.
